  During this promotional period, appetizers were available at a reduced price, prompting us to order multiple dishes to share among ourselves. My sampling of sopecitos consisted of four substantial corn tortillas, each topped with a distinct protein - chicken, steak, carnitas, and chorizo, respectively. While the meat was passable, the tortillas lacked freshness and arrived at our table merely lukewarm. 
  My attempt at the empanadas yielded a mediocre experience, as the beef filling failed to impress. This dish was unremarkable and forgettable. A few other items we ordered were similarly unimpressive. However, the flautas proved to be the exception, as they were the only dishes that garnered universal acclaim from our group. If only we had opted for multiple orders of these delectable treats instead! 
  Our experience was further marred by subpar service. It took nearly an hour for our appetizers to arrive, and one dish was incorrectly prepared upon its eventual arrival. Following my request for a correction, the mistake was rectified, yet the faulty dish remained listed on my bill. After having it removed, the entire ordeal proved bothersome.

"My sentiments regarding my recent culinary excursion to this establishment can be encapsulated in a single phrase: 'underwhelming experience.' Neither appalling nor exceptional, my dining adventure fell somewhere in between, prompting an unenthusiastic response. Opting to sample their al pastor and lengua tacos, my expectations were unfortunately not met. Specifically, the former suffered from an absence of succulence and a conspicuous dearth of that saccharine quality so characteristic of well-executed al pastor. As for the latter, although tender, it lacked sufficient seasoning, resulting in an uninspired flavor profile that failed to leave a lasting impression. In conclusion, my visit did not justify a special trip, and I would not recommend going out of one's way to partake in the fare offered by this particular eatery."

"The staff member's comportment was adequate, with the exception of a singular individual. During the lunchtime hours, as we were preparing to assemble our meals, one of the establishment's employees vociferously exclaimed, 'You can't be back here!' The staff member's remark was uttered in a discourteous manner, and it pertained to the spatial area situated between the dual self-service vegetable and meat stations. Notwithstanding the fact that one of the bars was temporarily inaccessible, it was somewhat arduous to extend my reach to procure an item positioned at the rear of the counter. Consequently, I opted to traverse to the opposing side, thereby facilitating my accessibility to the desired item. However, the aforementioned staff member chose to vocally reprimand me from a distance, rather than approaching me and issuing a warning in a more civil manner. Such behavior was utterly disrespectful and unbecoming! It is pertinent to ponder the underlying purpose and aspirations of this particular eatery. Should they not strive for excellence and grandeur, rather than settling for mediocrity?"

Following my companion's effusive endorsement and ardent enthusiasm regarding this establishment, I was disillusioned to discover that it fails to cater adequately to the dietary restrictions of vegetarians and vegans. The culinary offering I selected, specifically the burger, lacked a palatable flavor profile, characterized by an unpleasant combination of acidity and an overpowering sweetness. My dissatisfaction with the dish was so profound that I abandoned consumption of it, an occurrence that rarely transpires.

The gastronomical experience afforded by the veggie omelette was utterly deficient in terms of culinary quality, as it exhibited an egregious excess of doneness, rendering it arid and unyielding to the palate, which was particularly disconcerting given the establishment's previous reputation for serving delectable fare; indeed, my dining companion's omelette suffered from a similar dearth of flavor and texture, thereby substantiating my recommendation that patrons exercise caution when perusing the menu, especially in light of the premium pricing associated with such an underwhelming gustatory encounter.

I am what you would consider a mexican food snob. Small, hole in the wall type places are what i live for. 

I had the mini chimis (5) with beans and rice... Cost me $10 which is a little steep for me especially given the quality of food. 

The chimis had cream cheese and beef in them. More cream cheese than beef. They were sweet. Almost tasted like they were made with a flaky pastry dough or something. The rice was nothing special but their refried beans were delicious. I wish i would have had the option to get chicken ones. 

Their salsa bar salsas were nothing special to me, flavorless.  Their avocado + salsa verde one was pretty unique and delicious though. 

The restraunt was super clean and a little over the top friendly. Im from the south and enjoy being greeted with a smile, but 4 different times while i am trying to eat? Overkill. 

They have a fried ice cream milkshake that i would love to try! I might go back to try that, but that's about it. This place definitely isn't Carolina's/los dos melinos status.

"Flying into this location is exceptional. It embodies the essence of Las Vegas. Upon arrival, one experiences an unparalleled sense of excitement, eager to indulge in frivolous pursuits...

However, one's financial resources are rapidly depleted due to excessive gambling, rendering it impossible to cover the cost of an evening meal, gain entry into exclusive nightclubs, and ultimately leading to feelings of disappointment and the desire to return home forthwith.

Upon arriving at the airport, one is met with an extensive queue, stretching back to the walls, which would typically remain unoccupied. Following a prolonged waiting period of approximately one to two hours, one finally clears security protocols, albeit with considerable relief...

Subsequently, one becomes cognizant of the necessity to proceed to the D gates. Unfortunately, the sole means of conveyance, the tram, is nonoperational. Thus, one must undertake a brisk, mile-long trek while burdened with cumbersome luggage exceeding the recommended weight limit for checked baggage (a consequence of excessive purchases during one's stay in Las Vegas). 

Upon reaching the designated gate, one discovers a two-hour delay, further exacerbating the already trying circumstances...

In summary, this airport experience has been particularly unsatisfactory, marred by an interminable security line, the malfunctioning of the tram, and a protracted delay prior to departure."
Enjoyed my veggie burger with fries. Service sucked the last 2 times. We had to flag down a waitress to get our refills. Next time we'll do take out to avoid tipping poor service

"A pleasant ambiance and hospitable personnel notwithstanding, my experience at this establishment fell short of my expectations, as the therapeutic session itself left much to be desired. Despite the therapist's cordial demeanor and willingness to address specific areas of discomfort, they inadvertently created an additional knot that has persisted since the massage, which I had not experienced prior to the treatment. While the facilities were clean and well-maintained, and the front desk staff exhibited a welcoming attitude, the cost of services rendered was somewhat prohibitive and may deter potential patrons seeking comparable quality massages at more reasonable prices elsewhere. Although I was referred to this spa by a satisfied acquaintance and harbored elevated expectations, my experience did not live up to my standards, leaving me uninspired and unlikely to return. In essence, nothing extraordinary or remarkable distinguished this spa from others in its class, which is precisely what I seek when investing such sums of money."

Okay, unfortately SW Airllines needs to train their employees better.\nSW Airlines can only issue to a passenger two (2) boarding passes in a travel day. Example: Travel day 12/1; traveing from PHX to GEG with connecting flight in OKL (changing airplanes), got two boarding passes; got to GEG did my business and got an boarding pass at GEG with stop in LAS (no change of planes). It's frustrating because GEG was a full (over booked) flight.

had a $20 slow cooked pork dish (cochinito pibil) that was described as a house speciality.  Nothing special.  Salty, a little dry...lots of spices. Obvious sauce drips on plate rim were partially wiped off...made the plate look unapetizingly dirty at first.  The $7 Modelo tasted great!

I must confess that my contributions to Yelp are minimal, however, my dissatisfaction with The Haymaker warrants an expression of discontent. Previously, I held this establishment in high regard, frequently indulging in their culinary offerings and introducing them to my acquaintances visiting from afar. Unfortunately, my recent experiences have been marred by a discernible decline in quality. It appears that my glass is no longer replenished with the same alacrity as in times past, and the once-present garnish of lettuce has metamorphosed into an unappealing shredded form. Moreover, the complimentary to-go iced coffee, formerly imbued with a rich, toasted almond flavor, has vanished from their repertoire. Furthermore, during a recent Saturday afternoon visit, I was dismayed to discover the absence of marinara sauce for the mozzarella sticks. In spite of these shortcomings, the Happy Hour special featuring $2 Bud Light drafts remains a notable highlight. However, my "medium" burger arrived with a solitary tomato slice, which, regrettably, was positioned at the terminal end of the patty. Additionally, my request for an onion slice was fulfilled with a singular, somewhat limp ring of onion. Until I am apprised of improvements, I fear that my patronage of The Haymaker shall remain suspended.

We actually dine at this establishment with reasonable frequency, and thus, it may come as a surprise that my rating is not higher, as I have come to expect more from this venue. Upon closer examination, I have come to realize that the primary draws for me are the complimentary chips and salsa, which are undoubtedly delectable. Additionally, their margaritas are typically quite impressive. Furthermore, I have developed a fondness for their newly introduced pretzel stick appetizer. Most importantly, the servers have consistently displayed exceptional friendliness and attentiveness. However, the culinary offerings remain the sole area of concern, as I have yet to experience a thoroughly satisfying meal. Despite attempting a wide variety of dishes, I have found that certain components of each dish are occasionally palatable, but a uniformly excellent meal has proven elusive. Specifically, the margarita chicken is passable, but the accompanying sides tend to be lackluster and appear somewhat stale. Similarly, the burger is adequate, but the fries are often subpar. The children's meals are regrettably inadequate, prompting me to seek alternative dining options for family gatherings. Typically, my visits to this establishment are limited to luncheons with my spouse, during which we opt for the unlimited chips and salsa with soup and salad. Unfortunately, even these aspects have become less impressive over time. In spite of these shortcomings, I will likely return to partake in the aforementioned attractions, though for a well-rounded dining experience, I would recommend exploring other options.

I have had the privilege of visiting this establishment on multiple occasions, and unfortunately, my experiences have been less than satisfactory. The stylists have been adequate, at best, and their prices, while reasonable, do not align with the quality of service provided. My primary grievance lies with the customer service, which has been subpar. On numerous occasions, I have attempted to contact them outside of operational hours, leaving messages that have gone unreturned. It appears that they are either too busy or uninterested in addressing customer concerns, as they have failed to reciprocate my attempts at communication. As a result, I will not be patronizing this business further and would advise others to exercise caution before doing so themselves.

"This establishment represents the quintessence of mediocrity, as it is the fourth Hawaiian barbecue restaurant I have had the displeasure of dining at, and it falls short in numerous aspects. Firstly, the absence of teriyaki and katsu sauces, which are fundamental components of any respectable Hawaiian barbecue, is a glaring omission. Furthermore, the substitute condiments provided, specifically soy sauce and an overly sweetened, processed, and glowing red sauce, fail to enhance the flavor profile of the dishes they accompany. The macaroni salad, a staple of Hawaiian cuisine, is unacceptably prepared with overcooked noodles, an unappetizing seasoning akin to pepper, and an insufficient amount of carrot shavings, resulting in a lackluster presentation. The barbecue chicken, purportedly marinated, exhibits a striking lack of moisture and flavor, rendering it unpalatable. The bed of vegetables, comprising tired, desiccated cabbage, resembles imitation grass often found in Easter baskets, further detracting from the overall quality of the meal. The menu's confusion between Hawaiian barbecue and what could be described as 'ghetto Chinese food' of South Phoenix only serves to exacerbate the disappointment. Although the elderly Asian couple who own and operate the establishment are quite cordial, the service, while prompt, does not compensate for the culinary shortcomings. Despite the eatery's cleanliness, surpassing its nearby competitors, its location amidst a plethora of fast-food options makes it readily forgettable. Regretfully, I cannot envision a scenario where I would return to this establishment, unless, perhaps, I find myself in the vicinity with a strong yearning for something Hawaiian."

Hallo, ich gehe ins Milano seid 1990, diese Bar WAR der absolute Kultleider ist dem nicht mehr so. Zu wenig Puplikum, oft launiges, wenig motiviertes Personal, oft zu laute Musik, so das man sich wirklich anstrengen mu\u00df beim unterhalten zu h\u00f6ren und geh\u00f6rt zu werden.Deshalb dann auch die Fenster geschlossen werden, damits von drau\u00dfen keine Beschwerden gibt, die alte kleine Klimaanlage \u00fcberfordert ist und dabei die T\u00fcr vom Raucherzimmer aber offen bleibt, damit das Personal zum bedienen schneller rein und raus kommt. Du stinkst nach verlassen der Bar genauso nach Rauch wie fr\u00fcher. Ein Plus - die Tische drau\u00dfen, das macht Spa\u00df.

"This eatery constitutes one of my habitual destinations for the first meal of the day. Customarily, it serves as an excellent venue for a satisfying breakfast experience. However, on this particular visit, the demeanor of the hostess was not as cordial as I had anticipated, and the culinary offerings were merely adequate. Given its prolonged tenure in the industry, this establishment has garnered a favorable reputation among patrons. Nonetheless, the kitchen staff would benefit from heightened diligence in their preparation of dishes, while the presence of a welcoming and jovial host/hostess would significantly enhance the overall ambiance. My next visit to this restaurant will likely be deferred for an extended period."

"The personnel within the establishment exhibit amicable demeanors, however, subsequent experiences deteriorate precipitously from such an auspicious beginning. Specifically, Room 1122 should be avoided at all costs if a restful slumber is desired, as the confluence of a nearby train, an ice machine, and an antiquated AC/heat wall unit renders sleep an unattainable luxury. Furthermore, the peeling wallpaper in shared spaces and outmoded decor detract from the overall ambiance. Additionally, the culinary offerings served during the midday repast were unacceptably chilly, and a dearth of accessible power outlets hinders the charging of electronic devices."

"As an ardent devotee of second-hand shopping, I must confess that this specific Goodwill establishment fails to impress, exuding an unpleasant odor reminiscent of a deceased feline relative upon entrance, which unfortunately permeates the ambiance. However, for those seeking vintage furniture to refurbish or repaint, the selection appears adequate. Nonetheless, I would recommend visiting the location on 20th Street and Indian School, boasting a newer construction and a more pleasant atmosphere, replete with an array of superior quality items."

We arrived at this eatery with the intention of partaking in a midday repast, and as such, I opted for the 'Sweet Deal' option, which offered three items for the sum of four dollars. My selections consisted of a standard cheeseburger, an order of onion rings, and a beverage. The culinary creations were delivered to our table in a prompt manner, almost to the point of haste, as the kitchen staff appeared to have been remiss in their preparation of my burger, resulting in an excessive amount of mustard and ketchup, which caused the contents to overflow from the bun, creating an unappealing spectacle. However, the onion rings proved to be somewhat satisfying.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition." 
  The ambiance of the establishment appeared pleasant, and favorable critiques alluded to delectable pizza; however, our order of a large, thin crust pizza, adorned with tomato, mushrooms, pepper, cheese, and pepperoni, fell short of expectations.  The crust, rather than being crisp and delicate, was somewhat doughy and lacking in the characteristic crunch of a traditional Palermo-style pizza crust, which was a notable disappointment, given our familiarity with the authentic variety from having lived in Italy for four years.  Moreover, the mushrooms possessed a distinctly canned flavor, detracting from the overall quality of the dish.  Our encounter with the youthful server was marked by his stoic demeanor and an absence of even a cursory greeting, casting a further pall over the already unimpressive culinary experience.  In contrast, our brief interaction with an affable gentleman, presumably the proprietor, upon exiting the premises, was characterized by his congenial demeanor and warmth, offering a faint glimmer of hope that future visits might yield more satisfactory results.

I heard many good things about this place and so was excited to try it out.

My friends and I ordered the Thai Beef Salad, Asian Chicken Salad, Monsters Meatball and Spaghetti, and Grilled Salmon. We were extremely disappointed. I don't even know what the meatballs tasted like. The spaghetti and salad dressings were BAD. The rice was hard. The salmon was a-ok, but the portion was small compared to other dishes.

On the bright side, I tried their famous frozen hot chocolate, and I loved it! We all loved it! Totally made my experience better. 

I don't know if we didn't order the right food, but I'm definitely not coming back here for their food, ONLY FOR DESSERT!

"We waited for an interval of ten minutes for the presentation of both the menu and water, and it must be noted that the ambient temperature at the time was approximately one hundred degrees Fahrenheit. Our server's demeanor was perfunctory, as he persistently avoided eye contact during his visits to our table, opting instead to survey the surrounding area with an air of distraction. The wine list was summarily removed from our possession prior to our having the opportunity to peruse it, and when queried about beverages, our response was met with an abruptness that bordered on incivility. It was patently evident that any minor infraction or misunderstanding would have been sufficient to trigger a defensive and unprofessional reaction from our server. Moreover, the culinary offerings were unimpressive, with the Caprese salad being merely adequate and the calamari manifesting a remarkable lack of flavor and an unpleasant texture that could be described as rubbery. Furthermore, no expression of gratitude or well wishes was extended to us upon our departure, which contributed to an overall atmosphere that can only be characterized as decidedly inhospitable. Needless to say, we shall not be inclined to revisit this establishment in the future, and it might be suggested that a modification of their moniker to Luna Grossa would be more apropos."
I expected so much more. The food here was eatable, there wasn't much variety. The \"sushi\" was rice and veggie rolls. I'm not coming back.

"Two stars, owing to an appreciable level of service quality, yet, alas, the sushi rice persistently manifests a deplorable tendency towards excessive moisture and disintegration, much to my dismay and disappointment, especially when compared to the superior offerings of Kabuki in California, which, I must say, never fails to impress in terms of sushi quality. Indeed, I have endeavored to provide this establishment with multiple opportunities to rectify this unfortunate shortcoming, only to be met with consistent disappointment. Therefore, I implore the sushi chefs here to take a cue from their West Coast counterparts and elevate the quality of their Alaskan rolls. Furthermore, the ambiance leaves much to be desired, with grimy table booths, unsightly walls, and an overall lack of cleanliness that extends even to the sunshades and table lights. One cannot help but wonder what factors contribute to such a state of affairs at this particular Kabuki location in Las Vegas."

"Expressing my utter discontent with my recent dining experience at Bravo, I must say that this establishment has failed to meet my expectations on two separate occasions. During my initial visit, I opted for a grilled chicken salad, only to discover upon its arrival that the poultry was undercooked and sported an unappetizing pink hue. Compelled to return the dish, I was left feeling frustrated and disillusioned. Upon my second visit, I decided to sample their sangria rosa, which unfortunately proved to be excessively saccharine and bore a striking resemblance to a daiquiri. Furthermore, the chicken caprese I ordered was problematic, as the fowl was unacceptably lean and possessed a rubbery texture that made it nearly impossible to cut. Coupled with the lack of seasoning in the orzo, my meal was a culinary catastrophe. It is with great regret that I must express my profound dissatisfaction with Bravo, and I fear that future visits may not be forthcoming."

This location formerly served as my preferred venue for acquiring items at a discounted rate; however, circumstances have undergone a transformation. It appears that word has spread about the store's reputation, resulting in an influx of eBay vendors who have assumed control of the premises. These individuals display erratic behavior, engaging in unethical practices to gain an advantage over their competitors. Attempting to compete with them proves futile, as they seem to enjoy a preferential relationship with store employees, thereby securing early access to merchandise. During my most recent visit, I witnessed one of these eBay sellers providing food for the staff, which raises questions regarding their moral principles. In light of such occurrences, I now prefer to purchase items at full price from establishments like Nordstrom.

\"Tourist trap\" pretty much sums up this restaurant with mediocre food, service and atmosphere. I don't mind paying more money for quality, but things were far from exceptional. A 12oz beer was $10, and steak and fries was $30. The girls were nice to look at, but nothing more.

Recently visited this establishment and was somewhat dismayed by the perceived diminution in the quality of the sushi offered, specifically in terms of its freshness; thus, I am rather ambivalent about the prospect of returning.

Do NOT order the wings. For $14 you get scrap parts of the wings, which they call \"lollipops\" and their way of trying to convince you that they make it easy for you to eat...YA, because there is no more meat for you to eat to even get messy. They basically strip off all the meat and leave you with the bone and the driest parts. There are no drums(middle pieces). Literally there is no meat. I had ordered the General So wings. Anyways I would assume the flavor will be amazing but it was terrible. It was too salty and tasted like sweet and sour sauce out of a packet from Panda Express. What does it take to be a good chef? Just making the food look pretty rather than taste good or even filling? I was basically served chicken bones cleaned up and presented to me on a plate with some sauce on the side. I am so offended that they could get away with serving this garbage and charging for it. What do they do with the actual meat? I don't know if I would be more upset if they threw it away or used it on another dish, which means they get paid twice for it.

"Although it possesses some appeal, I surmise that this establishment has plateaued in quality, as my experiences over the past several years have indicated a gradual decline in the culinary excellence of its offerings, despite the continued proficiency of its staff. Furthermore, I have noticed that the facilities are not consistently maintained, particularly during early morning hours. Notwithstanding, I have contributed substantially to this business and anticipated enhancements, but unfortunately, they have not materialized. My apologies to the proprietors."

This is a painful review as I really used to like this place.  Echoing most of the other reviews as well as mine, the service here is still horrible.  The portions  have gotten smaller and the prices higher.  The quality of the food, DOWNHILLL..

The Wor Wonton Soup, compared to what you get in ANY other place, it was the smallest pot I have ever seen not to mention they use imitation crab meat.

This is the second time in a row I have ordered the Spring Rolls and they are cooked on the outside but still cold/frozen on the inside.

Like I said I used to really like this place but after this visit with continued CRAPPY POOR service, NO communication between the staff and overall they just don't seem to really care about customer service or quality of the food any more.  The portions have gotten smaller and the value for the price along with the service, this place is NO LONGER a place I can recommend.

"My recent pedicure experience was utterly dismal, bordering on traumatic. Following a comprehensive full set application and a pedicure, I was anticipating a relaxing and rejuvenating session. Unfortunately, the individual responsible for my full set demonstrated a lack of finesse when utilizing the drill, resulting in minor lacerations and considerable discomfort that will undoubtedly intensify in the forthcoming days. Although my nails appear well-manicured and aesthetically pleasing, the pedi portion of the service was subpar. The lady tasked with providing the massage exhibited a remarkable dearth of competence, merely grazing my feet with a perfunctory touch and neglecting to provide any meaningful pressure or manipulation. Instead, she resorted to unorthodox methods such as squeezing and pinching my toes, as well as slapping the soles of my feet. This bizarre encounter culminated in an unpolished and haphazard polish application, featuring an abundance of excess polish on my cuticles that remained uncleansed. Suffice it to say, I shall not be revisiting this establishment."

Ended up here since Mill was slammed for the ASU game..ordered the souvlaki, one beef and the other lamb.  The lamb was pretty under seasoned, the beef had a better taste except it was chewy and hard to swallow.  Had to spit out a piece in the napkin so someone got a surprise unfortunately.  Didn't think I got enough for what I paid for either.  The veg was also under seasoned, just bland tasting food.  I looked around and most people were ordering Apps like the hummus, so I may have missed something.  The waitress was very good and friendly, the extra star is for her.  Not sure I can go back with all the choices around there.

Bouchon, an eatery which has secured a prominent position amongst my preferred dining establishments in Las Vegas, served as the setting for a regrettable incident during my most recent visit in March, an occurrence which left an indelible mark on my culinary experience; following my submission of a comment via their website, which, much to my dismay, remained unacknowledged, I have opted to voice my grievances on this platform as well. It is worth mentioning that Bouchon boasts a menu featuring delectable fare, albeit at a cost which may be considered somewhat elevated; however, the true source of my consternation stemmed from the exorbitant fee associated with their house water, specifically $7 per carafe, amounting to a staggering $21 for a mere three glasses. My incredulity at such an egregious attempt to exploit their clientele knows no bounds; needless to say, I did not request any extraordinary variety of water, merely articulating my desire for tap water when queried about my beverage preference. A modicum of solace was derived from the fact that the management elected to reconsider the cost, yet the entire episode proved nothing short of mortifying in the presence of my esteemed business associates.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."

"Subpar service characterized by an excessive waiting period of over two hours for a routine oil change, during which time other patrons entered and departed the establishment, while maintaining a clean and welcoming ambiance, albeit hampered by inefficient management, prompts me to seek alternative options for my automotive needs."

"It is worth recalling the instance when Pomo previously occupied a particular tourist-frequented, faux-Mediterranean space in the most affluent area of Scottsdale, where they offered an exceptional Napoletana pizza within an atmosphere characterized by pretentiousness and snobbishness.  I am delighted to convey that my experience at the downtown Pomo was vastly dissimilar.  

Following a brief walk from Cibo, where we enjoyed a passable pie (although, I remain unconvinced that Cibo lives up to its extensive acclaim), we entered Pomo, anticipating an ambiance permeated by stucco, affected accents, and photographs of Florence.  To our astonishment, the establishment manifested a contemporary aesthetic, complete with hipster-esque waitstaff.  A remarkable transformation had transpired!  

The primary issue I had with the original store had been effectively addressed.  This dining experience was shaping up to be quite satisfactory.  We subsequently placed our order for a pie, expecting the identical quality we had relished from the original Scottsdale oven.  

Alas, our expectations were not met.  The pizza lacked the appropriate level of soupiness.  Moreover, it failed to showcase the extraordinary flavor and meticulous attention to detail that rendered it marginally tolerable to endure Scottsdale's most self-absorbed clientele.  Regrettably, it was an underwhelming encounter.  

Subsequent to departing from this location, we continued our stroll down the street to La Piazza Locale (which also boasts VPN certification), where we savored our third and most satisfying pie of the evening.  I strongly advise you to follow suit.  La Piazza Locale has adopted a modern vibe, which harmoniously coexists with a superior Napoletana pie."

This place was ok. I was with great friends on a birthday outing, so we could've been anywhere to have a fab time (and we did sample a few places that night). We had a good time by virtue of being the fun girlies we are, but I won't go out of my way to return to this particular bar.  I will, however, return to the Cosmo just for the secret pizza place...it's unmarked down a long dark hallway and has awesome pizza AND an old-timey arcade game and pinball machines. Sorry...did I digress? That's how interesting the Chandelier Bar was to me.\n\nIt's a multi-level bar with decent bartending (in fact, the barkeeps did present a touch of class to the place). The chandelier over the liquor bottles  was kinda pretty, but the plastic \"chandelier\" that draped from floor to ceiling...meh. Was pretty tacky looking, actually...reminded me of a giant version of the Mardi Gras beads you get for showing your boobies. Maybe they were going for Diva but got closer to Dive-y. I know it's Vegas, but there are plenty of less tacky places to hang. It felt very dated and old-fashioned. Dated can be good if there's at least a pinch of glam, but the obviously plastic almost-shimmer fell short of that pinch. Call me a snob, but it felt good to leave the verging-on-suffocatingly naff decor.

"MENU CHANGE: As an ardent devotee of the flatbread tapas during happy hour, I recently assembled a group of companions for a full-price dinner at this establishment, only to discover that the flatbread has been supplanted by what appears to be unaltered Matzoh Ball CRACKERS. Such a substitution would be readily apparent to any toddler familiar with the fundamental differences between crackers and bread. Furthermore, charging $10 for a few crackers accompanied by minuscule portions of hummus, bruschetta, and tapenade strikes me as rather exorbitant. However, upon observing my companion's struggle to consume the flatbread pizza due to the inability of CRACKERS to support the combined weight of pizza toppings and sauce, I realized the true extent of this transformation. A fellow patron politely inquired about the crackers, prompting the server to divulge that this alteration was, in fact, irreversible. In response, I have decided to permanently alter my dining habits by frequenting one of the numerous other exceptional gastro pubs in the area or simply crossing the street to savor the delectable cuisine at Firefly. Moreover, the freshly brewed beer available here fails to impress; many of the varieties possess a cloying, syrupy quality reminiscent of honey, which I find utterly unappealing."

1st time there, went to buy a toy helicopter for my child.  Didn't hold charge so we had to take it back for exchange and manager took care of us since I didn't save receipt.  While he was helping us he took on another task or decided to take a call rather then finishing our transaction.  The whole process took about 15 minutes since I had to wait for him to actually help but the actual exchange took 1 min.  He was still on the phone the entire time and customer service wasn't actually priority there.  Bad quality in toy helicopters and not very good customer service. Not a good 1st time experience.

UPDATE:

The owner is very personable.

The bid made to my insurance company was the highest of any bidder, I needed repairs, however, the bid submitted was for total replacement of all siding on my house.

The company did not get my business because the insurance company would not fund total replacement of all the of home's siding.

Unless you procure a "Go Room", you are destined to encounter an unkempt, unhygienic environment. The establishment displays an utter lack of concern towards providing cleanliness and maintenance. We were compelled to relocate thrice due to the deplorable conditions. Upon voicing our grievances, another guest was allowed to check-in prior to our complete evacuation, sans any tangible resolution to our concerns.

The carpet was in a state of extreme soiling, exuding an unpleasant odor and exhibiting prominent stains and dirt throughout. The mere act of stepping into the bathtub after walking on the carpet resulted in visible black footprints. There exists no reasonable justification for such squalor, nor for disregarding it and introducing subsequent guests to these unsanitary environs.

The hotel boasts an aged ambiance, accompanied by an unmistakable musty scent. Efforts are underway to modernize and enhance the facilities; however, substantial progress remains to be made. In light of the abundance of appealing hotels in Las Vegas, it is perplexing why anyone would opt to patronize this particular establishment. This experience marked both my initial and final encounter with the Flamingo. The quality of service I received was appalling.

Notwithstanding, a solitary aspect of the Flamingo merits commendation. Junius Johnson, Jr., a dedicated server within the buffet, has devoted thirty years of service to the organization. His exceptional dedication to customer satisfaction warrants recognition. He exemplifies the epitome of excellent clientele service, and his expertise would greatly benefit the remainder of the staff. My sincere admiration is extended towards this individual.
5/29 - waaaaccckkk!!!! the only thing nice was the view! other than that, crowd was wack! there was no where to sit! small danceflr! thank goodness it was free! Rain is better than this spot.

" Allow me to preface my remarks by expressing my unwavering admiration for all things characterized by an abundance of cheesiness, as well as my increasing fascination with culinary establishments housed within mobile vehicles. Following several weeks of diligently monitoring Chedda's whereabouts via Instagram, I was ecstatic to finally have the opportunity to sample their offerings in person, particularly when they visited my local vicinity on record day. My expectations were elevated, to say the least. Unfortunately, the dining experience failed to meet my lofty standards, leaving me utterly disillusioned and questioning the wisdom of my decision to part with hard-earned currency to the tune of $19. The 'dirt bags' (a name which, in hindsight, proved to be a portent of the underwhelming nature of the meal) that my spouse and I independently ordered, were, to our chagrin, devoid of any discernible flavor profile and woefully lacking in the cheesy essence that I had eagerly anticipated. Akin to a culinary travesty, the burgers were of generous proportions, yet the buns were unpalatably dense and exhibited telltale signs of excessive browning, while the accompanying 'tots' (a designation that presumably alludes to their diminutive size) were unremarkable in taste and texture, and the sauce served alongside them was decidedly peculiar. In light of these shortcomings, I would be remiss in recommending this establishment to others."

"Upon my return to this establishment subsequent to my previous assessment, I opted to procure fuel for our leased vehicle, thus prompting me to pull up to a designated dispenser and alight from the automobile. Subsequently, I entered the building and approached the attendant, requesting $120 worth of regular gasoline on pump number two. The attendant confirmed the availability of the requested amount and further informed me that, in the event that I required either change or a receipt, I should return indoors. Following her instructions, I proceeded to insert the nozzle into the tank and elevate the nozzle holder on the pump. During the process of refueling, I engaged in conversation with my fellow travelers within the vehicle. Upon the cessation of the pump's operation at the $100.10 mark, I elected to return inside the building to obtain the remaining balance of my change. The attendant, upon presenting my change and receipt, informed me that the car wash located on the premises would be undergoing renovations and reopening in approximately one month's time, during which period they would also be installing updated gas pumps and an additional gas island. Expressing gratitude for her assistance, I conveyed my approval of the forthcoming improvements and indicated my intentions to visit the establishment on two more occasions."

I suppose when it's Gordon Ramsay's restaurant you expect more or better than average.
Like everyone else I have watched his shows and he seems to be a passionate chef.
There was a 45 minute wait to get a table- that's fair it was a Friday night so we went and killed some time until our text message informed us the table was ready. The staff uniforms are RIDICULOUS, so blatantly inappropriate, ill fitting and unflattering. Please change them- what a joke they are. The umbrella girls at motorpsorts events are wearing more clothes than the poor girls working at BURGR.
The burgers took another 45 minutes to come out and they were okay but not great. My husband got the truffle fries with the truffle aioli, which frankly all just tasted like garlic and not much else. I cook for my family most nights so the burgers were not earth shatteringly good or something I couldn't whip up in 15 minutes. i just expected more.
Well I did get more when the bill came $150 for 2 adults and 2 kids for a burger meal. 
We won't go back to BURGR, but there certainly is a slew of Gordon Ramsay restaurants to choose from in Las Vegas. He seems to be a hard worker and he's making hay while the sun shines.

Tequila Bar, I came here after reading reviews on yelp. I was looking for a cheap bar with decent drinks. When I saw they had a 128oz Blue Fishbowl for $20 I YELPed! But was disappointed to hear they had no 
"fishbowls" and would service it in two large cups. The two cups turned out to be 64oz Plastic pitchers, which was pretty fun. What wasn't fun was that 1. It has no "fishies" in it (like the picture) and 2. It was 90% Soda. Boo! But hey, for the novelty- the price wasn't bad!

The Nacho's at the next table did look pretty delectable, but I just came from a big dinner so I just ordered the "southwestern corn on the cob". I was curious. What made it southwestern? I should have known when I ordered it and the waiter said, corn- you want the corn? ok. And Corn is exactly what I got. Just boiled corn with a square of butter... for $3 - FAIL

Four stars for the two appetizers (calamari and spicy shrimp)' both were very enjoyable.  The salad was also very good.  
One star for the main entrees.  Both mine and the wife's were awful.  I had the tilapia with asparagus.  The asparagus was way over cooked the the fish was very dry.  Wife had a pasta dish and was very disappointed. The kids meals were okay.
Atmosphere wasn't very appealing since areas were dirty in the waiting area and the dining area near the fireplace.  Wait staff was very inconsistent, our waiter was very neglectful, while the waitress at the table next to us seemed very attentive to her tables and we had to ask her for refills on bread, salad and drinks while our waiter was MIA.
Bottom line, go somewhere else while in the Concord Mills area.

I have had the occasion to visit this dental facility on multiple occasions over the past year, and my experiences have been eerily reminiscent of those described by Joan C. in her scathing review. It appears that the hygienist has adopted an unscrupulous modus operandi, whereby they endeavour to coerce patients into acquiring supplementary dental services and routine cleanings, which are often superfluous and not necessarily conducive to their oral health. My personal experience with the deep-cleaning procedure, performed only two months prior, serves as a case in point; my gum health has ostensibly deteriorated since undergoing the treatment, leaving me feeling dubious about its efficacy. Furthermore, my sole encounter with the dentist was cursory, at best; she merely glanced at my X-rays, divulged the necessity of fillings, and displayed a marked lack of interest in engaging with me on a personal level. Her conduct was perfunctory, to say the least, and I have resolved to seek out a more personable and competent practitioner to address my future dental needs.

Dos Gringos is unquestionably reviving the trashy ambiance, and it appears that the entire trailer park concept has profoundly influenced them. Two notable examples can be used to illustrate this point. Firstly, the drinks provided by the establishment were conspicuously lacking in potency; despite the generous glassware, the alcohol pours were remarkably scanty. This prompted us to speculate that perhaps the vodka was the root cause of the issue, so we opted to switch to rum. However, it became apparent that the trailer park theme was merely an excuse for parsimony on the part of the establishment. Secondly, the pervasive stench of vomit emanating from the men's restroom exceeded the bounds of acceptability, taking the trailer park motif to an excessive extent. Following my notification to the staff regarding the presence of vomit on a men's urinal, it remained unattended for an hour, which was quite disconcerting. These factors evoke a sense of nostalgia for the carefree days of yore. Admittedly, the atmosphere was enlivened by the DJ and the crowd, rendering the venue an ideal spot for daytime revelry and canine companionship. However, the prevalence of regurgitated matter and mediocre beverages somewhat dampened the spirits. As an aside, I must confess that the combination of these factors rendered me less than eager to sample their acclaimed tacos.

"While our experience at this establishment was by no means extraordinary, we did encounter certain aspects that left much to be desired. Specifically, our server, though adequate in their duties, failed to exhibit the warmth and attention to detail that one might expect from a truly exceptional dining experience. It appeared that their primary focus was on catering to the male patrons who were engrossed in the sporting events being broadcast, which unfortunately resulted in a lack of consideration towards our table. Furthermore, the gratuities seemed to be allocated in a manner that was disproportionate to the level of service provided. As for the culinary offerings, we were underwhelmed by the quality of the crispy tacos, which were merely passable. In light of the numerous superior dining options available in the surrounding area, it is unlikely that we will return to this restaurant in the future."

One of the most unfortunate coffee establishments I have had the misfortune of visiting is this particular Crazy Mocha location. Convenience played a significant role in my decision to patronize this establishment, as it was situated in close proximity to the Cultural Trust, where I had a class. Unfortunately, my experiences at this coffee shop were marred by a series of unpleasant encounters. Firstly, the chai tea was excessively sweet and lacked the depth of flavor that one would expect from a well-crafted chai. It was almost as if they had merely added milk to black tea and neglected to incorporate any discernible spices. This was a profound disappointment, as I had been eagerly anticipating a flavorful and invigorating beverage. Furthermore, the coffee was consistently brewed to a weakness that bordered on insipidity. I suspect that the coffee had been left to sit for an extended period before I received it, as it lacked the rich, bold flavor that I have come to expect from a freshly brewed cup of coffee. In fact, the second time I ordered coffee from this establishment, it was so unpalatable that I was compelled to discard it after only a few sips. The service at this coffee shop was adequate, but it fell short of being exceptional. While the staff was not unfriendly, their pace was somewhat leisurely, and they failed to demonstrate the kind of attentive, personalized service that one might hope to encounter at a reputable coffee shop. However, I must admit that the Wi-Fi connection was quite reliable, which proved to be a welcome consolation in light of the subpar quality of the beverages.

Was a huge fan of subway but they got rid of my favorite sandwitch chicken pizziola. I was able to still get it but they said that they couldnt anymore. I had to find a new fav but would like it more if they would bring it back. Most the subways in las vegas favor their own people or if you speak the language. Other than that could be better.

I will eat here when a friend insists, but I think almost every time I've eaten here, I have gotten diarrhea.  And the food isn't worth the diarrhea.  Its kind of bland.  And its overpriced.  Just my opinion though.  I know lots of people are ga-ga over this place.

They must have erroneously placed the refrigerated poultry intended for the grilled chicken salad within my sandwich, while the fries were merely lukewarm, bordering on unpleasantly tepid, in one of the two meals; however, the service was amicable and I do appreciate the novel choices that align with the contemporary inclination towards gourmet fast food, such as brioche buns and pretzel buns, as well as the availability of a purported "fresh lemonade" and various salad options.

Had fried tofu, fried pork, peanut butter dumplings and eggplant. The fried foods were dry and tough. Pretty much every dish here can be found in a much better version elsewhere in Montreal. Only try this if you're desperate for Chinese. (The pickings are admittedly slim in this neighbourhood.)

"Underwhelming experience, to say the least, characterized the visit to this establishment, situated in Casa Grande, on a Thursday evening, when, allegedly, the premises were slated to remain operational until the witching hour of midnight. However, it appeared that the management had chosen to cease operations ahead of schedule, as the server informed us that it was 'last call' at approximately 9:30 PM, despite the fact that our party had only recently arrived and had every intention of lingering for an extended period of time. This turn of events was, to put it mildly, rather vexing. Furthermore, the selection of beers available left much to be desired, with only a scant few offerings managing to surpass the threshold of mediocrity, which, regrettably, catered to the unrefined tastes of the predominant patronage. As an individual whose predilections do not necessarily align with those of a hophead, I yearned for a more diverse array of options to slake my thirst."

MONTE CARLO, an awesome name brand.We asked for a non-smoking room and we were sent into a SMOKING ROOM.I noticed that the carpet floor near the window had a minor crack.The room was NOT clean.The hotel was not nice because it is old.I will never stay in this hotel again and this hotel made me wonder why MGM Mirage made horrible hotels and never keep the old ones clean for there customers.Also,MGM's customer service need improvements.Stay at the Monte Carlo if you want a bad stay and want a feel of BARFED OUT EUROPE.This hotel is Sub-standard and below average.


Monte Carlo,a great name,and a great disappointment.

This was the inaugural grooming establishment we endeavored to utilize within the Phoenix metropolitan area, having garnered favorable assessments on the popular review platform known as Yelp, in conjunction with reasonable tariffs. Thus, we opted to give them a trial run. Unfortunately, I was not particularly enthused about their services, leaving me wistful for our previous groomer residing in California. In addition, I had expressly requested that my canine companion's tail receive exceptional attention during the grooming process. However, upon retrieving my dog from their care, I noticed that her tail still contained tangible knots and her visage had not been adequately cleansed. Consequently, I harbor considerable discontentment with their offerings and do not intend to revisit their facility in the future.

I really hate cold buffet food. Nd today all items were cold. Maybe we arrived too soon after opening but we had to leave and I asked for a refund. I was given a gift card for a return visit which was nice.

The thermally-administered peanut butter and jelly cake, characterized by its conspicuously fluid peanut butter and arid, dense texture, was presented at an elevated temperature. Consequently, the inherent viscosity of the peanut butter rendered it somewhat challenging to consume, while the cake's desiccated nature made it rather difficult to chew. Furthermore, the flavor of the jelly, which was situated at the core of the culinary creation, was only accessible upon penetrating the center of the cake. It is worth mentioning that the warm grape jelly, owing to its unremarkable taste, did not contribute significantly to the overall gastronomical experience. Lastly, the latte, with its unexceptional flavor profile, proved to be unremarkable in the grand scheme of things.

I have a propensity to enjoy this establishment, however, my most recent visit proved to be somewhat disillusioning. I sampled their eggs Benedict, but unfortunately, the Hollandaise sauce they had concocted did not meet my expectations. In hindsight, I would have been better off adhering to my customary blueberry pancakes. My companion, on the other hand, seemed to enjoy his meal, specifically the wolf pack he had ordered. The quality of service was satisfactory, as we were seated promptly on that busy Memorial Day Monday morning. Regrettably, both my companion and I experienced unpleasant stomach upsets later in the day, which served as a deterrent to my future patronage, considering the sole meal we had consumed was from this venue.

The novel proprietors are precipitating the degradation of this establishment, and upon my recent return to Montreal for a brief respite, I have observed that the personnel are excessively burdened with workload, thus impeding their ability to provide adequate service; consequently, I have decided not to revisit this venue, as it is preferable to preserve its former glory within my recollections, rather than exposing myself to the diminished quality of the culinary offerings.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."
 That's how I would summarize my visit to Portillo's. Despite the high expectations built up by the extensive promotion, the actuality fell short in multiple aspects. Firstly, the robust exterior of the hot dogs did not align with my personal preference, and the flavors failed to impress me as well. It is my conviction that Portillo's reputation plays a more significant role in its popularity than the culinary quality itself.

"I have had the privilege of partaking in the culinary offerings of this esteemed establishment on two separate occasions, with the initial visit being particularly enjoyable due to the exceptional quality of the service and the delectable Macaroni and Cheese dish. Unfortunately, my second experience was marred by a series of unfortunate events, beginning with a telephone conversation at 5:54 PM, during which I inquired about the availability of happy hour specials and was misinformed by an employee that they were indeed available until 7:00 PM. Upon arriving at the establishment merely ten minutes later, I was dismayed to discover that this information was incorrect, and that happy hour had already concluded. This sequence of events has led me to deduce that the quality of service and communication within this establishment is inconsistent, thus warranting a rating of two stars."

"It is patently evident that this establishment does not serve the optimal brunch experience in Charlotte, owing to its diminutive size and location within a commercial complex teeming with families accompanied by their dual-stroller conveyances and vociferous progeny. Despite the culinary offerings being passable, my sentiments align with disappointment and regret regarding the considerable distance traversed specifically for this meal."

I was definitely not impressed with this restaurant. There wasn't enough variety and my street noodle dish was subpar at best. It lacked any wow factor. The only dish I would recommend is the steamed pork bun. Literally the only thing I will go in there for. Otherwise, I would not suggest going here. It is overhyped.

I went to Caramel because I heard that it was great. It was a nice, simple, very small lounge. I was surprised at how small it was. I had the Oreo martini, which cost $20. I could care less about drink prices, and don't mind paying a lot for drinks in Vegas, but $20 was a bit much for a so-so martini with Oreo crumbs at the bottom. Or possibly Hydrox - who knows?\n\nLove the Bellagio, not wild about Caramel. Take the ten steps to the Sports Bar, put $20 in the video poker machine and get a free martini instead. The bartenders were much friendlier at the sports bar, too.

"I visited this establishment on a Saturday evening, anticipating an enjoyable experience, particularly since Kaskade was slated to perform. However, upon arriving, I encountered an extensive queue for those who possessed tickets, which proved to be quite frustrating. After waiting for approximately an hour and thirty minutes, I finally reached the entrance, only to discover that the club had already reached its maximum capacity. Consequently, the dance floor was closed, and there were no available tables. This led me to ponder the reasoning behind allowing additional patrons to enter when there was no sufficient space or accommodations for them. Security personnel continued to urge individuals to proceed forward, yet there was no obvious destination. The club's diminutive size was another contributing factor to the overcrowding issue. Moreover, the entryway was situated beneath a narrow staircase, which added to the overall unpleasantness of the experience. Despite these drawbacks, Kaskade's performance was impressive, albeit brief."

"The culinary offerings at this establishment are of satisfactory quality, however, my overall assessment of this restaurant would be significantly higher if it were not for the consistent negative interactions I have had with the staff during my two visits. Specifically, the service has been subpar, with prolonged waiting periods for food delivery and an absence of attention to detail in terms of ensuring a satisfying dining experience. Furthermore, despite expressing my concerns to the manager and receiving assurances of a complimentary gift card for a future visit, such a gesture never materialized. Therefore, while the food may be adequate, the poor service and lack of follow-through on commitments made by the staff preclude me from patronizing this restaurant again."

So I've been to this location and the one in Phoenix off ray and the 10. My friend has a membership here. So we've been gym buddies and trying to encourage each other to go more often. Sometimes u need that extra push to get you there! 

If you want something super basic, nothing flashy or fancy then this is the gym for you. It's about $10 a month, or you can do $20 a month for all locations and bring unlimited number of guests. 

Now I'm torn between a 2 star and 3 star rating for this place. First, I've been a member with 24 hour for years. Not switching, they're pretty basic as well, nothing fancy, has everything I need for a very reasonably priced. However, my gym has a sauna, basketball court, classes, pool, etc. which Planet does not. The big thing for me was no sauna! what!? AND what is up with that lunk alarm thing? They're supposed to be a judgment free gym supposedly, but then they have this alarm which screams and flashes when someone drops a heavy weight, grunts, or actually exerts effort.  what the!!?? Doesn't really make sense to me. & is that really necessary?

"It was patently apparent that the management at this establishment was utterly inept, as we were compelled to wait for an exorbitant amount of time to retrieve our vehicle from the valet service, while observing other patrons departing unimpeded. Despite bringing this issue to the attention of multiple staff members, we were ultimately informed that our automobile had been misplaced, which was particularly galling given the considerable sum we had expended on our repast. It is worth noting that a simple apology or complimentary beverage would have sufficed to assuage our dissatisfaction, yet we received neither. Following this debacle, I felt compelled to compose a missive expressing my indignation. While the waiting staff exhibited a certain level of cordiality, the cuisine was unremarkable and hardly worthy of the abundance of superior dining options available in Charlotte. In light of this experience, it is unlikely that we will return to this restaurant, as the quality of the fare did not justify the egregious lack of competence displayed by the management."

"I hereby retract my previous statement regarding II Vinao's alleged mismanagement, as it appears that the establishment was merely experiencing an isolated incident of subpar service; the proprietor has since reached out to me in quest of specifics to facilitate the rectification of any issues, demonstrating their commitment to providing exceptional patron experiences. Consequently, we intend to revisit the restaurant in the near future and bestow upon it a well-deserved five-star evaluation. Rest assured, I shall keep all interested parties apprised of any developments."

Should change the name to Lobster Mehhh. I felt like I was at the food court in the mall when i saw how this place was set up. It would have been better if it were since the mall has more seating.\nHad the lobster roll combo that came with fries and a drink. The Lobster roll was not a traditional one in my eyes. It was filled with plenty of lobster but was not tossed in the mayo/scallion mix a Maine lobster roll would have. It seemed to have a vinegar based medley that overwhelmed any on the natural flavors. The item that was the best was the fries, theses were actually very tasty. The lobster mac and cheese was so-so. A few lobster chunks on top but none throughout, not worth the $9.95. Definitely not returning!!

"Culinary offerings at this establishment are satisfactory, albeit with some caveats. Specifically, hot dishes tend to arrive at one's table at a temperature that is less than optimal, which can be somewhat disappointing. Furthermore, management has seen fit to remove certain items from the menu, a decision that is lamentable as said items were of superior quality. Additionally, the ambiance is not conducive to a tranquil dining experience due to an excessive level of noise pollution, both from the televisions and patrons gathered at the bar area, who often engage in boisterous conversations. Moreover, there appears to be a lack of seating arrangements designated for those seeking a more serene repast. According to our server, this state of affairs is a common occurrence, which unfortunately precludes us from frequenting the premises."

I guess I just don't get it.

It's advertised as a Madison favorite.  I hear people talking about going there all the time.  But the food just didn't leave me with a great impression.

The chips and salsa are great.  I suppose that's one thing that's pretty tough to get wrong.  But my burrito came out rather bland, as did my daughter's quesadilla.  Unless there was a kitchen mixup, my "hot" salsa sure did taste like mild.  

The service was good, the bar selection is solid, and the atmosphere is a neat one.  The food, however, just doesn't do anything for me.

If you didn't know where it was you'd miss it.  Dining area is sparse, basic tables and booths. Open deli-style.  

Got the chicken parm sub as recommended by Yelpers.  Mine was a little dry but a decent sandwich.  Still not sure i would order it again.  Fries are standard crinkle-cut.  

Summary: good place as alternative to nearby fast food joints but I wouldn't go out of my way to come again.

SAD! Wanted to like this place! Just got back from my first (and probably) last time to Elliot & Co. . . . . NOT worth the money - even with yelp discount!
  Services Recieved :  Haircut and a Shave Package  (getting rid of my beard!)
     First off let me say the haircut was/is very good (hence the chance, albeit slim, of a return) However,
 SHAVE LEFT MUCH TO BE DESIRED.....LIKE A CLOSE SHAVE FOR INSTANCE!!!  When i got home girlfriend and i noticed 1/4 inch hairs in spots on neck (must have missed it with razor?!) and stubble that i was able to remove with a simple disposable razor (which cost A LOT less).  All the fluff was nice; the towels and oils but at the end of the day the shave just wasn't there.

Bottom Line: Nice People, nice environment, good haircuts TERRIBLE SHAVE!

Your typical Sally's Beauty Supply. Have a good amount of items in stock, but unfortunately the customer service wasn't great. The manager of this store was kind and acknowledged me, but the other employees didn't seem to have a real drive to help me in a friendly manner. A smile goes a long way, as well as looking like you enjoy what you do.

I had lunch today at this joint with family... My sis-in law, big fan of this place and makes it a point to stop here when she is in town...  The place is not very big at all but the line was out the door...  I ordered the mixed plate.. I thought it was ok,,, it included a beef, chicken and some fish... The beef though in sauce did not have much taste,,, the chicken was good, i liked it.. tender and moist, it was de-boned thigh,, the fish was ehh,,, rather had extra chicken.. The portion was large, too large for me to finish...  I will try the Mami or Udon noodles next time....  I hesitantly recommend this place... I would eat here again but i wont make a special trip....  Hope this helps

"My previous visit to Las Vegas involved a brief sojourn at the Excalibur, owing to my companions' preference for its accommodations. Alas, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as the ambiance and amenities failed to impress me. The cost per night was exorbitant ($160), particularly considering the unpleasantness of our initial lodgings, which reeked of moisture damage and mold growth. Following an arduous wait, we were able to secure alternative accommodations, yet the prices remained prohibitive. The casino's location proved inconvenient, situated at a considerable distance from the bustling center of the Strip. The dining options within the establishment were also subpar. In conclusion, my experience at the Excalibur was less than satisfactory, and I am unlikely to return in the future."

The ambiance was underwhelming, to say the least, as the establishment's interior appeared unkempt, with grimy tables and an unclean floor that seemed to have been neglected for an extended period. Furthermore, the staff demonstrated a lackadaisical attitude towards providing adequate assistance, opting to observe passively as I endeavored to tidy up an unintentional spillage, leaving behind a sticky residue that remained unattended to by any member of the team.

"The ambiance was aesthetically pleasing and striking, fostering an environment conducive to culinary indulgence. I opted for the Chicken Meatloaf, which proved to be a delectable selection, boasting a rich, savory flavor profile. In contrast, my companion's Chicken Royale failed to meet expectations, lacking zest and leaving much to be desired in terms of gastronomic satisfaction. Notably, the accompanying vegetables, specifically the green beans and carrots, demonstrated superior taste and appeal. 

Although the server exhibited attentiveness upon delivery of the meals, his presence prior to that was regrettably lacking. 

Given the inconsistent quality of the dining experience, it is unlikely that I shall return."

"It is truly a gastronomical travesty when one encounters such an enticing bill of fare, only to be confronted with a dearth of culinary excellence in the form of frozen hashbrowns and subpar ingredients. Furthermore, the chicken fried steak was thoroughly permeated with an overpowering pork-like/smoky essence that utterly eclipsed any semblance of savory flavor. Although the waitstaff exhibited a certain charm and warmth in their demeanor, it proved impossible to surmount the immense disappointment engendered by the decidedly lackluster quality of the victuals."

it's partially my fault for not checking the lunch menu before i came, but i was very disappointed in lunch. i came on a recommendation, and was so excited to have tapas, bouillabaisse, spanish, italian, and french food! so i brought my family here at lunch only to see BORING sandwiches on the menu. we had a cuban and the chicken sandwich. lame. vegas is supposed to be a 24 hour city. i felt sad and embarrassed for bringing them here. the restaurant should at least have a few of their signature dishes, even in smaller portions, on the lunch menu.

We have recently acquired a residential property in Mesa, Arizona, which features an evaporative cooling system, and we have been informed by the previous proprietors that the construction of Tempe Town Lake has significantly diminished the duration during which the cooling apparatus can be effectively utilized, specifically owing to the augmented humidity levels in the surrounding atmosphere, and furthermore, the barrier that facilitates the impoundment of water has become compromised, resulting in the absence of a lake at present, which constitutes a negative aspect.

"Although my expectations were elevated due to the favorable reviews I had heard, my dining experience at this establishment ultimately fell short of my lofty standards. Despite the prolonged delay in being seated, which seemed to be a recurring theme, I opted to partake in their morning repast. While the cuisine was certainly passable, it failed to elicit any particularly remarkable sentiments on my part, and the atmosphere was regrettably characterized by overcrowding. In light of these factors, I would have to say that my preference would lie with the comparable venue situated nearby, specifically the Gilbert House."

"Sunday brunch at this establishment is merely adequate and lacks a certain je ne sais quoi that would elevate it to the next level. The selection of dishes is limited and uninspired, consisting primarily of standard breakfast fare and unremarkable flatbread pizzas. (It is worth noting that Upstream, a similar venue, sets a considerably higher standard for brunch.) While the food was not frigid, it failed to impress in terms of temperature. A previous assessment of the beverage offerings here suggested that they were diluted; unfortunately, this trend persists, as the Bloody Mary we ordered was also noticeably watered down. It is uncertain whether this is attributable to the choice of mix or some other factor. In any case, I have undoubtedly encountered superior iterations of this cocktail. Notwithstanding the preceding criticisms, the ambiance of this establishment is quite appealing and the crowd was indeed substantial, yet I cannot help but feel that the enthusiasm surrounding it is somewhat unwarranted."

Located in The Golden Nugget On Fremont Street Downtown Las Vegas. Ok so I hate to do this but, this place is just ok. the drinks were good, the service even better. The food was average to not so good. The fish and chips were saturated with oil. The 'tempura' lobster was more like funnel cake. There are much better choices downtown that are a lot cheaper. Live it up, you are in Las Vegas for cryin' out loud!

"My affection towards their burgers is nonexistent, as my culinary preferences are not adequately fulfilled by their offerings. Although I do appreciate the diversity of sauces and the quality of their French fries, my satisfaction with the dining experience is significantly diminished due to the prolonged waiting period for the food to be prepared and served, as well as the fact that my burger, which was cooked to a medium level of doneness, was unfortunately overcooked. Furthermore, my expectations for a superior dining experience were not met, as I have previously enjoyed more delectable burgers at other establishments, such as Serendipity, which does not specialize in burgers. Therefore, I must conclude that the restaurant's burgers are not worth the high price, and instead, I would recommend purchasing a frozen turkey patty from a local grocery store and heating it in a microwave oven for a more satisfying and cost-effective meal. However, I do acknowledge that the restaurant offers a diverse selection of flavors and cuts for their fries, which may appeal to certain individuals with unique tastes."

"My experience at Buraka fell short of my expectations regarding the quality and variety of Ethiopian cuisine. Although the menu offered a reasonable selection of vegetarian options, which I appreciated, the overall scope of dishes was limited. Furthermore, the absence of individual sampler platters, with the exception of a pricey two-entree combination, was disappointing. 

 My order consisted of a combination of misir wot and black beans, both described as spicy. However, upon emphasizing my preference for pungent flavors to the server, I was assured that the dishes would deliver an adequate level of heat. Unfortunately, they did not live up to my expectations in terms of spiciness or flavor profile. In fact, the injera, typically a highlight of my Ethiopian dining experiences, was unremarkable. 

 Midway through the meal, the server offered hot sauce as a means of enhancing the flavor, but I believe that the dishes themselves should possess inherent flavor without relying on supplementary condiments. 

 While the ambiance was pleasant and outdoor seating was available, my underwhelming experience at Buraka leads me to conclude that it is not worth revisiting in the future."

"Well, for starters, I must admit that I am not particularly fond of the Beatles (Yes, we do, in fact, exist), and thus, I did not have high expectations for this performance. Furthermore, our seats were only moderately decent, and the sheer magnitude of the venue, coupled with the 360-degree configuration of the stage, made it challenging to fully appreciate the experience. Additionally, Cirque's attempt to compensate for this by incorporating supplementary elements on either side of the primary stage only served to create an overwhelming sensory assault. While the soundtrack was undoubtedly impressive, given its ingenious reinterpretation of timeless classics, the acrobatic feats themselves were merely adequate, failing to live up to the exceptional standards set by other, more remarkable productions. My companion, however, appeared to derive some measure of enjoyment from the spectacle, although my own assessment yielded a less than enthusiastic verdict; hence, I would recommend this show primarily to ardent Beatles devotees, while those who are fervent admirers of Cirque's artistry might find superior alternatives."

"This evaluation pertains exclusively to the conference amenities and does not encompass an assessment of the sleeping quarters. Due to my absence of exposure to the latter, I cannot provide any remarks regarding their quality. However, my recent participation in a two-day technology-oriented workshop on the premises yielded an underwhelming experience, primarily owing to the dearth of electrical outlets within the designated area. This scarcity led to a chaotic struggle among attendees for access to the limited number of functioning sockets, rendering the learning environment rather challenging. Furthermore, an unpleasant odyssey befell us during the initial day of instruction, as an unidentified plumbing malfunction within the edifice precipitated a pervasive stench of sewage and gas throughout the facility. Despite the management's efforts to address the issue, the pungent smell persisted, necessitating our resilience and tolerance until its resolution."

Rather disappointed, ordered the kare-kare, although the meat was tender,vegetables were soggy.  The lechon kawali was pretty good, came with the gravy dip and rice. Perhaps will give them another chance due to the A/C not working on one of the hottest day of the year 122 deg,

Now that I have your attention, let me qualify the 2 Star \"award\". The good: the rooms are excellent; great design and better views. The architecture is captivating, and the prices are acceptable.\nHowever, the shuttle they claim to offer from the airport is pointless for most. Check the online schedule BEFORE you book a flight. The pick up times are sporadic at best.... who wants to wait 2-3 hours for a shuttle? the Taxi will cost $40 w/o tip. When you see the M Resort offer anything \"complimentary\", its NOT. At best, its a 2 for 1 offer.  Forget the buffet if your time means anything to you.... we stood 15 minutes and moved, I'm not joking, 4 feet! We arrived looking forward to relaxing at their gorgeous pool only to be told that the area is closed through March. We tried to get a glass of wine at the Hostile Grape; oops, closed 3 days a week! And if you like to shop, plan on renting a car because there is none at M, and the hotel is in the middle of NOWHERE. Next time I'll try Green Valley Ranch or South Point.

I want to give more stars and really like this place.  Service was ok, carne asada tacos pretty good.  Price is cheap.  They have beer.  Nice layout and good location.   All great things but................The place is filthy.  If you can't or won't maintain the dining room and bathrooms then just imagine the kitchen.  We didn't catch them on a bad day either.  What a shame.

"Hash House A Go Go in the Plaza offers a unique dining experience characterized by copious amounts of food, seemingly designed for athletic individuals with voracious appetites. Upon entering the establishment, we were immediately struck by the sheer magnitude of the culinary offerings, which appeared to prioritize quantity over quality. We elected to sample several items from the menu, including the Fried Chicken and Bacon Waffles, Andy's Sage Fried Chicken Benedict, and a House Salad. Our expectations were not particularly high, given the apparent emphasis on portion size rather than gastronomic refinement. The Fried Chicken and Waffles dish was somewhat unremarkable, with the chicken lacking succulence and flavor, while the waffles failed to deliver a distinct bacon flavor, prompting us to speculate that a few strips of bacon would have been a more effective way to incorporate that ingredient. The Fried Chicken Benedict presented an interesting dichotomy, consisting of three separate components stacked haphazardly atop one another. This unconventional presentation made it challenging to discern individual flavors, yet allowed us to create a diverse array of bites by combining various elements. Unfortunately, the House Salad proved uninspired and unexceptional, consisting merely of a bland mixture of iceberg lettuce. In conclusion, if you seek a novel dining experience and are willing to overlook the absence of gourmet fare, Hash House A Go Go may prove suitable for sharing a meal with a companion."

My second worst crepe experience ever!

I ordered a cheese and prosciutto crepe. The crepe was almost thick as a pancake and really doughy. I like doughy crepes but they should be much thinner. It was also not very hot. The prosciutto was too thick and it was kind of too strong in flavor. Worst of all are the flimsy forks they give you. I had a hell of a time trying to cut the prosciutto.

My BF ordered a decent veggie crepe. Mushroom and spinach I think. This crepe was also doughy and thick. If it were not for this decent crepe I would give this place one star.

The coffee here is awful. I will never return.

Parking is a breeze usually and it's free. It's in the Paris parking structure.

When we got here it was not too busy but when we passed by later on it was really packed. I really wonder why....The only cool thing here is checking out the stereotypical Parisian outfits the employees have to wear haha!
