first time here was a year ago. went with 2 of my friends, and we ended up going to their walk-up counter because the wait for an inside table was about an hour. we ordered small frozen hot chocolate. 

i must say - i wasnt really impressed. it tasted like a chocolate shake with sprinkles. maybe its better if you go inside to order it? i dont know...

second time i met some friends in town. they were eating dinner (i didnt eat because i just ate). everything looked really good and portions were pretty decent as well. 

third time we went in was a few weeks ago with my sister and some friends back home. ordered a frozen hot chocolate and a frozen white hot chocolate. i couldnt remember how big they were or how "eh" they were, but my sisters never been and we were already there. my sister ordered the frozen hot chocolate for two because her and her boyfriend were gonna share it. and it was waaaaaaaaaaay too much frozen hot chocolate! and as rich as it is, you really dont need anymore than a small. 

service was alright - the cashier there was a little slow at ringing in orders/putting the tickets up on the rail. and it seemed they were short staffed or something because the girl making the drinks seemed overwhelmed the whole time we were there. agian, maybe the hype was built up so much i expected a lot?

maybe i'll come back, stick out the wait and eat inside?

Should have never changed the recipes. I have been back twice since new ownership. I have to say I will give them one more shot. The place has lost the touch of service that was given. I feel while talking with workers that they can do better since everyone was really nice.

"Although the Peking duck possessed a certain degree of culinary merit, it is, in reality, a dish that is challenging to prepare incorrectly, thereby rendering its quality somewhat predictable. In contrast, the walnut prawns, owing to their excessive sweetness, could potentially induce a state of hypoglycemic shock in individuals afflicted with diabetes, thus warranting a classification as a dessert item. Furthermore, the crab dish, characterized by an overpowering flavor profile reminiscent of licking an ashtray imbued with garlic, demonstrated a discernible lack of subtlety in its preparation. Notwithstanding these criticisms, the service we received from the staff was indeed cordial and attentive, which made the experience marginally more tolerable. Unfortunately, the overall quality of the meal was subpar, leaving me with unpleasant gastrointestinal consequences the following morning."

After a year of basketing, I have  to downgrade Bountiful Baskets. The quality was never exceptional, but nonetheless I'm seeing the quality continue to decline. Too much produce that is spoiled within a day or two. I'm really getting tired of certain staples they throw in EVERY week (lousy apples, romaine lettuce). I bought a case of honeycrisp apples when they were in on special - extremely disappointing. They were tiny and started to spoil after just a few days. (That may have been my fault for not taking them out of the case immediately and checking for \"bad\" apples.) \n\nBountiful Baskets is more concerned with quantity over quality, which is fine because that's their whole M.O. I'm just tired of it and will have to look into a CSA.

1hr wait for our food after we got a seat.

Nice scenery and awesome vibe. That's were it ends.

The Blueberry muffins was unbeatable and dry.

The biscuits and gravy was pretty dang good. Should come with sausage or bacon though.

The Carne asada burrito was pretty bland.

The sandwich made out of French toast was the best thing and it was decent at best.

We will be back to the Perch but not here.

This venue offered an underwhelming experience, with the opening act being the sole redeeming quality.  The cost of admission, $39 for a mere hour of entertainment, seemed exorbitant, especially when compared to similar offerings in New York, which typically last longer and cost less.  The service provided by the waitstaff was abysmal, hindering our ability to enjoy ourselves further.  Unlike other comedy clubs, which often have a two-drink minimum, this establishment appeared to enforce a two-drink maximum, with the waitress disappearing for extended periods and demanding payment each time she delivered drinks, obstructing our view of the performance in the process.  Considering the lackluster nature of the experience, a reduced ticket price of half the original amount would be more appropriate.  To avoid a similar disappointment, it's recommended to attend comedy shows on weekends instead of weeknights.

Moe's culinary offerings can be described as unremarkable and uninspired, failing to differentiate themselves from their competitors such as Qdoba and Chipotle. The fare provided was fresh and palatable, yet lacked any extraordinary qualities or distinguishing characteristics. The burritos were diminutive in stature, with meager fillings that left much to be desired. 
  The pricing of their menu items was patently disproportionate to the quantity and quality of the food served. Specifically, the cost of an original-sized burrito, which was excessive in relation to its modest proportions and scant contents, was $7.50. Furthermore, the price of a small soft drink was $2.50, which seemed exorbitant given the absence of complimentary refills. 
  Notwithstanding these issues, each order did come with an accompaniment of chips and salsa. The chips possessed an agreeable texture and flavor, while the salsa was merely adequate. 
  Another anomaly that perplexed me was the packaging of my wife's Triple Lindy burrito, which arrived in a white box. However, when attempting to dispose of the container, its unusual design rendered it impossible to fit into the trash receptacle. This seemed like a curious oversight. 
  The names assigned to some of the burritos, such as Homewrecker and Art Vandelay, elicited my amusement. Nonetheless, Moe's generally underwhelming experience and unimpressive cuisine precludes it from ranking highly on my list of preferred dining establishments. In the vicinity of Jobing.com, there exist superior alternatives that warrant greater consideration.

"The culinary offerings at this establishment are undoubtedly delectable, however, the quality of service is utterly abysmal. This marks my third visit to this location, and unfortunately, the subpar service has been a recurring theme throughout. Notwithstanding my appreciation for the edibles, I would refrain from recommending this restaurant to any individual, as the prolonged waiting period for one's meal is followed by the delivery of an incorrect order, which is seemingly misplaced on another patron's table, thereby necessitating an additional extended delay. Upon requesting a bowl, I was compelled to physically accost a server at a neighboring table, and even then, the bowl materialized after an interminable duration, ostensibly still in the process of being manufactured. The most egregious aspect of this ordeal was the absence of any apology or attempt at reconciliation by the staff. In a separate incident, an order was placed, yet failed to arrive, prompting its cancellation due to the loss of appetite. Nevertheless, the restaurant saw fit to include the charge for the unconsumed dish on the bill, and when questioned, the staff became confrontational and adamant that the item had, in fact, been delivered. It appears that the management at this establishment is either oblivious or unconcerned with the issues plaguing their business, leaving patrons with no alternative but to opt for takeout."

"The establishment under the stewardship of Sushi Crescent and Sushi St-Denis' proprietors, I would say that this particular branch leaves much to be desired. With a dearth of attentive service (a significant drawback in an all-you-can-eat setting), the seafood lacks freshness, and the staff exude an air of indifference. For those seeking a genuine sushi experience without compromising on quality, I would recommend venturing a mere five minutes further to Sushi Crescent, where the same proprietors have consistently delivered satisfying meals. While it may seem inconsequential, the disparity in quality between the two locations is palpable."

We arrived punctually at the appointed hour of our reservation on July 4th, several minutes ahead of schedule, eager to partake in the culinary offerings of this esteemed establishment. However, upon entering the premises, we were met with an unexpected scene; numerous patrons were already present, patiently awaiting their turn to be seated, while a considerable number of tables remained unoccupied. Perplexed by this anomaly, we inquired as to the cause of the delay, and were informed by the hostess that the restaurant's computerized system dictated the order in which guests were to be seated, irrespective of the chronological order of their arrivals. Consequently, we endured a protracted wait of over twenty minutes before being escorted to our designated table, situated outdoors, adjacent to table number 108. Furthermore, a significant lapse of time ensued before we received our initial glasses of water, while other parties, who had arrived subsequent to our reservation, were promptly served their beverages and bread. The quality of the fare provided was merely satisfactory, as my spouse's seafood dish contained a portion of unopened clams, indicative of inferior quality, and the absence of pasta as an accompaniment was conspicuous. My own dish, consisting of lemon chicken, was compromised by the excessive fat content of the poultry. Additionally, despite our request for breadsticks, they were never forthcoming. Moreover, the powerful emissions from the outdoor steamers created visual obstructions and resulted in an uncomfortable dining experience for my daughter, who was also subjected to an unintended shower.

"Underwhelming gastronomical experience with too much repetition in the menu options and an unimpressive presentation of flavors, coupled with lukewarm beverages and an excessively oily texture in the dishes, culminating in a lackluster and overpriced culinary encounter that fails to justify a second visit."

Last weekend, I had an unfortunate experience while lodging at this establishment, which failed to meet my expectations as a loyal Marriott Rewards member. Despite my repeated attempts to request assistance through room service, the room remained unkempt and unsanitary. Furthermore, the light switches were defective, presenting me with the inconvenient option of having all the lights on or off simultaneously. In addition, the elevator access system, which required the use of my room key, was frequently malfunctioning. This resulted in numerous frustrating delays during my stay. To further compound the issues, I did not receive my bill portfolio via email, even after placing several calls to rectify the situation. The process was plagued by technical difficulties, ultimately leading me to leave a voice message on an alternate contact number. Based on my disappointing encounter, I would advise potential guests against selecting this hotel for their accommodation needs.

This particular Post Office branch boasts the advantageous feature of an Automated Postal Center, which enables patrons to expeditiously procure postage or dispatch packages with minimal effort, thereby streamlining the process for both the consumer and the postal worker. Unfortunately, the designated receptacle for depositing packages often becomes overfilled, rendering it inaccessible to patrons, much to their chagrin. Despite the convenience afforded by the APC, numerous attempts to alert the counter staff via ringing the bell or knocking on the door have been futile, leaving patrons exasperated and frustrated. On one occasion, the APC experienced technical difficulties on a Saturday morning, resulting in a lengthy queue of customers eager to utilize its services. Upon finally being attended to, the worker was oblivious to the malfunction and expressed surprise at the unusual volume of patrons, highlighting the lack of communication and coordination among staff members. Eager to maintain a positive relationship with the United States Postal Service, I endeavor to provide constructive feedback in the hope of improving the quality of service, as even a modicum of attentiveness and responsiveness would greatly enhance the overall experience for patrons.

"Having been apprised of the exceptional culinary offerings purportedly proffered by Rossario's, a reputed gastronomic haven in Monona, my expectations were unquestionably elevated. Alas, my recent nocturnal dining experience proved utterly disparate from such laudatory accounts, prompting me to express my profound disenchantment with the establishment's ostensible shortcomings. Specifically, my order of portabello mushroom lasagne, comprising an amorphous mixture of flaccid noodles, copious amounts of cheese, and mushrooms submerged in sauce, failed to resemble any semblance of authentic lasagne. Similarly, my spouse, a native Italian, was equally disillusioned with his selection of chicken Puttanesca, as evidenced by his desultory demeanor and palpable dissatisfaction following a mere two bites. Furthermore, even the humble salad proved underwhelming, further contributing to our collective discontent. In conclusion, my succinct assessment of Rossario's can be summarized thusly: 'Ugh, ugh, ugh.'"
This 24 Hour location is really busy and the equipment is worn out. I did not like this particular 24 Hour.

I had high hopes that this place was on the same level as Salt River in feel and character but I sure did not have that after visiting it last night.  Maybe as I never have been at Wrigley I am missing some of the customized elements.

By far the biggest issue, minus the stupid prices for t-shirts and concessions, is the exceedingly poor scoreboard.  We sat in the lower level of the first base side and had a heck of a time reading the scoreboard.  Here are my gripes on the scoreboard:

Too small to be useful
At night it is not very well lighted so seeing the non-lighted sections is impossible
About 1/3 was being used for advertising
No stats provided for the batter (take a lesson from Salt River)
The line up on the left side did not highlight the batter but with the letters so small it would not be of much use.

By the way the parking lot lighting but there was no signage as to how to exit and the entrance was blocked off!  

I never have been to a ballpark above a crude kids field that did not have the distances from home plate to the outfield fence shown with signs hanging on the fence.

I embarked upon the indoor ride and we shared a gondola with unfamiliar individuals. This turned out to be a minor blunder, as they maintained a stoic silence throughout the duration of the ride and did not appear to be in the mood for frivolity, furthermore, the male member of our group had an unsightly and rather substantial wart located on his temple which I found myself unable to divert my gaze from. Um.

The gondolier proved to be quite delightful. He possessed a charming demeanor, was extremely loquacious, and boasted a rich, resonant voice. He significantly enhanced the experience. However, the gondola ride itself was somewhat underwhelming. I frequently indulge in tacky, touristy attractions that are often considered rip-offs, but I would not advocate for this particular ride. It appears far more enjoyable than it actually is and its cost far surpasses the level of entertainment it provides. Upon reaching the turnaround point, you may find yourself thinking, "THAT'S IT?", and indeed, that is all there is to it. It fails to deliver the level of excitement one would anticipate. The outdoor version is purportedly superior, thus it may be worth considering instead. The indoor rendition can be safely skipped.

This grocery store gets 2 stars just for being open 24 hours.  
I only shop there if it's after midnight (when the other grocery stores in the area have closed). 

- overpriced
- very annoying security 'guys' follow you around the store
- limited selection

"It is rather uncommon for me to frequent chain restaurants, and even less so when it comes to chain steakhouses. Therefore, it was quite unexpected that I found myself dining at Outback Steakhouse during a recent excursion to Las Vegas. The circumstances that led to this occurrence were as follows: I was indulging in a business trip, and my associates requested steak and convenience. As we were residing at hotels situated south of the strip, our options were somewhat limited. Thus, I opted to visit the Outback located near the Outlet Mall, which I had previously noticed during my travels. My previous experiences at Outback Steakhouses have been sparse, with the most recent one taking place approximately six years ago. Upon entering the establishment, I was pleasantly surprised to discover that the quality of the food and service had improved since my last visit. My six-ounce sirloin was cooked to satisfaction, and the accompanying salad was also quite palatable. The server was attentive and courteous, providing adequate attention to our needs without overindulging in excessive familiarity. In summary, while the dining experience at Outback Steakhouse may not be classified as 'fine dining,' it was nevertheless acceptable and fulfilled its intended purpose."

Average food for average prices.  I came here with a $30 for $15 deal from Groupon and if I was actually spending the listed price on the menu, I would definitely not be satisfied.  Since my meal was basically half off, I would say that the food was okay and well worth it, but I would not spend more than that. 

I ordered in total about 6 dishes worth $90 that I paid $45 dollars for, and out of all of them I only liked the calamari.  Every other dish was either meatless, tasteless, or overcooked. 

The restaurant was absolutely stunning and nicely decorated.  The lights were dim and perfect for a date, if the food was better.  

The server was very attentive and friendly, one of the better servers I have ever interacted with.

The airport is in need of an update.  It is very lack luster, there are very few healthy options for food (although this is common for airports) and there are still random Oxygen bars (do people still use these?).  The bathrooms are pretty dirty.  They have some corporate sponsored \"charging stations\" but they are typically crowded and you can see people up and down the terminals either sitting on the floor or hustling to grab spots when they open.  Unless you are coming to or leaving LV, there are much better spots to have to lay over.

"The culinary offerings were merely adequate, while the hospitality we received was utterly disappointing. Specifically, we had reserved a table for the evening of December 24th through the online platform OpenTable, which indicated that the establishment accepted reservations at either 11:00 PM or 11:30 PM. Upon our arrival, however, the server informed us that they would be closing their doors at midnight, thus prompting us to hastily consume our meals in an attempt to avoid any potential inconvenience. Unfortunately, this decision proved ill-fated, as the waitstaff exhibited remarkable impatience and discourtesy throughout the duration of our dining experience. Furthermore, a significant portion of the menu items failed to meet the standards lauded by previous patrons, leading us to question whether the quality of the cuisine was adversely affected by the holiday season."

This restaurant was horrible. We ordered the special murg tikka and the chicken tasted as though they threw a frozen chicken packet into the oven, sprinkled some salt and pepper and served it to us. We also ordered the paneer makhani and it was sub standard.\nThe naan was tasty, so if you're up for some naan and pickles.. go for it. Otherwise i'd steer clear of this place.

One star for food and one for their awesome bartender Emmanuel who redeemed the offensive service I got here. I've came here twice and both times Emmanuel was working the bar-so friendly and personable! He's just an all around nice guy, likes to make sure everyone's having a good time. If I could've taken the tip back from our waiter and given it to him, I would've. He gave us more service in the 8 minutes we were at the bar than our "waiter" did in the 45 minutes we were at our table. 

I get it, not everyone likes their job every day. I don't like my job every single day! But when dealing with customers you pretend to like your job and don't make them feel like their presence is a burden. Our waiter didn't get that memo and his inattentiveness bordered on neglect. He came to our table three times, once to take our drink orders, food orders and then to bring the check. The way he asked if we wanted the check basically said "I want you to leave now." The busser came by more often than he did to see if we needed anything. 

This place isn't worth the time if you're coming from out of your way. If you choose to go for the simple fact that yard house is the cluster that it usually is, sit at the bar!

When the proprietor arrives to offer regretful sentiments, the nocturnal experience tends not to be optimal. The sluggishness of the service, coupled with the unremarkable nature of the culinary offering, which fails to distinguish itself within a municipality boasting several superior pie establishments, contributes to an ambiance that is not only disappointing but also peculiarly clamorous.

"For the purpose of attending a respiratory convention, I have opted to procure accommodations at a hotel that would not necessitate my presence for the entirety of the day. While the rooms themselves are clean and well-appointed, featuring comfortable beds, I cannot help but notice the pervasive odor of cigarette smoke emanating from the supposedly non-smoking area. It seems rather ironic that such a situation should arise in a city renowned for its laxity regarding gambling and other vices. Furthermore, I must express my discontent with the addition of a resort fee, which, quite frankly, strikes me as an egregious attempt to extort additional funds from unsuspecting patrons. Suffice it to say, my experience at Treasure Island has been somewhat tarnished by these unfortunate circumstances, leading me to dub it 'Pirate Island' due to its seemingly predatory business practices."

Come for the endless variety of BBQ, stay because you can't make a decision. Realize the selection of sides is equally expansive, and just sit there eating biscuits with apple butter until someone tells you to get the tri-tip sandwich with a side of cornbread.

I understand why people are lamenting about how stupid the prices are, but come on, y'all. You could totally share a meal with someone here and leave satisfied (as long as you eat yer biscuits.) Now, now, I know what you're thinking, "We don't take kindly to sharers 'round these parts..." But put down your pitchforks, because the portions are proportionally reasonable to their stupid prices.

Lucille's lands at 2 stars for good biscuit and cornbread game, solid tri-tip and peanut slaw, and subpar brisket and mac 'n' cheese. In another region, I might toss Lucy a fourth star, but anything less than the best in this BBQ-splattered town just won't win my stomacheart.

For the kitsch factor, for something to do for a day, this place is fine.  It's got games and the carousel bar and cheesy circus acts.  But it's dirty, it's run down, it's poorly planned, and I wouldn't stay here if my life depended on it.  (OK, MAYBE then.)  I tell people who come to visit all the time to not be taken in by the cheap rates here and at the Tropicana.  There's a reason WHY they're cheap.

I have used irrigation with SPR for over 30 years. They have really dedicated people who go out of their way to be helpful. The Zanjeros were always available and  ready to work out some water issue, and they  are varied and frequent (like a neighbors dead animal in a canal) . So for many years I have been a big fan of SRP.

Until today!

I needed to pay my water assessment so I went to the main office.
1. Now a security guard tells you you are in the wrong place, no more receptionist.
2. The payment  center was closed and turned into  a closet with some machines in it.
3. Customer service is now a telephone on a brown wall with a sign over the phone saying call for customer service.

Zanjeros are now computer baby sitters for the nee Water Master system. Getting a consistent flow is a real challenge now. They are ready to add time but after you get shorted 20 minutes you have to move to a new user and it really does not work to then get 20 minutes delivered the next day. The person responsible  for the Water master needs to be required to meet users at 2am when the order gets shorted by the system.

When I called today I spoke to an old style SRP person but you might as well visit the prison as use this facility, So no matter what the literature says SRP is now just another big faceless utility doing their level best to isolate the customer.

"I experienced an intense yearning for delectable BBQ cuisine, which unfortunately, was not satisfactorily fulfilled by my recent dining excursion. Upon ordering $35 worth of culinary delights, my expectations were not adequately met, as the quality of the fare failed to impress me. Specifically, the pulled pork was merely passable, while the brisket proved to be unremarkable. Furthermore, the chicken lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, and the beans, regrettably, were undercooked and rather unpalatable. Consequently, I felt compelled to discard them. However, I must admit that the assortment of sauces available did possess a certain degree of palatability. Ultimately, my quest for succulent southern-style brisket remained unfulfilled, prompting me to seek out alternative sources, including soliciting the culinary expertise of my father-in-law. Notwithstanding the eatery's commendable cleanliness and hospitable staff, the diminutive proportions of the dishes served left me feeling underwhelmed."

"As an individual hailing from the Philadelphia metropolitan region, merely passing by this establishment sparked a significant amount of enthusiasm within me. Upon entering the premises, I was immediately struck by the striking resemblance that Pop's Deli bore to Pat's King of Steaks, a renowned eatery in the city of brotherly love. Despite my initial excitement, however, I was sadly disappointed by the subpar quality of the food. Specifically, the cheesesteak sandwich that I ordered, which featured a combination of whiz, onions, and peppers, lacked any semblance of flavor or depth. In fact, I found it rather challenging to distinguish between the taste of the meat and that of the onions, which made for a rather unsettling dining experience. Furthermore, the bread utilized in the sandwich was unsatisfactory, possessing neither the crispy texture nor the rich, buttery flavor that one would expect from an authentic Amoroso roll. Aesthetically, the outdoor seating area was quite inviting, and the sweet potato fries that accompanied my meal were indeed delectable. Nonetheless, the underwhelming nature of the main course left much to be desired."
This was my first time trying Culvers. It's nothing special and is comparable to Wendy's or any other fast food burger place.

"Upon entering the establishment to retrieve an item from the ship-to-store department, I observed that the register was unattended, despite the presence of a sizable queue of patrons awaiting assistance. The gentleman manning the adjacent register informed me that the alternative lane was unavailable, which prompted me to request that he summon support staff to address the situation. In concert with two fellow patrons who shared my sentiment, I emphasized the need for expedited service, given that we were not present for layaway purposes. Fortuitously, our proximity to the employee entrance afforded me the opportunity to alert a staff member of the predicament, resulting in the timely arrival of reinforcements. Although the pace of service remained somewhat sluggish, it marked a considerable improvement from the previous state of affairs. Ultimately, it required approximately half an hour from the moment of my arrival to procure my items and secure permission to collect them from the rear of the store, owing to their bulkiness and the necessity of transporting them via a flatbed cart."

I guess I didn't order the right sandwich because out of all the awesome reviews my sandwich was just.... OK. I got the Italian and was not really impressed. It was just a small amount of meat and a slice of cheese with stock Italian dressing. So what's the big deal?? Ok I'm gonna have to go back and order something else because I gotta see what all the hype is about! To be continued...

I am a resident of the surrounding area and have been frequenting this establishment for an extended period of time, indulging in both takeout and dining in. Unfortunately, over the past six months, I have noticed a gradual decline in the quality of the cuisine, to the point where I question whether it is worthwhile to continue patronizing this restaurant. Specifically, the refried beans appeared to be from a canned source, which is unacceptable given my familiarity with the distinction between homemade and canned variants. Furthermore, the Cheese Crisp was subpar and excessively oily, while the shredded beef taco contained an abundance of fatty cuts. It is unfortunate that this establishment, which once prided itself on serving high-quality Mexican fare, has allowed its standards to slip. Consequently, my dining companions and I have decided to seek alternative options, such as Sylvia's La Canasta or Macayo's, which offer superior culinary experiences without relying on prefabricated ingredients.

"My experience at this establishment was subpar relative to the expectations engendered by its reputation, and I was accordingly disillusioned. Despite expressing the significance of the occasion to both the hostess and our server, the customary birthday dessert was omitted from our dining experience, which was an unfortunate oversight. Furthermore, the quality of the edibles did not meet my expectations, specifically the sweet potato tempura and king crab California roll, which were characterized by an unacceptable level of aridity in the rice. In light of these factors, I elected not to leave a gratuity, and I also took the time to provide feedback on the receipt regarding my dissatisfaction with the service. Overall, my visit to this restaurant fell short of my expectations due to the disparity between the acclaim it has received and the actual quality of the food and service provided."

I'm conflicted about this place.  The wife and I were in LV for the first time since 2003, so we were exploring new places.  We saw this restaurant on our travels before heading to a show and we love sushi so we stopped.  The food was very fresh and drink selection was excellent, however portion size was tiny.  After $72 with tip my wife commented that is was the first restaurant that she had ever left feeling more hungry than when she arrived.  We then had to hurry off to get more food before the show.

During our initial visit, we opted to be seated at the bar, whereupon we were immediately bombarded by an excessive amount of attention from the waiting staff, specifically two individuals who appeared to be endeavoring to provide assistance with an unparalleled level of diligence. However, as time progressed, it became increasingly arduous to procure the attention of any staff member, resulting in an interminable delay of approximately twenty minutes merely to obtain our bill and effectuate our departure. Despite the fact that the establishment was experiencing a high volume of patrons, my companion and I elected to sample a beverage, only to be ultimately dissuaded from doing so due to the absence of any semblance of attentive service.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition." 
The evening commenced with promise, as my gaze fell upon the menu, and my attention was captured by the presence of foie gras, which, to my delight, was not merely a pate, but a seared entirety.  Although the radicchio did not harmonize well with it, the flavor was passable, albeit slightly undercooked.  However, everything took a turn for the worse from that point forward.  I have yet to encounter a smaller or more insipid ceviche, and I must emphasize that if a dish is to be designated as ceviche, it should conform to Peruvian tradition and possess an unmistakable ceviche flavor.  The lobster risotto, though relatively satisfying, was meager in quantity, consisting of only three bites; while the black bass was unremarkable and quickly forgotten.  Furthermore, the prime rib eye was misleadingly named, as it excluded the eye, which is, in fact, the most delectable portion.  Though the complimentary soup and appetizer were appreciated, they failed to satiate our hunger, prompting us to seek a second dinner at Smashburger nearby.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition of unpalatable flavors and questionable presentation!"
The text is: "I ordered a burger, but they brought me a sandwich. I sent it back and waited for my burger. They brought me another sandwich. I asked them to make sure it was a burger and not a sandwich. They said they would, but they still brought me a sandwich. This happened three times before I finally got my burger."
The modified text is: 
"A series of unfortunate events culminating in an unsatisfactory dining experience due to recurring mistakes in food delivery and inadequate communication among staff members."

If you want quality, quantity, and reasonable prices--don't go here.  The food could hardly be deemed within an authentic deli realm.  The service is poor, the offerings minute, and taste lacking (chicken soup too salty, sandwiches bland, and desserts hardly unique or fresh).\n\nEven though they are open 24 hours, you have 24 hours to find another venue.  This is a side-show at Circus Circus that is not worth attending.

"Prospective advantages: Punctual arrival time. \n\nConsiderable drawbacks: Extended duration of operational execution, specifically 5.25 hours for loading personal portable storage devices, which, considering the extent of pre-existing preparation, should have required no more than 3 hours; additionally, supplementary fees amounting to $446 were incurred for requisite resources, thereby resulting in a total financial loss of $1150 for the day. Caveat emptor."

"Little Darlings, a purportedly adult entertainment venue, boasts an unadulterated nudity policy; thus, it is devoid of any alcoholic beverages. Although situated slightly removed from the Las Vegas Strip, its location does not pose significant challenges for those seeking to locate it. However, if one harbors expectations of experiencing a genuinely exceptional strip club adventure within the city limits of Las Vegas, they might wish to reconsider their choice of destination. The interior ambiance exudes an unmistakable aura of shabbiness and seediness, potentially arousing feelings of unease or discomfort in certain patrons. Furthermore, the physical appearance of the female performers falls short of the conventional standards associated with strip clubs. A considerable number of them exhibit visible signs of aging and/or lack of physical fitness, which may prove underwhelming for some spectators. Considering the abundance of alternative options within the city's nightlife scene, it seems judicious to bypass this establishment altogether."

I'm torn between the quality product and the poor service and WiFi.  

The coffee is exceptional but the entry fee (getting past the flaming hoops of attitude) to get your coffee is a little high.  Now I guess I'm one of the cool kids at times (working for the man - Buring Man), but unless that comes up in conversation, most often I'm not dressed the part in my business casual and just another target for the staff.

Beyond the slow service and attitude, the WiFi is crap.  They are riding a signal from a neighbor companies (Wet Paint) router.  I wish they'd get their own router and Cox connection!  Hell I'd even set it up for them, and when I suggested putting a WiFi tip jar the customers at the bar were all for it!

I like the location and the product but not the service and WiFi - both things that can be fixed.

"Prior to my visit, I had been apprised by multiple individuals of the culinary proficiency of this establishment, and while my personal preferences lean towards authentic Italian cuisine, I am cognizant of the fact that adaptations are often necessary in order to accommodate local tastes and ingredients. Thus, I opted to sample their lobster bisque, which, unfortunately, did not quite meet my expectations, as it possessed an excessive amount of pepper and contained what appeared to be desiccated fish fragments. Furthermore, I had intended to order the crab and shrimp cake appetizer; however, due to an oversight on my part, I failed to thoroughly peruse the menu and was accordingly served the entrÃ©e instead. Although the crab and shrimp cake was moderately satisfying, the presence of an excessive amount of filler detracted from its overall quality. Moreover, the accompanying grilled potatoes and vegetables were not merely lukewarm, but were in fact completely cold. In light of the exorbitant prices charged by this restaurant, I must conclude that the experience was not worth the cost, and I do not anticipate returning in the future."

"I believe this establishment could benefit from a thorough sanitizing, although certain individuals might argue that the grime enhances its charm. Be that as it may, I would prefer not to depart feeling an increased necessity for hand cleanser. The beverages are quite affordable and potent, at least relative to my expectations. I ventured forth solo in pursuit of social interaction and novel acquaintances with whom to imbibe and engage in casual conversation. Unfortunately, it appeared that the majority of patrons were clustered into tightly-knit coteries, exhibiting limited inclination towards expanding their social circles. This dive bar, while unremarkable in terms of musical entertainment during my visit, does possess the capacity to inebriate a group of individuals with reasonable efficiency. I shall revisit and revise my assessment should I deem it necessary."

The sentiment of satisfaction was conspicuously absent, as the culinary offerings failed to meet expectations, despite the establishment's convenient delivery options and extended operating hours. Although the front desk staff demonstrated proficiency in the English language, the gastronomical experience was disappointing, with dishes exhibiting an unfortunate lack of flavor and questionable preparation methods. Specifically, the pot stickers were overcooked and excessively crunchy, resulting in an inadequate filling-to-dough ratio, while the lo mien noodles presented an unpleasant texture, with some strands bunched together, others overcooked or undercooked, and vegetables displaying an unnatural waxiness. Furthermore, the beef in the lo mien was overcooked and insufficiently seasoned, rendering it unremarkable. The general's chicken, though not entirely unpalatable, fell short of expectations, failing to distinguish itself from other, superior iterations. In conclusion, the overall experience was unsatisfactory, prompting the abandonment of leftovers, typically considered a highlight of an otherwise satisfying Chinese meal.

"We halted our culinary excursion at this eatery for a midday repast, commencing with the crabby mozzarella hors d'oeuvre and the fungal morel bisque.  The crab mozzarella was relatively palatable and the mushroom morel soup was also quite satisfactory.  However, the soup evoked memories of the Cheesecake Factory's fungal soup, which remains my preference.  Absent any opinions regarding the brew, I shall endeavor to sample it on a future visit when I am free from medication. 

The seafood combination au gratin comprised a pair of clams, a mahimahi filet, scallops, and stuffed shrimp.  I was unenthusiastic about the shrimp's tacky imitation crab filling, while both the mahimahi filet and the scallops lacked seasoning.  The clams were adequate. 

For dessert, we indulged in the nutter butter ice cream cake, which was fairly satisfying.  Unfortunately, the fare did not elicit excessive excitement."

Close to my humble abode, I opted to investigate this establishment once more. Upon entering, I was met with an underwhelming experience, as the bartender seemed to prioritize his personal electronic device over providing adequate customer service. Despite my eagerness to indulge in their offerings, I found myself having to plead for a beverage, the cost of which was $45. Perplexed by the lack of attention from the staff, I decided to depart, questioning whether any improvements would be made in the future. Unfortunately, based on past experiences, I harbor doubts about the likelihood of change.

"Although the pizzeria offered an adequate array of flavors and toppings, I was somewhat disenchanted by the limited number of non-fat options available, which seemed to be lacking in variety and depth, thereby diminishing my overall satisfaction with the menu selections."

"Hailing from the Midwestern region of the United States, I had never had the pleasure of indulging in the culinary delights offered by Del Taco, a fast-food establishment that ostensibly specializes in Mexican-inspired dishes; however, based on my recent experience with their fare, I cannot say that I have been missing out on much in terms of gastronomical satisfaction, as the flavor profile of their offerings seemed to be largely overshadowed by the unremarkable nature of their fries, which were not only lacking in texture but also failed to deliver any discernible taste, and the so-called 'chicken' tacos, which were essentially little more than an amalgamation of wilted lettuce and unmelted cheese, did not exactly tantalize my palate."

"Upon perusing the reviews, I had anticipated a superior dining experience at this establishment. Unfortunately, my expectations were not met, to say the least. The ambiance was not conducive to a pleasant dining experience, as it was a smoking environment, which proved to be a significant disappointment, particularly during dinner. The service was sluggish and lacked warmth, which further contributed to an unpleasant dining atmosphere. Our order consisted of cheese sticks, which were unimpressive and lacking in flavor, beer-battered pickles that were excessively greasy, and a BBQ chicken sandwich that was unfortunately overcooked, resulting in an inedible batter that was nearly burnt. Despite our attempts to salvage the sandwich by cutting and removing the batter, it proved to be a futile endeavor. The garlic Parmesan fries failed to deliver any discernible traces of garlic flavor. Ultimately, the dining experience was a disappointment, with my boyfriend opting not to consume his sandwich. The lone redeeming quality was the beer, which was quite satisfactory."

We went for sunday brunch , i like the fact they open at 7am, i figure everyone still sleeping nursing late night hangovers. I was right at 7 am only a handful of us old folks in line. . The buffet was very limited and not many items. For about 25 bucks a head you should get more. The hot foods were mostly breakfast items what happend to the lunch part of brunch. Very sad. Everthing was fresh as it should be since we were their early. Still can't believe a beautiful casino , ' upscale\" would have a brunch that was so simple. Spend a few more bucks and go to wynn, or bellagio.  Service was fine.

"A further gem in the Fox culinary diadem, boasting an extraordinary appearance and sensation, yet accompanied by exorbitant prices for fare that, while undeniably delectable, fails to justify the cost. In a recent visit, a member of our party opted for the prime rib French dip, to which the server inquired whether they desired mushrooms, peppers, or onions, to which my acquaintance responded affirmatively. Subsequently, they had the audacity to impose an additional fee of $2 per item, totaling $6, for what can only be described as meager embellishments. It is utterly preposterous; I could procure ten pounds of onions for a mere $2... Ultimately, I chose to share a chicken club and a minuscule cheese platter, accompanied by iced tea, amounting to a staggering $24. To compound the disappointment, the server exhibited a discourteous demeanor. In light of this experience, it is improbable that I would voluntarily frequent a Fox establishment again, unless presented with the occasional gift card."

My spouse and I were utterly thrilled to discover a stylish and child-friendly eatery materialize in close proximity to our residential area, and we were eager to partake in a culinary experience therein. Upon entering the establishment, we were immediately struck by the captivating ambiance, which we enthusiastically admired for the duration of our beverage order (approximately 15 minutes). However, our fervor was quickly dampened by the underwhelming quality of the wine, which was served at an unimpressive temperature. Perusing the menu, we discovered a selection of edibles that, while adequate, did not particularly align with our dietary inclinations, save for a scant few options. Our server, though friendly, seemed to convey a sense of indifference towards our order, which perhaps contributed to the underwhelming nature of our dining experience. The hummus appetizer, while flavorful, was regrettably diminutive in portion, and the accompanying pita chips, though plentiful, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi. My Caprese salad, unfortunately, failed to exude the freshness one might expect from such an ensemble, while my companion's garden salad was unremarkable, to say the least. We pondered whether our order had been misguided, but ultimately concluded that a restaurant must take responsibility for the quality of its offerings. Disheartened, we opted to seek sustenance elsewhere, even on a workday, which speaks to the extent of our disappointment. It is truly disconcerting that a venue with such potential should fall short of expectations, and we sincerely hope that management will address these shortcomings, as we would otherwise relish the opportunity to frequent the establishment.

The dining experience was subpar, characterized by a tardy service and a burger presented on an unpalatable, moist bun. Despite requesting a novel bun, its procurement was delayed substantially, thus compelling us to consume the patty sans the bun. Furthermore, the ambient temperature within the establishment was excessively elevated, causing discomfort for all individuals seated at our table, who were perspiring profusely. Considering the overall unsatisfactory nature of our visit, we would not consider returning to this venue in the future.

"Prior to engaging in a cinematic experience, my spouse and I opted to dine at this establishment due to its proximity to the theatre. Upon entering, we were greeted by an accommodating staff who expedited our seating and ordering process with efficiency. The beverage selection boasted an intriguing watermelon margarita, which we found quite delectable. However, the culinary offerings failed to meet our expectations, as the dressing accompanying my chopped salad was excessively piquant, rendering it inedible. In response, the courteous server proffered a quesadilla as a substitute, which, while unremarkable in taste, did alleviate the discomfort caused by the spicy dressing. My husband's rancho burrito fared slightly better, yet still fell short of our gastronomic standards. Considering our underwhelming experience, we would not recommend this venue to any individual seeking a satisfying dining experience prior to a cinematic excursion."

It is 7:30 am, and the time has come for me to partake in the first meal of the day. As I ponder my options, I find myself faced with a dilemma; shall I opt for a plate of savory sausage gravy, or perhaps indulge in some turkey sausage? Or, maybe, just maybe, I could treat myself to both the gravy and the sausage, thus satisfying my morning cravings. Furthermore, I must consider whether to accompany my meal with a banana that has been ripening for approximately two weeks, adding a touch of sweetness to my breakfast. After deliberating for a span of ten minutes, during which time I observed Magdelina ensuring an abundance of froot loops to complement the overripe bananas, sausage gravy, and turkey sausage, I decided to proceed with my morning routine, grabbing a cup of coffee before embarking on my day, feeling somewhat peckish. It is worth noting that Las Vegas boasts an extensive array of hotels, numbering in the hundreds, and it may be advisable to consider alternative accommodations.

Huge rooms. Soft towels. Comfortable bed with tons of pillows.  
Three things that make me happy when I'm traveling.  

What's wrong with this place, then? First of all, the location is central to nothing aside from the mall which houses several chain restaurants.  Second, the staff could not care less about pretty much anything. While the woman who checked us in was helpful and friendly, that was the end of that. Despite requesting my Hilton status "amenities" (just a package of snacks and water...not much), I never received it.  I was also charged $30 for internet when I shouldn't have paid a thing (got the bill corrected at check out). And housekeeping didn't leave enough towels or replace the water.  

Considering we paid over $200 a night, the blase attitude of the staff is very disappointing.

When you enter the eatery and peruse the menu, you may perceive yourself in "Poultry Paradise," owing to the diverse array of flavors and seasonings available for your potatoes. Nonetheless, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled. I opted for the chicken wing and strip combo, accompanied by a side of fries. The poultry was cooked to a golden, crispy texture and presented at an adequate temperature. My selection of garlic Parmesan was unfortunately overpowered by excessive saltiness. Furthermore, some pieces of my chicken were regrettably undercooked. Due to spatial constraints within the dining establishment, I was compelled to retrieve my meal for consumption elsewhere. Despite receiving mixed feedback, I remain open to offering Chicken Shack another opportunity to demonstrate their culinary proficiency.

"My acquaintance and I opted to utilize the recent $25 for $50 Groupon to experience Pewter Rose on a Saturday evening. Honestly, I considered the pricing to be somewhat steep for the ambiance presented, thus I was grateful for the voucher. Although the atmosphere was agreeable, I felt that the plastic tablecloths were incongruous with the menu prices exceeding $20 per plate. Notwithstanding this, the venue was teeming with patrons; we had booked a table for 8 pm and arrived punctually, and the hostess promptly seated us within five minutes. Our server, however, immediately intimated that we should anticipate a prolonged wait for our cuisine, given the high volume of clientele that evening. As we were not pressed for time, we acquiesced to the delay. Our server was attentive and maintained our hydration, but despite placing our order without delay, we did not receive our initial course until well after 8:30 p.m., and indeed, it was closer to 9:20 p.m. before we were served our main dishes. While the restaurant was bustling, it is not particularly expansive, which made the extended waiting period slightly unexpected. Personally, I relished the seafood risotto and would certainly partake of it once more. My companion had the herb-encrusted lamb, which was palatable, albeit a tad too salty for our taste. I might consider returning to sample their brunch, yet I would hesitate to pay the full tariff for an evening meal."

"On multiple occasions, the quality of service has been subpar, and this particular experience was no exception. Upon removing my salad plate, the waiter callously deposited the accompanying utensil on the table, thoughtlessly leaving behind an abundance of lettuce. The preceding appetizers were unimpressive and potentially hazardous to my health, considering the dubious texture of the mushroom caps. Furthermore, the beverages were diluted, which only served to exacerbate my disappointment. Although the main course offered some respite, with a passable steak and an array of unremarkable vegetables, the potatoes were regrettably underheated. It is truly mystifying why anyone would choose to dine at such an establishment when there are numerous superior options available in the locality."

It required an excess of 20 minutes to procure my singular to-go order at this establishment. On a Thursday evening when the patronage was sparse, this prolonged waiting period was utterly absurd. The culinary offerings were merely adequate, as I have had superior Hawaiian BBQ in the valley for a lower cost. At nearly ten dollars for the entire meal, it was not a worthwhile investment. However, they do provide a smaller, more diminutive portion that would satiate most individuals for lunch.

I like Durant's out of principle, but this is by no means a great restaurant by my estimation. The three separate times I've been were riddled with lackluster service, improperly prepared seafood, and meat with the wrong temperature (medium means medium, right? or has beef fallen into the \"rare is the new medium\" fashion continuum?). \n\nI remain altogether unimpressed. I would, however, hide here if the law was looking for me. It's just that kind of place.

"Although our dining experience at this establishment did not necessarily qualify as unpleasant or subpar, there are undoubtedly superior alternatives in the vicinity for individuals seeking a satisfying culinary excursion, particularly if they wish to concurrently indulge in sports entertainment.  Given the underwhelming nature of our solitary visit, we have opted not to return."

My boss asked for a referral for an interior designer to decorate our new office building so I reached out to the Yelp community and got turned on to Neilsen. I sent all the contact info on to my boss and she was thrilled that I had a referral for her so quickly! Brownie points for me! 

Nosomuch. While Nielsen might be extremely talented, his follow through and time management were less than adequate. He wouldn't return my boss' phone calls without her leaving him several messages, was 2 weeks late turning in his proposal, and would go out of town for weeks at a time without letting her know he was gone....I could go on and on, but really, I don't want to re-live the embarrassment again. 

I know there is the chance that perhaps there were some crossed circuits here, especially since there are so many positive reviews, but honestly, something was amiss with this experience and that's why the low marks (I don't give a lot of low marks normally and it pains me to do so).

I'm not saying don't use this company, because they are probably extremely talented, but I would evaluate the situation you're in before you recommend them to someone so you don't end up in the same predicament I am in.

"It is utterly exasperating when certain luxury hotels fail to provide fundamental amenities such as a refrigerator and microwave in their standard rooms, which are readily available at more affordable establishments like Holiday Inn Express or Comfort Inn, for a fraction of the cost. Furthermore, it is absolutely preposterous to charge guests for WiFi in the year 2011, especially after they have already paid an exorbitant amount for a room that does not live up to its inflated price tag. This is truly an egregious affront to the principles of hospitality. Additionally, the lack of convenient access to nearby attractions, with the exception of a meager convenience store, only serves to further compound the issue. While the room itself was adequately furnished and comfortable, it did not exceed the standards of a typical 3-star hotel."

I recently consumed a grilled cheese sandwich that was utterly devoid of any semblance of culinary expertise, with a solitary slice of cheese haphazardly placed upon the bread, failing to extend its melted tendrils to the edges of the bun, thereby creating an unfortunate visual representation of the lackluster quality of the dish; I must express my profound disappointment at the stark contrast between this uninspired creation and my previous experiences at this establishment, where the fare was not only palatable but indeed tantalizing, leading me to surmise that the current preparation of comestibles within these walls lacks the fervor and dedication that once characterized the culinary endeavors of the kitchen staff.

I must confess that my expectations for Tex-Mex establishments in the Burgh are unyielding, and my perpetual pursuit of an eatery that serves palatable tacos has been consistently frustrated. My gripe with the local taco scene can be distilled to a fundamental misunderstanding of the intrinsic nature of the taco; specifically, the tortilla, which serves as the primary point of contact between the food and the consumer's taste buds, is often overlooked. In my opinion, a freshly crafted tortilla, be it from corn or flour, is the cornerstone of an exceptional taco experience. During my tenure in San Antonio and various regions of Mexico, I had the pleasure of indulging in straightforward yet delectable tacos, sporting minimal toppings and a succulent, fresh tortilla. Unfortunately, Verde appears to prioritize the accompaniments rather than the foundation of the dish, ultimately yielding an unremarkable, mass-produced tortilla that fails to elevate the overall taste experience. Thus, I find myself disheartened by the fact that I must spend $5 on a taco that falls short of my expectations.

"Although I was thoroughly enthused by the extensive array of culinary options presented on the menu, my dining experience was unfortunately marred by several unfortunate incidents. Firstly, the boisterous and intoxicated gathering that entered the establishment subsequent to my seating proved to be an insurmountable challenge for the staff to address, thereby precluding any semblance of tranquility during my meal. Additionally, my one-pound burger arrived with an unacceptably tepid side of french fries, which, despite their ostensible palatability, were rendered relatively flavorless due to their prolonged exposure to ambient temperatures. Furthermore, my accompanying biscuit was egregiously overlooked until I vocally reminded the server of its absence, at which point it was hastily delivered, only to reveal an unfortunate dearth of moisture. Considering my initial enthusiasm for this venue and my desire to sample their morning offerings prior to my departure, I am now faced with a conundrum regarding the wisdom of giving them another chance."

"Indubitably, this establishment appears to have experienced a gradual decline in quality over the passage of time. Despite my initial reluctance, I opted to give it another chance during a recent visit, primarily due to the fact that my customary dining destination, Saigon Noodles, was temporarily unavailable. My primary objective was to procure a bowl of soup, and thus, I placed an order for the Tom Yum variety. Accompanying the soup was a small salad, which, much to my surprise, proved to be remarkably fresh and palatable, although the dressing was excessively sweetened. My daughter elected to sample the chicken satay, which, regrettably, did not closely resemble the traditional peanut-based sauce typically associated with this dish. Rather, it was characterized by an overpowering sweetness, with only a scattering of peanuts evident within the sauce itself. As for my own soup, I must confess that it lacked the customary harmonious blend of sweet and sour flavors that one would reasonably expect from a Tom Yum preparation. Instead, it was decidedly sour in taste, rendering it marginally edible at best. Notwithstanding these shortcomings, the service we received was relatively prompt and courteous. In conclusion, should you find yourself situated on Madison's West Side on a Monday and in urgent need of a soup-based meal, you may wish to consider this restaurant as a viable option, provided you are willing to temper your expectations accordingly. Alternatively, if your preferences lean more toward Vietnamese cuisine, Saigon Noodles remains a superior choice; alternatively, those who absolutely require Thai fare might do well to venture to Ha Long Bay, located on Willie Street."

"As numerous reviewers have previously stated, this establishment masquerades as a luxury hotel while offering amenities and services akin to those of an economic motel.  The shower's water pressure was so excessive that it overflowed, flooding the bathroom floor to ankle depth, and there was no means of regulating the water pressure.  This occurrence was particularly problematic given the current global water scarcity issues. Following the assumption that the shower malfunctioned, I requested a room transfer, only to discover that the subsequent room suffered from the identical issue, leading me to conclude that this was a common phenomenon among guests.  Furthermore, the absence of high-end television channels and the requirement for a wired connection to access the internet in the room, accompanied by an exorbitant fee of $15 for a mere 15 minutes of usage, further contributed to my disappointment.  To exacerbate matters, the customer service was appalling, with staff members displaying an evident reluctance to assist me, exemplified by their tendency to disregard my queries and behave as though I were invisible.  Although suitable for gambling activities, the lodging failed to meet expectations, prompting me to reconsider my decision to stay there. In fact, I have encountered superior hospitality at various budget-friendly motels.  The sole factor preventing me from awarding a single star is the fact that the room was properly sanitized."

If I were at the helm of an M&M store situated on the famed Las Vegas Strip, I would have implemented various innovative and attention-grabbing elements to create an immersive experience for patrons, including but not limited to:  

1. Complimentary samples of the iconic candy to entice passersby and lure them into the establishment.  

2. Life-size, huggable M&M characters strategically positioned throughout the store to engage customers and foster an atmosphere of whimsical delight.  

3. An interactive demonstration showcasing the unique attribute of M&Ms candies, specifically their ability to melt in one's mouth and not in their hands, even in the sweltering heat of the Las Vegas desert climate.  

4. A sleek and modern bar/lounge area, offering an assortment of candy-colored cocktails and specialty beverages, further enhanced by the novel incorporation of M&Ms as a visual element within the drinks themselves.  

5. A collaboration with Cirque du Soleil, featuring acrobats adorned solely in M&M-inspired attire, performing breathtaking feats amidst a visually stunning backdrop, all while maintaining a playful and lighthearted tone consistent with the M&M brand.  

6. High-stakes poker games, presided over by the aforementioned life-size huggable M&M characters, serving as both dealers and ambient decor.  

7. A section dedicated to adult entertainment, catering to diverse preferences and interests, with a subtle integration of M&M-themed elements to maintain a cohesive atmosphere.  

However, it appears that the current management of the M&M store on the Strip has chosen to adopt a different approach, focusing on more traditional merchandising methods, such as offering four levels of M&M-branded products for sale, a 3-D movie experience, and a guided tour, but regrettably omitting complimentary samples, which seemingly contradicts the essence of the M&M brand's playful spirit. This disconnect prompts me to ponder the rationale behind the store's presence on the Las Vegas Strip, as its offerings appear to diverge from the expectations typically associated with this famed destination.

"Four overcooked shrimp on a whole shrimp po boy for 12 dollars?!? It's utterly inconceivable how they could possibly serve such an unimpressive dish without any semblance of embarrassment or shame. The red beans and rice were merely average, lacking the authentic flavor and zest that one would expect from a genuine Cajun culinary experience. As for the gumbo, it was utterly forgettable and unremarkable, devoid of any distinguishing characteristics or nuances that might have made it stand out from the myriad of other lackluster establishments purporting to serve 'authentic' Cajun cuisine. \n\nHowever, it must be acknowledged that the service was somewhat above average, although this fact was ultimately unable to compensate for NOLA's egregious failure to deliver an even remotely passable representation of Cajun cooking. In point of fact, it's highly unlikely that such an establishment would survive for even a brief period of time in New Orleans, where authenticity and richness of flavor are paramount and sacrosanct aspects of the city's culinary tradition."

"Positioned along the continuum of burgers, these offerings can be classified as relatively satisfactory. It is conspicuously superior to the fare offered by McDonald's or Burger King, although I Love Burgers might prefer their experience to be differentiated from that of fast food establishments, and thus, I shall refrain from drawing such comparisons. When evaluated against other upscale burger restaurants, however, I Love Burgers falls short of exceptional standards.

Commencing with the service, a brief delay ensued before securing a table, despite an abundance of unoccupied seats. While it is true that the venue was bustling with activity, a judicious allocation of seating and efficient management of waiting times could have facilitated a more comfortable dining experience. Moreover, the omission of fries from our order, despite their inclusion in the meal, necessitated a request for their delivery, exemplifying a lapse in attentive service.

Regarding the culinary aspects, the burgers, while palatable, fail to transcend mediocrity. My selection, the 'I Love Bacon Burger,' composed of a sirloin and applewood-smoked bacon patty, surmounted by crispy bacon, bacon mayo, gouda, and onion strings, satisfied my hunger, but its unremarkable quality precludes any compelling reason for future visits."

"Having had the experience of patronizing this establishment on three separate occasions, I must confess that my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, and I was left with an impression that the ambiance and quality of service did not justify the premium prices charged. Notwithstanding the fact that the staff demonstrated a commendable level of dedication by remaining open late on a Sunday evening, thereby enabling me to receive a hasty repair of a torn nail prior to a significant dinner engagement, I would not consider visiting this salon as anything other than a last resort in the face of an unforeseen contingency or emergency situation."

"The culinary offerings at this establishment all possessed a subtle yet discernible essence of Italian seasoning, which, while unconventional, was not necessarily appealing to our taste buds. Specifically, the vegetarian enchilada dish was replete with an abundance of zucchini, a fact that was not explicitly indicated on the menu and led to a certain degree of disappointment, as we had been expecting a more diverse array of vegetables such as bell peppers and onions. Furthermore, the absence of these ingredients rendered the dish less palatable for my personal preferences. Notwithstanding the shortcomings in the gastronomic department, the ambiance and hospitality of the venue were quite pleasant."

"It is patently evident that this establishment enjoys immense popularity, as it was teeming with an abundance of clientele during the entire duration of our visit, many of whom appeared to be habitual patrons.  We elected to partake of the vegetarian offerings, and while the seitan appetizer was indeed delectable and generously proportioned, the remainder of the repast was unfortunately lacking in quality. \nThe hospitality we received was somewhat erratic, as our server, though affable, was conspicuously absent, leaving us to fend for ourselves for extended periods, while the remaining staff members seemed overwhelmed and flustered."

"My significant other and I opted to partake in a nocturnal repast at Hash House, whereupon we encountered ambivalent hospitality; specifically, the hostesses exhibited cordiality and warmth, yet their propensity for lingering near the host stand proved somewhat bothersome.  Compelled to select our victuals from the truncated late-night menu, I opted for the grilled cheese sandwich, which, while palatable, suffered from an overabundance of tomato and a meager portion of avocado, rendering its presentation haphazard and challenging to consume.  Our server, Mike, provided adequate, albeit sluggish, attention, requiring approximately fifteen minutes to procure my strawberry lemonade margarita, a beverage that, despite its delayed arrival, proved quite satisfying, if not particularly pricey at eight dollars.  In conclusion, while the evening's culinary excursion yielded mixed results, we harbor hopes for improved service and fare upon our future visits."

"I have vivid recollections of visiting this establishment with my family during our previous excursions to Las Vegas, seeking an affordable and delectable dining experience. Upon perusing the menu, I opted for the half roasted duck, which, while palatable, was diminutive in proportion compared to similar offerings at California's Sam Woos. In addition, I sampled the barbecued pork and chicken rice, which elicited nostalgic sentiments of home cooking, and a medley of seasonal vegetables that were merely sautÃ©ed with garlic and salt, a culinary simplicity that cannot be disparaged. However, the cost of our repast proved to be somewhat prohibitive, amounting to approximately $50, and it is worth mentioning that payment by cash was the sole acceptable method. Notwithstanding these factors, I am inclined to attempt Capital Seafood, situated upstairs, during my subsequent visit."

We revisited the establishment this past weekend to acquire additional white balsamic vinegar, which we deemed to be of exceptional quality, and decided to partake in a meal on this particular occasion. The younger patrons divided a kids' grilled cheese sandwich and expressed satisfaction with their selection. My spouse opted for the antipasto, which she found enjoyable, albeit the portion size was somewhat diminutive for the cost of $12, and the accompanying bread consisted of three baguette slices that lacked both toasting and warming. I chose the Abrequine, advertised as a roast beef panini, but regrettably, this particular sandwich did not come into contact with a panini press; it was modest in size and sorely needed some form of spread to enhance its flavor profile. The potato chips possessed an agreeable crispiness, yet they were also rather oily. The children relished the gelato, and I sampled a portion, finding it pleasant. Additionally, I purchased a bottle of Mexican lime olive oil, but unfortunately, its fragrance and sweetness seemed overly synthetic. My partner approved of the spicy green beans, while the feta-stuffed olives were merely adequate. This excursion qualified as a delightful family outing, suitable for occasional visits, but not necessarily a regular destination.

Because I stayed in Luxor, I ate here because of convenience.  I ate here 3 out of the 4 days.  For the most part, the sandwiches, soups, and salad was pretty good.  It's cafe food yanno?  However, the last day, the  drink server poured too much water in my teapot and when i barely moved it, it swished around and splashed on my leg!  It was so hot that i almost dropped the entire teapot of hot water on my leg but i managed to put it down.  \n\nI was hungover and tired and trying to eat something before I catch my flight out so I didn't complain, I just wanted an icebag so I don't blister.  Now here's the bad service part....i had to ask another waitress to find our waitress, our waitress had to call the manager, the manager had to call security.  When he finally came, i said i just needed a bag of ice.  I should've just took it up with the drink server, told her that she filled up the pot to the absolute brim, and had her get me a bag of ice from the kitchen.  oh well.

I have had the privilege of visiting this establishment on three separate occasions, with the most recent visit being motivated by my desire to sample their taco offering, thereby enabling me to provide a comprehensive assessment of the restaurant's culinary prowess.  Upon ordering, I was somewhat dismayed to discover that the taco in question was rather diminutive in stature, measuring a mere 3-4 inches in length, and lacking the crispy shell option which I had been anticipating.  Notwithstanding this initial disappointment, I must admit that the shredded beef utilized in the taco's composition was indeed of superior quality; however, considering the paltry sum of $2 requested in exchange for this item, I cannot help but feel that its value was not entirely commensurate with its cost.  During a subsequent visit, I opted to sample the fried fish dish, and I must confess that the end result was utterly unsatisfactory.  The fish itself was presented in an unfilleted state, with only half of the meat remaining attached to the bone, and the method of preparation employed seemed to consist merely of placing the fish in a fryer, sans any semblance of finesse or attention to detail.  Furthermore, the ambiance of the restaurant struck me as decidedly juvenile and aesthetically unpleasing, with certain aspects of the dÃ©cor bordering on the offensive.  In conclusion, while the service at this establishment may be deemed passable, the prices charged are hardly reasonable, and the cuisine, with a few notable exceptions, falls short of expectations.

Can't comment about too much yet , but one thing that bugs me is certain things at the school must be paid for online at the schools website, seems that they want the parents money so badly that all your information is there,all they need is your credit card number.They also charge a 90 cent fee to pay online,but you can only pay online,WTF?who gets this fee?if it's a convenience fee,I'd just send 15 bucks to the school,but you can only pay online so if the extort .90 per paying parent,sure it adds up.

Visiting Phoenix and cognizant of the effusive acclaim bestowed upon this establishment, we opted to experience its offerings en route to our lodging. Arriving promptly at 8:30 PM on a Friday evening, we encountered merely a single couple preceding us, thereby ensuring a relatively expedient service.

However, upon entering the premises, we were immediately acknowledged by a lone staff member, fostering an impression that a definitive knowledge of our preferences was expected at the onset. The sole employee tasked with attending to our needs exhibited a reserved demeanor, potentially attributed to the culmination of a protracted work shift or other factors.

In regards to the frozen delights, my spouse selected the TC^2 and salted caramel flavors, while I opted for the almond buttercrunch and apple cinnamon varieties. Additionally, I sampled the honey blue cheese and sugar and spice options. Unfortunately, the almond buttercrunch failed to showcase a discernible almond essence, although the remaining flavors proved satisfactory. Notably, the texture presented a rather icy consistency, lacking the anticipated creaminess, given the extensive praise surrounding this venue.

The pricing, however, proved reasonable and, if seeking unique ice cream flavors at a fair cost within close proximity, a visit may be warranted. Nonetheless, based on our personal preferences, augmented by exposure to exceptional ice cream in the San Francisco Bay Area, we departed feeling unimpressed. Ultimately, our experience at this establishment fell short of our expectations.

"My sentiments regarding this establishment are rather unremarkable, to put it mildly. As an ardent advocate for small businesses, my expectations were unfortunately not met. While Sonic boasts superior flavored hotdogs and buns, their lemonade, regrettably, leaves much to be desired. Specifically, the'special' variety, purportedly rendered unavailable due to a malfunctioning machine, was nothing short of revolting - overly diluted and lacking any semblance of flavor. Suffice it to say that, after numerous occasions of driving past this eatery, my recent experience has solidified my decision to never patronize this business again."

"The culinary experience was satisfactory, and the ambiance was engaging; however, upon consuming a single draught of my beverage, I detected an unpleasant metallic flavor and subsequently discovered an unsettling crunch between my molars. Upon further inspection, it became apparent that the beer contained shattered fragments of glass, which understandably elicited my indignation. Despite my attempts to bring this issue to the attention of the manager, he displayed a dismissive demeanor and implied that I was being dishonest, citing the lack of visible damage to the container as evidence. Notwithstanding the replacement of the contaminated bottle, no additional measures were taken to address the unfortunate situation or alleviate my discomfort."

If not for the delicious turkey crepe and cookies I would have given this one star. The service was horrible, the decor obnoxious and the cupcake desserts were, I kid you not,  4/5th icing (seriously gross).  Our waitress was no newbie, but maybe she had too many tables, maybe she wasn't too bright or maybe she was just so slow that she couldn't recall the order by the time she got to the computer. She totally forgot our appetizer and I appreciate the fact that she owned up to it twenty minutes later.  By the time our food finally arrived, the pasta was cold, but we were so hungry we didn't send it back.  Stick to the carry out desserts.

"I profoundly detest the subpar quality of the tint applied to my automobile. In contrast to my previous vehicle, which was tinted several years ago and effectively mitigated the temperature inside to a relatively comfortable level, my current car's tint has failed to provide any discernible difference in terms of heat reduction. Despite opting for an identical shade of tint, my vehicle remains unbearably hot on a daily basis, rendering the substantial financial investment utterly futile. My dissatisfaction with this situation is exacerbated by the notion that the tint might as well be non-existent, thereby nullifying its intended purpose and rendering the entire endeavor a colossal waste of resources."

"The Flamingo exemplifies a bygone era in Las Vegas's history, serving as a tangible reminder of the city's rich heritage.
