Despite its venerable age, the hotel has managed to maintain its relevance, albeit in a somewhat anachronistic manner. While it may lack the glitz and glamour associated with contemporary Vegas establishments, the Flamingo's understated charm remains an enduring draw for those seeking a respite from the city's frenetic energy. Notwithstanding its relative dearth of modern amenities, the hotel's guestrooms are functional and comfortable, although some may find the absence of reliable cell phone reception in certain pool-facing accommodations to be inconvenient. Regardless, the Flamingo's proximity to other prominent Strip hotels renders it an ideal base for exploring the city's myriad attractions on foot."

"This hotel's offerings fail to surpass mediocrity, with accommodations that exhibit visible signs of deterioration and a staff whose level of assistance is comparable to that of a typical government agency, such as the Department of Motor Vehicles. It appears that the employees opt to perform their duties, but any notion of providing aid or support beyond the bare minimum is nonexistent. The establishment's overall quality has significantly declined over the past decade and a half, rendering it unsuitable for any purpose other than serving as a venue for a conference, which was the sole reason for my temporary residency. I shall not return."

This has been my all time favorite restaurant anywhere for years, since I lived here in very early 2000s, but this time it was a disappointment.

They didn't have the usual Cuban Bread on the menu but they said they could make it anyway... but it wasn't at all the same.  They used a different bread that was way too thick and not even toasted.

I got the bacon and cheese burger but the burger wasn't very good, I didn't finish it.  The fries were just blah.

Smoothie King is like a broke Jamba Juice! When I came here it was packed with loads of people and the staff here are far from good customer service. The way it is set up makes no sense what so ever. When it was time to pay the guy ringing us up got our order wrong and wanted me to $18.00 for two smoothies..overall smoothies were good but don't think i would go back ever again.

"I visited this establishment for a midday repast. My culinary selection was the Massaman curry, which I requested sans tomato due to my unfamiliarity with such an ingredient in this particular dish. 

I opted for a moderate level of spiciness, but unfortunately, the flavor was rather insipid. Although the dish contained an ample amount of poultry, the vegetable component was conspicuously lacking. A more equilibrium would have been appreciated. 

The broth and spring roll that accompanied the meal were merely adequate. 

To my dismay, the peanuts in the Massaman curry were uncooked. Considering my extensive experience with this dish, I had specifically requested additional peanuts, anticipating the customary cooked variety. The raw peanuts were a considerable disappointment. 

Should you have the opportunity to visit Chanpen Thai Cuisine, located a short distance away, I would highly recommend doing so. The quality of their cuisine is significantly superior. 

While the prices at this establishment were reasonable and the service was satisfactory, there are superior Thai dining options in the vicinity, particularly for those seeking a hasty meal."

Had a decent enough experience buying the car, but the service department was another story when I went to get my accessories installed.  They forgot to tighten a hose after a routine install, and my car died while merging onto the freeway immediately afterwards, putting me into a dangerous position.  I was not offered any kind of compensation for my time since I live an hour away and had to make a second trip, the inconvenience, or the danger they put me in due to their complete negligence.  Not even an apology.   This doesn't bode well for my trust in their mechanics.

Quite expensive for such a small bowl of food that isn't all that great. I had the Dan Dan noodles ($12 + tax/tip). The spice from the sauce overpowered the shrimp and the noodles -- I could barely taste them! You can get better Asian food in the strip, but if you're stuck at the Venetian, this is your best bet for something quick.

If I had to encapsulate my dining experience in a mere two phrases, it would be: unconventional morning repast. I initiated the meal with a kugel and strawberry amalgamation, based on a fellow Yelp user's endorsement, and devoured nearly the entirety of it! I would unquestionably recommend it or present it to guests at a leisurely breakfast gathering. Delightful. The matzo soup possessed an acceptable flavor, although it appeared to be enveloped by canned chicken noodle soup (Ã  la Campbell's), which slightly diminished its appeal. The main course consisted of holishkes, which were bland cabbage rolls accompanied by a chunky marinara sauce. The sides seemed to be randomly selected and lacked coherence, while the portion sizes were excessively generous. My offspring requested the children's macaroni and cheese, complemented by a minuscule container of applesauce. The hospitality staff exhibited kindness and adaptability. Although Sunday evening was remarkably tranquil, it can become overwhelming and oppressive during peak hours. In the future, I shall adhere to my preferred dish, specifically the open-faced tuna melt, which is an unfailing option. The menus are truly comical; after years of familiarity, I have become proficient in navigating them with celerity, but a drastic renovation Ã  la Restaurant Impossible would significantly enhance the overall dining experience. A streamlined menu showcasing skillfully prepared dishes, complemented by a selection of artisanal ice cream, would yield an instantaneous positive effect. Furthermore, refurbished, modernized, and functional decor would greatly revitalize this establishment. Despite this, we shall persist in visiting this restaurant, and such improvements would render our experiences even more enjoyable. I genuinely wish success for Ella's!

I have had the dubious pleasure of visiting this establishment on two separate occasions, and I must say that my experiences have been less than satisfactory. During my initial visit, I opted to situate myself at the bar and indulge in a few alcoholic beverages accompanied by a serving of nachos. While the service provided by the bartender was relatively prompt and amicable, the quality of the nachos left much to be desired, falling squarely within the realm of mediocrity.  
Upon my return, I was unfortunately subjected to an utterly disappointing dining experience. Our server, a veritable space cadet, displayed a complete lack of attentiveness and competence. Following a prolonged wait, she finally arrived with our water, only to disappear for extended periods of time, reappearing at irregular intervals to check on our progress. Furthermore, her ignorance regarding our beer order was nothing short of astounding. The food we received, arriving tardily, was also unimpressive, with the temperature being rather chilly, rendering it utterly unpalatable.  
It is worth noting that the same group of regular patrons was present during both my visits, their boisterous behavior and visible intoxication detracting from the already unpleasant ambiance. In light of these experiences, I would strongly advise against frequenting this establishment, instead opting for one of the numerous alternative bars in the vicinity.

I am not a big fan of seafood so it takes a lot to win me over.

I tried several of the dishes at Original Fish Market including the lobster bisque, the halibut, and the pork-chop with coleslaw.  The lobster bisque was bland and cold.  The halibut was decent.  The pork chop was so bitter and dry.

The whole atmosphere of the place seemed standoff-ish and was not friendly.  Furthermore, it took forever just to get our waitress's attention.  When we finally got her to look our way, she was short with us.  It was as if we bothered her.  I would rather go get sushi than spend more money here.

We opted to utilize a Groupon for our special day on November 11th, as we desired to indulge in a delectable dining experience without breaking the bank. Unfortunately, our first choice, Texas, was fully booked, prompting us to consider alternative options in the vicinity of our humble abode. Upon perusing the menu at this particular establishment, we were disappointed to discover that the salad bar appeared unimpressive, with a meager selection of ingredients that seemed to have been sitting out for an extended period. This was in stark contrast to our previous experiences at Texas and Via, where the quality and presentation of the food were vastly superior. When my spouse requested that his meat be cooked to a higher degree of doneness, the kitchen staff kindly acquiesced to his request, yet the end result was still somewhat undercooked. Furthermore, when we inquired about procuring a carbonated beverage, we were taken aback by the presentation of a can accompanied by a glass of ice, which seemed incongruous with the otherwise hospitable ambiance of the restaurant. While the selection of meats was limited, the quality was passable, albeit unremarkable. Upon receiving the bill, we were taken aback by the exorbitant price of $3 for a single can of Coca-Cola, which seemed excessive given the parity in pricing among similar eateries in the area. Consequently, we have decided to venture forth to either Via or Texas for future culinary excursions, as their offerings better align with our refined tastes and expectations.

"Culinary delights are satisfactory, yet the quality of service is deplorable. On two separate occasions, we experienced considerable delays in receiving attention from the servers, who appeared indifferent to our presence and failed to exhibit adequate attentiveness in addressing our needs. Moreover, the prolonged waiting period resulted in the dissatisfying experience of having our dim sum conclude before we could savor its full flavor. In light of these circumstances, it is our recommendation that patrons seek alternative dining options, such as Chang's on Decatur, where the cost-benefit ratio is more favorable and the quality of service is superior. We strongly advise against visiting this establishment, as the prices are exorbitant and the culinary offerings fall short of expectations."

Thank you, Groupon, for your financial benevolence, as this establishment does not warrant the price of admission. Having been raised in Seattle, I have always been fascinated by marine life and aquatic environments, and thus, I typically visit aquariums while traveling to observe and learn about diverse regional sea creatures. However, my expectations were not met here, as Phoenix, being a desert region, has limited aquatic offerings, and I should have been more discerning in my selection. Nonetheless, the novelty of this recently opened attraction and the advantageous ticket prices persuaded me to give it a chance. Upon entering, I was dismayed by the diminutive size of the tanks and the overcrowding of visitors in such tight spaces, which made for an unpleasant experience. Additionally, the brief lectures provided were futile due to the throngs of people, rendering it impossible to fully appreciate the exhibits. One tank, boasting a secondary upper level for observation, offered the most satisfactory view in the entire facility. In conclusion, I strongly advise potential visitors to journey to a coastal city in California and explore a genuine aquarium, thereby ensuring a worthwhile investment of their time and resources. Alternatively, they could opt for a more economical and convenient option, such as purchasing a relevant DVD.

First of all, I REALLY want to like JJ's. They have a great concept, a cool and clever menu, and a good atmosphere. They seem to be really involved in the community and use and sell a lot of local products (Local Beer, King of Pops, etc.) 

We have been 3 times now, and really just find it to be sub-par for our expectations. We have tried various dogs and sandwiches. Most recently, we both had the "signature dog" with Chili, onions, beans, bacon, jalapeños and mustard. We found the Chili and beans to be lacking in any flavor whatsoever. The bun and hot dog were high quality, and the hot dog gave that nice "snap" when you bit in. Despite all of those delicious sounding ingredients, we found it to be a bit pedestrian. 


We also split a side of onion rings, which were greasy and flavorless. We each took a bite and decided to throw the rest away. 

Overall, just disappointed.  I hope in time, JJ's becomes the Charlotte institution that it could be.

"The Excalibur Roundtable buffet elicited a sense of familiarity akin to that of a cafeteria-style eatery, which served as the backdrop for my critical assessment of its offerings, specifically pertaining to the morning repast. Frugality being a virtue, we opted to capitalize on a dual-benefit coupon, thereby reducing the tariff to a mere $9 per person. 

My consternation regarding the edibles was rooted in their lackluster quality, as they exhibited an unfortunate tendency towards desiccation and an unpleasant soddenness. The culinary selections, encompassing the customary breakfast items, were regrettably devoid of freshness. Such deficiencies precluded me from partaking in additional helpings. A dedicated area showcasing sweet treats, including pastries and donuts, proved underwhelming, inspiring a dismissive attitude. 

A silver lining emerged in the form of our server, whose endearing efforts to elicit mirth proved successful. 

In response to a remark posted below, it is indeed true that large-scale food production does not inherently imply mediocrity. Numerous buffets excel in providing exceptional cuisine. It is advisable to explore such establishments and avoid this particular venue."

Had an issue returning an item I got for Christmas. The same one was sitting on the shelf and they wouldnt give me in store credit because the tag was missing. Um....... it was a Christmas gift...... people tend to take the price tags off. \n\nThey're only getting two stars because VS Customer Service (called them) fixed my issue. Big applause for Corporate Customer Relations on the issue.

This was sad sad place. Even being the weekend the place didn't have many patrons. Maybe it was one of those off weekends but since were told that we are on the guest list and thus won't have to pay any cover so we said why not. Went in and saw some go go dancers but that just about it. We had a beer and after  that bolted out of there in less than 30 minutes.

*bed bugs* Stayed here for a conference this week. The place is big and they seem to have nice pools and lounge areas, however, our room smelled bad... Like musty and also like smoke. I really was unhappy with the smell. My girlfriends and I stayed in two separate rooms. After the first night one of my gf's woke up with 6-7 bites and was left uncomfortable and itching the entire trip. The second night of our stay ( i was staying in a different room) I was also bit! I went to sleep fine and woke up with two bites on my ankles. Just a side note, we never had the doors open and we were in two separate rooms.  We both sleep with the blankets covering us as well so I have determined that this is most likely a bed bug issue. My last night I was bit again twice and now I'm home and happy to be here. I am frustrated though that I am itching like crazy, just felt dirty yuck! I gave two stars because the facility is nice, but I don't think getting bit is acceptable.

First and foremost, it is imperative to acknowledge that this particular establishment is not a traditional Costco, but rather a specialized "business center." This distinction is crucial, as it significantly impacts the products and services offered, and thus, it is essential to emphasize this point to avoid any potential disappointment or confusion among patrons.  

In light of this, it is relevant to highlight that this specific Costco does not sell alcoholic beverages, which may come as a surprise to some individuals who are accustomed to purchasing such items at other Costco locations. Furthermore, there is no food court available on the premises, which may also be a departure from the typical Costco experience that some customers are familiar with. However, it is worth noting that this absence is compensated by the abundance of exceptional dining options and buffets in the surrounding area, which can easily satisfy any culinary cravings.  

This particular Costco focuses primarily on providing an extensive selection of snacks and beverages, intended for the purpose of restocking vending machines. In fact, they even offer vending machines for purchase, which speaks to the unique nature of this business-oriented store. One redeeming quality of this establishment is the diverse array of beverages available, ranging from juices, sodas, sparkling water, cider, and more, which is undoubtedly impressive.  

Unfortunately, this Costco falls short in terms of staffing, with relatively few employees present, and those who are on duty often appear uninformed about various aspects of the store's operations. For instance, upon inquiring about the availability of coupon books, a staff member incorrectly directed me to the guest/member service desk, only to discover that they do not, in fact, accept coupons at this location.  

In conclusion, given the distinct characteristics of this Costco "business center," it is advisable to carefully consider one's shopping needs before visiting, and perhaps opt for a different location, such as the Costco in Los Angeles, before embarking on a trip to Las Vegas.

"What an exasperating experience!"

Best aspect of today's midday repast was the hospitality - Anthony, a native of Astoria, Queens, New York City, who has been resident here for eight months, possessed a dialect that was reminiscent of his origins, which was utterly fitting given his occupation as a server in an Italian eatery!  His demeanor was helpful, attentive, interactive, and one of the most exceptional examples of fine service I have encountered within this metropolis.  Moreover, he presented a sample of the soup du jour for our perusal before we placed our orders.  Exceptional hospitality indeed - bravo, Anthony!

The comestibles, however, garnered decidedly mixed critiques.  The tilapia special was devoured with relish by both individuals at our table who opted for it.  Culinary staff, please take note: the portions varied conspicuously between the two plates, despite the fact that the lesser quantity happened to be consumed by the individual who customarily indulges in less food; thus, it did not pose a problem.  When identical dishes are concurrently presented to two patrons seated at the same table, it is imperative that the plates appear identical!

I initiated my repast with the minestrone soup (a staple offering on the menu), and although its flavor was palatable, it was served at a disappointingly tepid temperature.  This elicited a feeling of melancholy.  Furthermore, my meatball sandwich was somewhat lacking in warmth and excessively salty.  Alas, it failed to possess the freshness I had anticipated.

Notwithstanding these shortcomings, the concluding segment of our meal, comprising lemon cookies adorned with two striking candles, served as a pleasant conclusion to our dining experience.  Moreover, the cookies themselves were delectable - possessing an adequate degree of sweetness, a discernible lemon essence without being overpowering, and sufficient sufficiency to facilitate sharing among the assemblage at our table.

A notice posted on the entrance indicates that as of February 1st, this establishment will adopt a smoke-free policy.

--lost its traditional feel through the remodel. where has the personality gone?
--bulky dark wooden chairs need cushions, the whole place needs more fabric. great potential with lots of light and high ceilings. More bright mexican ceramics please. stark wall of crosses and exposed wood and wrought iron takes me straight to Nathan Lane's Birdcage apartment. LOL.
--remodel great for small (150ppl) wedding parties with dance floor in the center of the room.

--rice dry and unflavorful, no savor. beans again with no flavor.
--table salsa is canned tomato sauce with pepper seeds and BASIL and the touch of sugar you get from Ragu! It's salsa, not marinara, people!
--guacamole has cottage cheese as a thickener! ew!
--chili colorado is just thick, no flavor.
--service is slow and unhelpful, but prices are high high.
--$9 for the cheese crisp is worth it. great crispiness and good cheese blend.

"Having opted to lodge at the Sunset Station, which, incidentally, surpassed my expectations considerably, I found myself unaccompanied during the evening hours, as Gus had arranged to convene with several acquaintances for dinner. In light of this, I chose to procure sustenance and transport it to my lodgings, and, after perambulating the vicinity a couple of times, I settled upon Fatburger as my culinary destination.

Upon entering the establishment, I encountered a youthful female who demonstrated considerable amiability towards each patron, taking my order with alacrity and assuring me that the onion rings, as indicated by the signage, were indeed of superior quality. Thus, I opted to sample both the burger and the aforementioned onion rings, in addition to a shake, out of curiosity regarding the veracity of the sign's claim.

However, upon receiving my order in a remarkably brief span of time, I was thoroughly dismayed to discover that the burger was an unpalatable, amorphous mass, devoid of any discernible flavors, and the onion rings, unfortunately, lacked even a modicum of zest. The shake, while not utterly devoid of taste, failed to impress me profoundly.

Subsequently, the recollection of this experience resurfaced when the suggestion to visit a Fatburger was broached, prompting an involuntary shudder and a fervent resolve to avoid such an establishment in the future."

Not what I expected.  Food was good, but nothing special.  Portions seemed small.  I really did not expect the stand in line to place your order, go find a seat and wait for someone to bring your food, and then you never get spoken to again. Reminds me of McDonalds.  We got Thai Dynamite, which sounds spicy, but was bland, and sesame chicken, which was so so.\nWhile we were there, we saw someone spill a large amount of salt or sugar on the floor right by a door.  Saw a server going out the door about fall, and then 4 employees walk by it before it got cleaned up around 5-10 minutes later.  Lawsuit waiting to happen.\nDon't think we'll go back :(

I came to check this place out because it had four stars on yelp and my boyfriend and I were in the mood for Mexican food. I ordered the green chili plate and my boyfriend got the carne asada burrito and we shared the menudo. I was expecting the food taste more authentic but when we got our food, it was bland and not very tasteful. We felt like we could have just gone to Filerberto and got better food. The only thing good about this place was our food came out fast and the person who took our order was nice. Other then that, I will not be coming back to eat here. We left very unsatisfied!

"Prior to our arrival, I articulated to my companion that we should brief respite from our culinary excursion, but alas, we opted to persevere. Upon ingress, the eatery appeared tidy and welcoming; however, our server, though industrious, was the sole representative of hospitality during the luncheon hour. My culinary selection, a fish burrito, materialized approximately fifteen minutes subsequent to our order placement. Alas, it proved to be an unfortunate choice, as the dish contained scant vegetation, mediocre rice, and a breaded, fried fish fillet reminiscent of a shoe sole. In point of fact, I have previously enjoyed a superior fish burrito at Del-Taco, situated directly across the street. My comrade's chicken sizzling fajita, while promptly delivered and emitting an appetizing aroma, regrettably lacked gastronomical depth and featured undercooked rice and a venerable salad as accompaniments. Notwithstanding, the accompanying guacamole and sour cream were fresh. It is worth mentioning that the establishment's salsa exhibited commendable flavor, striking a satisfactory balance between piquancy and palatability. Thus, if seeking merely a snack of chips and salsa accompanied by a brew, this locality may suffice. Nevertheless, a visit to this restaurant for a fulfilling dining experience is not recommended."

"Our culinary excursion at this esteemed establishment involved indulging in their signature Tomahawk steak, priced at an impressive $98, accompanied by the delectable Glazed Sea Bass, available for $39. Furthermore, we opted for the verdant asparagus as a side dish, costing $14, and hand-cut fries, valued at $12. While our gastronomical inclinations lean towards flavors that are subtly piquant, the fare presented at this venue possessed an excessive sodium content, potentially posing a concern for cardiovascular health. Nonetheless, the ambiance of the restaurant exuded an air of refined sophistication, rendering it a truly unique experience. Additionally, the restrooms were noteworthy for their unconventional design."

Love the clothes,hate the staff! I'm sorry but something goes wrong every single time I come here. Today, brought 5 items to the counter, came home with 4. And that was from the kiddy mgr who had to take over because the rest had never seen a check before. After his 10 minutes of flubbing and absolutely ignoring anything I asked him he finally rang it up. Grrrr I hate having to go back.

"The prices for the services offered by this establishment are reasonable, however, the duration of time allocated for the cleaning process, specifically pertaining to the washing and vacuuming of my vehicle, is somewhat excessive, amounting to a total of 45 minutes, which raises some reservations regarding the efficiency of the service, thus leaving me uncertain about the prospect of becoming a repeat customer."
Average food.  Great concept and enjoyed my first visit.  However, the only really good item is the Red Jade Chicken.
Very slow -- even without a lot of customers -- and very disorganized. You can't pay with the Starbucks app -- they have to take your phone and key in the number by hand!

I arrived at this establishment in the company of my parental units prior to attending a performance of Zumanity, primarily due to the fact that it did not possess a waiting period. In retrospect, it would have been more judicious to await a brief interval before being seated elsewhere.

BEVERAGES:
I requested a glass of Sangiovese, a wine that I typically relish. However, on this particular occasion, I did not even desire to complete the consumption of the beverage. My maternal figure acquired a mixed drink infused with limoncello, which was not particularly unpleasant.

OVERALL: B

CULINARY OFFERINGS:
I opted for a bowl of soup and a specialized salad, consisting of cucumbers, "fresh" tomatoes, onions, red vinaigrette, and feta. Unfortunately, the salad was rather unpalatable. Initially, I presumed it contained marinated tomatoes, but upon further inspection, I deduced that it had simply been stored in a refrigerated state for an extended duration, as the tomatoes were unpleasantly cold. I merely picked at it without consuming it.
My maternal figure chose the rare veal, priced at over $30, yet she, too, barely partook of it, owing to the fact that it was excessively marinated, resulting in a lingering vinegar flavor. As an individual who greatly enjoys the consumption of red meat, even I did not find it appealing, thereby indicating that my maternal figure was not simply being fastidious.

OVERALL: D

SERVICE:
Our server did not inquire about our satisfaction with the meal until we had nearly completed consuming it, approximately thirty minutes later. Upon recognizing our discontent with the cuisine, she summoned one of her supervisors, who extended an offer to provide us with an alternative dish. Given that we lacked sufficient time to sample another offering, they elected not to charge us for either the salad or the veal.

OVERALL: C

"The culinary offerings were merely adequate, while the service provided by our server was utterly subpar. In our group of four individuals, three of us enjoyed reasonably satisfying repasts, whereas my son's Philly cheesesteak dish was unfortunately a saturated disaster. We pondered returning it, but the server's absence and subsequent lackadaisical approach to her duties rendered that option moot. Upon her return, she displayed a complete lack of interest in her profession, mechanicaly going through the motions with an air of indifference. My son requested water, which she neglected to provide... I shall not patronize this establishment again during future visits to Las Vegas."

Slow service and 15-20 for mediocre philly cheese steaks.  Sandwiches and fries do not have a lot of flavor.  Also the televisions are blaring loud, if you have sensitive hearing beware.  Seating is limited.

"Avenue Q was utterly captivating; nevertheless, it is imperative to acknowledge that the production features a touring cast. Furthermore, my experience at the Gammage Auditorium was less than satisfactory, particularly in terms of accessibility. While the exterior appearance may be visually appealing, albeit with some broken light fixtures, the interior design leaves much to be desired in terms of modernity and functionality. Specifically, the facilities for people with disabilities are woefully inadequate, rendering it challenging for individuals with mobility impairments to fully participate in the theatrical experience. Upon inquiring about the location of the elevator, I received a brusque response informing me that none existed, and that accessible seating options were only available at a premium price point. As someone who walks with a cane and experiences fatigue easily, navigating multiple flights of stairs proved to be an arduous task that left me feeling distressed and marginalized. Moreover, the lack of empathy displayed by staff members towards my plight only exacerbated my frustration. It is unfortunate that a venue hosting a satirical examination of prejudice would itself perpetuate ableism and classism through its architecture and customer service."

"Experienced a protracted period of one hour's duration in anticipation of consuming culinary offerings, only to be let down by the quality of the fare. Specifically, had the misfortune of sampling banana pancakes and a breakfast skillet, with the former exhibiting an unpleasant texture reminiscent of rubber and the latter devoid of any discernible flavor."

"Mid Town Pub has been a regular haunt of mine, but due to recent events, I will be compelled to seek an alternative venue. On a previous occasion, I requested the chicken cordon bleu sandwich, but what I received was a culinary abomination; a dish consisting of chicken smothered in an excessive amount of jalapeÃ±os. Upon bringing this to the attention of the server, they hastily replaced it with a similar dish, albeit devoid of the aforementioned jalapeÃ±os, but regrettably, the poultry was still infused with an overpowering essence of said peppers. I did not partake in its consumption, yet I was still charged for it. 

Despite this unfortunate experience, I opted to grant the kitchen a second chance during a subsequent visit. Unfortunately, the sandwich I was presented with was equally inedible. The bread was saturated with an excess of salt and pepper, rendering the initial bite an utter disappointment. 

It appears that this kitchen requires some semblance of direction and refinement. Farewell, Mid Town Pub."

During our brief sojourn at this establishment, my spouse and I had the pleasure of occupying a luxurious suite that offered a panoramic view of the interior courtyard. Unfortunately, our stay was marred by the cacophony generated by the delivery trucks and tour buses that converged on the premises at an ungodly hour, creating a racket that was nothing short of deafening. Moreover, we were dismayed to discover that the suite was bereft of even the most basic utensils, including spoons and bottle openers, which made it challenging to enjoy our complimentary continental breakfast. However, the piece de resistance was the nightly happy hour that took place in the expansive breakfast room from 5:30 pm to 7:30 pm, during which time complimentary cocktails and light beer were served to a motley crew of mostly elderly patrons who seemed to be taking advantage of the libations to medicate themselves for the evening ahead. The scene was both amusing and surreal, as my wife and I observed the throngs of seniors shuffling around the pool table with their tiny plastic cups of cocktails or light beer, creating an atmosphere that resembled a nursing home on steroids.

I agree with another reviewer that it is a well intentioned concept.  Decor and atmosphere was, clean, comfortable and inviting.  Service wasn't great, but was OK.  If the food was better I would plan a return trip, but it was unfortunately not good.

We are gluten free family so we were excited to hear that they had many GF options for us.  Ordered the Vegetarian Antipasto, Flat bread Trio, Chicken Caesar Salad, and 2 pizzas.  All GF versions.  It was disappointing.  GF crust and flat bread was hard and tasteless.  My GF homemade pizza crust and packaged versions I get from Whole Foods were 100 times better.  Sauce on the pizza was too sweet.  The salad was drowning in dressing, Antipasto was also tasteless,  Flat bread was not good and the dips were mediocre.  

So bummed that it wasn't better.  Hoping to check back in on Yelp and see and improvement and maybe we'll give it another shot.  Would really like to see more "healthy" and organic restaurants in Henderson.

i'm a vegetarian and was really looking forward to this highly recommended place. i'm immediately turned off that they serve actual real meat in a vegan restaurant. I will say that my unsweetened ice tea mixed with mango lemonade (mixed by myself) was delicious. the side salad with my pannini was excellent!!! pannini was DISGUSTING i could have made a to-furky pannini at home thank you. the highly recommended red velvet was very good for being 150 calories and 5 grams of fat. very disappointed :( service was SO SLOW and it was only us and two other tables....slow food +bad service = me no going again :( sadly! i was really excited

"The server who attended to our table exhibited a deplorable level of service, rendering the dining experience utterly unpleasant. In stark contrast, the busboy demonstrated a markedly superior level of attentiveness, providing us with a semblance of hospitable care. It is my conviction that the busboy would be better suited to fulfill the responsibilities of the server, as his proficiency in catering to our needs was palpably evident. While the culinary offerings were merely adequate and not particularly remarkable, it is indubitable that the prices charged for them were excessive, considering the mediocre quality of the fare and the absence of any truly exceptional features. However, it is conceivable that the ambiance of the establishment was intended to compensate for the deficiencies in the food and service, thereby warranting the elevated cost."

"The culinary experience was flawless, the atmosphere was captivating, yet, the hospitality was utterly disappointing. Upon arriving at the eatery, the hostess displayed an evident lack of interest, almost as if her prolonged tenure had led to a profound sense of apathy. We were informed that our table was in the process of being arranged, and, presumably, the cutlery was imports from China, as we waited for an unreasonable duration of thirty minutes. Subsequently, our server proved to be equally inadequate, taking twenty minutes to present us with menus and another twenty minutes to collect our beverage orders and food selections, giving us a clear indication of their sluggish pace. It took yet another twenty minutes for half of our party to receive their beverages. We were compelled to actively seek out our server to obtain round two drinks, which, predictably, required an additional twenty minutes. At the beginning of the evening, our server had boasted that Vintner offered Strip-quality cuisine off the Strip. Unfortunately, the quality of the service did not live up to the standards typically associated with the Strip, rendering the overall dining experience a disappointment. Despite the delectable fare and enchanting ambiance, the subpar service left much to be desired. Therefore, I would not advocate for this establishment."

"My initial acquaintance with Buffalo Exchange transpired subsequent to my return from Santa Barbara, and my profound disappointment at having missed the opportunity to visit the store was palpable. Upon discovering the presence of a branch in Las Vegas, my expectations were elevated, as I anticipated securing high-quality, pre-owned designer items at reasonable prices. However, upon entering the establishment, my hopes were promptly dashed, as the atmosphere and inventory bore an uncanny resemblance to Plato's Closet, a business I have previously expressed disdain for. The abundance of undesirable attire and the apathetic demeanor of the staff left me feeling underwhelmed and disinclined to peruse the merchandise further. After a cursory examination of the premises, I concluded that it was not worthwhile to expend time and effort at any of their locations."

We were meandering along the strip with a couple of acquaintances when we chanced upon this establishment. Our attention was drawn to its boisterous ambiance, with the music being quite captivating. Although we had no intention of halting, a companion opted to acquire some beverages from their bar due to the reasonable price of two for the price of one. As we awaited his return, one of the gentlemen stationed outside endeavored to entice us to enter for a fee of $15 per individual, which we respectfully declined. We continued to move away, only to have him pursue us and offer a reduced price of $10 each. We maintained our stance and continued to depart, leading him to approach us once more and propose an entry fee of $5 apiece. We remained steadfast in our decision and eventually gained admittance gratis following a brief negotiation. Upon entering, we lingered for approximately half an hour to an hour, during which time we appreciated the vigorous atmosphere and melodious tunes, while finding the beverages to be reasonably priced. However, our experience was somewhat marred by the unremarkable quality of the female patrons and the presence of males who exhibited characteristics commonly associated with fraternity members who had been expelled from their respective organizations. Consequently, we elected to vacate the premises, and I personally would not consider returning.
3 measly chicken fingers on a pile of soggy fries. How do you mess up chicken fingers?! 9 bucks...no thank you.

I recently underwent a comprehensive examination of my vehicle's mechanical condition, accompanied by a routine maintenance procedure involving the replacement of lubricants, and I must say that the experience left much to be desired in terms of the quality of service provided by the sole individual responsible for attending to my automotive needs. His manner of communication, characterized by a remarkable lack of articulacy and an unfortunate tendency towards primitive, grunted utterances, did little to inspire confidence in his abilities or foster a sense of trust between us. Suffice it to say that I shall not be returning to this particular establishment for any future automotive requirements.

There is absolutely no reason to dine here for Mexican food....it is non descript...no pride in preparation or presentation.  It is just bland food.  Service is very good but that does not make up for bad food....from the chips to the finale'....bad...and very noisy with screaming and misbehaving children.\n\nTry Lindo Michoac\u00e1n on Desert Inn...is was good but hope we can even find one that is better...it is an easy 3 star

"I eagerly anticipated savoring a delectable repast at an establishment I had not visited in over ten years, fondly recalling their succulent prime rib, fresh seafood, and mouthwatering crab dishes from my previous experience. However, upon my return, I was dismayed by the limited selection, which seemed to have shifted its focus towards offering an abundance of Chinese and Mexican cuisine, as well as an array of fruit options. Notably absent from the menu were traditional potato dishes, with the exception of mashed potatoes. Furthermore, the sushi offerings were subpar and failed to meet my expectations. Nevertheless, the prime rib remained exceptional, the crab was plentiful, and the calamari was cooked to perfection. Unfortunately, the pre-made salads did not impress, leaving my companion, who is a self-proclaimed meat and potatoes aficionado, with limited options. In light of the diminished selection, I believe a proportional adjustment in pricing would be appropriate. Additionally, I would appreciate the inclusion of more flavorful sushi options and a greater emphasis on hot crab dishes rather than their cold counterparts."

"I thoroughly enjoyed the culinary offerings of the previous establishment, specifically their delectable burritos, flavorful fondue cheese dip, and savory steak salads, accompanied by an array of refreshing cocktails, including the quintessential margarita, available during their happy hour. However, upon visiting the new location, I was dismayed to discover that certain aspects of the dining experience did not meet my expectations. Despite the novelty of the setting, I was taken aback by the absence of a frozen margarita machine, which I deemed a crucial component of the ambiance. Furthermore, there were noticeable inconsistencies in the quality of the food, particularly with regards to the texture and flavor of the rice, beans, and chicken in both the burrito and fajita dishes I ordered. Additionally, I requested hot sauce on the side, but it was incorporated into the dish instead. To compound matters, we failed to receive our subsequent round of beverages, despite having ordered them. While the service was adequate, I cannot help but feel a sense of nostalgia for the former establishment, and thus, I implore the management to consider reviving the essence of the original Salty Senorita, which, in my opinion, would greatly enhance the overall dining experience."

"Despite the amicable demeanor of the personnel, the financial investment required to partake in the culinary offerings of this establishment far surpasses the tangible value of the consumables served, particularly in reference to the pastrami sandwich, which, regrettably, failed to meet expectations. Furthermore, while the eatery possesses inherent potential, my personal inclination is to avoid revisiting it in the near future."

"The quality of their chips and fries is satisfactory. However, the absence of a unified menu location hindered our decision-making process, as we were forced to search for alternatives in disparate areas. Specifically, one menu was positioned near the entrance, while the other was situated behind the counter, which led to confusion and inconvenience. Upon inquiring about the hotdog, we discovered that it was not listed on the menu displayed before us, prompting us to seek assistance from the staff. Furthermore, we encountered an issue with the availability of ice, which the cashier attributed to a supposed need for the machine to naturally regenerate its supply, rather than offering a solution or providing a refill. Lastly, the demeanor of certain cashiers left much to be desired in terms of cordiality and customer service."

"Not suitable for every individual. Despite the fact that children might experience a moderate degree of enjoyment, two adults seeking a meaningful and engaging experience may find Rawhide lacking in substance. Following the payment of $5 for parking, we invested approximately 30 minutes of our time exploring the faux town and captured several photographs. However, it is highly debatable whether the visit was truly necessary. Thus, it is not recommended to prioritize Rawhide on one's list of must-see attractions in the region, unless one harbors an exceptional fondness for Western themes and finds the artificial town captivating."

"An exceptional establishment specializing in yogurt, conveniently located in close proximity, offers an economical price point of thirty-five cents per ounce, which is truly a remarkable value. However, upon visiting the premises yesterday at approximately seven twenty-five in the evening, we were met with an unfortunate scene; the store was shrouded in darkness, and the entrance was secured, suggesting that the business was not operational during the hours specified on the voice message, which stated that the establishment remained open until nine o'clock on Saturdays. This led me to leave a message expressing my utter bewilderment and disappointment regarding the inconsistency demonstrated by the business in terms of their operating hours, which seems to be incompatible with the basic principles of running a successful enterprise."

Do not come here!!! We waited 45 mins to get a seat. No one is clearing tables. The food is marginal at bedt. I got a beef short rib. The meat is so tough and grisly that my knife cannot cut through. 
STAY WAY FROM HERE.

Ok the buffet had some decent food. But the wait for a clean table made this a no return.

Poor service by the wait staff is my biggest complaint. We were there at 5:00 (and it wasn't busy yet), and it took probably 15 minutes to place our order. \n\nFinally, $16.95 for a fish fry. Yowzers!

"My spouse and I ventured to this establishment with the intention of procuring sandwiches. Our initial inclination was to visit Quizno's, but upon observing this venue, we opted to sample its offerings instead. Following my placement of an order for a Chicken Gyro, Chicken Kabob, and Baba Ghanouj for takeout, my thoughts began to wander aimlessly, drawing an association with the television program "Kitchen Nightmares" for reasons unknown to me. Upon the completion of our order, we retrieved it and returned home. The Chicken Gyro featured generous portions of poultry, yet the slices could have benefited from being more slender. Unfortunately, the pita bread used for our "to-go" order became partially saturated with the juices emanating from the tomato and onion components. My kabob proved to be a letdown, consisting of thick, dry strips of chicken that did not align with my expectations of chunky meat. Eating it presented a challenge, prompting me to consume only the chicken. The Baba Ghanouj, on the other hand, was utterly unpalatable, resembling a watery mixture overpowered by olive oil. We found it unbearable, limiting ourselves to a single bite. In contrast, the most delectable Baba Ghanouj I have had the pleasure of savoring was at Sabuddy, an Israeli restaurant that regrettably shut down due to the proprietor's return to New York. As for the sandwiches, the pita bread demonstrated exceptional quality, and I intend to enjoy it on the premises during my next visit, forgoing the "to-go" option."

I selected this establishment based upon the confluence of factors including price and reputation, precipitating my decision to visit the premises. It is imperative to note that appointments are not accepted, thereby necessitating a prolonged waiting period, in my case, approximately 90 minutes. Upon entering the facility, I was not presented with a choice between a male or female therapist, which proved to be advantageous given my lack of preference in this regard. In preparation for the massage, I communicated specific areas of focus to the practitioner, encompassing my neck, the region between my shoulder blades, and most notably, my sciatic nerve. Additionally, I specified the desired duration for each area, prompting the therapist to inquire about the nature of a sciatica and the appropriate trigger points to address the condition effectively. Unfortunately, the practitioner failed to exhibit proficiency in time management, displayed a limited understanding of relevant terminology and anatomical knowledge, and devoted excessive attention to adjusting the bedding and draping, requiring multiple attempts to achieve adequate coverage. Following the conclusion of the massage, I did not receive any hydration or recommendations for post-massage practices such as stretching, aromatherapy, or epsom salt baths, which would have enhanced my experience. Therefore, I would advise potential patrons to exercise caution when considering this establishment for their massage needs.

I was excited to try this place since I heard so much rave reviews during my visit in NY.  I was disappointed.....!!

We went on a Tuesday @ 1:00pm and we had a flight to catch at 3:30.  There was no line and the service was quick.  We ordered chicken wings, ABC burger, and strawberry sundae.  THe portions were huge, but everything tasted very mediocre... For the quality of the food, I think it is overpriced!

I think out of everything... I only enjoyed the sweet potato fries.... :(

Bad experience with in room dining ~ 

Had called previously to ask for prices and how much we get if we ordered wings. In the beginning they said we get 6 wings/$16 during the day and 12/$16 after 10 pm. We has ordered around 11pm last night and when the food came we only got 6. I had called the room service again and she told me that we were suppose to get 12. Then she put me on hold to check what had happened. 

She then goes to tell me oh we changed our menu sorry. She didnt even know the menu changed along with the other guy worker we had talked to before. I know you they are still in transition but it shouldn't be an excuse for indecent service.

We had bought 2 orders which was 12 wings for 41$ we would've never bought if the hotel didn't trick us. We would have  ordered something else. The order didn't even get us full one bit. 

We order in room dining quite often so this was a very bad experience. 


Overall experience at the Delano is ok though. Less crowded which I like and the hotel is very nice. Next to the elevators they put up a new quote every day on a mirror which is my favorite part.

This place is the perfect example of a tourist trap.  Nice location not far of the main drag of Old Scottsdale, beautiful building and layout.  The margaritas are good, but probably $2-$3 more expensive than they ought to be for every one of the many styles.  I thought paying $5 for chips and salsa was a rip-off, but then when the chips tasted stale, I was even less happy.  C'mon, if you have tortilla and factory in your name, you ought to have fresh chips.  I thought the tortillas themselves were okay, not great, but okay.  The carne fuego, or whatever I had the waitress recommended, was not good.  Small chunks of fire roasted steak completely ruined by a gloppy sweet/hot sauce. The veggies that went with it were just okay and the sweet potato-stuffed chile was weird.  It could've been great, but it was nowhere near good.  Unless your Aunt Hattie who has never had Mexican food is in town from Ohio, i'd skip this place altogether.

Apparently, when one opted to expend $185 to engage in recreational activity on the golf course, it seemed utterly impractical to eliminate the grass clippings from the fairways by means of a sudden gust of air. I do not intend to convey the notion that I am an elitist individual, as I am undoubtedly not; however, upon residing in Scottsdale for nearly a decade and experiencing the course for the initial time with such a substantial price attached to it, one would anticipate a level of excellence that sadly did not manifest itself. The greens presented a sluggish pace, and the overall state of the course was merely average. Although I acknowledge that every establishment is undergoing or has recently completed their overseed process, charging such a fee for the condition it was in appeared somewhat comical. Personally, if I were to invest such capital, I would greatly prefer to partake in recreation at We-ko-pa or Troon North.

"Based on my most recent experience, I must say that the service at this establishment leaves much to be desired, with the youthful staff exhibiting a lackadaisical attitude towards customer service, necessitating me to vociferously summon their attention despite having a guest present in the lobby. Furthermore, were it not for the fact that this location boasts a convenient proximity to the base of Las Sendas, I might be inclined to seek alternative dining options, thereby forgoing the pleasure of partaking in their culinary offerings altogether. Store Manager/Owner, take heed: this represents an opportune moment for you to effectuate a marked improvement in the quality of service provided by your team. My propensity for fairness and generosity in reviewing establishments notwithstanding, this particular venue unfortunately ranks as the weakest within the Mesa Valley.

Notwithstanding the aforementioned shortcomings, I must confess that Rosatis manages to deliver a commendable rendition of pizza, even if it falls short of the exceptional standards set by authentic Chicago-style pizzerias, which benefit from the region's unique water quality. The young man who attended to our order demonstrated a praiseworthy level of competence, expeditiously delivering our meal in approximately 15 minutes, piping hot. Moreover, the sausage served at Rosatis deserves high praise. My family and I customarily patronize this restaurant during our visits to see our parents, who reside in the neighboring area. A word of advice: consider adding extra cheese to your order, as the ensuing abundance of melted, oozing richness pairs perfectly with the pepperoni, making for a truly satisfying dining experience."

"THE GOOD: Ridiculously economical lodging options, with rooms available for a mere $35 per night. FAT TUESDAYS offers large quantities of alcoholic beverages at a relatively low cost, specifically their signature giant Everclear drinks, which may have contributed to my temporary memory loss. The sleeping quarters were exceptionally comfortable, boasting cleanliness and superior bedding. Hairdresser Elvis was an additional amenity. 

THE BAD: The quoted price failed to include the mandatory $5 per night resort fee, which was an unpleasant surprise. Only two members of the hotel staff displayed courteous behavior towards us, with one staff member even laughing at our friend over the phone when she requested additional towels. Although situated far from the strip, the hotel's proximity to downtown Las Vegas was a welcome advantage. 

THE HIDEOUSLY UGLY: The rooftop pool, reserved for patrons who preferred to sunbathe sans clothing, was an unsightly spectacle. The absence of a bar and the prevalence of imposing, muscular men and large, voluptuous women donning minimal attire made for an uncomfortable atmosphere. While body confidence is commendable, this setting did not foster a welcoming environment.

In conclusion, while the hotel offered some positive aspects, I would opt for a more luxurious establishment, with a greater emphasis on customer satisfaction and a more reasonable pricing structure, thereby avoiding the need for a costly taxi ride."

P.S. The question remains, why do parents choose to bring their offspring to Las Vegas, a city renowned for its adult entertainment and indulgences?

"It is truly perturbing to encounter establishments purporting to specialize in a particular geographical area's gastronomical delights, yet failing to deliver an authentic representation of said cuisine, which, in my opinion, is a grave injustice to the rich culinary heritage of the region in question. 

As an individual with limited familiarity regarding the intricacies of Greek gastronomy, I must admit that my expectations for an genuine Hellenic dining experience have been disappointed on multiple occasions, leading me to surmise that there exists a discrepancy between the quality of the ingredients utilized in the preparation of these dishes and the standard of freshness I have come to expect from a reputable eatery. 

In a city such as Las Vegas, where the restaurant industry is highly competitive and susceptible to the fluctuations of the economic climate, it is imperative that establishments prioritize the quality of their offerings, lest they risk falling prey to the perils of financial decline."

"Indubitably, this particular route serves as the most feasible means of accessing the city of Las Vegas, which has evolved into a preeminent tourist destination boasting an array of extravagant casinos, luxurious hotels, and elaborate entertainment venues. However, it is worth noting that the once-luminous appeal of this city has diminished somewhat over time, with certain areas adopting a more tawdry ambiance, while the convenience of navigating its streets has become increasingly challenging for visitors. Moreover, it is uncertain whether alternative methods of transportation exist that would facilitate a more enjoyable excursion, given that the nearby airport may not necessarily constitute the pinnacle of one's travel experience."

Upon entering the establishment, an overwhelming pungency permeated the atmosphere, which was somewhat disconcerting, given the fact that a plethora of canines were concentrated within a relatively diminutive space. Notwithstanding, I acknowledged that maintaining pristine conditions in such an environment might prove challenging, yet I would venture to assume that periodic sanitizing endeavors would ensue. My curiosity piqued, I inquired regarding a particular service advertised on both the promotional flyer and digital platform, only to be informed that it was not offered. This begs the question: Why publicize it? Furthermore, my attention was drawn to the absence of visibility into the area housing the canines from the front office, although auditory evidence suggested their presence. During my egress, I noticed that the lateral vantage point provided a view into the confined quarters, teeming with an abundance of dogs, unsupervised and seemingly unattended. Additionally, a cursory examination of images showcased on the review portal revealed a worrisome state of disrepair regarding the furniture intended for canine accommodation, appearing hazardous due to considerable wear and tear. Considering my proximity to the facility, a mere mile distant, the potential convenience was tantalizing, but regrettably, my experience precludes me from endorsing or utilizing their services in the future.

Well, this place is good.  The food is kind of that outdated tropical fare and lacks any sort of innovation.  The atmosphere has that TGI fridays chain feeling to it, but instead of shit on the walls its upscale tropical.\n\nI wouldnt really go back unless i was invited by someone else.

The act of precipitously diminishing your rating by a single celestial body, gentlemen, appears to be an indubitable necessity, considering the establishment's recent shortcomings in terms of quality and quantity of the broth, as well as the relatively sluggish pace of service, despite a marginal improvement, all of which cumulatively militate against the retention of its erstwhile triadic stellar ranking, thus compelling the quest for an alternative venue worthy of serving as a reliable substitute for the consummation of pho.
This has to be the worst cupcake I've ever tasted. I've had better cupcakes from the grocery store. every thing is over priced (even for Vegas). But I will say that the shakes are good.

Finally, I had the opportunity to visit Greenberg's and indulge in their renowned Pastrami Sandwich; as I observed the skilled woman expertly slice the meat, I couldn't help but notice the generous portion she was allocating onto each sandwich. My mouth began to water uncontrollably at the prospect of consuming such a delectable meal. When she presented it to me, the pastrami was overflowing from the confines of the rye bread, much like an overstuffed sausage casing. My anticipation was palpable. However, upon taking my first bite, I was taken aback by the lack of the distinctive pastrami flavor that I had been expecting. I added salt and mustard in an attempt to enhance the taste, but to no avail. The peppery essence that I had been eagerly anticipating was nowhere to be found. Furthermore, there was an unusual lingering sensation of fat in my mouth, which only served to further perplex me. Upon inspecting the meat, I noticed that the usual amount of marbling was present, leaving me utterly baffled. It was almost as if I had encountered a singularly unremarkable cut of meat that particular day. Despite my disappointment, I am willing to give Greenberg's another chance, if only for the sheer value of the substantial quantity of meat offered for a mere ten dollars.

"My culinary experience at this establishment was somewhat disappointing, as the fare provided was slightly too oleaginous for my taste. Furthermore, the epidermis of the poultry dish I ordered was separating, which I found rather peculiar. Considering the tariff, I expected a higher quality of cuisine. Frankly, I have visited numerous more affordable restaurants that serve genuinely authentic Asian-Fusion dishes, which were far superior to what I was served here."

Meh, I've experienced better, pretty much covers it.

The young man who brought water and tea didn't know what tea he was serving us. No straws were brought- big peeve of mine. I dislike drinking from cups at restaurants.

The egg rolls tasted of perfume. Chicken chow mien was ok, $5.95 for M-F lunch special. They never asked if we wanted desert.

There were an abundance of employees present on the day of my visit, a total of 15 individuals, which was quite conspicuous given the sparse population of patrons within the confines of Tivoli Village. Upon my entry, I was not acknowledged by the two women who were engrossed in their conversation, and subsequently, they extended a warm welcome to the individuals who followed me. Subsequently, additional female staff members observed me vigilantly, their gazes suggestive of suspicion that I might be inclined to pilfer items from the store. Either I was completely imperceptible to the staff or they perceived me as a youthful customer, approximately 14 years of age, who was accompanying a few peers and evaluating the quantity of merchandise that could be concealed within my attire and personal belongings. fundamentally, they offer accessories comparable to those found at H&M or Forever 21, albeit at elevated price points. My confidence in the notion that paying a premium for their products would postpone the acceleration of skin aging is limited. In essence, the items remain economically manufactured. While it is plausible to discover acceptable articles at reduced prices or in an as-is state, I would never consider purchasing anything at the original cost due to the lack of quality in their products.

I wish I had read the Yelp reviews before booking. The bathroom is really small, which wouldn't be a problem if the door opened towards the outside... The power plugs were loose in the bathroom and non-existent throughout the rest of the room.

We were there for two nights, and was never serviced. We traveled with our two dogs so i made sure to call the front desk to let them know when we would be out with the dogs so they could come and clean the room... I did that twice the same day, and was clearly unsuccessful.

I sent clothes to dry cleaning, and they were supposed to be ready by 9am the next morning... 11am nothing and we were already 2 hours behind schedule to hit the road. It took another 45 mins to get them and check-out. When I called to inquire about it, the lady at the front desk was as unpleasant as one can be. 

I won't go back to this hotel.

"Optimize your culinary experience by selecting the chicken teriyaki bowl, thereby circumventing the necessity of sampling the remaining menu items. I recently had the opportunity to partake in their tempura and teriyaki combination platter during the luncheon hour. The tempura consisted of a singular carrot and what appeared to be a zucchini, although I cannot verify its exact identity with certainty. Furthermore, there was an extended, cylindrical entity adorned with a shrimp tail, the dimensions of which led me to question whether said crustaceans are indeed of a comparable magnitude to writing utensils. Notwithstanding these observations, the two California rolls accompanying the dish were merely adequate, a fact made all the more disappointing by the absence of both ginger and wasabi, two crucial condiments that would have undoubtedly enhanced the flavors of the meal. Considering the cost of $10.82 for a midday repast, I must conclude that the establishment's offerings do not provide commensurate value. In light of this assessment, I recommend the implementation of additional lunch specials to entice prospective patrons and elevate the dining experience to a satisfactory level."

We had the privilege of hosting a family gathering at this esteemed establishment, and unfortunately, our experience was marred by certain shortcomings. Specifically, while the quality of the entrÃ©es was merely average, the service we received was subpar and left much to be desired. Despite having reserved a table well in advance, it appeared that the staff was ill-prepared to accommodate our group, resulting in an extended wait before our orders were taken. Moreover, numerous requests for wine and water had to be repeated multiple times before they were eventually fulfilled, prompting my spouse to take matters into his own hands by proceeding to the bar to procure beverages for our party.

"At the confluence of Sandy Porter and Tryon, nestled within a retail complex, lies this Food Lion establishment. Although my exposure to Food Lion stores has been limited, I cannot determine whether this particular location is larger or smaller than others; however, what I can attest to is that the prices here appear to surpass those of Harris-Teeter, Bi-Lo, Wal-Mart, and Super Target. Offering an extensive array of products encompassing frozen items, dairy, fresh produce, beverages, and various meats, this store provides the necessities for a comprehensive grocery excursion. Nonetheless, budget-conscious shoppers may find the costs to be somewhat elevated. For those who opt to frequent this Food Lion location, consider obtaining their MVP shopper loyalty card, which promises to yield substantial savings."

The food tasted good, but everything else about dinner tonight was awful. \n\nThe waitress forgot some of our food and didn't bring my order to me the way I asked. After that, she brought us the check and refilled our drinks, but then we never saw her again. After a while I was thirsty enough that I literally got up, went behind the counter and refilled our drinks myself. No one noticed. After about an hour a new waitress came by and offered refills -- leaving our two empty dirty cups on the table but finally removing the dirty dishes. Over the course of more than two hours we were never asked if we wanted to order anything else. To top it off, two of the stalls in the women's restroom were completely out of toilet paper.

I came here a couple of times while staying at the Tropicana this week. Overall, it's everything you would expect from an in-resort snack bar, but I still found it to be a bit overpriced. A couple of small scoops of gelato will run you $7, and the gelato is only okay. You can actually get more for less over at the Bellagio.\n\nThe self-serve frozen yogurt is a better deal, at $0.49 an ounce, and there are some interesting flavors to try (coconut to peanut butter to cake batter). I guess I never really understood the fro-yo craze. Everytime I eat  it, I just wish I was eating ice cream instead.

I hate this airport.  I thought I loathed O'Hare.  I thought I truly hated the 'Nati (CVG) airport.  I REALLY thought I hated ATL's airport.  McCarran set a whole new low for me.  All of the queues you have to stand in are at least 150 people deep all the time, whether it's the security queue or the taxi one.  The TSA people here are so not the brightest stars in the sky.  And for Chrissake...all the slot machines.  Airports are already crazybusy and noisy as it is.  I don't need ringing slot machines to contribute to the migraine that is McCarran.

So all this hype about Tao Beach... Got there, it was nothing like I imagined. It looked liked kiddie pools compared to the other places. \n\nIt was free cover for girls, and open bar (well drinks) until a certain time, so I can't complain. But for the guys that do have to pay cover, I think you would find it more worth it to pay cover to the other pools like Wet Republic and such.  Less cramped, and probably nicer pools too.

Well, it's food!! That's about all I can say for The Smithfield Cafe.  
I had the "daily special" which is pretty much the universal way of condensing "two eggs, bacon or sausage, and toast" into two words. Sausage was room temperature, eggs were decent, and the greasy home fries contained the flavor of the dozen meals that were cooked before mine this morning (not i'n a good way). Coffee was plentiful, but not flavorful. 
The waitresses were grizzled and archetypal for their profession.  
To surmise; meh...

Here is a succinct synopsis of our culinary experience at this establishment:

It is our considered opinion that the prices charged at this eatery are somewhat exorbitant, especially considering the fact that it is an Americanized Chinese restaurant. The average cost of a single dish was in the range of $15 to $20, which we found to be a tad steep. 

However, they do offer some unique beverages, such as Vietnamese coffee with boba, which arrives in a generous portion and is not only delightful but also quite potent. Additionally, they serve soy milk with boba and various fruits, including watermelon, and the prices for these drinks fall somewhere between $5 and $7. 

The menu selections are rather limited, comprising primarily of beef, pork, soup, rice, and noodle dishes. Notably absent from the menu are certain signature dishes commonly found at authentic Chinese restaurants, such as pan-fried noodles or combination plates like chow fun. 

We must say, however, that the ambiance of the establishment is quite pleasant, boasting attractive white and orange hand-blown glasses and stylish dÃ©cor. The service we received was adequate, and the food was prepared fresh. Particularly noteworthy were the noodles in our chow fun, which were handmade and our favorite among all the dishes we sampled. Furthermore, the salt and pepper shrimp were quite delectable. 

It is worth mentioning that while the servings are 'Ã  la carte,' or family-style, the portions are somewhat smaller than what one might expect at a traditional Chinese restaurant.

I discontinued frequenting this establishment upon recognizing that I possessed the financial means to procure accommodations exceeding $99 per night in Las Vegas. The location's proximity to the terminus of the famed Strip, the underwhelming nature of the gaming facilities, the lodging's antiquated ambiance reminiscent of 1997, and the pervasive odor akin to a damp towel forgotten in a laundry basket for a fortnight, combined with an unsolicited and inebriated female individual's futile attempt to engage my group in social interaction before stumbling away with a prominent masculine footprint embossed on her lower leg, collectively warranted a rating of two stars, primarily attributed to the cost and the aforementioned unsavory encounter.

Reading some of the other reviews, I feel like I must have eaten at a different restaurant. I order two spicy tuna rolls with brown rice. Both had zero flavor and could have been molded from Elmer's paste instead of fish. \n\nMaybe I ordered the wrong thing. Seems like a good concept.

"For the price, this lodging alternative constitutes a remarkable value proposition, offering a plethora of amenities and services that cater to the diverse needs of its guests. The accommodations are clean, comfortable, and modern, boasting an impressive array of features that enhance the overall experience. The location is optimal, providing effortless access to various points of interest while affording visitors the opportunity to immerse themselves in the vibrant ambiance of the surrounding area. The guest services are truly exceptional, with a team of dedicated professionals committed to ensuring a seamless and enjoyable stay. Complimentary wireless internet access and a well-equipped fitness center further contribute to the appeal of this establishment. Of particular note is the captivating outdoor fire pit, which serves as a popular gathering spot for guests and adds to the charm of the property. The menu at the on-site restaurant merits special mention, showcasing an extensive selection of culinary delights that cater to discerning palates. However, it is important to note that the proximity of this establishment to nearby nightclubs may result in disturbance to guests, particularly those who prioritize restful slumber. This was evident during a recent visit, when the thumping bass and raucous revelry emanating from adjacent venues proved disruptive, even on a typically quieter weeknight. As such, it is crucial to consider this factor before selecting this hotel, especially for those whose sleep is paramount."

"Having been born and raised in San Diego, I possess an unwavering fondness for all things Mexican, particularly the delectable fish tacos. However, my experience at this establishment has left me feeling underwhelmed and disappointed. Despite my initial excitement, the fish tacos failed to meet my expectations. Upon receiving my order, I noticed that the fish appeared to be breaded at the restaurant, which begs the question: why bother breading the fish in the first place? The quality of the fish itself was passable, but the fact that it was served in pieces left much to be desired. Typically, when fish is cut correctly, it does not result in pieces. Furthermore, the batter lacked any discernible flavor, reminiscent of store-bought frozen fish sticks. It seemed as though the chef had taken great care in presenting the dish visually, but ultimately, it felt like leftovers. In light of this experience, I shall seek out alternative establishments for my fish taco cravings in the future. For those visiting San Diego, I recommend trying Rubio's, a fast food fish taco chain that appears to understand what the customer desires and what not to serve them. Unfortunately, Cabo's did not share this philosophy, leaving me feeling overcharged for a subpar meal."

"The culinary offerings were satisfactory, with a focus on the delectable bibimbap dish; however, the quality of service was subpar and left much to be desired, evoking a state of utter dismay and incredulity in this patron. Furthermore, the imposition of an 18% gratuity charge on the bill was deemed unreasonable and nonsensical, contributing to an overall ambiance that discourages future visits."

I embarked upon a culinary excursion to this esteemed eatery on the twenty-eighth day of December, two thousand and fourteen. Upon my arrival, I was greeted by an ambiance that exuded an aura of refinement and sophistication, which was befitting of a establishment that prided itself on serving premium quality steaks. However, much to my chagrin, the steak that was presented before me failed to meet the lofty expectations that I had harbored in my mind's eye. As an ardent devotee of steak, I have had the privilege of partaking in numerous steakhouse experiences, and thus, I could not help but feel that the steak offered at this venue was not commensurate with the price point that was being charged. Nonetheless, I must admit that the oysters that were served as an accompaniment to the steak were quite delectable and possessed a certain je ne sais quoi that left a lasting impression upon my palate.

"I am compelled to revise my assessment of this establishment for two primary reasons. Firstly, my initial visit occurred in 2009, and secondly, my most recent experience differed significantly from my inaugural encounter. I shall endeavor to convey my sentiments succinctly and straightforwardly for the benefit of those who prefer brevity. The hamburger lacked discernible flavor. While I comprehend the rationale behind the unrestricted variety of toppings available for customization, even the combination of A-1 steak sauce, chipotle sauce, and banana peppers could not mask the unmistakable taste of overcooked, arid ground beef. Come on, Cheeburger; even Chili's boasts its unique flavor profile! My expectations were unfortunately unmet during my latest visit, but I have moved past my disappointment, as I do not intend to return."

In the geographic location this afternoon for commercial enterprise activities.  Surprisingly, I have never had the pleasure of visiting this establishment previously.
 Hit the smorgasbord - with carbonated beverage it cost $8.50, give or take a few shiny metal discs.
 It brought to mind a vague similarity to Shakey's menu, but did not quite meet their elevated culinary standards.  Additionally, it invoked memories of the bygone era of my daughter and I partaking in gastronomical indulgences at Chuck E. Cheese's, although this venue is superior in quality.
 Salad bar - basic fare - enjoyed a few slices of cured meat on my leafy green salad!
 Pasta - spaghetti and elbow macaroni with dual sauce options - can you say...Ragu (actually a slight improvement)?
 Chicken and potato wedges - both coated with the same breading...hmmm...tasted identical as well.
 Pizza - well...initial round, THERE WAS NO PIZZA
 Second round - pizza - had a slice of seasoned pork and pepperoni - nothing extraordinary about it - my conjecture is the pre-cooked, SYSCO sausage; the pepperoni lacked flavor but possessed an abundance of oil!
 If I had a few youthful offspring, I could envision returning for post-athletic event celebrations, otherwise, regretfully, no future plans are anticipated.

I just arrived in Madison and was pooped from a long day + travel. I was really hungry and excited for a low key, hot meal. I had a bunch of work to catch up on so searched for a vegetarian friendly place that would also deliver. I was excited to find veggie Nepalese food that was close to the hotel. Every dish, even things that seemed like sides seemed pretty expensive so I assumed the portions would be enormous. I don't want enormous portions but I also didn't want teeny portions with a high price tag. I ordered a soup and it was basically a cup of soup for over $10. I didn't order anything else sadly and am left feeling pretty hungry. Wahh. Haha. \n\nShould have read more of the reviews!!!

Updated: Echo Canyon renovation. Echo Canyon used to be my favorite trail but after this new renovation it sucks.
