Following that, we submitted our second, third, and fourth requests for water, ultimately receiving it simultaneously with our main courses. Would you desire additional salsa? Unfortunately, such a query was futile, as the waitstaff was nowhere to be found until my companion rose and approached the bar to have her carbonated beverage replenished. At that point, it dawned on her that we were vexed. The culinary offerings could have been the most magnificent experience conceivable, but owing to the dearth of adequate service, I shall never return."

You will discover here a plethora of gastronomical options, including but not limited to:

1) Subpar, frostbitten sashimi that lacks the freshness and quality one would expect from a reputable establishment serving raw fish.

2) Scallops that have the potential to induce adverse gastrointestinal effects due to questionable handling and storage practices.

3) A dining area reminiscent of a witches' coven, creating an unsettling ambiance that may or may not enhance your culinary experience, depending on personal preferences.

A detailed explanation of the third point follows:

The cuisine offered can be classified as average Americanized sushi, garnering a rating of three stars at best. The ambiance, while unconventional, has the potential to elevate the overall experience to a respectable 3.5 stars. However, the exceptional quality of the service unfortunately warrants a reduction in rating to a mere two stars.

The wait staff, comprised of Chinese individuals, engage in surreptitious and unethical practices, such as covertly peddling inferior alcoholic beverages to unsuspecting patrons, including myself and my colleagues. This reprehensible behavior necessitates a decrease in rating.

In conclusion, Hiro offers superior dining options for those seeking a truly satisfying culinary experience.

Love their coffee.
They need to add help in the morning.
With all the moms and high school kids ordering double latte whatever's there is a line to the door from 7:45 to 9:00.
I'm not going to wait for ten minutes for a cup of plain coffee.
Usually buy beans there and make at home. But now when I want to stop in to grab a cup to go, I go elsewherel
They should have someone who only takes straight coffe orders. They would get more business.

I really wanted to like this place.  It is a fun looking place.  We were there when it was slow.  The downstairs bartender was friendly.  We went upstairs when our friends arrived.  The service was slow, food was boring.  We had a variety of dishes.  This place has potential but they need to bring up the food flavor and service.

"The lodging facility in question does not conform to the traditional definition of a resort, as it is, in fact, an apartment complex that has been adapted for use as a motel. Furthermore, during our stay, we did not have access to air conditioning, which rendered the interior of our room uncomfortably warm, particularly given the external temperature of approximately 60 degrees Fahrenheit in February. When I inquired about this issue, I was informed that the establishment did not possess any air conditioning units and that the thermostat was merely a cosmetic feature that produced a modicum of warm air upon activation. Although the staff members were amicable, the oppressive ambient temperature significantly detracted from our overall comfort level."

"This aerodrome is tainted with an aura of squalor and ineptitude, rendering it unaccommodating to patrons who seek a seamless and convenient experience. Specifically, the absence of sufficient power outlets throughout the terminal hinders the ability of business travelers to recharge their electronic devices, thereby creating an unnecessary obstacle for those seeking to maintain productivity during transit. Furthermore, the physical distance between gates poses an additional challenge for passengers facing layovers, as they must traverse an excessive distance on foot, thereby augmenting the already heightened levels of anxiety associated with air travel. Moreover, the proliferation of slot machines within the airport serves only to exacerbate the financial burden inherent in modern-day travel, thus further undermining the overall quality of the facility."

It has been approximately six years since we last partook in a culinary excursion to the streets of New York, and on this particular occasion, we opted for a delicate and crunchy pizza, accompanied by a Caesar salad and an order of bread knots. Upon reflection, the pizza proved to be somewhat superior to my previous recollections, yet still fell short of excellence. Conversely, the salad was regrettably inedible, with the romaine lettuce displaying visible signs of browning and an unmistakable lack of freshness, indicating that it had surpassed its prime by at least four or five days. In response to our dissatisfaction, the restaurant graciously accepted the return of the salad and offered a complimentary piece of cheesecake as a gesture of goodwill. Unfortunately, the individual responsible for preparing our meal should indeed feel deeply embarrassed by their subpar performance... Ultimately, we are unlikely to revisit this establishment in the future.

slow to leave the airport. waited about 20-30 minutes for the shuttle to fill up before we left.

calling for a pick-up wasnt very helpful. they say the shuttle can arrive within a 15 minute window and then take up to an HOUR to get you to the airport. i sucked it up and just had a taxi take me. well worth it the money.

don't recommend this company unless they improve their efficiency.

they do get 2 starts because of their cheap rates. cant beat it if you don't mind waiting

My spouse, progeny, and I have been patronizing Casey Jones for an extended period, yet our most recent visit presented a precipitous decline in culinary excellence. In the company of acquaintances, we sampled their newly introduced burger, the "Juicy Lucy," and were dismayed by its lackluster quality. Upon ordering the burgers at a medium level of doneness, we were served two patties that appeared to be hemorrhaging, with an overflow of cheese reminiscent of a gruesome cinematic scene where a character suffers a mortal wound. Following our return of the burgers to the kitchen and receiving assurance of their rectification, the subsequent dishes were cooked to an extreme degree, bordering on incineration, and were devoid of any semblance of dairy products, thereby negating the essence of the "Juicy" moniker. As a result, my previous endorsement of this establishment has been rescinded, and further visits will be forestalled until a more competent culinary artisan assumes responsibilities in the kitchen, as the likelihood of such an unfortunate series of events had previously been considered improbable.

"Subsequent to receiving a $20 discount voucher via postal delivery, my companion and I opted to sample the culinary offerings of this establishment. Suffice it to say that several months have transpired since our inaugural visit, and the sole instance in which this venue has resurfaced in my consciousness was during a conversation with a colleague who shared a comparable account of an unremarkable dining experience. \n\nWhile the hospitality we received was adequate, the fare served proved to be underwhelming. Specifically, I requested cheese enchiladas, while my partner opted for chicken enchiladas. However, upon presentation, I discovered that the tortillas were conspicuously absent from my dish, compelling me to embark on a quest to locate them. My significant other expressed equal disappointment with her entree. Notwithstanding, the sangria I ordered exhibited a modicum of palatability, although it failed to suffice as a sufficient reason to warrant a future visit."

Good food and decent service, but way too expensive for galbi and meat! They also have menus, new and old, that say certain dishes include dessert, but at the end when we asked for them they said that it wasn't being offered anymore. Um, okay, can you let us know before we order and/or update the menus please? I hate surprises like that when eating out when it's been spelled out. That alone knocks off a star or two. \n\nThis place would also be better to eat at alone or with two people for better value, because they give you the same amount of side dishes and seafood pancake no matter how many are at your table.

"It has been an appreciable duration since my last visit to Dos Gringos, or perhaps this particular establishment is inferior in terms of cleanliness compared to the Tempe location, but my recent experience at this venue was utterly disappointing. The lavatory facilities were emitting an unpleasant odor, and the overall ambiance seemed grimy and unkempt. I would not consider partaking in culinary indulgences from this establishment, given that the state of their bar area raises concerns about the cleanliness of their kitchen. Frankly, I am perplexed by the preference of some individuals to frequent such an uninviting atmosphere when there are numerous alternative destinations in Scottsdale that offer a more enjoyable and sanitary experience."

I have been to this Jasons Deli several times, it has always been good.  We have ordered delivery from here several times, it has always been very delicious.  I ordered delivery from here today, and it was very forgetable.  The butter croissant that held my turkey sandwich together was really dried out, it was actually breaking as I ate it, it was that dry.  I have said before that they have the best brownies I have ever had....... Just not today. The brownies were overcooked,  one of them actually tasted burned.... they were very dry, not moist and fudgy the way they have been, when I have had them before.  Everything was disappointing about this meal...... it might be awhile before I order from here again.

"The prices are exorbitant, to say the least. It is ostensible that they possess cutting-edge equipment, but unfortunately, we were unable to take advantage of such modern amenities due to the prohibitive costs. Despite the cordial demeanor of the staff, we had a doctor suggest callously that it might be in the best interest of our canine companion to be euthanized, which is utterly unconscionable. As medical professionals, it is their ethical duty to prioritize the well-being of their patients, and such a comment is reprehensible. Our dog required a brief, 24-hour stay at the facility, which resulted in an astronomical bill totaling approximately $2000. In contrast, we transferred our furry friend to another, more affordable establishment, where he received identical care and treatment for a mere fraction of the cost, totaling less than the amount we paid for a single day at VCA."

"Upon entering the establishment, I noticed that they possessed an array of cosmetic lines; however, the abundance of products available for purchase was unfortunately meager during my visit. Specifically, the selection of items from MAC, the brand I was seeking, was quite limited and many of the products were either already opened, damaged, or appeared to have been heavily utilized. Furthermore, the quality of customer service I received was subpar. The trio of employees stationed at the cash register failed to acknowledge my presence or offer any assistance, leaving me feeling ignored and disheartened. Consequently, I will be venturing to the interior location in the future, hoping to find a more extensive range of options."

"Satisfactory victuals at a reasonable cost. We visited this establishment in the early hours of a Friday morning, following our arrival in Las Vegas. Despite the lateness of the hour, the venue was bustling with activity; however, we were promptly accommodated. I opted to partake in the 7 oz. steak, accompanied by hash browns, eggs, and toast, which I shared with my companion due to my limited appetite. The steak presented a dichotomy of doneness, with one half being well done and the other half falling somewhere between medium and medium-well; we had requested the latter, but such minor inconsistencies were inconsequential given the affordable price point of less than $4. The hash browns lacked the desired crispiness, while the toast was satisfactory, and the eggs fell within the realm of mediocrity. A cursory examination of the culinary offerings revealed an absence of sodium, a characteristic seemingly tailored to the preferences of the mature clientele that frequent this establishment. In summary, this restaurant serves as a suitable option for those seeking sustenance following a night of revelry or for individuals who prefer a more relaxed dining experience, but it does not qualify as a premier gastronomic destination."

"We partook in a culinary excursion at this esteemed eatery last week, during which the comestibles were merely adequate, while the tariff was somewhat prohibitive. Specifically, supplementary dishes incurred an additional fee of $11.00 or more. 

However, the hospitality we received was quite another tale. Our trio of servers, with the primary one being conspicuously discourteous and haughty, bordering on impolite, and her countenance betrayed no hint of joviality. Such behavior, though unfortunate, might have been tolerable had not the supporting staff member committed the egregious faux pas of extending his arm across my spouse to retrieve my plate, leaving me utterly flabbergasted. I forthrightly admonished him, stressing the importance of proper decorum. Subsequently, the manager appeared and, upon being apprised of the situation, expressed contrition and effected a transformation in our attendants, resulting in a marked improvement in the quality of our service. 

My indignation stems from the fact that, at an establishment of such lofty stature and cost, one should never be compelled to lodge a complaint to receive satisfactory service. The Las Vegas Strip boasts a plethora of exceptional restaurants, rendering it unnecessary to squander one's resources and time at a venue incapable of maintaining top-notch service consistently. My recommendation: seek an alternative dining destination!"

"I partook in an evening repast at Leroy Fox, whereupon I had the pleasure of savoring their culinary offerings within the refurbished confines of the erstwhile Hotel Charlotte. The revitalization of the establishment was indeed impressive, as it successfully integrated elements of the original edifice into its contemporary design. Unfortunately, the ambiance was somewhat marred by the cacophony of sounds that permeated the dining area, which was exacerbated by the advent of live musical performances. Notwithstanding the auditory challenges, my dining experience was largely satisfactory, as I relished the flavorsome 'north' chicken, comprising a breast and wing that were skillfully prepared via deep-frying. Furthermore, the menu presented an array of enticing options, and the attentive service was commendable despite minor delays attributed to the overwhelming volume of patrons. However, owing to the aforementioned limitations in auditory comfort, I would not advocate for visiting this eatery with expectations of engaging in effortless conversation with fellow diners."

This lodging establishment proved to be a profound disappointment, failing to meet our expectations of a luxurious four-star hotel experience in Las Vegas. Despite its unremarkable appearance, we opted to spend a single night at this venue, only to discover that for an identical tariff, we could have secured accommodations that were markedly superior in both quality and amenities.

"My experience at this particular BJ's establishment has been rather inconsistent, as the culinary offerings have demonstrated a propensity for variability in terms of adhering to the specified parameters of my orders. Specifically, on seven separate occasions, I have visited this restaurant with a group of colleagues, and on six of those instances, the kitchen has failed to accurately prepare my meal according to the details provided in the faxed order. Notably, the kitchen has consistently struggled with the seemingly straightforward concept of a vegetarian pizza sans cheese, as evidenced by the fact that I have received deliveries with cheese included, as well as others with sausage substituted for the requested cheese. While the waitstaff has displayed commendable contrition in response to these errors, the persistent incompetence exhibited by the kitchen staff raises concerns regarding their capacity to effectively fulfill patrons' dining requirements."

I was eager to relish the culinary offerings of this eatery and had high expectations, however, upon entering the premises, my enthusiasm was dampened by the cramped layout, which appeared to prioritize maximizing seating capacity over patron comfort. Although I comprehend the economic rationale behind this decision, it created an unpleasant ambiance, particularly during peak hours. Moreover, the menu options were limited, which made it challenging to find a suitable dish that catered to my taste preferences. My spouse opted for the turkey sandwich, while I selected the grilled cheese BLT. The total cost for these two items and a single fountain beverage was almost $20.00, which seemed excessive given the quality of the fare. Furthermore, the service was sluggish, with a prolonged delay between placing our order and its fulfillment. When the food finally arrived, it was merely satisfactory, with the bacon in my sandwich displaying an unpleasant texture and appearance, suggestive of having been stored for an extended period. Additionally, my spouse's meal lacked the specified vegetables and condiments, but due to the prolonged wait, he chose not to request a replacement. In conclusion, this establishment failed to meet my expectations, offering a noise-filled atmosphere and unimpressive cuisine at an exorbitant price point, leading me to concur with my spouse's sentiment that alternative dining options, such as Capriotti's, would provide better value for the money.
All the used records here are basically beat up dollar bin records priced at $5 and up. Bad customer service too. Not coming back.

As a denizen of the San Francisco Bay Area, I felt compelled to sample the Asian gastronomic offerings within Montreal's Chinatown precinct, and Beijing emerged as a highly acclaimed establishment according to the aggregated opinions on Yelp. Thus, we opted to partake in their culinary experience.

The dining area was characterized by a cavernous interior with an excessive number of tables and chairs, creating an environment that was boisterous and lacking in intimacy. Our order consisted of the Chicken Soo Guy, which our server defined as being imbued with a distinctive Asian sauce, the specificity of which was left undefined. It became apparent upon sampling that this purportedly special sauce was, in reality, a rather conventional sweet and sour variety, which did not particularly impress me.

In contrast, the spicy beef dish displayed a modicum of flavor, albeit only after we requested that it be prepared with an extraordinary degree of piquancy. This led me to ponder about the nature of the dish when served in its standard form.

Taking everything into account, my expectations were not met by this eatery, and I would not consider returning.

I have had OnTrac delivery many packages for me from Amazon Prime shipping. But a couple of times already they have delayed the package. The first time they were unable to delivery after I paid the extra 3.99 to have the package delivered the next day. the second time which happen today they're tracking information said "out for delivery" and now it says "UNDELIVERABLE - OTHER REASONS" followed by "REDELIVER ON NEXT BUSINESS DAY". 

The delivery man couldn't even put a legitament reason why my package could not be delivered. I am sure he felt he was running late and decided he would just take care of it the next day. Also the guy that first started to delivery packages to me would never smile even if I smiled at home and said thank you after receiving the package and he would not even say you are welcome. He would just hand me my package with a face as if he hates his job turn around and drive away. OnTrac needs to do a better job at training their delivery men on customer service skills. 

Overall they do a good job at delivering but I can't give them no more than two stars because compared to UPS or FedEx they just are not as good.

When I visited the recently established Panera on a Friday evening, I was cognizant that we were encountering difficulties when my youthful companion requested the poultry noodle soup in a bread bowl. The staff member tasked with taking orders curtly replied, "We've exhausted our bread bowl supply," upon which my acquaintance, who had been craving such a dish since becoming aware of its existence, decided on a conventional salad featuring avian components instead. Subsequently, I placed an order for a Thai-style poultry flatbread sandwich. We navigated through a narrow passageway leading to the dining area, whereupon observing the unimpressive decor illuminated by subpar lighting, it became apparent that none of the vacant tables had been adequately sanitized. During the interval preceding the arrival of our cuisine, I ventured to the lavatory, which regrettably had not undergone recent cleansing and featured a substantial cylindrical container of toilet tissue positioned atop an empty dispenser. Ultimately, our culinary selections were brought to our table, and it was evident that the individual responsible for the kitchen shared a familiar relationship with the decorator, as the presentation was uninspired. Although the prices at this establishment were more reasonable than those of Paradise and the exceptional Wildflower, we opted to visit Frys en route home and acquired a La Brea Olive Oil and Rosemary round loaf along with a can of Progresso chicken noodle soup. Indeed, that meal proved to be delectable.

This is our go to place for great food,but not this past Thursday for Burger night.
My hamburger was made ahead of time,....results..dry ,cool ,tough.
Same for the chicken ....super dry and tough...hard to swallow.

In the past hamburgers were fresh made,juicy ,served hot.Ditto per the chicken.

Want to attract people to your burgers ,don't precook them the meat and let in sit in a pan.

McDonald's does that!!!

Two star for service.

"While it may appear to be a unique establishment, upon closer inspection, it becomes evident that this venue does not offer anything particularly remarkable, unless one is an uninformed tourist seeking novel experiences. The overly saccharine nature of their confectionaries, coupled with the exorbitant prices, renders them unworthy of consumption. Furthermore, the notion that a lollipop holder designed by Katy Perry would warrant a price tag of $25 is utterly preposterous. In conclusion, this location receives two stars, one for its mildly amusing decor and another for providing a modest seating area for patrons to partake in their overpriced treats."

I was very disappointed with my first (and now probably only) experience at Hepatica. I came in to get half a dozen roses and it took almost half an hour, even though I was the only customer in the store. They also threw in greens with large, noticeable bug bites, without mentioning the added cost until they'd already charged me for the flowers. They even mentioned to charge my card twice, which was part of why it took so long.

Last evening represented the second attempt at consuming this particular culinary creation, yet unfortunately yielded analogous gustatory consequences. Specifically, the dough exhibited an unpleasantly raw flavor, while the exclusive availability of a crimson sauce for the pizza resulted in an excessive influx of acidity within my digestive system. Consequently, I shall persist in preparing my own pizzas or opt for establishments such as Domino's, which incorporate authentic spinach rather than relying on canned alternatives. The thought of consuming such processed produce is utterly repugnant.

While it was gratifying to behold vegan alternatives, they were profoundly restricted and the presumption appeared to be that vegans intensely yearn for meat and dairy.  The culinary offerings were satisfactory, but by no means exceptional.  The beverages were mediocre at best, and a single drink would cost more than the entire meal.  The servers were brusque and discourteous; the host who attempted to emulate a secret service operative with his earpiece and inappropriate attire was boorish and impolite.  It did not merit the expense, and I would unlikely return.  The din and fumes from the gambling establishment significantly diminished the pleasure of consuming food.

"A contingent of discerning gastronomes, including yours truly, opted to partake of a midday repast at this establishment on a Friday, and although the culinary offerings were undoubtedly of superior quality, the pace of service was somewhat lacking in celerity and attention to detail. Furthermore, I personally sampled their Blue Petit Mignon, and I must say that the quantity provided was perfectly suited to satiate my hunger without feeling excessively indulgent."

The food is excellent, of that there is no doubt, but the service recently has completely gone down the drain.

When we ordered from them we were told thirty minute delivery time - it took an hour. We ordered three gyros and more and only half the order was delivered. When we called to make this matter known we were met with a rude manager that could barely be bothered to fix the service issue. 

It's been an hour and a half since the original order was placed and we are STILL waiting for our food. Food that was paid for in full.

Absolutely terrible customer service.

I was experiencing an intense craving for some alcohol-infused noodles, and upon observing that this establishment was in close proximity, I decided to venture inside and partake in their offerings. However, upon arriving at 10:58, I discovered that the premises were still unoccupied, and thus, I chose to kill time by visiting a nearby dollar store. Upon my return at 11:14, I was somewhat taken aback to discover that the entrance remained unlocked, leading me to speculate that the staff member who had recently entered the building had done so with her personal belongings still in hand. My curiosity was piqued when I placed an order for takeout drunken noodles and inquired about the expected preparation time, which was estimated to be a mere five minutes. I found myself in a state of flux, unsure whether to feel elated or apprehensive about the impending culinary experience. It became apparent that the dish was prepared using pre-existing materials, as the aroma emanating from the kitchen suggested a blend of recycled oil and stale flavors. As a novice in the realm of Thai cuisine, I cannot profess to be an authority on its authenticity; however, my previous encounters with drunken noodles in San Diego have left me with a lingering desire to sample a comparable dish in this region. Unfortunately, this particular establishment failed to meet my expectations, as the dish was not only lacking in freshness but also imbued with an unpleasant odor reminiscent of aged mothballs.

HORRIBLE customer service. My sister and I went there after having no success at finding a brides maid dress from David's Bridal. No one greeted us. After browsing for 10 minutes I finally had to find someone to help us. I told her what we were looking for and she just brushed us off. It was a terrible experience. That alone caused them to lose our business. They get 2 stars because the dresses were beautiful and they had a decent amount of accessories to chose from. I would never suggest this place to anyone.

It was okay. The server at the counter was more concerned with the call-in orders, which I guess is more common at this location due to the small amount of tables, but disappointing. It took me over 5 minutes to place my order. After being seated, with no one else there, I retrieved my order and was satisfied, but not impressed. The meal was very greasy & the rice and egg roll were so over-cooked. Won't bother again.

"Committed $300 for my companion and me to gain admittance, it proved to be engaging yet ultimately, the cost did not justify the experience. Subsequently, it transpired that we were among the select few who had to cover the entrance fee, which served as a considerable blow to our financial wellbeing, given the exorbitant nature of the beverages offered.

An intriguing live production, certain performers engaged with the spectators, yet the ticket prices were grossly disproportionate to the actual presentations. If you are part of the fortunate majority who received complimentary passes, it may be worth your while to attend, but I would strongly advise against visiting this establishment unless you are accustomed to indulging in luxurious habits such as smoking $90 cigars lit with $20 bills.

The artistic display was captivating, and the audience participation added a unique depth to the performance, evocative of sophisticated street artists, a hint of 'Tap Dogs,' and a touch of 'Blue Man Group'-esque flair. However, I refrain from labeling it a scam, but the price point was unquestionably tailored for the affluent, failing to align with the substantial entry fee, particularly when the bulk of the patrons appeared to be enjoying complimentary admission.

Left feeling somewhat disillusioned and financially drained, it is a stage show followed by a typical nightclub. Envision a fusion of the marquee with a dash of cabaret and a subtle touch of Cirque du Soleil, and the cost for a pair reaches $300; there lies the essence of rose rabbit lie."

I like the ambiance and feel of Grassroots - however, the cook has a bit of an attitude. \nWhen I explained this was the second time I had come in and they were out of what I  wanted to order he said because everything is fresh. Ok-I can appreciate and love that! However, I was asking for a baked potato. How can you be out of baked potatoes? That seems pretty standard. He then went on to say they are doing pretty well.....what?? How about just apologizing for not being able to accommodate your customer. Lose the attitude.  Food is par - I would recommend this place for drinks only.

Stopped going to the Sunset road location in Las Vegas about a a year ago because food was not good anymore. When the new one opened up on Stephanie St In Henderson, we'd thought we'd give it one more shot. BIG MISTAKE! Steaks were not cooked as ordered, even when cooked a second time. Service wasn't the best either. Only thing good was the bread & salmon. Big disappointment Outback.....

Really disappointing. Dropped by here on a Friday night with my wife hoping for a good dinner but all we got was marginally decent food that was very pricey.

Cocktails were 10 dollars each, not bad, but didn't really taste too good. nothing special.

Servers were unpolished. Felt like they were all newly hired.

Food was not that good. New York Strip Steak was a small portion. Tasted all right, but not nearly enough for a young man. Asked for medium rare but got it medium. Wife ordered medium sandwich but got rare. Had to send it back (after waiting for 10 minutes). 

Overall, came out to 40 a pop, but was a lackluster meal.

I visited this establishment on a singular occasion, as a particular club affiliated with the University of Pittsburgh was hosting a fundraising event at this venue, and my expectations were not entirely met, specifically regarding the quality of the food items offered.

I opted for a pumpernickel bagel accompanied by a plain cream cheese spread, which, unfortunately, failed to impress me owing to its lackluster taste and unremarkable texture. The bagel itself was rather thin and unsubstantial, and the cream cheese application was sparse and haphazardly distributed, thereby detracting from the overall experience.

While the site's accessibility is a definite advantage, gastronomic aficionados would be better served by venturing to alternative establishments specializing in superior quality bagels, such as Einstein's Bagels or perhaps even Panera Bread's offerings, instead of settling for the comparatively mediocre fare provided by this particular business.

"Acknowledged, we are all cognizant of the merchandise; it has an appearance of being costly, and its expensiveness seems to be appealing to everyone...\nHowever, my recent experience with the customer service was problematic. I must confess, I have visited this store previously, and the encounter was satisfactory, but this particular instance was not. Upon entering the establishment, I noticed a sign positioned at the entrance, indicating a discount of forty percent on a single item for men, without any further specifications. (It was intended for Father's Day.) Consequently, I selected a shirt and proceeded to the checkout line. After waiting patiently, I approached the cashier, only to be informed that the item I had chosen was not part of the promotion, as it was recently introduced. I then expressed my desire to return the item. The cashier uttered some words, which I could not decipher whether they were addressed to me or to her headset. She eventually stated that they would still honor the discount. Throughout the entire transaction, the cashier did not make any eye contact, nor did she extend a greeting or express gratitude. In fact, it was I who offered a 'thank you.' The interaction gave the impression that I was imposing upon them by purchasing the shirt! The level of friendliness and courtesy displayed by TSA agents far surpasses that of the cashier's behavior."

While there are, indubitably, fewer sightseers at this end of the regal thoroughfare, it remains patently evident that the World's End public house is an establishment tailored to capitalize on its diverse and frequently macabre history, catering predominantly to transient visitors who are eager to immerse themselves in the rich cultural heritage of this storied metropolis. Fundamentally, this drinking establishment exudes an aura of inflated prices, seemingly oblivious to the needs and preferences of local patrons, instead choosing to prioritize the interests of those who are merely passing through, fostering an ambiance that is somewhat alienating for residents. My associates and I were rather disenchanted by the bar staff's inquiry regarding our touristic status, which seemed to imply that our response would determine the extent of their attentiveness and hospitality, leading us to feel marginalized and inconsequential. However, upon being served, we did enjoy a pleasant interval, although my inclination is to avoid revisiting this establishment in the future.

I understand why people like this place.  Their portions are huge and the plate presentations are pretty cool. 

They almost always have a long wait which takes away from the quality of service.  Plus, their food is greasy and not very fresh tasting.  They also don't have good healthy options on their menu.

However, I'm sure most people who are going out to eat in Las Vegas aren't looking for healthy meals so I get why people flock to this spot.

"This establishment represents a binary paradigm, wherein the culinary experience is either satisfactory or disappointing, with no middle ground. Hailing from Chicago, I was intrigued to compare the quality of Asian cuisine herein. Upon entering, Satay's interior exuded a sense of cleanliness and coziness, fostering an inviting ambiance. Regrettably, my visit was marred by the unfortunate circumstance of dining with a large group, which significantly impacted my overall impression. Our endeavors to await the arrival of every individual's dishes proved futile, as a considerable lapse of timeâapproximately 50 minutesâelapsed before the final dish was served, rendering our meals frigid. Ultimately, we relinquished our initial plan, but those who opted to wait were confronted with lukewarm dishes. \n\nMy order, chicken pad thai, a ubiquitous and uncomplicated dish, failed to impress, as its flavors were unremarkable and lackluster. In light of this underwhelming experience, I find it unlikely that I shall return to this establishment in the future, barring the possibility of a happy hour visit or similar circumstances."

Ok. The two stars are because the floors had many sticky diseases on it. WTF? Don't they clean the floors? But the bartenders did make me forget about the nastiness with the strong and cheap drinks. That was the only reason it didn't get one star. I'd go back if I'm in Champaign again.

Update - finally went to the new Lincoln Square Mall location. The decor is just awful, which is sad considering how nice the old place was. Cramped seating, depressing track lighting, drop ceilings, weird art right behind your seats so you keep bumping into it. They were out of the first two things I ordered (one was a special, so fine, but out of a basic bread-based app?)\n\nPasta took forever to come out, and my friend's was so cold that the cream sauce had congealed. Sigh.

During Restaurant Week, we reserved a table for six individuals through OpenTable and indulged in a culinary excursion encompassing a variety of dishes. Our party opted for the appetizer sampler, which featured an assortment of delectable delights such as fish tacos, bacon-wrapped bacon and eggs, and chicken pot pie nuggets. Although the chicken pot pie nuggets lacked a certain je ne sais quoi in terms of flavor, perhaps a pinch of salt would have sufficed, the remaining dishes within the sampler platter proved satisfying. For our entrees, we selected the crispy fried game hen and shrimp and grits, while the other half of our party chose the Niman skirt steak. Unfortunately, these dishes failed to leave a lasting impression on our palates, with the exception of the bacon-wrapped bacon and egg appetizer, which demonstrated a remarkable balance of savory and rich flavors.

Midway through our meal, we finally received our sides, specifically zucchini and mac and cheese, upon request. The dessert menu presented a duo of tantalizing options: freshly baked cookies accompanied by milk or a trio of refreshing sorbets. While the cookies boasted an undeniable charm, their quality seemed unremarkable, mirroring something one could easily concoct in the comfort of their own kitchen.

Upon receipt of our check, we were taken aback by the various supplementary fees we had not previously been cognizant of, including a charitable donation in conjunction with Restaurant Week and an upcharge for the appetizer sampler. My extensive investigation of the restaurant's online menu failed to reveal any mention of such an upcharge fee, nor were we apprised of it during the ordering process. Moreover, the restaurant increased the price from $40 to $50, rendering our dining experience even more disappointing. In retrospect, we would have benefited from selecting a different establishment for Restaurant Week or opting for individual dishes from the standard menu. Despite the underwhelming experience, the Jameson mule cocktail proved quite satisfying.

"Our culinary excursion to Rustic Cafe this morning was motivated by its ostensibly impressive 4-star rating, which we believed would be an accurate reflection of the eatery's quality, given the generally reliable nature of Yelp reviews. Unfortunately, our expectations were not entirely met, as the dining experience fell somewhat short of our standards. Both my spouse and I opted for omelets, which, while filled with various ingredients, were regrettably saturated with oil. Moreover, the hash browns accompanying my husband's dish were unpleasantly cold. Our overall satisfaction with the restaurant was limited, to say the least, and we were left feeling somewhat underwhelmed. Notwithstanding, the prices charged were reasonable. However, I must admit that my uncompromising stance on the quality of orange juice served at establishments of this kind led me to deduct a star from my overall rating, as the OJ provided was unmistakably derived from concentrate, a fact that I find difficult to reconcile, particularly when considering the $3 price tag."

"Underwhelming experience at Terzetto Steakhouse Las Vegas. 

The M Resort Spa Casino boasts an upscale eatery, Terzetto Steakhouse, exuding sophistication and elegance in its ambiance and interior design, reminiscent of high-end restaurants found further north on the renowned Las Vegas Strip. Despite its visually stunning appearance, the menu lacks innovation and creativity, offering only traditional steakhouse dishes. 

A group of seven guests were impressed by the exceptional service provided by their server, who demonstrated punctuality, attentiveness, and helpfulness, despite the restaurant not being fully booked. However, the culinary offerings failed to meet expectations, with steaks lacking rich beef flavor and a satisfying char. Although priced lower than premium steakhouses, the quality did not match the value. The sides were satisfactory but unremarkable. 

In conclusion, Terzetto Steakhouse presented an underwhelming dining experience, with disappointing food quality and unimpressive sides, despite its attractive atmosphere and excellent service."

I want Tom's to be better... but it isn't.  The place has a cool "Cheers" vibe, the service is excellent, but...

I ordered a grilled cheese.  The simplest thing on the menu, right?  WRONG!  

Those of you who are grilled cheese experts, like I am** will understand when I say: there was no butter on the bread and there was only one paltry slice of american cheese.  Seriously.  At least give me some cheese for my grilled cheese sandwich.  It's even in the title!

I am sure that Tom's has more options for non-carnivores on their huge menu, but I was in a hurry and didn't have time to peruse the menu at length or concoct a special order.

The worst part?  My sub-par grilled cheese, fries, and iced tea came to $12!!!  Come on!  They put a piece of individually wrapped cheese between two dry pieces of toast!

At least the service was good.

**side note: I really wish more restaurants would get on the options for vegetarians bandwagon.  No, I do not want iceberg lettuce on a plate with italian dressing, thank you.

Wow did this place suck. I came here for lunch with a work collesfur. I am from out of town but this was the closest place and it did nothing for me. Dirty interior, poor service. I just got a chicken salad and it was not memorable.

I have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on multiple occasions due to its proximity to my place of employment. While I have always found the service to be satisfactory, with the lady at the front being particularly cordial, my culinary experiences have been somewhat inconsistent. Although I have never had any major qualms with the food, my most recent meal was somewhat disappointing. Specifically, the shrimp fried rice I ordered for lunch lacked any discernible flavor, despite its appealing aroma. Even after augmenting it with soy sauce and pepper, the dish remained inedible. As an ardent admirer of fried rice, I am utterly perplexed by this turn of events. Consequently, I must now seek alternative options for my midday repast.

"Motivated by an unwavering predilection for exceptional fougasse, I hastened to Batch Bakehouse, eager to sample their various offerings. Unfortunately, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as the Madison fougasse failed to meet my standards. By attempting to marry the characteristics of a pizza crust and a pretzel, Batch inadvertently created a dense, chewy bread that did not live up to its potential. Despite consuming the roasted garlic, sun-dried tomato, and rosemary pretzel in disguise, I found it lacking in both texture and flavor, falling short of the optimal balance between a crispy exterior and a soft interior. It is my opinion that Batch would be well-advised to focus their efforts on less complex pastries, such as the delectable yet unpretentious "Hello Dolly" 7-layer bar."

Fuel Pizza (uptown) Gets 1 star for being in uptown Charlotte' and another star for good customer service. Too bad the pizza is bland and flavorless, the side salad is colorful but lacks a good dressing to at least put it over the top. I thought the combos were too expensive for a pizza so flavorless and unexciting. 

You can get a totally awesome tasting, HUGE, super slice of pizza for $6.50. Here you'll pay almost $8.00 for a drink, salad, and a decent size slice. I would say go to Sabarro's instead. You'll pay just a little more, but your meal will taste waaaay better. 

The decor is interesting, but looks unfinished. The restrooms are clean, but they look nasty, with graffiti and poorly placed bathroom fixtures. I would think a "theme restaurant"  located in the heart of Uptown Charlotte would have a better looking design. Its a mess here. Glad I don't own this restaurant, I would be embarrassed to have it in my portfolio.

Room was ok...nothing special. Staff was nice. Parking garage was very spooky! Pools were not impressive to me. There is an adult store right across the street....weird & creepy. Very convenient location but I won't stay here again.

"Initially, the service was satisfactory, albeit somewhat sluggish. The wait staff member exhibited remarkable cordiality, whereas the culinary specialist in charge of managing the kitchen operations opted to offer a pecuniary reduction on our entire bill due to the prolonged waiting period surpassing three quarters of an hour for our midday repast selections. However, the carbonated beverage and citrus-flavored liquid refreshment did not meet my expectations in terms of flavor, prompting me to return them thrice. The complementary tortilla chips and tangy dip were relatively palatable. I opted for the mixed grill consisting of both bovine and avian components. Unfortunately, the beef exuded an intense sweetness akin to teriyaki sauce, while the poultry was overcooked, resulting in an unpleasant dining experience. Therefore, it is unlikely that I shall revisit this establishment in the future."

"This culinary excursion is not intended for tourists; rather, it caters to individuals possessing a domestic kitchen setup. While meandering throughout the premises, I observed a dearth of vendors proffering complimentary tastings, and there was a conspicuous absence of readily consumable fare, such as one might encounter at numerous other mercantile centers. Perhaps my expectations were skewed due to my familiarity with Pike Place Market. Additionally, the venue itself was unexpectedly diminutive in scale, which was surprising given the region's temperate climate and the resulting abundance of fresh produce available for cultivation throughout the year."

After an abundance of initial acclaim on Yelp, I opted to partake in a culinary excursion to Nourish, eager to sample the fare that this purportedly health-conscious eatery had to offer. As an individual who does not adhere to a vegetarian, vegan, glucose-free, or lactose-free dietary regimen, yet still maintains a penchant for delectable and nutritious cuisine, Nourish appeared to cater to a specific niche that was previously unfulfilled in the local dining scene, with True Food being the sole comparable establishment that came to mind. Unfortunately, my expectations were not entirely met, as certain aspects of the dining experience fell short of my standards. Specifically, the unremarkable taste of their plain water prompted me to appreciate the variety of flavored waters available, while the salads, though undoubtedly flavorful, were minuscule in portion and priced unreasonably high. In contrast, the sandwiches presented a relatively better value, although superior options are readily available at numerous other establishments. Furthermore, the "air-fried" sweet potato fries, while satisfactory, failed to surpass their conventional counterparts in terms of quality, raising questions about the necessity of specifying such a detail. Notwithstanding, the accompanying dipping sauce deserves commendation for its delectability. The ambiance of the restaurant exuded a sense of comfort and relaxation, and the service was indeed impressive. However, the crux of a successful dining venture lies in the quality of the food, which, unfortunately, did not inspire me to consider a future visit.

My husband had the new 5-cheese Mac and Cheese with chicken. Looked pretty good and he said it was tasty.\n\nI however had the tried-and-true baby back ribs. Awful! Very dry to the point the meat was very cooked down and the ends were all but burned. They didn't even try to cover it up with globs of bbq sauce, which is a common stunt. Very BLEH... Won't ever get the ribs there again and highly dis-recommend them from others. Ew.

I genuinely yearned to relish this eatery since I possess a predilection for diners and dives, albeit not drive-ins, per se; and this establishment boasts the quintessential diner layout within an area of town, specifically Melrose, that I am fervently hoping will metamorphose into something exceptional, as it already harbors an inherent coolness. However, my culinary experience proved underwhelming. I opted for the breakfast sandwich, comprising eggs, sausage, and cheese nestled between a croissant. While the croissant itself was merely passable, the eggs, sausage, and cheese combination exuded an unpleasant oiliness and lacked any remarkable flavor profile. Furthermore, it was accompanied by a side of potatoes that failed to elicit even a modicum of enthusiasm. Despite my initial disappointment, I shall grant this venue another opportunity at a later time.

Wait staff and service was good.  My steak was excellent (Tabasco peppered Kobe flank). My friends duck was mediocre and the fat was not rendered. We didn't have time to wait for a fix so she just ate it.  The sides with it were good. The worst part of the experience was the fact that they charged $5 for hot water. 35 for mediocre duck and 40 for a steak.  I find charging for hot water ridiculous.

This store is like a Mega store. Maybe they are a little bit over they head because sadly the meats are not the best. They have meat on sale for 3 and 4 bucks and its coloring is brown to black. Meat should be Red. I will shop here but I will stay away from the meat. If you can get pass that the store is really ok.

"I recently endured an extremely unpleasant encounter at Picture People in Henderson, Nevada, which left me feeling utterly dissatisfied and taken advantage of. The pure white backdrop of my photographs conspicuously displayed noticeable scuff marks, indicating a lack of attention to detail and carelessness on the part of the studio. Furthermore, the staff imposed an arbitrary limit on the number of images I could store on my disk, without providing any written documentation or explanation of this policy. When I inquired about the cost of their services, I was met with evasiveness and a refusal to provide a detailed breakdown of prices, leading me to suspect that they were attempting to conceal something. To add insult to injury, they rejected my coupon for a $20 discount on a $100 purchase, citing an ambiguous and unclear exclusion clause that was nowhere to be found in the promotional material. The most appalling aspect of this entire ordeal was that the manager, who was supposed to ensure a positive customer experience, was the very person who displayed such unprofessional conduct and apathy towards my concerns. My husband's intervention prevented me from expressing my indignation and frustration in a more vociferous manner. Currently, I am gazing at the photographs, feeling saddened and disappointed by the whole experience. It is my conviction that Picture People failed to uphold their advertised guarantee of complete customer satisfaction."

Once again, the culinary establishment within the Station Casino premises has undergone a transformation in ownership and management, with the previous entity known as Guadalajara ceding its operational responsibilities to a new proprietorship under the name of Cabo. 
  Upon conclusion of my work-related duties on a recent Friday evening, my fiancÃ© and I opted to partake in a visit to the aforementioned eatery, primarily motivated by my desire to indulge in a celebratory alcoholic beverage, specifically a margarita, in commemoration of the successful completion of my training program. 
  Unfortunately, our experience at the restaurant was marred by an excessive amount of waiting time, as we were forced to endure prolonged delays in the provision of various essential elements of our dining experience, including the arrival of the hostess, the distribution of chips, and the servicing of beverages, resulting in a considerable delay before the gratification of our thirst and hunger. Moreover, I failed to receive a glass of water that I had requested, prompting me to consume my fiancÃ©'s beverage instead, and no offer was made to replenish our depleted supply of chips. 
  The young woman tasked with attending to our table appeared visibly overwhelmed by the demands of her role, while the supporting staff member, referred to as a 'busboy,' proved to be of minimal assistance in addressing our concerns. 
  Notwithstanding the aforementioned deficiencies in service, the quality of the edibles we consumed was merely average, with the exception of my margarita, which was expertly blended and presented a most satisfying taste experience. Additionally, we received complimentary sopapillas as per the restaurant's policy for checking in, which we elected to take away for subsequent consumption. 
  It remains a mystery as to why Station Casinos persist in altering their dining establishments, but it is evident that this particular transition did not result in an improvement in the overall dining experience. The sole reason for my potential return would be to sample another raspberry margarita, as it was truly the highlight of the evening.

"The quality of service is exceptional, the beverages are quite satisfactory, yet the culinary offerings are merely adequate. Specifically, the stuffed peppers and dates stand out as the most delectable options on the menu. Nonetheless, a pervasive odor akin to that of a soiled dishrag permeates the entire eatery, raising concerns regarding the overall cleanliness and hygiene of the establishment."

"Beer: Satisfactory. 

Culinary offerings: Subpar. 

It is my conviction, formed after indulging in an excessive number of culinary establishment rescue programs, that eateries boasting menus of considerable volume invariably serve fare that is, at best, unremarkable. BJs falls squarely within this category. 

Their menu, replete with pizza-esque items, led me to deduce that opting for a flatbread would be the wisest choice. Alas, the execution fell short of expectations. While the dish did contain tomatoes and cheese, the sausage component was conspicuous by its absence. A paltry few pieces of sausage-like matter graced the flatbread, rendering the claim that it featured sausage dubious at best. 

The bread itself presented a dichotomy of texture, with certain areas exhibiting a satisfying crispness while others descended into sogginess. This inconsistency rendered the overall experience less than satisfactory. 

Given that the primary item on their menu (i.e., pizza-like products) failed to impress, it is reasonable to surmise that the remaining menu items, sprawled across a whopping 12 pages (an exaggeration, perhaps, but not by much), are likely to be forgettable, at best."

We dined the last night of restaurant week(which we didn't know until we arrived). The menu was very limited, the appetizer of pork bellies(my husband's) was so greasy he couldn't eat it, his entree was cod and very bland. My entree, sea bass was overcooked and tasted bland and not very fresh.  The only part of the meal that we liked was the dessert.\n\nThis was our first time here for my birthday and was very disappointed considering all the great reviews.  Was this any off night, maybe but will probably not go back. One positive was our waiter-very knowledgable and friendly.

I spent a good three hours studying. Besides having a great facility for wifi, seating, and noise level, the service could use a lot of work. If you're in the service industry, people who apply for this jobs should be mindful that they will be working with people. In other words, they can be more friendly and cheerful no matter how difficult it may be. Other than that, I did enjoy my peach green tea lemonade.

"The gastronomical experience provided by this establishment is satisfactory, but the process of preparing authentic Italian cuisine is indeed arduous, as even esteemed restaurants such as O Garden may struggle to achieve culinary excellence. However, this venue purports to offer 'exceptional Italian food,' an assertion that is belied by its uninspired menu offerings and exorbitant pricing. The dearth of creativity and the prevalence of hackneyed dishes serve as a paradigmatic illustration of the pervasive trend in Las Vegas eateries where high prices, unremarkable ambiance, and unimpressive culinary selections converge, catering to individuals who equate cost with quality without possessing a sophisticated understanding of gastronomy. Furthermore, the bartender's cursory greeting, 'I'll be with you in a minute!', epitomizes the lackluster service that often accompanies such establishments, leaving patrons feeling undervalued and unimportant."

Bad experience during my last visit. Found few strands of hair in chicken curry, posted picture. Naan bread was really flat and dry. Not much chicken in curry . Lot of variety and some other food was good. Expensive compared to other buffets. Not sure if I will come back

This eatery proved to be a modest letdown. Indeed, it boasts a quaint setting within St. Mark's Square at the Venetian, with an ambient atmosphere that is quite pleasant; however, the overall encounter was not particularly satisfactory.  

The service was sluggish and unreliable. Upon being seated, the waitstaff informed us that she would promptly deliver water; regrettably, said water did not arrive until we had already received our meals and beverages, and only subsequent to our repeated queries directed towards our server. When we were presented with the opportunity to add parmesan to our dishes, the gentleman who inquired about it simply disappeared without a trace, leaving us to solicit the attention of our waitress, who was conspicuously absent for the majority of the evening. Subsequently, she carelessly dropped a sizable piece of cheese onto the table, which remained there throughout the duration of our repast.  

The culinary offerings were adequate, albeit their rapid arrival seemed almost too expedient, as if they had been previously prepared prior to our placing our orders.  

In light of this underwhelming experience, I would unlikely return. Given the abundance of alternative dining establishments in close proximity (it is Las Vegas, after all), it is reasonable to explore other options.

Arrowheads Applebee's offers a vastly superior experience, in contrast to the unfortunate events that transpired during my recent visit. Specifically, the karaoke session was marred by the DJ and his associates dominating the performance, rendering the atmosphere rather unpleasant. Furthermore, the presence of rowdy families and boisterous adolescent females, who insisted on vocalizing their renditions of Spice Girls hits, only exacerbated the unbearable nature of the evening. Thus, I implore management to address these issues and establish a more appropriate ambiance for patrons.

This establishment undoubtedly offers exceptional yogurt, particularly the oatmeal cookie variant, which stands out as the most superior option among their extensive array of flavors. However, their customer service approach significantly hinders the overall experience, as they opt for distributing samples by hand rather than maintaining easily accessible sample cups. I endured an agonizing wait of over five minutes to receive a solitary sample from the indifferent employee, who barely acknowledged my presence with a cursory greeting. Upon presenting the price, he concluded the transaction with a brusque demeanor, omitting even the most basic expressions of gratitude or well wishes. Needless to say, I won't be revisiting this location, considering the underwhelming encounter I had.

I've been to this place several times and LOVED it!! BUT.. this time; not so much! The only person that speaks english was not there, so trying to communicate with anyone was a challenge. I have always asked for \"Andy\" cause he does such a good job, but this time he was busy, so I got one of the ladies. The therapists were chatting with each other, and it was very distractive. The lady I had seemed very rushed and bothered. Not the best experience this time.. After my massage I walked back to the restroom and noticed a man being ushered in to a private room in the back with a door.. I thought this was weird and asked myself \"Why does he get a private room and my friend and I were out in the open and had to listen to all the distracting noises. I really hope nothing illegal is being done.. I don't condone this behavior and am not 100% decided if I will be returning.

"Underwhelmed, to say the least. Contrary to my expectations, I was part of a considerable gathering, thereby rendering my experience somewhat unremarkable. My tardiness, coupled with the fact that my fellow diners had already placed their orders, likely contributed to the server's lack of attention towards me. Upon requesting a beverage and food menu, I was merely presented with the former, and the server's subsequent visits to the opposite end of the table did not alleviate my thirst. It was only after an extended period of time had elapsed and one of my companions brought it to the server's attention that I was still eager to peruse the menu that I was finally able to place an order. Regrettably, by the time I had the opportunity to sample the culinary offerings, my fellow patrons had already devoured their meals. My selection, the apocalyptic pork with a side salad, fell short of my gastronomic expectations. The absence of moisture and flavor left much to be desired, and the haphazard placement of the aioli on the plate only served to further disappoint. The meat, too, was problematic, as it disintegrated effortlessly, necessitating the use of cutlery to consume it properly. In hindsight, I would have been better off opting for the soup."

"Two stars for the frozen hot chocolate, a culinary indulgence that elicited a profound sense of satisfaction, albeit accompanied by an unfortunate concatenation of events that transpired during the dining experience, specifically pertaining to the temporal duration between our arrival and the moment we were seated, which exceeded thirty minutes; the interval between requesting hydration and its actual delivery at our table, which amounted to fifteen minutes; and the additional quarter hour spent awaiting the taking of our orders, resulting in a cumulative delay of forty-one minutes before the consumption of sustenance, which, regrettably, did not meet expectations, falling short of excellence while failing to justify mediocrity, thus prompting the decision to circumvent the conventional dining protocol by opting to place future orders at the window, thereby eliminating the need for a reserved table and streamlining the process, all in pursuit of that delectable frozen hot chocolate."

"During the sweltering month of July, I opted to lodge at the Rio, primarily due to its proximity to a conference I was attending. Unfortunately, my expectations were not met, as the establishment presented itself in a state of disarray and neglect. The ambiance was tainted by the pervasive presence of dirt, mustiness, and mildew, which permeated every corner of the premises. Furthermore, the pool was frequently inaccessible during customary operational hours, much to my chagrin. The culinary offerings, while adequate, failed to impress, and the gaming area was characterized by a sense of dilapidation and squalor, evoking an unpleasant odor reminiscent of fecal matter. The elevators were consistently overcrowded, leading to interminable waits amidst a throng of impatient patrons. Reception and concierge services were similarly affected by lengthy queues, further contributing to the overall frustration. Our midweek stay did little to alleviate these issues, and the shuttle service proved unreliable, necessitating prolonged waits for successive vehicles. In light of the numerous superior alternatives available in Las Vegas, I would not consider returning to the Rio, despite any ostensibly advantageous rates. In fact, I would have opted to transfer accommodations after the initial night, had it not been for the aforementioned conference."

"Perhaps owing to its recent opening, this establishment has yet to iron out certain operational wrinkles. We opted to be seated in the bar area, whereupon our server required nearly thirty minutes to return and take our order after we had informed him that we wished to consume sustenance. Upon sharing the General Li's dish, we requested that they partition it into two separate portions; regrettably, they merely provided an additional plate, which, while appreciated, proved somewhat inconvenient and messy for us. Furthermore, the quantity of rice provided was insufficient to counterbalance the saltiness of the soy sauce, resulting in an overpowering flavor. To avoid a similar experience, it is advisable to request supplementary rice."

So so food. Had kung pao chicken and its just like every other strip mall Chinese joint around here. Lots of celery in the food. Wife had cashew chicken and it looked about the same. Actually if it wasn't for the nuts you couldn't tell them apart by looking at them.

"Subpar choreography and uninspired dance numbers were ostensibly compensated for by the incorporation of scantily-clad performers, an aesthetic choice that diverted attention away from the lackluster execution of the routines. Notably, Holly remained mute throughout the production, while her counterparts, a African American female and Caucasian male, assumed the responsibilities of vocalization and communication. Visually, the performance may have been satisfactory for some audience members, with the exposed bosoms of the dancers potentially eliciting a positive response from certain viewers. However, it is arguable whether the display of such physical attributes truly warranted the cost of admission. In contrast, the lavish and extravagant nature of the Wynn's La Reve production delivered a truly captivating experience, one that was commensurate with the opulence of its venue."

"I possess an immense fondness for Pottery Barn, to an enormous extent. Their assortment of furniture exudes timelessness and durability, comprising robust, solid materials that transcend fleeting veneers. As an ardent devotee, I conduct a rigorous examination of each piece by vigorously shaking it; if it exhibits even the slightest movement, I promptly proceed to the next item, as I seek furniture that exudes sturdiness and indestructibility. 

Notwithstanding my profound admiration for their products, I have assigned a rating of two stars to this specific establishment, and the primary reason for this lies in the realm of customer service, specifically, the behavior of the store manager. It bears a resemblance to the scenario depicted in the film Pretty Woman, where Julia Roberts' character encounters discriminatory treatment due to her appearance. Similarly, I have experienced dismissal in favor of more affluent-looking patrons, despite my genuine desire to furnish my newly inhabited abode gradually. Hence, I opt to peruse the display models on the floor and procure my desired items from either Pottery Barn Henderson or through online means. 

In my line of work, it is crucial to refrain from judging individuals based on their external appearance. Instead, it is essential to treat all clients with familial warmth and respect, thereby fostering a reciprocal sense of belonging and loyalty."

"Motivated by curiosity, I opted to sample the culinary offerings of this establishment, despite its modest patronage, consisting merely of two other customers within its confines. The hospitality of the waiting staff was indeed commendable, as they exhibited an attentive and affable demeanor, contributing to the overall appeal of the eatery's ambiance. The clam chowder, in particular, proved to be a gastronomic delight, worthy of praise. However, my order of Angel Hair pasta, accompanied by a Marinara sauce, fell short of expectations, as its flavor profile was found wanting, lacking the depth and richness one would anticipate from such a dish. Furthermore, upon attempting to combine the pasta and sauce, I observed an excessive amount of liquid at the bottom of my bowl, which, ideally, should have been drained from the cooking vessel, thereby preventing a soggy, unpalatable outcome. My dissatisfaction with the dish prompted me to return it, and while my child's cheese pizza was adequate, it failed to impress. Of greater concern, though, was the fact that, despite the waiter bringing my concerns to the attention of the proprietor (who appeared to be the individual in question), no effort was made on his part to address the issue directly with me, leaving an indifferent impression. Although the problematic dish was removed from my bill, and the owner bid me farewell upon my departure, the absence of a personalized apology or explanation left me with a lingering sense of disinterest in revisiting the establishment."

Went to ditka's.... It was good. The food was wonderful.  Shrimp cocktail was perfect. Pork chop was wonderful. Burgers were great. Dessert tasty.  The chef is totally on the ball... 
Unfortunately our waiter was horrible. One of our party arrived first, waited 10 min before approached! Beverages took forever, a beer was ordered 10 min later it arrived. Had to ask for bread. Waited 10-15 min to give dinner order. Had to ask for beverage refills. Gave the order he wrote it down.... Then we added a salad, which he did not write down....you guessed it, salad never came. The good thing was we weren't charged for it. 
Thank goodness the meal was comped.... I would have been totally pissed if I had to pay the $100.25 bill with the waiter we had. 
When your in an upscale restaurant you should NEVER have to ask for anything. (Period) no excuses.
Good food, bad waiter. Would give 2.5 if possible for the food only.
Take a chance... Eat in the bar area, dinner specials inn bar not available in dining room. My family usually eats in the bar and they say the waitstaff is great in the bar.

"While it may have been accorded an elevated status by some, this production fails to deliver an optimal theatrical experience, with mediocre humor, an underwhelming stage design, and a general sense of antiquation that permeates the entire performance. Consequently, I found myself mentally disengaging from the show midway through, rendering the second half of the production a tedious and unfulfilling experience. Therefore, I would advise against prioritizing this show as the sole entertainment option during a visit to Las Vegas, unless, of course, the ticket is complimentary and the prospect of participating in the audience-interactive elements, such as playing with oversized beach balls, holds significant appeal."

I've eaten at Hubbard Ave Diner many times.  Great pie, good service, average food, really inconsistent execution by the kitchen.  If they aren't busy, you've got a good chance to have your order arrive correct (as in get what you ordered as you ordered it) and hot.  If they are busy, forget it.  They really need to have an expediter in the kitchen.

"Consequently, the majority of my critiques will be predicated upon the culinary prowess and flavor profile of the edibles. I don't encounter exceptionally poor or remarkable service with great frequency; most instances fall within the realm of mediocrity. Now, onto the assessment proper. The initial bread offering was quite delectable, albeit its appeal waned in light of the fact that it constituted the pinnacle of the meal. A considerable portion of our party opted for pasta, which, in my case, was remarkably lacking in flavor (I had the creamy garlic chicken variety). I found it necessary to supplement it with an appreciable amount of sodium, a practice I rarely engage in. My betrothed's fresh tomato mozzarella pasta dish was similarly unimpressive, with the tomatoes displaying a glaring dearth of taste. The sole item among our sextet that elicited favorable comment was the chopped gorganzola salad. In light of the fact that I would prefer to support a locally owned establishment over a chain, I must confess that, given the option, I would opt to dine at Olive Garden instead."

My maiden visit to this establishment transpired last weekend, and regrettably, it failed to live up to my expectations. Following the placement of my order, an appreciable duration of time elapsed before its procurement. Subsequently, upon the arrival of our culinary selections, my order was inaccurate. By the time the kitchen staff rectified the error and delivered a corrected version, my fellow patrons had already concluded their repasts, necessitating that I consume my breakfast ex situ. The server, having removed the check from our table, neglected to proffer any form of compensation or apology for the inconvenience I had endured. Notwithstanding the palatable quality of the fare I managed to consume, I shall not be returning to this dining establishment, as the overall experience left much to be desired. In situations where a restaurant's blunder precludes a patron from savoring their meal in the company of their table, it behoves the management to offer some manner of recompense for the inconvenience incurred.

"My culinary preferences do not include burritos that have been subjected to moisture, as it utterly negates the fundamental purpose of said burrito. During a recent visit to an establishment that specializes in such fare, I was taken aback by the staff's insistence on exposing my unfinished burrito to heat via an oven, followed by their assertion that any additional ingredients could only be applied to the surface of the aforementioned burrito. Suffice it to say, I nearly departed the premises without consuming my underwhelming burrito, which consisted of mediocre chicken, rice, and cheese, and cost me a whopping twelve dollars."

We went for breakfast here while on vacation, although I didn't pick the place, I had heard good things but found it to be ok (I prefer to visit non-chains). It reminds me of any other breakfast at any other diner that isn't really memorable or great. I had the eggs benedict but whatever they called the version with avocado. It was ok, a nice change from regular eggs benedict but not as good as the menu seemed to make it out to be. Everyone else seemed to enjoy their food just fine (they got salads or some skillet things). \n\nOverall the wait wasn't too bad, I didn't care for unattended children running around and the service could've been better (I waited forever before I got my coffee, and I'm not happy until I've had my coffee fix). I'd say its ok, but I don't plan on ever going back.

I came with high expectations to this place of of a recommendation and was really not impressed. I came in after the dinner rush to place a take out order. The staff was pretty friendly but they didn't seem all that excited to be at their job. As for the location, there is both indoor and outdoor  seating which is nice. 

I got two veggie sandwiches to go for my vegan sister and I. As a vegan in-training, I made sure to ask for dressing on the side and no cheese and came home to find both on the side salads. I also found a hair in my salad which was a bit unappetizing. The sandwich itself was alright... a little soggy but pretty tasty. 

I think I will come back and give it another try if I am in the area.

Be prepared to drop some serious cash here at the Shoppes. (I'm wondering myself why they added an 'e' in shoppes - maybe for that added flavor of pretention, haha). They definitely don't mess around here with high-end shops like Barney's New York, Coach, and Burberry just to name a few. Built just across the street from the Wynn Hotel and their own bougie shops, I'm sure they aim to cater to that same crowd. 

My friends and I walked into Michael Kors and there was a purse that caught her eye. She picks it up and then asked an associate how much it was. He casually replies, "That one is $1400." Upon hearing this, she immediately returned the purse to the display, looks at us, says "Okay," and walks away from the bag. With our incomes, we can only dream about getting the stuff here. Unless you can afford all the things here and can actually purchase them - that seems like a lot more fun!

Nothing special about the decor of the Shoppes. But, there is one thing worthy of note, a waterfall that is two-stories high at the center of the mall. Be prepared to see lots of tourists taking pictures. And hey, why not take one yourself? 

For the hard-working middle class schmo and "normal" crowds, I recommend the Miracle Mile shops or Fashion Show Mall. I'm sure once the blazing summer heat kicks in, people will use this mall as an air-conditioned excuse to stay off the strip.

"My sojourn transpired on a weekend morning in excess of twelve months prior, and it serves as a testament to the eatery's lackluster service that the nuances of my visit remain indelibly etched in my memory. The establishment appeared to be plagued by disarray, with the proprietor, a female, vociferously issuing directives in a manner suggestive of being overpowered by the demands of her patrons. Perhaps a reservation at a table situated outdoors would have afforded us a more tranquil dining experience, obviating the need for an interior seating arrangement."

This most recent visit marked the second occasion on which I had partaken of culinary delights at The Parlor, and I had fervently desired that my significant other and sibling experience the establishment's offerings, having personally enjoyed a previous luncheon there during its initial week of operation. Unfortunately, the service we received during this particular visit was subpar, the fare was merely adequate, and the staff's demeanor seemed tainted by an unpleasant aroma, leading me to wonder whether it was the comestibles themselves that were responsible for the unfortunate olfactory sensation. Suffice it to say, I shall not be returning to The Parlor in the future, as it has become apparent that the venue's reputation has been unduly amplified, and superior pizza can be obtained at nearby NYPD or Pizzano's.

The individual who performed my nail care services exhibited a discourteous demeanor, and the gel manicure they applied extended beyond the confines of my nails and onto the surrounding skin, resulting in an untidy appearance.
