It is conceivable that I encountered an inadequate nail technician; however, I observed that the staff members displayed impolite behavior towards the majority of patrons who entered the establishment. Consequently, I shall not return to this salon.

"In light of the fact that the address listed did not align with the actual location of the establishment, and taking into account the lack of responsiveness exhibited in regards to offering guidance via telephone communication, it becomes increasingly challenging to generate an optimistic outlook regarding the potential for a satisfactory customer experience; thus, tempering one's initial enthusiasm and anticipation to engage in culinary indulgence at said venue."

Definitely overly hyped!

Their bread is good, but their meat is poor, they barely put anything in between the slices of their bread! I felt like I just paid for their bread. I waited in line for 25minutes for the sandwiches with high expectations. Instead, I was still hungry after eating the sandwich and grumpty for having to wait that long for something not so amazing. What was I thinking?!

I'm giving them two stars for their soft, delicious bread. However, if you don't like your bread being a little oily, you may not like it. You can definitely get better sandwiches at other local sandwich shops in Vegas. Definitely over hyped. You can definitely go if the line is short, but honestly don't wait in line. There are SOO many other places to eat in Vegas.

I like to think of Petal has \"hit or miss.\"  Lately it has been a miss.  I feel like I can try on like 6-10 things and nothing will work- it won't fit right, too see through, etc.\n\nAlso, every time I am in there I feel rushed in the dressing room.  They are constantly trying to take things out (I assume for shoplifting reasons).  But I hate feeling so rushed.

My oral cavity is experiencing an unpleasant residual flavor, which could have been caused by the unwelcome presence of a periplaneta americana, commonly known as a cockroach, that traversed the distance of the floor and eventually found its way into my culinary creation, specifically a burger. It is gratifying to learn that certain establishments offer complimentary avian appendages on Monday evenings during football games. Additionally, it is commendable that they were able to collect a substantial amount of funds, specifically $1,000, for a philanthropic organization that aims to provide assistance to local adolescents who are in need of support. Lastly, it is worth mentioning that our present location is Wickenburg.

I am not particularly fond of this specific branch, and as a background, I have been a patron of Chase for an extended period of time, possessing two active accounts. Upon entering the establishment, I attempted to cash a sizable check, only to be met by a novice accounts specialist who persistently endeavored to persuade me to open yet another account. Feeling pressured, I hastily provided my contact information in the hope that he would not overhear one of the digits. However, my efforts were futile, as the specialist continued to call me for a fortnight, leaving a voice message urging me to return and open the additional account. Furthermore, during my interaction with the teller, I inquired about a sign posted on the entrance window, advertising a feature that enables users to scan checks and deposit them through their mobile devices. When I asked if this service was compatible with Blackberries, the teller was unable to provide a definitive response, instead opting to search for the answer. While her diligence in seeking the truth is commendable, it is also reasonable to expect that such fundamental knowledge should be readily available to her. Lastly, upon entering the premises, I noticed an unkempt plastic waste receptacle positioned beneath the sole ATM in the room, giving the appearance of neglect over an extended period. This unsightly scene does not present a favorable initial impression, particularly for prospective clients who are considering establishing a new account.

We conducted an exhaustive search of this establishment prior to our impending departure, in conjunction with a companion, and our culinary experience was merely satisfactory, whereas the hospitality was adequate; however, the ambiance left much to be desired, eliciting an intense feeling of dissatisfaction that precludes any future visits.

"I have a profound aversion to the notion of queuing up to place an order, as it contravenes my predilection for expediency and efficiency in service delivery. Moreover, the absence of a greeter and the bartender's attempt to compensate by offering assistance only served to exacerbate my dissatisfaction. Furthermore, the cashier's preoccupation with their financial gains at the expense of attending to our needs struck me as particularly discourteous. Additionally, the lack of a receipt and the instruction to proceed to a table without any semblance of communication left me feeling perplexed and inconvenienced. Lastly, the height of the chairs necessitated an uncomfortable act of jumping in order to mount them, which further contributed to my overall disappointment with the dining experience. Notwithstanding the subpar culinary quality of the burger, which fortunately stopped short of being overcooked, the entire enterprise struck me as excessively costly given the need to endure a queue to place an order."

"Eh pizza, an edible flatbread typically topped with cheese, tomato sauce, various meats, vegetables, and condiments, is merely satisfactory in my opinion. However, it's possible that my lukewarm appreciation for this culinary staple stems from the fact that the delivery process took an hour, despite our proximity to the establishment, which is a mere five minutes away."

I have been frustrated more and more with Danny's Family over the years.  The constant up-selling is out of control.  I brought in a new car (2K) miles on it and they asked if I wanted a buff & wax.  I told them it was brand new and the sales guy still persisted.  Then of course the windshield chip guys.  I have a tiny, and I'm talking tiny, crack in the windshield and the rep basically said that if I didn't get that fixed today the entire windshield might completely shatter while I'm driving.  Serious?  The detail on the washing is good, but the up front selling is ridiculous!  I just wish there was a better alternative, but it seems like this is par for the course with car wash establishments.  Oh well....
Chips and salsa were good but that's where it ended. Dry meat on my tacos, my wife had a really bad salad. Chicken coated with sauce that was more like Italian sauce than anything Mexican.

I have to say St Rose Pediactrics is wearing super thin on me. Appointment time was 11:00am. 45 minutes after we are put in a room. 25 minutes later a doctor still has not come in. It's about time to scale back the number of clients and/or appointments you take. Look, I've even had enough time to write this review AFTER reading all the others.

Food was perfect. i got the galbi burger with house kim chi on the side. why the bad review? we came in with a group of 12+ we called in they accommodated us and had a warm welcome. So still why the terrible review...its courtesy especially when eating with people you havent seen in quite some time to wait for all the food to arrive at the table to begin chowing...2 of our parties food took 30 minutes later than everyone else's to come out. appetizers came in too fast which were fantastic (sweet potato fries) huge gap in between that and the entree. the waitress kept telling us the kitchen was behind and that the burger was being made. 10 minutes later she told us that they forgot the order. finally after 30 minutes the burger comes out. i dont care how many orders you have, the next burger should have been ours but no...we watched tables come in and sit down and get their food faster.\n\nwhen coming to visit vegas, my friend told me this place was great and he wanted to try it. sadly i was a little disappointed not by the food. but its not always bad food that ruins the experience.

Initially, I experienced an enjoyable outing as I was afforded the opportunity to spend quality time with both my mother and child, a circumstance that has become increasingly scarce due to my hectic work schedule; however, my satisfaction was significantly diminished by the subpar customer service and overall experience provided by the establishment. Despite its visually appealing interior design, replete with numerous televisions broadcasting various sporting events, the venue was only moderately occupied during our visit. Unfortunately, our server proved to be inattentive and unreliable, frequently neglecting our needs, whether they were minor or significant. It is worth noting that my criticism is not motivated by personal bias, as I am employed in the service industry and comprehend the challenges associated with it. In fact, the server herself acknowledged her shortcomings by inquiring if she had been neglecting us excessively that evening. The supplementary game section was merely adequate, as the machines frequently malfunctioned and required repeated assistance from an attendant to rectify the issue. The culinary offerings were also unremarkable, with my pizza lacking the advertised thick crust and necessitating multiple requests for additional dressing. Moreover, my mother's order of a wheat beer was mistakenly replaced with an alternate beverage, and the delay in procuring her desired drink extended for an unacceptable duration, ultimately prompting me to seek out the server and request prompt attention to this oversight. Notwithstanding the enjoyment we derived from each other's company and observing the game and my son's playful exploits, I do not foresee a future visit to this establishment in the near future.

"Our dining experience at this establishment was merely adequate, as we have had the pleasure of indulging in superior culinary offerings at various other sushi restaurants in Charlotte, Davidson, and Asheville. This particular venue failed to impress us with its uninspired menu selections, which lacked the creative flair and flavorful nuances that we have come to expect from such establishments. Furthermore, the ambiance was rather unremarkable, which only served to enhance our sense of disappointment. However, we remain optimistic about the prospect of enjoying a more satisfying dining experience at another restaurant, courtesy of a coupon obtained through the Ayrsley restaurant."

The waiter, despite my explicit articulation of my culinary desires, proceeded to deliver a meal that was antithetical to my expressed preferences, substituting a cheese enchilada and chicken taco for the beef enchilada and chicken taco that I had ordered; upon being made aware of this discrepancy, the waiter gazed at me with an unsettling intensity, querying whether I desired an additional side dish comprising of beef, an offer that I declined with alacrity and, in light of the totality of the circumstances, have resolved never to return to this establishment again.

Chips & Salsa were the only things that were good. Margarita on the rocks was ok, spinach dip was ok. Chese enchilada & chile relleno was ok. Husband had a chicken chimi, he did not like it but like the beans and rice. My friend from Canada like the beef enchilada & hard shredded beef taco.  Flan was tough.

The food was awful. My mushroom ravioli was rubbery and so unappetizing looking they should have been ashamed to let it out of the kitchen. My daughters chicken was so overcooked she could not cut it. The waiter told us we should have sent it back but he did not come back to check on us. Will never go back to this location again. Stay away there are a lot of other restaurants nearby try one of those

The only reason I give this a two star is purely because the customer service was fantastic. I will say this was a positive I experienced. I contacted Jay via email, and he got back to me very quickly, and his shop staff were very friendly. My cupcakes were not ready at the time I requested to pick them up, which wasn't too big of a deal, as everyone was very apologetic and sincere. Unfortunately the cupcakes themselves were awful. I can say that I have had better tasting cupcakes from Walmart. I ordered a dozen cupcakes, 6 with pink bows, and 6 with blue ties. The decoration did okay, but seemed liked something I could have done myself with some help, but the cupcakes were nearly frozen in the middle, stale, and the icing was hard. This could have been due to the fact that I was suppose to pick up my cupcakes on a Friday, but due to a car accident I was not able to get them until Monday. I did how ever send an email to Jay letting him know this Thursday evening. To me it tasted as if the cupcakes were made several days in advance and left in the walk in frig. Again, 3 of my cupcakes were practically frozen in the middle. I was pretty disappointed as I had heard great things about KAK, and was looking forward to using them in the future for other needs, but I will not be utilizing their services anymore.

The persistent and unpredictable nature of the internet service disruptions has become an exasperating source of frustration for me, with a total of three instances in the past week alone where my connection has been rendered non-functional due to purported "maintenance" endeavors. Despite the service provider's claims of striving to enhance the quality of their offerings, my personal experience has been marred by a complete absence of connectivity during these intervals, which have proven to be particularly vexing and inconvenient. Moreover, the frequency and duration of these outages have led me to question the reliability and competence of the service provider, with its subpar performance rivaling that of Comcast, a company notorious for its poor customer satisfaction ratings.

I so wanted to like this place, but I was not a FAN! I got the combo with BBQ pork and teriyaki chicken and chicken fried rice.  The BBQ pork was not GOOD at all, chewy and tough to eat.  The teryiyaki chicken was even worse, the sauce was a clump of jello like substance.  GROSS!  The fried rice was so soggy and the beans did not go with the rest of the food.  =(\n\nThey have a friendly staff and hurdle customers in like cattle.

Came here for dinner, waiters took a while to get our order and there was not alot people. We ordered \"The Theresa\" and the Corn on cob with chili, cheese and lime. The food tasted fine but i feel like it was overpriced, $6 for one corn on a cob with chili and cheese? come on now.

The culinary offerings were merely sufficient, with the quality of the fare failing to surpass the threshold of mediocrity. The hospitality, unfortunately, was subpar, with the server struggling to communicate effectively in the English language, resulting in an erroneous execution of our order. A one-hour time constraint further limited our dining experience, while the pervasive presence of ginger in every dish overwhelmed our taste buds. The ambiance left much to be desired, with inadequate illumination rendering the menu difficult to decipher. Consequently, we have decided against returning to this establishment, despite its proximity to our domicile.

I have been to this restaurant dozens of times throughout the years. I find the steaks are always good, but the seafood is really hit or miss. Was there yesterday and my lobster was totally over cooked. It was like complete rubber. It was barely edible. I should have known better to order it there, but I love surf and turf so I gave it a shot. Very disappointing.

Several people said I had to go here during my first-ever visit to Pittsburgh so I obliged. Whoa, I've never been this confused about why a place gets such high recommendations. 

Upon entry, expect a chaotic atmosphere. We were first told to find a seat ourselves, but then were told to be seated. Once seated, we waited for several minutes before anyone came by to ask us anything. However, after the first staff member showed up, another two came by within two minutes to ask us for our order as well. 

The food was okay, nothing spectacular. The one interesting part was that the fries came stuffed in the sandwich. As for the taste, really nothing out of the ordinary.

Why this place is so popular will remain a mystery to me. Was it worth going just to say I had gone?  Not really.

"It is patently evident that the quality of service provided by the hotel staff at Caesar's during my recent stay was subpar and utterly unacceptable. Specifically, upon entering our accommodations, we discovered an unfortunate surprise in the form of a previous guest's intimate apparel, which had been carelessly left behind. Furthermore, it took an unreasonable six hours for the hotel staff to furnish us with an additional blanket, and a staggering 24 hours for the procurement of extra pillows. To exacerbate matters further, the wake-up call we had requested failed to materialize altogether. It is worth noting that such egregious lapses in service are particularly glaring given the hotel's self-proclaimed status as a 'world-class' establishment. When I brought these issues to the attention of the hotel staff, their response was dismissive and lackadaisical, with the manager offering a flippant excuse about the limited availability of staff due to the holiday weekend. In light of these events, I would strongly advise against entrusting one's hospitality needs to this establishment."

Das Essen ist ganz ok, nicht berauschend. \"Typisch\" Griechisch halt, zumindest das was man hier als \"Griechisch\" bekommt, Gyros-Spie\u00dfe usw, meistens mit Saucen. Der Service ist leider weder freundlich noch aufmerksam, oft sitzt man 20-30 Minuten lang vor leeren Gl\u00e4sern. Preis-Leistungsverh\u00e4ltnis stimmt nicht so ganz, ist aber eine Alternative, falls man beim um die Ecke gelegenen Sokrates keinen Tisch bekommt und unbedingt Lust auf Griechisch hat.

I arrived at this eatery in the company of multiple colleagues, seeking a convivial midday repast. Upon entering the premises, I observed that the interior design was indeed distinctive and intriguing, although I could not help but feel that the abundance of black hues was somewhat excessive. Furthermore, the chairs appeared to be custom-made, and their unusual triangular shape caused discomfort while seated, owing to the pressure exerted on my lower back. Thus, I was compelled to perch on the edge of my seat, which was not ideal. However, the service we received was both prompt and cordial, despite the absence of other patrons during our visit. Each of us opted for a diverse selection of ramen noodle soups, along with an order of waffles accompanied by Korean beef, edamame, and miniature burgers, commonly referred to as "sliders." The edamame proved to be an absolute delight, boasting an intense garlic flavor complemented by a delectable dipping sauce. Unfortunately, my expectation for the ramen were not met, as the sesame tonkatsu broth seemed overly viscous and lacked any semblance of heat; it was perhaps tepid at best. The noodles themselves were only marginally warmer, which did not enhance their appeal. Consequently, I was unable to complete my ramen due to its unpleasantly thick consistency and lack of piping hot temperature, rendering it unappetizing. My fellow coworkers concurred that their ramens failed to meet their expectations in terms of temperature as well. The waffles were merely adequate and not particularly memorable, whereas the sliders were described as unremarkable by those who partook of them. Considering the culinary offerings and ambiance, I cannot envision myself returning to this establishment in the future, though I do wish it success in its endeavors.

This establishment formerly possessed an exceptional quality, but it appears that they have adopted a more parsimonious approach to their operations. The removal of their delectable queso fundido from the menu serves as a prime example of this shift in policy. Furthermore, the pace of service has become lethargic, and the once-around-the-clock availability has been drastically reduced. Additionally, the staff seems to take umbrage with patrons who request beverages, evincing a reluctance to provide adequate refreshments for those engaging in gaming activities. In light of these changes, it becomes apparent that there exist superior alternatives within the locality, rendering further visits to this venue unnecessary and unwise expenditures of both currency and time.

Sadly, we had a really bad experience. Our guacamole had a really strange texture and unpleasant taste and the tacos were hardly even mediocre. The fish tacos had no cabbage, cilantro, or lime, they were pretty lacking in general and were served with wilted green leaf lettuce. The black beans and rice had no flavor. The party at the table next to us had to send their meal back for being uncooked. It was just not a meal I would ever come back for.

My companion and I opted to patronize this establishment while the remainder of our coterie remained in their lodgings, slumbering due to the previous night's festivities. I was experiencing an intense sensation of hunger, yearning to consume any edible substances. Fortuitously, the smorgasbord had commenced at this locale around 11 am for a nominal fee of 11.99 per individual, excluding beverages. It embodied an Italian-inspired assortment of culinary delights, encompassing spaghetti, lasagna, meatballs, and Parmesan-infused poultry. Additionally, they offered a soup and salad course. Unfortunately, I must admit that the gastronomic quality was subpar. My clam chowder was unpalatable, and the sole item I derived enjoyment from my plate was the fettuccine. I somewhat overindulged in bread due to my concern about not receiving adequate sustenance for my financial outlay. Furthermore, I was taken aback by the chilly temperature of certain comestibles, considering that they had initiated the buffet immediately upon our arrival, and we were, in fact, the initial patrons.
It was ok. It is like someone who is drunk and this is what the craved for munchies. They combined a Panda Express with a Taco Bell into one dish. Also the fried rice was terrible

The best word I can think of to describe this place is 'meh'. I went here for lunch and I was underwhelmed by the menu. I ended up getting chicken salad with fruit. It was a small scoop of mediocre chicken salad on top of a bed of undressed greens with some grapes and two strawberry slices sprinkled on. When I asked for some dressing they told me there was some on the table. They must have been talking about the oil covered squeeze bottle containing a tasteless vinegarette. Not impressed.

I took my parents here mostly because of the view-but also for the food, which supposedly is good (really, 4 stars?). We ordered the peppercorn new york strip, one of the chewiest steaks I have ever tasted, the filet and salmon. The filet and the salmon were ok, but nothing special. The beet appetizer was acidic and did not taste good. \n\nSuch a shame-and very pricey. For 3 people without drinks it was close to 200$. Cannot recommend. Although the view is absolutely fabulous, that's why the 2 stars.

I held an intermediate stance pertaining to the overall quality of this establishment, as my expectations were not particularly elevated nor diminished during my visit; however, I must admit that the all-inclusive champagne brunch we indulged in was quite satisfactory, but unfortunately, my culinary experience was marred by a series of unimpressive dishes, including a lackluster salad with excess moisture, flavorless eggs, and an array of grease-drenched offerings that failed to satiate my hunger, even after consuming a subpar breakfast burrito, which typically would have been devoured with relish given my state of morning-after hunger, rendering my departure from the premises still feeling peckish and prompting me to advise others to forgo this particular buffet in favor of more exceptional options within the city.

"Samurai Sam's endeavors to create culinary delights inspired by the Far East, albeit with questionable success

A trio of gastronomes, including yours truly, visited this establishment recently, each opting for a distinct dish. My own selection consisted of three chicken tacos, which, while palatable, were regrettably lacking in substance, as evidenced by the dearth of meat visible in the accompanying photographs. A plethora of vegetables was present, however.

My companions chose diverse teriyaki bowls, both of which were abundant in rice, yet limited in other ingredients. Disappointment ensued, as the quantity of sustenance was nowhere near comparable to that offered by Panda Express, a similar eatery. Our total cost, inclusive of two soft drinks and a single water, tallied $24.70, rendering the experience a relatively pricey disappointment. Thus, two stars seems an appropriate rating, given the superior quality attainable elsewhere."

We indulged in a culinary experience at this establishment on Thanksgiving Day, which precipitated an unwavering sensation of mediocrity. The menu options were restricted and lacked excitement, while the cuisine was merely satisfactory. The hospitality, unfortunately, left much to be desired â?the food runners displayed a perplexing lack of familiarity with their duties, frequently confusing the intended recipients of their fare, while the servers demonstrated remarkable adeptness at avoiding eye contact and swiftly navigating past patrons. Moreover, the ambiance was tawdry and kitschy, rendering the overall experience forgettable. Therefore, it is advisable to bypass this venue in favor of more exceptional dining options.

"If you are experiencing hunger, or perhaps a hangover, and are seeking a delectable culinary experience that will satisfy your cravings, we would advise against dining at this establishment. While the ambiance and novelty items may be appealing, the fare served here has been described as subpar. We did appreciate the complimentary take-home glass offered with each beer purchase, however, the quality of the food did not meet our expectations. Our server was attentive and personable, but unfortunately, the cuisine did not live up to its potential. We cannot recall the specific dishes ordered by our party members, but suffice it to say, we were underwhelmed. It is recommended to visit this venue for its souvenir offerings rather than its gastronomic delights."

I have been to Claim Jumper in CA.  They have been great!  The one in Avondale is just ok, I have been coming back a few times and it still has not changed my mind.  The service has been just so-so.  One time my chicken was served under cooked.  I do not know if I will return.  I still love in Claim Jumper in Deer Valley.

On two separate occasions during the past four excursions to JJs, we arrived home only to discover that the submarine sandwich did not contain the desired toppings we had explicitly requested. Upon bringing this issue to their attention on the second instance, the establishment's representatives adamantly maintained that the responsibility lay with us, the customers, and proffered an unreasonable solution, suggesting that we return the sandwich and receive a replacement, an offer we promptly declined, thereby eliminating any future intentions of revisiting the establishment.

"The comprehensive encounter was unsatisfactory, characterized by an absence of warm welcome or explicit guidance upon entry. Furthermore, the culinary offerings, specifically the burgers, were prepared with insufficient doneness, failing to align with our predilections. The fare, in its entirety, lacked zest, rendering it unremarkable. In contrast, Smash Burger, located nearby, excels in providing delectable dining experiences. It would be superfluous to draw parallels with 5 Guys, as the disparity in quality is self-evident. Moreover, the management and operations of this establishment appear disorganized, casting doubt on its longevity."

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."

I believe I made a mistake in my steak selection, given the exorbitant price point of $60 per steak, I anticipated a superior quality steak.

Upon perusing the restaurant's menu, I opted for the bone-in steak, cognizant of its rich flavor profile, despite the acknowledgment of its tenderness being inferior to other cuts. Unfortunately, the steak proved to be disappointingly chewy, which was not commensurate with my expectations.

I have had the pleasure of indulging in superior steaks in Texas, which were not only equally rich in flavor but also more tender. The dining experience at CUT fell short of my expectations in this regard.

The sides were somewhat of a mixed bag; the mac and cheese, which was prepared tableside, was undoubtedly a highlight, as was the spinach complemented by a poached egg. However, the remaining sides were merely adequate.

The wine and drink menu, presented via an iPad, was certainly innovative, but the lack of multiple units for a group of seven patrons was somewhat perplexing. Notwithstanding, the cheesy bread was truly exceptional and merited the establishment's two-star rating.

The service was indeed impressive, though it was expected given the upscale nature of the restaurant. In conclusion, my dinner at CUT consisted of an unsatisfactory steak accompanied by mediocre sides, save for the outstanding cheesy bread. The cost of my meal totaled two hundred dollars, which I deem excessive for the quality received. Therefore, I am unlikely to return to this establishment.

Cold Tuna, frozen vegetables, unremarkable service!\n\nI travel constantly, so I notice the small stuff as well as the big stuff.  In my second trip to this Phillips I was hoping for a better experience tan my first.  Next time, I think I will save the dough and just go to CPK ASAP in terminal B.

The influx of juveniles, conveyed via multiple buses, and characterized by a conspicuous absence of adequate supervision, precipitated a state of utter chaos and disarray within the confines of the science museum. The sheer number of children, coupled with the dearth of authoritative figures to regulate their behavior, engendered an atmosphere akin to bedlam itself, replete with the unbridled enthusiasm and cacophonous clamor inherent to youthful energy. The concatenation of these factors rendered it exceedingly problematic for visitors to fully appreciate and savor the various exhibits on display, thereby transforming an otherwise edifying excursion into a decidedly vexing ordeal. It is imperative that measures be taken to ameliorate this situation, lest the museum relinquish its status as an institution dedicated to the promulgation of scientific knowledge and evolve into a mere playground devoid of any semblance of order or decorum.

Food was OK (food temps could be hotter). Clean restaurant. Upholstery was outdated. Service was slowwwwww! There was very few people eating here and only one waitress and what could of been a 30 min experience turned into an hour because of her slow response time. I would come back only if the service was quicker (Which is customary for a Chinese restaurant) and my rice and music soup was hotter!

"At the onset, I must express my unwavering enthusiasm for the delectable cookies and bran muffins that graced my palate. Furthermore, I must commend the accommodating and courteous service, despite the presence of a few discourteous patrons whose expectations appeared to be unreasonably elevated. However, upon ordering the chopped salad with a mix of greens and romaine, I was taken aback by the unfortunate state of the produce. The leaves not only exhibited advanced stages of senescence but also presented an unpleasant olfactory experience, which left me feeling utterly disenchanted with the dish. Considering the substantial cost of $13, I felt that such negligence on the part of the culinary expert was inexcusable. In conclusion, while I am generally not fastidious regarding culinary matters, the lack of attention to detail displayed by the chef in this instance struck me as a telling indicator of subpar standards."

"Alright, undertook an arduous excursion from Gilbert to Camelback, primarily due to the effusive acclaim bestowed upon Delux by Phoenix Magazine, which extolled their burgers as among the most delectable in the Valley. Upon arriving at the establishment, we opted for two burgers, a single serving of mixed fries, a lemonade, and a Diet Coke. The total cost of our repast, inclusive of a gratuity, tallied $39. While the fries proved to be quite satisfying, the subpar service unfortunately hindered our ability to fully appreciate the quality of our chilled burgers. In fact, Susan was compelled to seek assistance from one of the other servers, as our designated waiter seemed to have vanished into thin air, leaving us in a state of utter neglect. Everyone surrounding us, who had placed their orders subsequent to ours, was receiving prompt and attentive service, which only exacerbated our frustration. It is unfortunate that we cannot, in good conscience, patronize this establishment again, despite its potential for greatness, given the considerable expense involved in procuring a mere couple of burgers and the unpredictability of the service. Instead, we shall opt for more reliable and familiar options, such as Burger King or McDonald's, where we can confidently anticipate a certain level of quality and consistency."

"Indulged in an early evening repast at this establishment on Sunday, June 28, opting for it due to its proximity to our accommodations and my spouse's and my desire to sample the culinary offerings of the city with our discerning eight-year-old offspring, who boasts a predilection for fastidious fare. 

The hospitality we received was indeed prompt and attentive, the atmosphere resembling that of a bustling gaming facility, while the comestibles proved satisfactory, albeit at a cost that far exceeded their actual worth, in this patron's opinion. Specifically, the charge of $14 for a rudimentary burger, augmented by cheese and bacon, struck me as exorbitant, especially considering the supplementary fee for fries, which seemed an affront to my sensibilities as a consumer. 

In light of the aforementioned factors, I must regretfully decline to endorse this venue, given the glaring discrepancy between quality and cost."

"My experience at Pearl was somewhat disconcerting, as while the quality of the sushi was undeniably exceptional, the overall dining experience was marred by several notable shortcomings. Specifically, the presentation, service, and ambiance failed to meet my expectations, leaving me feeling underwhelmed. To begin with, the positive aspects of my visit must be acknowledged; the variety of sushi options was truly impressive, and the fact that they offered all-day happy hour was certainly a welcome surprise. Furthermore, the taste of the food was indisputably superb. However, the temperature of the food was so extreme that it bordered on being unpleasantly hot, causing us to feel nauseous by the time we finished our meal. Additionally, the plates that our food arrived on were noticeably chipped, which detracted from the overall aesthetic appeal of the dining experience. The service we received was also subpar, as our waiter persistently touched us in a manner that was uncomfortable and intrusive, such as patting us on the back or brushing against us unnecessarily. Lastly, the sequence in which our dishes were served was confusing, as our soup was brought out after we had already received our entrees, which seemed peculiar and poorly timed. In light of these various issues, it is unlikely that I will return to Pearl in the future."

"Placed my order approximately 8:10 PM, and subsequent to waiting for forty minutes, the status update still indicates that the order has yet to be transmitted to the culinary establishment. It is imperative that if your enterprise's primary function is delivery, then it should be executed proficiently and efficaciously. Unfortunately, delays in receiving and processing orders are commonplace, which can lead to an unsatisfactory customer experience. Moreover, the limited selection of eateries available for delivery within the platform is subpar, particularly in comparison to larger metropolitan areas where a greater variety of cuisines can be delivered promptly. Upon contacting their customer support, I was informed that an abundance of orders and a shortage of drivers were the root causes of the delay. A feasible solution would be to increase the number of drivers to meet the demands of their clientele."
"The culinary offerings are of superior quality, but I shall not return due to the subpar service. It ranks among the most unsatisfactory dining establishments, according to government inspectors."

Saturday night. Looking forward to this show and we got here before 8pm. Show started near 930. So freaking crowded you can't see the band.  Its so loud you cant hear the band.  Fire Marshall bill would close the place. So over capacity you can't move. Let alone get to the bathroom. All about greed. Need to stop ticket sales while there is still room to move.

"If I were to offer an assessment of this dining establishment, I would venture to say that while the culinary offerings were indeed impressive, the quality of service was subpar and detracted significantly from the overall experience. It is conceivable that my visit occurred on an off-day for the restaurant; however, even taking that into consideration, the discrepancy between the exceptional food and the lackluster service was striking. Initially, our server, Rodrigo, appeared to be making a concerted effort to provide attentive service, but this proved to be short-lived. Throughout the meal, I encountered considerable difficulty in securing the attention of any server, including Rodrigo, and witnessed multiple instances of tables neighboring ours having their glasses replenished with water in a timely manner while I waited an unacceptable fifteen minutes for a refill. This disparity in service was particularly glaring given the high standards one might expect from a restaurant of this caliber and price range. As a patron, I seek an immersive dining experience that encompasses not only delectable cuisine but also exceptional customer service. Unfortunately, my experience at SOL Cocina fell short of these expectations, leaving a lingering negative impression. In light of this, I would not consider returning to this establishment."

"Culinary offerings were merely mediocre, with the potential for enhancement, specifically, the hot wings and fries combo. Regrettably, the service was painfully sluggish during a peak period on a Friday afternoon, compelling me to assume responsibility for locating and settling my bill with the server. However, the beverage selection boasted an impressive array of options, including an assortment of bottled beers from esteemed breweries such as Miller and Coors, which partially compensated for the deficiencies in the dining experience. The ubiquity of sports programming on numerous televisions throughout the establishment contributed marginally to its appeal, thereby warranting a rating of two stars."

"An optimal geographic location, accompanied by passable lodging and dining facilities, was unfortunately juxtaposed with an uncooperative and discourteous team. Their behavior conveyed an impression that I was imposing upon them by requesting elementary guidance. The personnel's demeanor was utterly disrespectful, and their countenances suggested they were wretched. The spa was appalling, bordering on squalid, and emitted a pungent odor that made it uninhabitable for me to endure for more than a brief period. Following a futile attempt to partake in the supposed relaxation offered by the spa, I opted to expedite a thorough cleansing of my person in the sanctuary of my accommodations instead. The front desk was unresponsive, requiring an exorbitant amount of time to address my concerns, often taking between ten to twenty minutes on each occasion. There are numerous superior establishments in close proximity, offering comparable prices and vastly improved quality. I shall not consider this hotel for future visits."

I have been deliberating on articulating my thoughts regarding this establishment for an extended period of time. My spouse and I had the privilege of exchanging our vows at the Venetian resort, which boasts exceptional accommodations and services, thus, we make it a point to visit annually. On the eve of our nuptials, our group of six individuals opted to partake in an intimate dining experience at this quaint Italian eatery, primarily due to its captivating ambiance and our shared affinity for Italian cuisine. However, upon ordering a pasta dish, which I cannot recall by name, I specified that it should be served with chicken; alas, the wait staff neglected to include this crucial component. Upon bringing this oversight to the attention of our server, he displayed contrition and ventured into the kitchen to rectify the situation. The ensuing presentation of the chicken, presented in a bowl, raised my suspicions, as it appeared to be pre-cooked frozen chicken that had been hastily reheated in the microwave and was now intended to be incorporated into my pasta dish. This resulted in a comically disconcerting experience, leaving me feeling underwhelmed, and our associates were similarly unimpressed with their pizza selections, merely picking at them.

This critique pertains to the culinary concourse. It is utterly deplorable. The tariff for the quantity obtained is exorbitant, rendering it unreasonable and inappropriate. Personal experience has demonstrated that superior burgers can be procured at McDonald's establishments, and at a mere fraction of the cost.

Space is off the lobby with views of the pool and the Strip - great atmosphere. Vibe was sports oriented with lots of flat screens broadcasting the Wisconsin v Arizona NCAA game. \n\nBurger was good but the service ( Erin  from South Dakota) was not. It took 40 minutes to get our burgers and the Rings arrived at table cold and in edible. They comp'd our coconut shrimp app and the rings - which was appreciated. But would have preferred to have gotten our food timely and hot. The establishment was not particularly busy - so it was hard to imagine what the problem was....judging from other yelp reviews this place has service issues.

Maybe it was an off night?  This is the worst review I have given.  It is my Son's 26th birthday today so we met up with him at Brat Haus.  I had a really good feeling about this place due to it's current star rating on Yelp and the way it is designed.  It  has a really cool vibe.  The service and food were not acceptable.  The Scottsdale market demands good food and this place is not making the cut. My son ordered a Chorizo Dog and he sent it back (no flavor). My wife and I split a burger and they did not ask how I wanted it cooked. The burger arrived and it was well done and the only flavor I could taste in it was a strong taste of pepper?  It was horrible, I am sure they cook it to death because the quality of the beef won't allow them to cook it on the rare side.

I did not drink but we had plenty of beer lovers at the table who were ready to have a beer or two but they had a hard time getting a server to stop by and take their order.  

I tried some of the other's food and the only thing I found to be tasty was the pretzel fundido.  Not sure I will try Brat Haus again.

"My culinary experience at this establishment was not particularly impressive, as the fare served did not exceed my expectations. Specifically, the wonton soup was palatable, but the orange-flavored chicken was merely average, lacking the depth of flavor that I have come to expect from this popular Chinese dish. Furthermore, the fried rice that accompanied the meal was unremarkable in both taste and appearance, bearing a striking resemblance to plain white rice. In fact, I would venture to say that the quality of the cuisine was comparable to that of Panda Express, a chain restaurant known for its mediocre Chinese-inspired dishes. Another drawback of dining at this establishment is the presence of a waitstaff, whose services, while appreciated, necessitate a gratuity. Lastly, the dining area itself was somewhat disorganized, with boxes of supplies conspicuously stacked near the entrance, detracting from the overall ambiance."

OK sushi. It has been my fervent desire to partake in the consumption of sushi on multiple occasions. Whenever I find myself engaged in the act of perusing the aisles of various retail establishments such as Home Depot, Target, or Pet Smart in pursuit of items necessary for either home improvement or the satisfaction of my pet's needs, I experience an unwavering inclination towards indulging in a serving of sushi accompanied by a refreshing glass of cold Japanese beer. Furthermore, I have had the good fortune of discovering a dining establishment specializing in the culinary delights of Japan situated in close proximity to the parking area of Home Depot, thereby rendering it easily accessible. However, much to my dismay, my expectations have been consistently thwarted each and every time I have endeavored to sample their offerings, leaving me in a state of utter disappointment.

It was just ok, I got up sold for the hand wax and then tipped pretty well in advance to assure a good job, when It was ready the didn't really do a good job cleaning the inside, still had trash in the floor and door panels... Outside and tires wet pretty good though... I would say just use them for te cheap exterior wash next time

... this was the worst experience with a class/instructior I've had in my 10 plus years practicing yoga.

I decided, on a recent trip to Phoenix, to drop in to a Candlelight Yoga class. Sounded really nice and relaxing. Not ... so ... much ....   I just don't understand why there has to be pop music blaring in the background THE WHOLE CLASS  ?? How about some softer music? Or silence. I found it both annyoing and super distracting.

The instructor was very uninvolved and seemed bored. She paced back and forth in front of the room at the beginning of class ... she did not at any point seem calm, centered or really connected to what was going on with her students. It was like she was distracted, or tired ... or BORED.

What it was, and why I gave it two stars (and not one) was a good workout. Oh, and the studio is really nice ... urban, artsy, hipster style.

I guess this is what they mean by competitive yoga. Everyone decked out in lulu, trying to outpose one another. Nothing wrong with that, but not my thing ... and I would advise anyone who's looking for more depth, presence and actual flow to try somewhere else.

This was my second visit. I had a great experience my first time in- very personable waitress, great service overall and a really great sandwich. I ordered the cheese-stuffed tenderloin with their \"signature\" white sauce. Disappointment. The sauce was yellow (the waitress said it was because of the addition of paprika) but honestly, it tasted like cheese wiz but on the watery side. It did not have a good flavor- very bland. The pork was pretty tough for being a tenderloin and I wished I had a serrated blade with which to saw through it. Not sure what happened today in the kitchen. In the future I will stick with sandwiches. They do that pretty well. And even though I left half of my meal on the plate there was no offer to discount my meal- even by 25%, which would have probably made me happy enough to have not even written this review. Restaurants are a tricky business. You have to be great in the kitchen -or hire someone who is - and have a great business sense- or hire someone who does.

I stopped in here on my way to Cali hoping for something gluten free before my flight. It was pretty busy and only a couple overly stressed servers. It has a long bar, naturally as its Vegas, and then lots of little crammed in tables in booths with barely any room. 

My server was nice enough to point out a few things she thought I could have. There wasn't a lot of confidence as to what was and wasn't gluten free. She asked the kitchen if I could have the nachos. They said yes but in retrospect I probably should have been more careful cause I could hear there was a pretty significant language barrier. 

So I did go with the nachos which were pretty good. Chicken and a cilantro sauce along with the nacho cheese and jalapeños. There was a pretty good sized portion and I took some in a box with me for later. I never did end up feeling sick so I think the nachos are a safe bet here.

Other notes, I did hear another customer complain of dirty silverware, mine was ok. Food came out in good time but not a lot of server attention in regards to filling water glasses or getting you anything else you might need. Price was pretty average for airport food. 

Overall, it's ok. I may try something different next time I'm in the airport.

I procured two exorbitantly priced beverages - a vodka soda and a vodka cranberry - from an irritable bartender who callously disregarded patrons who had been patiently awaiting their turns for significantly longer periods of time in order to accommodate boisterous intoxicated females. It is utterly inconceivable that such an experience could have transpired, considering the fact that there were, at maximum, seven individuals present at the bar; furthermore, it required an unacceptable duration of fifteen minutes to obtain a pair of feeble potations. In retrospect, it would have been more judicious to have conserved my financial resources.

Just sad how this franchise killed my opinion of this restaurant chain. Quality has gone down drastically since opening. A great burger does not give excuses for poor service and quality. This is my last experience here.... one of my 3 combos of half & half included 3 onion rings and 14 fries. My expectations as a customer that has had Fudd before... 5 to 7 onion rings 20 to 25 fries. No combo my family ate today met my expectations. Dirty tables. Dirty restroom. Dirty floors. Nickel & dime the customers.

Terrible food and drinks. Cool restaurant layout. Service staff and managers were attentive. 

It was packed for First Friday, which was opening night. Bad decision. The manager who stopped by admitted he had not yet tasted the food or drinks. One more indicator of why everything was so poorly executed.

The craft beer selection is unfamiliar but mediocre. The mixed drinks were all made in batches, according to staff, and tasted watered down. All were terrible.    
                                                     
The appetizer menu has 3 chips & dip options including salsa, guacamole and queso. The chips were chewy, as if they were either not cooked enough or they were stale. The salsa, queso and guacamole were all lacking in flavor. The queso looked and tasted like potato soup.

They have 5 tacos on the menu. The carne asada and carnitas were very dry and flavorless. Temperature was between luke warm and cold. The cactus was unique, had a mild grilled flavor but was only so-so. The calamari tasted overly breaded and overly fried. The chicken was flavorless, as if frozen chicken had been reheated and some sauce had been thrown over it at the last minute.

Service staff and managers seemed to care, visited us on many occasions and ultimately comped our meal. They asked us to come back and we will. I will gladly update this review if food quality improves. I hope it does.

Again, I'm not sure why Yelp encourages double pages for the location, the only difference being abbreviations within the street address.

When the restaurant opened almost ten years ago, it was great! Management was friendly towards people of all ages, prices were cheap, and pizza and wings were excellent. I remember Amore working out a deal with my cousin's middle school for pizza Fridays, and all the kids appreciated it.

I'm not sure when the change happened, within five years ago, or if there was another change after that. After the original owner changed hands for the restaurant, things took a turn for the worse. Employees eventually consisted of teenagers looking for extra cash instead of the workers who put their heart in soul in cooking, delivery, and service. The food quality also was much more sloppy, and prices steadily raised over the years.

Now it's just another greedy restaurant. If Amore were in its original hands, it'd still be one of the best places for pizza in Scottsdale. Now it just blows.

"I refrain from frequenting Panda Express due to my previous encounters with overcooked vegetables and subsequent gastrointestinal discomfort. However, given the limited dining options during the renovation of our kitchen, I opted to give their Buckeye location a try. While my expectations were tempered, I was pleasantly surprised by the freshness and crispness of the vegetables, which replaced the customary noodles or rice in my entree. Unfortunately, the chicken and mushrooms, along with the Shanghai Angus steak, lacked distinct flavors and were somewhat forgettable, despite being palatable. Ultimately, while it served its purpose in a pinch, I would not consider Panda Express a primary dining destination, as my culinary skills and budgetary constraints allow me to prepare superior meals at home."

We entered the establishment as a group of four individuals without prior arrangements. Following a brief waiting period of approximately twenty minutes, which we spent at the bar, we were escorted to our table situated in the al fresco dining area. The ambiance was enhanced by live musical performances emanating from the lower level of our seating area, which contributed to a pleasant atmosphere. Unfortunately, this marked the conclusion of our favorable experiences at this venue.

The hospitality we received was unremarkable, lacking any extraordinary qualities. Specifically, the duration between ordering beverages and their arrival at our table was considerable. Each member of our party opted for a distinct entree from the menu.

Regrettably, the culinary offerings did not prove particularly impressive. Our initial courses arrived promptly, consisting of melted cheese and chips. However, the main course, priced at thirty dollars, consisted of only three modest tacos that failed to elicit much enthusiasm. Lastly, the dessert, a banana cream pie devoid of flavor, left much to be desired.

Despite the underwhelming experience, I would consider giving this establishment another opportunity in the future, as there are other menu items that pique my interest and warrant further exploration.

I was thoroughly not impressed by this place.  Vacant tables were not cleaned and there was generally uninspired staff and service.  The cashier didn't take my order correctly; she asked me about what sauce I wanted with my fish (tartar) and didn't put it in my takeout order.  Another customer approached the counter to ask for bread after it was left out of his dinner.  I subsequently found that it was left out of my dinner order as well.\n\nThe chicken, although nice and crispy, was pretty bland.  I'll say the same for the catfish (Old Bay seasoning, anyone?)  The cole slaw was not very fresh.  The Chicago Harold's left me with a better impression even though it was a hole-in-the-wall storefront spot.  I would not recommend that you waste your time or money at this place.

Panchero's Mexican Grill presented an intriguing dining experience, primarily due to their unique method of preparing tortillas utilizing a large presser, which piqued my interest and culinary expectations. However, upon further exploration of their menu and ordering process, certain aspects proved underwhelming, specifically the quality of their rice and steak, which respectively resembled Uncle Ben's cooked rice and lacked the anticipated tenderness and flavor typically associated with grilled meat. Furthermore, the medium-level spiciness of their salsa failed to meet my expectations, despite the availability of various hot sauces at the condiment bar, including TapatÃ­o, which I eagerly sampled. Additionally, my companions' chicken quesadillas, while satisfying, did not quite live up to their full potential, largely due to the limitation in cheese options, specifically Monterey Jack. Notwithstanding these shortcomings, the pricing remained reasonable and may warrant future experimentation with alternative menu selections.

I have had the pleasure of frequenting Rositas for an approximate duration of ten to fifteen years, primarily during the luncheon hours of the workweek. Their tacos possess an exceptional quality, while their enchiladas, though rich in cheesy flavor, have a propensity to induce a state of drowsiness. Despite this, Rositas has remained one of my preferred establishments, garnering a rating of four stars; however, my most recent visit, which included my family, proved to be somewhat underwhelming. The culinary offerings were merely satisfactory, and the service was subpar, with our server appearing discontent and neglecting to attend to our needs in a timely manner. Specifically, one of our orders was incorrect, and it went uncorrected due to the absence of our server for an extended period. Additionally, there was a considerable delay in receiving both the tortillas accompanying the fajitas and the bill itself. While I typically patronize Rositas on a monthly basis, my last visit occurred several months ago, leading me to hope that this experience was an anomaly rather than indicative of a decline in the restaurant's overall quality.

"The erstwhile Nabisco plant has undergone a transformative metamorphosis into what is now known as Bakery Square, an exemplary instance of urban revitalization. This once-forgotten enclave has been resurrected into a thriving hub of activity, boasting an array of cutting-edge enterprises such as Google, Urban Active Fitness, and a charming, albeit diminutive, coffee establishment (whose name momentarily eludes me). Sufficient subterranean parking is available, although it is advisable to avoid peak hours if you seek to avoid the throngs of luxury vehicle owners who seem to take great pleasure in vociferously announcing their presence via the incessant honking of their horns."

Way overpriced for the 3 pieces of equipment that they offer. My 5 year old was extremely bored with it after only an hour and and my 20 month old did enjoy the "Toddler Zone" for about 30 minutes. Don't forget your socks-they cost about 3 dollars a pair...

The only thing for small children (under 3) is the Toddler Zone which had maybe 6  padded shapes in it along with a little bounce house which mine really enjoyed, but that is it. The rest of the equipment is for ages 4 and up.

Friendly Staff and the place was very clean for the most part- bathrooms could use some updating and deep scrub.

Not worth the 22 dollars for 1.5 hours we spent there...would rather take them to Bounce Jungle or Bounce U for half that price.

Second time around at the Indian Land Red Bowl yielded an underwhelming experience, as the culinary offerings failed to impress despite adequate service. Although the Won Ton soup boasted a satisfactory broth, the Beef a la Szechuan lacked discernible flavor, and the Sea of Love seafood combination proved uninspiring. A ubiquitous dearth of piquancy and zest characterized the menu selections, which was particularly disconcerting given the eatery's otherwise pleasant ambiance and well-appointed interior design. We harbor skepticism regarding a prospective revisit.

I've had better Indian food, especially for the price.  But, they are in the old port of Montreal, someone has to pay for that rent!  I've also had better service, the waiter was a real jack ass.  The guy I went with did not leave a tip due to the poor service, and the waiter followed us into the street accosting him for a tip.

I ordered saag paneer ($17), it tasted good but it arrived in small quantity, and the naan, while good is expensive at $4 per piece.   Note that they also close between lunch and dinner seating's. 

I do not plan on returning to this restaurant

I had aspired to relish this establishment, as they had ostensibly invested a considerable amount of capital in its renovation. However, the culinary offerings and hospitality did not align with their architectural endeavors. I had intended to partake in a rapid repast at the bar, but the environment was somewhat disorderly, with barstools scattered haphazardly, which, although seemingly inconsequential, demonstrated a lack of attention to detail that I had previously overlooked. The personnel appeared to be a group of juveniles left to their own devices, carelessly dropping tableware and engaging in boisterous banter. The pollo fundido was unfortunate, possessing an unpleasant flavor reminiscent of flour and a superficial resemblance to a mushroom soup sans mushrooms. The dish itself resembled a fried fajita wrap, which only added to my disappointment. Despite my initial enthusiasm, this establishment failed to meet my expectations, and I sincerely hope they address their shortcomings.

I presumed that by entering the establishment and placing my order directly, I could circumvent potential errors. Unfortunately, my strategy proved ineffective, as the staff misinterpreted my instructions and included three additional items on the bill that I had not requested and which were substantially costlier than what I had originally intended to purchase. Despite harboring some skepticism regarding the accuracy of the total amount, I did not verify it until arriving home, at which point I was taken aback by the unexpected and exorbitant charge.

"While we have historically derived pleasure from visiting this establishment during periods of high foot traffic along Market Street, we have recently encountered difficulties in procuring satisfactory culinary options. Specifically, the quality of the hamburger steak, once a reliable staple, has diminished in quality, likely due to cross-contamination from previous grilled items. Furthermore, the Philly steak sandwich failed to meet our expectations, with insufficient cheese and underseasoned meat. Such disappointment prompted us to forgo ordering the customary wonton and teriyaki beef dishes."

"I placed an order for the culinary delight known as General Tao chicken, emphasizing my desire for it to be prepared with an elevated level of spiciness, as I had the pleasure of partaking in this delectable dish during my lunch break at my place of employment. Unfortunately, the execution of said dish fell short of my expectations, as the addition of a mere packet of hot sauce hardly qualified as the epitome of piquancy. However, I must commend the establishment for their judicious use of genuine poultry and generous portions, which served as a pleasant departure from the dubious practices of certain eateries that prioritize quantity over quality. Alas, the unfortunate deficiency in the preparation of the General Tao sauce has left me disinclined to revisit this establishment in the future."

"Indifferent ambiance with an outdoor sitting area of mediocre appeal, but a subpar experience with too much repetition in the hospitality department, leading to an unfortunate sense of exclusivity and alienation for paying clientele, thereby rendering it an undesirable destination for future visits."

Never ever will we revert to such an unpleasant dining experience, as the ambiance was tainted by the pungent odor of tobacco smoke and the hospitality was subpar, with the culinary offerings being merely average, and perhaps even surpassed by the likes of IHOP, thereby rendering it unworthy of recommendation to any acquaintance.

Hired 2 cleaners for 2 hours to clean an empty condo.  When I arrived about 3 days after the cleaning, the place looked pretty much the same as before, minus the alcohol, spare light bulbs and cleaning supplies the previous tenants left behind.  I was told that it was usual to take everything out of the cabinets for the new tenants.  How about 'if it is not yours, don't take it' policy?  Obviously, it was not garbage.  \n\nI gave 2 stars because they did clean the oven and the fridge and a few drawers, but other then that, I am not sure what else they did for 2 hours.  After walking around the newly cleaned condo with bare feet for 30 minutes, my feet were black!  They did offer to come back and clean again, but after their first performance, I figured it wasn't worth my time.  Never again.

"Gross!!!!

A dearth of diversity characterizes this buffet's offerings, with a meager selection of pasta, pizza, and Chinese cuisine available for a hefty price tag of $30. Furthermore, the establishment touts its'seafood section' as a notable aspect of the menu, yet said section consists merely of an array of fried items, including unpeeled shrimp. 

The pulled pork and chicken dishes were regrettably lacking in texture, having been cooked to a sodden state and inundated with copious amounts of BBQ sauce. Canned beans rounded out the underwhelming experience, and the salad bar's rigid adherence to pre-assembled salads left much to be desired. 

Exacerbating the disappointment was the subpar service, which bordered on neglectfulness and necessitated the intervention of a manager. 

Despite these shortcomings, the edibility of the fare and the appeal of the desserts, including miniature donuts, ice cream, and cookies, warrant an additional star in this review."

"Despite my recurring monthly payments, the quality of service I received was subpar and left much to be desired. The domicile was merely superficially cleaned, with a cursory swipe of dusters and mops, leaving behind an unacceptable amount of grime and dirt. The cleaning personnel seemed to be in a hurry, rapidly completing their tasks without adequate attention to detail or thoroughness. The tiled floors, in particular, were abysmally cleaned, as evidenced by the photographs I took after their purported 'cleaning' and brought to their attention on multiple occasions. Unfortunately, this company's approach to cleaning lacks the necessary diligence and personal touch, rendering their services unsatisfactory."

We disagree with the previous posting. Recently, we visited the 1902 Tavern for lunch. Upon entering, we noticed that our server seemed to be under the influence of either crack or speed. Our party consisted of four individuals who all opted for salads. However, we made an unfortunate decision to order a steak. The salads arrived 45 minutes late, accompanied by the return of our seemingly intoxicated server. Unfortunately, the steak was overcooked, cold, and of poor quality. The excessive amount of iceberg lettuce in the salads negatively impacted their flavor. We will not be returning to this establishment until the city of Pittsburgh takes steps to revitalize Market Square and address the issue of vagrants in the area. It is unclear where these individuals originate from, and it appears that they have no more productive activities to engage in other than loitering in Market Square, smoking cigarettes, and discarding trash for city workers to clean up. Our advice to young individuals is to follow in the footsteps of their ancestors and secure gainful employment.

"If Hometown Buffet were to establish a gaming facility, this is the ambiance that would ensue. Patrons would be required to remit a fee of twenty-five dollars and ninety-nine cents per person. The dining area, analogous to a secondary educational institution's cafeteria, would possess an atmosphere characterized by both auditory and atmospheric discomfort. A diverse array of culinary options would be available, yet their preparation would be merely adequate. One advantageous aspect would be the availability of alcoholic beverages, specifically Miller Light, served in individual containers akin to those utilized at carnival events. However, it is advisable to exercise caution in regard to utensil usage, as a solitary replacement would be provided."

Same as the first review.  It's close and near my place of employment but unfortunately every time I try it out the chicken tenders are always dry as hell. The corn and potatoes can be kept on a heat lamp for the most part but when it comes to the chicken it should be cooked to order. Skip Popeye's Louisiana and head to canes.

I was craving dim sum late night, and this was the only place that was open. Since I've been craving dim sum for a few months now, this place got lucky that I devoured everything in front of me. The bad news, I got food poisoning. I knew there was something wrong with the pork shumai when it reeked of bad pork and the cavier on top was still gooey on top, but I was beyond hungry and going through one of my cravings so I forged ahead. There is a limited dim sum menu for night time. Here is the breakdown: Edible and decent: sweet custard buns and shrimp balls. Reminiscent of dim sum: banana leaf sticky rice, shrimp potstickers and pork buns. Either bland or bad: pork shumai and shark fin potstickers. I heard there are much better places to go for dim sum in Vegas...so don't go here for it, unless it's really late and you are beyond crave monster status. FYI - I saw a family order 7 orders of fried rice...maybe that is what I should have ordered....

I called at 6PM to inquire if they had a \"kids section\" here because my youngest is 2. The guy that answered said yes we do, I said great we are on our way.  We got there at 630 and when we paid he tells us just so you know the kids area closes at 7PM.  WTH. Someone should let them know when people call at 6PM thats some important info to tell them.  Now why they close off their kids section is a WHOLE other problem... I have a 9 yr old and a 2 year old, so after 7PM my 9 yr old could go jump with the other scraggly teenaged boys and hoodlums that were showing up (urrgh) while my 2 year old does nothing. I did ask for a refund and then left and went to Jumpstreet which I recommend because they DONT close their kids section at odd times, its open during their business hours and is a lot cleaner.

"It is my opinion that this establishment did not meet expectations in terms of service and culinary offerings, with the staff exhibiting a lack of promptness and cordiality, and the food, specifically the hummus, being characterized by an overabundance of tahini and a dearth of lemon juice and seasoning, rendering it unpalatable, while the lentil soup was reminiscent of a poorly prepared version of Chef Boyardee's chili, and thus, I would not recommend this venue to anyone seeking a satisfactory dining experience, given the abundance of alternative options in the vicinity."

This eatery has a propensity for exhausting their menu items, a phenomenon that has been observed on multiple occasions. Specifically, my previous attempts to order the chicken fried steak have been futile, as it has failed to include the fresh bread that is purportedly served alongside it. Furthermore, during my most recent visit, I personally witnessed the waitstaff informing two separate groups that certain menu items were unavailable, including baked potatoes and a breakfast dish. The server who attended to our table exhibited lethargic behavior and took an extended smoke break while we, along with other patrons, awaited her return. It is worth noting that she did not demonstrate sufficient attentiveness towards her customers, which, when combined with the team leader's lack of cordiality, created a rather melancholic ambiance. Notwithstanding, the culinary offerings, when consumed on an empty stomach, are quite satisfactory. I must confess, however, that the unlimited hot cocoa is a delightful aspect of dining here. Conversely, I would advise against ordering the water, as its taste is reminiscent of algae.

Over priced for portion size. Good luck actually tasting the guacamole in their food.  Also look out for cold food, half way through my carne asada burro was cold. I will say that they did replace it.  Otherwise the taste of the food is great.

"This eatery did not possess any extraordinary attributes that would render it remarkable. We initiated our culinary excursion with spring rolls, which, unfortunately, failed to surpass the norm in terms of quality. Subsequently, I opted for the Pacific Cove salad, which, regretfully, exhibited an excessive fishiness that rendered its flavor profile somewhat disagreeable. Moreover, the presentation of the dish appeared haphazard, as each constituent element was segregated on the plate, thereby detracting from the overall aesthetic appeal. Furthermore, the crab and shrimp components seemed to have been hastily thawed from their frozen state, which only served to further diminish my enthusiasm for the dish. In light of these factors, it became apparent that the cost was not commensurate with the quality of the cuisine. Lastly, the ambiance of the establishment lacked any distinguishing features that might have elevated it above the realm of the mundane, chain-like settings that are ubiquitous in the hospitality industry."

"I had been fond of this establishment for a considerable period of time. Although I am occupied with work on weekends, I do not object to the fact that it remains closed on Sundays. However, I have encountered an issue with the prolonged duration of the checkout process, which typically requires approximately 20 minutes and occasionally longer. There are numerous checkout stations; yet, they are often understaffed, resulting in an inordinate amount of time spent waiting in line. It is not uncommon to observe a significant number of employees roaming the store, rendering the experience even more frustrating. 

In addition, this store was the sole location that offered Dill buttons, which are renowned for their superior quality and durability. As a regular user of buttons, I found this to be a significant advantage. Unfortunately, Hobby Lobby has recently discontinued the sale of Dill buttons and now exclusively offers their own brand, which is inferior in quality and available at a discounted price through promotions. 

Fortunately, I no longer need to endure the lengthy lines, as I have opted to shop online instead."

Ok, the selection is amazing.  But, after the nightmare of shopping on Black Friday last year (I had a certificate that I could only use that weekend, so had no choice), this time I planned.  This was last weekend.  I stared shopping at 10:40 in the morning.  Hardly anyone was there.  Merchandise was organized.  Not a single shopping bag to be found!  I found everything I needed.  Somehow, 4 items!! FOUR OF THEM!  

Since I was using a gift certificate, I couldn't return or exchange items, so I didn't keep the receipt (that I know of).  One of these items was a gift:-(  

Somehow, this didn't happen during the Black Friday from hell with tons of people.  Also, they let people bring their alcohol in there.  Bad idea.  Saw a girl go up the escalator the wrong way...

WTF??!!  It was not a stressful morning.

This was at the Forum Shops.

Forever 21 would NEVER let this happen!

We arrived late and they sold our room, requiring us to move to another hotel, and then move back the next night. NOT COOL! 

We did however get comped breakfast for two nights, and the "continental" breakfast on the executive level was much better than I expected. 

Executive level aside, the gym has very limited hours and costs extra to use, and so does the internet. To me, that's a bit disappointing.

There are plenty of restaurants with great food or even better food for a fraction of the price. It's just ok... My shrimp on my salad were so overly salted that they cut my tongue. Scallops were great, steak good too... Just not worth the absurd prices.

I have had the occasion to partake in the culinary offerings of this establishment on three separate occasions, with two of those visits being dedicated to indulging in the weekend breakfast buffet and a single visit for lunch. While the fare provided can be likened to that of Denny's, it cannot be considered particularly exceptional or noteworthy. Moreover, my experiences have been marred by an unfortunate encounter with a dish containing hair, which raises concerns regarding the cleanliness and hygiene of the kitchen. Furthermore, the service has been merely adequate, and the appearance of the staff members themselves has been less than impressive, leading me to form the opinion that this establishment does not warrant future visits.

"I am utterly dumbfounded by the plethora of 5-star reviews lavished upon this establishment, as my experience was anything but satisfactory. As out-of-towners seeking a convenient dining spot in close proximity to our workplace, we were disappointed to encounter a packed venue that necessitated a 30-minute wait, which, while not inherently problematic, was exacerbated by the humorless demeanor of the greeter, whose lack of amiability set a decidedly inauspicious tone for the evening. Our initial order, comprising a tofu appetizer accompanied by ikkura and an assortment of condiments, was indeed delectable, with the tofu exhibiting remarkable texture and flavor. However, the hand scallop Soy roll, despite its diminutive size and failure to meet my explicit request for added spiciness, was unfortunately overshadowed by the underwhelming quality of the edamame, which, having been cooked to an unfortunate excess, resulted in an unpleasant texture and a general lack of freshness that permeated the remainder of the meal. Specifically, the various rolls, including the much-touted'monster' variety, suffered from an evident dearth of inspiration and attention to detail, with listless ingredients failing to impress even the most cursory of palates. Furthermore, the tuna sashimi, despite being sent back twice, remained subpar, prompting us to query the kitchen's dedication to quality and culinary expertise. Notwithstanding the preceding litany of disappointments, the green tea crÃ¨me brÃ»lÃ©e, while undeniably delicious, was served in such a meager portion as to border on the laughable, especially when juxtaposed with the exorbitant price point of $12 per bottle for the sake, which, while admittedly of superior quality, did little to mitigate the overall sense of disillusionment and frustration engendered by our dining experience."

"Subpar service experience with too much repetition."  I had a pedicure, and while the polish appeared satisfactory, the remainder of the treatment was disappointing. The young man who performed the service seemed to assault me with cuticle clippers, leaving my skin feeling raw and irritated. Four hours have passed, and I am still experiencing discomfort. The massage component of the service was also lacking, failing to provide adequate relaxation. Furthermore, during the manicure process, both my friend and I were left sitting in the pedi chair, enduring an unpleasant and painful experience as the staff members pulled our arms out of their sockets. Consequently, I do not anticipate returning to this establishment for any future services.
