"The atmosphere exudes an elegantly refined charm reminiscent of bygone eras, characterized by luxurious table settings and high-quality cutlery. However, the service we received fell short of our expectations, potentially due to our casual attire, which seemed to convey the impression of a tourist seeking a laid-back dining experience. It is worth noting that tourists often possess financial resources and are willing to invest in their culinary experiences. \nRegrettably, the menu offerings appeared to cater primarily to meat enthusiasts, disregarding the preferences of health-conscious individuals. In response, I requested a customized salad, only to discover that it was insufficient in size and arrived with an excessive amount of unnecessary toppings. My entree-sized salad, intended to satisfy my hunger, proved woefully inadequate, leaving me still hungry and dissatisfied. Furthermore, my special request was incorrectly prepared, compelling me to observe my companion's dining experience while mentally calculating the quantity of carbohydrates contained within my napkin. \nGiven these disappointments, I must conclude that future visits to this establishment are unlikely, as there are numerous alternative dining options that better align with my values and provide a more satisfying experience for my hard-earned currency."

For the good: beer is cold, great TV's and the food is not bad BUT for the service OMG every single time it gets worse and worse. It is TERRIBLE and every time we go there are new servers. I have been told many times the turnover of employees is because the management is awful and they treat their employees BAD!!!!!  Time to STOP supporting This place especially because there are SO many great sports bars with great staff!!!!!

This place is just too hyped up.  I ordered a burger medium well and it was oozing red on the inside.  i could barely fit my mouth around it.  I'm sorry but burgers are 100% about perfect proportioning of quality ingredients.  If you want to make a bigger bugger, make it bigger in a direction that makes sense.  Burgers are my favorite food, but I was not thrilled by this place.  Stack'd in shadyside is better for 1/4 the price.  Also the restaurant was freezing cold!  I was sat at a teeny high table where our plates could barely fit even though the restaurant was mostly empty.  I didn't like the way the burgers were served also, they were crammed in a tiny basket that made it hard to eat.  Don't get me wrong this place isn't bad, but there are so many other places nearby that will give you better food/atmosphere for a fraction of brgr price.

L'hamburger steak est ok  mais trop ch\u00e8re. Il commence \u00e0 4.50$ mais peut monter facilement \u00e0 une dizaine de dollars avec les extras. Le take out peut prendre facilement une quinzaine de minutes (pour un hamburger). Trop de boucane \u00e0 l int\u00e9rieur aussi lorsque il est en pleine production.

Ok, so I've never had pho before this, so I don't have a benchmark. What I do know was the pho was really bland, so the second time I tried the Asian Invasion cheesesteak... $9 for a sandwich with nothing else, made on a cheap store-bought roll that tasted nothing like french bread. 

When my sister saw I wasn't all that enthusiastic about my sandwich, she offered to let me try her banh mi. It was super salty and on the same roll, with veggies that I thought were supposed to be pickled but lacked any bite.

Put enough sriracha on anything and it's edible, but for these prices, I want better.
Went for Sunday brunch. Edible items include bacon and funnel cake strips. Everything else appeared to have been purchased frozen from Sam's club.

I've been to this establishment twice.  The first time we did not have a reservation.  We bellied up to the bar and waited, and waited and waited...eventually a table opened.  I had no complaints that night.  The food was lovely as was the atmosphere.

Fast forward to tonight.  We had a 5:30 reservation for a birthday celebration.  At 7:09 we were told that we needed to leave as the table was spoken for.  Now granted we were winding down anyways, but A) this was a terrible business practice and B) yes the table was spoken for, BY US.  They knew we were celebrating a birthday and did bring out a very lovely birthday surprise for the birthday girl.  But for 60 bucks a plate I do not expect to be rushed out the door.

So now that we've gotten the service outta the way - onto the food, this is a restaurant after all.  Well, my meal of tenderloin tips was super salty but still pleasant.  The dessert (key lime pie) was really good.  My dining companions had the special - a prime rib/ shrimp combo.  They said the shrimp scampi was really good, but they've had better prime rib.

I'm just flummoxed, why would Beef and Bottle risk alienating customers?  I sure as heck won't be back.  Oh and I got sick from my meal - not sure if it was me or them, but after being rushed out the door I'm gonna say it was them!  I will not be back.

"Although Chez ma grosse truie cherie did not initially feature on my list of essential Montreal eateries, I ultimately found myself dining there due to the challenge of securing a reservation at a popular restaurant on a bustling Saturday evening. It appeared that this establishment catered primarily to large gatherings, boasting communal tables and a family-style menu that proved well-suited to our group of five.  

The service we received was attentive and impressive, but unfortunately, the cuisine did not quite live up to the high standard of hospitality. We opted to share several dishes, including a selection of oysters ($15), which were paired with apple ice cider vinegar from Vergers de la Colline. While they were not bad, I have certainly had superior oysters on previous occasions.  

The Chef Choice Seared Foie Gras ($23) was, without a doubt, the highlight of the meal. In fact, I would return solely to indulge in that particular dish once again. The sourness of the fresh grapes harmonized beautifully with the richness of the foie gras, making it a truly memorable experience. It's worth noting that I selfishly refused to share this dish with my fellow diners.  

The Whole Hog ($32/pp), comprising baby back ribs, smoked grilled pork chop, braised shanks, braising juices, and Parmesan cheese French fries, made for an visually striking platter. However, the majority of the meat proved to be underwhelming, with the exception of the tender and moist shank. Additionally, I found the roasted vegetables to be quite satisfying.  

In hindsight, the only redeeming aspect of the dining experience may have been the selection of locally brewed beers available in bottles. Specifically, the offerings from Dieu du Ciel managed to somewhat enhance the overall dining encounter.  

Unfortunately, I cannot envision a scenario where I would return to Chez ma grosse truie cherie in the near future, unless, of course, I could guarantee having that sublime foie gras all to myself."

"The culinary offerings were of satisfactory quality, however, our server, Maggie, displayed a remarkable lack of acumen and social grace, leading to an unfortunate series of events that ultimately resulted in a successful resolution through my personal intervention and discourse with the proprietor, yet, unfortunately, my dining experience was irrevocably tarnished, thereby precluding any future visits to the establishment."

Why do people eat here?  It was packed on a Thursday night.  We had to eat in the bar to avoid a 20 minute wait to be seated.  Everything on the menu is SOOO Expensive.  The only reason we stayed and ate is we had a $50 gift card.

Wanted to order something eat that we could share while having our cocktails.  The waitress could not recommend or guarantee anything that was gluten free.  So I just ate all the free bread and butter they brought and then we ordered dessert.  He got the ice cream sundae and I had a lemoncello raspberry cheesecake or something like that.  The waitress recommended it.  It wasn't very good at all.  I only ate a few bites because I didn't want to waste eating that many calories on something not so tasty.

With three cocktails (A mojito for me and 2 gin and tonics for him), the sundae and slice of cheesecake, with tip was $45).  I think that is quite a bit.

The best part was the free bread, no joke.  Service was pretty horrid as well.

Firstly, this establishment exudes an ambiance reminiscent of a national chain franchise, complete with staff who appear to be feigning enthusiasm in accordance with their prescribed guidelines. Notwithstanding, the culinary offerings, specifically the burgers, are of satisfactory quality, albeit the standard iteration boasts two patties while the diminutive version consists of a solitary patty. Furthermore, the fresh-cut fries merit high praise, perhaps ranking among the finest in Tempe. While we may consider returning, it is unlikely that we would venture out of our way to do so.

"The accommodations were aesthetically pleasing, sanitary, and provided an ambient atmosphere for relaxation. However, the familial unit residing above us exhibited boisterous behavior, engaging in nocturnal activities that transcended the threshold of auditory tolerance, thereby diminishing our capacity to enjoy a restful slumber. Specifically, the sounds of consumption, footsteps, and disagreements permeated the floor, effectively mitigating the quality of our sleep. Furthermore, the parking situation was problematic, as there were limited spaces available near the edifice, compelling us to abandon our vehicles at a distance and navigate the remaining expanse by foot. This proved particularly challenging for our geriatric companions, who struggled with ambulation and required assistance in traversing the terrain. Additionally, the WiFi connectivity was restricted, necessitating a financial investment of forty dollars for a single device over the course of seven days, which seemed exorbitant given that complimentary internet access was offered at other establishments we visited during our travels. Lastly, one of our associates was approached at the point of entry and invited to participate in a timeshare presentation, but the representative's demeanor transformed abruptly when informed that attendance was uncertain, culminating in a brusque dismissal and an admonition to enjoy the day."

My wife goes here ever chance she get, but I refuse to go with her. Coffee deserves 5 stars but the chick behind the counter is so rude. I refuse to spend money at a place that lets it indie hipster staff treat regular Joe's like my self rudely.

We have had the misfortune of experiencing subpar service on three separate occasions during our visits to this establishment, which has unfortunately diminished our overall satisfaction with our dining experience despite the breathtaking panorama that the restaurant boasts.

Had dinner there last week ...... went there with great anticipation because of its legendary status in New York ....... mildly disappointing but easily correctable .... the place itself is fun ... its old-timey Italian restaurant decor with all the celeb photos hung on wall ... very professional and most attentive service...... good food but not great ...... seems like the kitchen is trying to '' play it safe'' and the result is a very ample portion of just slightly above average entrees ...... my veal dish was good but not as good as I had hoped based on the Rao's reputation ( hype ? ) .... so they have a nice,fun setting,great servers and decent offerings but if they really got into that kitchen and tweaked their prep a bit ...... they'd improve on a product that is just a tad on the bland side. I hope they address this as it is a fun restaurant with good personnel .

"Indifference was my initial reaction, as the culinary offerings, although of satisfactory quality, did not seem to justify the cost, particularly in relation to the hot dogs, which, while flavorful and abundant in toppings, failed to meet my expectations regarding value for money. Furthermore, my anticipation of experiencing the fabled Poutine, a dish revered by my Canadian counterparts, was unfortunately met with disappointment, thereby necessitating a future visit to Quebec to sample the delicacy in its authentic form."

My #1 pet peeve with this airport is that you must board a tram everytime.  Why?  SFO is bigger yet there's no tram.  

While waiting to fly home, the jacked up PA system near gate D1 was ear-piercingly loud and distorted.  Are they oblivious to this?  They even have to add the 3 loud ass toots after their deafening message just for added pleasure. Everyone was covering their ears from the shreiking.  Are they that busy with checking to see if people are sneaking water bottles onboard that they don't know this?

Also, why is it that a taxi ride to the hotel is $25 and only $15 to the airport?  Isn't it essentially the same distance?

Came here yesterday and didn't have a great experience like I've had at many other Yard House Restaurants before.  We were able to be seated right away +1 star.  
 
Our waiter came over and we placed our order. Lunch special with pizza and tomato basil soup, kids meal with pizza and veggies and ahi appetizer which  was being eaten for lunch and not appetizer.  My cousin also ordered a beer, which took forever to come out.  The waiter finally came over after about 10 minutes and said they had to replace the keg.  

Beer finally came, next we waited for our food... And waited, and waited and waited!  Thank goodness I had snacks in my bag for my 3 year old to settle him while we waited.  When the food did arrive, the cheese on the pizza looked old and dry, as if it had been sitting under the heat lamp for quite awhile.  We only had a few bites and moved on to the soup, which my 3 year old and I basically split because it was delicious +1 star!

Threw the leftover pizza away since it was gross.

Wait wait wait... this place is still open? No, seriously? Um. I'm confused. No, I mean like, in business? Operating? A manager? Employees? Hours of operation? Transact monies? Uhhhhh. You sure? Because when you define \"Air\" as a smoker's patio and \"Earth\" as weird alien shit on the walls and \"Fire\" as the burning of your ear drums and \"Water\" as a place to buy really expensive drinks that dehydrate you, I just can't really comprehend how our $30k millionaire ballers can afford to keep this place going, even in an economic environment that protects only their class. But that's why I'm a $20k impoverished sycophantic parasite on our society. No business sense. \n\nTwo stars for the money they put into this place in the first place. And the elevator to the private VIP bullshit area. Classy. Retarded classiness.

45 minutes d attente, au lieu des 20 annoncees, pour \u00eatre en terrasse, la salle \u00e9tant vraiment trop bruyante, \u00e7a.commencait mal... \"Les meilleures pizzas de Montr\u00e9al\", bon, ca valait surement le coup d attendre. Et bien non... La pizza du chef n'avait aucun interet tout comme les pates d un de mes amis, noy\u00e9s dans une sauce grasse insipide... une addition elevee m'a convaincu de me mettre que deux \u00e9toiles, le seul int\u00e9r\u00eat \u00e9tant la terrasse, agr\u00e9able. Bref, une adresse \u00e0 \u00e9viter, pour qui aime un tant soit peu la cuisine italienne!

"The precise delineation of two celestial bodies: MEH. I'VE ENJOYED SUPERIOR CULINARY EXPERIENCES. \n\nFor an individual who has an unwavering fondness for Korean BBQ and partakes in it with remarkable frequency, I would not advocate for this establishment as a suitable location for satisfying one's KBBQ cravings. Throughout my extensive exploration of diverse KBBQ locales, I have yet to encounter a restaurant that charges such exorbitant prices, which, regrettably, seems to be a common trait among businesses situated within the Strip. Given the prohibitive cost of a meager serving of kogi, I opted to procure dolsot bimbimbap instead. Unfortunately, this particular dolsot bimbimbap proved to be the most expensive instance of its kind that I have had the misfortune of encountering. The eatery, in general, lacked any distinguishing qualities or exceptional characteristics. In light of these factors, I shall confer upon it a rating of two stars, primarily due to the passable quality of the culinary offerings and the waitstaff's commendable honesty regarding the portion size of the KBBQ meat. Needless to say, I do not intend to revisit this establishment in the future."

"There are two categories of individuals who frequent this venue: senior citizens and those possessing complimentary passes. We fell into the latter category, courtesy of my fiancÃ©'s employer, who generously provided us with a pair of tickets to a Regal cinema. Unfortunately, the Regal chain does not have an extensive presence in this particular region, thereby limiting our options. However, we opted to utilize the passes at this establishment, despite its somewhat antiquated nature. The theater itself was rather desolate, with a limited number of staff members present, including a lone individual manning the concession stand and a single employee stationed at the ticket counter. The auditorium itself was modest in size, with a less-than-impressive audio experience and a distinctly retro ambiance. In fact, the seating arrangement was such that one had to ascend a slight incline in order to reach the screen, which struck me as somewhat unusual. Were it not for the complimentary passes, we likely would have elected to depart and seek alternative entertainment. Instead, we chose to persevere and endure the less-than-ideal conditions. Our intention now is to visit the Northsight location, where the second set of tickets can be redeemed. My assumption had been that the majority of Scottsdale was characterized by upscale surroundings and a significant population, rather than the sparse, geriatric demographic that we encountered in Sun City. It has become apparent that this establishment is in need of a radical transformation or, perhaps, even retirement."

This is NOT a 3 star hotel/resort. It is a 2 at best. The rooms smell musty, the interior and linens are not clean, and the entire place just looks worn out. Maybe back in the day it was something more but not now. The beds were lumpy and the linens were of questionable cleanliness which made me look for bed bugs - which there were none although there some type of small critter in the tub. On the plus side, the Speakman shower heads are great as was the water pressure and hot water.  Still, not a place to which I will return.

We found ourselves on the aforementioned side of town, eager to indulge in the culinary delights that this establishment purportedly offered, specifically the zucchini fingers that we had heard so much about. However, upon our return, we were dismayed to discover that the aforementioned zucchini fingers lacked the crispiness that we had anticipated, instead displaying a remarkable propensity to bend in half when lifted, which rather detracted from the overall experience. Furthermore, we were taken aback by the absence of tatziki sauce, which we had been led to believe was an integral component of the dish, only to be presented with a minuscule container for an additional fee. This development struck us as somewhat analogous to visiting an American diner and being charged extra for ketchup, which seemed incongruous with our preconceived notions of what constituted a satisfactory dining experience. 
Additionally, we observed that the zucchini appeared to be in dire need of salt, a deficiency that significantly impacted our enjoyment of the dish. Our beef and lamb gyro, while adequate, was regrettably characterized by a notable dryness, while my husband's Oscar burger, renowned for its inclusion of pastrami, suffered from a similar lack of moisture. The accompanying salad, ostensibly intended as a palliative to the uninspiring fare that preceded it, was instead replete with an excessive quantity of dressing, eliciting a response akin to alarm rather than gratitude. In light of these developments, we reluctantly concluded that a future visit to this establishment would not be forthcoming, as more satisfying Greek cuisine could be obtained at Stephanos, a venue situated closer to our domicile.

"If you desire to consume a beverage prior to having expended three hundred dollars within the establishment's gaming devices, it is imperative that you vocalize your request with clarity and conviction. Unfortunately, securing the attention of a server can be a formidable task, particularly during peak hours or after ten o'clock in the evening when the atmosphere becomes increasingly vibrant. Upon successfully procuring your libation, it may be advisable to request a double portion, given the diminutive nature of the standard serving size. Notwithstanding the aforementioned challenges, this venue does offer an exceptional 'Rooster' salad, which regrettably may not appeal to the majority of habitual clientele, who appear to be more preoccupied with maintaining a fastidious household than indulging in culinary delights. Their demeanor is often characterized by an unwavering focus on their personal hygiene and an unsettling intensity, leading one to surmise that they may have temporarily abandoned their arduous efforts to scrub their grout and opted to display their bruxism in a public setting instead."

They ought to consider incorporating the flies as a culinary option on their menu, as our dining experience during the afternoon hours was significantly impaired due to an excessive number of airborne pests, which rendered the food essentially unpalatable; thus, it is advisable to prepare oneself for such eventualities.

I was sadly disappointed, after reading all the excellent I thought it was shoe in. not so much. Long wait for food then it was just ok. Id rather pay more for food that tastes amazing and doesn't take forever to get.

I was a skeptic of this chemist of brew.

Needless to say, I wasn't too far off.  This is great for a night out with the boys to watch the game.  That's all I can say since I wouldn't recommend coming here to chat.  

I ordered me a beer and some fried fish and chips.  I don't like soggy food, but I guess that's how it comes here.  The fried fish was laid on top of my garlic fries, which were way greasy.  As the fish and fries came together it was a hot soggy mess.  I might want to add tasteless too.

The place definitely has a pub look and feel.  Live music when I came that night, but the football game was going on too.  Rowdy fans and loud music doesn't go well, but I guess it wouldn't matter after a few drinks.  Our service was good, but splitting checks again can be a challenge. - Enjoy!

I personally partook in their midday culinary offering, anticipating a diverse array of gastronomical delights, only to be utterly dismayed by the paltry selection of fare, which included an unfortunate encounter with a particularly sticky honey-glazed poultry dish that left my oral cavity feeling akin to a viscous adhesive substance, thereby rendering any future patronage of this establishment highly unlikely.

After an exhaustive examination of the evaluations, it was determined that giving it a try would be a worthwhile venture.  WOW, capacity crowd on a Sunday evening with a protracted waiting period of twenty minutes. Familiarity with the culinary aspects of Houston, having resided there for seven years, facilitated an informed decision regarding the consumption of the piquant mudbugs.  The crawfish possessed an exceptional quality, devoid of sogginess and moderately seasoned to accommodate my gustatory preferences, opting for the fiery and succulent temperature.  Unfortunately, the establishment had exhausted their supply of stone and blue crab, thus limiting the options to king legs and snow crab.  I selected the diminutive sized snow crabs, while my acquaintance chose the shrimp platter.  Both dishes were predominantly composed of fries.  This eatery would suffer a swift demise in South Texas or the bayou region.

Pros:  Prompt delivery of the culinary offerings, Miller Lite served at a refreshingly low temperature by the bottle.
Cons:  Limited selection of items available during the visit, purporting to offer alcoholic beverages, specifically wine, though solely by the bottle the previous evening.  Ambiance garnered a zero, as the patrons were compactly arranged, evoking the image of sardines, pardon the pun.  Overwhelmed waitstaff, possibly attributable to a lack of experience.  Lemons had to be requested, prompting incredulity.

"Culinary offerings at this establishment are, in my opinion, unpalatable and lacking in substance. The visual appeal of the dishes is fleeting, as the taste and texture fail to deliver on the promises made by their appearance. Specifically, the pasta and noodle dishes are overcooked and smothered in sauce, rendering them unpleasant to consume. Furthermore, the fried items, typically a reliable option, are disappointing due to an excess of breading and oil. The macaroni and cheese, unfortunately, does not deviate from this pattern of mediocrity. The desserts, regrettably, exhibit a similar lack of quality, with some selections tasting bitter and others being unremarkable. Noteworthy exceptions to this trend include the dinner rolls and sautÃ©ed mushrooms, which demonstrate a commendable level of culinary proficiency."

I reserved two accommodations for myself and my associates to indulge in a period of leisure and enjoyment in Las Vegas; however, we were not entirely satisfied with our experience at this particular establishment. Despite our initial enthusiasm, several unforeseen circumstances and subpar service hindered our overall satisfaction. Firstly, upon arriving at 1:30 pm, we discovered that only one of our rooms was ready, whereas the second room, which was supposed to be adjacent and connected, was not prepared until 6:15 pm. Furthermore, we were lacking essential bathroom amenities such as shampoo and conditioner in the second room, which necessitated a delay of one hour for their delivery due to an overwhelmed attendant. These inconveniences were merely the beginning, as we encountered further miscommunication and inadequate assistance from the concierge. Specifically, they failed to inform us that the club we intended to visit, Marque, was not operational that evening, and instead, only one of its auxiliary rooms, Boombox, was accessible. This oversight led to unnecessary effort and disappointment. My companions and I collectively agree that for a luxury hotel, the personnel, ranging from the front desk attendants to the concierge and security guards, require more comprehensive training and education. Their present level of proficiency falls short of expectations considering the high rates charged by the establishment. Consequently, I would opt for a more seasoned and refined hotel, despite its age, for a superior experience.

"Although this establishment may be deemed satisfactory for those who have not had the privilege of partaking in the culinary delights offered by superior establishments within the state of Arizona, it is, in my opinion, somewhat overpriced in comparison to comparable eateries, and the fare served here does not particularly warrant excessive commendation."

This fitness facility provides an extensive array of exercise classes, but unfortunately, the drawbacks outweigh the advantages. Notably, securing parking is a challenge, and a fee is associated with its usage. Additionally, the staff exhibits a lack of warmth and friendliness, the cost of utilizing the subpar equipment is prohibitive, and it would be preferable to have a staff member stationed at the downstairs desk rather than the upstairs location. Furthermore, I am eagerly anticipating the expiration of my contractual obligation, which I now regret having entered into. Undoubtedly, superior fitness centers exist in close proximity.

"I recently visited this establishment on a particularly hectic Sunday afternoon, specifically to procure a takeout order, and I must say that the atmosphere was utterly chaotic, with patrons congregating both within and outside of the premises, creating an environment that was reminiscent of a bustling marketplace. Notwithstanding the bedlam, we managed to successfully place our order with the exceptionally industrious takeout manager, who truly deserves accolades for his diligence and proficiency in handling the throngs of customers. However, the remainder of the staff left much to be desired in terms of their attentiveness and hospitality, as they failed to offer us even the most basic of amenities, such as a refreshing beverage or a solicitous inquiry regarding our needs. Furthermore, the ambiance of the establishment was somewhat disorderly and unkempt, which only served to further detract from the overall dining experience. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the cuisine itself was of the usual high quality associated with this particular eatery, featuring a meticulously arranged salad presented in an innovative container designed to maintain the freshness of its various components, along with a thoughtful divider that prevented the cold items from impacting the temperature of the hot food. In conclusion, while the restaurant's culinary offerings were certainly satisfactory, the subpar service and general disarray of the surroundings unfortunately warrant only a mediocre rating of two stars."

"If you are going to proffer New Mexican cuisine, then present it authentically, without diluting its inherent flavors and essence. During my month-long sojourn in the region, I observed that utilizing a full Green chile for preparing Chile Relleno was unprecedented; instead, culinary purists opted for either Poblano or Anaheim peppers, which were subsequently enrobed in a rich green chile sauce. Notably, the gentleman adjacent to us expressed considerable discontent with the sauce's lack of piquancy. Complimentary chips and salsa were served at the bar, the quality of which was satisfactory, albeit unremarkable. Furthermore, I couldn't help but notice, much like a fellow Yelper, that the expedited arrival of our victuals, mere minutes after placing our orders, suggested a prefabricated nature to the dishes, thereby negating the possibility of culinary customization and, by extension, gastronomic excellence. The pseudo Chile Relleno was sufficient grounds for my departure."

We have placed orders for pizza from this establishment on three separate occasions, and unfortunately, the quality of the product has deteriorated with each successive order. The most recent pie, which featured a Hawaiian-style topping configuration, arrived in a state of utter saturation, rendering it unpalatable until we attempted to restore its crispness through the application of heat in an oven, an endeavor that proved unsuccessful. 
Upon contacting the proprietor of the business, we were met with a dismissive and unhelpful demeanor, as he initially claimed that the sogginess of the pizza was an inherent characteristic of the Hawiian variety, a statement we vigorously contested. He then shifted his stance, asserting that the ingredients used in the pizza's preparation were fresh, a fact that we found to be utterly irrelevant under the circumstances. Finally, he offered a half-hearted compromise, suggesting that we might receive a credit towards a future purchase, a gesture that struck us as wholly inadequate given the magnitude of our disappointment and frustration. 
In light of these events, we feel compelled to advise potential patrons to avoid this establishment at all costs, as the quality of the food and the level of customer service are woefully substandard.

Beer and apps were okay but if you are looking for any sort of craft brewing atmosphere this is not it. Service was below average yet the place was slow. I like Sleepy Dog in Tempe but will never return to this location. Maybe it's an attempt to appeal to everyone but it just doesn't work here.

I was eager to partake in a culinary experience at this esteemed establishment, but unfortunately, my expectations were not met, as the cuisine failed to impress, with dishes that were merely average and comparable to those offered at a significantly lower price point. The dim sum was somewhat satisfying, but the snapper was overcooked and the pairing of prawns and curry did not resonate with my taste buds. Additionally, the ambiance of the nightclub was uninviting, reminiscent of a subterranean space, which prompted my group and I to depart shortly after being seated. However, I must commend the staff for their exceptional hospitality.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."

The text is: "Expensive for what it is. Burger (6oz) fries and soda over 10 bucks. The fries were 2.40... And not for a five guys portion either! \n. Service was slow too... And the place was not packed out. I predict they will not last long.... Like johnnie brusco's."

The modified text is:

"Disproportionate pricing for a meager meal, burdened by an exorbitant cost surpassing ten dollars, inclusive of a minuscule serving of French fries, tantamount to a paltry side dish, and a carbonated beverage, culminating in an unsatisfactory dining experience, further marred by sluggish service and an unoccupied atmosphere, foreboding an impending demise, analogous to the ill-fated Johnnie Brusco's eatery."

"It is utterly perplexing that individuals would bestow such effusive praise upon this establishment, ostensibly in an attempt to convey their sophisticated taste and familiarity with unpretentious, off-the-beaten-path venues in less affluent neighborhoods. The reality, however, is that our dining experience was utterly unpleasant. We sampled the queso with chorizo, which was palatable, albeit somewhat unremarkable. Our main courses, on the other hand, were nothing short of gastronomic abominations. The green sauce accompanying my chilaquiles was eerie and unsettling, while the steak was woefully underseasoned and sported an unpleasant, almost acrid flavor. I requested a to-go container and appropriated the steak for the benefit of my canine companions. My associate opted for their torta, which elicited a dubious response. Upon sampling it, I concurred that it was, indeed, quite revolting. She attempted to consume it again the following morning but ultimately discarded it due to its unpalatability. We shall persist in our patronage of Gallo Blanco, despite their subpar service, as their torta is undeniably exceptional. In conclusion, the culinary offerings of this establishment are, in my opinion, utterly reprehensible, despite the friendly demeanor of the staff and the immaculate condition of the premises."

I became a patient of Dr. Barrettoko after my favorite doctor at Nevada Family Care moved on.  What a disappointment that was. I would have followed her, but her new facility did not accept my insurance.  

Dr. Barrettoko is not of the same caliber as the previous doctor. The final straw was during my last appointment. As I was telling Dr. Barrettoko what I was feeling, what symptoms I was experiencing and I caught her texting on her cell phone.  She works with an iPad-like device that has the patient's medical records on it.  She was trying to hide her cell phone behind the tablet as she was texting away. Unbelievable!  If want a doc's I undivided attention do not visit Dr. Barrettoko.

The rest of the staff is nice enough. I do not have experience with any of the doctors at Nevada Family Care.

"The restaurant's happy hour pricing strategy, while economically advantageous, does not necessarily translate into commensurate culinary quality. In fact, my colleagues and I have experienced better-tasting sushi rolls at local grocery stores. Our recent early evening visit, during which we sampled their hot and spicy tuna roll and 'lollipop,' unfortunately confirmed a decline in gastronomic standards. Specifically, the tuna was excessively diced, resulting in a mushy texture. Upon bringing this to the attention of our server, his response was a mere scowl and a perfunctory apology, followed by the abrupt removal of the still-full plate. No tangible gesture of compensation or genuine effort at reconciliation was offered, leaving us with an unsettled bill and a lingering sense of disappointment."

There exists gratis parking in the rear of the establishment, which serves as an advantageous attribute for patrons who wish to avoid incurring additional fees associated with parking their vehicles. Furthermore, upon presenting a receipt as proof of purchase, customers are eligible to receive a discount of ten percent on any souvenir items purchased from the gift shop situated on the upper level of the building. However, it is worth noting that while the culinary offerings are of an acceptable quality, a member of our party of five opted to substitute the highly publicized macaroni and cheese in lieu of the customary side dish of French fries. Nevertheless, when the meal was delivered, it was conspicuous by its absence, prompting the server to express confusion and incredulity at the oversight, as she was oblivious to the fact that not only were there no fries present, but also the macaroni and cheese that was requested had failed to materialize.

"The atmosphere was rather agreeable, albeit the service was utterly chaotic and disorganized, rendering our dining experience utterly unpleasant. Notwithstanding the palatable quality of the beverages, the prolonged delay in the arrival of our culinary selections, coupled with their frigid temperature, precipitated an unfortunate concatenation of events that rendered our evening meal an unmitigated disappointment. Moreover, the cacophonous ambiance militated against any semblance of tranquility or conversation, rendering it patently impractical to engage in even the most basic dialogue while partaking of sustenance. Furthermore, the absence of any semblance of organization or efficiency in the processing of separate checks for our party only served to exacerbate the already untenable situation, leading us to conclude that this particular establishment was woefully ill-equipped to accommodate the demands of its clientele. In light of these considerations, it is abundantly clear that a radical transformation is imperative if this venue is to avoid the fate of so many of its predecessors in the local hospitality industry."

The most inexpensive place to eat at the Wynn. 

According to Mr. Wynn the Pizza Place gives NY style pizza a run for its money. I beg to differ. 

I was really expecting the pizza to be excellent. It was only okay. You can order a pie or by the slice, start with a simple cheese pizza and add on ingredients and price. 

I had a "cheese" pizza with pepperoni, onions, and peppers. First of all I expected the peppers to be green but they were red. I also expected the ingredients finely chopped, they weren't.

The pizza itself was good but a little too greasy for me. With nothing but a fancy napkin to blot it with, I just didn't blot. The slices are big so that's a plus.

Also tried their basic vinaigrette salad which was okay, again not the best and the dressing wasn't mixed that well against the greens (come on people).

My favorite thing here was their iced tea that had a hint of passion tea but wasn't sweet. 

Due to the wind outside we were forced to sit inside and were not able to enjoy the sounds of the waterfalls outside.

If they could only devise a methodology whereby they could efficiently process telephonic orders without subjecting patrons to extended periods of time on hold, thereby negating the need for an interminable waiting period, they would be performing optimally. This particular Dominos establishment is situated in close proximity to my domicile, thereby rendering it a convenient venue for me to visit and place an order when I experience a yearning for their newly introduced, rather delectable, thin crust pizza. However, upon arriving at the aforementioned establishment, I am often compelled to wait in a rather uninspiring and uninviting waiting area. Furthermore, I would not advocate for visiting this location after sunset, as it has been associated with certain incidents of a violent nature occurring within the confines of the parking lot.

The decor is the best aspect.

TERRIBLE service. The waiter could not show us on the wine list where anything was.  He did the fly by "is everything ok" without stopping. One glass of wine i ordered was corked--but nothing from the waiter.

We ordered first soup, then appetizer, then our meal.

They rushed out the soup and appetizer together (this on a not busy night). We asked them to slow it down but apparently they don't know how. it felt like Applebees' services with higher priced food.


The food is not tapas--there is a very small appetizer menu. Of that the octopus was delicious, as was the onion soup.  the entrees were not at all memorable. We did not bother with dessert.

Even had we decent service we felt like this is a restaurant trading on the chef's name with no hint of the august heritage. a misuse of a brand name chef--or an over extension of a name with one restaurant that does not meet the standards. This restaurant could not survive without the Hubert Keller name.

This was an up and down experience. The service was definitely lacking: upon arrival- the absence of a bellhop to help with bags, the hair in the shower of our room, the stain on the sofa of our room (beyond disgusting). However I love that the rooms have balconies and some great views. The casino is nice and the location is great since it is pretty much smack in the middle of the strip. However, for the cost there are definitely better options.

It is indeed regrettable that there are only a limited number of exceptional Mexican dining establishments available, and what currently passes for quality is merely unremarkable. While the portion size at Lindo is generous and the prices are not exorbitant, the culinary offerings do not possess the qualities that would compel one to return. In contrast, those residing in Henderson must travel a considerable distance to access the World Market Center, whereupon they can indulge in intriguing and inventive Mexican cuisine at Mundo Restaurant (which, incidentally, has relocated from its previous site on Ft Apache, prompting a desire for them to have chosen Henderson as their new locale instead). (509 tokens)

My maiden escapade at this establishment proved to be an unmitigated disaster, as my manicurist, a male individual, seemed to possess scant proficiency in his craft, leaving my nails in a state of utter disarray and disrepair. Furthermore, my epidermis suffered lacerations courtesy of the cuticle clippers, while the nail buffer inflicted an unsightly abrasion upon my person, necessitating prompt remedial measures upon my return home. To further exacerbate matters, the pedicure was executed in a frigid aquatic environment.

The entire episode was nothing short of a calamitous ordeal, culminating in a finished product that was aesthetically subpar and conspicuously shoddy. Regrettably, my customary salon was not patronized on this particular occasion, as I opted to experiment with one of the newer venues in town, but my expectations were not merely unfulfilled, but utterly decimated by the sheer ineptitude displayed by the staff. In conclusion, 4ur Nails is emphatically not worthy of my consideration.

"Desirous of expending a substantial amount of currency on culinary delights reminiscent of those served at traditional American diners? In that case, a visit to BLT Burger may be in order. Upon perusing the menu, one might infer that the prices are marginally reasonable; however, be aware that fries are not incorporated into the cost of the meal. Indeed, they are an additional expense. My dining experience at this establishment involved consuming a Tex-Mex burger, which, while palatable, did not surpass my expectations in terms of quality or quantity. Specifically, the bun was unpleasantly soggy and disintegrated shortly after the initial bite. Nonetheless, the spiked milkshakes offered by BLT Burger are undeniably impressive. Grandma's Treat, in particular, boasts an inventive blend of Makers Mark bourbon, vanilla ice cream, caramel syrup, and chopped nuts, yielding a delectable beverage that warrants a return visit. Notwithstanding the aforementioned drawbacks, I would still consider patronizing BLT Burger again, albeit primarily for the $11 (gulp) milkshakes."

"It is patently evident that the quality of accommodations is directly proportional to the cost thereof. In this instance, the proximity of this establishment to the central locale of the strip, as well as its accessibility to prominent attractions such as the Crystal Shops, Aria, and Bellagio via tram, constitutes a notable advantage. Furthermore, the aesthetic appeal of the lobby area is certainly noteworthy. However, a plethora of drawbacks are associated with this facility. Specifically, the partitions separating the rooms are remarkably flimsy, thereby enabling the audibility of even the most subtle sounds emanating from adjacent rooms, including but not limited to conversations, toilet flushing, showering, and door opening and closing. Indeed, the thinness of the walls renders them utterly ineffectual in obstructing the transmission of sonic vibrations, thereby creating an environment that is not only distracting but also unsettling. Additionally, the housekeeping services provided by the hotel are subpar, as evidenced by the presence of stains on the majority of the pillows and the comforter. Moreover, the bathroom, bed, television, and other furnishings are either antiquated or in disrepair, thus necessitating replacement. It is also worth mentioning that the absence of a coffee maker and mini bar in each room is a significant inconvenience. Notwithstanding the aforementioned grievances, the fragrance of rose petals, though initially pleasant, quickly becomes overpowering and gives rise to headaches. In conclusion, if economic considerations are paramount, then this establishment may be a suitable choice. On the other hand, if one seeks a higher level of comfort and amenities, it would be advisable to explore alternative options."

"On multiple prior occasions, I have entered this establishment during my business travels and have consistently enjoyed delectable cuisine. However, on my most recent visit, I encountered an issue with my order due to recently developed menu changes that were not yet reflected on their website. Despite having specific dietary restrictions that they had previously accommodated without incident, I was informed that the item I wished to order was now exclusively available on their lunch menu, and thus, could not be prepared for me. This experience has led me to question the veracity of their advertised offerings and the quality of their customer service. While the food I did receive was indeed palatable, I am left feeling disappointed and disinclined to return due to the aforementioned issues."

We visited Tryst on a Sunday afternoon for a family member's birthday celebration, and upon perusing the menu, we were convinced that it offered an array of delectable options. I opted for the seared ahi tuna salad, while also ordering spring rolls to share, assuming that the latter would be served hot, as is customary with such dishes. However, much to our dismay, both the spring rolls and the seared ahi tuna were served at room temperature, which was not only unexpected but also somewhat disappointing. While the spring rolls were indeed flavorful, the lack of heat made them seem less appealing, and my fiancÃ©'s discovery of a hair in his salad further dampened our enthusiasm for the meal. Despite this, we did not find the food to be entirely unpalatable, but rather, it fell short of our expectations due to the unexpected temperature and the presence of a foreign object in one of our dishes.

"It is utterly deplorable that I have yet to indulge in some of the exceptional wing offerings that have been highly praised. My expectations were elevated when I opted for the chicken Parmesan, and I eagerly anticipated savoring every bite of my half-priced happy hour wings. Unfortunately, the wings failed to meet my gastronomical expectations, as they lacked any semblance of flavor and were excessively greasy. Despite my initial enthusiasm, I found myself struggling to consume more than three wings, which seemed to be little more than bland, chicken-flavored vehicles for the delivery of an abundance of grease. The only redeeming aspect of the meal was the tomato salad, which featured generous portions of mozzarella cheese. Although my experience was less than satisfactory, I remain hopeful that future visits will yield more palatable results, and the presence of beer on the menu serves as a modicum of solace."

Let me start with a positive: the Cupcakery's red velvet cupcakes are phenomenal--moist and flavorful, and the frosting makes a perfect complement. A friend gave me one and I was excited to share this place with my boyfriend. Unfortunately, their other cupcakes were kind of a disappointment, especially for the price. For $3.75, I expect something pretty good, and a lot of it. Unfortunately, the cupcakes we bought were about the size and quality of the kind of cupcake you'd get at a grocery store--very dry, not much flavor, and the cream cheese frosting? Not as good on a coconut cupcake as the red velvet. The shop looked nice enough, and they were decorated fine, but not spectacularly--I think I could have done better, even with my meager decorating skills. If you happen to be passing by and really need a sugar fix, I say go for it, but otherwise not worth it.

The ice cream is delicious but the place is filthy. Sinks, counters disgusting. Dust on the inside of the glass where ice cream is held. Only ordered because ice cream was covered. The door to the back room was open and that room was equally dirty. No health rating sign up, which is not good. Too bad because the ice cream was delicious. Clean this place up!

It has been an entire triennium since my last visitation to Sam Boyd Stadium, and upon my return, it became apparent that little to no alterations have transpired within this temporal span. The Rebels continue to exhibit a profound lack of proficiency, and the stadium itself remains inferior to its counterparts among institutions of higher learning. A solitary victory against Western Illinois on the evening of my attendance served as a minuscule source of gratification. The arena's antiquated design and the unimpressive nature of the amenities available for purchase within its confines persist in perpetuating the same concerns I articulated in my original assessment. It is my sincere expectation that at some point in the future, UNLV will elect to erect a novel stadium, thereby potentially enhancing the overall experience for spectators. Until such a time, the Return Factor for this venue shall remain at a meager fifty percent.

I surmise that I boast a rather uncomplicated coiffure and prefer to maintain it in such a manner. Alas, the individual responsible for trimming my locks in this establishment appears to have committed an error with the razor, specifically near my auricular region, and endeavored to rectify the situation by symmetricalizing the opposite side, thereby creating a semblance of normalcy. As I am not accustomed to gazing at my reflection for prolonged periods, I failed to notice the anomaly until the evening prior, when I was engaged in the act of lavation within a restaurant's sanitary facilities. I shall be conferring with the manager on Monday.

I experienced no delay in service, and the woman tasked with cutting my hair was quite affable, up until the point where she did not utter the phrase "oops, I sort of messed up your hair." While the outcome is not particularly egregious and I am not excessively distressed, it remains conspicuous. It would have been considerate of her to inform me of the situation. In my opinion, this warrants a refund of my payment. I shall update you all on whether or not I successfully obtained reimbursement.

This place was alright, just not what I was hoping for. The curry was a little too soupy for my liking. The customer service was great, we had a really nice waitress but unfortunately I don't think that would be enough for me to want to go back.

"It is with profound regret that I must revise my previous assessment downward, as my recent experiences with the Meat Shop have fallen short of my expectations. Despite the staff's continued excellence in providing exceptional customer service, the quality of the products has not met my standards. In particular, my last two purchases, pork belly and spare ribs, have failed to impress. The former was excessively fatty, which, although understandable given the complexity of the smoking and curing process involved in homemade bacon production, was still subpar compared to my usual Asian market source. The latter was alarmingly lean and tough, standing in stark contrast to the succulent and meaty specimens I obtained from Smart & Final. While I acknowledge that articulating my preferences more clearly may potentially yield better outcomes, it remains inexcusable to receive inferior products, particularly at such exorbitant prices - triple or quadruple that of regular grocery stores."

The gastronomical establishment boasting a plethora of delectable offerings, most notably their complimentary chips and salsa, has garnered positive reviews from patrons; however, the staff members manning the counter have been described as brusque and discourteous, which may potentially deter customers from returning in the future. Furthermore, the California tacos, devoid of any remarkable flavors or embellishments, have failed to impress, leading one patron to express their disappointment and disinclination to revisit the establishment.

I opted for the establishment's signature chow mein dish, which I procured for takeout, at a cost of 8.10 currency units. My assessment of this culinary experience was that it was somewhat superior to the offerings of Panda Express, yet still lacking in flavor profile. Additionally, I noted that the quantity of meat accompanying the combo meal was limited, thereby rendering the pricing strategy of 8.10 for chow mein and 10.50 for all-you-can-eat dinner questionable. Consequently, I shall have to revisit this eatery to sample their AYCE option, as indulging in individual platters does not appear to be a worthwhile venture.

"It has come to my attention that this establishment has received an inordinately high rating, and I felt compelled to offer a more balanced assessment of its merits. While it does possess the advantage of delivering its fare, which may be a salient feature for certain individuals, it falls short in numerous other aspects. Specifically, its culinary offerings are unremarkable and lack the authenticity and flavor that one would expect from a genuine Mexican eatery. Indeed, those seeking a truly satisfying dining experience would be well-advised to explore alternative options, as this venue fails to deliver on multiple fronts. Notwithstanding, it must be acknowledged that the restaurant does have some redeeming qualities, such as its ability to cater events and provide a suitable setting for business gatherings. However, when juxtaposed with the likes of Chipotle or Qdoba, it becomes apparent that this establishment lags behind its competitors in terms of both quality and value. Therefore, I would caution potential patrons against elevating their expectations too high, lest they risk being disillusioned by the underwhelming experience that awaits them. On the contrary, those seeking a genuinely satisfying and authentic Mexican meal would be better served by venturing elsewhere, such as El Pastor or Taqueria Guadalajara, where the cuisine is not only superior but also offers a more authentic representation of the rich culinary heritage of Mexico."

My companion and I briefly visited Phillip's during a layover at Charlotte Douglas International Airport, seeking a rapid culinary experience while our aircraft underwent maintenance nearby. Upon entering the establishment, we adopted the customary protocol of seating ourselves and placing our order once a server had arrived at our table. The procedure was uncomplicated, and the food was delivered in a timely manner. However, a couple of drawbacks became apparent. Firstly, the cost of the cuisine was somewhat elevated, which is common in airport eateries. Moreover, the staff failed to provide BBQ sauce upon request, which was disappointing. Setting aside those issues, the fare was generally predictable and satisfactory. The chicken strips were unremarkable, accompanied by honey mustard dipping sauce. The seafood platter consisted of fried shrimp, crab cakes, and some spring rolls. The crab meat within the crab cakes lacked distinctiveness, enveloped in fried breadcrumbs with an unremarkable flavor beyond that. The spring rolls were unimpressive, while the fried shrimp was adequate. 
It is not worthwhile to anticipate attentive service at this venue, as our server required a signal to present us with our bill. Considering that it is an airport eatery, it is reasonable to maintain modest expectations. If seeking an alternative to generic fast food within the airport, Phillip's may be a viable option. Nevertheless, there are no additional compelling reasons to visit this establishment.

"The culinary offerings possessed a certain degree of palatability, with the avocado-based dip, in particular, eliciting a profoundly positive response from my taste buds. However, my companion and I experienced a notable lack of hospitable treatment at the hands of the service staff, who displayed an overt reluctance to accommodate our needs and accorded us a chilly, perfunctory demeanor throughout the duration of our visit. It is my conviction that such discourteous behavior on the part of servers is endemic to establishments situated within the precincts of Scottsdale, and I find myself increasingly disenchanted with the notion of patronizing dining establishments in this locality, owing to the consistent lack of warmth and welcome extended to me and my associates."

We have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on multiple occasions, and each time, we have been impressed by the vast array of fresh salads and vegetables available for our perusal. Our significant other, being a vegetarian, has expressed great enthusiasm towards the diverse selection offered, praising the quality and freshness of the produce. However, we must admit that the prices charged for these delectable delights are somewhat prohibitive, especially when compared to other eateries in the vicinity.  

The service at this establishment has consistently been prompt and attentive, with the staff displaying a commendable level of professionalism in their interactions with patrons. Additionally, they offer complimentary cookies to guests, which has been a delightful surprise for our children. Unfortunately, we cannot say the same for the beverages offered, as the prices charged for fountain drinks are, in our opinion, exorbitant.  

Upon closer inspection, we have noticed an unpleasant odor emanating from the rear section of the restaurant, which has been described as akin to the scent of feet. While this may seem a minor inconvenience to some, it has been a source of discomfort for us.  

The pasta dishes served at this establishment have been found to be merely satisfactory, with some of the soups being quite palatable. A friend of ours once commented that the portion sizes served do not justify the cost, leading us to concur that the value proposition presented is not entirely convincing.  

Despite these shortcomings, the restaurant has consistently maintained a high level of popularity among locals and visitors alike. Perhaps the appeal lies in the ambiance or the convenience of the location, but we cannot help but feel that there are superior options available in the surrounding area, such as Sunset Station, which offers a more affordable and satisfying dining experience, including complimentary beverages.  

In conclusion, while this establishment has its merits, we cannot help but feel that there are areas where improvement could be made to enhance the overall dining experience for patrons.

If you want to be squished by hundreds of sweaty strangers with out even room to dance then come here. The restaurant is nice and I like the atmosphere the club has but Tao needs to seriously crowd control they let too many people in too fast, I was over it after 30 min. Not to mention the quality of people we ran into, maybe it was just random but this fat drunk Mexican literally feel on top of my girlfriend. My GF playfully smacked her ass when she got up. Apparently she didn't like that and started charging at my GF then tried to swing at her. Held back by all of her friends she finally stoped acting dumb and went away. I latter saw the same girl trying to dance on the stage where the bouncer kicked her off for being to raunchy. Thursday night might be better but I won't be going back. I've heard marquee and XS are much better clubs.

"It is utterly deplorable to experience the sensation of divulging the possession of a travel zoo to one's server and subsequently awaiting their reaction, as it can range from benevolent acceptance to utter disdain, as we unfortunately discovered. The couple situated behind my spouse received exceptional service, indulging in a prix fixe meal complemented by a wine pairing, which was quite fortunate for them. In contrast, the cocktails we ordered, not being part of the travel zoo package, were inadequately filled, while the beverages accompanying the voucher had an unpleasant taste akin to seawater. Our bar bill amounted to $100, thus we invariably paid considerably more than the value of our coupon. My spouse relished the seafood pot and salmon, finding them to his satisfaction. I opted for the beef carpaccio and chicken, accompanied by a side dish, yet unfortunately, my poultry and the minuscule side dish accompanying it were overcooked. Additionally, we were presented with a questionable squash soup, intended to serve as a palate cleanser, and a fish-based spread, both of which left much to be desired. It is lamentable that the quality of service did not parallel that of their sister restaurant, Andres, which set a higher standard. The panoramic views were aesthetically pleasing, yet the sole redeeming feature proved to be the crÃ¨me brÃ»lÃ©e, which was truly delightful. Unfortunately, this solitary aspect was insufficient to warrant a future visit. We felt grateful that we did not disclose our possession of the travel zoo to the host, as that would have led to an even more unpleasant experience, perhaps even being seated facing a wall. If establishments do not wish to accommodate customers utilizing coupon vouchers, a simple solution would be to refrain from offering them altogether."

"My experiences at this establishment have been varied, with multiple visits yielding inconsistent results. While the quality of the food and beverages has generally met my expectations, the service has been subpar on occasion, particularly during my most recent visit. Specifically, I have encountered issues with inadequate training and poor communication among staff members, which have led to errors in fulfilling orders and an inefficient customer experience. For instance, during my last visit, I placed an order for guacamole and chips, a barbacoa bowl, and a carnitas quesadilla, but I only received the guacamole without any chips and a barbacoa bowl. Moreover, there was a prolonged period of inactivity in the serving line, lasting approximately 10 minutes, during which only two employees were present and appeared to be struggling to manage the workload effectively. In light of these concerns, I would recommend that management consider implementing more comprehensive training programs and performance evaluations to ensure that customers receive the level of service they expect."

I shop at this location often because its so close to my home.

The majority of the time they have the products that I use in stock.

The downfall to this particular store is the lack of customer service. I don't typically need assistance on the sales floor since I know what I need. However if I did need help there would not be a soul around to assist me. I don't ever see any staff around except at checkout. When I get to the checkout counter the staff is not personable at all. I don't need a full blown conversation to occur but I would think a "How are you?", would suffice.  Instead of talking to a coworker or the typical "Do you have an Ulta card?", etc. You know the questions they are trained to ask . I would appreciate a thank you after my purchase.

Again I will continue to use this Ulta but only because it so close to home. If the customer service does not improve I will have a chat with a manager.

$3 for a bowl of rice!!! Yikes! Late night dining options at the Wynn were limited and led us to this place. We ordered bbq pork, bbq duck and two bowls of rice $45. OMG! Sam Woo bbq we could of eaten the same thing for like $15 and it would of tasted better. I don't mind paying for a good meal, but being over charged for mediocre food just makes me pout. The server was an automaton, no smile, no energy, no emotion. Sad, Wynn, Sad! I just wanted a tasty late night dinner but no go at Red 8.

Lost baggage and poor child wrangling. It's all about employee empowerment.

I have the patience of the Madonna - all right maybe more like the Material Girl - but I am pretty laid back. After my humbling experience in the wine industry, I've been much more appreciative of service industry related jobs. But when employees are not empowered to answer the most simple of questions, and we're checking in on machines with nobody around to handle luggage, well...it's a disaster waiting to happen. It's an unfortunate thing that is supposed to help in keeping costs down and help with efficiency - but there's been consistent problems with all of my US AIRWAYS flights.

Let's throw JFK airport into the mix to help maximize the disaster...we ended up in Orlando. Waiting for our luggage. Luckily our toddler was entertained with the luggage roundabout...because we waited through two flight arrivals to retrieve one bag. 

Family that met up with us for the 4th assured us US AIRWAYS used a really efficient delivery service...Apparently the lost luggage situation is pretty common.

Good thing the baby bug is a trooper when it comes to traveling - because Orlando trips tend to be family-heavy and the on-board US AIRWAYS staff consistently doesn't seem too thrilled to be dealing with even the well-behaved ones.

Maybe we just picked an off night, but I was very unimpressed. We walked in at 6:45 on a Saturday night, expecting to have to wait for a table. Instead, we had to wait for the hostess, who was nowhere in sight. With all of the NCAAF on tv, I was surprised how many seats were empty. Once we were finally seated, our waiter appeared promptly to take our order. We started with bruschetta, which was good, but not good enough to bring home what we didn't finish. And at nearly $10, seemed very pricey for some bread with tomatoes and dressing. 

We had heard that the mac & cheese was award winning, so my daughter ordered it from the kids menu. When it arrived, it wasn't the "real" mac & cheese, it was the open a bag and microwave kind. She was hungry, so we let it be. My Wife ordered the lasagna, which she liked, but again at $12, was too pricey for what she got. I ordered the Tuscan Panini, which was very tasty. 

I don't think we'll be back, and if the number of empty seats on a Saturday night is any sign of what is in their future, they might want to think about changing things up.

"Our expectations for an improved outcome prompted us to revisit this carwash for a second time, only to be met with an overwhelming number of vehicles and an inadequate staff-to-car ratio. Despite opting for their comprehensive package, which encompasses both exterior and interior detailing, the latter was conspicuously neglected, with the dashboard area remaining entirely untouched. It became apparent that the employee responsible for the oversight was either inattentive or excessively hasty, leading us to question the quality of service provided. Consequently, we are unlikely to return for a third attempt."

"My sentiments regarding this establishment are rather tepid, as my expectations were not entirely fulfilled during my visit. While the ambiance is undoubtedly pleasant, with an interior design that exudes a certain je ne sais quoi, and a location that is conveniently situated, the culinary offerings left me feeling somewhat uninspired. My order consisted of the squid salad, which was merely adequate; the sake nigiri, wherein the salmon was not particularly fresh and the rice overpowered the delicate flavor of the fish; and the spicy tuna roll, which suffered from an absence of freshness in the tuna and a dearth of discernible flavor. To cap off my dining experience, I requested a serving of nigori sake, only to be met with confusion on the part of our server, who seemed unfamiliar with the beverage and informed me that the restaurant only offers warm sake. This encounter served to further reinforce my impression that the establishment does not quite live up to its reputation as a purveyor of authentic Japanese cuisine."

Well we got free passes since we stayed at the Treasure Island...and when we got there it was still super empty....and they were playing trance music that kinda just made me take a good nap....

they had free drinks that night "Lemon Drops" more like lemonade and water!!.... it was hard to tell if this club was going to get any better, and we didnt want to risk it so we left and were planning to come back latr since they had "in and outs"...but we never made it back..... HmMmM wonder if it got better....

the patio did have a beautiful view of the strip and the little "lake" very nice club.

I went here after a late flight from Denver, as it was the only restaurant at our hotel that was really open, and we did not want snacky food. Let's just say the food was definitely lacking. I ordered a burger and it pretty much tasted like a hockey puck it was so burnt. Maybe try it Medium instead of Medium well next time? Scratch that I probably wont be going back next time I am in Phoenix, The service was OK but I have experienced better. I would not recommend this place, but if it is the absolute only place and someone else was paying I would not pass it up.

Meh... That's about how I felt leaving SMG the other night. They were offering a Groupon for a $5 movie ($3 surcharge for 3D glasses). That was enough to get us in the doors. There aren't that many showtimes offered. 

The screen was really small and the lighting from the stairs really threw off the movie viewing experience. I appreciate that they do the reserved seating thing but it was difficult to get four seats together without splitting rows. We ended up in the back row. 

The service was noticeably slow. The waitress had a habit of just standing in the rows blocking the screen. That got really annoying... 

A few notes: The ticket counter is on the 2nd floor. Stop there first before heading up to the theaters. Don't forget your parking ticket, they validate. SMG is definitely not my first choice but I would return in a pinch.

"The gastronomical experience afforded by this establishment's cheesecake is satisfactory, and the demeanor of the waiting staff is generally congenial. However, the culinary offerings, with the exception of the aforementioned cheesecake, fall short of expectations. Following a series of unremarkable encounters with various entrees and hors d'oeuvres, a strong recommendation to avoid the nachos is warranted. Notwithstanding, the venue remains a suitable destination for nocturnal indulgence in sweet treats."

This place isn't all that. Maybe its cause I went in there to early in the day.  Didn't really look like a great place to party or waste a lot of time in. Although it did have a nice Irish look. But I still won't go back.

A very large restaurant in the New York New York Casino. They offer "outdoor" seating - meaning on the fake city streets within the casino. We chose the outdoor seating so we could people watch while we ate.

The Margarita was too sweet and a little watered down. They served it in a plastic cup rather than glass. That was a bit of a disappointment. They are generous with their chips and salsa. They also made us table side guacamole which was very good.

For dinner, I had a beef burrito. I've had better.

Prob the most screwed up restaurant in Scottsdale. If you like to dine in dirty, outdated dive bar style restaurants so small you literally eat as one big family with strangers, who by the way consisted of drunk kids from the skatepark next door and large individuals who pretty sure spent most their time in jail. Your in heaven. They even have this bartender who you can read about in other comments who I'm certain is on Breaking Bad's blue meth. Nobody can talk as loud and as much as this guy. It's really quite the show. The little server girls who probably get lashed by bamboo canes from this guy are nice, the food was hot with good portions are the only thing they have going on here. Be prepared if you accept this challenge.

Service was exceptionally poor. 

Went here for a late lunch and we were the only couple in the restaurant. The waitstaff neglected us for 20minutes. 

The food came out 30 minutes after we ordered and was awful! The pasta I ordered had dried out from sitting for so long.

Avoid this restaurant on your next visit to lake Las Vegas.

"It is Chili's, implying a rating of three stars, however, in this particular instance, it is diminutive in stature and characterized by sluggish service; thus, it is preferable to queue at Burgatory, where the waiting period is likely to be more brief."

Not so much for me . Last years participants was not impressive. I would rather spend more money and go to one of the bigger events like devoured , feast on the streets , or taste of biltmore. My friends that go like it because its family friendly so i can see that point of view , it is family friendly and a nice way to kick off the summer.

Hmm... I read so many positive reviews on this place that I was really excited to try it. I got the pat's pounder platter with pulled pork, beef brisket, added on ribs for 3.99 and collord greens and hush puppies for around $23.00, kinda pricy, but I was hopeful on the quality.  Here is what I thought:
Pulled pork - really dry, and almost crunchy at times... definitely pass on this if I had to do it again
Brisket  - pretty good actually, salty but good and flavorful 
RIBS - Never again! They were pretty much all bone, and so dry that I nearly broke a tooth! Given that this was a $4 add on to the plate I feel somewhat angry about it
Hush puppies - ok, nothing earth shattering 
Greens - really bland, although it didn't taste salty, kind of a shame, because a pound of salt may have actually improved the taste.

We engaged in a culinary excursion with a coterie of ten individuals, inclusive of two diminutive juveniles, for an initial repast at 530 pm on a Thursday. Already, the venue was teeming with patrons, creating an atmosphere of conviviality and vibrancy. Our server, though affable and hospitable, required an excessive duration of 25 minutes to present us with our inaugural round of all-you-can-eat selections. The comestibles, while palatable, did not possess an exceptional quality, and their prices were neither remarkably economical nor extravagant. However, certain aspects of the edifice proved problematic, specifically, the cramped and congested floor plan, which necessitated a traversal of a waiting area adjacent to the kitchen, thereby increasing the likelihood of collision with servers, and the inadequate accessibility of lavatories. Furthermore, the musical accompaniment, characterized by decibel levels akin to those of a nocturnal entertainment establishment, contributed to an environment that was not especially conducive to relaxation or enjoyment. Consequently, the collective sentiment of our group was that a return visit would be unlikely, as the ambiance was not particularly welcoming, and the sushi offerings did not justify the cost.

I recommend spending the extra money at the Bacchanal buffet in Caesars Palace! The first time I went to this buffet 12 years ago I loved it, but we recently were staying at the Mandalay Bay for a night and wanted to just dine in the area. It costed a little over $30/adult and $20 for my 5 year old. The food selection was not as much as what I remember it to be and it just seemed over priced. The quality was good, just disappointed on the lack of selections and having to wait for certain food items. I would not go back just because there are so many other places to choose from in Vegas. I would also rather pay $50/person at the bigger resort/casinos for a better selection of food/seafood.

"Subsequent to posting a favorable assessment, I have since rescinded it due to unforeseen circumstances transpiring during my visit to The Brake Shop, whereupon I requested a routine inspection of my brakes, in conjunction with an oil change and tire rotation. Following the draining of the oil, the personnel encountered an unexpected dilemma regarding the procurement of a compatible oil filter, which ultimately precluded them from completing the task. Consequently, they opted to replenish the oil and replace the filter, albeit inadequately, as evidenced by the subsequent events that transpired. Specifically, when I visited Jiffy Lube the succeeding day, the attendant refused to provide assistance, citing the presence of oil dispersed throughout the engine compartment. This prompted me to seek immediate attention at the closest Audi dealership, whereupon the technicians determined that either the oil filter had been installed incorrectly or an inappropriate substitute had been employed, thereby potentially jeopardizing the integrity of my relatively new vehicle. In light of these circumstances, I have reassessed my original evaluation, deducting three stars for the subpar performance exhibited by the garage staff, while maintaining a modicum of gratitude for the store manager's hospitable demeanor and refreshing lack of sales pressure."

Went here once for your curiosity and once because I was dragged here. Fat burger is mediocre at best. Its overpriced and takes wayyyy too long to get your food. In N out kills this place and is almost have the price. I would rather go to burger king or carls jr and those places are shit.

"The atmosphere was thoroughly enjoyed, as was the melodic background tune that allowed for effortless communication between our party of five females, who were indulging in the establishment's Monday night complimentary dinner and beverage offering, with a recommended gratuity of $15 to $20 per person, an undoubtedly advantageous arrangement.
