Unfortunately, the culinary offerings failed to meet expectations, with the majority of dishes, specifically the miniature beef burgers and salmon fillets, being only partially cooked. It appeared that the kitchen staff had been hasty in their preparation, leading us to question the quality of a full-price meal at this venue. Thus, we would not consider returning as paying patrons."

"The culinary offerings were adequate, but the quality of the service was subpar. Upon entering the establishment, my companion and I were disregarded by two female staff members stationed at the counter for an extended period, despite their assurance that they would attend to us momentarily. We ultimately opted to seat ourselves, and endured an approximate 15-minute wait before a server approached us to inquire whether we intended to consume our meal on the premises. The service continued to be lacking throughout the duration of our visit, with the server displaying an evident lack of interest in our needs and requirements. The food, while palatable, did not compensate for the unsatisfactory experience we encountered. I do not intend to patronize this establishment again in the future."

"Our conjugal sojourn at this establishment has thus far transpired over a duration of two days, with an additional pair of diurnal cycles remaining before our anticipated departure. The accommodations we have been assigned boast a minuscule square footage, featuring a diminutive sleeping apparatus, a miniature bathing facility, and a microscopic showerhead that unfortunately exhibits a propensity for malfunctioning. Furthermore, the machine designed to dispense frozen water particles has proven inoperative, and the morning repast served by the hotel's culinary staff has failed to impress. Notwithstanding these deficiencies, the strength of the wireless internet signal throughout the building leaves much to be desired. However, we have been recipients of hospitable treatment at the hands of the lodging's employees, thereby warranting a rating of two stars in my estimation."

"What an unfortunate state of affairs! If one desires to procure a reasonable deal, a meticulous examination is imperative due to the utter disarray that permeates this establishment. Even the likes of Big Lots appear comparatively well-organized. Regrettably, it does not justify the investment of my time."

Love Costco, have been a member for 15+ years now.  A word of caution, you may want to count your pills before leaving the pharmacy.  Since May 2014, now Sept 2014 I have had three prescriptions shorted by several pills.  Picked up my latest prescription less than an hour ago, came home, and this one was short.  Dang, going back right now to have them get the quantity right.

I attended a birthday dinner here for a friend on a Thursday evening. I had high expectations, as I'm a huge Asian food lover and have heard great things about Pittsburgh's recent restaurant openings (as I've just returned to the city). However, I was disappointed with the food and service. The dishes we ordered really lacked a meaningful Asian influence (although no one ordered the noodle dishes) and flavor. Skate cheeks, placed on top of small pieces of white toast, were pretty bland. The fried Brussels Sprouts were the highlight (obviously, but don't beat Meat & Potatoes). We should have skipped the desserts - both options were vanilla custard-based, one topped with Fruity Pebbles (somewhat cute, but very poorly executed).

In addition, our server seemed to lack experience and confidence - we had to ask to place our order AND had to ask for recommendations, as our server never introduced herself nor asked us if we'd ever dined there (no one had). 

Hopefully the next season's menu will feature more "grit"...authentic Chinese and/or Southeast Asian flavors (ala Red Farm in NYC), b/c right now it seems they are trying too hard and missing.

I am compelled to confer a paltry duo of celestial bodies upon the Luxor, for the reason that I possess an abundance of fond reminiscences pertaining to my sojourns at this establishment during the course of several years. The Pyramid Cafe serves as a welcoming haven where one can indulge in a steaming bowl of soup and momentarily respite their fatigued pedal extremities subsequent to traversing the Luxor from Bellagio by foot.

The omnipotent authorities responsible for the metamorphosis of Luxor have, in my opinion, irrevocably marred its former splendor, and such an assertion is uttered with utmost sincerity. The Egyptian theme, being an integral component of the edifice's erstwhile allure, has been callously expunged, leaving behind a regrettable and aesthetically displeasing ambiance. In light of the aforementioned alterations implemented at Luxor, in conjunction with its relatively remote location along the Las Vegas Strip, relative to other points of interest, I fear that I shall refrain from partaking in any further financial transactions or investing additional periods of time within the confines of this hotel while visiting Sin City.

"Observations: My assessment of Vietnamese eateries revolves around four fundamental aspects: pho, spring rolls, peanut dipping sauce, and avocado shakes. Unfortunately, Vietnam Grille failed to impress me on multiple levels. Given its reputation as a renowned Vietnamese establishment, my expectations were not adequately met. The spring rolls lacked generosity in size, and while the ingredients were undoubtedly fresh, a certain je ne sais quoi was absent. The peanut sauce was excessively sweet and did not boast a robust peanut flavor. Moreover, the pho was problematically overspiced, resulting in an overwhelming aroma that overpowered the broth, with the star anise exerting an intense influence. The pieces of flank steak did not compare to the delicate, paper-thin slices typically encountered at other Vietnamese restaurants. Instead, the tendon was undercooked, leading to an unpleasant chewiness. Notably, the absence of an avocado smoothie from the menu was glaring. It is worth mentioning that, generally, Vietnamese cuisine is distinguished by its affordability, with a copious amount of food offered for a reasonable price. However, the prices at Vietnam Grille seemed slightly elevated compared to what I am accustomed to.

On a positive note, the service was satisfactory, and parking was abundant. In conclusion, my pursuit of a preferred Vietnamese eatery in Charlotte will continue."

It appears that Eliseevsky has recently undergone a transformation under new leadership, and unfortunately, the experience no longer lives up to the high standards set by its predecessors. Gone are the days of the delectable horseradish-infused vodka shots and cranberry-flavored delights, as the establishment is now sans alcohol license. Furthermore, the menu has been significantly diminished, with options such as caviar, veal, beef in sweet and sour sauce, Shashlik (kebab), and many others no longer available. Although the quality of the cuisine remains relatively consistent, the chicken Kiev (butter-filled) and borscht were satisfying, albeit unremarkable. The ambiance retains its rustic charm, evocative of a cozy log cabin, complemented by contemporary Russian melodies playing in the background and a server who performed a medley of Russian songs (the authenticity of which was uncertain). However, the pace of service was somewhat sluggish, likely attributable to an absence of refined dining expertise on the part of the patron. Despite this, the prices remain steady, ranging from $12 to $16 per dish, which may be considered excessive for the value offered. Notwithstanding, the possibility of sampling alternative dishes in the future still holds appeal, and thus, warrants a revisit.

"Punked! An egregious discrepancy in the quality of service and culinary offerings, resulting in a reprehensible dining experience, characterized by an unacceptable disparity in the value received for the price paid. We had selected this establishment with the expectation of indulging in a refined dining experience, replete with delectable cuisine and exceptional service. However, our expectations were not merely unfulfilled, but utterly decimated, as both the fare and the service fell woefully short of our standards. Specifically, we communicated our time constraints to our server, who assured us that we would have ample time to savor our repast at a leisurely pace. Yet, one hour and ten minutes later, our steaks arrived, while the two parties seated adjacent to us, who had arrived subsequent to our arrival, had already consumed all three courses of their meals. This anomaly can be attributed to either favoritism, inadequate planning, or a combination of both. Consequently, we were compelled to devour our meals in haste, precipitating our tardiness to our scheduled event. Furthermore, our server neglected to include the mushrooms that I had ordered, opting instead to expedite their preparation and subsequently include them on our bill, sans any consideration for complimentary compensation. This instance highlights the dearth of common sense and customer-oriented values in the realm of hospitality. In conclusion, if a premium dining experience is what you seek, it would be judicious to reconsider your choice of dining establishment, as Delmonico fails to deliver an experience commensurate with its pricing."

"A remarkably pleasant domicile situated within a highly desirable neighborhood, yet unfortunately, the cost of residency proves to be quite prohibitive. Furthermore, the property manager, Nancy, exhibits a striking aversion towards youthful inhabitants, as evidenced by her excessively stringent regulations imposed upon children during the summer months, effectively precluding them from venturing outside unaccompanied by an adult at any time. Additionally, Nancy has seen fit to dispatch a memorandum explicitly forbidding the presence of bicycles within the courtyards, which, ironically, had been a significant factor in my initial decision to reside here, given its quaint atmosphere and the availability of a courtyard suitable for children to engage in recreational activities. Moreover, Nancy's extreme fixation on exerting authority and her apparent distaste for young residents have led her to assume the role of an overbearing authoritarian, as exemplified by her unwarranted intervention in my household affairs, questioning the suitability of a mother allowing her 10-year-old child to dispose of trash, and deeming it inappropriate for residents of Altessa. Furthermore, Nancy has chosen to augment her already restrictive measures by installing a chain lock on the pool during summer evenings after 9 pm, effectively transforming the community into a veritable senior citizens' enclave, much to my dismay, as I had previously believed it to be a family-friendly environment. Were it not for Nancy's draconian management style and the exorbitant rent, I would have remained a resident, as it remains a superior choice for apartment living."

I have been on the search for a good nail salon for some time now and this is NOT the place.  I get gel manicures every two weeks like clock work and every two weeks I am going somewhere new. I don't like when they use Acetone to soak off the old gel polish, it it extremely bad for your nails, and I'm not even sure what the half cut lime rubbed on my nails was for.  Also I asked her to just cut them a tiny bit and she cut them almost all the way down.  Not going back and the search continues..........\n(4)

"Prior to participating in the December Yelp Hours event at Cartel located nearby, I indulged in a delectable lunchtime repast at this establishment. The allure of the $6.95 green curry with chicken proved irresistible, and I was compelled to place my order forthwith, as the cacophony of sounds emanating from the premises threatened to overwhelm my senses. Although it was indeed during the lunchtime hours, I have also visited this eatery during the evening, and even with a mere four or five tables occupied at the time, the ambient noise level remained elevated. 

A petite bowl containing vegetable soup with tofu arrived promptly, its light saltiness and fresh flavor serving as an effective precursor to the culinary delights that were to follow. Shortly thereafter, a tripartite platter consisting of jasmine rice, an oval-shaped bowl of green curry, and a diminutive egg roll made its way to my table. Upon sampling the egg roll, my expectations were unfortunately not met, as the presence of * within its confines became apparent. This deviation from the customary Thai recipe was both surprising and disconcerting, as my Thai colleagues have assured me that such an ingredient is not typically included in authentic egg rolls. Moreover, I must note that the pad woon sen offered by this restaurant, which consists of silver-bean noodles accompanied by vegetables, tofu or chicken, and an egg, is habitually served in an overly saucy manner, thereby compromising its inherent quality. 

The green curry sauce, while palatably medium-spiced and pleasantly light, lacked the desired consistency and texture, appearing somewhat watery. Regrettably, the aforementioned factors, including the excessive noise level, questionable pad woon sen preparation, and unorthodox egg roll ingredients, may preclude me from future visits to this dining establishment."

I had the Firehouse Hero, hot roast beef, turkey and ham. It really lacked in flavor, just tasted like warm mystery meat. This is my first time eating at Firehouse and I wasn't impressed. The meat was piled up in the middle so I opened it up to spread it around and with 3 meats it barely covered the bread. Expensive for a toasted sub. Also they made my sandwich on wheat but I asked for white, not a big deal, but when I asked to have it remade they didn't even apologize. And I had to wait until they finished making the other guests sandwiches. I won't be coming back, customer service isn't there, no flavor and overpriced.

It's ok, good for a quick bite. I don't understand the almost cult like following.\nMade a mistake and had the shake instead of pop and was sick for hours.\nStaff was very friendly, but they needed someone dedicated to keeping the place clean.

Is my bartender supposed to be drunker than I am?  I thought there were some rules about that.  This is the old Nick's Fat City building reskinned to look like a swanky deal.  It's really not a bad place for a show unless it is incredibly crowded.  If it is, you'll quickly learn what human sweat tastes like, and you'll forget what it was like to drink beer because you will never get back to the bar.  The last time we were there, I made it to the upstairs which was great, but since the bartender up there was seriously hammered, he didn't seem super interested in giving actual service.  The sound is good, the space isn't bad, and lord knows it's good to have concert venues in the area, but the bartenders kind of blow, and security was having trouble keeping up with the crowd.

-Cozy atmosphere in a nice building with great outdoor seating 
-Server (heavyset black woman) was bad and behaved inappropriately
-Food is slightly pricey for some dishes. Flank steak was amazing. Pizza was okay. Nachos were standard fare. Nothing special here.
-Girlfriend saw server (slender black lady) use restroom, pick her teeth, and leave restroom without washing hands! This was before we left. Awful!

I didn't know that a return policy was so difficult. I went to return $28 worth of facewash and toner that broke my face out and the sales girl was making such a big deal that I had used half of the product. Almost anyone will tell you to keep with a facial routine for a week or two to see if it works. I bought the product two weeks ago. I didn't notice anywhere on the receipt that said \" only use a few times, if you don't like it, bring it back\"....

The only reason I came here was because the TI provided us with a 2 for 1 coupon. The food was over cooked and greasy, and some just tasted funny. The desserts were the only things that we ok, not horrible but not great either. Very disappointing!

I haven't been back to a Chili's in a long time and when we were given a gift card after moving to Pittsburgh we decided to use it. Their service was really nice, but their food was lacking. My husband and I shared their fajitas for 2 and were given the wrong kind of protein, we asked for pork, chicken, and beef. We were given shrimp instead of chicken so they replaced it with the chicken. The waitress let us have the shrimp, but decided to not eat them since they seemed a little under cooked. Also when our sides to the fajitas were served we noted that the beans were cold, and had to flag down the waitress to heat them up. 

I will say that their pork was really good as well as their beef, their guacamole was tasty but could use more lime. 

The ambiance was nice and the place was clean. But overall despite the friendly service, we were not very impressed with their food.

Wow this place has crazy prices for a sandwich come on get real I don't understand what justifies paying so much for a soup or a sandwich and the portions are extremely small do yourself a favor and pass unless you have money to blow

"My prolonged abstinence from consuming dim sum culminated in an unwavering yearning for this delectable cuisine, prompting my spouse and me to visit this establishment on a Sunday prior to noon, with no reservation. Upon entering, I was immediately struck by the welcoming ambiance of the restaurant's well-appointed, expansive, and unified space, which refreshingly diverged from the cramped, obscure nature of many other eateries specializing in this genre of fare. However, my initial optimism was swiftly replaced by disillusionment upon sampling the menu offerings. The edibles were, for the most part, underwhelming and failed to satiate my gastronomical expectations. Specifically, the beef spare ribs were exceedingly greasy, fatty, rubbery, and bony, leaving an unpleasant, lingering aftertaste throughout the day. My shrimp wontons were also unimpressive, lacking the desired temperature and arriving in a state of refrigeration. Additionally, the chow fun was characterized by brevity and aridity, deviating from my preferred texture. Notably, the sole dishes that escaped my censorious scrutiny were the shu mai and the shrimp flat rice noodle, which provided a modicum of gastronomic satisfaction. Apart from these relatively palatable options, the eatery's embellishments, such as the absence of a waiting list, the hospitable service (despite my non-Chinese ethnicity), and the attentive demeanor of both the dim sum attendants and our server, contributed to a positive experience. Our total cost, inclusive of gratuity, amounted to $38 for two individuals."

We went on a Friday night as packed as it looked we actually went right in and got a table. The waitress was good and always on point with service. 

As for the food I ordered the Jack Daniels ribs and shrimp. The shrimp were really good. As for the ribs they showed you shouldn't order ribs unless its a BBQ place. They were suppose to be baby backs but they were dry. Some parts of it were pretty good but a majority of it left your mouth dry wanting water. My wife ordered the steak, sadly a majority of that 10oz consisted of nothing but fat. 

To top it off there was a huge party they sat next to us that ended up getting drunk off their ass. They were so damn loud and obnoxious you couldn't hear your own self think. I don't mind people being loud but c'mon you don't go to a restaurant and get blitzed. But from the way it seemed the manager and servers acted like its an everyday thing so what do I know I was just eating there. 

Eating there made me realize why I never actually go eat there. Nor do I really plan on going anytime soon

"This instance marked neither my initial visit, nor my maiden encounter with subpar service, unfortunately. The 'premium' bundle proved a fallacious misnomer, as the standard of cleanliness failed to meet even the most basic expectations. Visible particulate matter remained on my dashboard, while the windows presented an opaque, grimy appearance. The rear seats and trunk area were utterly neglected, leaving me no choice but to request additional attention to these areas. Even then, the surfaces were merely cursory in their cleanliness, with conspicuous footprints marring the sides of my vehicle. The tires were the sole redeeming feature, boasting a superficial sheen that barely warranted mention. Suffice it to say, I shall not return, nor would I recommend such a lackluster establishment to any individual seeking thorough and meticulous automotive detailing services."

"Despite the abundance of glowing endorsements, this establishment fails to impress outside of the 11pm-4am timeframe characterized by a heavily intoxicated clientele. While securing a table is significantly less arduous, it is not advisable to visit this restaurant for a routine dinner. My reservations regarding the culinary offerings are rooted in my personal indifference towards the unconventional combination of squeaky curds, fries, gravy, and cheese. Although I have had the pleasure of indulging in exceptional poutines that would astound my taste buds regardless of my level of intoxication, the fare served at this establishment does not warrant the prolonged waiting period in a queue, particularly during peak hours when the primary objective is to alleviate the impending symptoms of a hangover."

My nephew who resides in Madison has an unwavering fondness for this establishment, hence we frequent it, yet I must confess that aside from the outdoor seating, I fail to comprehend its allure. The flavor options are remarkably lackluster, with the customary chocolate and vanilla being offered daily, accompanied by a rotating "guest" flavor (on Monday, it happened to be Espresso); furthermore, the staff members appear to be unfriendly and unwelcoming, with their proficiency in the English language being limited. Moreover, I am uncertain about the nature of the ingredients utilized in their products, and I harbor doubts about the authenticity of my raspberry shake, given its absence of seeds (typically a reliable indicator of naturalness) and its slightly synthetic taste. Concerns regarding the hormone-free status of their milk also linger. Despite these reservations, the venue boasts a charming ambiance that appeals to patrons of diverse age groups, and during our latest visit, we became acquainted with K-9 Custard, a canine treat that our furry companion relished thoroughly (priced at $2.75, ensure your pet's hunger before purchasing!). In conclusion, while I would like to award more stars, I must candidly express my disappointment with the underwhelming experience provided by this custard stand in comparison to my previous encounters with richer, more fascinating ice cream and gelato.

Perhaps I expect too much out of a diner. 

They put us in a room that was about 90 degrees. The waitress seemed more fit to be a bartender at the Rouge West than a waitress at a Diner. 

The food was ok, kind of bland and tasteless. I much prefer My Mothers Restaurant for this type of food. 

On the plus side a dude in a bear suit scared the living hell out of a small child, so the trip wasn't a total loss.

"Upon relocating to MTL, we encountered an unanticipated culinary dilemma: my companion had yet to indulge in a quintessential smoked meat sandwich. Our gastronomic quest led us to a nearby Dunns establishment, which, fortuitously, had been endorsed by my roommates who had relished a delectable dining experience at said venue. Thus, I opted to introduce TJ to the local delicacy, albeit with mixed results. Our shared platter, comprising a medium-sized smoked meat sandwich, fries, coleslaw, and a pickle, presented several positives, including copious sustenance for two individuals, commendable fries, and a flavorful pickle. However, certain drawbacks, such as an elevated price point (approximately $15 for a single serving) and underwhelming smoked meat (dry, salty, and excessively processed), tempered our enthusiasm. Ultimately, the dining experience was merely satisfactory, making it challenging to persuade my companion to venture forth and sample smoked meat once more."

Enjoyed the beautiful weather sitting on the terrace at the Wynn but our service was horrendous.  \"I'll be right back\" translated into \"I'll be back in 15 minutes\".  Same as \"your order will be right out\" meaning \"I have not even put your order into the kitchen yet.\"  It took 35 minutes to get our food after we ordered it and the food was not that impressive.  My omelette was subpar, the hashbrowns were inedible and the french toast tasted almost burnt.  However, the black angus burger was delicious and after tasting my husband's burger I knew I made a mistake in ordering.  Don't go here if you are in a hurry and sit outside if the weather is nice so that at least the atmosphere will make up for the crappy service and mediocre food.

Wynn, you have to be eff'in kidding me. I know you feed your employees better than this in the cafeteria.  Most of the food was per bunk.  You didn't even have lox with the bagels but you have no problem charging 40 bucks for breakfast.  Shame on me, you lost me for life. 

The food: The only good thing about the food was the desserts.  The sushi was similar to  gas station sushi.  It was not fit for human consumption.  
Make sure you confirm they are not serving breakfast.  I made the mistake and it was super expensive for pancakes and bacon. They had no quality breakfast food at all. Shoney's quality at best. 

The line: 1 hour and 30 mins for sub par food. I should have went to McDonald's. NEVER AGAIN!

Perhaps our expectations were excessively elevated, or possibly we merely failed to perceive the ostensible appeal, but the generally acclaimed and ardently cherished Honey Salt did not quite live up to its prodigious reputation, at least in our experience. Following an amicable encounter with the accommodating bartender during lunch, we embarked upon a gastronomical excursion that unfortunately proved somewhat disappointing. Specifically, the initial offering of calamari was characterized by an unfortunate rubberiness and an unpleasant greasiness that bordered on the inedible, thereby establishing a less-than-auspicious beginning. Subsequently, we opted to share the renowned Biloxi chicken sandwich, which, regrettably, exhibited a notable lack of moisture and a certain blandness, coupled with the My Wife's Favorite Salad (featuring duck confit), an uninspired assemblage that neglected to impress. Furthermore, the Caesar salad, adorned with an unpalatable abundance of kale, tragically fell short of our expectations, its flavor profile reduced to a barely perceptible hint of saltiness derived from the minute shreds of overcooked, previously prepared fried egg situated atop the bed of wilted lettuce. Fortunately, the attentive bartender, cognizant of the unappealing nature of the offending egg, graciously provided a fresh, properly cooked alternative, thus salvaging the dish from utter disaster. In conclusion, while no compelling reason exists to revisit this establishment solely for culinary purposes, the possibility of encountering Carrot Top at the bar may, for some, constitute a moderately enticing incentive.

I went in on my lunch break one day to try out their bento boxes.  I ordered brown rice, garlic noodles, diced salmon, and diced filet mignon.  As you can tell with the pictures posted on here, Volcano Grille tries to bring a menu filled with healthful options (salad, choice of carbs, and protein). While this may be the case, flavor should not be compromised. I was actually a bit disappointed because their food was not packed with flavor.  I understand that they have a bunch of different sauces to pick from and take to go, but at least make the flavors of the actual food stand for themselves.  And no, the seasoning of the garlic on the noodles, and the rub on the fish did not really help.  

Besides their food being a level or two above the borderline of bland, staff was really helpful.  The noise level is a bit average here, not loud at all.  The dining area was very clean, so I appreciate that.  

I would say that if you do not really want to be impressed and are looking for just "ok" food that you can just smother a bunch of sauces and sriracha on, consider going here.

My significant other coerced me into visiting this establishment due to her ardent desire to indulge in unlimited portions of crustacean extremities. Upon arriving at 7 pm, we observed that the venue was teeming with patrons, yet we were seated in a timely manner. It is worth noting that payment is not required initially; however, beverages are supplementary. The buffet itself was rather diminutive and offered a limited selection of subpar Asian cuisine, including several platters of shrimp and fish, a few plates of sushi encased in plastic wrap, and a scant amount of crab legs. The dessert bar was a disappointment - consisting of generic cookies, stale cake, fruit, pudding, and soft-serve ice cream. During our hour-long stay, I made five excursions to the buffet, and not once did the staff replenish the offerings. The spare ribs appeared unappetizing, which garnered attention from the numerous clientele, resulting in minimal consumption. Conversely, the crab proved to be the crowd favorite, as everyone availed themselves of copious amounts. Personally, I am not partial to seafood. Others have bestowed favorable reviews upon this restaurant, primarily citing its affordability as the sole advantage. While the fare may not be particularly impressive, an unrestricted supply of ice cream is available. For visual reference, please peruse the images located at the following URL: <http://www.usmenuguide.com/krazybuffetmenupics.html>

They transport you from seat to seat as you undergo various treatments, deftly orchestrated by the salon's personnel who exhibit remarkable proficiency in their respective domains, albeit with a discernible dearth of staff members, prompting Lannie to concurrently attend to two clients at once, which, while demonstrating her admirable multitasking abilities, might potentially compromise the quality of service delivered; furthermore, upon venturing to cleanse my hands, I encountered unsanitary conditions surrounding the faucets of the washbasins, specifically those situated within close proximity to the water dispensing apparatus, thereby eliciting my utter discontent and disappointment.

"The positive aspects of our experience at this bakery were undoubtedly the delectable cupcakes we sampled. Specifically, the quartet of red velvet, pink champagne, s'mores, and peanut butter chocolate varieties we procured was quite satisfying, despite some reservations regarding the unconventional flavor profile of the pink champagne iteration. Nonetheless, we found the cupcakes to be suitably moist and the frosting to be of satisfactory quality, which, in our opinion, are the primary criteria for an enjoyable cupcake experience.  

Regrettably, our encounter was not without its drawbacks. Upon entering the establishment, we were met with a noticeable lack of warmth and hospitality from the staff members present. Their demeanor could be described as brusque and impatient, giving us the distinct impression that they would have preferred us to vacate the premises as expeditiously as possible. This was particularly perplexing given the relatively low volume of customers at the time of our visit, which led us to surmise that perhaps the proprietors or their employees were experiencing an off day. Additionally, our sampling of further flavors yielded less than desirable results, specifically in the case of the orange creamsicle and strawberry cupcakes, which exhibited an overly synthetic taste and an unpleasant chemical odor that we found objectionable.  

In conclusion, while the cupcakes themselves were certainly palatable, the deficiency in customer service and the questionable quality of certain flavors left us feeling ambivalent about our overall experience at this bakery. As the chalkboard inside the shop so aptly put it, 'Can't say anything about customer service, but the cupcakes are good!' â?a sentiment with which we wholeheartedly concur."

"Initially, the culinary offerings possessed an acceptable flavor profile, albeit with a conspicuous sodium-rich quality. However, subsequent to partaking in their fare for an extended duration, I was compelled to desist. Uncertain whether the issue lay within the salt content or the plethora of processed constituents, but my digestive system and overall wellbeing suffered significantly post-consumption. Which is lamentable, as I harbor a certain fondness for the po'boy sandwich. \nIn summary, if one's dietary preferences lean towards indulging in processed, albeit vegan, victuals, this establishment may serve as a suitable venue. Convenient, expedient, and relatively relaxed, it presents an attractive option for those seeking such attributes. Nonetheless, for individuals prioritizing nutritional value and unadulterated sustenance, alternative destinations may be more suitable."

"I was experiencing an intense desire for some barbecued delights and decided to accompany my mother to this establishment, perusing the extensive menu that boasted an array of delectable options and inducing salivation in both of us. The biscuits, while slightly dense in texture, possessed a satisfying flavor. We opted to share a two-meat combination platter, which proved to be a colossal portion. The beef and St. Louis ribs we selected were somewhat chewy, prompting me to inquire whether the latter was indeed St. Louis or baby back ribs, as the meat was scarce. We were informed that it was the former, yet its taste closely resembled the latter. Furthermore, our experience with the mashed sweet potatoes left much to be desired, as its consistency and flavor strongly evoked the sensation of consuming infant food. However, the apple pie we sampled was generously portioned and exhibited a satisfactory degree of culinary excellence. In conclusion, while this venue appears well-suited for large gatherings and offers copious helpings of food and drink, it fell short in terms of authenticity and gastronomic quality. If I were to choose a chain restaurant specializing in barbecue cuisine, my preference would lie with Tony Roma's."

"Upon visiting this establishment on a Saturday, I was eager to peruse their offerings, having recently relocated to Pittsburgh from New York, where I had access to an array of exceptional juice bars. However, my expectations were not entirely met, as the selection of juices available was rather limited in scope. It is my sincere hope that the proprietors of this business will draw inspiration from esteemed establishments such as Liquiteria (http://liquiteria.com/cold-pressed-juices.php) and Juice Generation (http://www.juicegeneration.com/menu/smoothies), both of which offer a diverse array of cold-pressed juices and smoothies. Furthermore, I would suggest that they consider blending juices and smoothies on-site, as this would undoubtedly enhance the overall experience for patrons. In light of the aforementioned factors, I must express some skepticism regarding the likelihood of our return during the summer months, unless, of course, they opt to expand their menu to include a greater variety of options. Nevertheless, I extend my well wishes to the proprietors in their future endeavors."

"As a native San Franciscan, it is only natural that I have had the pleasure of dining at both Crustacean and Thanh Long within my hometown. However, I must say that the culinary experience offered by this particular establishment is incomparable to either of the aforementioned eateries. During a recent excursion to Las Vegas approximately three years ago, I had the opportunity to partake in a friend's celebratory gathering, which of course necessitated a visit to this esteemed restaurant. Upon ordering the garlic crab and garlic noodles, our server presented us with a crab shell lavishly stuffed with an abundance of crab meat, the taste of which was remarkably dissimilar to that of its San Franciscan counterparts. I must admit that I was thoroughly impressed by the novelty of cracking open one's own crab, an experience that was further enhanced by the slightly elevated cost. Notwithstanding the unconventional gastronomical adventure, the ambiance of the venue itself was quite pleasant, prompting us to indulge in a bottle of wine and optimize our evening's enjoyment."

"Underwhelmed by the culinary offerings and their inherent quality, we were disenchanted by the seemingly recycled nature of the a la carte entrees, such as the curries and samosas, which appeared to be leftovers from either the current day's buffet or perhaps even the previous day's. The absence of flavorful complexity and textural variety in the naan bread, which was overly plain and exhibited a burnt quality, only served to further accentuate our disappointment. Visually, the dishes presented themselves in a manner that was merely adequate, with sauces that boasted an unnaturally bright, neon hue; however, it was the one-dimensional taste of each item that truly left something to be desired. Despite requesting all dishes be prepared'mild' in terms of spiciness, several members of our party still experienced gastrointestinal distress later that evening. It is with great regret that we cannot, in good conscience, recommend this establishment, despite its outward appearance of authenticity, to our friends and loved ones."

"We recently celebrated Father's Day by partaking in a culinary excursion at this esteemed eatery, and while the gastronomical offerings were indeed satisfactory, the quality of service we received was somewhat subpar. Specifically, our server's attendance to our table was sporadic and inadequate, leaving us feeling parched and neglected for the majority of the meal. Moreover, when we required additional condiments, we were compelled to solicit the assistance of an alternative staff member, as our designated server was nowhere to be found. Although it is conceivable that this poor service was simply an isolated incident, it is equally possible that it may be symptomatic of a more pervasive issue. Nonetheless, we shall reserve judgment until we have had the opportunity to sample the restaurant's wares on a subsequent occasion."
I had ordered a pizza for the NFC championship game. I understand you could be busy but my order was cold and the cheese had dried out. Unacceptable.

I'm giving it 2 stars for the service and quickness. Now for the food, we ordered the pad Thai and the pad se ew. The pad thai was a big clump of sticky gummy ramen like noodles you could barely chew let alone swallow, but the flavor was good they need a flatter noodle and the chicken was over cooked. The pad se ew had good flavor but the noodles were not wide the pork was tough.\n\nI prefer the food at the corner Thai kitchen around the corner on trop.  Give it a try and please let me know what you think.  I jugde a Thai place on the pad Thai if they can make that well, you can bet the rest will be good too.

This place is way overrated. They hook you with their one signature item (a glorified Mocha Ice Blended from Coffee Bean) and get you for their overpriced basic menu items. The service is sooooooooo slow, especially for a place that really isn't that big. Good place to hang out if you're in the right mood and the right people though I suppose.

"The culinary offerings at this establishment are of exceptional quality, and I must say that the ambiance is quite pleasant as well. However, if you intend to partake in their happy hour specials, I would advise you to exercise caution when selecting your seating arrangement. During my recent visit, our group of revelers opted for an alfresco table, only to discover that our particular table did not fall under the happy hour pricing umbrella. Had we situated ourselves at the bar to our right or at an alternative table to our left, we would have been able to capitalize on a substantial savings of approximately fifty percent on our total bill. Unfortunately, even the manager proved unable to supersede this policy, despite our protests. It is worth noting that the table in question was positioned between the primary entrance gate and the main entrance of the restaurant, rendering the term 'private' somewhat of a misnomer."

Waited a really long time to be seated for a mediocre birthday dinner. I ordered some sort of shrimp pasta plate.  Our meal was a long time coming after being seated. My shrimp had gone bad...really bad, so I ordered something meatless. The replacement dish took so long to arrive that I ended up eating part of my wife's  I only had a limited amount of time before an event I had to be at and couldn't wait any longer for my meal. My daughter didn't finish her plate & my wife was underwhelmed by hers (same thing I had).  It just tasted bland to me.\n\nThere are too many alternatives in this town to wait 40 minutes on \"meh\" entrees that are not inexpensive! That's what makes the world go round though. Some people swear by this chain. Just not my thing.

I requested ornately embellished large-sized cupcakes for an intimate celebratory gathering commemorating a milestone anniversary of a family member. One of the four individually portioned confectionaries was designated to feature the inscription 'Happy Birthday Grandma' prominently displayed upon its surface. The cupcake in question boasted a plain white circular adornment devoid of any elaborate design or embellishment, with the salutation 'Happy Birthday Grandma' applied haphazardly in a stark black marker. My sentiments regarding this discovery can best be described as utter dismay tinged with profound disappointment. The unrefined appearance of the cupcake's adornment seemed incongruous with the otherwise fastidious presentation of the dessert, thereby detracting from the overall aesthetic appeal of the culinary creation. Notwithstanding my chagrin, I elected to persevere with the original plan, albeit with a slight modification involving the substitution of a fondant-based circular accoutrement in place of the erstwhile plastic component. Following the postprandial festivities, I must admit that the gustatory experience afforded by the cupcakes was quite satisfying, despite my earlier reservations concerning their visual appeal.

"It perplexes me profoundly why individuals are effusive about this production, as my expectations were not met, despite my previous admiration for their work on the ABDC. As a Las Vegas show, it falls short in numerous aspects. The only redeeming quality was the musical accompaniment, which elicited momentary hilarity when they briefly performed moves reminiscent of 'Single Ladies.' However, the narrative was unengaging and nonsensical, with an inexplicable focus on a deceased custodian. The choreography lacked synchronization, the attire was unremarkable, and the masks created a barrier that precluded any semblance of emotional connection with the performers. My recommendation is to only attend if tickets are complimentary, as paying for admission would not be worthwhile."

Dear Beat,

It is my sincere hope that this correspondence finds you in an optimal state of existential fulfillment, and that the inherent trendiness of your establishment has not been compromised by the proximity to an exceptional hub of artistic expression (Emergency Arts). However, I must confess that my experiences with the hipster staff responsible for attending to my culinary needs have been consistently marred by an unfortunate display of haughty demeanor. It is my ardent desire that, in the interest of fostering a more convivial atmosphere, they might consider adopting a more affable and helpful countenance, thereby enhancing the overall dining experience for patrons such as myself.

With the notable exceptions of Heather (whose exceptional customer service skills are truly commendable) and the charming foreign gentleman whose adeptness at slicing tomatoes is a source of perpetual fascination for me, the prevalent attitude exhibited by the staff has been one of aloofness and disinterest. While I must admit that the quality of your food offerings is indeed impressive, and that the ambient surroundings and diverse array of weekly events do serve to mitigate the deficiencies in the coffee and espresso department, I cannot help but feel a sense of disappointment and disconnect. My fervent hope is that, in the future, I might be able to cultivate a deeper emotional investment in your establishment, but until such time, I fear that our relationship shall remain tenuous at best.

Yours sincerely,

[Your Name]

Well... I would maybe have been inclined to give Chez Claudette a higher rating if it hadn't been for the following....

ordered a poutine classique to go, and then because it was pouring rain decided to eat it inside by the front door.  Even though the place wasn't busy, our french quebec waitress told us that "next time we order it to go, we have to eat it outside".

the sauce also kind of tasted like thick canned poutine sauce.  

it was still a delicious poutine and we ate the whole thing.

Our small poutine was around $7.  the same price as any other poutine spot.

Man, the quality of Outback has really gone down since the last time I came here. I hope it was just an off night, but everything seemed to go wrong.  The menu was wrong on several occasions. My husband ordered the Sam Adams on draft. Says it should be a Boston Lager, but the Summer Ale came out. Apparently they were out of Boston Lager on tap but the server didn't tell us and didn't offer anything else. The chicken artichoke flatbread was delicious, but the menu says a \"sprinkling of parmesan cheese\". The thing was heavily covered in it. I would have asked for light cheese if I'd known it was more like a cheese crisp. I ordered the steak salad medium, it came out medium rare. Also, it didn't say that gorgonzola cheese crumbles came on it, otherwise I would have asked for those to be left off. So unfortunately I had to send it back. The manager was very polite and took the flatbread off our bill, but when he tried to explain that they were out of the Boston Lager beer and that's why we got the Summer Ale, I was a little annoyed. Okay that's fine, it would have just been nice to know that in the beginning. Don't give me excuses. All in all it was a very mediocre service and just not as good as I remember.

We experienced a pleasant culinary excursion, yet unfortunately, my spouse succumbed to a bout of food poisoning, which precipitated her awakening at the ungodly hour of 4 am, accompanied by acute gastrointestinal discomfort and persistent nausea throughout the day, rendering her unable to retain any liquid or solid substances within her digestive system, leading to extreme dehydration. Furthermore, the restaurant's management, despite their politeness, appeared to harbor suspicions that I was attempting to exploit them when I requested a partial abatement of our substantial bill, which amounted to $300, a rather sizable sum; this turn of events was quite vexing, to say the least, and left much to be desired in terms of good fortune.

Ok, so going to Vegas, you have to do at least one buffet. However this place should not be on your bucket list.

Crab legs...yes, prime rib yes....but both were of low quality and the prime rib was super dry. And yah, it's supposed to be a French buffet so they did have some of my macarons, but they were gross and unappealing. They didn't care about the presentation at all with respect to the macarons.

The food handles were sticky and gross. There's no wet naps or purell nearby. It's like someone purposefully lathered the the food handles with syrup and pretty much played a prank on everyone. Gross, and unattended, and lack of ownership amongst the cleaners and food servers.

The waitress knows who you are too, ethnicity, etc...so when she saw a bunch of filipinos, she got into Filipino mode. I guess she really wants to provide that awesome customer service, that or she wants a fat tip at the end. Either way, she was pretty attentive. 

It was a Sunday, so champagne was included. They went all out with the Wycliff Jean champagne....whewwww. Mix with the oj and you get the mimosa. Not bad, they even allowed us to keep the bottle to walk aimlessly throughout the casino and along the vegas strip.

For $30, I would probably invest a little more somewhere else next time. This was more of a cafeteria leftovers like food with mediocre quality instead of the higher more quality food that can be found elsewhere.

Normally, I wouldn't bother reviewing a chain restaurant, but the subpar service I received during my recent visit compelled me to share my experience in writing. This review focuses primarily on the quality of service rather than the culinary offerings. Upon being seated, our server promptly took our beverage order and delivered our complimentary bread, along with our entrees. However, it took an unacceptable 15 minutes for our Blossomin' Onion appetizer to arrive, followed by another 20-minute wait for our main courses. Our server offered a feeble excuse, attributing the delay to a supposed computer malfunction. This explanation seemed dubious, as patrons who arrived after us received their orders without incident. I would have preferred honesty over such an implausible justification. Despite the prolonged wait, the taste and presentation of the food were satisfactory, and we devoured our meals with relish. After finishing our food, we waited an additional 10 minutes for our check, only to spend another 5 minutes awaiting our change. In total, we spent more time waiting than dining. Typically, I leave a minimum of 20% gratuity, but given the lackluster service, we opted for a reduced tip of approximately 12%. At that point, I had become thoroughly disenchanted with the overall experience.

I am not one to write reviews but I had to on this place.  I was super excited to try this place.  It looks cool and seems to have a cool vibe.  I've been waiting for this place to work out some quirks since I have heard bad things and they have bad reviews on yelp.  I thought they are new and are just trying to find the groove.

My boyfriend and I went last night for date night. We saw all the bad reviews, then a couple good reviews showed up and we thought let's give this place a shot, maybe the other reviewers are just not used to this style of Mexican food.  The price is what I would expect at a this kind of place but the food was not.  The chips and salsa were great but the two entrees we got were sooooo bland.  Where is the flavor, it seems to be non-existent.

Our server was great, she even offered to take one of the entrees off the bill.  Which I think is super cool because I assumed we would just pay for them and be unhappy.

Bottom line, I will not come back for food!

I did see they have happy hour and I have heard the margaritas are good, so I will come back and try the discounted margaritas some time. Maybe if we drink a couple margaritas we won't care that the food is bland.

A decidedly unremarkable athletic pub. Advantages:  well-maintained, visually appealing (albeit somewhat antiseptic) ambiance; congenial, accommodating, and pulchritudinous personnel; expansive televisions and colossal projection screens, ensuring an optimal viewing experience from any seat. Drawbacks:  limited selection of artisanal draft beers; uninspired bill of fare with underseasoned comestibles (specifically, the Southwest Turkey sandwich lacked flavor, while the accompanying coleslaw was devoid of vitality); prolonged interval of ten minutes elapsed before receiving an initial beverage, even during a tranquil Sunday evening. Would confer supplementary celestial bodies for ameliorating any singular aspect, and two stars if all deficiencies were addressed.

Yet another Asian-inspired food chain! Oh c'mon do we need this in Champaign? We have so many Chinese/Korean restaurants in campustown and honestly, they are way better than Flat Top. 

So, the whole stir-fry concept that they have is actually Mongolian BBQ. The difference is that they have tonnes of raw vegetables and ingredients to choose from. Oh, not to mention, weird sauces and food combinations. My combo was okay (it was brown rice, clams, beef, vege, salmon and roti prata) but if you don't have a sense of what goes with what, then your dinner is going to be a disaster. 

It's clever of them to have this pick-your-own-ingredients kinda concept because if the food was bad and you complained, they can point their fingers back at you and say that you chose the ingredients. Then again, you are not the only culprit. The grill sensei is responsible as well. If he over-grilled your food, it will taste just as bad no matter how wonderful your selections are. My friend's moo shu was not wrapped very well and some of the rolls fell apart. Well, there goes your dinner. 

I think it is good to try it once but more that once? You decide. Still, the combo of rice, salmon and roti prata bothers me. Maybe I am just a stuck-up purist who thinks that chickpea dhal is the only way to go. Could this be a one-hit wonder like Bar Louie? We'll have to see.

"While it would be inaccurate to describe the culinary offerings at this establishment as anything approaching exceptional, it is undeniable that certain aspects of the dining experience merit commendation. Specifically, the quality of the edibles, which, on a scale of one to ten, with five being the minimum acceptable threshold for gastronomical satisfaction and ten representing an unparalleled degree of epicurean delight, rates a respectable seven. However, it must be noted that the ambiance, while not unpleasant, falls short of truly captivating, garnering a mere six on the same scale. Furthermore, the value proposition, taking into account both the cost and the quantity of sustenance provided, earns a middling rating of eight. Notably, the service, characterized by an almost perplexing lack of attentiveness, leaves much to be desired, warranting a meager five on the aforementioned scale. Nonetheless, it is advisable to sample the creme puffs, which, despite their unremarkable provenance, prove to be a satisfying indulgence. Be that as it may, the experience is marred by an inexplicable tardiness in settling the bill, which, compounded by the sluggish pace of table turns during the luncheon hours, renders the overall experience somewhat less than optimal. In conclusion, while the novelty of the restaurant's conveyor belt system, reminiscent of those found in Japan, may hold some appeal for the uninitiated, it cannot compensate for the various deficiencies in the dining experience."

I availed myself of his proficiencies, specifically Paul's, approximately three years prior, in relation to an infestation of termites. My selection of his services was predicated upon the favorable assessments he had received on Yelp. Following the initial treatment, he was obligated to return roughly four months subsequent to the primary application, which I deemed appropriate, given the circumstances. Upon contacting him via telephone, he expressed his intentions to return, albeit reluctantly, as he was not pecuniarily compensated for his efforts, due to the warranty's still being in effect. At the time of his second visit, he emphasized, with palpable displeasure, the financial burden that honoring the warranty entailed. As a consumer, I have never been subjected to such a peculiar scenario, wherein a business proprietor sought to induce guilt in me, for merely requesting that they uphold their contractual obligations, which, might I add, I had paid an additional premium for. Consequently, I shall refrain from engaging his services in the future.

Shucks..a bit disappointed, last night I took family for the first time hoping to have the same experience as we did for about 10 times. The Clam Bake was the reason we always go on a Sat to have the $5 off, found that it wasn't anymore...crabs was an added option and you had to pay extra for it. It was still tasty but we should have gone to a buffet for the price we paid...It was still tasty though...Sadly..Shucks is now not on the top of my list..for value as the prices went up immensely...

The pizza is pretty good. Especially at 2am. But when it takes over an hour for delivery, no thank you. I shouldn't have to call 3 times to find out where my pizza is. Then when he finally showed up he asked for a tip. That's the best way to not get a tip.

I visited this establishment with my significant other last week for an evening meal, and I must say that my expectations were not entirely met. Despite the courteous and obliging demeanor of the waiting staff, the culinary offerings took an inordinate amount of time to arrive, and there were only a scant few other patrons present in the dining area. Upon the eventual arrival of our repast, my companion's poultry dish was unfortunately not adequately cooked. The waitress, however, demonstrated great proficiency in addressing the issue by promptly removing the item from our bill and ensuring that it was properly prepared before its return to our table. Although the flavor profile of the dish may have been somewhat lacking, we were, at that juncture, primarily concerned with the satisfaction of consuming palatable victuals. In light of this experience, I would not wholeheartedly endorse partaking in a dinner meal at this venue, but it may prove suitable for those seeking indulgent desserts.

I discover it perplexing that individuals possess a predilection for this establishment, as the culinary offerings are, in my opinion, subpar. I have an unwavering fondness for any dish that incorporates chilli cheese; however, the chilli cheese items available at this venue are, regrettably, unpalatable. Even a novice chef such as myself can effortlessly prepare superior quality hot dogs in the comfort of their own abode. My sole motivation for repeatedly visiting this eatery is to indulge in their delectable ice cream and lemonade float, an indulgence that elicits a profound sense of satisfaction. Despite my reservations regarding the edibles, I persist in partaking of their menu, with the jalapeno poppers being my preferred victual, which, fortunately, exhibit a satisfying degree of flavorfulness.

This pertains to an excursion that transpired approximately a month prior. During this visit, I consumed a burger and a couple of beverages classified as beer, while my spouse opted for a chicken flatbread accompanied by a pair of mixed drinks. Unfortunately, the fries provided were limp and overcooked, while the temperature of the burger served was tepid. My wife's culinary experience was satisfactory, albeit unremarkable. However, what truly distinguished this establishment was the utter absence of any semblance of urgency in the provision of service. I did not formally time the waitstaff, but various delays became apparent throughout the dining experience, including those encountered during seating, menu procurement, replenishment of beverages, food preparation, and ultimately, receipt of the bill. It became patently evident that avid players of slot machines and a select few regular clientele garnered a disproportionate amount of attention and expedited service from the staff, whereas all others were afforded a markedly inferior level of care. Consequentially, I felt compelled to dock Mr. John a star in light of the subpar nature of the service proffered. Given my proximity to the establishment, a plethora of superior, consistent alternatives exist within the local community, thereby rendering my inclination to return dubious at best.

This culinary establishment offers fare that is economically priced, ostensibly due to its perceived quality. The egg rolls possess an unmistakable texture reminiscent of flour, while the fried rice lacks both flavor and warmth. Although the vegetables in the vegetable lo mein exhibit a satisfying crunch and freshness, their taste is overpowered by an excessive amount of garlic, rendering them unpalatable. The eatery's location, situated on a rather unsavory thoroughfare, belies its interior, which boasts cleanliness and relative tranquility. Given the abundance of Chinese restaurants in Madison, it remains unclear why patrons would opt to dine at this particular venue.

"Although it fails to motivate me to elevate the star rating in my assessment, it is still worth mentioning that David, the General Manager of Rice and Company, reached out to convey his worry and remorse regarding the subpar service I encountered during my visit. Such attentive client care is what I would have appreciated while dining at the establishment. It remains to be seen whether a hypothetical 'trickle-down effect' or any analogous economic phenomenon will manifest itself, but I am skeptical about voluntarily participating in such an experiment on my next visit."

Obviously great selection of Rebel merchandise but outrageous prices. Seriously, the prices are almost twice what they should be. Why does the same hat cost $30 here, $20 at the ballgame, and $16 online from the manufacturer? But... If you want nice Rebelbilia, they've got stuff here that no one else carries. Bring a few quarters for parking.

First, their clothing is arranged by color, not by size. While thrift stores may think this looks great, it's not great for people shopping for one size.\n\nAlso, their prices were outrageous. Many of the items I liked I could have bought new for a little bit more. The upscale prices did not match the dingy and dirty store. We won't be back to this one.

If we could get my g-parents network switched over, I'd NEVER have them return to this St Lukes.  Quality of care seriously depends on who's on shift and what floor you're on.  Cath-Lab and ICU staff has always been fantastic, but staff on the 7th floor is a hit or a miss.  Likewise with staff in the ER. \n\nSeriously makes me wonder WHY some people get into the medical field, when they clearly are not cut out for working in that type of environment.

It started out really well. Was seated in less than 10 minutes and our server started out great, but it went downhill from there. \nThe food was great but they forgot our appetizer. Trying to find our server was impossible. Had to keep asking for refills n they forgot to bring out the dessert for my friends bday. When it came to paying the check....once again had to find the server. Keep in mind it wasn't that busy.  Got the busboy to finally take our check. Maybe ill just try another location.

Pizza was ok.. I ordered Vinnies, which is your choice of 5 toppings.  Italian sausage, black olives, onions, garlic and basil.  It wasn't bad - but it wasn't great either.  \n\nThe server was exceptionally friendly and helpful - but the service was the high point of the experience.

The food is good, but it is very annoying that they will deliver to my house some days and not other days..... Your delivery range is 3 miles and grub hub says I live 2.8 miles away, mapquest says 3.3.  Either way I think its close enough.  Don't be jerks and deliver me some damn Asian food when I want it, not just on days when you have nothing better to do.

My vehicle experienced an operational failure within my residential garage, prompting me to contact this towing company, based on the recommendation provided by my automotive dealership. Following my initial telephone call, which transpired at 10:30 am, I was informed that the estimated time of arrival for the tow truck would be approximately 90 minutes. However, upon the lapse of said time frame, with no signs of the tow truck in sight, I opted to place a follow-up call to the company at 12:30 pm. During this second communication, I was assured that the tow truck would arrive within 30 minutes. Notably, the representative also requested that I provide my personal information once again, sparking my curiosity regarding the fate of the data I had previously conveyed during our initial conversation. As the hours passed, my frustration mounted, and I began to ponder the possibility of seeking assistance from an alternative towing service. Ultimately, after enduring a three-hour wait, the tow truck finally arrived at 2:30 pm. Although the driver exhibited a friendly demeanor, he encountered notable difficulties while attempting to jump-start my vehicle, necessitating the utilization of specialized equipment to facilitate its removal from the garage. Upon completion of the task, the driver departed without extending a farewell gesture or expressing gratitude for my patronage, leaving me feeling undervalued as a customer. In light of this experience, I am unlikely to engage the services of this particular towing company in the future. Moreover, I cannot help but wonder whether exceptional customer service has become a rarity in today's business landscape.

"We visited this establishment for lunch today, and upon perusing the menu, elected to order two burgers and a large Cajun fry to share, anticipating a delectable meal. However, our culinary experience was marred by an unfortunate series of events. Despite being the sole patrons present, we were compelled to wait for approximately 15 minutes before our order was prepared. Upon receiving our food, we discovered that the Cajun fries were not prepared in accordance with our request, prompting us to return them to the counter. The gentleman behind the counter, a larger individual with spectacles, inquired whether we desired the fries to be remade, to which we replied affirmatively. He then offered us a container of Cajun seasoning, which we declined, expressing our preference for freshly prepared fries with the appropriate seasoning. Our request seemed to be met with indifference, as the gentleman ignored us thereafter, leaving us no choice but to return to our table and consume our meal without further incident. It is my opinion that the level of customer service we received fell short of expectations, particularly when compared to the excellent service we have experienced at other locations, such as the Val Vista and Baseline restaurant at Dana Park. In light of this, I would consider traveling the additional distance to enjoy superior service and high-quality cuisine."

"The establishment presented itself to be merely adequate, with pancakes that failed to impress. The taste was reminiscent of a pre-made mix, lacking the fluffiness and texture one would expect from a quality pancake dish. Furthermore, the addition of powdered sugar, which I personally find unappealing, only served to detract from the overall experience. The waiting period, both for seating and food delivery, proved to be within the realm of averageness, neither particularly lengthy nor expedient. Unfortunately, the orange juice served did not fare much better, possessing an unmistakable similarity to the economical brands commonly found on grocery store shelves. Despite my initial enthusiasm for supporting a non-chain restaurant, my encounter with the pancakes left me underwhelmed and skeptical about their ability to deliver a truly exceptional dining experience."

I would confer upon STK in Las Vegas a rating of five stars, were it not for their deplorable customer service, which regrettably compels me to reduce my evaluation to two stars. Specifically, the blonde woman who processed our reservation exhibited an unmistakable haughtiness, bordering on impertinence, and her mannerisms struck me as utterly inappropriate for someone in a client-facing role. Furthermore, our server seemed overeager to expedite our dining experience, posing queries such as "Are you done now?" without first ascertaining whether we desired to procure additional sustenance for takeaway. This brusque behavior, coupled with his precipitous removal of our plates while one of my companions was still partaking in their meal, led us to deliberately prolong our ordering and consumption of desserts, ultimately resulting in a gratuity of merely 10% on a $400 tab. It is my conviction that courteousness and attentive service are indispensable components of a satisfactory dining encounter, and I cannot help but feel that the staff at STK fell short of these expectations. Notwithstanding the aforementioned deficiencies, I must admit that the culinary offerings at this establishment are indeed quite delectable.

Pathetic, utterly deplorable, and patently unacceptable, charging exorbitant fees for a meager glimpse of automotive masterpieces cordoned off by flimsy barriers, thereby denying enthusiasts the opportunity for an up-close examination and tactile experience with these magnificent machines. A glaring contrast to the welcoming atmosphere fostered by the Arizona Ferrari dealership, where an extensive array of vehicles is accessible for perusal at one's leisure, sans the burdensome constraints imposed by the aforementioned venue. A veritable travesty, leaving visitors feeling shortchanged and disillusioned.
Turns out eating here, appropriately, is a crap game. Food always OK To good. Service, you need to bring your luck.

"Upon our second visit, we opted for a Greek Salad accompanied by Chicken Kabobs; regrettably, the diminutive proportions of the plate rendered it arduous to portion out the meager serving of iceberg lettuce, resulting in an unfortunate cascade of ingredients onto the table. Furthermore, the chicken was excessively sauce-laden, rendering it challenging to consume with any semblance of dignity. However, our previous experience with their gyro sandwich remained a pleasant memory, as it was prepared to perfection. Despite these shortcomings, the staff exuded warmth and kindness, fostering a welcoming ambiance."

We indulged in an impromptu visit to this establishment today, and our culinary excursion yielded a rather ambiguous outcome. While the tofu summer rolls demonstrated a certain degree of gastronomical prowess, their quality was somewhat diminished by a lack of exceptionalism. In contrast, the lemongrass soup exhibited a profound depth of flavor that was nothing short of remarkable. However, my pad see ew, despite its inherent merits, was regrettably compromised by an excessive saccharinity that bordered on the unpalatable. My spouse, whose gustatory preferences are notoriously discerning, experienced a series of unfortunate events that began with the Penang curry, which, much to his dismay, was prepared with coconut milk despite our server's assurance to the contrary. This unforeseen development precipitated a chain reaction of gastronomic disappointment, culminating in a Pad Thai dish that, while undoubtedly delectable, was marred by an overpowering sweetness and a formidable capsaicin kick. In conclusion, while Curry on Murray earns commendation for its ambiance and hospitality, the cuisine, unfortunately, falls short of true excellence.

"Individuals were expressing to us that they were experiencing such intense hilarity that it precipitated lacrimation. However, we did not encounter a considerable amount of mirth or sorrow. It remains uncertain whether this was due to our inability to establish a connection with the content or whether it was attributable to some other factor. Nonetheless, this program appears to be tailored towards an audience of individuals aged 45 and above."

We made the decision to visit this establishment based on perusing various reviews; however, my expectations were unfortunately not met, as this coffee shop proved to be nothing extraordinary.  Accompanied by my spouse and one of our twin children, I had intended to order the breakfast burrito, but I expressed a preference for turkey sausage instead of the customary pork sausage.  Unfortunately, the young woman behind the counter informed me that accommodating my request was not feasible.  Thus, I opted for the turkey sausage, egg, and cheese on an English muffin instead.  When I requested a scrambled egg for my infant daughter, the counter attendant regretfully stated that their eggs are pre-cooked into patties, which lacked appeal, much like my running shoes post-workout.  Consequently, I elected to cancel the food order and solely pay for the coffee and bottled orange juice I had purchased for my baby.  It is unfortunate, as I am perpetually seeking suitable breakfast locales.

Trying too hard to be upscale, with none of the effort you would expect to accompany such high prices and professional demeanor. I don't mind paying more for quality, but the only thing that was 5 star was the view and the price.

Seriously!!!  I would never ever pay $50.00 for a pedicure EVER.. Well again and I wouldn't have paid it this time NEITHER.  We asked for pricing, I stated what I wanted  and the only change i made from time of check in to done was that I now wanted french tips.  Had I wanted to spend this kind of money, i would have gone to TheBathHouse.\n\nthe other thing that puzzled me was \"why, were they mopping the floor at 9 am in the morning, when the salon JUST opened\"  Who really wants to be at a Salon when they are cleaning up yesterday mess.

Uhh... came here on a Thursday night and what an awkward Thursday night it was.

At least our group of about 9 guys all got in free, somehow? Promoter probably put us on guestlist but I don't really remember.

Let me say, this was my first night in Vegas EVER and first club in Vegas EVER, and it was a sad experience.

The club itself was just full of a "dead vibe" where you feel like nobody was excited to be out. The only area of the club that was open was the outdoor patio upstairs. So you would have to try and venture through the crowd of older people, composing of cougars and manthers to find some socialization. Only one bar open which was extremely overwhelmed as you can figure.... really disappointed and haven't returned since!

"The quality of service was satisfactory, however, the culinary offerings did not meet my expectations, specifically, the soup and pasta dishes were subpar. Upon ordering the Tuscana Sausage Soup, I discovered that the potatoes were not adequately cooked, resulting in an unpleasant texture, and the seasoning was excessively salty, although the sausage itself was palatable. Furthermore, the Build Your Own Pasta option, which included spaghetti, bologonese sauce, meatballs, and mushrooms, was disappointing, as the noodles were only lukewarm, and the accompanying ingredients lacked flavor. Notably, the meatballs had an unmistakable taste and texture reminiscent of store-bought, frozen products. In conclusion, my experience with the pasta dishes was underwhelming, leading me to consider alternative options, such as a slice of pizza, for future visits."

I did not like this place.  I was into the retro look and 'dive' appeal but it basically a dive without anything GOOD about it.  It isn't the cheapest place and the burgers were not that good at all.  Setup is awkward, hard to get inside for soda refills.  I think this place only survives due to tourists.  They don't know any better.  I would not go back.

"Our dining experience was marred by the unfortunate encounter with an extremely discourteous server, which led us to question the validity of leaving a positive review. Notwithstanding the palatable quality of the culinary offerings, we were compelled to confer a solitary star in light of the egregious behavior exhibited by the aforementioned staff member. It is worth mentioning that a comparable establishment, located in close proximity, offers not only a more satisfactory dining experience but also presents a significantly more affordable price point. A cursory examination of the menu revealed the presence of vegetarian options, which, while appreciated, proved insufficient in mitigating our overall dissatisfaction with the restaurant."

I fervently desire that I could have successfully established communication with Sherry's Pampered Pets, thereby enabling me to procure the reservation that I deemed essential. However, despite my concerted efforts, which included two telephone calls and an unreturned voicemail, I was unable to progress beyond the initial stage of securing said reservation. Following a protracted period of three to four days, during which I awaited a response to my voice message in vain, I opted to pursue alternative arrangements. It is utterly unfeasible for me to consider entrusting my canine companion to your care if I am unable to attain a responsive dialogue with your organization.

"We opted for a single night's stay at this establishment, primarily motivated by financial considerations, but unfortunately, our expectations were not met. Despite its visually appealing exterior, the hotel's interior appeared outdated, and the service we received was subpar. Specifically, we requested a 'non-smoking' room, but upon arrival, the room was permeated with a strong odor of smoke and tobacco. Following our complaint, we were instructed to proceed to the'manager's desk' to obtain a new room assignment, but our attempts to secure assistance were met with indifference and disinterest by multiple staff members. Eventually, we managed to engage with a representative who directed us to the farthest end of the desk, where we waited for approximately 10 minutes before being attended to. Unfortunately, the staff member who eventually assisted us seemed annoyed and informed us that we needed to wait further. After another 10-minute delay, a different employee arrived and instructed us to relocate to the opposite side of the extensive front desk, which proved challenging given the size of our luggage. Our overall experience was marred by poor customer service, and while we might consider returning if absolutely necessary, we would generally avoid this hotel due to the unpleasant encounter."

"Due to the dearth of adequate Chinese cuisine in my immediate vicinity, I opted to venture slightly further afield to sample the culinary offerings of Chopstix, based on the acclaim bestowed upon it by patrons. Unfortunately, the establishment's card reader was non-functional, prompting the staff member attending to me to request that I procure cash to facilitate the transaction. In light of this, I undertook a brief excursion to the nearest automated teller machine located within Smiths, incurring an additional fee of three dollars due to the fact that it was not affiliated with my financial institution. Upon my return, I found the premises devoid of any other patrons, with the same staff member who had initially attended to me now engaged in a personal telephone conversation on his mobile device, utterly disregarding my presence. I persisted in waiting for several minutes, during which time another employee was occupied at the counter, similarly neglecting to acknowledge me. Eventually, he glance up and enquired if he could provide assistance, to which I replied that I wished to settle the payment for my meal. At this point, the previously engaged staff member finally terminated his phone call and accepted my payment, without offering any expression of regret, discount, or token of appreciation for my trouble.
