The 'french fries' tapas were merely adequate, while the manchego mac and cheese was unremarkable. The grouper, unfortunately, was overcooked and devoid of any discernible seasoning. The salad, though passable, did not particularly impress, nor did the empanadas, which seemed diminutive in comparison to other establishments serving tapas. The albondigas, consisting of unremarkable meatballs devoid of distinct flavor, failed to excite my palate. The sole dish that elicited even mild enthusiasm was the paella, yet even that was surpassed by numerous other superior renditions I have sampled."

"We opted for the Maine Lobster Pot Pie and Shrimp and Scallops as our entrees, complemented by crab cakes as an appetizer. Unfortunately, our culinary excursion proved to be a letdown, as the flavors were predominantly unpalatable and occasionally off-putting. Despite the visually appealing presentation of the Pot Pie, it failed to translate into an enjoyable gastronomic experience. Our server's attempts to convey authenticity were unsuccessful, and the evening's dining experience fell short of our expectations, particularly when compared to other high-end Vegas establishments helmed by celebrated chefs. Disappointment was the operative word, and the discrepancy in quality was underscored by the fact that the cost was only $30 less than that of a Gordon Ramsay restaurant, rendering the experience even more unsatisfactory.

The shopping/selling environment would be much more enjoyable if the associates were not rude, unfriendly and incompetent. I am currently sitting in the store waiting for them to go through my clothing that I'm selling, wait time is estimated at 45min, which I don't get as there are 5 associates in here and 3 customers (me included). When entering, not one associate said hello or even offered a smile. I stood waiting at counter for 5 minutes until an associate finally approached me, rudely. I don't get it, don't they want business?! 

They have a great selection of clothing here, but the negative energy in the store definitely makes the shopping experience a downfall. A sign reads "like us on Facebook," apparently they don't want to be liked.

As an avid shopper and seller, Platos closet will no longer get my business after today, I think Ill stick with the more professional and friendly Buffalo Exchange. My social network will be notified of this negative experience that I normally receive when coming in here.

Went in for a meal on Sunday night.  Not a great move.  The food was really not great even for a chain italian place.  Service was good, we sat at the bar to watch the Sunday night game.  \n\nI'm still not sure if the issue was the poor food, the poor menu, or something I can't nail down.

"My affection for Korean BBQ is unwavering, and Sura's innovative concept has captured my attention. The eatery offers a buffet-style format, allowing patrons to select their preferred meats and side dishes, which are then transported to their table for grilling. A dedicated server will attend to beverage orders and periodic grill cleaning. While the cuisine may not be exceptional, with some frozen meat pieces noticeable upon selection, the experience is not without its drawbacks. During my visit, I had the misfortune of observing an employee exiting the restroom without proper hand hygiene practices, only to subsequently witness her handling food items behind the buffet counter. This distressing encounter left me feeling utterly revolted, prompting a strong desire to retreat to the restroom and vomit. Considering Sura's all-you-can-eat menu is comparably priced to other local establishments, I would recommend exploring alternative options, particularly in light of the questionable sanitation standards evident in their facilities."

"The Fringe, the International Festival, and the Film Festival, I can all comprehend with relative ease and cognitive fluency, however, the Book Festival, that particular event seems to stretch the boundaries of my understanding, as it appears to be somewhat of an enigma, a conundrum that challenges my mental faculties and capacity for rational thought, nevertheless, I shall endeavor to persevere and attempt to grasp its significance and inherent value, despite my reservations and misgivings. The Politics Festival, on the other hand, strikes me as a tad excessive and perhaps even superfluous, as politics, while undoubtedly vital and relevant to our contemporary world, does not strike me as the sort of subject that warrants a dedicated festival, per se, as it lacks the certain je ne sais quoi, the ineffable quality that renders a topic worthy of celebration and commemoration, at least in my humble opinion. However, I digress, and shall continue to expound upon this theme, as I visualize a gathering of eccentric individuals, unconventional and free-spirited souls, assembled together in a circular formation, engaged in a fervent discussion, a spirited dialogue, regarding the intricacies and nuances of the capital gains tax, their faces adorned with looks of intense concentration and unbridled passion, reminiscent of a group of ancient philosophers, debating the mysteries of the universe, and next, we have the Festival of Accountancy, a spectacle that defies explanation and transcends the boundaries of rational comprehension."

"If this purported spa presumes to proffer a genuine pampering experience, it patently fails to deliver. Following a protracted twenty-minute wait to be seated at a table, I was peremptorily requested to relocate. My nail technician, who appeared to be more engrossed in conversing with colleagues in a foreign tongue than attending to my needs, uttered a paltry pair of phrases in my direction throughout the entire procedure. Moreover, an antiquated array of lotions and creams was relegated to a dusty corner cabinet, while a worn, dilapidated spray tan booth was offered for sale. Despite these deficiencies, the establishment seemed to enjoy a steady stream of clientele. Although my nails did ultimately appear satisfactory, following a $15 fill, I have no intention of returning to this subpar salon."

I went in today to have a look at their selection, i walked in and no one was there. I heard someone snoring in the back so i figured i would take a peek. As i thought, someone was laying on the couch sleeping! ahah. I hate waking people up so I took a few business cards, took note of their products, and went on my way.

Products were some of what i am looking for, drip tips, and batteries, and also looking for new brands of liquid i haven't tried out. I'll be back in a few days maybe, and hopefully someone will be awake to answer a few of my questions.

It's a small store from what i saw, i didn't see any testers i could help myself to, i did see a showcase full of flavors which was nice. I did find a couple that caught my eye as i was reading them. Other than that, it was a shame i walked in at a bad time.

for now 2/5 stars i can't leave this mistake unsaid.

"Numerous patrons have praised the welcoming nature of the personnel at this establishment; however, my recent visit on February 26th at 6:00 pm did not align with such favorable assessments. Upon entering, we were not acknowledged or bid farewell upon departure. The cashier's initial remark to me was simply a curt 'hold on,' followed by her attendance to two other orders, including a smoothie, before taking my order for a medium tea. Notwithstanding the uncomplicated nature of my request, I was compelled to wait while she fulfilled the more complex beverages. Furthermore, she failed to pour the steaming water into my cup, leaving it, along with the tea bag, on the counter unattended. While I comprehend the challenges of being the sole employee attending to customers, it is imperative to develop adequate multitasking abilities and maintain a pleasant demeanor. A simple greeting or courteous remarks would have elevated my rating of this establishment to three or four stars. Unfortunately, the subpar customer service greatly influenced my experience, and I cannot, in good conscience, provide a higher rating. Despite this, I shall return in the future, as this coffee shop remains one of the few options in close proximity to my residence, and I am perpetually seeking suitable locations for studying."

I had appt with Doctor Meghan How ever she din't  show up as she was Sick I get it everyone gets Sick However that is not the Point..Front Desk Judy she just had a straight additude she was definitely not happy to be there Overall she is Unprofessional, i even over heard her go to the techs and told them how stupid I was and how I gave her additude and other Nonsense  **OVERALL** patients should NOT get Treated like this. I was mistreated I got to my appt in time I waited one Hour to get treated How ever the service that I received from the asst and Doctor Michaels was Excellent. Judy needs some training on how to treat the patients with respect and By being more proffesional the other girls there as well very Unprofessional they need to stop talking about patients as we can all hear what they say..

Went for Sunday brunch. Ordered a Western Omelet - it was ok. Others at my table got the all-you-can-eat buffet, and seemed to enjoy it - I think this is a quantity over quality kind of place.\nOne highlight was the hashbrown casserole - very tasty!

I have been here three times now. For some reason a lot of my coworkers really like it. It's a popular lunch-time destination. 

They are known for their southern, Louisiana style dishes. I would say it's just pretty typical, heaving-tasting foods. Their gyros are not bad actually, but the creole with shrimp and blacken fish I had as a lunch special were just too salty and heavy for me. I'm sure some who love their soul food would appreciate it, but it wasn't for me. 

It gets pretty crowded during lunch hours, and the spaces are quite tight.
I ordered the spicy shrimp whichis noted as very spicy.  It was so NOT spicy and NOT flavorful.  However I had a nice time inspite of the food.....
decent at best.  if you know real cajun this place won't impress you but for the lack of any other option it's passable.  the Rat Toes appetizer is pretty good.

I have been an ardent devotee of this Fry's since its renovation last year, lavishing considerable financial resources upon it.  My most recent shopping excursion, regrettably, proved to be a profoundly vexing and disillusioning experience, as I discovered upon arriving home that several items were conspicuously absent from my purchases.  This reprehensible occurrence marked the third instance of such an event transpiring at this specific establishment, and my attempts to elicit even a modicum of contrition or empathy from the store's staff (including, most recently, an assistant manager) have been met with a resounding lack of success.  In stark contrast, a previous shopping expedition to Safeway resulted in my acquiring shrimp that, upon arrival at my domicile, proved to be irredeemably spoiled; yet, upon returning to the store, the manager not only graciously replaced the tainted seafood with twice the quantity, but also refunded my original payment in its entirety.  Now, that, my friends, is unwavering dedication to providing exceptional customer service.  While Fry's may boast competitive pricing, the incalculable value of a satisfactory customer experience cannot be matched by any monetary sum.

I'm not sure when this started but tonight I noticed a sign that states from 9pm to 5am there is a 25 cent surcharge on every item sold. The establishment is open 24 hours. It's ridiculous that they would operate in this manner.  Are they paying their employees more in the evening? Highly doubtful. \n\nBread was delicious as usual. Hot and fresh.

"The culinary offerings were indeed impressive, however, the quality of the service did not live up to our expectations. Specifically, we experienced an unacceptable delay in receiving our beverages, which significantly impacted our dining experience. Our server seemed somewhat indifferent to our concerns and offered an unsatisfactory explanation for the prolonged wait. His response, 'It's not my fault they are way behind in the kitchen,' did little to alleviate our frustration. Given the abundance of exceptional steakhouses in Las Vegas, it remains to be seen whether we will give this establishment another chance."

"Agave- how I ardently wish it were not so: 
1. Egregious service- no hospitable hostess upon our arrival, no utensils accompanying our culinary offerings, and no attentive server to facilitate our financial transaction. Everything transpired at a languid pace, inducing an increased level of anxiety in this humble patron, despite my lack of urgency. 
2. Culinary offerings- Crispy quesadillas, both chicken and corn variations: aesthetically pleasing corn masa shell, yet underwhelming fillings. Subsequently, we sampled the fresh fish tacos, which unfortunately possessed an unpleasant sogginess and an unfortunate mess. The oceanic delicacies exhibited an unpalatable, stale flavor, which I, with my proficiency in consuming fish sauce akin to ketchup, found particularly disagreeable. 
3. Ambiance- surprisingly pleasant. From the exterior faÃ§ade, one would not anticipate such a harmoniously assembled interior. A commendable fusion of color scheme, illumination, and an imposing central bar contributed to a welcoming atmosphere. However, as a gastronomic enthusiast, my expectations remained unfulfilled."

"The pinnacle of inadequacy in mixology stewardship within the city of Charlotte's confines manifests itself in the form of bartenders whose proficiency, or lack thereof, warrants an unprecedented nadir in customer satisfaction. Patrons who have had the misfortune of encountering such individuals often recount tales of prolonged waiting periods, unresponsive demeanors, and a seemingly innate propensity for error when fulfilling straightforward requests. One such instance involved a patron who, having placed an order for three Two Hearted Ales, instead received three shots of Fireball, an egregious discrepancy that, despite being brought to the attention of both the bartender and a bar back, remained unresolved, leaving the customer in question still awaiting their beverages."

"Although I failed to perceive the presence of a staff member during the initial ten minutes of my visit, upon encountering an employee subsequent to my unintentional collision with them, I was provided with beneficial assistance."

For Scotland's busiest, most important and the capital's train station it sure was pure chaos.  I took a taxi here to go down to London and the moment I went underground I was amazed at how unorganized this place seems.  Maybe me or maybe it was the construction that was going on.\n\nAll the usual amenities you would expect from a modern train station, you have a pub nearby, the snack shop and all of the other usual suspects are here.  The open roof feeling of being underneath main roads doesn't sit well with me, because it rains here and it is cold here more than it is warm so why an open roof. And being from California being underneath big things that can collapse just rubs me the wrong way, almost as much as finding out that the trains to London are on a track all by itself not with the others. They realize that people drink or wake up way too early to get on trips right?

"The juvenile bruin filler personage garnered a rating of four celestial bodies for his assiduous endeavors in captivating the attention of my celebratory offspring, despite her pronounced fidgetiness and propensity for unpredictable behavior, stemming from her neurological distinctiveness, as previously expounded upon in my written evaluations. However, a deduction of one stellar increment was necessitated by the eccentric conduct of an employee stationed at the checkout terminal, who vociferously demanded the relinquishment of a Build-A-Bear tote bag containing cardiac symbols, both of which were proprietary components of the establishment, and which my daughter had surreptitiously stuffed with the aforementioned tokens. Following a hasty confiscation of the item without my daughter's cognizance, I strategically positioned it beyond her visual scope, atop a lofty ledge. Unfortunately, the aforementioned staff member, whose designation was not that of a cashier, chose to adopt an excessively boisterous demeanor, repeatedly imploring me to surrender the object, thereby potentially compromising my efforts to conceal its existence from my inquisitive progeny. My better half, who was engaged in pecuniary transactions at the time, even rotated his visage in the direction of the commotion, piqued by the clamorous exchange. Twice, I reiterated my desire to maintain the item's absence from my daughter's perception, prior to retreating from the scene. It is my conviction that said individual ought to have exercised greater restraint and discernment when confronted with a parent's attempt to shield a child from an unnecessary tantrum, particularly given the unique challenges posed by my daughter's neurodiversity."
I like the back area of the bar outside. The music is pretty good. Didn't get to stay there long. I'll have to try it again some time.

I grew up in Las Vegas so I've been here a zillion times. The security lines can be long during peak travel times (Fri and Sun afternoons), there's a nice variety of food chains and random and expensive stores. I always pray I get to fly out of the A and B gates since it is waaaay less crowded and there's never a line for security. Since it's a big airport, it can take a long time to get from your car to checking in your luggage to your gate, so allow for some extra hiking time. \nOf course there's cheesy Las Vegas crap all over the place and slot machines, but that's what makes this place so... Vegas. The TSA clowns are usually pretty easy-going and apparently the taxi lines are realllly long. So save time ad hire a limo. It probably costs about the same. Also, free Wi-Fi!!

I've been here for brunch before and it was amazing! However, I was disappointed by a recent trip for a friend's bday. 

We had a big group and hung out in the bar area, standing/mingling, and occupied the three tall, center tables. It was a Monday night and the service was EXTREMELY slow. It looked like the server, in addition to the bar area, was also responsible for some tables in the dining room.

I ordered a drink and it arrived about 20 minutes later. A friend ordered food at the same time and his food arrived about 10 minutes before my drink. And we were sitting right next to the bar! The drink did not fit the description on the menu (it sounded like a martini, based on the description, but ended up being some sweet concoction served in a wine glass) and I sent it back (something I very rarely do). I asked for a different drink and it arrived, another 15 minutes later.

The dinner small plate and entree options leave much to be desired. With a large group, we wanted to order a few shareable plates, but all the small plates on the menu did not seem very sharing-friendly. Also, why does EVERYTHING have bacon?? The entrees seemed very over priced (tilapia for $22, are you kidding me?). 

I would definitely return for brunch, but never for dinner or drinks.

Ah. This place kills me......for two reasons. Firstly, it USED to be amazing...Then all of a sudden, the quality of the food and service kind of crashed. And secondly, what kind of restaurant DOESN'T ALLOW YOU TO TAKE YOUR FOOD TO GO?!??! This is the reason I won't be back. I had gone there with a friend, and we ordered and appetizer to share and then a main dish each. I had the veal with mushroom sauce which in the past was pretty amazing. However, halfway through that dish, I got full (shocking, I know). At the end of our meal, both of us asked for the rest of our dishes to be packed to go and we were told by a very unhappy woman that this would not be possible. Either eat it all here, or too bad. It was SHOCKING. So.....although the food is ok, I won't be returning here. I don't like feeling ripped off, and the fact that they won't give you the rest of your paid-for food, makes me feel totally ripped off.  :|

"I must have traversed past Frank's A Lot numerous times prior to deciding to give it a chance. Located on the eastern side of the thoroughfare that transforms into Airline Boulevard, directly behind the aerodrome, Franks' unassuming edifice has always piqued my curiosity. En route to my daily employment, utilizing Airline Boulevard as a means to circumvent several signalized intersections, I have had the pleasure of observing Franks frequently. Eventually, my intrigue was aroused, and I opted to partake in their culinary offerings for lunch.  

My expectations were surpassed by the delectable gastronomic experience that awaited me. For a most reasonable tariff, I savored a succulent hot dog, augmented by an exceptionally cordial staff whose familiarity and camaraderie suggested a familial proprietorship. Although I cannot confirm whether the establishment is indeed a family-run enterprise, their proficiency in both culinary and customer service aspects leaves little doubt. 

Franks provides both a drive-through window and a quaint outdoor seating area for patrons' convenience. It is worth noting that they only accept paper currency, but fear not, as the total cost of your repast will unlikely exceed seven dollars. 

Their signature dish, the Chicago dog, boasts an array of flavorsome embellishments, including onions, celery salt, sport peppers, and tomatoes. Pair it with a portion of their freshly prepared French fries, and you will be poised to depart, relishing life's simple pleasures. 

While their bill of fare encompasses other delectable options such as Polish sausages, cheese fries, and even Philly cheese steaks, my predilection for their Chicago dog has thus far precluded exploration of alternative choices. However, I would unhesitatingly recommend a visit to Franks A Lot to anyone who finds themselves in the vicinity."

"In the event of a cerebral explosion occurring within the confines of Grandmother's cognitive faculties on a lazy Sunday afternoon, the resulting scenario would closely resemble a sprawling, chaotic array of artistic paraphernalia, replete with an assortment of vibrant paints, versatile adhesives tailored for diverse surfaces and materials, an array of brushes in varying sizes and shapes, picture frames in assorted dimensions and forms, seasonal artistic endeavors, beads and bedazzlers, candles in abundance, irregularly shaped styrofoam blocks, construction paper, wooden shelving units susceptible to staining or coloration according to one's preference, artificial floral arrangements, glass containers, and other miscellaneous crafting supplies. Moreover, for those who harbor an ardent passion for scrapbooking, a visit to Michael's store would likely transpire as a veritable dream come true, offering an extensive array of materials and tools designed to facilitate the creation of unique, personalized mementos."

"The bartender, a reprehensible and detestable female, ostensibly endeavored to proffer an amicable demeanor; however, her inherent misanthropy and acrimonious disposition proved palpable, rendering her efforts futile. Despite this unpleasant encounter, the potables she served were undeniably exceptional, possessing an explosive and gratifying flavor profile that would unquestionably entice my return. Regrettably, the quality of the beverages was juxtaposed by the deplorable customer service, which was characterized by an uncooperative and indifferent attitude, reminiscent of the spiky, inhospitable plant known as Yucca."

Brass metamorphoses into "The Beat" on initial Fridays, and I'll return! Initial Friday is currently appropriate to visit again.

LOCATION: Fremont, of course. However, rather than being down on Fremont, it's up on Fremont! (huh?) :) It's positioned above Hennesy's Tavern. Head upstairs because that's where the celebration is. There's a balcony, so all you smokers may take a smoke break and observe the crazies walking on Fremont. If you wish to exit, there's no issue; Beauty Bar, Vanguard, and Insert Coins are merely across Las Vegas Boulevard, allowing you to bar hop and throng the remainder of downtown.

MUSIC: I believe KidFunk was spinning records. And he didn't let me down. It was a persistent flow of excellent tracks. Many houses and technological houses, with some electro and dubstep thrown in. It was an excellent evening! For the venue's size, there's a fair-sized dance floor. I explored just the main room, but on the opposite side, there's a much more extensive room with a different DJ, presumably playing distinct music. If they maintain it, I will make this a regular stop on the first Friday.

BATHROOMS: They were revolting and filthy. Drinks and other unmentionable items were strewn about the floor. Before you pop-a-squat, double-check that there is toilet paper. The dispensers were consistently empty, so grab a handful of paper towels before entering.

GOGO: Sorry, but the gogo(s) were utterly underwhelming, both in appearance and dancing.

GUYS: There is no dress code or cover charge when I arrived.

Remember to FOLLOW and RATE!;)

Despite my reservations based on the unfavorable reviews, I opted to give this establishment a chance, and my experience validated the prevailing sentiment. The ambiance was visually appealing, but the lavatory presented an unconventional layout. The hand dryer was situated on a single faucet, prompting a sequence of inconvenient delays for patrons awaiting their turn to utilize the facilities while attempting to operate the cumbersome dryer. Furthermore, the absence of sanitary disposal units within the stalls necessitated a departure from the stall to discard items in the central waste receptacle, posing an additional challenge for female patrons. 

My culinary selection was a vegetarian burger, which, although flavorful, was diminutive in stature, inviting comparisons to a slider. The accompanying fries were palatable, yet their portion size was standard, rendering the supplementary fee seemingly unwarranted. Moreover, the minuscule dimensions of the water glasses necessitated a deliberate sipping motion, akin to savoring a fine wine. Following my meal, I remained unsatisfied, capable of consuming a medium-sized popcorn at the cinema without difficulty. 

Regrettably, I must conjecture that this dining establishment may struggle to flourish, given its steep prices and inadequate serving sizes. A revision of their pricing strategy or generosity of portions seems imperative to justify the cost. Notably, the absence of an option to augment the vegetarian patty was conspicuous.

For those stuck in the convention center area, this is a ok place for a beer and pub food.

As a graduate student in the area only to attend a conference, I have been to this bar twice.

The jalapeno poppers and onion rings are a favorite. The buffalo wings are ok...nothing special.

Gets very crowded during games, but makes the place fun.

So, if you are trapped around the area with no car and crave a beer and munchies, this place is A-Ok.

I was a loyal Sakana fan for years up until the birth of my sone.  Going out for sushi is not so convenient with a lil one. So after a 3 year hiatus, my husband and I opted for Sakana on date night.  Would it be all that we remembered? Disappointed to say that it wasn't. We sat at the sushi bar and the chefs were not as personable as they were in the past - very little banter or recommendations. The saving grace was the scallop dynamite - the best I have had in the Valley and the oranges for dessert. Gosh how I missed those.  \nI accept that maybe a 3 year break might have built up my expectations.

I have an inclination to visit this establishment to acquire some subs en route to the river, as it is situated between our domicile and highway 17. This is due to my reluctance to frequent Subway or Blimpie's. Primarily, it is a rather extensive Italian market offering a wide range of products. If you are in need of olive oil, they possess an array of over 20 diverse varieties. Pasta? You will discover an entire aisle dedicated to it. Even one of those wooden utensils designed for crafting gnocchi can be found among their wares. 
  In the rear of the store, a counter extends along the entire length of the back wall, where you will encounter an assortment of cheeses, cold cuts, sausages, and a few sweet treats. Additionally, this is where you can place your order for sandwiches. Be prepared to articulate your desires with precision and celerity, as the gentleman operating the counter can be somewhat irritable and terse. The abundance of hand-written sandwich combinations posted on the wall can further exacerbate his demeanor. Fortunately, the lady manning the cash register consistently exhibits a warm and friendly demeanor, which partially compensates for his behavior. 
  Although I aspire to cherish their sandwiches, I merely find them satisfactory. The meat is invariably of superior quality, but it is not abundant enough. Perhaps I am not selecting the appropriate options. Until such time that I can refine my sandwich-ordering prowess, I shall persist in supporting Romanelli's, albeit with a mediocre rating for their deli. Nonetheless, their product selection earns high praise.

This place is just ok for me. The restaurant has a nice setting, good service, and nice entertainment. The food is good but not great for the price. The steaks were slightly over aged for my taste, au gratin potatoes were very tasty though. They have a nice wine list with many options for all budgets. Its worth a try if you are at gvr and looking for a nice meal but I prefer most of the steak houses on the strip over this place.

$4 OPI!  Read Carina's review, b/c I didn't want to pay $8.50 at Ulta... geez, so cheap... alot of the OPI colors already have separated (heat?  age?) so make your choice for price over quality... I'm so cool for $4 though.\n\nOn the same end where China Magic Noodle is, same plaza as Lee Lee's.

Went in for an early dinner and ordered the Pot Roast Sandwich. The vegetables came and were not cooked. They were raw, I ate the meat which was great. I told the waitress and she commented that that is pretty normal actually and offered to give me another side vegetable. I am glad that she did that but at the same time was a bit subdued by the fact that this was a regular thing for them. My husband enjoyed his chili burger loads. The drinks we ordered were very strong as well. This place is always busy but perhaps we ordered the wrong food for this place!

Had a carne assada torta.  It was actually not bad.  For the price it was real good.

A few comments/observations...

- Comically unorganized. There is no process for how this place works.  I got my food but if they actually had something that resembled organization I would have got it a lot sooner.

- The grill was a bit on the dirty side.

- The meat while ok was a bit on the fatty/chewy side.  Chopping it into smaller pieces would have been helpful

- Not the cleanest dining area.

Not really a 3, but not a 2 either.  I gave them the benefit of the doubt.

The ambiance of the bar was bereft of any melodic accompaniment or auditory stimulation, that is, until I entreated the bartender for a second time, at which point a subtle, reggae-inspired tune was faintly perceptible in the background, a sonic element that was ostensibly intended to enhance the overall experience but ultimately proved to be suboptimal due to its barely audible nature; furthermore, the menu did not feature any culinary options that were within my financial means, specifically during the designated period known as "happy hour," although I did partake in a few Cuba Libras, a potent cocktail comprising rum, cola, and lime juice, which I found to be quite satisfying despite their relatively modest price point of three dollars each; lastly, I must admit that I did not have the opportunity to sample the establishment's gastronomical offerings, and thus, I cannot provide an informed assessment of their quality, leaving me in a state of indecision regarding a potential future visit.

"Given our considerable distance from the French Quarter, my stomach infrequently impels me towards Cajun cuisine; furthermore, owing to the limited dining options within our vicinity, this establishment emerges as the de facto venue for satisfying my periodic craving for gumbo; while the quality of the fare may be marginally superior to the local average, the tariffs charged are somewhat elevated relative to our expectations."

Went to this buffet (gorgeous d\u00e9cor by the way) two weeks ago and although it was great, it's not the best buffet I've eaten at.  I do have to agree with the other reviewers that the options were poor.  The quality was good and the portion control in individual containers helped but other than that, I'd say this was more like a three star place.  Luckily I didn't do the weekend $40-/+ buffet that most mentioned.  We went on a Monday during brunch time and it was about $22 I think.  Not bad for an all you can eat place in Vegas as it kept me full all day, but I felt the lack of options bored me and was done within 45 minutes.  I expected a little more from a place that looks so posh!

Dude, totally didn't realize how many lesboz are in Vegas. But they're like the totally stereotypical mullet-wearing, jean vest with ripped sleeves wearing, big arms type of galz. You know, have you seen that movie Monster with Christina Ricci and Charlize Theron? Well, that type.

Am I seriously the only hot one? Hehe jk.

Sushi's alright. But who pays $15-17 for a roll of fish?
For that money, you can go to Oakland and get yourself some
V
V
V
V
V

The pictures of the burgers looked super crazy and deadly but the portions are actually very feasible. Our group of 5 shared: sashimi \"won-tacos,\" triple T fries, the original ringer burger, and the bacon mac-n-cheese burger. We probably could have stuffed ourselves with another item. My favorites were the fries and the original burger. The fries were super crisp and full of truffle flavor, especially the aioi. The original burger had the flavors I like most, although I think the bacon mac-n-cheese is more unique and a good combination to try.\n\nTo me, the burgers are a little better than your average burger but not a favorite I would want again and again (I still prefer Bachi burger or even Holsteins). The tacos were definitely a let down- super small portion of tuna and not very interesting. Overall, I would only come back for a beer and some of those fries.

While the gastronomical indulgences are delectable and meticulously crafted, the tariffs and hospitality fail to align with the expectations of an establishment of this caliber. The ambiance is permeated by a palpable sense of disinterest among the staff, who appear to be preoccupied with matters unrelated to the provision of quality service. Upon placing our order for the triumvirate of sweet delights, my companion conveyed to the server that we would appreciate the second selection, given that the initial offering had suffered an unfortunate mishap. However, the server, rather than addressing our concern, opted to delegate the responsibility to a colleague, thereby inadvertently perpetuating a chain of miscommunication. Ultimately, we were compelled to rectify the situation ourselves, as the damage to the dessert became apparent only upon payment and seating. Although the process entailed minimal effort, it remains an inconvenience that could have been readily avoided with a modicum of attentiveness and competence on the part of the service staff.

"Alright, so I had to perform an upgrade. 

I was physically present at the BuyBack$ site in Henderson, near the Galleria Mall, when we were unable to locate the desired item. 

As a result, we contacted the Decatur location to determine whether or not they possessed the film we were seeking on Blu-ray. 

Of course, they did! They possess everything; it's unquestionable. 

We then inquired whether they could retain the product for us, stating that we would arrive shortly to collect it since we were located across town but en route. 

Therefore, we drove across the city, and you know what happened? 

These individuals had the audacity to inform us that the item was, in fact, being held for another person. They asserted that it had been previously reserved but ultimately left the decision of who would obtain it up to management's discretion. 

Well, we informed you that we were traveling from across town, and you assured us that you would hold it for us. As a result, I failed to acquire it. 

What I did receive, however, was a review update, which resulted in a loss of one star. 

Although I won't say I wouldn't revisit, I certainly won't go out of my way to return to this particular location again. 

They lost a steadfast and dedicated client."

"I have had the pleasure of dining at this establishment on multiple occasions, and I must say, it is a veritable chain of restaurants. My spouse and I have patronized this location intermittently, and while the culinary offerings have been satisfactory, the service has been somewhat inconsistent. Specifically, our most recent visit was quite enjoyable, thanks in large part to the exceptional service provided by our server, Paul. His proficiency in beer-related knowledge was impressive, and his attentiveness towards our children and myself was greatly appreciated. The food, while not necessarily mind-blowing, was adequate. My better half opted for the fish and chips, which were encased in a flavorful panko batter, albeit a tad lacking in seasoning. The garlic fries accompanying the dish were quite delectable, however. As for my meal, I chose the cheeseburger with blue cheese, which, while unremarkable in its presentation, was nevertheless palatable. It is worth noting that my previous experiences at this establishment have been somewhat variable in terms of quality, leading me to confer a rating of three stars overall. Notwithstanding, I do harbor hope that the positive aspects of our latest visit might suggest a trend of improvement."

The modified text is: "Arrived at this establishment on a radiant, balmy Saturday evening, I couldn't help but feel a twinge of envy towards the individuals reveling in the picturesque backyard patio, their merriment illuminated by the soft glow of suspended white lights, while I was confined to the dimly lit interior. Despite my reservations pertaining to the seating arrangements, I opted for a pear and arugula salad, which, albeit palatable, failed to satiate my hunger, leaving me $8 poorer. It appeared that the majority of my associates had elected to order beverages, which might have been a more judicious decision."

"My endorsement is unequivocal. In case you are oblivious to my penchant for economical indulgence, allow me to elucidate: I am an ardent devotee of happy hour. This establishment offers a satisfactory rendition of said promotion, featuring several discounted appetizers and rolls, in addition to palatable beverage specials. For a rapid repast and a pint of Kirin, this venue is an optimal choice, particularly if you find yourself on the western periphery of the city. However, I must qualify my recommendation by stating that, when seeking a more refined dining experience with a significant other, Sakana may be a superior option. Nonetheless, for convivial gatherings with a coterie of acquaintances, this locale is eminently suitable."

"The pricing strategy implemented by this retail establishment is quite competitive, with certain items being offered at a significantly lower cost compared to other regional stores, such as Safeway, while others are priced similarly to those found at Fry's. However, it is crucial to note that the affordability of specific products can vary greatly depending on the customer's individual needs and preferences. Personally, I tend to favor Fry's in my local area due to its proximity to my friend's residence, which makes it a convenient option for us to quickly acquire the necessary items we require. Additionally, I must admit that the ambiance of the Albertson's located near my domicile can sometimes be rather unpleasant, with an odor reminiscent of spoiled seafood that can be overwhelming and potentially nauseating. Nonetheless, this particular store boasts a user-friendly layout, facilitating effortless entry and exit, and the staff consistently provides exemplary customer service."

This was the only buffet we tried (first time visitors) so we don't have anything to compare it to in town. It was nice and at $40/pp reasonably priced. The variety is small but great tasting, and I could have eaten the Na'an all night. The husband enjoyed the brisket. Everything was clean and bright but a bit too cafeteria style for my taste. Overall I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here but if it's convenient it's a good option.

We had Lunch there on a Sunday ,pretty busy .
I say the food is ok not a wow but ok.
The service was good and the place looked pretty clean .
They got lots to pick from. 
We did wait a long time for are food.
The prices are not to bad either .
I will give them another try maybe for dinner.

The only downfall is the wait during lunch through the drive thru.  I have always had a long wait but today was horrible.  Only 2 cars in front of me and my wait was over 15 minutes after ordering.  This was for a simple sandwich and smoothie nothing crazy or extreme.  The service is getting slower and slower every time I go.  It's really making me consider avoiding it in the future and it used to be one of my favorite places.

I was suprised how much I liked Kahunaville. Sandwiches are all very reasonably priced- around 11 bucks- and very large. The drinks are spendy like most of Vegas but be nice and they pour stiff. I highly recommend a Bombay and tonic yard. \n\nOur server was very friendly and professional, She did a great job especially since one of my group pulled a rude dipshit maneuver with an empty ketchup bottle.

Typical Panda Express, but add a drive thru. Service is not exceptionally friendly, but lets face it, who cares. You have to deal with the employees for a whole minute and a half. Food is always good, portions are generally good, and close to shopping.

My date and I decided to try something new and stopped at The Lodge for Happy Hour.  We were really pleased with the prices, and all the bartenders/servers seemed really friendly.  And the deep fried cheese curds were to die for!  (I am from Wisconsin, after all.)  However, the bar stools are INCREDIBLY UNCOMFORTABLE.  We didn't stay long, but thought we liked it enough to try it again...at a table next time.\n\nP.S.  We couldn't decide whether to Yelp about the so-scantily-clad-it-was-almost-inappropriate server.  I mean, I know it's a bar and she's working for tips but...geezuz....it made us look around the bar for her pole.

This West End restaurant holds the honour of being Edinburgh's oldest chinese restaurant! (Or so it claims). It's over 50 years old, and it's become such a local favourite they're some people who've been visiting for quite a few decades. The name is a little bit dodgy, but the food definitely isn't!

The restaurant specialises in Cantonese and Peking cuisine, and there's sooooo much choice on the menu it's difficult to decide what to have. Like many chinese restaurants, the desserts menu isn't elaborate and there is something with banana's in it; this seems to be a constant in just about any chinese restaurant I've been to! 

One great sign in this restaurant is that there are actual Chinese people frequently eating there, as we all know its most difficult to please the home crowd.

Didn't stay at the hotel but the Craps game is the best even though it only pays double on 12, it offers 100X odds!!! Well worth it for cheap gaming on the Strip. The place is a little old but not run down, with low ceilings and the air smelling like smoke. The locals are friendly and the drinks are okay.

C'est avec une certaine impatience que je fantasmais sur ce restaurant... un peu trop peut-être.
Nous avons partagé des "croquettes" au foie gras : vraiment rien d'extraordinaire.
Ensuite, je me suis laissée tentée par la cote de cochon heureux: viande tendre et bien cuite, mais la sauce n'était pas assez tasty à mon gout. Mon ami a pris le magret de canard, pour le coup clairement décevant.
Tarte aux pacanes excellente, mais vient-on ici pour ça?

Vraiment contente d'y être allée, mais plusieurs restaurants dans la meme gamme de prix me rendent bien plus heureuse.

This particular venue and other adjacent locations, such as the Teepee, serve as poignant reminders of a bygone era in which the culinary offerings associated with Mexican cuisine were unwavering in their consistency and our expectations were decidedly modest. However, there are instances in which such familiar and unsophisticated fare strikes an emotional chord, thereby eliciting a profound sense of nostalgia. It is worth noting that this establishment boasts a rich and storied past, as evidenced by the numerous accounts chronicled by the illustrious Marty Robbins.

You inevitably obtain what you expend, although I yearn that you could acquire the fundamental necessities. This establishment fails to provide a minuscule refrigerator, an electric kettle, or even a rudimentary coffee brewing device, let alone a microwave oven, thereby coercing you into expending all your hard-earned currency on procuring sustenance from external sources. Furthermore, the rugs appear somewhat antiquated and emit an unpleasant odor. Our faucet malfunctioned; however, subsequent to our vocalization of this issue, it was successfully rectified the following day. The advantages of this lodging include: a tranquil ambiance after midnight, thereby enabling a restful slumber, and a proximate location to numerous points of interest. While I wouldn't object to returning, I would initially explore alternative options.

This sushi spot is average at best. The rolls have too much rice and hardly any fish. I would rather pay extra and get more substance than just eat a bunch of rice. I wish they had some sort of seating. I go here when I need to grab a quick work day lunch. It's on par with grocery store grade pre made sushi

This place was aight,

$4 Beer specials were a pretty good deal but the sole reason I'm not rating this place any higher is because of the food. (Better options at 4Peaks and Santan)

It was Underwhelming and Overpriced~ The ambiance of this place was nice though

Had the Oyster Po Boy and well.... if you want seafood I guess one should move a bit closer to the W-Coast.

"My experience at this establishment was a stark contrast to the dearth of assistance I received at Fry's. Upon entering the store, I was pleasantly surprised to find that the mini computers, e-readers, and the coveted Kindle I sought were prominently displayed at the forefront of the store, thereby obviating the need for me to navigate the labyrinthine aisles. This was particularly welcome, as I was sporting heels for the first time in an extended period, and my feet were already beginning to protest the unfamiliar terrain. My primary objective was to procure the aforementioned Kindle and expedite my departure; however, my penchant for aesthetically pleasing accessories proved impossible to suppress, and I found myself captivated by a vibrant blue case. Although the selection was limited, I felt compelled to acquire a suitable protector for my new device. My ideal scenario would have involved a pink or Hello Kitty-adorned case, but such options were regrettably unavailable. The staff members demonstrated a markedly superior level of helpfulness compared to their counterparts at Fry's, where extracting information often felt akin to an arduous dental procedure. As we prepared to complete our transaction, the cashier inquired about our possession of their rewards card. While we did possess such a card, I harbored reservations about utilizing it due to a previous incident in which we encountered an inexplicable glitch in their reward system. Following a series of substantial purchases, the associated gifts were erroneously dispatched to an unfamiliar address in Illinois, despite our repeated attempts to rectify the situation through their customer service department and a conversation with a manager. Given the persistent lack of resolution, I cannot in good conscience award this establishment a rating exceeding three stars, as my trust in their capacity to competently manage their rewards program remains dubious."

The nightclub within the Palms Casino Resort boasted a panoramic view of the city skyline from its lofty perch on the 53rd floor, yet the distance from the Las Vegas Strip rendered outdoor excursions impractical, save for the fortuitous meteorological conditions that prevailed during our visit; in essence, the club's unremarkable attributes, with the exception of its prime location, constituted a considerable achievement for the resort.

We ate here a week or so ago and I have to say it was okay. It's nothing either one of us was blown away by but the food was good. We ordered the gnocchi with marinara and the ravioli al formmagio.  Both were good but the stand out was the marinara sauce. I'm rather picky about it and it's probably some of the best I've had in awhile. We also ordered the caprese as an appetizer and again it was good but nothing wonderful. Service was very good as well. For a restaurant in a strip mall setting it was good however the prices are really high considering.

"As an ardent admirer of Gordon Ramsay, I have always been captivated by his unwavering dedication to culinary excellence, which resonates with my own unyielding pursuit of perfection during my college years while manning the cast iron grill at Buffalo Wild Wings. Thus, it was only natural that I would be eager to experience the epicurean delights offered at his establishment. Upon entering, I was faced with a daunting dilemma - what to order from the extensive menu? This proved to be a formidable challenge, rivaled only by the complexity of the ACT exam. After deliberating at length, I decided to deviate from my customary burger and instead opted for the pie sampler, reasoning that it would afford me the opportunity to sample a variety of flavors without committing to a single entree. However, this decision ultimately proved to be a miscalculation, as the sampler, though replete with an array of savory pies, left me feeling somewhat unsatisfied due to its modest portion size. Each individual pie boasted exceptional quality, yet this was somewhat mitigated by the fact that it was merely an appetizer, leaving me still yearning for a more substantial meal. In retrospect, I would have been better served by selecting either a whole pie or a burger, or perhaps even pairing the sampler with one of these options. My companion's burger, which I surreptitiously sampled, appeared to be of exceptional quality, and I must admit that I was tempted to pilfer a few more fries had my friend not been vigilant. Notwithstanding this minor disappointment, I am resolved to return and indulge in the delectable burger that had eluded me on this particular visit."

"The computer science program leaves much to be desired, but the institution's size is quite impressive.  Its ambiance is reminiscent of Arizona, with an oppressive heat that can be overwhelming at times, especially for someone who currently resides in Las Vegas.  Despite this, my fellow students were quite cordial, although the instructors occasionally exhibited an excessive strictness.  A peculiar aspect of this school was the prevalence of bicycle thievery, resulting in the creation of Frankenstein-like vehicles, composed of various parts and colors, which provided a source of amusement.  Additionally, there were numerous individuals who enthusiastically promoted their religious or ideological beliefs, contributing to the diverse and eclectic atmosphere that I found appealing, even though my expectations regarding the teaching staff were not entirely fulfilled."

This hotel had it's ups and downs. Checked in late on Friday night and the non-smoking room we requested was given away so we had to settle with a smoking room. They told us to come to the front desk between 12-3pm the following day to change rooms since they gave our room away so we agreed. 

Next day rolls around and after a great time at the pool and gym we called and they kept pushing back the time on when the room would be ready. We wasted 5 hours of our day not being able to leave and waiting for our non smoking room to be available. For someone who comes for the weekend and hours are limited it really sucks to waste time. Finally they gave us a non smoking room after complaining for 5 hours and sounding upset. It was a big disappointment. I'm giving three stars because that was an awful experience but the hotel itself wasn't too bad. The room we got upgraded and it was really nice. 

On a positive light the hotel is in the middle of the strip and it's across the street from Cosmo and Bellagio. Had fun shopping and eating at Gordon Ramsey's Burgr place.

I wish I had better things to say, but this is sadly a joint that should have stayed in my undergraduate days. I wanted to say this is for people on budget BUT, its not that cheap either.

The place is decent, clean and the sushi chef is friendly greeting us when we came in and was leaving.

I would say, I wouldn't eat any raw stuff here, and the cooked dish I got was also so-so. Tonkatsu was dry and batter was not really there. $14.50 instead of the $10 lunch price I get at King Muramoto... nah. not gonna work.

The only saving grace was the hot miso soup on the cold day I visited. 

Just not worth the price you pay, and the low traffic in the restaurant on Friday night makes me doubt the freshness of the sashimi and sushi they have.

"GIGANTIC SERVINGS. ENORMOUS. Located within the unremarkable Imperial Palace hotel, situated on the Las Vegas Strip (upstairs), this eatery boasts voluminous compartments, partitioned into two distinct rooms. Upon entering, I was taken aback by the cavernous interior, which belied its unassuming exterior. A humble breakfast consisting of eggs, hash browns, a biscuit, and coffee was my selection. The biscuit, in particular, was suffused with an abundance of butter, exuding an irresistible aroma and warmth. Unfortunately, the sheer magnitude of the meal proved to be too much for my digestive system, as I was unable to consume the entirety of the biscuit or the remainder of the dish. The culinary offerings were undoubtedly delectable, with prices commensurate to the copious amounts of food served. My entrÃ©e, one of the more basic options, cost a reasonable $9, while other dishes exceeded that amount. However, an unfortunate incident marred our dining experience, as a patron, seemingly recovering from a vigorous night of Vegas revelry, precipitously vacated the premises, leaving behind a trail of regurgitated contents. Witnessing such a scene before even finishing my meal was indeed unsettling. Nonetheless, this establishment remains an optimal destination for those seeking a satiating dining experience, perhaps best enjoyed donning protective attire..."

This lodging establishment appears to possess an aesthetically pleasing ambiance and the personnel are quite courteous. The physical fitness facility contains a diversity of equipment, which operates effectively. The complimentary morning repast is truly remarkable. However, the sleeping quarters lack functionality. Although a refrigeration unit is present, a microwave oven is conspicuously absent. When dining outside of the hotel, I often have surplus food remaining and I find it distasteful to discard it unnecessarily. The showering facilities in the single bedroom accommodations are reminiscent of those typically found in a university dormitory. The shower enclosure consists solely of a ceramic tile surround with a singular shelf and lacks a comprehensive shower door. Consequently, while immersed in the shower, a perceptible draft is encountered. I am beginning to feel somewhat fatigued by the frequent stays at ostensibly luxurious establishments that offer little in terms of utility.

I go to this restaurant usually on Sunday morning because they have their awesome double stamp days. 

Now for the restaurant-The wait can be a little annoying especially on the weekends. But, that's expected. 

The atmosphere-I usually  go to the one in Chandler off of Ray Rd. The atmosphere is very friendly and the restaurant is clean. I like the little breakfast bar they have. 

Food-The food is delicious and they have the perfect portions for me. However, my husband often complains that they don't give him enough food. But, this is where the cool little $1 menu comes in. They have a wide  range of things that you can add to your meal for $1. I usually add the fruit cup or mini-pancakes. I haven't had a chance to try a lot of their menu items. They have a pretty long list of items and I often get overwhelmed trying to figure out what to order. I have had the 7 Veggie Omelette. It was very tasty! What made it more enjoyable was knowing that I was eating a healthy omelette. Some of them have tons of ingredients and even one with all meat. The one thing that I have tried that I DO NOT recommend is the biscuits and gravy. I have had better. The gravy can taste a little bland and the biscuits taste chewy on the inside. 

Services-The service can be hit or miss. But, I do like that they give a large cup of your beverage to go. 

Great place overall.

"I have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on multiple occasions, with each visit culminating in my fervent decision to adhere to the recommendations proffered by the staff, with the expectation of experiencing a transformative, Superwoman-esque sensation. Alas, such lofty aspirations have yet to materialize. In essence, this venue purveys an array of health-oriented comestibles, including cod liver oil tablets and garlic capsules, among other similar items. The staff, it must be acknowledged, are utterly delightful and display an unwavering dedication to their work. My most recent visit occurred upon learning that ingesting a spoonful of Manuka Honey prior to retiring for the night has the potential to enhance one's complexion and contribute to weight loss. Indeed, the results were palpable, albeit modest in scope; nevertheless, the sensation of improved self-esteem was undeniable. The staff, demonstrating their extensive knowledge, provided me with both the Manuka Honey and cider vinegar for culinary purposes, though the total cost exceeded \u00a340, thereby accounting for the absent dual stars. For individuals genuinely committed to pursuing a path of health and wellness, this establishment constitutes an excellent choice. Conversely, those less concerned with such matters may find their needs better served at Boots."

It's K Mart, not bad just nothing special. Nothing really sets K Mart apart from any of the other conglomerates. Gotta shop here from time to time for MH exclusives so you'll see me busting out my Maverick patch & showing it off with pride

"The server exhibited remarkable attentiveness and helpfulness throughout our dining experience.  The egg-based dish known as an omelet was quite satisfactory.  However, we strongly advise against ordering the grape leaves, as they were liberally coated with a mysterious, reddish substance that resembled a gelatinous paste.  Upon taking a single bite, we promptly returned the dish, as it was unpalatable.  The ambiance of the establishment was reminiscent of a yellow mausoleum, complete with numerous small, enclosed spaces surrounding the primary dining area, which bore a striking resemblance to niches designed to house urns containing cremated remains.  Given such inconsistencies in the quality of the cuisine, it was apparent that the success or failure of any given dish was largely dependent on chance."

"The pizza served at this establishment boasts an acceptable level of culinary expertise, drawing comparisons to the esteemed Setabello. However, it is worth noting that the menu has undergone a significant reduction in scope, which may limit the options available to patrons. Furthermore, the cost of the pizza, while not exorbitant, does veer towards the higher end of the pricing spectrum. Nevertheless, the staff maintains a commendable level of proficiency, ensuring that the dining experience is both seamless and hospitable."

"I indulged in the delectable smothered chicken, accompanied by a scrumptious serving of macaroni and cheese, as well as a side of flavorful green beans. Following my culinary excursion from the Balyntyne suburbs, I must admit that the gastronomical experience was indeed worth the journey. Arriving promptly at 11:30 am on a Wednesday morning, I had the privilege of being one of the establishment's earliest patrons, preceding the influx of the lunchtime throng. While I would have preferred a slightly more affordable price point for the quantity of fare provided, I assigned a respectable rating of 3.5 stars. However, due to the discrepancy between cost and value, I reluctantly deducted a star, feeling that a reasonable price for such a dish should have been around $7, rather than the $10 I was charged, excluding a beverage. Unfortunately, this disparity precludes me from considering future visits to this eatery."

"During our most recent leisure excursion, we opted to halt for a repast at Braddah's Island Style for the second time, and decided to partake in a Kalua pig burrito, replete with seaweed rice, black beans, charred pineapple verde, lettuce, and tomato. Despite the fact that the administration had the temerity to deplete their stock of cilantro, an herb commonly used as a garnish, our burrito remained palatable. However, we noticed a perceptible decline in the cordiality and attentiveness of the staff during this visit, as evidenced by the absence of complimentary samples, uncleared tables, and the delayed provision of condiments, which were only provided following a patron's request after a considerable interval of ten minutes had elapsed. Consequently, we would assign a rating of 3.5 to this dining experience."

"This culinary establishment presented itself in a relatively satisfactory manner, prompting us to peruse their menu and select the egg rolls and grilled pork dishes. However, the duration of time that elapsed between placing our order and the arrival of our meals was truly protracted, particularly considering the modest number of patrons present within the restaurant during our visit. 

Notwithstanding this inconvenience, the interior of the eatery appeared well-maintained and organized. Unfortunately, a considerable quantity of smoke emanating from the kitchen region managed to permeate the primary dining area, perhaps indicative of an issue with ventilation. 

Upon receipt of our order, it became apparent that the egg rolls were diminutive in stature and accompanied by a sweet and sour sauce, rather than the customary fish sauce typically associated with such fare. Furthermore, while the flavor of the grilled pork was undeniably palatable, its portion size seemed somewhat meager in relation to the cost. 

In conclusion, although our experience at this restaurant was not without its drawbacks, it did possess certain redeeming qualities that rendered it a worthwhile excursion. However, it remains uncertain whether a subsequent visit would be warranted."

Decided to yelp for a good breakfast place while I was chilling at vegas and came across this place. 

It was a sunday morning about 10am and it was already super pack. It was about a 30 min wait. Which i thought for good food, should be worth the wait. 

Finally got in and everything look really good. All portions are huge! I end up ordering a original Benedict.

I thought the food was good on presentation but the food was just okay for me. My order was kind of cold which I thought was a buzz kill. It wasn't even a little bit warm. I would think if it was nice and hot everything would have tastes great but I guess i would never know.

Le Marly, a seemingly ordinary establishment, proved to be satisfactory. Although I did not partake in their culinary offerings, I did indulge in their unique beverages. Specifically, their signature raspberry martini, crafted with vodka, raspberry puree, and a fragrant basil leaf, was quite palatable. The majority of their potations, including liquor-based drinks, were priced below $10, with a standard 20-ounce beer costing approximately $7.50. The delectable appetizers sampled by my associates appeared visually appealing, although I did not have the pleasure of consuming them myself. Unfortunately, this modern, purple-themed watering hole, situated in the heart of downtown, does not seem to attract a considerable clientele. During our nearly three-hour visit on a Thursday evening, no new patrons entered the premises. The hospitable staff members, who graciously accepted our outerwear without charging a fee, were attentive to our needs, particularly regarding beverages. While I would not select this venue for an exclusive evening excursion, I would accompany a group if they chose to frequent it.
We eat breakfast here frequently. It's typical IHOP, but the food is fine and the staff takes good care of us.

This hotel is really cool for the younger group, I'd say 27 years and below.  I am thirty and I have to say that although its a great hotel, its not quite my style.

The rooms are pretty good.  They are decorated very sexy but there were a few little things that could have used repair, such as the wall plugs were a little loose and rattley.  Be warned, they have vibrators and lube in the mini-bar, so if you have little kids, probably not the best.

I definitely think that the pool brings in a younger crowd.  I didn't go to the pool, but there were so many guests there in their early twenties, clearly coming from the pool and highly intoxicated and loud that I think the hotel could do without. 

I do recommend eating at the Pink Taco inside the Hard Rock while you are there.  Very good Mexican Food.

I think its a great hotel, but I wouldn't necessarily recommend it to people over thirty and definitely not to people bringing kids.  However, if you are in your twenties, this is the spot.  The guests that were there in the appropriate age range were having the time of their lives.

If you are from out of town, which I assume most people in Vegas are, please note that this is not on the actual strip.  It is really close, but you will have to take a cab ride to and from.

"It appears that our initial intention of partaking in a leisurely luncheon at L'Avenue was thwarted by an extensive queue that extended beyond the entrance, thereby necessitating a modification of our plans. Subsequently, we opted to traverse the street and visit a nearby eatery with an inviting outdoor seating area, whereupon we were delightfully surprised by the culinary offerings, generous portion sizes, and attentive service. Notably, the prices were rendered eminently reasonable due to the copiousness of the servings, and furthermore, pints of Boreale draft beer were available at the exceptionally affordable rate of $5, which struck me as a veritable bargain. It is worth mentioning that the prevalence of individuals in Montreal who customarily consume alcoholic beverages during the midday repast appears to be somewhat reminiscent of certain European traditions, a phenomenon that I wholeheartedly endorse. In conclusion, this establishment may be deemed a reliable venue for a satisfying dining experience."

My boyfriend and I dropped in for the first time on a Sunday afternoon.  The atmosphere was nice and the restaurant was very clean.  Our server Dan was knowledgeable and pleasant. The food was average but good for the price. We will definately be back.

I went here for the first time yesterday and was waiting to meet someone.  When I arrived I wasn't greeted for a good 5 minutes in a mostly empty dining room.  I had to wonder around until someone attended to me.  After telling them that I'd like a table for 2 they sit me at a big table with 5 places as opposed to a booth.   

After my friend arrived our order was taken promptly and our waitress was nice. The food was lukewarm and could have been seasoned better although the meat on my dish was cooked tender and came in a good portion size although there were a TON of onions I'm contrast to the meat portion.  The rice was bland and boring as well.  

The decor looked great and very classy and the staff was overall friendly.  The price was fair for the portion size and I'd be willing to give this place another go, but I hope for better food and someone at the door to greet me right away.

"This establishment, Bison Witches, presents itself as a purveyor of gastronomical delights, specializing in sandwiches, and offers an array of beverages, specifically beer, at a price point that can be considered reasonable. Upon partaking in their culinary offerings, I have found their chili cheese nachos to be particularly satisfying, while my dining companion, Kristen, has expressed a fondness for the Miss Pris. While there may not be anything remarkably unique or exceptional about this eatery, it does provide a commendable level of quality in terms of both the edibles and potables served, as well as the attentiveness of the staff. Thus, it can be concluded that Bison Witches warrants a rating of three and a half stars."

I think this mom and pop restaurant is awesome! The food is great, I had the lobster roll with the clam streamers. Granted not huge compared to something you get at the coast, but living in las Vegas. It'll help cure the ache until you can hit the coast.

"Upon perusing the menu, we opted to sample their culinary offerings, specifically the tamale burger, which unfortunately did not meet our expectations due to its arid nature and an unpleasant aftertaste. However, the fries accompanying the dish were quite delectable, boasting an inventive blend of spices that included a subtle hint of nutmeg and cinnamon, thereby evoking a sense of warmth and depth. Despite the underwhelming experience with the food, we were thoroughly impressed by the ambiance, characterized by dim lighting and a welcoming atmosphere that fostered a convivial ambiance, which was further enhanced by the bartender's proficiency in crafting expertly mixed cocktails. Moreover, the staff demonstrated exceptional customer service, as they graciously offered us a complimentary replacement drink following an unfortunate spillage. Consequently, we intend to revisit this establishment, primarily for the purpose of indulging in their beverages, and perhaps experimenting with alternative menu items, such as the sweet and spicy burger, which our server enthusiastically endorsed."

"Our inaugural visit transpired two days prior to the culmination of the year, and we partook of their midday repast.  The Green Papaya salad and Panang curry, both piquant and flavorful, garnered our unwavering approbation.  The hospitality we received was quite satisfactory, and the beverage, an icy brew, was quaffed with relish.  However, a cursory inspection of the premises revealed a minor shortcoming; specifically, a negligible amount of detritus was scattered about the floor, which remained unattended throughout the duration of our meal.  Nonetheless, we would unhesitatingly recommend this establishment to any individual who takes pleasure in Thai cuisine...nota bene:  The thermostat settings, purportedly the most scorching, did not quite live up to our expectations."

Not so bad. The entrance looks like a hotel check-in. The security team here was cool, which is refreshing for a club on the strip. Usually security crew's think they are real cops with a Napoleon complex.

It was a week day when I went, so it wasn't too crowded. Lil Jon was playing and he's a decent DJ. 

Since I'm a local and I usually avoid the strip, I was (as usual) SHOCKED when I was told it was $52 for a beer, wine, and a shot for the the birthday boy. This is why I stay away from the strip. Not that it is their fault - that's how they pay their rent. I wish clubs like this would offer local prices even when it comes to drinks. Because seriously we could just stash alcohol in our car and run in and out of the club. It's not like we're staying in a hotel and have no way to get more booze. Just a thought!

Overall, compared to Haze, Tryst, ... (and all the other clubs I've been to but can't remember at the moment), this one was pretty decent. Moon is still my favorite, but XS wasn't bad.

I'd give this place 3.5 stars... after reading the other reviews I expected a half of a cup of pasta or something ridiculous but I thought the portion was adequate. And, I was REALLY hungry when I got there. 

We ordered the olives as a starter (they are all green and served warm) and were able to get some bread to accompany the reserve oil. 

Our server voluntarily explained menu items with important details like: it's ricotta gnocchi, not potato and the extra items in the puntanesca sauce (my recipe only has 7). We both had the orecchiette with sausage and greens. I found it to be a bit oily but the pasta was cooked well. 

He described the deserts perfectly and the chocolate bark with almonds was a nice finish with a second glass of nero d'avalo, and, by the way... I though the wine prices were very reasonable! 

Without tip, we spent about $36 a person and we each had two glasses of wine and left satisfied!

Seemingly, bars such this are effected massively by the clientele. This particular All Bar One, nestled in the middle of Edinburgh's financial district results in mostly desk job monkeys frequenting the place.

One thing I've learnt in my time in Edinburgh is that such clientele and students don't mix. Thus, All Bar One is best avoided .

Drinks, food etc are all pretty standard - not that dissimilar to Wetherpoons in what it offers.

After seeing the Fry's Signature in Scottsdale, I had high expectations with this supermarket. The store was not as fancy, but it was still nice looking. 

Bathrooms are located next to the pharmacy. The air fresheners gave the bathroom an extra touch.

This supermarket has a Starbucks, sushi area, etc. No price scanners though.

Considering that this supermarket is in the middle of nowhere, it does have a lot of customers!

Not a bad place. Service is good with friendly employees. The food, although not the beat does taste good and is fresh.  While there I had the angry whopper. Im not a fan of thick french fries, but theirs was still good. 

What I liked most was their choices of soda. They have "orange coke" flavored soda. I never even heard of it before, so I had to try and and wow. Was it good.  

Sadly the whole time I was thinking there they never swept the floor that needed it. Yeah its a small thing and I am not going to eat off it, but visually it is not appealing. The same is true of their bathroom floor.

"I am attending a conference at the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino, and I have opted to frequent this establishment for two meals during my stay. On my initial visit, I indulged in a delectable Angus steak burger, complemented by an assortment of mushrooms and a tangy bleu cheese, all for the reasonable price of $20, inclusive of tax. Although not particularly economical, this culinary delight proved to be the most satisfactory value within the vast confines of the resort's dining options, especially considering the late hour of 9:47 p.m. upon checking in. 

The following morning, I returned to partake in their breakfast offerings. While the individual dishes were quite expensive, I elected to exercise fiscal prudence by ordering two side dishes instead: two eggs prepared to my liking for a moderate fee of $8, accompanied by a portion of home fries for an additional $3. Furthermore, I treated myself to an oversized cup of tea, which, although priced at a somewhat exorbitant $3.50, was nonetheless a worthwhile investment due to the inclusion of a high-quality English Breakfast tea bag, honey, and the availability of soy milk. 

The staff at this establishment has consistently displayed warmth and efficiency in their service, creating a welcoming ambiance that more than compensates for the lack of a sophisticated dining experience. In conclusion, while not an exceptional eatery, this venue provides a suitable setting for a satisfying meal at a tolerable cost within the context of the resort's generally elevated prices."

I guess I don't get it?

Everything was wholly average. Burgers, service, prices--average. I ordered Kiki's burger--average. Some bites were overly sweet, but the mushrooms added a good savory touch. I had the garlic fries--average. They trick you into thinking you're getting an f-ton of fries and you're getting about a handful.

Also, their hostesses kept seating people directly next to us, too, which was kind of irritating considering the restaurant was nearly empty. Twice the other diners asked to be moved so they weren't joining us for our meal.

I'd have to be dragged back---to me, it's not worth a revisit.

You should come here to revel in the ambiance and to partake in the phenomenon that has captivated the attention of many. Order a frozen hot chocolate and you shall have indulged in an experience comparable to the one offered by its counterpart in NY, albeit the latter being a humble shack. Be aware, however, that this frozen delight is excessively sweet, and even when shared with another individual, you will likely consume only half of it, leaving behind a substantial amount of whipped cream. 

Their culinary offerings are unremarkable and typical of establishments serving standard American fare, such as TGIF. The loaded potato skins, priced at $11, are not worth the expense, and the chicken dijon pizza, at $14, is arid and unappetizing. It is advisable to opt for store-bought frozen pizza instead and cook it in the comfort of your own home. 

People flock to this establishment for the experience alone, which warrants three stars. The ambiance possesses an ineffable quality that makes women feel pampered and special. :))

I have had the pleasure of visiting the Bank on two separate occasions, and I must say that my experiences were somewhat disparate. My initial visit was rather anomalous, as the club was brimming with an electrifying atmosphere, courtesy of the pulsating music that permeated the venue. I was thoroughly enthralled by the DJ's mix, which unfortunately, I was unable to procure. The club was teeming with people, creating a sense of intimacy akin to a house party, which was further accentuated by the diminutive size of the establishment. Everyone was in high spirits, evidenced by their fervent dancing and jovial demeanor. We had the good fortune of encountering some affable individuals with whom we spent the bulk of the evening conversing and sharing laughter. The ability to indulge in periods of respite was greatly appreciated, as it afforded us a chance to recharge our energies. My second visit, however, proved to be somewhat lackluster in comparison.
