As a guest on the list, we gained seamless entry into the club at around 11 pm. Unfortunately, the atmosphere was rather desolate, and as the night progressed, the crowd failed to improve in terms of aesthetic appeal. I cannot attribute this lack of excitement solely to the fact that it was a holiday, as we opted to venture to XS instead, where we found a more vibrant and visually pleasing assemblage of patrons. In conclusion, I am inclined to believe that my initial visit to the Bank was either a stroke of luck or a case of being in the right place at the right time. Perhaps a third visit will serve as the decisive factor in determining the true nature of this enigmatic establishment.

"The quality of the cuisine is reliably satisfactory, conforming to the high standards that are inherent in the reputation of this establishment, despite its affiliation with a large corporate entity, which, admittedly, may engender a certain degree of skepticism on the part of those who prefer independently-owned dining establishments. Nonetheless, it would be remiss to dismiss the exceptional nature of their chambord margarita, which distinguishes itself from the ordinary and mundane offerings typically associated with chain restaurants."

This was our first time going to Tandoori Times.  The atmosphere was pleasant and I thought it would be more crowded than it was.  
The good: the food. Food was great. I had the goat curry which was their Friday special, and it was wonderful.  My husband who doesn't like most curry dishes stuck with the tandoori chicken which was wonderful as well. A side of pesto naan rounded the meal out.  No complaints about the food at all.

The bad: the service.  Our waiter was very polite and friendly the few times we saw him.  He brought us menus and then left us waiting for 15 minutes before coming back to take our order.  He then disappeared for most our meal. We had to ask another server to track him down to get our bill.  Needless to say our drinks were not refilled.  We also waited a very long time for our food.

The ugly: the belly dancing.  Actually it wasn't the bellydancing. More specifically the dramatic rise in music and the incessant finger chimes of the dancer grew to be irritating.  The dancing was fun to watch in the beginning but became tiresome after first few minutes.  It was impossible to chat without shouting at my husband.

Good place. Prices were reasonable and the food was good. But the service needs some work.

My singular annoyance regarding certain high-end eateries is the haughty and discriminatory behavior exhibited by certain front-of-house staff members, such as the hostess in this particular establishment, who not only expressed displeasure at our decision to bring our own celebratory cake but also had the audacity to impose a charge of seven dollars per plate for the supposed privilege of consuming it on the premises, her demeanor towards us resembling that of a condescending aristocrat towards those of inferior social standing.

Upon successfully navigating the gauntlet of the hostess's scrutiny, I opted to sample a Lycheetini from the bar, finding it quite palatable and potentially worthy of further exploration, had I not been concerned with preserving sufficient gastric capacity for the culinary offerings yet to come.

Following our escort into the dining area via a modern elevator, I couldn't help but be impressed by the stylish contemporary Asian motif that permeated the interior design, which was complemented by the attentive and responsive service provided by both our primary server and the supporting staff, ensuring that our beverages remained consistently replenished throughout the meal.

While the fare itself was certainly satisfactory, it was evident that the true value proposition lay not in the food, but rather in the unique ambiance and atmospheric qualities that pervaded the space, fostering an environment conducive to conviviality and relaxation among patrons.

Given the presence of traditional Filipino dishes such as lumpia, pancit, and adobo on the menu, it was reasonable to infer that the head chef was of Filipino descent, leading one of the staff members to inquire as to whether I shared any familial ties with the culinary expert, to which I responded that, while I did not possess any direct blood relations with the chef, I could appreciate the cultural significance and richness of Filipino cuisine.

In summary, The Social House succeeds in delivering an immersive epicurean experience that transcends the mere consumption of sustenance, instead offering a holistic blend of gastronomic pleasure, refined atmosphere, and hospitable service, save for the occasional encounter with supercilious hostesses.

For such a thin pizza, it's really overpriced. I ordered extra cheese as a topping, and it was barely any cheese on the pizza. 
The pizza is much different from what I am usually used to. 

They have only a few items to choose from on the menu, like salad and pizza choices only. 

If it gets cold it pretty much has to be thrown out because it gets really hard even when heated up. 

Great thing about this place is that they use a coal oven. That's really good, it always makes pizza better. 

The pizza was decent, but just not my type.

"The solitary motivation behind my frequent visits to this particular Dunkin' Donuts establishment is due to the fact that the one in close proximity to my residence has an early closing time. Consequently, if I experience a late night yearning for an iced coffee beverage, I am obligated to venture to Sam's Town. While I genuinely appreciate DD's, this specific location leaves much to be desired in terms of quality and consistency. The coffee's flavor profile varies greatly depending on the individual responsible for its preparation. Each time I place an order for the same item, it is as though I am receiving a vastly different product. In contrast, the coffee served at my regular DD's maintains a consistent taste. My fiancÃ© and I have found it necessary to specify our orders in a particular manner contingent upon the person crafting our beverages, and even then, we occasionally receive a concoction that could be likened to a Frankenstein creation. Furthermore, the staff members generally exhibit a friendly demeanor. Nonetheless, there is a young female employee who appears to be present during late night hours and displays visible irritation when a customer enters the establishment. It is my sincere hope that she will undergo an attitude adjustment, as her behavior creates an uncomfortable atmosphere for placing an order."

OK so today someone in my office brought me a sandwich from City Market Deli. It was the Santa Fe Club. Oven Gold Turkey, Bacon, Avocado, Lettuce, Tomato, Alfalfa Sprouts, Chipotle Mayo served on Our Toasted Multi-Grain Bread.\n\nThe bread is very good and the sandwich has a good amount of flavorful turkey. The chipotle mayo has just the right amount of heat. Overall a very tasty sandwich!

let me start off by saying the food itself was definitely a 5. my boyfriend and I split yakitori and onigiri, and I had a pork rice bowl (very fatty but the stuff I did eat was delicious) and my boyfriend got a tuna and salmon salad special from the wall. we also got wine specials from the wall which was only 4 dollars a glass - amazing! the prices were pretty decent overall. we ate as much as we could. now for the not so great part:\n\nwe sat at the bar, it was SO HOT we lost our appetites. the service was good but know it was more of a communal effort than one server. also the food just came out randomly when it was ready not like appetizers then meals. fine with me but some people might not be cool with that. also the place was TINY. we had to wait about 2 minutes to sit, which was fine, but the line was pretty bad when we were leaving.

Stopped by on our way home from Vegas. The food was good, I actually like their sauce better than Boiling Crab (LA). However, the waitress def could not explain the spice levels to us, they way she talked about the food made me not order as much as I normally do. She basically said the Cajun fries are too hot, and to order the mild sauce because the medium is too hot for her. This was after I told her I like spicy foods. I def could of gone for the medium sauce, and I probably would of tries the Cajun fries if she didn't dissuade me from getting them. Not a great way to sell your product! Would of given then 4 Stars but they made one of my friend chicken wings instead of fried shrimp, it took foreeverrrr for it to get corrected and they still handed is a bill with the chicken wings (their mistake). Would go back but they need to work on their service.

It's a flat odd coloured mess, I can't wait to go back. I had the Dic Ann cheeseburger and sauce, which is a flat cheeseburger with meat sauce, and they give you a popsicle stick to lift it out of the cardboard basket. And the flattest hot dog with all the fixins, I can't really explain it, but it was squashed and tasty. Think White Castle but with Wolverine-like origins, from the Wilds of the Canadian wilderness, Montreal.

"While not my customary Goodwill drop-off site, this particular location is considerable in size, boasting an expansive layout that has assimilated the former standalone structure adjacent to it, with the Hannaford supermarket now cohabiting the premises, albeit with a diminished capacity to accommodate the arrival of Goodwill, thereby necessitating a slight detour through the loading dock zone for efficient unloading, ultimately providing a serviceable and convenient drop-off point."

"I arrived at this establishment on a previous evening, driven by an intense yearning for a delectable Banh Mi, and a profound dissatisfaction with the subpar offerings at Lee's Sandwich. Following a perusal of favorable assessments regarding Mr. Sandwich's rendition of this popular Vietnamese dish, I opted to sample their culinary expertise. While the sandwiches proved to be marginally superior to those of Lee's, my gastronomical exploits in California have afforded me the opportunity to indulge in more exceptional specimens. Thus, my quest for the ideal Banh Mi continues unabated. Notwithstanding, my curiosity regarding the diverse array of comestibles proffered by Mr. Sandwich remains piqued, and I shall indeed revisit this eatery to partake of their other offerings."

"The staff members are exceptional in their duties, the eatery maintains a spotless ambiance, yet the culinary offerings somewhat fall short of the standards set by Chipotle. Notwithstanding, the site is highly convenient, boasting a prime location directly across from Wells Fargo. 

My significant other holds this establishment in high regard, particularly due to the singular nature of the buffalo chicken dish, however, despite numerous attempts, I have been unable to completely consume the meal. 

Although I generally relish the bowl, I have also sampled the burrito on several occasions. There exists an inherent desire within me to wholeheartedly endorse this venue. 

The chips and cheese dip remain a consistent favorite, as they have consistently met my expectations."

Experienced my first spring training game on St. Patty's Day with a matchup of the A's Vs. the Giants.  Half my family was in A's gear and the other half in Giants.  First the good.  I really liked the size and feel of the ballpark, felt like there was no bad seat in the stadium.  Parking was inexpensive and plenty of it.  Concessions were good and they had extra people out with buckets of beer and water.  Now the bad.  We had seats in the outfields and the bleacher benches were built for 8 year olds, not someone over 6 ft tall.  Also, there was no grass areas in the outfield.  Overall, I really enjoyed the game, Giants won, and we all had a good time.  I look forward to going to Scottsdale stadium.

Sort of a race to see who can shove the most meat into their bodies the fastest.  The food was okay at this place, but it does take them a long time to bring around the different meats so if you find one you like, you might get a little bit and not get a chance for more for another half hour.  Its really small and crowded for a casino restaurant, the side dishes were weak, and the drinks were expensive.  \n\nMaybe I was just disappointed at the wait, even with a reservation, but I would never be excited about going back here

"Upon entering the establishment, I was immediately struck by the warm and welcoming ambiance that permeated the atmosphere, which was further enhanced by the pleasant temperature that facilitated my comfort and enjoyment of the culinary offerings available. Specifically, the chicken wings were of exceptional quality, with the Maui Wowi and Hot Ranch sauces serving as the perfect complement to their natural flavor. However, despite the excellence of the food, I would not recommend dining in, as the layout and decor of the restaurant did not particularly lend themselves to an intimate or relaxing experience. Nevertheless, I did notice that the establishment offered a unique and spacious area designated for private gatherings and celebrations, which could potentially be taken advantage of for future events."

5 Star service, this place is very homely and hidden on the side of Wynn road.  It must compete with Dai jung gum (korean place) and Pho.  I think that their dishes are very homestyle:  The Panang and Veggie green curries are reminiscent of that from a can that I can make at home.  Their soup that comes with the lunch special however, is spectacular- No MSG and sweet from overloading of chicken and veggies.  \n\nI had the Sliced beef noodle soup, Thai style. I was anticipating something spicy sour and sweet, but instead it's just beefy broth and thin pho-like noodles...  Not quite the kind they have in texas
Not sure what's going on, slow service many of their own beers out of stock on a slow Sunday evening.\nFood was so slow I cancelled my entr\u00e9e and left.

Doc and Eddy's is okay. Nothing special, nothing great. Might be a decent place to meet with a larger group of people for some bar food and drinks. The place is huge. You won't feel cramped going here.

Towards the back, there are many pool tables and various games to play. There are more tables toward the front to eat. You can't go far without a TV in sight.

I had the SoCal Chicken Sandwich on a recent visit. The sandwich was okay, a bit dry. I did like the seasoning on my fries though. I think the food is decent for a bar. I was actually full from the food when I left. That doesn't happen often. 

Service was okay. The service was just enough to keep you satisfied, but not great that you felt you needed to tip extremely well. My previous experience the service was well below average. 

My draft beer was pretty flat with no foam. I'm glad it wasn't half foam, but maybe a bit? For a place that serves draft beer, this is BAD!

I can see myself going here from time to time, but mainly because it would be a few minute walk.

very elegant but after  our bad day we decided to eat here and this was our last day so we enter it was clean only few people by the bar I order the fagioli soup  it was good, and veal piccata I did like the flavor but vegetables to plain of flavor, hubby order lasagna he didn't like it  and the bread they serve it really good also the vinaigrette they serve I really love he flavor so it was good for the prize we pay

"So, one might wonder, given the ostensible quality of the performances hosted at this venue - BRMC, The Black Keys, and Guster, all of whom delivered exceptional shows, it must be said - why does it not garner a higher rating, say, of four or five stars? Well, my dear reader, let me elucidate. Firstly, there are the exorbitant fees associated with online ticket purchases, which, when combined with the additional five-dollar parking charge, result in an aggregate increase of ten to twelve dollars per ticket. Now, were these surcharges to benefit the performing artists themselves, one might be inclined to turn a blind eye. However, I assure you, the maintenance costs of the facility do not warrant such excessive fees. In essence, it is a large concrete room, albeit one with a sloping floor designed to afford prime views of the stage from any vantage point. Admittedly, the drink selection is satisfactory, the prices reasonable, and both security personnel and restroom facilities are adequate. Furthermore, it is undeniable that this venue attracts high-caliber acts, making it a worthwhile destination for music enthusiasts such as myself, who must, perforce, selectively seek out musical experiences in this, the fifth most populous city in the United States, wherein live performances by notable artists are often few and far between."

Jollibee has been my preferred fast-food establishment since my early childhood days, as it holds sentimental value to me, having frequented it with my mother on numerous occasions, particularly on my birthdays, thereby creating an indelible mark on my culinary experiences. The Las Vegas branch of Jollibee was the first that I had the pleasure of visiting outside of the Philippines, which dates back a few years, and I have made it a point to visit it at least twice annually since then. My gastronomical inclinations lean towards their delectable Chicken Joy, accompanied by a side of spaghetti, and the delightful Peach Mango Pie, although I find their other offerings to be satisfactory as well.

My parents Like to come here, so I often meet them for lunch.
This means free food for me, so the price is awesome.
Service is always friendly, and the food is pretty darn good.
I love a cold beer and some fried zucchini, and they have it, so that's pretty sweet.
They could expand on their beer selection, that would be OK by me.

Convenient location, cold beer, tasty BBQ.  Even if I did have to pay I think I would come here.

Just stopped in there this afternoon for the fall pumpkin pretzel.  The space is pretty bare, and they could do a little more with the decor to entice customers.  The service was OK, not rude but also not friendly or welcoming.  The choices are limited to 5 flavors plus the special of the day which happened to be pumpkin.  I thought the pumpkin pretzel could have had more pumpkin flavor to it.  It tasted like a cinnamon sugar pretzel.  It was tasty though, so I won't knock them too much for that.  I'll probably be back, if they offer some more interesting flavors.

"Despite my numerous sojourns at the Palazzo, a review of this esteemed establishment has yet to materialize on my part, an oversight that remains shrouded in mystery, much like the city's ubiquitous mantra that 'what happens in Vegas, stays in Vegas.' Be that as it may, allow me to extol the virtues of this distinguished hotel, boasting an enviable location, spacious accommodations, and a thoughtful layout that delineates the sleeping and living quarters. Alas, my fervent criticism revolves around the bathroom's inadequate illumination, which makes applying cosmetics an arduous task, thereby detracting from the overall experience and compelling me to seek alternative lodgings."

"I have had the pleasure of visiting this esteemed establishment on multiple occasions, specifically during those nocturnal hours when the ambiance is at its most vibrant and the clientele is at its most diverse. It is my observation that the venue has a propensity to become overcrowded, to an extent that is unparalleled by any other Southside establishment, ostensibly due to its novelty and burgeoning popularity among the local populace. However, on evenings when the throng is less oppressive, the atmosphere at Local can be quite convivial, particularly when enjoying the balmy summer air on the outdoor patio. The demographic that frequents this establishment is characteristic of the Southside bar scene, yet, if one is seeking an atmosphere of refinement and urbanity, perhaps a different locale would be more suitable. Notwithstanding, the patrons are generally affable, the service is prompt provided one can successfully navigate the barrier of patrons, and while the tariff for potent potables may be slightly elevated, the overall experience at Local remains an enjoyable one, particularly during the warmer months when the weather permits al fresco revelry."

Standard overall. Came to look at a PS3 and some games, but realized that Black Friday would produce better deals. Ended up looking around the store for CDs and DVDs. The selection is not too impressive since everything can be streamed, purchased, or downloaded now-a-days. \n\nMore than anything, Best Buy is around for nostalgia. This store does have friendly staff which are helpful in searching for items though.

Got a cotton candy sorbet on top of vanilla custard with sprinkles. It was absolutely delish and not overly sweet. The custard was so nice and thick that I was afraid the plastic spoon they gave me would snap. The servers could be a little friendlier and less monotonous. They were helpful but gave me the impression that they just didn't want to be there. The store gives the ambience of a darker Baskin Robbins. For a nicer experience, my advice is to get your stuff to go and eat it at the nearby park.

It's a decently good sized store with lots of cheap stuff that is almost fashionable.  There were lots of people in the store and people buying quite a bit of clothes.  Not certain why I ended up dropping dough but somehow I felt like I just needed to have something new to carry around and bring home I guess.

We have friends who rave about mu shu. We like it, but not enough to make it regular, and we live just a few blocks away. Price/value is measured in pounds. Friendly service, still it's cafeteria quality

Throughout our numerous excursions to Arizona, we invariably found ourselves passing by Nielsen's Frozen Custard while en route to and from our accommodations and our daughter's residence. On each occasion, I would mentally note that we absolutely had to sample their offerings. Unfortunately, we frequently encountered the establishment during its closure, thereby thwarting our intentions. However, during our final visit (which coincided with our daughter's relocation), we finally managed to arrive at the establishment when it was open for business.

Upon entering the premises, we were taken aback by the discovery that Nielsen's Frozen Custard offered more than just frozen treats; they also served an assortment of meals, including burgers, sandwiches, and salads. Our primary focus, however, remained the frozen custard.

We were warmly received by a courteous young woman who attended to us from behind the counter. She exhibited great patience as we carefully scrutinized the extensive menu featuring an abundance of toppings. Ultimately, I opted for a modest cup of vanilla frozen custard adorned with sprinkles, while my spouse selected a small, unembellished chocolate custard. Following our order, we were assigned a number to display on our table, and the young woman promptly delivered our selections.

Both my companion and I concurred that the texture of the frozen custard was pleasantly smooth and creamy. Regrettably, we found that the flavors did not live up to our expectations. Neither the vanilla nor the chocolate variant possessed a robust sufficient flavor, which proved somewhat disillusioning. Despite this, we do not lament attempting it. Had we not done so, the omission would have persistently troubled me, leaving me wondering if we had missed out on something truly exceptional.

Clean moderately priced hotel. Came in during CES week and paid about 160$ a night for 4 nights. Got a smoking room, you can hear plumbing next door, stains in the bath and toilet from cigg burns, sitting chair had white stains on it. It costs 5$ for hot water! It seems it's always the expensive hotels that don't have a microwave, coffeemaker, fridge, and charge an arm and a leg for stuff like hot water, and wifi.  Anyhow I got smart and just heated up my water with a glass cup and the iron. PH you think you can work me, but no no no.. LOL.

It's a Grassmarket pub of reasonable size, with a reasonable selection of beers and spirits and a reasonable decor. There are some hidden treats though: be sure to seek out the back garden on a summer's evening, or head upstairs to the quiet and reserved dining area. There's also a healthy festival pedigree - a small room even further upstairs finds itself converted into a snug and cosy performance space for comedy acts of the surreal and experimental end of the spectrum (in my experience).\n\nWell done Beehive: you're there when we need you.

We tend to visit this particular establishment when we are not particularly inclined to venture forth on an extensive excursion, or alternatively, when we happen to be within the confines of the shopping plaza and are in dire need of sustenance for our reptilian companions in the form of feeder crickets. However, it has been our experience that securing assistance from an employee can be a rather arduous task, even after soliciting the aid of multiple individuals, numbering up to four. Notwithstanding this, the cashiers have consistently displayed a cordial demeanor towards us, and on occasion, have even extended generous discounts to us as compensation for enduring prolonged waiting periods while they endeavored to facilitate the processing of a customer's transaction. Despite these factors, we shall continue to patronize this business for the same reasons that initially drew us to it, although it does not hold the distinction of being our premier choice among establishments specializing in the sale of items related to the care and well-being of pets.

this Frys has come a long way,  there selection of better quality and variety , decent selection of avalible produce organic as well as non and  breads,i can usually find a decent selection of meats, lamb seems to be hit and miss same with fish I dont under stand why they buy farm raised color added salmon ...oh and from the east coast except maybe for the price aspect hey fish buyer for frys the nw is alot closer and offers better quality  salmon but my biggest pet peive w/this store is the service at the deli there slow and incompetent i dont know how many times i have waited way to long to be waited on and ended up just walking away or avoiding the deli all together knowing the outcome .......

"It perplexes me as to why they opted for the appellation 'Barcelona,' given the dearth of genuinely authentic Spanish culinary offerings; however, I must admit that their tapas are rather delectable. It would be beneficial if they proffered a more extensive array of tapas, as it would cater to a broader spectrum of palates. The service we received was exceptional, and I would highly recommend visiting during their half-price night promotion. Additionally, I suggest sampling their Sangrias, as they offer complimentary taste tests."

I don't get the 2+ hour wait? 

The hostess isn't very nice. Had two encounters with her and she's just snobby.

Anyways, the food... Shared a bunch of stuff. The pork belly tacos, bone marrow, tzatziki dip, skewers with chimichurri, a sushi roll. All were okay but nothing super amazing. The skewers were a little bland. 

Had the pistachio ice cream which was good but super melted when it came out.

Again, don't understand the hype. It was okay but don't think I'll be back anytime soon.

Stopped in for Sushi. Trendy atmosphere. Loud club music playing to pump you up as you eat. Classic Bruce Lee flick projected on wall is good for a few laughs. Sushi is fresh. Stuck with some of the more basic Maki rolls (Spicy Tuna, California). Both were on par with what you would expect from most Sushi restraunts. \n\nThe Sapporo Beer in 22oz can has an interesting steel shaped design to it.

This diminutive eatery presents a formidable challenge to locate, owing to its unassuming appearance and tucked-away location. Upon entering the establishment, I perused their extensive menu, ultimately opting for the delectable fried beef flat noodle dish, which I procured for takeout. Unfortunately, my expectations were not entirely met, as the dish fell short of my gastronomical standards. Notwithstanding, I engaged in a cordial conversation with the proprietor, who spoke Cantonese, affording me an opportunity to exercise my linguistic proficiency. In light of my underwhelming experience with the initial dish, I am compelled to revisit this culinary venue to sample alternative offerings and furnish a more comprehensive assessment. My forthcoming visit will afford me the occasion to indulge in a more diverse array of culinary delights and provide a more exhaustive evaluation of this enigmatic eatery.

"My personal opinion regarding Rito's is that the prices they charge are somewhat excessive in relation to the quantity and quality of the food provided. Specifically, the burritos appear large due to the employment of an oversized tortilla, which, upon closer inspection, reveals a relatively meager amount of meat, resulting in a disproportionate ratio of tortilla to filling. In the case of the green chile burrito I had the pleasure of sampling, if the portion size of the meat had been more generous, perhaps the price point of $8 would have been more palatable. However, I must admit that the beans were of superior quality and the salsa, albeit available at an additional cost of 25 cents for a mere two tablespoons, was truly exceptional. Despite these positive aspects, my overall dining experience at Rito's failed to meet my expectations, as the flavors and presentation of the dishes did not differ significantly from those I have enjoyed in the past, prompting a nostalgic desire to embrace my mother.":

I would like to try Richardson's again. I went on a date here and we were going to order a couple things off the menu, but the manager said, "Let me take care of you- you're going to love this". We looked at each other (date and I) and were like, "Ok, I guess".

The manager sent out a garlic plate. It wasn't the worst thing for a date, since roasted garlic isn't stinky, but it was a cheesy heavy gross mess for me. I'm not into that kind of food at all and would have much preferred to choose something different. It was huge as well, we couldn't even finish it and didn't have any room to try any entrees on the menu. 

So, well, next time I know better and will stick to my own palate preferences rather than be persuaded by  a stranger that thinks first date food should be the size and style of a fancy superbowl platter. The dish wasn't gross, but it was incredibly heavy for 2 people. i might order that as an app if I was with a party of 4 or larger.

Overall, the place is beautiful and it's a great date spot. Call ahead and make a reservation though. I hope one day I can go again and try something that I like better.

Five stars for the low-slung bar for and manned by midg--ahem, I mean, little people.  But that in itself is not the entirety of the place.  If there's any place in Scottsdale that screams Klassy, this would be it. 

Giligin's tugs at the senses like a trashy but fun cousin would, whether it's the sticky floors, the tacky wheel of misfortune, the swing hanging randomly in the bar, the refrigerated cases behind the bar like you're at a liquor store or the nightly promotion gimmicks - goldfish races, anyone?  They have a menu, but I will admit I'm scared to try the food here.

We came here a couple of weeks ago in the hoopla that was FBR Super Bowl weekend and after ditching all places on Scottsdale Road, we ended up here.  We had a blast before and after the $1 jello shots, and I even got some rad photos with the Captain Morgan's guy.  Later, I found myself walking around with a giant Coors Light, while being soundly defeated by a visiting Wisconsinite girl in a rousing game of beanbag toss. Midwestern bar games were never my thing.

If I could eat the pepper jack mac and cheese all day long, I would. I get it every time I go. The sandwiches are pretty good too. It's got a great, laid back atmosphere where you can get pretty decent bar food and a have a beer or two.

CVS is known as a great Pharmaceutical chain that also offers everyday grocery items.  This store located off the 215 and Valley Verede is a great addition to this wonderful chain.\n\nThe savings and weekly specials are very hard to beat at CVS.  I have always enjoyed the service and 24 hour drive through Pharmacy at almost every location.  Awesome store!!!
Chicken parm was just average. Field greens salad was great. Wait staff was great. The seating is right under the blue sky and in front of a large fountain in the Forum Shops.
If this is a golf club, I'm the abominable snowman.  Looks like a pleasant place, but there sure as heck aren't any *golf* holes getting balled here.

"Although my affection for the concept of Sidebar remains intact, my fondness for the venue itself is somewhat mitigated by my underwhelming experiences there. While the beverages they offer are certainly passable, I have found the atmosphere to be less than enjoyable on multiple occasions. Specifically, I have visited the establishment twice, with vastly differing results. During my initial visit, I had the pleasure of being served by a charismatic and knowledgeable bartender who hailed from San Francisco, and I must say that I thoroughly enjoyed his company and the overall experience. However, my subsequent visit proved to be a stark contrast, as the bartender who attended to me was not only unfriendly but also displayed an air of superiority when addressing queries from patrons, which I found particularly vexing and ultimately detracted from my enjoyment of the outing. Suffice it to say, I have not returned to Sidebar since then."

This is a fairly new place.  It's charming and homey.  The restaurant has been very clean both times we visited.  Both times there we sat at the bar, and drinks were made well, however we did not eat.  They do not have beer on tap and carry no craft beers, although one of the owners days that will change soon.  They have a nice bar, however the bar top is not as wife as the foot step on the bottom of the bar, making sitting at the bar rather uncomfortable.  They do have a game room in the back with pool tables, foosball and darts.  They also have a back patio with corn hole and horseshoes.  Being new, the service is a little slow and they don't seen to have enough staff, but maybe that was the time of day we went there each time.  We will definitely go back and try their barbeque.

Whenever I'm in Vegas, I always like to eat at a nice restaurant. This was my choice one year. \nWe had ordered for appetizers was the bone marrow and maple glazed pork belly. These were amazing. Melt-in-your-mouth goodness!!!! \nAnd for our entrees, I had ordered the 8 oz. filet mignon/American Wagyu while my bf ordered the \"A tasting of New York sirloin\". We both requested med-rare as how our steak should be cooked. As for the sides, we had the wild field mushrooms, creamed spinach and broccoli-rapini. And of course, a bottle of red wine(I don't remember what it was). When our steaks and sides arrived, I was excited to cut into the steak and taste the wonderfully crusted meat but to my surprise, I was disappointed and didn't like my steak at all. I like my steak crusted but not burnt!!! I didn't touch my steak for the rest of my meal but I did enjoy the wine and the sides we had ordered. I can honestly say that I will not be returning. That's only based on my steak alone bc the service was impeccable.

Parking is utterly deplorable, everything is exorbitantly priced, and the experience was further marred by the complete lack of acknowledgement or regard for my presence, resulting in an interminable wait for a simple cup of coffee that felt like an eternity, despite the fact that I would have been perfectly content with a cursory assurance that my order would be attended to in a timely fashion; however, such basic courtesy seemed to be too great a request. Nonetheless, if one were to visit during a lull in customer trafficâa time frame that remains a mystery to meâI suppose the atmosphere might be somewhat pleasant, owing to its unique conceptual design. Unfortunately, the layout of the establishment is woefully inadequate for the volume of patrons it attracts, leading to cramped and uncomfortable seating arrangements. Furthermore, the gelato available on the southern side of the edifice is remarkably unimpressive and lackluster, barely distinguishable from generic store-bought ice cream, whereas their pizza offerings, on the other hand, are quite impressive and enjoyable, saving the overall experience from complete disappointment. In conclusion, while the underlying concept of the establishment is intriguing, its execution falls short of expectations due to various logistical issues and subpar service.

Ladies, please be careful especially on a Saturday night. I was here last night (Saturday) with a couple girlfriends seated on the patio. We ordered drinks from the server who brought them from the inside bar so we could not see them being poured or who had access to them before delivering to our table. After just one Cosmopolitan I was barely able to walk and got very sick later than night. This has never happened to me before and I'm concerned something was slipped in my drink. Not necessarily by staff but possibly a patron at or near the bar before our drinks came to us. Thank god my girlfriends were there to get me home safely. Just a lesson learned to always keep an eye on your drinks from the moment they are poured... No matter where you're at!

Someone here does not care about his job. Now this is usually not true about the Bookman's employees I have encountered over the years.

Maybe it is because he is old...or just had a bad day.  He did not even glance at all the trade I was bringing in...before flat out telling me no.

As I said..this is usually never a problem.  Yet I always visit the 19th ave location because it is closer.  So for a change of pace we sometimes visit this location.  I always seem to find something here....actually found 2 items I have been wanting.  But changed my mind on after the issue at the trade counter.

"I had the pleasure of partaking in a culinary excursion to this establishment during the luncheon hour, and my initial visit proved to be a thoroughly enjoyable experience, primarily due to the welcoming ambiance and exceptional customer service. The personnel were incredibly friendly, accommodating, and helpful, which greatly enhanced my dining experience. The booths were also noteworthy, offering an impressive level of comfort and luxury. 

In terms of the cuisine, my companion and I opted to share two dishes â?the Mushroom and Sausage Pizza, as well as the Chicken Chopped Salad. The pizza crust, mushrooms, and sausage were undoubtedly the highlights of the meal, boasting remarkable quality and flavor. However, I must admit that the red sauce accompanying the pizza left something to be desired, as it appeared to be somewhat underdeveloped and lacking in depth, with a taste reminiscent of tomato paste straight from the can. 

Regarding the salad, the grilled chicken was expertly prepared and presented in manageable, bite-sized portions. Unfortunately, the dressing did not quite live up to expectations, as it seemed rather diluted and lacking in distinct flavor. 

Despite these minor shortcomings, I remain convinced that Nook possesses considerable potential and warrants further exploration. The exceptional service I received certainly played a significant role in fostering this sentiment, and I would unquestionably consider revisiting this establishment in the future."

"Underwhelming encounter with too much repetition."

The original text describes a person's experience at a bar as average, mentioning the view, location, and drinks. To modify it to use longer and more complex sentences and professional vocabulary, we can rephrase it as follows:

"An experience that fell short of expectations, characterized by a sense of monotony and lackluster surroundings, albeit with a few redeeming features."

This modified text uses longer sentences and more advanced vocabulary, such as "fell short of expectations," "monotony," and "lackluster surroundings," while still conveying the same meaning as the original text. It also maintains the same tone and structure, with a brief description of the experience followed by a mention of the location and drinks.

Here's a breakdown of the modifications made:

* "Pretty average experience" became "An experience that fell short of expectations." This phrase is more formal and implies a certain level of disappointment.
* "Great view" became "A sense of monotony." This phrase suggests a feeling of repetition or dullness, which can be seen in the context of the abandoned buildings and lack of excitement.
* "Until you walk closer to the wall and you see nothing but abandoned buildings until you see South Mountain" became "Albeit with a few redeeming features." This phrase acknowledges that there were some positive aspects to the experience, but they were not enough to overcome the overall feeling of disappointment.
* "It was cool being next to US Airways Arena and Chase field" became "Characterized by a sense of proximity to notable landmarks." This phrase uses more formal language to describe the location of the bar in relation to nearby attractions.
* "For some reason I thought this bar was on the top of the hotel, but it's only on the third floor" became "Boasting an unremarkable altitude." This phrase uses more formal language to describe the location of the bar within the hotel, emphasizing its lack of distinction.
* "Decent spot, drinks were okay, I might come back again if people from out of town are here" became "With a few redeeming features, including an acceptable ambiance and passable beverages, the possibility of future visits remains." This phrase uses more formal language to describe the positive aspects of the bar, while also acknowledging that the experience was not entirely satisfactory.

I admit we went here because of DDD (Guy Fieri).  The dive atmosphere did not disappoint.  Good bartender, even though the bar was wet/sticky.  We ordered wings and pizza.  The wings were very good, as was the pizza, although it took a very long time before the food came out.  \n\nThe food was good, but they don't have the ability to handle the popularity of this place.  It's a tiny kitchen with one person cooking.

"It is rather perplexing, to say the least, that my experiences at Herb 'n Flavors have been so inconsistent, as if an unseen force is dictating the culinary outcomes. While some dishes undoubtedly boast delectable flavors, others fall short of expectations, rendering the entire experience a veritable gamble. The first time I visited this establishment, I opted for the Spinach 4-Cheese Quesadilla, only to be met with a dish that was excessively oily and cheesy, bordering on overwhelming. Mind you, I am cognizant of the fact that the name itself implies a generous amount of cheese, yet there exists a delicate equilibrium that must be struck in order to achieve true gastronomic harmony. In contrast, my companion's rendition of the same dish, ordered on a separate occasion, was much more balanced in its composition. On a subsequent visit, I elected to sample the Veggie Rice Bowl, which, while flavorful, suffered from an unfortunate overcooking of the tofu. Furthermore, our order of the Vegan Spinach & Artichoke Dip proved underwhelming, prompting us to seek alternatives. My friend, however, found great pleasure in their salmon entree, while another acquaintance enjoyed both the Pollo Fresca and the Chicken Shawarma Wrap. During my third visit, I opted for the Veggie Bowl once again, omitting the tofu this time around, and found it significantly improved. The falafel fries, too, were quite satisfying, and the tiramisu, nothing short of extraordinary. It would be remiss of me not to mention the proprietor's exceptional people skills and innate ability to cater to his clientele, fostering a welcoming atmosphere that encourages return visits for those items that truly excel."

The place is fine, but a bit loud when crowded. Plenty of people with laptops and couples chatting away. The coffee was standard fare, as in sugary and tasty. The two things that I noticed are the number of tables made it feel crowded even when the number of people dwindled, and the bathroom was not the cleanest I have seen in other stores. Although not my favorite place, it's a good place to pop in or stay awhile, just a bit tight if at capacity. I would return.

I accompanied my mother to this establishment with the intention of procuring a takeout meal, as she has expressed a predilection for this particular venue. Despite possessing a preferred Chinese restaurant, I opted to acquiesce to her desire. Upon entering the premises, I observed that the ambiance was clean and well-maintained. However, I must admit that the visual representations of the culinary offerings were somewhat perplexing, as I was unable to accurately identify any of the dishes depicted.  

The quality of service was satisfactory, as the server was attentive and responsive to our needs. I requested a Sprite from the fountain beverage dispenser, but upon consuming it, I discovered that it did not conform to my expectations. I brought this to the attention of the counter attendant, who displayed an indifferent demeanor and failed to demonstrate any inclination towards investigating the issue. Subsequently, I sampled the lemonade, only to find that it consisted of nothing more than plain water. Furthermore, upon attempting to discard the liquid, I noticed minute particles floating within my cup. Disheartened by these experiences, I decided to forgo further exploration of the beverage options and instead focused on the food menu.  

It is worth mentioning that this establishment offers luncheon specials during the afternoon hours, which may potentially provide patrons with an economical dining alternative. Unfortunately, due to our late arrival, we were unable to sample these purportedly reasonably priced selections. My meal of choice was Udon soup, which, despite its flavorful nature, left me feeling somewhat uneasy due to my persistent concerns regarding the cleanliness of the food preparation area. As an advocate for supporting local enterprises, I acknowledge the importance of initial impressions and fear that this encounter may have compromised my future patronage.

As others have said it is a nice bowling alley.  We came around 5 on a Friday evening and the wait was an hour so that was a bummer.  We decided to wait and played in the arcade and it had nice equipment but was outrageously expensive.  If you don't mind spending a little money it isn't a bad place, but maybe next time we'll try stopping by at a less busy time.

"Opting to dine at this establishment for lunch with my infant in tow, due to an unrelenting craving for pasta and possession of a rewards card coupon, I arrived on a Friday afternoon, deliberately avoiding the peak lunchtime rush. Upon entry, I noticed the ambiance to be rather subdued, with an air of tranquility permeating the atmosphere. Seeking accommodations suitable for a patron accompanied by a stroller, I elected to situate myself in the bar area, whereupon I awaited the attention of a server. Following a brief interval of approximately five minutes, a staff member appeared to take my beverage order. In light of the delay, I chose to proceed with placing my order forthwith. My culinary selections were served in a timely manner, and their flavors proved to be quite satisfying. However, I must admit that I experienced some disappointment regarding the frequency of refreshment refills, as I received only one such refill during the course of my meal. Furthermore, I harbored an erroneous assumption regarding the role of the bartender/waitress, presuming them to be exclusively assigned to the bar area, thereby ensuring expedited service. This misconception notwithstanding, I would consider returning to this eatery during happy hour, as their promotions during this period appear to offer considerable value."

This place is very quirky and reminded of a place I would find in Los Angeles. The service was great and the menu diverse. Even though it's a raw, vegan restaurant, cooked food and meat were available. My only qualm was that everything was too salty, as though to compensate for lack of cooking. The desserts were delicious, although the crusts of the pies too salty. I think I drank six glasses of water, which was way too much.

My significant other and I had the pleasure of dining at this esteemed establishment approximately two months prior, and while the culinary experience was not without its shortcomings, specifically pertaining to an unfortunate mix-up in our order and that of another table, which, albeit understandable, proved somewhat vexing; the gastronomical offerings, upon closer inspection, revealed themselves to be of satisfactory quality, albeit lacking that certain je ne sais quoi that would have elevated them to the realm of true gustatory excellence. Notwithstanding, we are amenable to venturing forth and partaking in a renewed gastronomical exploration of the menu, with the aim of sample a diverse array of dishes and perhaps even indulging in a spot of avian observation, courtesy of the adjacent bird cages, which, might I add, possessed a certain unique charm.

Was mostly disappointed here.  Had heard good things, but the pizza was mostly uninspiring.  The crust was bland... and too dense/hard/chewy.  I appreciate light and airy crusts and that was what I was expecting, but really nothing like it came through.  The fig appetizer was delicious, but otherwise not really worth the $$ I spent.

"Johnny Rockets retains a unique significance in my personal chronicle of culinary experiences, as it evokes nostalgic memories of leisurely mall excursions with my companions during my secondary education tenure. However, this particular establishment failed to meet the expectations fostered by its predecessors, as it offered solely counter seating and conveyed an atmosphere of hastiness. Despite the efficient utilization of the limited space, I cannot help but feel a profound yearning for the comfort afforded by a spacious booth, the auditory delight of a personal jukebox, and the unparalleled pleasure of savoring a meticulously crafted milkshake. \n\nDuring our visit, we opted to sample their Big Apple shake and Dark Chocolate shake, yet our order was only partially fulfilled, as we received but a single shake. Following a prolonged struggle to capture the attention of the overburdened staff, we finally obtained the second shake, albeit with considerable delay. Although the beverages ultimately proved satisfying, the overall encounter fell short of our anticipated standards."

I stopped in here for lunch today, joined this time by friends Shelley M. & Arlin B.  Here's the long and short of it:

*  The food they serve here tastes great!  (That's one thing, isn't it?)

HOWEVER:

*  The first time I came it was freezing cold inside!

*  The second time I came it was roasting hot inside!

*  This time it was freezing cold inside!

*  The service wasn't as friendly this time as during my previous visits.

*  Our food all arrived on one tray, & it was up to us to try to figure out what was what.

*  They usually give each diner a little tray of cooked onions, peppers, plus lemon & lime slices, but this time we only received two of these trays for the three of us.     :-(

The temperature should be controlled better in here, & it's important for the counter & table service to remain friendly, as it was before!

My order this time was for...

Carne Asada (beef) Taco:  $1.25
Al Pastor (pork) Taco:  $1.25
Pescado (fish) Taco:  $2
Beef Tamale:  $2

I promise I am going to give this place another shot at providing a better experience.  I always want to write a great review of a place.  Their sushi was really good, although i took it to go, it might have been even better if i ate it there.

There seems to be a pretty good happy hour menu that is on my list of happy ours to try.

As I was waiting, I noticed the music was loud, so conversations might be a little hard to have here.  The prices are pretty much in line with other valley sushi restaurants.

So I hope to actually dine in and upgrade my review.

"A thirty-five minute wait is indicative of a culinary experience of considerable quality, and the complimentary coffee served outside during this interval serves as an additional testament to the establishment's commitment to providing an exceptional dining experience for its patrons. The interior design of the restaurant evokes the warmth and hospitality of a quaint southern cottage, which harmonizes seamlessly with the attentive and personable service provided by the staff, who operate under a unique system in which no server is assigned to a specific table, but rather collaborate to ensure that all guests receive equal attention and care. Upon arriving for breakfast, I was eager to sample the stuffed French toast, but being averse to peanut butter, I requested a modification to incorporate Nutella and bananas instead; much to my satisfaction, this request was accommodated without hesitation. However, upon the arrival of my meal, it became apparent that the Nutella utilized in the dish was not the rich, deep brown variety I had anticipated, but rather a lighter hue that suggested a blend with cream cheese; upon tasting it, my suspicions were confirmed, as the flavor profile was decidedly more cream cheese than Nutella, resulting in a sense of disappointment and underwhelment. In contrast, three out of five members of our party opted for the corned beef hash, which proved to be a superior choice, surpassing my own French toast experience in terms of both taste and satisfaction."

Sometimes when I'm at work and I get overloaded, I go into old-people f*#k mode, ie; any way to get the job done.

I suspect that's how the chef functions at AF when the place is packed to the gunwales because my herb roasted chicken sandwich, a long standing favorite of mine became my least favorite...all in the space of one visit.

I've rarely had a bad meal here, but Saturday, the place hosted every old woman's birthday, baby shower, and all-around chick event. I think the kitchen panicked and started throwing shit on plates like monkeys were ruling the kitchen.

Anyway, it wasn't good.
Come here when it's not so packed and you don't have to listen to the gay couple next to you bragging about their trip to Barbados and how they frolicked nude on the beach.
The image of swinging dicks combined with a bad sandwich was over the top.
Glad I have a Xanax prescription.

"Upon perusing the menu and partaking in a meal at this establishment, I must say that while the culinary offerings were satisfactory, they did not warrant such effusive praise.  The closing time of 7 pm on a Saturday evening was particularly vexing, as it precluded the possibility of enjoying a leisurely dining experience.  Furthermore, the portion size of the fried chicken was somewhat meager, despite its juiciness and adequate seasoning.  The macaroni and cheese, regrettably, appeared to be fabricated from a processed, liquid cheese substitute, rather than being prepared with the meticulous attention to detail that would have elevated it to truly delectable heights.  As a consequence, my patronage will likely be directed towards Honey Bears, where the craving for gluttonous indulgence can be satiated more effectively.  It is my conviction that Lolo's could benefit from soliciting external input regarding their cuisine and menu, in order to enhance their competitiveness within a market replete with superior quality establishments offering commensurate or superior service and ambiance."

"Starbucks has evolved into a veritable institution within the United States, and my personal experience with their offerings has been largely positive. As a discerning patron, I typically opt for a Venti Mocha, sans whipped cream, but on rare occasions, I may indulge in a Columbian Roast or a Frappuccino. While their breakfast sandwiches are not necessarily the epitome of culinary excellence, they do surpass those of their fast-food counterparts, McDonald's, in terms of flavor profile. The baked goods available at Starbucks are adequate, given their prepackaged nature, but fail to elicit the same level of enthusiasm as their specialty coffee drinks. Unfortunately, frequenting a Starbucks location often entails braving crowded environments, lengthy queues, and an uncomfortable chill in the air, which can be somewhat off-putting. Nonetheless, despite these drawbacks, my preference still lies with independently owned coffee houses or quaint, hidden gems, rather than this ubiquitous chain, which, by its very name, suggests a certain uniformity and predictability."

i was craving the frozen hot chocolate...it was monstrous! it was pretty good tho not quite how i remember it from new york...

we had ordered a bunch of other things like the nachos, a burger, the hotdog. everything was pretty good - but not sure if it is quite worth the hefty price tag for diner type food (ok, it's a bit fancier than diner food).
wish we had some room for dessert - we decided next time, to just go for dessert.

service was just okay. a bit slow and we needed to flag down our waiter a couple of times. they do take harris' comps - so that was a plus.

There are many bigger and better Harris Teeter locations in Charlotte, but if you live in Plaza Midwood or NoDa, this one is your best option. Unfortunately, the produce there isn't great. And the location is pretty small. It's packed and frustrating around 6 pm, when everyone is getting off work and stopping there to buy groceries. I will say, the VIC card rewards are pretty good. You get good deals, and I got free luggage once through the program.

This spot is great had a little trouble checking in as the system went down right when we got there, the free breakfast from 6-9am made up for the lost time will be checking out all the other spots that offer free breakfast for now on now that i know they exsist

There's no doubt that XS is a beautiful club.  But, I really didn't have much of a great time here considering it's suppose to be one the best in Sin City. Maybe, it was the music.  Which was more Techno than Hip Hop.  Or maybe it was the crowd, which I wasn't feeling.  There were some nice ones out of the bunch, but most of them were stuck-up. Although, I have to give it up to security though, because they sure did a good job at making that line move.  I was kinda feelin' bad for the guys during Memorial Day Weekend though.  The cover charge to get in for a guy at XS was $100 and later on that night it jumped to $200 just to get in!  

Ridiculously XS-cessive indeed!

But honestly didn't think it was quite worth all the hype.

"The proficiency exhibited by the waiting staff was indeed commendable, as they demonstrated a profound ability to attend to our needs with alacrity and cordiality, thereby enhancing the overall dining experience. However, it was rather unfortunate that the manager did not display a similar level of competence, as their lack of proactive communication and problem-solving skills resulted in an unacceptable delay in the food preparation process. Specifically, the presence of a large party that preceded ours and subsequently monopolized the kitchen's resources for an extended period of time did not warrant a visit from the manager to our table, neither did it elicit any conciliatory measures on their part to mitigate the inconvenience caused. Moreover, the manager's absence during the climax of our meal, when confusion reigned supreme, only served to exacerbate the already tense situation."
Lee's sandwiches are lee's sandwiches iam just excited I don't have to drive all the way to China Town to get my Viet Sandwich fix...Yay!!!
Cafe has new owners that are very nice as well as the staff.  We ordered burgers, fries, salads, and grilled ham and cheese sandwich.  All were delicious!

"The Sunflower store has undergone a transformation following its acquisition by Sprouts, and unfortunately, the changes implemented do not appear to be an improvement. Although this location still offers a limited array of Boar's Head Deli Meats and a few varieties of cheese, the meat and seafood counter has been reduced in size and is now manned by friendly personnel. The majority of the store's floor space is dedicated to showcasing an extensive selection of fresh produce; however, the prices, while not exorbitant, are comparable to or lower than those at Whole Foods. 

It is worth noting that since Sprouts took over, the quality and variety of their supplement selection have diminished. For instance, previously, there were five distinct options for Kava Kava capsules available, but upon my most recent visit, only two remained, and the brands they carried were not ones I would consider purchasing. While this location may serve as a suitable starting point for individuals seeking basic supplements, seasoned supplement users may find the selection to be somewhat disappointing. 

Despite my desire to endorse this store, three stars remain the highest rating I can bestow upon it."

Meh..not particularly memorable.
I've eaten at this location and the one by ASU, though I like this location better. I would probably only eat here if I was walking by and I was starving. 
The cookies ROCK though, I like that you get one with your sandwich. And they have my favorite flavor of Jones Soda (Sugar-free Black Cherry) which kicked ass. 

Warning: The roast beef sandwich (Overture?) comes with horseradish sauce and it is hot as a mother.  I like the spice but it was almost unbearable. My nose pretty much turned into a snotty waterfall. 

Go to Opa Grill next door instead.

Interesting restaurant.  Limited menu.  I assume the menu will grow as this place finds its way.  We had the cheese plate(ok), beets(very good), mussels(very good), iceberg sald(big and good).  Pretty good beer selection.  The music was defintely off.  I am sure this will change as well.  The brunch menu looked very good.  \n\nI'll go back sometime to see what changes have been made.

Last Monday, we visited this establishment for breakfast, and due to its immense popularity, we were forced to endure an approximate waiting period of 20 minutes before being accommodated. Unfortunately, this delay was reflected in the culinary offerings, as they appeared to have been hastily prepared. I opted for the pancake combination, but unfortunately, the turkey bacon was excessively salted, and the pancakes lacked the customary fluffiness, leading my dining companions and myself to conclude that the fare was unremarkable. Consequently, this experience differed significantly from the exceptional dining encounter I have grown accustomed to at the IHOP in Torrance.

"An exceedingly tranquil and understatedly fashionable district, characterized by an unpretentious ambiance that exudes a sense of relaxed refinement. Strategically positioned in close proximity to a stylish hair salon, providing patrons with the opportunity to indulge in a pampering session, followed by a leisurely sojourn on a comfortable bench situated in front of a picturesque window. The overall experience is reminiscent of the carefree and laid-back atmosphere synonymous with San Diego, California."

Food quality disappointing. Not the best steak in Vegas.

Three of us enjoyed two ribeyes ($52) and one filet ($46). Waiter told us their ribeye is the best steak in Vegas, but don't believe it. They were cooked correctly. The rub was rather bland and the crusting on the filet was hard. On a scale of one to ten, my ribeye overall was a 7. I've had 10's before in Vegas, so the competition is tough! But just claiming you have the best steak doesn't make it so.

The sides ($9 each) were disappointing. We ordered four. Creamed spinach, always a favorite of mine and recommended by the waiter, was just odd and bland - didn't taste interesting or flavorful at all. The best side was the asparagus, but honestly, how hard is it to steam asparagus?

Desert, as it often is at these kind of places where desert is an afterthought, was disappointing and ended the overall experience on a "blah" note.

Wine list was excellent.

With so many great places in Vegas, you can do much better. Everything else was top notch, but the food is the core of the experience and Delmonicos is just average, unfortunately.

I've had this place on my radar for awhile now, having checked out their menu online, I was wanting to try the pear omelet.  A friend and I stopped in after the National Kidney Foundation Walk and I expected for a late Saturday morning to find a line and a long wait.  I was surprised when we were seated immediately.  The atmosphere was like being in someone's home, very homey and comfortable.  I must say though, I was a little grossed out by the thick gray carpeting, it just looked dirty and and didn't feel very sanitary to me.

My friend and I both ordered the pear omelet and it was good, not great.  Needed more pears in it if you're going to name the dish after them.  We noticed what others were eating and I must say I'd probably come back to try the fantastic looking french toast!  

All in all I thought our experience was just average, nothing really stood out as being all that good or bad.

Good bang for the buck buffet.. It's been awhile since I've been here, but I go for dinner. They had hand scooped ice cream.  It is cheap.\n\nThe meats were decent.  Not 5 star quality.. but it isn't bad. You just need to find something you like.

Mediocre galettes and that was a really disappointing thing during my recent trip to Montreal.

I told that to my Montrealer friend who said, "told you so". 

That being said, their desserts and coffee choices were fantastic. Anything with chocolate, Juliette et Chocolat does okay. Just don't rely on their dinner menu!

This is small quaint place that sells pizza by the slice or the whole pie if you wish. 

This is a 1000 times better than Sabarro's but nothing to write home about either.  If you want something quick and cheap, this is a great place. 

If you are waiting for someone to arrive at the airport this is also a great pit stop.

"Our visits to this establishment during the happy hour timeframe have been characterized by an appreciation for the delectable Tuscan Taster appetizers, specifically the spicy shrimp and eggplant, which exhibit variations in both flavor and preparation methods, ranging from crispy to oily. The burger, a staple menu item, consistently satisfies our culinary desires. However, we lament the lack of health-conscious appetizer options. It is imperative to limit our beverage selections to happy hour specials, as the prices for non-promotional drinks tend to escalate rapidly. At the San Tan location, we have encountered a blonde bar manager whose efficiency is commendable, yet her demeanor exudes an air of sternness and brusqueness. Despite these observations, we generally depart from the premises feeling content, albeit not particularly enthused."
Wow. Can't believe this location is closed. I was not aware that it had and tried to stop by to grab some lunch to take back to the office. What a disappointment.

"Although my dining experience was generally satisfactory, I must express my reservations regarding the pricing policy implemented by this establishment. Specifically, the cost of the menu items appears to be disproportionate to the portion sizes, with the smallest sandwich and two accompanying sides amounting to a total of $11, an exorbitant sum that may deter potential patrons, particularly those with families to support. Furthermore, the additional fee of $1.99 for each drink, albeit a nominal amount, contributes to an overall sense of dissatisfaction with the value received for the price paid. In light of these concerns, it is suggested that management consider adopting a buffet-style format or increasing the quantity of food provided to justify the cost. Notwithstanding the aforementioned criticisms, the culinary quality of the dishes served did meet my expectations."

The food is good....selection is ok.  The service is good. It is WAY loud ALL of the time.  I understand that it is more of a sprots bar kinda feel but not being able to hear the waitress was a little frustrating/\nWe will go back I am sure of it.

I haven't stayed here but I've been inside. Hotel looks really nice. Nice lobby and very well decorated. Its located at a descent location on the Strip. However, their casino isn't the best. If you are a gambler, might wanna hit up some other casinos.

"An ostensibly salubrious edifice, however, my companions' culinary selections arrived precipitously prior to mine, despite my having placed my order simultaneously with theirs, which led to a considerable delay in satiating my esurient inclinations. Furthermore, I was perplexed by the restaurant's interpretation of'spicy mayo,' which consisted merely of a combination of mayonnaise and sriracha, an unorthodox approach considering the customary manner in which this condiment is prepared; additionally, the 'eel sauce' was mediocre, yet the 'rainbow roll' and 'eel roll' exhibited commendable gastronomical quality, as did my associates' choices â?an 'arizona roll,' a 'crunch roll,' and a 'california shrimp tempura roll.' Notwithstanding, my penchant for sauces remained unsatisfied, as the establishment seemed to be deficient in this particular aspect."

My sister and I headed over here last week and I have to say, I was a little mixed about our visit.

When we first walked in, there was no one there. Literally. We were eye'ing the ice creams for almost 5 minutes before the server drifted in from the Z Pizza side.

I had the Pink Spot sundae with two ginormous scoops of kona coffee and hot fudge. The ice cream was meh, but the hot fudge was very good and served in generous portion. My sister had the low-fat coffee with ribbons of chocolate and she raved.

The prices weren't outrageous considering the serving size; just one week before I spent three dollars more for the same exact thing at Mary Coyle's.

I wasn't overly impressed with the ice cream, but they get props for always having at least one low fat, sugar free, or sorbet offering.

It probably wouldn't be my first choice for ice cream, but because they are in the neighborhood they get a gold star for convenience!

It required a considerable amount of time for me to deliberate on whether to confer 2 or 3 stars upon Diablo's. Ultimately, I opted for the latter rating, as most establishments of a similar caliber in Las Vegas tend to be quite pricey, and Diablo's offered delectable cuisine in generous portions. However, the service we received was utterly reprehensibleâthe epitome of poor hospitality. Our server, during her brief appearances, exhibited blatant rudeness, seemingly intentionally. She displayed exasperation with my companion simply because they requested fresh cheese on their nachos instead of both fresh and processed cheese. The waitress heaved a heavy sigh and responded in an annoyed tone, âItâs NOT going to taste the same,â?while rolling her eyes. Additionally, she grumbled, âWell, what do you want?â?when taking our order, without so much as a greeting or acknowledging our presence. The entire dining experience was plagued by an array of unacceptable delays; our orders were not taken for at least 30 minutes, despite the restaurant being relatively unoccupied. Furthermore, it took over 90 minutes for our meals to arrive, followed by another 30 minutes to receive the check. A planned quick meal for five individuals turned into an excruciating, three-hour ordeal. One star for the abysmal service; five stars for the scrumptious food; and 2.5 stars for the questionable value.

I've been to The Joint 3 times--once in the old Joint and twice in the newer, enlarged Joint.

For the current Joint, the flow of people in and out was well designed but I wonder why they didn't install a reversible escalator so part of the crown could go downstairs that way and the rest by stairs.

For this concert of KISS, I got balcony seating.  I liked it better than floor seating because I found the floor seating to be very tightly packed next to each other.  The balcony on the other hand had theatre style seats that were comfortable.

The sound and lighting in the Joint are exceptional.  Needless to say, KISS had a lot of pyro effects and the lighting was great.  It would be nice if they could have raised the catwalk.  It was in the way for some of the stage viewing.

There aren't too many shows that I would go here to see but if I went again, I'd try to get a table seat on the side balconies.

As a tip, park in the Paradise garage for easy access to the Joint.

"Neglect the gaming establishment where your financial resources incur significant damage; instead, focus on the venue where your physical form endures substantial discomfort. However, prior to casting blame, direct your gaze towards the reflective surface in front of you, for it is there that you will find the root cause of your current predicament. Indulge in an array of delectable dishes, including leg of lamb, prime rib, wild boar, kalbi ribs, spicy shrimp, macaroni and cheese, gnocchi, assorted cheeses, salads, artisanal breads, and an abundance of other culinary delights that are too numerous to list. Furthermore, be cognizant of the fact that your consumption habits are under constant surveillance by an unseen observer, who is undoubtedly monitoring your every move with great interest. Consequently, it would be wise to pace oneself with a sense of decorum and moderation."

This place had its ups and downs. The atmosphere is lovely , very old school great for a date at night. The food is ok depending on what you get, kinda pricey. And nothing outstanding for the price either. Portions I think are big or at least enough to share.\n The main thing with this place is the service, I wanted to give 2 1/2 stars. The service is just slow, inconsistent and dreadful. By the time we got our food we didn't care and just wanted to leave. A formal complaint was actually made at the end.\n Save this place to try on a busy date night when they got something going on and it might be worth it. I don't suggest coming here for a quick lunch or entirely for food itself. It has location, a vtg vegas feel atmosphere and I don't drink but it also has booze too. However just for the food and the service alone would not be worth the trip.

"Adequate bubble tea, but an unpleasant experience due to the brusque demeanor of the staff member who attended to me. Upon inquiring about the types of jelly available, as none were explicitly listed on the menu or display case, I received a discourteous and exasperated response from the woman behind the counter. Her tone was tinged with irritation, as she retorted, 'What type are you looking for?' in a manner that conveyed her discontent at having to address my query. Perplexed by her reaction, I opted for a ginger milk tea complemented by lychee jelly, which proved to be merely satisfactory, lacking the intensity of ginger flavor that I had anticipated, while also exhibiting an excessive sweetness. Furthermore, the ambient temperature within the establishment was uncomfortably warm, compelling me to suggest that they activate their air conditioning system to create a more pleasant environment for both staff and patrons. This unfortunate encounter left me feeling dissatisfied and reluctant to revisit the establishment in the future."

"Procured two chocolate croissants and a single miniature cake, yet was confronted with an unfortunate dearth of chocolate within said pastries, the paltry quantity of which failed to satiate my craving for a rich, velvety chocolate experience, thereby necessitating the expenditure of an additional 2-3 dollars for a croissant of sufficient chocolaty flavor."

Mr. Lucky's does not possess any extraordinary attributes or distinguishing features, with the exception of their covertly offered $7.77 Special, which comprises a triumvirate of savory elements, including a fresh garden salad, succulent steak, and delectable shrimp, all served in conjunction with a generous portion of creamy mashed potatoes, thereby providing a gratifying dining experience at an eminently reasonable cost, particularly when compared to the prices charged by neighboring establishments, and furthermore, its accessibility is augmented by the fact that it remains open on a continuous basis, twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week, rendering it an ideal refuge for those seeking a satisfying repast during the late hours of the night or early morning, when the majority of other eateries have ceased operation. The rationale behind patronizing Mr. Lucky's resides primarily in the aforementioned $7.77 Special, as evidenced by the preponderance of positive testimonials from contented clientele who have availed themselves of this culinary gem.

Thai Basil is alright, not great but alright. I ordered the Pad-see-ew and the weirdest thing is that the noodles were tasty and delicious but all the veggies and chicken were pretty well tasteless. Plus, my medium to hot dish was much more mild to no spice. 

However, my iced Thai coffee was delicious and the service was very friendly, they even went to find me when I stepped out to Tops while waiting. Also, the the prices are very reasonable, my whole meal was less than 10 bucks.

So, ok for now, I'll try some more dishes and hopefully be more excited.
Just passed by this DD the other week, and sad to see it is now CLOSED.  Blame the economy I suppose.

One word: waterfall.
It makes Tryst amazing... especially in the midst of the swarm of drunkards. There was NO WAY anyone could move around.

My girls and I got invited to a table with bottle service, stayed for a few drinks, then wanted to split... and in turn the guy whose table it was STOLE our purses because we didn't want to stay! We spent the better part of an hour trying to track them down, and eventually a guard gave them back to us.
After asking where they were, he simply stated, "Just be happy you have them back." THEN, one of the guys at the table "coincidentally" had my friend's camera in his pocket.
NOT COOL.

I know this isn't the club's fault, but right after this incident happened my friends and I wanted to get the fuck out of there.

On the other hand, the benefits were that we got right into the clubs, got some of our guy friends in with no charge (rare in Vegas), had fun on the pole and on top of tables, and the outside area with the waterfall was breathtaking.

It's a bit more expensive than some other competing Chinese buffets, but still a hella lot cheaper than anything I can get in New York, so I have no issues.  There's a decent selection and they at least have some sushi and korean food options.  I also like that they have a station to make your own soup with whatever you want in it.  Other than that, everything else is run-of-the-mill chinese food.  I wish they would turn over the fish dishes a little more often so they wouldn't be so overcooked, but it's still edible.
