I could tell that they were itching for me and my family to hurry up so they could turn the table over, but I didn't see anyone waiting and there were plenty of other open tables, so I didn't mind taking my time to get my money's worth.

I'd go back if I had to, but wouldn't necessarily go out of my way.

I've been here for the weekend brunch on a few occasions, and for the price, really can't be beat. If you are a local take advantage of a super cheap meal on Mondays and Wednesdays: $3.99 for breakfast, $4.99 for lunch, and $6.99 for dinner. All you have to do is show your Hilton rewards card and local id. 
 
The weekend brunch has crab legs, prime rib, and beer/wine or some days champagne for either the weekend brunch or dinner. There is all the classic breakfast items already made and then a made-to-order omelet station along with grilled meats and sausages. All pretty much traditional buffet food, nothing fancy or ethnic, but solid. 
 
18 bucks for prime rib, cocktail shrimp, and crab legs is a deal...take advantage of it if you are looking for a decent weekend brunch buffet but can't pay for one at the Wynn or Bellagio. Service might not be 100 percent, but come on it's a friggin buffet.

"Reminiscent of a familial Italian eatery, albeit with an excessive luminosity within its interior spaces. Gastronomical offerings are satisfactory, yet unremarkable in terms of quality, garnering a middling rating of six on a scale of one to ten. Service, while adequate, does not particularly distinguish itself. A quaint establishment with a quasi-authentic ambiance that beckons patrons to partake in a personal experience, thereby comprehending my enigmatic description."

"Although I am not one to be overly enthusiastic about culinary establishments that specialize in porcine delicacies, my spouse and I decided to partake in a gastronomic excursion to Salty Sow, primarily due to my innate curiosity regarding their unconventional preparation methods. Unfortunately, our dining experience proved to be somewhat underwhelming, as the dishes we ordered failed to meet our expectations. Specifically, I opted for the candied pork belly, anticipating a crunchy texture; however, it was cooked via braising, which rendered it rather unremarkable. My companion's lamb burger, while flavorful, featured an abundance of tapenade that did not particularly appeal to my palate. Furthermore, a considerable delay occurred between our request for the bill and its eventual arrival, which contained errors. In conclusion, our visit to Salty Sow was merely passable."

"Although we conceded that the noodles were somewhat overcooked, it was our expectation that the vegetables would be fresher, rather than frozen, which unfortunately did not align with our preferences. Notwithstanding, it remains worthy of an attempt, yet it fell short of our anticipated standards, particularly when juxtaposed with other build-your-own wok houses we have visited in various locales."

I have had the privilege of firing an assortment of firearms (for further information, please visit http://www.yelp.com/biz/bullseye-precision-indoor-shooting-range-san-rafael), which includes the Uzi, Thompson, and two other automatic weapons, as well as a desert eagle handgun. Additionally, I had the opportunity to discharge a grenade launcher, albeit with a shotgun shell rather than an actual grenade, at a cost of $35 per round. It is worth mentioning that the weapons appeared somewhat worn out, and the ear protection provided by the establishment was inadequate, causing discomfort to my auditory senses throughout the duration of my visit. Notwithstanding, I would suggest this venue as a suitable destination for a group of individuals seeking a diversion from the typical gambling activities, and perhaps even consider renting a limousine for transportation purposes, as securing a taxi back to one's lodgings may prove challenging.

The hubbie's sister and her husband were in town and wanted to try RigaTony's since they have a friend who is a Snowbird and likes the place.  We had not eaten there in a while.  

We've been eating at Olive Garden a lot, mostly because I get $25 gift cards thru work. Having gone to RigaTony's, it will definitely be the go to place when we are dining solely on our dime and want a nice dinner and salad. It is well worth the slightly higher cost per menu item.

I got the chicken with lemon and artichoke...yum.  I love their house salad.  One of my bunco buddies always gets that salad when it's her turn to host.  Hubbie liked the bread (and the salad).  The hubbie got the lasagna and enjoyed it...until later in the evening when he had some major acid reflux.  Getting older sucks.   Stubborn cuss won't try my crystalized ginger remedy...I haven't had a Tums in a looooonnnnng time.

We topped the evening off w/ a trip to Angel Sweet.  Yum.

This establishment appears to be exhibiting evident signs of wear and tear. Upon visiting this venue to observe the cinematic experience known as Avatar in their Imax theatre, I noticed that the seating was somewhat dilapidated and showed visible indications of prolonged usage. Furthermore, the film itself encountered an unexpected interruption during its initiation, owing to unforeseen technical obstacles. Consequently, a considerable amount of time, approximately 10-15 minutes, elapsed before the issue could be rectified and the motion picture resumed. Notwithstanding, I must admit that the culinary offerings at this cinema, specifically their hot dog and nachos, are relatively palatable in comparison to other establishments of a similar nature.

The sushi was surprisingly really good, but the rest of the food was mediocre. The place was clean and service was decent. It's no five star buffet, but my experience was much nicer than the previous reviewers. I would recommend for large parties as there are many options, especially for kids.

"The visual spectacle was captivating, as the female performers exhibited their proficiency in dance, but it appeared that the screenwriters had indulged in some form of substance when conceptualizing the narrative, while Mickey, among the actors, was the most entertaining."

So-so Mexican food.  I have heard people raving about this place and I don't really get it.  Don't get me wrong, it's better than Manuel's or Filiberto's... but that's about all I can say.

Okay, their Pollo Fundido is good (but not great like you will get at Ajo Al's). But let's talk about the purple and teal accent colors that scream "I was remodeled in the 80's"! Lame.

Good chips and salsa but small-ass bowls! 

Oh, and don't expect to park in their little lot during dinner rush.  Also, the surrounding neighborhood is definatly the ghetto-side of the Moon Valley area.

So I recently went here with a friend of mine because they were craving IHOP, and I didn't care were we went to eat as long is it had food.

I got one of there new healthy choice menu items the balsamic chicken and my friend got the club sandwich with a side salad and a side of pancakes...don't ask.

The food was surprisingly really good and the service was excellent.

Some people will be upset with this review, but when we are asked to write a review, Yelp wants us to be honest right? 
Finally tried out Hash House a go go for lunch yesterday. Had read great reviews and many a celebrity have endorsed it. 
The interior is great and the service is pretty good too. That is why I gave Hash 3 stars, but the food did not appeal that much to me and I consider it forgetable.
I tried the mushroom and goat cheese sandwich and have no complaints about my dish, The potatoes au gratin looked very cheesy, but tasted good as the cheese wasn't not all overpowering as I had expected. My wife tried the chicken and waffles and we both agreed: nothing special! The all white meat chicken and waffles were both too dry and bland and we prefer Roscoe's for sure.  
For the average 'white' person, this food probably tastes great, the presentation looked above par, but for those among us who consider themselves foodies, the wide gamut of Asian food offered in this city is soo much more appealing. And finally their lunch prices are a little high at $38 for two. Again, this is just my honest opinion.

My uncle owns a pretty famous bbq restaurant in Memphis, TN. So I am always a bbq sceptic and tough critic. I have only tried the pulled pork sandwich and the bbq chicken breast sandwich. Both really good. All the way down to the bun it comes on....tasty and not too thick. The potato salad is good, except I did miss the chopped egg. A few customers walked by me w/ amazing looking deserts that made my mouth water. The true test of great bbq is the ribs. Next time I shall try them and update....\".y'all come back now, ya hear?\"
This is a great, quality Taco Bell recently built with fast service and consistant food. I love Taco Bell because it's cheap and yummy!

Really great atmosphere, wines, etc... but I didn't think the food was very good, so I give it only 3 stars.  The bread is very thick and maybe uncooked, no oil.  It was not what I expected.  I was hoping for crunchy bread with creatively delicious toppings.  The toppings are great combinations, just not executed like I expected.  I thought the bruschetta would be warm, but instead it was cold, nothing melded, and the bread was very large.  Great concept, but I don't get all the great reviews.

"Fundamental victuals, devoid of any extraordinary attributes, yet still managed to tantalize our taste buds with their inherent flavors. A concise culinary catalog, featuring a roster of familiar favorites, albeit lacking in diversity, particularly in regards to the vinous offerings, which failed to include such esteemed Italian varietals as Montepulciano or other customary options. Instead, an assortment of ubiquitous, entry-level vintages were presented, rendering the overall experience somewhat predictable, yet surprisingly satisfying, given its proximity to a well-known thrift store."

This only gets three stars cause the food is amazing! Other then great tasting food, place is very confusing. When you walk in there is a line that no one has any idea what line they are in. The first two are for tacos, but if you want a burrito or fish tacos you have to go to another line.  They tell you to go there but then you pass 10 people and I feel like I'm cutting everyone in line.

Everyone stood and looked at each and was  like what line are we in? Once you get to that line your suppose to be in, they don't speak English.  I ordered a carne asade burrito, and they tried to give it to someone else. I told them that's mine and he said ohhhh, and had to open it, but looked at me weird cause he did not speak English!

I would give them a 1 star but the food is amazing! Great prices too! Just really confusing.  We also came on a Tuesday night and damn if there wasent 50 kids running around up and down making a ton of noise!

If you read all my Yelp reviews so far, you will find that the majority of them cover barbecue joints. Yes, we like barbecue. My wife and I each have a sibling living in Austin, Texas, so we think we know the real deal when we taste it. Dickey's isn't quite that, but it's a nice addition to the Madison 'cue scene and I hope it's here to stay. 

The meats have a good smoke flavor and they're tender, if sometimes overcooked. But that's to be expected in a fast-food/fast-casual place where I'm not sure the meats are smoked in-house daily. They might be smoked elsewhere and delivered, but for the price, that's OK. The ribs and brisket are worth ordering. The chicken is a grilled breast you can get anywhere.

The sauces (original, spicy), are served hot, just like in Texas, and they're of that thinner, Texas consistency. I like them. The option to top your meal with jalapenos and onions is also very Texas-like, but the smoked sausage isn't. The slaw and potato salad are decent sides; the others are unremarkable. 

Dickey's offers free soft-serve ice cream where the most clever among us can make a root beer float in our big yellow drink cups. Kids eat free on Sundays with each adult meal purchased. We are always satisfied when we leave. What more can you expect for under $20?

We have been patronizing the Dragon Noodle for an extensive period of time, and our experiences have been rather inconsistent. While the culinary offerings are generally satisfactory, the prices are somewhat elevated and the service is merely adequate. In concurrence with certain fellow Yelpers, we have found that the ambiance in the rear section of the establishment tends to be somewhat melancholy. Prior to the renovation, the atmosphere was more convivial, with kitschy embellishments and souvenir t-shirts available for purchase. 
  Following a prolonged day at a trade exhibition, we seek to unwind and avoid venturing excessively far from our lodgings. The Dragon Noodle is rarely crowded, thereby enabling us to secure a table for any size gathering with minimal difficulty. 
  Our preferences lean towards the Chinese menu, as the sushi options appear overly pricey and our previous experiences with them have been underwhelming. Specifically, we enjoy the Kung Pao Chicken, Mongolian Beef, and Wonton Soup. During a recent visit by a group of six, the total cost was approximately $140.

"During my most recent sojourn to Las Vegas, I partook of a culinary excursion at this esteemed establishment, indulging in a delectable assortment of Kobe beef sliders, which, while palatable, did not quite justify the rather exorbitant price point of $13, in my humble opinion. Furthermore, my companion nearly experienced an adverse gastronomical reaction due to the richness of the dish. However, the Shichimi fries proved to be a satisfying accompaniment, boasting a delightful balance of flavors and a pleasant level of piquancy. Additionally, the Yukon Gold mashers were cooked to perfection, contributing further to an overall gratifying dining experience. The mixologists at this venue also demonstrated proficiency in crafting well-balanced cocktails, which served as a fitting complement to the meal. All things considered, I might consider returning to this eatery on a future visit to Las Vegas, provided that my stomach grumbles and I find myself in close proximity."

Came here for a networking event a couple weeks ago. They had some apps out to try and my friend ordered the quesadilla that was on happy hour. Nothing remarkable about this place food wise. I ordered a moscow mule and it was good.

We were outside on the patio which is super cute. Definitely a great place to have some wine and sit outside and enjoy the perfect weather. 

I need to try the main dishes because I wasn't that impressed with the food we had. We tried their chicken wings, ahi avocado salad of some sort, flatbread and parmesan, and then my frriend's quesadilla. It wasn't that the food was bad, it's just not something that I'm ever gonna think about and be like "hey, remember xyz at Kitchen 56?". 

Worth a shot to try but it's just whatever.

"It is not advisable to harbor lofty expectations regarding establishments serving culinary delights along the primary thoroughfare catering to visitors, as these eateries tend to exhibit elevated pricing and subpar hospitality, though this may merely be a personal observation. We initiated our gastronomic excursion by sampling an assortment of artisanal cheeses, featuring four regional varieties whose appellations escape my memory, with the exception of the ubiquitous brie, and I must confess that I derived considerable pleasure from the unfamiliar specimens, particularly the tangy goat cheese iteration. Our party opted for a diverse array of principal courses, including pasta Arrabbiata, which I inexplicably selected, and it conformed to my expectations of mediocrity. The remaining members of our group chose mussels and a quarter chicken, respectively, and while the portion sizes were satisfactory, the fare itself proved unremarkable."

I am a hertz gold member so i always go straight to the gold check in area. This location is hit or miss. Sometimes they are very good and the car i have requested is ready to go and easy to pick up and go. Other times they have given me cars that either had too much mileage, one time a car that looked like it had been driven thru rocks, another a car with stickers on it. Also, they are sticklers about the gas tank being full. Due to this fact i always fill right by the airport now. Always check to make sure the car they give you is acceptable and dont be afraid to ask for another one if there is a problem. And check the tire tread. Otherwise the gold service is useful especially when the regular counter line is long.

Today, I was rushing from one place to another and needed some fast food.  Not feeling like a burger, I thought that Panda Express sounded convenient.  I was not disappointed though at the same time, the meal was not a gourmet one either.  There was only one person working the register while at the same time serving food so there was a bit of a wait (and the staff member was a bit flustered with much going on at once).  I am guessing that another staff member was on a break as there was a second person there by the time I left.  The restaurant was also kept quite clean though it appeared that the forks and napkins needed some restocking.  \n\nThe food, however, was fresh and as tasty as I had hoped it would be.  I got a two-item combo with fried rice, beef & broccoli, and string bean chicken.  I also added on a chicken egg roll.  The restaurant had several families, a few people on their own, and a couple all also eating, and it appeared that everyone else was also pleased with their meals.

Sep 25 2011 2:10 pm

1 item lunch combo -$5.50
Comes with soup, entree, appetizer 

Red curry- 3/5 little too oily for a Thai dish
Garlic and pepper stir fry -3.5/5

2 Thai iced tea- 4.5/5

Customer service- 4.5/5

Stopped in here for lunch today, joined by Arlin B, Robyn N & Mike C.  Scott's was a bit of a disappointment for me this time.  My expensive bowl of Kreplach Soup was lukewarm & only contained one little Kreplach the size of a Ping Pong ball!  Even the smaller cup sized soup should have two or three of them.  My corned beef sandwich was good but the service was only so-so.  Considering all of this and the prices, it's down to 3 Stars this time for Scott's.\n\nCorned Beef Sandwich $10.95, bowl of Kreplach Soup $7.95 (!)

I was drove past there this weekend, and then read yesterday on azcentral.com that they have closed their doors.  I had never dined there but the building & decor looks awesome, huge outdoor patio with a glass enclosed fireplace, guess it's just another sign of the struggling economy....

"Perhaps it was the prolonged duration of my journey that induced a state of bewilderment, rendering me incapable of navigating the labyrinthine corridors of the terminal, thereby necessitating a circuitous route to the exit; however, upon encountering the high-velocity tram, I experienced a momentary cognitive dissonance that hindered my ability to comprehend its functionality, leading me to erroneously assume that it would impede my progress. Despite this minor setback, I must commend the airport staff for their cordial demeanor and the meticulous upkeep of the facilities. While it may not boast the same level of grandeur as Portland International Airport, it remains a serviceable and efficient transportation hub."

My coworker recommended this place so I decided to give it a try. I had the Gyro lunch with fries. It was pretty good, nothing outrageous and I've definitely had better but given the area and it's limited lunch options I can see myself coming back here in the future.\n\nThe restaurant was small and service was friendly. The \"bar\" was awkward; looked like it didn't really belong but I guess it's always great to have the option of enjoying a drink with your meal. I guess I see this more of a quick service dine and dash kind of joint, that's why.

I'm reviewing my rating. After Mor telling me i had to wait for them to come inspect the table (i'm moving dont have time for this) and i left my review, i ended up getting a call the next day from a manager & they actually delivered a brand new table, said the old one turned out to be from a bad batch- 

So overall i'm NOW happy with the customer service- and i'll take their word that it was a bad batch and not bad quality overall.



Old Review: Bought a dinning room granite countertop table from here, within 6 months the legs are cracking, the marble actually stains real easy from heat. Absolute garbage, $800 wasted

"I requested a spider roll, a lobster roll, and Uni, and upon consuming these delectable dishes, I discovered that the rolls possessed an exquisite flavor, particularly the spider roll, which featured a soft crab that was both fresh and crispy due to the expertise of the culinary artist who prepared it; however, my experience with Uni was somewhat different, as its taste was reminiscent of fish, lacking the expected freshness, leading me to surmise that it may be wise to inquire about the quality of this particular dish before placing an order, thereby ensuring a satisfying culinary experience."

It wasn't horrible. The girl seemed like she couldn't be bothered and wanted to be else were. The guy was trying to be impressive with all his different topics. He was be over bearing and ignoying  to me. I wasn't  impressed by his conversations.\n\nThey job they did was standard.

"Although I harbor a certain skepticism towards public car washes as a whole, my recent visit to Classic Car Spa proved to be a refreshing exception to this rule. Not only were there an absence of streaks or droplets on my windows, but also the meticulous attention devoted to buffing the rims of my BMW left me feeling truly satisfied. Opting for the comprehensive package, which encompassed a thorough cleaning of both the vehicle's exterior and interior, I was impressed by the staff's fastidiousness. It is worth mentioning that my modest Z4 happened to be the most economical automobile in the queue, surrounded by an array of luxury SUVs, a Porsche Panamera, and even a Maserati. Such an assemblage of high-end vehicles served as a poignant reminder that, were I able to afford the latter, I likely would have had the means to engage the services of a professional detailer to come to my residence and pamper my car for me."

I am originally from New York City, where the Chinese cuisine is of superior quality and reigns supreme, and when I relocated to this region, it was a challenge to discover anything that could compare to the exceptional culinary standards that I had become accustomed to in the city that never sleeps. While China Red cannot be considered an exact replica of the remarkable Chinese restaurants found in the Big Apple, it undoubtedly comes close to satisfying my cravings for delicious and authentic Sino-American dishes. The generous portions, rich flavors, and delectable egg drop soup are all factors that contribute to making this establishment a top choice among local diners seeking a taste of the Far East. Furthermore, China Red offers reasonable lunch specials, which provide customers with an unbeatable value of two meals' worth of food for approximately six dollars. Additionally, the restaurant provides delivery services, a convenience that is uncommon in the Arizona area, thereby making it a standout among its competitors.

We went this past Sun and overall had a great time. My only issue, and why I'm on Yelp, is the food. Just horrible and way, way, way overpriced.
I would suggest spend the extra $10 for preferred parking and bring a cooler. Don't buy any food in the park. Out of desperation my sons a I had 2 slices with 2 breadsticks. Survey says-I've had MREs that tasted better.
                              Oh yeah, $14 by the way.
Preferred parking is only $10. Bring your own chow and have a great time.

"SSSSSsssssshhhhhhhhhhh.............. DON'T TELL ANYONE. I have an affinity for Hooters. 

Consequently, allow me to elaborate on the narrative: We had reserved a remarkable bargain at the Hilton; however, it was merely for two nights. We required a place to stay for our final night in Las Vegas and desired a cost-effective and proximate location to the airport due to our extremely early departure. Hooters corresponded to our requirements. Positioned at the southernmost point of the strip, the taxi ride to McCarran is relatively brief. Although it lacks luxury, there are affordable rooms available, and the staff member at the registration desk was incredibly cordial. We requested a nonsmoking king room situated on a higher floor, and he accommodated us with an impressive panorama of the Tropicana, Excalibur, and the roller coaster at New York New York. The lodging was fundamental, yet acceptable. 

We traversed the street to the MGM for the majority of the day. 

Later in the evening, we returned to the Hooters Casino, and surprisingly, we experienced immense enjoyment! The minimum wagers are minimal, permitting a genuine sense of recreation. The ambiance is more relaxed compared to the high-stakes casinos, and the clientele is youthful, eliminating the pressure to be a seasoned player. Frankly, I am not a dedicated gambler, nor would I desire to be, so the environment at Hooters aligned perfectly with my preferences."

Bacchanal is okay! They got lots of stations but I can't say much was super memorable and something I must go back to have! Wait... Does dessert count? If so then they do have orange beer sorbet and mango habanero gelato which was a little different from the norm. It was spicy for sure!

Crab legs hot or cold was okay! They plate it for you which isn't bad and keeps from people hogging it so I do like that. Too bad no dungeoness crab tho! Prime rib wasn't bad, lamb chops were good but again... Nothing memorable. I did like the Chinese chicken wings with lots of flavor but a little salty. Oysters were not fresh at all and super obvious for those who eat them on a regular. 

Go on a off hour and you'll be seated in 30-45 minutes otherwise plan on waiting forever!

"This critique pertains to the Tiffany Showroom and its latest production, 'Yesterday - A Tribute to the Beatles.' The showroom's interior boasts three distinct levels, each offering a unique seating arrangement. The uppermost tier features individual chairs and a smattering of diminutive round tables, while the middle level is appointed with banquettes and chairs. Lastly, the floor level offers an array of seating options, including two rows of banquettes and several minuscule table settings. The stage, of considerable proportions, benefits from exceptional acoustics and illumination, courtesy of the meticulous planning that has gone into this homage. The performance itself is characterized by the vocal prowess and instrumental proficiency of the male cast members, who excel when harmonizing. However, during solo passages, the sound deviates slightly from the iconic Beatles' sonic signature, albeit momentarily. The duration of the show approximates sixty minutes, leaving this reviewer with a desire to assign a rating midway between three and four stars, given the minor inconsistencies in the performance."

Indulge Burger is a fun place to stop & grab a bite.

They are a dog friendly place, with water bowls outside in the patio area.  We first started coming here when a coupon appeared in our mail box, and we've been back every few months.  

The food is generally good and they have a wide degree of choices.  The sweet potato fries, onion strings, and the garlic chips are great.  The burgers are in the $10 to $14 dollar range.  But they are very large one half of pound burgers.  That's why it important to remember to check for coupons before you come.  

I just noticed after posting the above review that there is a current "Yelp Deals -- $15 for $30 Deal at Indulge Burgers & More"

The Cajun Queen is a really nice neighborhood restaurant for me. The service is consistently good especially in the bar. I love the atmosphere and the live Dixieland jazz is a wonderful plus.\n\nWhat troubles me now and has troubled me from the first time I started going to the CQ : it seems like the kitchen believes everything must be really hot (spicy) since it's a Cajun restaurant. But some things just shouldn't be hot. Tonight I ordered the crawfish scampi appetizer. Scampi is generally shellfish flavored with garlic and herbs. Red pepper flakes are sometimes added but not as a predominant flavor. The CQ  added so much chili that it overpowered the crawfish. There is not a lot of difference between the scampi and etouffee which is supposed to be hot. If they would just not be so heavy-handed with the Cajun spices.....

"The culinary offerings at this establishment are of considerable quality, particularly considering its affiliation with a larger hospitality conglomerate. The cost of said provisions is quite reasonable, and the quantity provided is indeed generous. Upon perusing the menu, I opted for the chicken katsu, which was accompanied by an ancillary dish of gravy fries. The latter was satisfying, albeit lacking a certain je ne sais quoi in terms of richness. The former was notable for its inclusion of corn, a characteristic that, I presume, is a hallmark of Hawaiian cuisine. However, I must confess that the ambiance of the venue left something to be desired. Despite my understanding that renovations have been ongoing, the interior and exterior aesthetics appear to be stuck in a bygone era, evoking the image of a traditional 50's diner. A refurbishment of the premises, coupled with a modicum of tidying, would greatly enhance the overall experience for patrons such as myself."

This establishment was situated at a considerable distance from the location where my acquaintance resided (West Side), necessitating an arduous journey to arrive there. However, the culinary experience was well worth the effort, despite the fact that the venue was crowded during the luncheon period. The eatery maintained a high level of cleanliness, and the preparation time for the dishes was surprisingly swift, even when considering the large number of patrons present. On days when the temperature rose significantly, it was possible to take a seat outside beneath the misters; however, as an individual hailing from California, I found the heat in Arizona to be excessive, even when taking advantage of the cooling effects provided by the misters.

Food: The Fontina burger, topped with blue cheese, was remarkably fresh and bursting with flavor. The juiciness of the burger was complemented perfectly by the addition of the blue cheese, which greatly enhanced its overall taste. I appreciated the diverse options available for selecting side dishes. Unfortunately, the garlic fries were excessively oily, which detracted slightly from their appeal. Nonetheless, the beet salad offered a delightful and revitalizing contrast. Although the strawberry cheesecake, which was prepared from scratch and not listed on the menu, was merely adequate, it was still a pleasant surprise. Additionally, the fried okra was overcooked to a degree that rendered it unpalatable. On the other hand, the BBQ pork sandwich appeared delectable, and my companion expressed great satisfaction with their meal.

In conclusion, I thoroughly enjoyed the culinary offerings and would highly recommend paying a visit to this establishment.

This critique pertains to the eatery situated on the upper level:

Upon partaking in the culinary offerings of this establishment, my sentiment can best be described as a profound sense of indifference, verging on utter disappointment, owing to the fact that, despite a few notable exceptions, such as the pork belly, salmon, and beef tartare, which demonstrated a modicum of gastronomical prowess, the majority of the dishes served were, regrettably, forgettable to an alarming degree.

Furthermore, our server, seemingly obsessed with maximizing our expenditure, adopted an overzealous approach, bordering on the impertinent, by insisting we commence our repast with a copious quantity of oysters, twenty-four to be precise, in addition to interpolating several ounces of wagyu beef into the meal, an suggestion that struck me as not only superfluous but also utterly preposterous.

In conclusion, given the plethora of superior dining options available in Las Vegas, it is my conviction that one would be ill-advised to allocate their resources towards experiencing the culinary endeavors of this particular restaurant, upstairs or otherwise.

"This establishment served as a recurrent destination during my formative years in Las Vegas, as it offered an economical and convenient dining experience, allowing me to indulge in their culinary offerings without incurring exorbitant costs. My recent visit proved to be a satisfying encounter, with their rendition of steak and eggs exemplifying the quintessential breakfast staple. However, I must deduct a star from my overall rating due to the price point of $20, which seems somewhat excessive in light of the local standards. Nonetheless, I must commend the attentive service rendered by our server, who graciously provided a bottle of Heinz 57 sauce upon request."

I've been to this yard house 3 or 4 times.  I think if I would have written a review the first or even second time, I would have given 4 stars... But, I just don't think it deserves that high of a rating...

The beer selection is fabulous.. Mostly because they have Triple Karmeliet.. my favorite :)  

The food is pretty darn decent too.  Great place to grab a steak and I am a huge fan of the hawiian pizza.  Good is good.

A little on the pricey side if you are planning to stay for awhile.. which is fine, but I don't like to have to spend 100 bucks for a diner and drinks for two.... especially when it's only a couple of drinks.. Boo on that.  Pretty much my only complaint.. I'll get over it though and go back soon I'm sure. :)

Oh, and one las thing, I love the music selection.. Always playing good tunes.

"Indulged in a culinary experience with a valued patron at this establishment for the initial time today, relishing the delectable yellow curry dish of medium piquancy and the pre-prandial soup, albeit the hospitality was somewhat tardy, necessitating a protracted waiting period of sixteen minutes for my primary course to arrive, despite which numerous staff members inquired about the possibility of replenishing my beverage."

"Rating: 3 and a half stars\n\nLocated directly opposite Marriott's opulent hotel, this timeshare complex boasted an impressive occupancy rate during our stay in May, with the premises bustling with activity. Despite the somewhat diminutive size of our accommodations, my companion and I found them to be adequately furnished and suitable for our needs. The staff members we encountered were unfailingly courteous and helpful, and the well-manicured grounds contributed to a pleasant overall ambiance. Serving as an ideal base for daily excursions to popular destinations such as the Grand Canyon, Sedona, Prescott, Scottsdale, and the Phoenix Botanical Garden, among others, this timeshare complex offered a convenient and comfortable respite after a day of exploring."

I would say this place is pretty much like every other nail salon in Charlotte.  The fumes greet you at the door, they have you pick your color, they point to the chair they want you to sit in, they stare at you and smile, attempting to connect with the few English words they know, they do a decent job and slap you with a bill.  Sound familiar?  That was my experience.  It wasn't bad, it wasn't amazing, it was just....familiar.  They did have a very nice selection of colors which was nice but nothing else stood out to me.  They were friendly enough and priced the same as everyone else.  They did a nice job on my cuticles which other places have not been as detailed.  I would come back.

If Spearmint Rhino and Treasures were to be considered siblings in the realm of adult entertainment, it would be analogous to comparing Charlie Sheen and Emilio Estevez, where Spearmint Rhino embodies the unbridled and riotous spirit of Charlie Sheen, while Treasures assumes the role of Emilio Estevez, lacking the pizzazz and excitement of its counterpart, despite offering a comparatively economical bottle service experience.

My family and I serendipitously encountered this establishment while perusing the retail offerings in Townsquare, and upon entering, we were immediately captivated by the aesthetically pleasing ambiance. Our attention was graciously captured by an exceptional waitress who informed us that the duration of the happy hour was rapidly approaching its culmination, with only twelve minutes remaining until the prices would increase exponentially. In light of this information, we unanimously decided to expedite our order, ensuring that we could partake in the discounted beverages prior to their transformation into double the original cost. However, much to our dismay, the bar manager, Jessica, declined our request, maintaining that the designated time frame for happy hour had already elapsed. Despite this setback, we opted to continue dining at this location, investing $160.00 in delectable cuisine that thoroughly satiated our palates. The impeccable service we received further enhanced our dining experience, yet unfortunately, the actions of Jessica left an indelible impression, precluding us from future visits. As an ardent patron, I habitually demonstrate loyalty towards establishments that cater to my preferences, frequently returning with my acquaintances and loved ones; regrettably, the $18 saved does not justify the relinquishment of our custom.

This minuscule canine recreational area, confined to a singular expanse of land adjacent to a baseball field, presents a rather limited scope for canine exercise and socialization, which, in conjunction with its questionable maintenance, renders it an inferior choice for discerning dog owners seeking a suitable venue for their pets. Despite the occasional visit from myself and my spouse during our tenure in the vicinity, the dearth of upkeep and the recent, albeit ineffectual, "renovation" have rendered this park somewhat disappointing, particularly in light of the presence of more well-appointed facilities in the surrounding area. Notwithstanding, its proximity to my place of employment shall continue to facilitate my patronage, though an inclination towards alternative, superior destinations persists.

I had passed this restaurant dozens of time without knowing what magic was behind the plain building. I was very pleasantly surprised upon walking in at around 9pm on a Friday night to see ducks and turtles swimming around. The tables outside were filled with lovers, adding to the romantic ambiance of El Encanto. There was a older gentleman singing Spanish love songs while playing the guitar. It was like another world from the street that we entered from; it almost felt like a secret club for some reason. And I was happy to have found it.\n\nAnyway, on to the food. I shared the pollo fundido with my other half. I wasn't TOO impressed, because I still think X Tapa Joe's has the best Pollo Fundido in town, but the yellow rice that accompanied the dish was superb. Usually, I am disappointed at the dry and bland Mexican rice that comes with entrees. Not here. It tasted like the yellow rice that I make, which is moist and rich in flavor. The margaritas were a bit too sweet but still okay. Overall, I thought it was a great place for a date night as it seeped with romance. I would love to try another dish sometime to give them a higher rating, but so far, the 3 stars I gave it seems right on point.

Although the food, wine, and atmosphere are all good, sadly I must say I have been let down. One of my problems is the sometimes slow service. Also we decided to go here for a friends birthday and they ran out of food. It was not fun feeling like you had the angel of death for a server ready to kill your order. I really would love to give the place four stars, because the food and wine are certainly worth it, but due to my traumatic experience its just a-ok. Maybe I will get a chance to go back and update my review to what I know it really could be.

"As a resident of the surrounding area, I recently had the opportunity to visit this establishment and witnessed a portion of its promotional presentation. My initial impression was that the club card perks were somewhat mediocre, yet still managed to pique my interest upon signing up. The gaming selection featured an agreeable balance of contemporary and vintage machines, which catered to my penchant for more intimate gambling venues. Although my own gaming experience was relatively unremarkable, my spouse enjoyed a streak of good fortune. We opted to utilize the provided coupons and sample the culinary offerings at the on-site deli. The breakfast special I ordered was satisfying, with a generous serving of fresh tomatoes, crispy bacon, and a warm, toasted muffin. My spouse's burger was equally impressive, boasting a juicy patty, crisp lettuce, and flavorful tomatoes, accompanied by a side of golden fries that were cooked to a perfect crispiness. While the quality of the food was undeniably impressive, the true test of consistency lies in future visits."

"On a Tuesday (December 18, 2012), we embarked upon a culinary excursion to an Italian eatery in Edinburgh, which, regrettably, did not live up to our expectations in terms of gastronomic excellence. Despite the presence of some delectable antipasti, the crostini unfortunately exhibited a discernible staleness, thus somewhat diminishing our overall satisfaction. However, the pork belly proved to be a redeeming factor, boasting tenderness and flavor, while the roast potatoes were cooked to perfection, earning them high praise. Unfortunately, the chocolate tart that followed left much to be desired, as its richness bordered on overwhelming. Notwithstanding the shortcomings in the food department, the ambiance of the establishment exuded a certain charm and appeal, rendering it an enjoyable experience for all. Nevertheless, in light of the middling quality of the fare, it remains uncertain whether a return visit would be warranted, especially when considering the abundance of superior, family-run establishments in the vicinity, such as Nonna's in Morningside, which undoubtedly outshine their competitors in terms of sheer excellence."

"It constitutes a sizable storage establishment, boasting an array of diverse unit sizes. The premises are relatively well-maintained. In light of my requirement for storing documents, I opted for the smallest available unit. The administrative staff appears to be cordial and competent. Notwithstanding, I have certain reservations pertaining to the considerable amount of dust that manages to infiltrate the units, as well as the considerable distance between the facility and my domicile. Improved entranceways with enhanced dust-proofing capabilities would be a worthwhile investment."

"As I embarked upon my journey through the bustling streets of downtown Chandler, I chanced upon a singular establishment that piqued my curiosity; a freestanding edifice housing none other than a Jimmy John's franchise. This particular venue boasted an unprecedented distinction - it was the first of its kind that I had ever laid eyes on. 

The menu offered the customary array of delectable items associated with the esteemed sandwich chain, albeit at a marginally lower price point (approximately fifty cents less) in comparison to the Chandler Fashion Center location. My affection for Jimmy John's notwithstanding, I felt compelled to deduct a half-star from my overall rating due to the multitude of distractions that permeated the interior of the store. 

Upon entering the premises, I was struck by the striking similarity to a typical high school cafeteria. Staff members vociferously engaged in banter, their voices raised to an earsplitting volume, while the ambiance was further heightened by the blaring music. Such an environment made it challenging to fully appreciate the culinary experience. 

We have all, at some point in our lives, cherished memories of our formative years spent within the hallowed halls of high school. Have we not, dear reader? For instance, who could forget the inimitable Ferris Bueller and his unforgettable exploits?"

I like that Pei Wei will let me get a kids' meal, even though I'm not a kid. 

Truthfully, I need the help with portion control when it comes to rice and sauces and allowing me the kids' meal option makes this one of the first places I think of when I'm looking to satisfy a rice craving -- and, it's definitely the only "guilt-free" place that comes to mind. 

The parking lot here STINKS!! Otherwise, I'd totally give you one more star.

I have been to Toby Keith's a couple of times over the years. The first time was a couple of years ago for a local concert that became ridiculously overcrowded and claustrophobic but I will disregard that initial experience and review only this experience today. I met my mom here for a late lunch around 3pm because we were in the area so it was convenient. Our waitress was really nice and attentive and we wanted to take our time and she didn't have a problem with that.

I ordered a green chili chicken sandwich (with no bun) and a side of coleslaw. My mom had a turkey club sandwich. My chicken was pretty good. It was a little overcooked but it wasn't bad. Nothing to write home about. My mom's turkey club was a HUGE serving and she said it was just okay.

Overall for a midday dining experience we had an okay experience. The food was okay, the service was good. Would I be back? Maybe...

The overall quality of the performance was subpar, failing to meet expectations and commencing tardily, approximately 10 to 15 minutes behind schedule. Notwithstanding, the standup comedian's segment proved to be the most enjoyable aspect of the show, eliciting copious laughter and applause from the audience. However, my attempts to locate her YouTube videos have been futile, thus far. Additionally, certain female performers possessed aesthetic appeal, yet their movements lacked coordination and synchronization, detracting from the overall impact of their performances.

We arrived at this culinary establishment due to our possession of a Restaurant.com gift certificate, which we utilized with the hope of experiencing a delectable dining experience. Our expectations were moderately met, as the comestibles served were merely satisfactory, with the exception of the taco shells, which were freshly fabricated in-house and displayed an agreeable texture. Unfortunately, the rice was overcooked, resulting in a lackluster consistency. Additionally, the cheese employed in the dish was pre-shredded cheddar, which did not contribute to an authentic Mexican culinary experience. Despite these shortcomings, the meal was relatively inexpensive and fulfilled our hunger.

This eatery is situated within the confines of a somewhat seedy, yet still appealing, local casino, whereupon it manages to maintain an ambiance conducive to enjoying a satisfying and filling breakfast, further enhanced by the surprisingly reasonable prices. Additionally, the presence of a well-stocked bar ensures that one may indulge in a morning cocktail or two, complementing the delectable menu offerings, which, might we suggest, lean decidedly towards the more traditional breakfast items. Furthermore, the attentive service consistently provided by the staff serves to enhance the overall dining experience.

It is utterly arduous to select a venue to indulge in gastronomical delights in Las Vegas, given the plethora of options available, which seem to permeate the culinary landscape. However, the fact that Mon Ami's dining area was brimming with patrons could be construed as a positive harbinger. Upon partaking in their delectable offerings, I discovered that their bread was truly exceptional, presented in a charming manner reminiscent of the quintessential French baguette, albeit served with an unconventional accompaniment - a paper bag, a peculiarity that seems to defy convention in the land of its origin. My taste buds were further tantalized by their beef bourguignon, a dish that would undoubtedly garner the approval of the illustrious Julia Child, even if the noodles accompanying it were regrettably overcooked. Unfortunately, my experience with their mixology was marred by a subpar French 75, a cocktail that fell short of expectations within the context of a purportedly authentic French establishment. Notwithstanding these shortcomings, the ambiance of the venue was relatively pleasant, thanks in part to the ambient temperature provided by outdoor heaters, the melodic background music, and the captivating spectacle of the Bellagio fountain display. However, the cramped nature of the patio left much to be desired in terms of spatial comfort. In conclusion, while Mon Ami may not have fully satisfied my epicurean inclinations, I am willing to consider alternative dining options in Las Vegas that can deliver a comparable caliber of cuisine and overall experience, should they exist.

"It appears that Espee has succumbed to the pervasive trend of exorbitant pricing, with a paltry three-item combination commanding an astronomical sixteen dollars, a sum that could easily be expended on a lavish repast at an establishment such as Agave, where the culinary offerings are of a decidedly higher caliber. Furthermore, the tamales at Espee seem to have diminished in size, which is particularly noticeable when contrasted with the previously generous proportions. The salsa bar, once a highlight of the dining experience, has sadly degenerated into an unappetizing state, prompting one to wonder what befell the erstwhile pico de gallo. Although the happy hour specials, featuring two-for-one margaritas and discounted nachos, remain a salient aspect of the eatery's appeal, the steep prices and diminishing portion sizes have regretfully compelled me to downgrade my original four-star assessment to a more modest three stars."

I am fervently desirous of conferring a rating of four stars upon this establishment, as my previous experiences have been largely satisfactory. Upon multiple visits, I have endeavored to sample a variety of items, and each dish has proven to be delectable, to say the least. However, due to my proximity to MTO Cafe, I frequently opt for their delivery services, which regrettably, have proven to be somewhat unreliable, as certain items are often omitted from my order, such as green drinks, salads accompanying chicken and waffles, and side dishes like mashed potatoes, among others. Despite these inconsistencies, the food remains flavorful and nutritious, providing an ideal solution for alleviating hangovers or enjoying a leisurely weekend brunch at home. Furthermore, the recent opening of a second location at the new Summerlin Mall has piqued my interest, and I intend to visit it in the near future.

"I have had the privilege of partaking in numerous sushi dining establishments, ranging from economical to luxurious. However, upon visiting Yokoso, it became apparent that their sushi offerings were not their forte. The sushi pieces were predominantly composed of rice, with an unfortunate lack of moisture. I opted to sample both the Rainbow Roll and The Pitt Roll, but unfortunately, they did not meet my expectations. While the pricing was reasonable, the quality of the sushi was subpar. I cannot comment on the remainder of the menu, as my focus was solely on the sushi. Nevertheless, I would only recommend visiting this establishment if you have an unwavering desire for sushi. On a positive note, the service we received was both attentive and efficient."
The prices are a little high and the food is ok. I have had better pizza. The wings where also ok. The people where nice both times we have eaten there.

Came here a few weeks ago with friends. Breakfast was good, tea was nice, atmosphere ok. I wasn't blown away but I also wasn't disappointed. I love the location and the interior is vintage and original. The outside was ok to have breakfast and enjoy the weather. Moderately priced.

For a place that's supposedly known for wings, it wasn't so good. I was very hungry but couldn't finish the 20 wings I was sharing with my friend. The 10 grilled wings were tossed in this super spicy tangy Cajun sauce. Eeee. Should've had the sauce on the side. The other 10 wings had sauce on the side but the batter was chalky tasting. Eeee.\n\nThe shrimp and spinach salad was good. Tsk. Was so craving good wings though.

"Rio De Janeiro, a city synonymous with vibrancy and extravagance, boasts an array of captivating attractions that warrant a visit from even the most discerning traveler. In order to elevate the experience at this esteemed establishment, certain enhancements are proposed, including but not limited to: looser slots, cordial security staff, additional cute shops, and entertainment tailored specifically for the under 21 demographic. Furthermore, aesthetic improvements, such as glitz and glamour upgrades, would greatly contribute to the overall ambiance. Already renowned for its delectable seafood buffet, spacious accommodations, and lively atmosphere, the implementation of these suggestions would undoubtedly revitalize the Rio, transforming it into a premier destination once again. Needless to say, my return is imminent, thanks in large part to the allure of rewards points."

"The edible sustenance provided by this establishment, while undoubtedly satisfying the hunger of its patrons, fails to elicit any semblance of excitement or originality in its culinary offerings, thereby imbuing the ambiance with an unfortunate dearth of distinctive character; meanwhile, the service proffered by the waiting staff exhibits commendable efficiency and attention to detail, even as the selection of beverages available for consumption boasts a few notable options, yet the overall experience remains somewhat dubious in terms of value received for the price paid."

I attended this establishment on the occasion of a friend's birthday celebration, whereupon I partook in an assortment of delectable victuals, specifically the soft pretzels accompanied by a savory fondue, which were indeed scrumptious. Our server, though attentive, did not expedite the delivery of our repast and potables with sufficient celerity, unfortunately. Notwithstanding, I thoroughly enjoyed my entree selection, the Sweet Corn Cannelloni, whose rich flavors were abundant and gratifying. Furthermore, I appreciated the diverse vegetarian options available. In addition, we received a complimentary dessert, the Monkey Bread, which, despite its unassuming name, proved to be surprisingly delectable. Moreover, the ambiance of the venue was quite pleasant, characterized by comfortable, uniquely designed chairs at each table and magnificent chandeliers that contributed to an overall sense of elegance. However, certain drawbacks did exist, including an excessive delay in the preparation and service of our meals, an excess of noise, insufficient illumination, and portion sizes that seemed somewhat diminutive relative to the cost.

Let me state that this initial review is pretty old (sat as a draft that I forgot to post), but I can't update it yet. Review 1,  2 stars : Poor service. Had to wait 6 minutes or so just for someone to come to the front and take our order. Asked for mayo and ketchup only on the burger and the girl taking our order was a smarta**, stating that if we had been here before we would know that ketchup and mayo was on the table. Of course the whole burger came out wrong because the girl interrupted us when trying to order it with her smarter-than-thou attitude. The second girl I talked to fixed it and was really nice.\nReview 2, 4 stars : We got some food while we were bowling for my little sister's birthday. Service was good. Food was pretty good. Overall, a pleasant experience.

Ok, this place can get pricey quick, but if you know how to get \"bang\" for the buck like me you'll be ok.  My friend and I got the Veggie sandwich with extra roast beef.  I really need to invest in a real camera, because what we got was a 5 star Roast beef sandwich for 15 bux.  With Coffee and cake we were under $30 bux for the both of us.  I will say this....if you eat more food than what came out you really need a diet.  It was MORE THAN enough.  Split your food here as its just too much for one person and you don't want to take leftovers back with you do you?  Great sammy, half sour pickle with decent coffee.  Geez the chocolate cake is good.  Fries mehhhh.

The place is really cute and has a really nice outdoor area to include a bar. Went for lunch and sat outside on the artificial turf.  The lights strung up outside I'm sure will provide great atmosphere at night. The food was good, but noting spectacular. I had a garden salad and the other people in my group had a chicken panini sandwich in which the chicken was dry and a strawberry salad where the strawberries were mushy. I could look past all of that, but the thing that got me is how slooooowwww the service is. We ordered fairly quickly and the it took forever for the food to come out. I hope that they get it figured out and pick up the pace because this place has potential, especially in a neighborhood that lacks these cute, trendy places.

"Peruse the menu, select your preference, and prepare your palate for an authentic culinary excursion, as this establishment's commitment to genuine flavors and traditional preparation methods is unwavering. Although linguistic barriers may exist, the staff's hospitable demeanor and willingness to accommodate curious patrons more than compensates for any potential communication difficulties. Indeed, an inquiry regarding the taste of the barbacoa was met with an offer to sample the dish, graciously provided by the attentive server. The robust flavors present in each taco are a testament to the culinary prowess of the kitchen staff, with the chicken variety boasting a satisfying spiciness and the guacamole maintaining a refreshing simplicity, comprised primarily of fresh avocado and a squeeze of lime juice. However, it would be remiss to neglect mentioning the somewhat questionable state of the seating area, characterized by utilitarian metal chairs and worn, torn booth cushions, with the occasional rusty nail protruding from the frame. Despite these shortcomings, the booths remain a preferable option for those opting to dine in. Unfortunately, the quality of the meat leaves something to be desired, thereby precluding this venue from becoming a regular haunt for this writer, who is admittedly particular about such matters. Nonetheless, the unique experience merits documentation and recommendation to intrepid gastronomes seeking an authentic taste of Mexico."

I had a very pleasant dinner at Fleur de Lys last month but nothing wow'ed me.  I ordered from the $59 prix fixe menu, which includes an appetizer, entree and dessert - all in all, a good value!   

I enjoyed the onion soup, served with shaved truffles and duck.  It was rich and earthy with an unexpected presentation.  Next I had gently heated salmon with juilinee vegetables and a green horseradish sauce.  My salmon was perfectly cooked and the dish looked beautiful, but the sauce, frankly tasted like grass clippings!  Bitter and overpowering.  My friend seemed to enjoy her stout braised short ribs.  The dessert, a "trio of chocolates", was a miss: a dry souffle, a salty peanutbutter shake and Baily's ice cream.  None of the desserts really did it for me.  

I may have expected too much from this place, but hey, it's Hu bert Keller's spot!  Who knows, maybe I caught them on a bad night.  I'd like to return some time and give the regular menu a chance, but with so many INCREDIBLE places to eat in Vegas I can't make any guarantees.

PROS: Great service, Great wine and Reasonable prixe fixe menus. 
CONS: Too many 'miss' dishes for a 4 star

"Subpar, at best, was the quality of the culinary offerings presented before me. Specifically, the buttermilk pancakes, potato pancakes, eggs, and sausage links appeared to lack the requisite level of doneness, despite the expedited manner in which they were delivered to my table, a mere three minutes after placing my order. In fact, I would have willingly tolerated an additional two-minute wait to ensure that my meal was thoroughly cooked. Furthermore, it is worth noting that my mother's pancake recipe remains unsurpassed in its excellence."

This place gets a 3 star because they've never blown my socks off with anything, but I've never had experience with them that made me want to quit pizza. It's pretty close to my house and my nephew loves pizza so I'm here a decent amount. They're very consistent, very friendly and my food is always ready on time. On the single time my order was messed up, they were very quick about fixing it,  which was majorly appreciated. To be honest I have nothing bad to say about them at all. They get the job done

We indulged in a culinary excursion at this establishment on a Thursday evening, bringing along our 14-month-old progeny. Despite the availability of infant seating accommodations, we would advise against introducing young children to this venue, as it is not particularly suitable for their presence. However, we would enthusiastically endorse partaking in gastronomic delights at this location. Our repast began with an order of crabcakes, which, while satisfying, could have benefited from a slightly crisper exterior. This deficiency could have been remedied by extending the cooking duration in the pan. The accompanying spicy aioli presented a delightful complement to the dish.  
I relished in the delectable brie and bacon burger, characterized by exceptional quality bacon and beef, enveloped within a soft, yet robust bun. The burger was cooked to a perfect medium, with an adequate amount of juiciness. Unfortunately, it did not arrive with fries, much to our dismay. My spouse opted for the lobster bisque, which, despite its commendable flavor, was overpowered by an excessive amount of sherry. Additionally, she sampled the beef and blue salad, which emerged as the highlight of the meal. This dish showcased exceptional quality blue cheese, eliciting our utmost appreciation.  We eagerly anticipate our next visit to this culinary haven.

"Substantially superior to my previous recollection. During our last visit, we partook in breakfast, which was regrettably unpalatable. On this occasion, we opted to sample their dinner offerings. 

A twenty-four hour buffet pass for the reasonable price of forty dollars...an offer that cannot be declined! However, subsequent to the second helping, an overwhelming desire to hasten towards the nearest restroom or secure a quantity of antacids becomes unavoidable. In all seriousness, consuming more than a single buffet within a twenty-four hour period is not recommended for optimal digestive health. Nonetheless, such excesses are customary in Las Vegas...a city where both financial losses and gastronomical indulgences are embraced with equal fervor! 

Our third buffet excursion during our pass was a dinner visit. 

Highlights included: 
CREPES!!! Deliciously soft and fluffy crepes, which I preferred without any additional toppings, aside from a light dusting of powdered sugar. A friendly female attendant skillfully prepared them. The texture was delightfully chewy...I consumed two. *ugh* 

Seafood. A medley of crab, shrimp, mussels, and clams. While not exceptional, it was still adequate. 

Dessert. An extensive array, showcasing the standard assortment of sweets found at most buffets. Although nothing particularly remarkable, it sufficed in satiating our sweet tooth. 

The roasted duck was also quite satisfying...served with a tangy orange sauce and accompanied by rice pilaf. The remaining dishes did not leave a lasting impression, as they were largely similar to those encountered at other buffets. 

A respectable buffet experience...ranking third on our comprehensive buffet list."

Whenever my travel itinerary has necessitated that I be accommodated in the vicinity of the renowned Las Vegas Strip, but I have been reluctant to incur the additional expense associated with lodging within the Strip's premium hospitality sector, I have opted to take up temporary residence at this establishment, which, while not situated directly on the Strip, remains conveniently proximate thereto. The amenities available to guests include a refreshing pool and complimentary wireless internet access, both of which are certain to enhance one's stay. Furthermore, sustenance options are readily accessible, mere steps away from the hotel's entrance. Finally, the management has graciously elected to include parking facilities within the cost of accommodation, thereby obviating the need for guests to allocate additional funds for this purpose.

It looks just like the Hofbrau Haus in Munich. I think the only Germans in the place were in the band! Service was good. Music was good. Beer was good. The food was another matter. My wife's Jager Schnitzel was so tough you could barely cut it with a knife. The sauerkraut with my wurst plate was bland and over cooked. The mashed potatoes tasted like they were made from a mix. We definitely had better German food.

I like the suite at Mandalay Bay its 750 sq the service at the front desk are always friendly, But I dislike it when my room were comp and they still charge me if I didn't look at my credit card the same week I wouldn't catch it that they charge me for 2 nights when those 2 nights are suppose to be free.

This establishment offers an exceptional nocturnal dining experience on Tuesdays, particularly after 9 pm when the premises become increasingly crowded. It is advisable to arrive ahead of time to secure a seat, as the venue tends to reach its maximum capacity shortly after 9 pm. Despite the elevated seating area being relatively tranquil, it was a Tuesday evening, and thus, the atmosphere was somewhat subdued. A diverse array of draft beverages is available, featuring Pumking, which I would have ordinarily chosen; however, the price of $10 for a small serving seemed somewhat excessive. Consequently, I opted for a bottle of Purple Haze, another favorite of mine. The bartender informed me that a technical issue with the computer system resulted in a reduced price of $3 for my beverage, a most welcome surprise. Regrettably, this anomaly did not persist for the subsequent round; nevertheless, the bartender considerately alerted me in advance, which was thoroughly acceptable. I remained on the premises until 9 pm to partake in the delectable burger special, which surpassed my expectations. The double burger was truly gratifying, and I wholeheartedly endorse the Stack'd special sauce!

I would give it 3.75. Never would guess a cool little breakfast spot would be located under some shady apartments on 7th street. Sat at the bar and ate. Could see right into the very small kitchen. I only had scrambled eggs and bacon which are nothing to rave about but it's hard to mess those up. Some of the other dishes that came out of the kitchen looked great!  I'll have to try the pancakes next time!  Would definitely come back.

I am utterly perplexed by the exaggerated acclaim surrounding this establishment, as my experience fell short of the lofty expectations engendered by the plethora of 4-5 star reviews on Yelp. Upon entering, I anticipated a culinary masterpiece, only to be disillusioned by a minuscule sandwich that failed to satiate my hunger. The overpowering presence of horseradish contaminated the flavor, leaving an unpleasant aftertaste that further compounded my discontent. My disappointment was so profound that I found myself questioning the credibility of Yelp's rating system. In an attempt to assuage my hunger, I opted for the chicken noodle soup, which proved to be merely average and did little to alleviate my dissatisfaction. It is worth mentioning that my recent dining experiences in Las Vegas had been largely positive, thus making the subpar quality of this particular meal even more conspicuous. In conclusion, I must emphasize that the sandwich underwhelmed me to an extent that left me incredulous, and I cannot fathom how it garnered such an abundance of glowing endorsements.

I had been cognizant of numerous laudatory remarks pertaining to Noca, and thus, I was eagerly anticipating partaking in a culinary experience at this establishment. However, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as my dining encounter was somewhat disappointing. 
  All four of us opted for the tasting menu, with two individuals selecting the wine pairing option as well. The visual aspect of the dishes was undeniably impressive. We initiated our meal with a preliminary palette cleanser of sorts. The first course consisted of either a mushroom soup or a salad, wherein I chose the former, and my spouse opted for the latter. While both dishes were satisfactory, they failed to elicit an exceptional degree of culinary delight. 
  The second course, which comprised pasta accompanied by a meat-based sauce, was indubitably the most delectable offering thus far. Moving on to the main entrÃ©e, we were served a flat iron steak, which, albeit enjoyable, did not quite attain remarkable status. The concluding dessert course featured blue cotton candy and chocolate cake accompanied by banana gelato, the former of which proved to be a pleasant surprise. 
  Lamentably, the wine pairings fell short of our expectations. Our server seemed to possess limited knowledge regarding the wines, and rather peculiarly, he adhered to identical pairings irrespective of whether we selected the soup or salad, and fish or steak entrÃ©e. Moreover, the entire wine selection was confined to the red family. 
  In summary, while Noca presented visually appealing dishes, adequate portion sizes, and passable service, the overall experience did not prove extraordinary. If one seeks a truly remarkable dining establishment, I would instead recommend Alto at the Hyatt Gainey Ranch.

"I thoroughly relish the ornamental elements within this establishment, as they exude an air of refined sophistication while simultaneously incorporating industrial undertones, thereby enhancing the overall ambiance. However, my enthusiasm for the decor does not extend to the culinary offerings, as they fail to surpass the quality one would expect from a typical Brazilian steakhouse. Patrons partake in an initial course consisting of a limitless supply of salad and soup, followed by the prompt arrival of sides and entrees upon the reversal of a card. The steak selection boasts an array of cuts, ranging from prime sirloin to flavorful flank steak, all of which are adequately prepared. Yet, the genuine gastronomic highlights of the menu prove to be the delectable pork ribs and savory lamb, while the chicken dishes remain unremarkable and somewhat perplexing, given the prevalence of superior meat options. Supplementary dishes include crispy fried bananas, garlic mashed potatoes, and irresistible baked bread rolls filled with cheese. Although the desserts come at a premium price, they provide a satisfying conclusion to the meal. My experience, unfortunately, was marred by several shortcomings, including subpar food that failed to impress, particularly in comparison to the superior quality offered at Fogo de Chao. Furthermore, the seasoning proved insufficient, and the variety of meats available was limited, which may have been attributed to our early arrival. Lastly, the lobster bisque received mixed reviews from my dining companions, with some expressing disappointment at its unremarkable taste."

This McDonald's is conveniently nearby the Pepsi Center.

It opens late, and was perfect for the post-clubbing crowd I was with.

A friend bought me a McChicken sandwich (not sure why, but I appreciated it), which I made short work of - it tasted normal, as expected.

As usual, the food and service is very good here but can you please refinish the floor? It's really showing it age. Worn and discolored, it takes away from the overall experience. The ottomans in the lounge area also need cleaning or even better, reupholstered. \n\nThe place is looking rundown and that's really a shame for a high end, Summerlin dining spot.

Cute spot and lots of fun for the kiddos.  However, when we went out to the pumpkin patch to pick pumpkins, I saw one sitting in the field with a sticker on it from a store, complete with bar code.  I don't mind paying a little extra for locally grown pumpkins, but I am not paying $12 for a pumpkin they paid $4 for at Walmart!  I immediately put our pumpkins back.  I know they grow pumpkins there, you could see the vines, but if you sell them all, it feels wrong to me to supplement your inventory with store bought ones!

"For individuals seeking palatable victuals, Oliveo's presents itself as an optimal destination, irrespective of the time of day, be it during the nocturnal hours or the midday interval. While the prices may be perceived as somewhat elevated, the culinary offerings are undeniably of Greek provenance, thereby justifying the additional expense. My personal experiences with their menu have been nothing short of satisfactory, as I have had the pleasure of indulging in their delectable chicken souvlaki, gyros, and chicken breast plates, all of which have been expertly prepared and bursting with flavor. Furthermore, Oliveo's extends its operating hours well into the late night, making it an ideal choice for those seeking a nutritious repast beyond the conventional fast-food options. Thus, I wholeheartedly endorse this establishment for anyone seeking a satisfying dining experience in a collegiate setting."

Nice place. More upscale than a \"pub\" ...menu wise that is. I had a newer item..chicken tacos. each one had a alrge deep fried/crusty chicken finger in it ( I was expecting more shredded chicken)  They were pretty tasty and had a nice spice. Harder to each with one large chunk of chicken though. The table we were at was a little warn and slightly sticky. They could use to take a step up on cleanliness. take everything off the table when you clean it so its done right.

"Gosh darn it! I thoroughly forgot about my significant other discovering an extensive dark-colored strand of human hair in our culinary creation proximate to the point of completion of our repast. How on earth could I have overlooked such an occurrence?! It's absolutely unacceptable for any eatery to have such a disgusting situation transpire, particularly when the victuals were as delectable as they were."

I'm not sure how this made it onto eaters list but I wasn't impressed. I've been a couple times and had different experiences each time. 

Price is decent. Style is fast casual but chicken was too greasy.  Burgers are very messy but decent in flavor. However I would  consider come here before going most fast food places.  Honestly, I've had amazing burgers so I have high expectations. 

I liked the French fries and flash fried veggies... Probably not healthy at all because it was too salty but I give them credit because it very unique.  It's not something I would order frequently though.

I think the mac and cheese is their best dish.  Get it with the bologna.  Good comfort food.  Their cheese plate looked good and their onion rings are great if you like heaps of the thin cut type (which I do).  

The perch is my favorite of the fish selections.  I had that tonight while there.  Ordered a bowl of the beer cheese soup, too.  Somewhat flavorless and they garnished it with popcorn.  Bleh.

The rest of the menu is passable.  They try too hard for down-home Wisconsin cooking.  Whatever that is.

I was actually at the Staples next door, but had seen this place several times before and was curious enough this time to stop in, not knowing at all what to expect. I was here in the early afternoon, and it was plenty busy, but nothing like the megacrowds that others are describing, presumably dependent on the time and day. I didn't get a chance to experience the aggressive customer aspect, but most likely because I wasn't shopping in the women's section, and 95% of the other customers were women, who did look a bit frenzied; the four or five men in the store were, by contrast, subdued. I will have to come back again when I have more time to explore what they have, but to say I was "impressed" with the selection of (men's) shoes would be understating itâit was wingtip heaven in there! Unlike many of the items in this place, most of these shoes were in great condition, with the worst thing being a missing lace or two, which is an easy fix anyway. I came out with a $30 pair of Maison Forte boots which have no imperfections at all and were originally priced at $215.00! (I should add that I'm not designer/brand aware at all, so I'm mostly impressed that the shoes are gorgeous and don't so much care about their brand names.) Will definitely come back, even if just for more shoes! :)

"While the culinary offerings at this establishment were of satisfactory quality, the ambiance and aesthetic appeal of the physical location left much to be desired in terms of creating an optimal dining environment. Notwithstanding, the eatery's maintenance and upkeep were commendable, and the staff's attentiveness and responsiveness to our needs were adequate. Under the circumstances, I would still consider patronizing this restaurant for takeout or delivery purposes."

Decided to have dinner at Tofu Hut tonight. Overall experience was not bad, but I wouldn't call it great either. 

They were a bit short staffed when we first walked in. I would say it took them over 5 mins to even acknowledge our presence even though they did see us walk in.  I expected a "Hello, or Welcome" at the very least.

We passed on the AYCE tonight & went ala carte. We ordered short ribs & spicy chicken. Both orders were good, but nothing memorable or anything to rave about. I did love their banchan offerings! I liked the fish cake, japchae, spicy cucumber, and I don't recall the others but it was yummy!

I would go back.. but don't think I'll be a regular at this place.

I love this hotel, but I think the Bellagio still wins in my book. 
My family and I got upgraded to the 60th floor, which had an amazing view. The rooms are SO cute and clean and there's a TV in the bathroom... lol! However, the TV in the room didn't work at all, despite the "directions" on how to use the TV on the remote control.  
Also, the walls were SO THIN! I could hear people talking in the hallway all throughout the night, plus I could hear the neighbors during the middle of the night (although this might be because they were fighting...). 
Anyhoo, I'm a fan of the hotel itself, La Rev the show, the buffet (for brunch and dinner), and the shops.

"The sushi exhibited palatable quality, however, the service was merely adequate. Notwithstanding, the numerous servers' frequent comings and goings rendered it challenging for us to maintain their individual identities.
