Furthermore, our dissatisfaction was exacerbated by the fact that the various types of sushi rolls we had ordered were being served in an uncoordinated manner, arriving at disparate intervals rather than being presented simultaneously. Despite the proximity of the Wynn, where we were lodging, we opted to partake of this dining experience."

"The cinematic experience offered by this establishment possesses both beneficial aspects and drawbacks. On one hand, the relatively diminutive size of the theater enables the exhibition of merely six to seven films simultaneously. Nevertheless, the auditoriums themselves boast exceptional comfort and generous legroom between seats, much to the delight of tall individuals. Unfortunately, the luminosity of the pathway illumination within the theater is excessive, resulting in an annoying distraction akin to having a light source directed into one's eyes throughout the entire film. Not exactly an optimal viewing environment. 

The pricing scheme adopted by this cinema is generally unremarkable, with the exception of a discounted rate of $5.50 for students. To take advantage of this offer, it may be necessary to employ creative methods such as presenting an outdated student identification card or sporting orthodontic appliances to convincingly portray a youthful appearance. 

For convenient access to the theater, park your vehicle in the adjacent parking garage and traverse the food court on foot."

Seeing as I've been reviewing my recent Vegas adventures, I should probably get this one out of the draft burner.  I have a habit of letting drafts collect dust on Yelp.  So allow me to finish my four month old thoughts:

Zumanity is said to be "adults only," but it's no Absinthe.  It caters to adults with a few raunchy jokes here and there.  And it caters to Vegas with a few topless acts.  But for the most part, it's very tame and even a bit campy.  I didn't find the show pushing the envelop on anything and it didn't appear at all sensual to me.

I brought the boyfriend.  he enjoyed himself but didn't see why I fuss over Cirque du Soleil so much.  On reflection, I should have taken him to see something a bit more awe-inspiring (like "O").  

A lot of the comedy is just heckling the nearby crowd.  And a lot of the acts highlighted in the program were absent during our particular show.  No midgets, no fat twins.  Perhaps that would have added some flavor to an otherwise lackluster evening.  Maybe I was suspecting something too outside the norm and my expectations were bridging on pornographic?  To me, this was a typical Cirque show with some dirty jokes and sexier outfits thrown into the mix.

50% off tickets for military.  So a good deal to fill a few hours of your time.

We made the conscious decision to patronize this culinary establishment based on an abundance of favorable critiques, thus fostering elevated anticipations on our part. Unfortunately, our gastronomical experience fell short of our lofty expectations, as the victuals served were merely adequate. Specifically, the fish taco exhibited a notable lack of moisture and flavor, while the guacamole accompanying the rolled tacos failed to impress our taste buds with its blandness. Furthermore, we sampled the carne asada taco, which, albeit palatable, did not live up to our expectations. Our spouse opted for the steak and eggs, the appearance of which resembled machaca. Although the dining area appeared well-maintained, the state of the lavatory left much to be desired. In light of our underwhelming experience, we would only consider returning to this eatery in the event that it was the sole option available and our hunger was unrelenting.

Holy SMOKE, this place had so much cigarrette smoke in the air it looked hazy.  It made the dining less enjoyable.  We went for the famous \"Steak Special\". And I must say it was pretty darn good.  The green beans and mash potatoes that accompanied it was enjoyable as well.

"Public House, an eatery that embodies the essence of a contemporary gastropub, boasts an interior design reminiscent of dark wood accents and an atmosphere conducive to indulging in delectable dishes such as poutine and foie gras. In keeping with the Las Vegas tradition of incorporating unique features into their establishments, Public House showcases an extensive wine list, readily accessible through a state-of-the-art iPad interface, which allows patrons to peruse and select from an array of exquisite vintages, thereby enhancing the epicurean experience. Additionally, this culinary hotspot demonstrates proficiency in offering lighter fare options, as evidenced by the succulent scallops entrÃ©e, whose sweetness was complemented by the freshness of the seafood, while the salads, adorned with pomegranate seeds, provided a delightful contrast of flavors and textures."

I must confess that my unwavering admiration for North Kierland had me anticipating an exceptional dining experience at North Arcadia, yet my maiden visit proved to be a somewhat underwhelming affair, save for the visually captivating ambiance. We arrived prior to 11:30 a.m., and although we were merely the fourth or fifth table to be seated, the service we received was regrettably sluggish, with a discernible air of indifference. Furthermore, the zucca chips, which typically rank among my favorite items on North Kierland's menu, were unfortunately overcooked, thereby diminishing their customary appeal. It is worth mentioning that the portion of bucatini with meatballs, priced at $17, was rather modest in size, given the cost. While none of the dishes were unequivocally unpalatable, the total expenditure of $59.00 for three individuals, exclusive of beverages, struck me as marginally excessive, particularly when juxtaposed with the superior quality and comparative affordability offered by neighboring establishments such as T. Cook's or Coup des Tartes, where one can indulge in a delectable meal for a considerably lower price point.

"City Cafe boasts an array of appealing attributes, including their delectable breakfast offerings, pool table, and affordable beer pitchers, all of which contribute to a convivial ambiance reminiscent of an American diner. However, their big burger challenge is a formidable feat, both to witness and undertake. Additionally, their chips arrive in unique wire fry baskets, adding to the eatery's charm. Unfortunately, their cocktail pitchers lack potency, failing to deliver a satisfactory level of intoxication even after prolonged consumption. Furthermore, their culinary offerings are somewhat unpredictable, with their guacamole-topped nachos tasting eerily similar to mayonnaise and their vegetarian burgers suffering from an unfortunate texture issue that results in a soggy, frothy bun. Despite these drawbacks, I frequent City Cafe and will likely continue to do so, albeit with a preference for pints and chips."

This place has a great location in Tivoli Village. They have a good indoor outdoor bar and several inexpensive offerings for happy hour. One of the best features of this restaurant is that they allow your dog to sit out with you on the patio while you dine. 

The food is not traditional (authentic) Mexican food which doesn't bother me. But, the poor execution is an issue. We have eaten here a handful of times. I guess because I keep hoping to select something on the menu that I love. Unfortunately, that hasn't happened. The highlight of the menu is their guacamole and chips which are made table side. Their complimentary salsas are also very tasty. 

I would give Cantina Loredo another try. It's a shame that we haven't found a good Mexican restaurant in the Summerlin area. My husband likes this place a lot more than I do. He is a fan of the fajitas. So, the 3 star review is an average of both of our opinions.

Food and service was good not great but  certaintly not memorable. The noise level is horrendous with the waitress having to almost yell to describe the specials,etc. This was in the dining room too not in the bar. Also, the table are way too close together. Better places can be had nearby.

"I have had the pleasure of visiting various Red Robin establishments throughout the Bay Area, and while it is undeniable that the uniformity of menu items across all franchises is commendable, my personal experience at this particular location was somewhat underwhelming. Admittedly, I do not frequent this restaurant with sufficient regularity to justify a zealous recommendation, but I do acknowledge the appeal of certain menu items. Specifically, the colossal onion ring tower, despite its unremarkable taste, commands respect for its sheer magnitude. Additionally, the chicken pasta dish we shared fell short of my expectations, rendering it an unlikely candidate for future orders. Nonetheless, I must concede that Red Robin does offer some delectable options, such as their fish, fries, and shrimp sampler appetizer, which I have had the pleasure of enjoying on previous occasions. In conclusion, while this establishment may not warrant an enthusiastic endorsement, it is not entirely without merit, and I would still advise others to sample their fare."

I have eaten here two times now the first time it was pretty dead in the place and there was what looked like a group of kid's part of the family... My server seemed to cater to that group over me I am a paying customer keep that in mind... I ordered the General Tso's Chicken (Crunchy fried white meat tossed with scallions in a spicy sauce. I was a good meal nothing above and beyond... The second trip was for a lunch and I ordered the Mongolian beef (Spicy marinated beef saut\u00e9ed with scallions and sweet yellow onions served over a bed of crispy rice noodles and sprinkled with sesame seeds... This was a really good meal and great service so let's hope the third this as good.

In my search for great BBQ this place stands out.  Not only is it tasty but it doesn't irritate my stomach.  That is a major plus in my book.  The one drawback is service.  I've ordered online and arrived at the specified pick up time 30-60 minutes later to still have to wait another 15-20 minutes.  So be advised to just go to the take out counter and order, as it will take just as long.

"I am delighted to be partaking in an evening repast with my dearest kin at this picturesque establishment, the Pointe Hilton Squaw Peak Resort, boasting a tranquil ambiance and delectable culinary offerings. Upon perusing the extensive bill of fare, I was pleased to discover an array of options catering to diverse gastronomic inclinations. Although the service was merely satisfactory, the fare itself was, for the most part, expertly prepared, save for a minor mishap involving the overcooking of the lamb entrÃ©e for one member of our gathering. In conclusion, while not flawless, our dining experience was, on the whole, acceptable."

"The venue offered an enjoyable experience, attributed largely to the convivial atmosphere fostered by the presence of a group of females, complemented by the gratuitous provision of beverages at our table. 

The hospitality extended by the staff was remarkably warm and welcoming, facilitating a seamless dining experience. Although my culinary explorations did not extend beyond the appetizer selection, the fare presented was satisfactory, albeit unremarkable. 

It is advisable to secure reservations in advance, as the establishment tends to attract a significant volume of patrons."

GRIMALDI's PIZZERIA has a lot going for them with tools and technique at the top of the list. to my sensibilities, a coal fired oven really produces the perfect crust and, at least in my experience, GRIMALID's consistantly does it well.

but the quality of their toppings is really no different than the national chains that dispatch pimple-faced kids to your doorstep when you're too tired to drag your ass to a "real" restaurant and that's kind of disappointing.

and i can't say i'm wild about their sauce either. theirs is raw (and "lightly drizzled" over the other toppings so the crust stays crispy) and i'm partial to a long-simmered version -- i enjoy the additional depth of flavor.

so, the quest for the perfect pizza goes on ...

Ah.. the Flamingo.  First time I was there was back in 1987.  My buddy's parents went to Vegas to gamble and I tagged along to keep him company in the arcade as we weren't old enough to drive yet let alone gamble.  We spent a couple hours on a turbo speed Ms. Pacman machine and walked around the strip.  \n\nI haven't been back in that place since, until last week.  It seemed a bit nicer back in the day.  It's a bit dingy now, and walking in from the parking garage you get hit with a wall of stale smoky air reminiscent of a smoking room at a Super 8 Motel.  Blech.  Circulation is better once you make it through the hall.  The layout is confusing, but I was able to enjoy a few Sam Adams on tap at the bar with the owner of my company who had just flown in from Germany so that was nice.  I refrained from playing here though as I have issues with Harrah's properties after enduring some horrendous customer service at their Rincon San Diego casino.

When I lived in the area, I used to come here a lot both to eat in and take out. The quality has gone down a bit over the last year - the last few times we went, the service wasn't great, the portions are getting smaller, plus they are giving too many vegetables and not enough meat. However, they do make a great Pad Thai.

It's a new small place, clean, order at the counter fresh fish fry. They had several types of dips and the french frys were good. No beer :( sad hope that's too come soon. There was plenty served in one serving didn't need more. Husband wished his was crisper and wanted Texas toast.  Fish was white and very good. Coleslaw ok.  Hope they stay and grow - we'll be back.

My maiden voyage to the shooting range transpired to be an enjoyable escapade; however, certain drawbacks tarnished the overall experience. Firstly, the staff members exhibited proficiency in their field, imparting valuable knowledge and ensuring a seamless experience for patrons. Additionally, an extensive array of firearms was available for utilization. Unfortunately, these advantages were counterbalanced by several negative aspects. Specifically, the range was characterized by a high volume of patrons, leading to extended waiting periods, particularly during peak days of the week. Furthermore, the physical space was limited, resulting in a cramped environment with individuals occupying every available spot, including the floor and corners, and shoulders were literally rubbing against each other. Moreover, the range officers appeared flustered, struggling to manage the throngs of people and maintain order amidst the chaos. Lastly, the cost of utilizing the range was deemed steep, with a shared lane, gun, and ammunition for a mere thirty minutes totaling a whopping eighty-eight dollars, which included a fifteen-dollar fee per weapon. Despite these limitations, the range still presents itself as a suitable destination for those interested in partaking in such activities, though it is crucial to be cognizant of the aforementioned constraints.

"In pursuit of Shrimp Pad Thai, I conducted a Google search, which led me to this establishment. Upon placing an order for pick-up, I was informed that it would be ready within 15 minutes, much to my delight. However, upon arriving at the venue, I encountered a rather unsettling situation regarding parking. Specifically, the designated parking area was situated down a dimly lit drive-thru/alleyway, which caused me some apprehension due to the presence of a worker who appeared to be smoking in the corner. To avoid any potential discomfort, I suggest that patrons consider parking their vehicles on Spring Mountain and walking around to Valley instead.  

Upon entering the restaurant, I was immediately struck by the warm and welcoming ambiance created by the friendly staff. Moreover, the dish itself was quite flavorful, with a spicy level of four that left a lasting impression on my taste buds. However, I must admit that I was slightly disappointed by the noodles, which were noticeably thinner than what I was accustomed to - almost akin to angel hair pasta, if you will. Additionally, the shrimp used in the dish were of a smaller variety, which didn't quite meet my expectations. Nevertheless, despite these minor shortcomings, the dish remained enjoyable, and I would still recommend it to others. In fact, I might even go so far as to suggest ordering larger shrimp in the future, provided that one has the opportunity to sample the regular dish initially, as I did."

Very cozy, love the various rooms ad seating opportunities. Must be a great place to hang in the warmer weather on the patio. 

Lost a star for two reasons:
1)they pour the cream for you. I didn't realize this and would have specified skim milk ahead of time, but instead watched a big glug of half-and-half go into my husband's coffee. They were very accommodating and made me a new one, but I would still like to be able to doctor my coffee myself. 

2)The music is a radio station, complete with annoying, repetitive GreatClips ads (Men's haircuts just $7.99!!!). Come on, just plug in an iPod and play some constant music. No one wants to listen to radio ads while chilling at the coffee house. 

Coffee was fine. The food looked good; people have complained about the prices, but why are you going to a coffee place for food? It was maybe a dollar on the pricey side, I guess. 

I have no problem with the presence of beer, but what with the beer and the gigantic PIZZA banner out front, it makes me wonder if Hob Nobs is struggling with identity. Pick one and go with it, please. 

Overall a pleasant experience; just a few glitches.

I harbored lofty expectations for Cheddatruck, as I possess an unwavering fondness for a delectable burger, which, unquestionably, ranks among my most beloved culinary indulgences. Alas, Cheddatruck failed to captivate my taste buds, leaving me feeling underwhelmed and unimpressed. My companion, who shares my ardor for burgers, eagerly anticipated the opportunity to sample their mac-n-cheese embellished burger, only to be thwarted by the absence of this pivotal ingredient. Thus, he settled for an alternative option, adorned with an egg, while I opted for a straightforward cheeseburger. In addition, we elected to order tots, handcrafted, no less.  

Unfortunately, our burgers proved to be merely passable, with mine suffering from a slight overcooking and a general dearth of flavor. My companion concurred, describing his burger as unremarkable and forgettable. The tots, despite their artisanal preparation, disappointed us, lacking the rich, savory flavors we had anticipated, even with the presence of cheese within them and the accompaniment of an herb-infused cream cheese dipping sauce. Moreover, the price of $3 for a mere seven tots struck us as somewhat exorbitant. 

In conclusion, taking into account the cost, numerous superior burger alternatives exist in the vicinity, rendering Cheddatruck's offerings inferior and, thus, not worth consideration. My apologies, Cheddatruck; your culinary endeavors have fallen short, prompting me to bid thee adieu.

"While on vacation in Phoenix from Chicago, I opted to dine at this establishment based on a recommendation from a friend. Upon arriving, I was met with an extensive wait time that I deemed rather excessive, had I not been on holiday and disposed to relax and pass the time, I would not have waited three hours for a table elsewhere. However, the delay was rendered tolerable by the entertaining ambiance of the adjacent bar. The pizza served was undoubtedly flavorful and the wine selection was satisfactory, yet, having been accustomed to the superior quality of authentic Italian pizza in my hometown, I found the culinary experience to be merely adequate, rather than exceptional. Nonetheless, the eatery presented a commendable display of fresh ingredients and a satisfying dining atmosphere, ultimately yielding an enjoyable evening once seated."

I have never gambled here, nor had a meal in any of there Restaurants.  I have really only been here to go see a movie in the theater.  So, with that said.... parking was easy, all of the employees we came into contact with were nice and the signage was easy to follow.  So, I have no complaints nor did I have any expectations.  I will update my review if I ever do anything substantial here.
One of the larger Second Cup around.  Always tons of fresh goods.\n\nCan get busy on Sundays where students come to study.

"I recently partook in a culinary excursion to this establishment, seeking to indulge in their gastronomical offerings, specifically their pizza, as part of my ongoing quest to sample an array of pizza varieties from diminutive, family-owned restaurants. Prior to my visit, I had cultivated a predilection for such establishments, as they often exhibit a more personalized and hospitable ambiance, in contrast to the more impersonal nature of larger pizza chains. Upon entering the premises, I was greeted by a congenial staff who displayed a welcoming demeanor, contributing to an atmosphere that was inviting and pleasant. However, my enthusiasm was tempered by the dearth of patrons, which raised concerns regarding the eatery's popularity and reputation. Following a brief interval of approximately 20 minutes, my pizza was presented, yet its appearance seemed somewhat haphazard, prompting apprehensions regarding its quality. Unfortunately, my concerns were substantiated upon consuming the pizza, as it lacked a certain je ne sais quoi and failed to elicit an extraordinary degree of culinary satisfaction. Despite this, I remain open to revisiting this establishment in the future, as I believe that each dining experience presents an opportunity for growth and improvement."

Came in super late for some munchies and to cure our sweet tooth. I got the bread pudding and my friend got the french toast. The food was solid, but the service was less than desirable. The bartender was more concerned with her phone and gossip than being personable to us.

If the café out of Eastenders were real, I'm pretty sure this is what it would be like. I've never seen somewhere that better sums up the definition of "good old greasy-spoon café" as well as Brambles.

It's only just opened, and I assumed it would be yet another of these sandwich/wrap/panini type places that Edinburgh is crawling with, but I was very wrong. Although Brambles do offer things like baked potatoes and paninis, their specialty is anything fried served with chips and buttered bread. And I mean literally everything - from good old chicken nuggets, chips and beans to remind you of school dinner days, to friend haggis and chips and mushy peas.

They did have some slightly healthier options on the menu, like lasagne (served with chips, of course!) but it's not really the kind of place you go to eat healthy food. The lace curtains, neon sign in the window and plastic tables should be the most off-putting thing you've ever seen, but it works in that sort of way that it's so bad it's good. It's kitsch, a bit tacky and dated, despite only being open a few weeks, but it does exactly what it says on the tin and serves good honest junk food at really reasonable prices.

Definitely not as good as Ka or O, but not a bad show to watch in Las Vegas.

Don't get me wrong, the acrobatics were very impressive. However, the show as a whole was kind of slow... (My mom fell asleep a bunch of times). Also, the little acts between the shows were long, and useless (in my opinion).

Anyways, if you are watching a Cirque du Soleil show for the first time, you will be impressed by Mystere. However, if you have seen other shows, I would skip this show and watch something else instead.

My partner and I partook in a preliminary dinner at a novel eatery. The ambiance was reminiscent of a masculine refuge, which was quite agreeable to my preferences. This establishment would be an excellent venue to indulge in a delectable burger and beverage on a Saturday afternoon while enjoying a sporting event or to treat a romantic companion on a weeknight. The Grind has proven to be a valuable dining alternative for the Arcadia community!  

The hospitality staff displayed exceptional cordiality and attention to detail. Kudos to them for their well-organized efforts during the inaugural evening.  

My partner and I opted to share a delectable melted rosemary brie complemented by strawberry relish. The brie cheese exuded rich flavor, and its texture was enhanced by the subtle infusion of rosemary essence. The accompanying strawberry relish showcased notable intensity. A balsamic reduction sauce would elevate this dish to new heights.  

Our culinary exploration continued with the BLT burger and the Sweet and Spicy Burger. The 1000-degree coal fire oven effectively sealed in the juices and produced a satisfying crunch on the exterior of the patty. Freshness and palatability characterized all additional components. The bun exhibited a delightful contrast between its toasted surface and soft, spongy interior.  

The fries could benefit from refinement; however, it is essential to consider that this was merely a preliminary launch.  

The beverage menu boasts innovation and educational value.  

I eagerly anticipate revisiting this establishment in the future.

"Although this establishment possesses certain qualities that are appreciable, it is essential to acknowledge that an analogous dining experience can be obtained at a nearby location, specifically Eastern Pizza, where the culinary offerings are not only comparable but also superior in terms of quality and richness. It is conceivable that the pizza provided at this venue may have been slightly undercooked, resulting in a lack of crispiness, and the flavors may have been somewhat muted. Thus, while consuming food at this establishment may not necessarily result in profound disappointment, it is crucial to recognize that forgoing the opportunity to partake in the gastronomic delights offered by Grimaldi's Pizza, situated in close proximity, would constitute a significant omission."

establishment is great, and quite large. We were immediately greeted and seated. Our waiter was very friendly and made us feel comfortable
I ordered the 12oz NY strip steak MEDIUM RARE.
It took about 30-45minutes and I was quite disappointed. My steak was overcooked, nowhere near medium rare, I could of made a scene and complained but my body was in much need of protein so I ate it and told our waiter to notify the chef about the overcooked steak. They apologized and offered me a new steak but I was in a rush and hungry so I was letting it slide.  Giving it another chance next time I come back to Vegas

Establishment 4/5
Waiter/Staff 4/5
Food 3/5
Price 2/5 (lower score the pricer it is)
Cleanlines 4/5

Overall 3/5

Vovomeena why were you so hard to find!!! Whether you're driving down McDowell or 7th avenue you won't see it. Maybe we just missed it, but I didn't see any sign whatsoever. The only one was right about their door, but you can't see it well from the street. We got lost and drove around and couldn't find it. I had to text my sister to see where it's at. 

I ordered the banging pocket which I didn't think was very banging. Lol. It comes with sausage and eggs wrapped in a pita with a side of potatoes. It would've been nice with some onions or mushrooms or something. It just wasn't anything great. 

There isn't a lot of seating at the restaurant. You probably have to come early to get a table or you'll end up sitting outside in the hot weather. They should really install misters. The service was really good but it was a far drive for mediocre food.

This would be a 3.5 star place - 

Love the old vegas look, cheap prices, glittery light show, and more local feel.  99 cent frozen chocolate covered bananas are the bomb!  Hennessey's is a great value with really good food.  2 dollar blackjack!  Fresh donuts from Krispy Kreme!  Free shows (good and bad).

Not in love with the rude people (but they're everywhere).  The casinos have low ceilings, which means lots of cigarette smoke lingering.  Wouldn't walk far from the light show, but plenty of security on the strip itself.

In general, it's a good contrast to the mega-corporate new strip, doesn't have the awesome food, but doesn't have the awe-inspiring prices either.  A lot of fun for the right reasons.  Just a matter of what you're in the mood for.

Just remember:  Vegas is about fun - and the Fremont Street Experience packs a lot of it into a 3.5 short blocks.

From all the other reviews I read it appears my experience was the same as many others: great atmosphere, good good, terrible service. 

I go up for a refill of my coffee and a worker is standing in front of the espresso machine pouring herself and drinking espresso shots. After standing there for about a minute I finally say something to her, "Could I please have a refill?" She then decides to acknowledge my existence and hastily pours me a refill. 

The coffee tasted great and so did my sandwich, but I don't think I should have to wait for the barista to finish her self-poured shots of espresso before I'm allowed to get my refill.

It's not a bad hotel for the price.  Really.

The room I stayed in was fine (save for some odd stains on the curtains), the casino and show offerings are about standard (Carrot Top, Criss Angel), and there's a fairly diverse selection of restaurants.

That said, if you want to drop an extra $40 or $50 a night and stay somewhere else, I'd probably recommend doing that.  While I'd take the Luxor over the Imperial Palace, it's certainly no Caesar's or Mandalay Bay.

Dalkeith Road is so sad-looking. I don't know how a street can looks sad, but it does. It's sort of saying 'I'm out of the way, I'm long and there are other roads parallel to me that are much better and get there quicker. sigh.' Is it possible to feel sorry for a road? 

Anyway

C's Tasty Bites thus lacks the va va voom I look for in a snack shop. It tries, nonetheless, and 10/10 for effort. 
The place itself is small, I think too small to breathe so only ever come here for take-away. The price is alright and the food isn't amazing, but maybe i;m lacking enthusiasm because when I leave i'm left with Dalkeith road. aw.

"I decided to stop by for a beverage after work prior to proceeding home to surprise, and was informed by staff that if I opted to utilize a debit card as my method of payment, a minimum purchase of $10 would be required. This prompted me to ponder why such a stipulation would exist, particularly when it comes to the type of payment employed. Generally, I would consume an amount in excess of $10, but on this particular occasion, I found myself constrained by time. Furthermore, upon inquiring about the possibility of settling my tab with physical currency, I was met with an affirmative response, albeit accompanied by the caveat that the ATM was currently non-functional. While this turn of events did not typically bother me, it nevertheless proved vexing under the present circumstances."

MGM is an acceptable lodging establishment if one can procure a reasonable tariff... The check-in and check-out processes at MGM, like those of its fellow hotels along the Las Vegas Strip, necessitate a considerable amount of time devoted to queuing. However, upon gaining entry to my accommodations, I was pleasantly surprised by their quality, particularly in regards to the efficacy of the blackout shades, which performed exceptionally well in obstructing solar illumination. Additionally, the internet connectivity was relatively rapid, the miniature bar offered an adequate assortment of potables, and I had the good fortune of being assigned to a floor that was relatively tranquil. 

It is worth mentioning that the superior dining establishments affiliated with MGM surpassed my expectations, with the notable exception of Fiamma, which failed to impress. 

Unfortunately, several drawbacks were also encountered, including uninspired and, on occasion, discourteous blackjack dealers, inadequate cocktail service in the blackjack area, a lack of shaded areas around the pool (which, given the intense heat of the Las Vegas sun, made lounging by the water somewhat challenging), an inability of the room's air conditioning unit to effectively cool the space, and substantial throngs of people in all public areas. 

In conclusion, while MGM may not be the optimal choice for lodging among the multitude of options available along the Strip, it remains a passable alternative for those who prefer to stay in this vicinity.

"The staff members appear to be selectively attentive, wherein they opt to listen only to the aspects of customers' orders that align with their preconceived notions or preferences, thereby conveniently disregarding the remaining components of the instructions. This phenomenon was exemplified when I barely managed to utter the word 'cafe' before the staff member in question hastily departed, leaving me wondering whether my desire for condensed milk had been adequately conveyed. Furthermore, the menu's layout seemed to be intentionally designed to perplex and confuse, with an absence of rice plates as the primary option, which struck me as a glaring oversight. Notwithstanding my grievances, the egg rolls were indeed impressive, boasting an abundance of filling; and the coffee, though served via an antiquated metal drip mechanism, was nonetheless palatable, particularly when accompanied by a cup of ice. As for the pho, while its quality was undeniable, the sweltering temperature of 105 degrees Fahrenheit made consuming a sizeable, steaming bowl of noodles somewhat less appealing."

"The culinary establishment under investigation is situated within the lobby premises of the Westin hotel, where I was temporarily residing; however, I refrained from partaking of their gastronomical offerings due to their subpar ratings on the popular review platform, Yelp. On the final evening of my tenure, I was exhausted and had worked late into the evening, thus opting to sample their fare.  

Upon perusing their bill of fare, I discovered an array of delectable options, including an assortment of seafood and sushi dishes that piqued my interest, although I ultimately settled on a pair of sushi rolls. The quality of the sushi was satisfactory, and their draft beer selection was quite impressive. Based solely on the culinary aspect, I would assign a rating of 3.5 stars, nearing the threshold of four; however, this assessment was derived from a limited sampling of their offerings. Thus, I shall endeavor to partake of their cuisine once more. 

Unfortunately, their service left much to be desired, potentially contributing to their mediocre reputation. The bar area was moderately populated, while the dining area was largely unoccupied; yet, patrons seated at the bar were compelled to signal the bartender to garner his attention, and the preparation time for my meager order of two sushi rolls exceeded 25 minutes. These factors might account for their suboptimal rating. Since I shall likely be extending my stay at this Westin for an indeterminate period, I shall consider giving their eatery another chance in the future."

The good: great flavors- the pork is delicious, different options, clean and friendly team

The bad: this is my first time here so my biggest concern was the temperature of the food. I came for a late lunch, I get it, but didn't feel like the items were super fresh or hot. I think this would have been different should I have come during lunch or dinner hour. My other suggestion: the sauces should've served warm, not cold.

Overall, I enjoyed it and would try it again. Love the concept.

"I had the privilege of indulging in the delectable brisket at a local establishment recently, and I must say that it thoroughly satiated my gastronomical desires. The meat was cooked to perfection, boasting an optimal balance of tenderness and juiciness that left me yearning for more. While I did appreciate the addition of the savory sauce, I would request that it be served on the side during my subsequent visit, thereby allowing me to relish the unadulterated flavor of the brisket without any distractions."

Spent $200 on 2 ppl when u have a $200 dinner  u have high expectations. My Girl hated her steak it was dry the sauces they offered where nasty, My beef wellington was good but not great, the mac and cheese is hella dry ,,,, why?????? overall more hype... u pay for the environment and the way they serve the food. Will not return but will try Burgar next  time.

Located in close proximity to the renowned Rio All-Suite Hotel and Casino, the Flamingo hotel boasts an unparalleled position, rendering it easily accessible by foot for those who relish a leisurely stroll along the Las Vegas Strip. However, it is worth noting that the pedestrian route traverses an overhead bridge above the highway, which may not be the most scenic or enjoyable trek. Despite its unpretentious nature, this establishment offers exceptional value for money, with tariffs that are considerably reasonable compared to neighboring luxury resorts. As a subsidiary of Coast Properties, this hotel benefits from an abundance of on-site facilities, effectively rendering it self-sufficient and obviating the need for guests to venture beyond its confines in search of dining or entertainment options. Thus, for travelers seeking a relaxed ambiance and economical accommodations, this venue is certainly worthy of consideration, allowing them to experience the vibrant spirit of Las Vegas without breaking the bank.

Didn't come here to eat just drink but can't really go wrong with 2.50 coronas this is definitely is a college bar and a bit noisy what's wierd is there Oregon duck fans and not ASU fans? Great place for day drinking though

Typical mall but a bit over priced and not geared towards locals. Definetly a tourist trap mall but still has a few nice specialty shops and occasionally a good sale here or there. The coffee bean here is awesome and the mall has free yoga on sundays at lululemon so thats a plus as well.
Popped in for a few tacos today... The carne asada was lacking in flavor, no marinade, and pretty bland. The carnitas were very good and I'd eat a dozen at one sitting :)

Nice local establishment with great food and fantastic patio to hang out on in the summer . The interior is dark and the tvs need to be bigger and placed in better viewing areas . If you don't know where this place is , it is Kind of hard to explain to people how to there . Still a nice clean and safe place to hang out .

"This eatery can be classified as a typical Chinese dining establishment, offering culinary fare at a reasonable price point. As part of their lunchtime offerings, a meager $5.95 affords a clientele an entrÃ©e accompanied by a beverage. The level of hospitality displayed by the staff is commendable, as they exhibit attentive behavior, periodically inquiring about the satisfaction of their patrons and ensuring that glasses remain filled in a timely fashion. Unfortunately, the gastronomical offerings themselves are merely adequate, which is unsurprising given the affordable pricing. Furthermore, it is worth mentioning that the presentation of the food appears somewhat lackluster, as the utilization of Styrofoam containers and absence of serving utensils detracts from the overall visual appeal. In conclusion, this dining establishment is suitable for those seeking a rapid and economical meal, but may not cater to the preferences of more discerning gourmands."

I've frequented this location a couple times & I've never had an issue with them, service or food wise. I just enjoyed a peanut buster parfait & it was just like the picture, how many restaurants can say that!, lol  when I'm in the mood for DQ & I'm in the area I'll stop in here for a bite

After having such a horrible experience at Babystacks (see prior review), my friend and I drove over to Lulu's. I don't know if it was the contrast to the poor service we just experienced but it was so nice to have such good service.  Although  you order at the counter, you can sit in the Metro pizza area which is easier with kids. Also, they brought out drinks over to us, which again helps with kids. They didn't bat an eye when my friend sent her egg back because she forgot to ask for it to be over hard instead of over easy as it normally comes. The manager is always nice and has gone out of her way to make us feel welcome before. 

 I had the Herman breakfast sandwich, a little pricey (about $8 if I remember correctly), but I love that it comes on a pretzel bun and it is surprisingly filling for just being a sandwich. It is just the sandwich with egg, sausage, cheese and a stone ground mustard. 

I have had the chocolate croissant before and it was okay - but of course I am a chocolate croissant aficionado (aka snob) and really only like the traditional french chocolate croissant (as served at Patisserie Manon and the Baguette Cafe). The lemon tart is really good and reminds me of a sour cream lemon pie my hubby makes which is phenomenal. They usually have cookie and muffin samples out which is nice.

"While my sojourn in Phoenix was underway, I elected to peruse the evaluations on Yelp to identify an optimal purveyor of donuts that could cater to my unwavering predilection for the delectable treat. Although Lamar's positioned itself as a mid-range establishment, my expectations remained grounded in the hope of securing a scorching hot and fresh batch of classic glazed donuts, which, regrettably, proved unattainable during my visit. However, despite the absence of optimal donut consumption conditions, my overall experience did not descend into utter disappointment."

Specialty food should be special. There should be a reason why you pay a bit extra for a few morsels of goodness. Reid's has a lock on these specialty foods with a nice looking meat department, array of choice cheeses and impressive wine selection. Let's break down this location a bit, shall we?

The Good: As mentioned, it's a great spot to grab a quick bite, snag a bottle of wine, some tasty snacks and get on your merry way. The service is pretty spectacular - whether your seeking said bottle of wine or dining on a sandwich during lunch. Many of the sandwiches and salads I saw coming around looked fresh and delicious. Also, there's a decent sized wine bar next to the wine vault/selection area that could kick your feet up while you taste away. 

The Meh: The parking is pretty much horrendous. Unless you're stealing parking from business across the street, you better be comfortable walking a ways. The sandwich I ate here was underwhelming - the grilled pimento cheese was gut busting-ly greasy (granted, it's grilled pimento cheese) and also missed the zing I was looking for. I barely got through half of the sloppy mess and had to put it down for fear that I may have a heart attack in the shop. 

If I'm walkin' around Selwyn and need to score a few snacks before heading home, Reid's is a fine choice, yet they definitely have plenty of competition in the area if we're talking tasty sandwiches and wine tasting!

"The delectable crepes boast an array of flavors, ranging from the traditional simplicity of lemon juice to the richness of Nutella complemented by bananas. In contrast, the savory crepes appear unimaginative and lacking in inspiration. However, the inviting ambiance of the coffee shop, enhanced by the well-crafted coffee, compensates for the deficiency. Unfortunately, the service has been inconsistent, marred by the presence of a bothersome fly during our last two visits."

"Upon entering the establishment, one is immediately struck by the presence of a mechanical bull, which serves as a central focal point within the venue and lends an air of rugged excitement to the proceedings. The atmosphere is further enhanced by the abundance of masculine patrons, whose boisterous revelry contributes to the overall ambiance of the establishment. The auditory senses are similarly stimulated by the high volume of the musical offerings, which serve to augment the convivial nature of the gathering. Of particular note, however, are the exceptional quality of the lettuce wraps served by the establishment, which truly distinguishes itself from the standard fare typically associated with such establishments. While the author's experience with similar venues may be limited, it is evident that this particular location offers a unique and enjoyable initiation into the local nightlife."

"I have been frequenting this establishment for approximately a decade, and while I have had a strong affinity for their culinary offerings in the past, recent experiences have left me feeling somewhat disillusioned and disappointed. The issues that have been raised by other patrons, such as the limited quantity of meat on the sandwiches, the high prices, and the sluggish service, have unfortunately become increasingly apparent. Furthermore, I must express my dismay at the lack of environmental consciousness displayed by the restaurant, as evidenced by their refusal to reuse punch cards and instead opting to discard and replace them, resulting in unnecessary waste. Despite these criticisms, I may still continue to visit, albeit with reduced frequency."

"The advantages of this establishment include an affordable menu featuring fresh culinary offerings, delectable milkshakes, a pristine dining environment, affable and welcoming staff members, and a unique pepper bar. However, the drawbacks consist of an uninspired and lackluster dining area, an awkward layout within the dining room, unoriginal menu selections, and pre-made salad dressings. While it may be suitable for a rapid burger craving, in my view, alternative burger venues in the locality are preferable."

This is definitely a bento box place that is a GREAT place to go to just pick up some sushi for lunch that tastes yummy and reasonably priced. However, this place is NOT awesome for a sit down date. 

They serve the sushi in the to-go packages, and there are no real silverware available. It's just disposable stuff and styrofoam cups. They also didn't have any sugar for their tea. It took quite a while for the rolls to be made as well. The service was very spacey - like the guy didn't know what he was doing.

HOWEVER, their roll (rainbow roll) was AWESOME and their green tea was TO DIE FOR. They don't serve any white fish (at least they didn't when I was there). I would definitely recommend this as a place to pick up a good lunch, but not as a date or a dinner meal.

"A pleasing culinary establishment removed from the gambling venues, offering an assortment of delectable seafood dishes, proficiently prepared and presented with a satisfactory degree of taste, although not particularly remarkable in terms of their flavor profile; complemented by a clean and welcoming ambiance, both indoors and outdoors, with ample parking facilities and unremarkable restrooms, resulting in an overall assessment of 7/10, with a personal preference for the adjacent Texas de Brazil, rated significantly higher at 9/10."

Walked in and the SeaHawkers club had just left.  The place was a wreck and they were scrambling to get the tables cleaned and the restaurant back in order.\n\nGood service, good food and cold drinks.  Use the 4Square app and unlock an additional dollar off your drinks, even during happy hour.

Fun environment, good service.

If you are tired of high prices for average drinks, then this is another place to bring a flask to. I did not see a single tap and the beers are kinda standard; nothing to exciting and prices just over reasonable.

Been there 3 times and the bartenders are attentive and helpful. One bartender accidentally gave me too many beers in a bucket and other other politely explained to me that "she gave you an extra, enjoy it and don't worry, but I didn't want you to be surprised when there is 1 less next time." This is a situation that makes guest service snobs like me very proud to give an establishment by business.

I gave it a 3 star because overall the hotel was just ok, I did expect It to be better..  First time at the Trump hotel and found mold food in the refrigerator!! Customer service is not that great..Housekeeping took forever to clean my room, I did call early in the morning to inform them I need housekeeping which was provided but finish around 3pm... The hotel is away from the strip..we have to take taxi to and from Caesars Palace even though there was shuttle provided because we have to wait at least more then 25 min. Shuttle does stop at midnight which sucks because we can't enjoy ourselves just worrying the shuttle will stop soon and that's why we have to take taxi which charge us $20 plus tips and taxi driver doesn't want just $1 tip, they want more....
It's best to stay on the strip so no more taxi or shuttle rides !!
Pros:
Quiet, luxurious, doesn't smell, kitchen in the suites, luxurious bathroom
Cons:
just a few minor things. The shuttles stop way too early and it take a long time to pick you up. It's far away from the strip if you were to walk..there's really nothing to do at the hotel..it's just a basic hotel with a pool and a gym..

great eats, even if you don't get the all you can eat spaghetti. Had the arugula and white bean salad plus two penne pasta dishes. Both very good. Good Italian food in a nice atmosphere at decent prices with good waitstaff.

we have gone to this \"ol'school (of the strip, local)\" restaurant/casino/brewery a ew tims (btw are you confused yet---so am I)\nto say the least it is a jack of all trades but, you cant beat there breakfasts, cheap and good, last time i went it was steak and eggs for $3.99. as i stated previoulsy this is also a brewery and they make there own root beer, yeah its good stuff..this is not a place i would staay at or even gasmble at but its good bang for your buck......last time i went with my pops in law we had a coupon all u can drink for 1 whole hour, no purchase necessary, i think we rocked 22 coronas, pretty awesome...

"Our dining experience was marred by an overwhelmed server who appeared flustered by the numerous tables she was attending to, and we felt somewhat inconvenient when requesting a replenishment of celery sticks, which were scantily provided alongside the delectable buffalo wings that boasted an impressive quality, albeit with varying degrees of spiciness; specifically, the mango-spicy variety was quite piquant, while the garlic Asian version was noticeably milder, and the jerk chicken offering was surprisingly bland, thus rendering the overall enjoyment of the meal somewhat inconsistent; furthermore, we were taken aback by the unexpected charge for additional celery refills, which amounted to $1.20, a sum we deemed disproportionate considering the minimal cost of a single celery stalk."

Napa location is on a different level compared to Vegas. The food and service at the bar were both a little rough. Our server/bartender completely forgot about us several times and we had to reorder a few times as well. In addition, I overheard the bartender blame the chef for an error in food to a customer. I thought that was very unprofessional. Quality of the food did not seem up to par from my previous experiences in Napa.

"I must confess an unwavering fondness for Trader Joe's; may I be so bold as to express my enthusiasm for this establishment? The prices and quality of their nuts (encompassing almonds, pecans, walnuts, et al.) and nut-based products (including almond butter, and so forth) are, in my humble opinion, unparalleled. Furthermore, their produce is of exceptional quality, and they offer an array of unique items that are simply unattainable elsewhere. Allow me to emphasize my unequivocal endorsement of Joe Joe's; indeed, it is nothing short of magnificent! 

However, I must deduct two stars from my rating due to the following factors:

1. The quest for a parking spot during peak hours (specifically between 12 pm and 1 pm from Monday to Friday) borders on the impossible. Accept the challenge at your own peril, dear reader! 

2. Lamentably, the store's dimensions are rather diminutive, leaving me with an inescapable feeling of disappointment. In spite of these drawbacks, I maintain that Trader Joe's is an outstanding retailer."

Oh Treasure Island, and your old-school pirate show, where have you gone?  Welcome to TI, and the scantily clad pirate show...my have times have changed.  Across the street from the Venetian/Palazzo sits TI.  Definitely has seen better days, and by that I mean pretty much everything.  Rooms, casino, food.  If you want to save a few bucks and stay down at this end of the Strip, this is your place.  Just be prepared to hear the pirate show every night!

You know, after going back to the convention for a second year and eating at the Golden Palace Buffet again, I have to say that ordering off of the menu provided a significant improvement over the buffet.\n\nThe food wasn't nearly as greasy and was actually quite flavorful.  I was pleased with my meal and I'm sure my friends were, too.  My friend, who was wearing a giant costume, was treated with courtesy.

"Preferring a culinary experience characterized by a pleasant combination of texture and flavor, specifically, a dish wherein the tofu is cooked to a satisfying firmness, devoid of excessive softness or squishiness, I placed an order for the yellow curry tofu, anticipating a delightful repast. Unfortunately, the restaurant's interpretation of this popular Thai dish fell short of my expectations, as the tofu was presented in a state of uninspiring softness, lacking the crispy exterior and tender interior that I had hoped for. Instead of being expertly fried or otherwise prepared, the tofu was merely cut into small pieces and added to the curry without further ado. While the rich, well-spiced curry sauce and generous portion of vegetables did somewhat compensate for this disappointment, the overall effect was diminished by the absence of a satisfying textural contrast. Notwithstanding this letdown, the eatery does offer a diverse selection of Thai dishes at reasonable prices during the lunch hour, and the unpretentious ambiance of the establishment, replete with high-top tables by the window and conventional tables inside, provided a suitable setting for a casual meal. However, the dearth of patrons during our weekday visit suggested that the restaurant may struggle to attract a consistent clientele."

"Upon returning to Las Vegas from an excursion to Phoenix, we opted to halt at this particular Subway establishment, strategically positioned on the right-hand side of the thoroughfare leading towards our destination. 

My order consisted of a 6-inch BMT sandwich, augmented with jalapeno cheddar bread, which I requested to be toasted. Furthermore, I customized my sandwich by adding an assortment of vegetables, including tomatoes, lettuce, green peppers, pepperoncinis, mustard, mayonnaise, oil, vinegar, salt, and pepper. The accommodating staff expedited the preparation of my meal, enabling me to partake in it without any significant delay. 

The quality of the ingredients utilized in the sandwich was exceptional, thereby contributing to its delectable flavor. This impromptu dining experience served as an optimal respite during our journey. Additionally, it is worth mentioning that the establishment boasts well-maintained restrooms, which are a welcome amenity for travelers seeking a brief pit stop. In light of the fact that every service station in Wickenberg was brimming with travelers availing themselves of the facilities, it is judicious to consider this Subway location as a viable alternative. 

In conclusion, based on the positive experience we had, it is highly likely that we shall revisit this eatery on future excursions between Phoenix and Las Vegas."

"During our most recent sojourn in Las Vegas, my associates and I opted to take advantage of an offer that allowed us to lodge at Treasure Island at a price that was considerably lower than usual. Upon arriving at the establishment, we observed the presence of a restaurant specializing in Vietnamese cuisine, which we found rather peculiar. Furthermore, we expressed our skepticism regarding the quality of the fare served within said eatery, as evidenced by our derisive comments directed towards those who had chosen to partake in their meals there, and presumably, pay an elevated price for the experience. Ironically, we would later find ourselves returning to the very same venue, albeit under different circumstances, as we sought sustenance to alleviate the unpleasant symptoms brought about by our excessive consumption of alcoholic beverages during the previous night's festivities. In conclusion, while the cost of dining at this particular Pho restaurant may be somewhat prohibitive, it remains a viable option for those seeking nourishment in the midst of a debilitating hangover, particularly for those already lodging at Treasure Island."

"It is rather perplexing that the culinary offerings at mainland L&Ls seem to lack the distinct flavor profile associated with those from Hawaii. The fare is palatable yet uninspired, which is somewhat disappointing given the brand's reputation for serving quality local-style comfort food. Furthermore, patrons should exercise vigilance when settling their bills, as the menu board prices may not align with the actual amount charged. Upon bringing this discrepancy to the attention of the staff member responsible for processing my transaction, their response was dismissive and unhelpful, citing the computerized system as the basis for the inconsistency. This raises concerns regarding the establishment's pricing policies and practices, which could potentially undermine customer trust and loyalty."

Had dinner with a large group. We had a superb wine, but I'm sure it was not cheap and was chosen by the host of the dinner. The food? Well...the chopped salad was pretty mediocre, and too filling with all the red kidney beans it it. The table breads and muffins were too dry, kind of inedible.

Duck pancake...like someone had poured half a bottle of cheap, sweet syrup on it so who knows what the duck tasted like.

The porterhouse lamb chops - very good. This was by far the best thing I had. The lamb was perfectly grilled, and the sauce was inoffensive so you could enjoy the meat. 

Dessert - that warm, pudding-like cake that I can't remember. It was good, and chocolate. Like many restaurants they served the dessert and then came around asking for coffee as kind of an afterthought. The coffee service took so long that it was tough to wait on eating the cake. Dang, I like coffee WITH dessert. But, most restaurants haven't figured out how to serve both at around the same time.

The restaurant is a nice spot in Caesars so I don't want to dissuade people from going. But, I'd make the grilled meat the centerpiece of what you order and not get too high on hope for the rest, based on what I experienced. And get a nice bottle of wine to go with it!

It is a Wal-Mart store location that has recently opened its doors to the public, and my initial thoughts were that perhaps it might possess a distinct ambiance, a departure from the conventional Wal-Mart experience to which I had grown accustomed. However, upon entering the premises, I was quickly disabused of such notion, as it became apparent that this establishment adhered to the standard template associated with the Wal-Mart brand, complete with an array of unremarkable products offered at prices designed to appeal to budget-conscious consumers. Furthermore, the clientele that frequents this store appears to be drawn from the same demographic that has come to be synonymous with the Wal-Mart shopping experience, as depicted on websites such as peopleofwalmart.com, characterized by an atmosphere in which children vociferously proclaim their knowledge of numerals, while adults engage in behaviors that impede the progress of others, all within an environment that seems tailored to accommodate the preferences of senior citizens who prefer a leisurely pace when navigating the various aisles.

This is a 'Superstore' and the biggest close by supermarket for Leith / Shore residents. 

It has 2 entrances one at the Tesco Car park at the back and the back entrance on Duke Street. 

It is a Tesco supermarket and they do what supermarkets do. In addition to that they have also clothes and electricals available.

For a so-called Superstore it is a little small. but it supplies what is needed and it is open from 06:00 till Midnight. 

Be aware that the law of baying alcohol before 10am  and after 10pm also counts for supermarkets.. Some Leith residents tend to 'forget' that rule and get into a discussion a the till. - happened a few times. 

They have a section dedicated to self-service tills and 2 fast lane basket only cashiers. 

They are not as frequently visited by me, certainly after the whole Horse meat scandal. But they are a handy go to for packaged products. Whiskies, spirits, wine and chocolates. - that's about it. 

Not the worst of shops, but not the best either

"Based on the copious acclaim this establishment had received, I was anticipating an exceptional experience, but unfortunately, it fell short of my expectations. Notwithstanding, I must commend the ambiance and aesthetic appeal of the venue, which were undeniably impressive. My beverage of choice, a nonfat chai latte, was somewhat unremarkable and lacking in distinctiveness, which may have contributed to my underwhelming experience. However, I must emphasize that the company was pleasant, the atmosphere was agreeable, and the interior design was indeed captivating. If I were to revisit, I would perhaps reconsider my beverage selection and opt for their coffee offerings instead, in the hopes of a more satisfactory encounter."

Not bad. Better than other fast food joints in Scotland. Actually WAY better than the fast food joints in Scotland. \n\nI kinda expected more, but was won over by the rootbeer float. That was definitely worth going. OMG, you have not experienced American fast food/diner fare til you've had a rootbeer float. Brought me back to the days of Dairy Queen and the likes. Yet the burger wasn't all that. It was ok but it just felt like there was something missing, to make it a home run. Also, I probably should've ordered the cajun fries. I ordered the onion rings. They were good but clearly frozen. So now I'm on a mission to find fresh made onion rings, any rec's?

"Although I had aspired to procure a reservation at the central area, I would have opted for the Flamingo establishment for a slightly higher tariff, considering my current knowledge. Nonetheless, I cannot express any dissatisfaction due to the fact that, despite its minor shortcomings in terms of cleanliness and maintenance, our accommodations provided us with an outdoor balcony, which surpassed my sister's lodgings at the Mirage hotel. Furthermore, the breakfast spread presented an adequate variety of edibles, without any notable culinary highlights, but also without any adverse gastronomical repercussions, which I deem a paramount aspect of any hospitality experience. Therefore, while the lodging may not constitute a substantial upgrade from a Motel 6, it still represents a marginal improvement and a reasonable value for a location situated at the heart of the Strip."

Went here for dinner last night. 3 courses and a glass of wine (making use of the £10 set menu) strikes me as good value for money. The service from boath the greeter and waitress was pleasant and attentive and my sardine starter and hake main course w/ side of spinach were both very well cooked and presented.


 I'd like to give them a further half star but as ever having to dock a full one instead. The cheese board was the one minorly negative aspect of the meal. It could have done with a couple more oatcakes and maybe more onion marmalde and the slice of brie had clearly been allowed to dry out and harden a bit + the cheese knife had seen better days (the plastic handle was cracked clean through on both sides near the base of the blade).


 No idea if the interior's changed much since it was a Harry Ramsden's but it's well decorated and gets a lot of sun. I intend to go back.

"Utopian haven for hipsters. Bring on the 1920s era boots with dungarees that are a perfect match. 

Exquisite ambiance. A magnificent, vintage roaster is showcased and utilized extensively. 

Evidently, there is a scarcity of artisanal coffee in my hometown. A queue extended nearly to the entrance. 

I managed to acquire an espresso. It was presented promptly and proficiently. In my modest opinion, the coffee was satisfactory...not exceptional. An excess of fruitiness/acidity. Insufficient rich, velvety texture reminiscent of chocolate. However, that's merely my taste. Not necessarily everyone else's preference.

Nonetheless, my companion ordered a pour-over. And, pour-overs require a considerable amount of time. Following ten minutes of waiting, we inquired. Oh! We neglected your pour-over coffee! Wait an additional ten minutes. Derrrr...I'm unwilling to wait another ten minutes, but I suppose I must since my girlfriend and I both have an addiction to caffeine and cannot function adequately without it. 

Fortunately, I had the opportunity to sample my companion's brew, and it was delightful. 

In summary, they possess a successful formula, but minor adjustments are necessary. I would certainly revisit."

We partook of a culinary experience at this establishment in the company of our kin, and we must say, the ambiance was quite pleasant, albeit a tad tranquil for a Sunday afternoon. Upon entering the realm of the all-you-can-eat extravaganza, we were struck by an unpleasant olfactory sensation akin to that of a sewage system, which momentarily deterred us from indulging in the gastronomical offerings. However, our ardent fondness for sushi (a staggering fifteen times per mensem, no less!) impelled us to persevere and sample the wares presented. Alas, our expectations were not entirely met, as the quality of the sushi failed to meet the standards of a top-tier establishment, eliciting comparisons to the pedestrian offerings found at your run-of-the-mill grocery store. Notwithstanding, the diversity of options available on the buffet table was quite impressive, and it would have been even more satisfactory had the taste lived up to the price point.

We saw this place on Bar Rescue and wanted to check it out. My wife and I showed up about 9:30 PM. I was starving and planned on eating here. Unfortunately the bartender said the kitchen was closed because they had a slow night. I had one beer and left only because I couldn't keep drinking without getting some kind if food in my belly. Next time in Vegas I will definitely give this place another shot. And maybe more stars. The locals were extremely friendly and greeted us as soon as we walked in. The bartender was also very friendly. Wish I could have experienced the food.

I enjoyed the food, I got the chicken fried steak and it came with mashed potatoes and the gravy that comes on the steak. Also some green beans and a side salad that comes out first. All in all the food was good. 

Coming in was confusing. We weren't greeted and since it was our first time there we were very confused. Because it's a cozy place I'm ok with there not being a hostess stand. But I do feel like someone should be on top of greeting the guests so that we know how the waiting works (you just walk in and stand awkwardly at the door and they ask who was there first when they have a table ready.)

All in all it's so so. But I do love that it's a famiky business and the food was good

Food and service were okay. Among the dishes I ate were sweet & sour soup and tofu with baby bok choy.\n\nThe decor seemed fancy. I liked the jellyfish lights near the entrance and the wood-covered menus.

"It is patently evident that this drinking establishment boasts an exceptionally pleasant ambiance, further enhanced by the rational pricing strategy implemented for the consumables served. However, it is suggested that the proprietors consider augmenting the seating capacity by introducing two diamond-shaped tables, preferably situated in a proximal location to the existing bar counter, thereby creating an atmosphere conducive to social interaction and potentially generating increased revenue through the accommodation of pool league tournaments and round-the-clock patronage."

"Average American eatery providing satisfactory culinary offerings, yet lacking any truly distinctive features. Suitable for those seeking an unremarkable dining experience. The bar section tends to be rather boisterous, making communication and auditory comprehension somewhat challenging."

"Pros: Aesthetically pleasing and well-organized retail space offering an extensive array of unique, second-hand items. \nCons: Lacking clear signage indicating individual booths' discount rates during storewide sales, leading to confusion. Difficulty in distinguishing employees from customers due to absence of identifying attire such as aprons or name tags. Utilizing recycled newsprint instead of clean wrapping paper for purchases. Areas ripe for enhancement to elevate the overall shopping encounter."

I liked this place.  The ambiance is nice and the service is superb.  The mojito was delicious and so was the waffles.  My daughter was excited by the red velvet pancakes.  The down side was price - SO EXPENSIVE!  An order of pancakes was $13!  I can't afford to frequent this place very often.

"An establishment that offers culinary delights, possessing an air of contemporary sophistication. It is advisable to anticipate a brief period of time, approximately 20-30 minutes, in which to secure a table, as advance arrangements or reservations are not feasible. The fare served is of satisfactory quality, however, upon my recent visit, I opted for the Eggs Benedict and was somewhat dismayed to discover that the eggs were cooked to a greater degree of doneness than I had anticipated, although the seasonings employed were indeed flavorful. Notwithstanding this minor drawback, I am inclined to accord the venue a subsequent opportunity to demonstrate its gastronomic prowess."

We halted our perambulation at this establishment for the purpose of partaking in a midday repast, as we were experiencing fatigue and an absence of inclination to continue our pedestrian journey. Both of us opted for the creamy potato and leek soup, which proved to be a delectable choice. My companion had the tuna sandwich accompanied by a side of fries, while I selected the unembellished green salad, also with a side of fries. I was dismayed to discover that my salad contained several leaves that were not as fresh as they could have been, yet the waitress, Dana, did not include them in the calculation of our bill. The fries were served hot and crispy, their flavor being enhanced by the addition of aromatic herbs. While the culinary offerings were certainly satisfactory, they did not possess any exceptional qualities that would render them memorable. Nonetheless, Dana's hospitable demeanor and attentive service left a favorable impression upon us.

Quite disappointing when I expected the same flavor and price when I was in LA. 

Don't get me wrong, the waiters/waitress were super friendly. We ordered bulgogi and ribs. The food was flavorful but average. No refills for the side dishes when you are grilling at the grill-your-own-bbq table. 

Extra: went with a groupon deal but still ended up paying way more than expected and received less food. 

TL;DR: ok place for food, clean, but does not justify the price.

Upstream is probably thought of as one of the best restaurants in Charlotte.  I am from Philadelphia where there are excellent restaurants with iron chefs so my viewpoint may be a bit skewed.   The food was good but not great or amazing.  Every dish (except the house salad) was over salted.  My husband had the tuna and I had the seabass. They were both very good but as I said before not great.  We would go there again but for sushi/raw items not necessarily the cooked menu items.  The salad was was the highlight for me (house salad) and the crab bisque was pretty tasty too.   Overall the service was very good but slow.  Our waiter was one of the most knowledgeable wait staff we have encountered since moving from PA.

After our unsuccessful attempt to dine at Harlow's due to an overwhelming influx of patrons, we opted to venture forth and sample the culinary offerings of this novel breakfast establishment. The copious servings were indeed impressive, and the fare, in general, was of superior quality. However, a slight increase in tariff did occur, yet the cost did not preclude the possibility of future visits. Unfortunately, a minor deduction in rating was necessitated due to the subpar quality of the ham, which possessed an unmistakable hint of being past its prime, and the orange juice, which was merely average. Notwithstanding, the gratuity of delectable chocolate-covered strawberries was truly remarkable.

It's BBQ at an airport.  If you're in the mood for BBQ while in the airport, well friend, you have pretty darn limited options.  This place is affordable for an airport, and decent.  Great BBQ it is not, but it's serviceable, and quite a bit better than your options to the left and right.

I went with the three meat platter.  The brisket was 1/2 fat; I'm pretty sure I got the end chunk.  The pulled pork was decent, and the turkey had a good smoke but was pretty dry.  They have one sauce option...yes or no.  Definitely not mustard-based, but recommended as it's not overbearing.  

For healthy sides...well, you're at a BBQ joint, so good luck with that.

....and boy are my arms tired!

Comedy clubs are easy to review when focusing on the club itself, and not the talent.  You could be in the perfect comedy club and see a horrible act, just as you could see something amazing at a dive bar's open mic night.  

This "club" is really  a conference room that has been converted into a comedy club.  The staff sets up chairs around the room for the patrons the night of the show, adding seats when needed.  There are a few VIP couches, but since this intimate setting is quite quaint, there really is no reason to pay the high price for them.

There are two waitresses who run around frantically trying to fill all the patrons' orders, but be ready to wait for your beverage.  Walking up to the bar in the room is usually a better way to go.  

I saw the late (9pm) show on a Saturday night.  Seating starts at 8:30, so get there early if you want to sit in the front.  Really, there isn't a horrible seat in the house though.  

I saw Todd Paul the night I went in, and laughed my A$$ off.  He was charismatic and hilarious.  His act was a mix of magic, stunts, and comedy.  He did an amazing job of making fun of Las Vegas shows, specifically magic shows.  I would definitely return for another fun night.

We indulged in a culinary experience at this establishment several weeks ago, pursuant to a suggestion proffered by the lodging facility in which we were residing. Although I do not partake in the consumption of steak, a number of my associates do, and they expressed their satisfaction with the quality of the dish. I opted for the Chicken Peppered Penne, which proved to be an exquisite selection. Following my request for an additional degree of piquancy, the culinary staff accommodatingly augmented the spiciness of the dish. The pasta was cooked to perfection, the sauce exhibited a velvety texture, and the flavors present in the dish were truly delectable. The attentiveness of the servers and the reasonable pricing further enhanced our dining experience.

This culinary establishment serves the most delectable and flavorsome Pho within the confines of Scottsdale; however, in relation to the quality and magnitude of the dish, it can be classified as merely average or unremarkable. The broth, which is the fundamental component of the dish, is rich and savory, but unfortunately, its quantity is rather limited and its cost is disproportionately high. It appears that the restaurant is reluctant to provide an adequate amount of noodles and meat, leading to a sense of dissatisfaction and underfillment. Despite this, the service staff is quite attentive and friendly, which somewhat compensates for the deficiencies in the food. Ultimately, it is recommended to patronize this establishment, but it would be wise to supplement your meal with additional noodles and meatballs to ensure a satisfying dining experience.

"This public house exudes an aura of pleasantness, albeit with a strong inclination towards catering to the sensibilities of travelers and sightseers. Within the confines of its upper level, the culinary offerings are undoubtedly delectable, yet the ambiance fails to compare favorably with the environs situated below. Downstairs, an impressive array of authentic ales awaits discerning patrons, raising questions regarding the logic behind offering a glass of effervescent wine as a token of appreciation for relinquishing one's calling card, when either a sampling of these exceptional brews or a dram of fine whisky would prove far more apropos. Furthermore, the establishment takes pride in meticulously tracking the volume of hand-pumped ales dispensed on a weekly basis, as evidenced by the tally of 1987 recorded during the previous week, which I found rather fascinating."
Not a big fan but Tax free yeah!  Off base has more selection and you can find deals. Unless your buying a high price item i would shop elsewhere. The lines get bad so don't be in a rush.

"Alright, the embellishments within this establishment are rather kitsch and over-the-top, yet they seem to be an integral aspect of the overall experience, perhaps even intentionally so, as if to convey a sense of steadfastness and tradition amidst an ever-changing landscape; furthermore, the wait staff's attire, while aesthetically displeasing, seems to be a deliberate choice, evocative of the utilitarian and somewhat oppressive nature of workplace attire, as seen in films such as Office Space; we visited this venue for breakfast, and while the culinary offerings were satisfactory, the divergence from the typical buffet-style fare found in nearby Disney-fied Las Vegas strip locales was palpable."

The beer was ok, nothing special! I think it has a good atmosphere. But really only seemed to focus on sweeter beers. \n\nGranted they were out of the blonde and anything else lighter. We will try them again another time and re-judge!

I would not recommend this airline if you are traveling with kids. This is a no frills airline. Nothing special. There was no TV, period on our 5 hour flight from NY. All the kids in the plane were going nuts. The seats are very cramped and small. The plane seemed very old. \n\nGo Delta, if you have kids.

Decent place, good food, great  atmosphere to watch a game. Thank god the karaoke was not there tonight. Service could be better, mainly faster. The servers are spread too thin, as there seem to never be enough top handle the crowd. Otherwise a decent pace too have a drink, grab a bite and watch sports.
