This place is open 24 hours and is located outside in the Paris Hotel Casino. It very nice and the Ambiance is really nice and classy. Food is actually OK, but nothing special. The dessert are great though and actually cheap for the amount you get. I got the banana split and share it with two other people and we didn't finish it. Cost like $10 bucks or something. The Sugar Factory store however is over price. Mints and such are like $5-$8 for a small tin. It one of those place you should try once. It a fun place and has outside seating. Dessert and Drinks is what they known for.

"Gastronomical assessment on a scale of one to ten, based on a singular visitation:
Eight for comestibles
Five starred beverages
Eight for hospitality
Eight for ambiance
Seven for value

Personally, I found the culinary offerings to be relatively satisfactory. Particularly noteworthy was the manner in which the yolk of the eggs rested atop the dish, a hallmark of New Mexico's gastronomical tradition. The blue corn tortillas accompanying my enchiladas were substantial and possessed an appreciable texture. Regrettably, the margaritas failed to meet expectations, exhibiting an unpleasant sweet and sour taste, devoid of any discernible bite or depth. Furthermore, the machine-made quality of their production was evident, detracting from the overall experience. Lastly, the serving of salsa, while possessing a commendable level of piquancy, lacked distinction in terms of flavor profile."

While at Fiesta Mall with my son who was getting his hair cut we decided to eat. We wondered around the food court and was approached by an employee of Sarku Japan offering free samples of their teriaki chicken. After trying it my son just had to order from there.  The staff was friendly and the price was reasonable.  He ordered the teriaki chicken & shrimp. The amount of food that he got was way more than expected and he was happy it tasted like what it was suppose to. \nA definate place we'll visit in again and highly recommend!!

The hostess, Maria, exhibited a discernible expression of incredulity by rolling her eyes, which appeared to be indicative of an attitude predicament, whereas Kyahl, a name phonetically reminiscent of Kyle, demonstrated a relatively adept proficiency in responding to the queries posed by my spouse's mother, despite the culinary offerings being somewhat inconsistent in quality, with the veal parmesan garnering approval, while the macaroni rosa suffered from an unfortunate lack of flavor and the broccoli within remained undercooked, and the pasta maintained a firmer texture than what we are accustomed to.

I've been here a few times and its decent food. There is nothing special about this place that makes me want to specifically go back. Although, if someone is holding a party or special occasion here I doubt I would avoid this place.

I've never been here just for lunch or dinner, so that may effect my review. Although, I've eaten this food on multiple occasions for events at the restaurant. Its good Indian food, and you can never say no to good Indian food. It just wasn't spectacular. I would give most Indian food places 5-stars if the quality of the meat they used was better and if the quality of everything they use is just better. The salads weren't green, the meat in the korma and tikka was very small. It just felt like they were cheaping out on us.

Desserts weren't really special either. If you give me gulab jamun or some jelebi, I am a sucker for that stuff. Theirs was decent, but there wasn't much of it available. However, there really isn't much better stuff in AZ in this vicinity. I'd say India Gate is a little better, maybe try that place out first.

Awwww MAN!!! I have written a review on their Pecos and Washington location, which I love and obsess about during the summer when craving sea food. However, felt like this location is lacking that \"touch\". I ordered the shrimp ceviche and fish tacos and they were definitely not as flavorful as they are at their north town location. The ceviche tasted way too fishy, needed lots of lemon and salt and the tacos where just blah!  \n\nThe restaurant itself is nice. Waitress was nice and attentive, just didn't get the same experience. The people I was with also agreed as they have also tried the other location. I will not be coming back to this location, especially because the prices have increased but worth it if you get the \"Islitas\" experience. This place does not have it. Go to north Las Vegas location. They are overpriced for the quality. I give them 3 starts only because I know they have potential on improving, or else I would give them 2.

"I placed an order for the white pizza, featuring a delectable combination of tomato, onion, and Kalamata olives, and upon consuming this culinary masterpiece, I must say it was quite flavorful. However, I must note that the cooking time was somewhat excessive, resulting in a crust that was marginally overcooked, leading to an unfortunate texture that was slightly too crunchy for my liking. Notwithstanding this minor drawback, the establishment appeared to be well-staffed, and the interior ambiance was passable. Nonetheless, I must express my reservations regarding the pricing policy, as I perceived it to be somewhat steep and lacking in value. Therefore, I am unlikely to return, especially considering the distance between my location and the restaurant, and the abundance of alternative dining options that are more likely to receive my patronage."

"This establishment did not conform to my preconceived notions. Rather, it constituted a vast expanse of unencumbered space, with a sizable bar situated in the centralmost location. The culinary offerings, while admittedly delectable, were notably elevated in comparison to those typically found at traditional sports-oriented drinking establishments. Furthermore, the absence of a diverse selection of draft beers was conspicuous, with only a few pedestrian options available. The abundance of flat-screen televisions, while certainly appropriate for a venue of this nature, failed to compensate for the overall lack of individuality and distinctiveness that permeated the atmosphere. Ultimately, this establishment's overt commercialism proved distasteful to my refined sensibilities."

"While there may not be anything particularly extraordinary about this hotel within a hotel, aside from perhaps the convenience of abbreviated check-in queues, which is indeed a welcome amenity, the ambiance of the accommodations themselves does exude an essence of Asian-inspired elegance. However, it is somewhat unfortunate that the overall experience fails to meet the expectations typically associated with a five-star establishment. This is largely due to the fact that Caesars Palace, despite its venerable reputation, appears to have fallen victim to the pitfalls of aging infrastructure and inadequate staffing, resulting in sluggish service and an overall atmosphere that falls short of the luxurious standards set by comparable resorts such as Wynn, Bellagio, and The Venetian."

Have been to Joe's a number of times and enjoyed their food.  We have had terrible service every time, though.  It's worth going because the food is good and the atmosphere is fun.  Just be patient, and your night will be fine.
Great selection of beer. Plenty of it! The food is so-so. Typical bar-food. Very nice wait-staff and bar tenders. Large enough place to accommodate a busy night. Worth the stop.

I went here for dinner with my guy last night and I completely agree with the other reviews, the patio is fantastic. It has a great view and its surprisingly quiet and secluded while being right above Indian School road. The wine and beer selection is impressive. I really like all of the local choices. \nThe food however was underwhelming. I started with the fries which had rosemary and parmesan and a dipping sauce similar to a thousand island on the side. It was good, but not great. For our entrees we had the sausage and mushroom pizza, and the penne ragu. The pizza was tasty, it had caramelized onions three types of mushrooms and Italian sausage, the crust was just the way I like it not too crispy and not too soft, but definitely a fork and knife needed pizza. The ragu was interesting; it reminded me of everything that would be inside a shredded beef burrito but instead of a tortilla it's in a bowl with penne pasta underneath. It wasn't bad just unexpected. I wish we would have tried desert they all looked delicious, perhaps next time. \nAll in all I think this is a great place for appetizers and drinks especially on their wonderful patio.

"Prodigious coffee connoisseurs who relish the rich flavors of expertly brewed beverages may find it challenging to accurately assess the quality of a cafe's signature edibles, such as doughnuts or bagels, if they are currently abstaining from consuming them; thus, it is advisable to solicit my opinion on these culinary staples at a later time, when I have had the opportunity to indulge in them and formulate a well-informed evaluation, perhaps after a 40-pound weight gain."

Upon entering the establishment with a group of companions, I was immediately struck by the pleasant aroma that permeated the atmosphere, which piqued my interest in sampling their waffle offerings. However, upon being seated, I observed that the service was lacking in attentiveness, as no staff member inquired about our need for water or additional menus for our group of three. We eventually determined our orders and approached the counter to place them, only to be interrupted by the lady behind the counter, who shouted to another employee while my dining companion was attempting to order, which I found to be somewhat discourteous. Our meals took a considerable amount of time to arrive, but they were visually appealing. The red velvet wafflenut, Nutella and almond wafflenut, The Fat Elvis waffle, strawberry and chocolate waffle, and Vegas churro waffle with honey, cinnamon, sugar, and vanilla ice cream were all satisfactory. The churro waffle was the preferred selection among our group, while I personally enjoyed the strawberry waffle, excluding the chocolate sauce. However, due to the subpar service and inconvenient location, I do not foresee myself making a concerted effort to revisit this establishment in the near future.

Service was fast, but the burger, hotdog, and fries were overrated for the expensive price.\nInn n Out  is still my favorite fast food burger and Bachi Burger is my favorite gourmet burger place in Vegas!

"It is a location frequently visited by travelers seeking leisure activities, and it is not uncommon for the delay in securing a table to be utterly abysmal. Thus, it is imperative to be cognizant of this fact beforehand. The dish consisting of noodles topped with a crispy duck confit is, without a doubt, utterly sublime. However, its cost relative to its quantity is somewhat disproportionate, as the serving size falls short of expectations considering the premium price point. This, in essence, constitutes my primary criticism of LOS. Either the portion sizes should be more generous given the tariff or the culinary offerings should exhibit flawless execution. Unfortunately, this disparity between quality and price resulted in the deduction of two stars from my overall rating."

My wife dragged me in here after she tried their surf n turf and raved about it. I can't comment on that yet.
We sat at the bar and played poker for awhile. Not a big deal but they make you play max bet for a 2nd drink. They were nice enough to warn me about that and still comped my 2nd drink. Might be a reason why we were about the only ones playing.
We ordered food and then sat at a table and brought our drinks with. The portions were big for the sandwiches (philly is great) and very good BUT wait till you get the bill. Yes, we saw the prices but by the time we got done with food and tip it was almost $40 for 2 sandwiches and we didn't have any drinks to pay for. 
It was good but I just don't see the attraction for a sandwich place and their prices.

We went here for our engagement dinner with our family. It was BUSY for a Wednesday night and parking...well let's just say there isn't that many parking spaces available. For a party of 13, we were stuck in the corner closest to the door. Every time someone opened the door a gust of cold air would come in or the smell of cigarette smoke. YUCK! This was when it was raining for a couple days straight. Luckily, my brothers and sister are tiny, because putting them 4 in the chairs closest to the wall worked out. No average size adult would be able to fit....yes that is how crammed we were. \nIn typical Chinese fashion, there was Lobster, Red Trout, Fried Flounder, Chicken, Beef and a lot of veggies. I felt that everything was just ok. Nothing too special and they had messed up one of the kids orders. I believe my Grandma liked it for the most part and that's all that mattered to me. Overall, I do prefer other places, but I won't be against coming back here again as long as I'm not sitting next to the door when its freezing outside.

Paul Martin's possesses numerous attributes that render it an appealing dining establishment, regrettably, the peripheral aspects are subpar. Paul Martin's exudes an air of refinement, reminiscent of upscale steakhouses in the nation's capital, with its dim yet pleasing illumination, vibrant but unobtrusive musical ambiance, and welcoming atmosphere.

The culinary offerings at Paul Martin's are generally satisfactory, with the Sunday special, comprising a salad, prime rib, and ice cream, priced at $25, being a notable example. The salad boasts a diverse array of flavors without becoming overpowering, while the prime rib is tender and benefits from an exceptional spice rub that elevates it to a higher level. Unfortunately, the interior of the prime rib is somewhat lacking in quality, resembling a vast expanse of mediocre meat. The dessert option fails to impress, as the absence of lactose-free selections renders it inaccessible to patrons with dietary restrictions, which is both disappointing and perplexing, given the high standards that Paul Martin's purports to uphold.

The service at Paul Martin's falls short of expectations, as the server appears overwhelmed on occasion, exemplified by their response to our query regarding lactose intolerance, where they erroneously inform us that the ice cream is gluten-free. Furthermore, the staff's handling of gift cards sold by the establishment borders on offensive, as paying customers are made to feel awkward and guilty for utilizing them.

In conclusion, Paul Martin's cuisine warrants a rating of four stars, whereas its service only manages to achieve two stars. Thus, a rating of three stars seems appropriate.

"The personnel at this establishment generally exhibit a high level of cordiality and assistance, refraining from an excessive display of authority while maintaining a clean and organized environment. However, it is my observation that this particular location suffers from a noticeable dearth of diversity and options in terms of size..."

So, heres the deal...Uncle Bears is a great place to meet up with friends for dinner, a few beers and a game. The menu is ok. Nothing too great, nothing bad. I like the sliders. They're pretty solid every time I get them. The Chicken Fajitas are good too and contrary to what some other yelpers have said, they do not taste like rubber. 

Beer selection is great for the area. There are several local beers on tap from Four Peaks and several national micros as well.

The theme and decor are great. As a dog owner, we love looking at pictures of everyone else's dogs and wondering after all these years of going to this place, why we've never brought in a picture of our own dogs. 

This is just a good old all around neighborhood bar and grill.

D'Arcy McGee's culinary offerings constitute an amalgamation of diverse gastronomical traditions, which can be traced back to their Anglo-Saxon roots. Encompassing an array of delectable dishes such as Irish boxty, corned beef and cabbage, Scotch eggs, Canadian poutine, and British Yorkshire pudding, the portions are generous and the hospitality is warm and welcoming. While the gustatory quality of the fare is merely satisfactory, the eclectic menu provides a refreshing respite from the ubiquitous pub grub staples that proliferate at similar drinking establishments.

"Although the pho served at this establishment may be of satisfactory quality, it fails to rank among the superior offerings of its genre that are available in the city of Pittsburgh, particularly when considering the absence of fresh lettuce and herbs as an accompaniment. However, it is worth noting that the proprietor of this business exhibits a commendable level of cordiality towards patrons."

This Marble Slab Creamery is situated in the Stonecrest Shopping Center, precisely towards the forefront of the development, in close proximity to an array of establishments such as JoJo's, Miro, Dean & DeLuca, et al. It embodies a conventional ice cream shop, offering a diverse selection of flavors, along with a unique assortment of "Ice Cream Cupcakes" that caught my attention for the first time. Additionally, whole ice cream cakes in varying dimensions are prominently displayed within a stand-up freezer. Although a limited number of chairs and tables are dispersed throughout the interior, this location is conveniently positioned near an expansive outdoor plaza, replete with ample seating options adjacent to a magnificent fountain, providing an idyllic setting for patrons to relish their frozen treats during favorable weather conditions.

 On my visit, I opted to sample one of the aforementioned ice cream cupcakes at a later time, which proved to be satisfactory. Furthermore, I purchased a Birthday Cake milkshake, which, unfortunately, was not blended with the utmost care, resulting in an uneven consistency. The initial sips consisted solely of sweet milk, succeeded by occasional clumps of ice cream. While not exceptional, it remained adequate. The staff members exhibited kindness and hospitality, contributing to a pleasant experience. Ultimately, my expectations were not exceedingly high, and this establishment met them with its unremarkable yet acceptable offerings.

This place is located near the outlet center and is easy to access. In the store they provide you with packing tape if you need it. Unlike some other places that require that you purchase it. The customer service members are nice unlike USPS workers.

My husband and I stopped in before we went to see a movie. We had already had dinner so we only stopped in for a cocktail and some deserts. 

We sat on the patio which was really nice. We were the only ones sitting at the patio, so we were worried that we would be forgotten about but the service was still rather good.

He had a beer and I had a frozen strawberry margarita. The margarita was slightly watered down and could have used a bit more strawberry to it. My husband tried a beer called Victoria which actually wasn't bad at all. I also ordered a frozen ice cream. I went with the vanilla ice cream. The presentation was lovely and I enjoyed the deep fried ice cream. 

I did hit up the bathroom before we headed out to the theater and I was very impressed with the bathroom. The women's bathroom has a large full sized mirror and the handicapped/nursing bathroom is very large and has ton of room. 

Overall, it was a nice experience and we may end up going back for dinner on our next date night.

Rented a twenty-five footlong recreational vehicle that encountered thrice electrical malfunctions during a ten-day excursion. Fortunately, the rental company's customer support staff proficiently arranged for a field technician to visit us at distant national parks to diagnose and rectify the issues. Regrettably, the motorhome had been inadequately maintained prior to our rental, resulting in persistent problems. Despite this setback, we enjoyed our journey after resolving the battery-related difficulties. I would consider renting from them again, but I would insist on a more recent model with lower mileage and thoroughly inspect the vehicle before embarking on my trip.

We indulged in a culinary excursion to Fairview Grill one evening, anticipating a convivial ambiance, delectable pub fare, and an assortment of potables. Our expectations were thoroughly fulfilled, as we savored an array of flavorsome dishes and beverages. Utilizing a complimentary entree voucher, we discovered the prices to be eminently reasonable, with most entrees, primarily consisting of sandwiches and burgers, priced at approximately $8, constituting an exceptional value given the copious portions served. Both of us opted for burgers, which we found to be exceedingly satisfying, accompanied by fries and onion rings that garnered favorable reviews. Our server demonstrated impressive proficiency, accurately recalling our orders, including specific requests, without resorting to note-taking. She maintained a high level of attentiveness, ensuring a steady supply of beverages and fostering a welcoming atmosphere. The setting itself exuded a relaxed, casual aura, mirrored by the cordial demeanor of patrons, including two gentlemen who warmly greeted us upon entry and inquired about our well-being. Given our proximity to Fairview Grill, we shall certainly revisit this establishment, potentially taking advantage of their pool tables for a recreational diversion. While it remains to be seen how Fairview Grill ranks among local pubs, our experience was undoubtedly pleasant and fulfilling.

"The lodging establishment and its personnel are exceptional. I have a predilection for Hilton hotels and, in terms of accommodations, this particular venue is satisfactory. However, the location is not optimal due to the necessity of utilizing taxi services to reach destinations beyond walking distance; nevertheless, the guestroom and overall structure are quite pleasant. 

It is advisable to avoid participating in a timeshare sales presentation if feasible. The reduced tariff for the hotel stay was not worth the unpleasant sensation lingering in my mouth after enduring a prolonged sales pitch lasting two and a half hours. 

In the event that you already possess ownership and have dedicated yourself to taking vacations, then indeed, this would be a suitable place to lodge. 

In the event that you resemble the majority of individuals and are unable to tolerate aggressive sales tactics, I would refrain from accepting any offers that may appear appealing in exchange for attending a sales presentation, as it is unequivocally not worthwhile. I would willingly return in time and compensate someone to avoid reliving that experience once more."

I am fond of the concept of this establishment, as it offers the opportunity to partake in live musical performances while enjoying a meal before proceeding to witness a comedic act in the adjacent venue. The culinary offerings were indeed delectable. However, my sole grievance pertains to the sluggish pace of the service, as it required an excessive duration of time to receive our initial course of fried potato slices. Despite their flavorfulness, the prolonged wait was unacceptable. Nevertheless, the assortment of beverages available on tap was impressive. It is my hope that the efficiency of the service will improve with the passage of time.

"My expectations were not entirely met, as I had anticipated a more satisfactory culinary experience, encompassing an unhurried and indulgent dinner, marked by seamless service and a palpable sense of refinement. However, my entrÃ©e arrived prematurely, prior to my completion of the appetizer, and the concluding dessert course fell short of my expectations, thereby diminishing my overall satisfaction. Despite the laudable quality of the cuisine, the hurried pace and perceptible deficiency in attention to detail detracted from the dining experience, leading me to question the commensurability of the cost with the value received."

"This particular paper possesses adequate quality, augmented by the convenience of accessing the writers. Moreover, I find the geographical positioning of the publication to be highly advantageous, as it lies in close proximity to my workspace, thereby enabling me to easily acquire the necessary materials through a brief pedestrian excursion. Furthermore, this newspaper serves as an excellent supplementary fuel source for my outdoor fire pit, eliciting mirth and providing an additional practical utility."

Overall spent a fun evening in this buzzing,pseudo loungy Portuguese.
The Pros: nice atmosphere where you can watch the kitchen if you're into that kind of thing. You can rub elbows with a hip very well to do Montreal crowd. The food is very good and the menu extensive.
Cons: this place is quite expensive for what you get and  you can easily spend more than $150 per person if you go with a variety of tapas,mains, dessert drinks and wine.
Lots of sea food and fish items but at nearly $40 a plate it's almost at the ripoff price point. Conclusion if you got money to burn by all means go.  If you don't skip it or beware.

This is my first time to this Hampton Inn location. The set up is typical of other Hampton Inns. But, the staff is friendly and helpful unlike some other locations I have been to. I arrived before 3 PM and the front desk was able to put me into a room right away without fuss. The room is clean.\n\nI went to the Fitness Center in the late afternoon and discover the fitness closet instead. It was mislabeled as a Fitness Center. It was a small space with three pieces of equipment and a few balls. This fitness closet cannot accommodate more than 4 people at at time. So disappointed.

"The culinary experience was, at best, unremarkable. The lamb entrÃ©e, while adequately prepared, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi in terms of flavor profile; specifically, a dearth of fresh vegetables on the plate, instead relying heavily on legumes, resulted in an underwhelming sensory experience. Furthermore, the absence of any discernible herbs or spices, such as rosemary, rendered the dish utterly forgettableâakin to the uninspired fare one might encounter in a British gastropub. The service, while not unfriendly, was somewhat haphazard; our server, though pleasant, appeared unversed in the finer points of table management, necessitating that we ourselves rearranged our table settings to accommodate the dishes he brought forth. Overall, an unfortunate confluence of factors led to a disappointing dining excursion."

During the frenzied holiday season, department stores metamorphose into an atypical realm where the maniacal consumer culture assumes a captivating form. Amidst the throngs of shoppers, an unwavering emphasis on display transpires, attaining an unprecedented level of urgency and fixation. As an ardent observer of human behavior, I derive a perverse satisfaction from immersing myself within the midst of this spectacle, relishing the opportunity to witness firsthand the intriguing dynamics that unfold. Despite my lack of purchases, I must confess that I enjoyed the 25 minutes spent meandering through the multilevel store, indulging in people-watching while accompanying my sibling in his quest for a necklace suitable for his significant other. Furthermore, I must note that this specific department store boasts a veritable perfume section of gargantuan proportions, replete with an endless array of aromatic offerings. Each individual aisle within this vast domain is tended to by a personable, model-like attendant, eager to lavish unsuspecting passersby with generous spritzes of fragrances endorsed by none other than the illustrious Cher herself. This surreal atmosphere, simultaneously hellish and hypnotic, serves as a testament to the allure and absurdity of our contemporary consumerist culture.

Those who are familiar with me are cognizant of my proclivity for indulging in enjoyable experiences; indeed, I customarily partake in such activities. In conjunction with a sizable assemblage of approximately thirty individuals, my excursion to this establishment transpired. It is worth mentioning that, for reasons unknown to me, I felt a sense of disinclination towards this venue. Although the typical accoutrements associated with adult entertainment were present - including several comely women who were meandering throughout the premises, engaging in their duties with considerable zeal, as well as a solitary female patron who appeared to be thoroughly enjoying herself in the company of a group of performers - the ambiance simply did not resonate with me. Furthermore, the cost of beverages was exorbitant, which only served to augment my dissatisfaction. It is worth noting that establishments of this nature share certain parallels with self-gratification; initially, the concept may seem appealing, and one may experience a brief period of pleasure. However, upon reflection, one may realize that the experience ultimately proved unfulfilling and perhaps even financially burdensome. Notwithstanding the aforementioned sentiments, I must acknowledge that a particular stripper captured my attention; her demeanor was endearing, and she displayed a genuine interest in conversing with me. Moreover, she graciously accompanied me to an isolated area that was not in use that evening, thereby affording us the opportunity to engage in a relaxed discussion unencumbered by pecuniary motivations. This interaction served as a redeeming quality of my visit, and thus, I choose to confer a favorable rating of +1 star.

Bonne nourriture, ambiance et d\u00e9cor.\nPar contre, service tr\u00e8s in\u00e9gal et boiteux.\nProbl\u00e8me \u00e9vident de gestion du service \u00e0 la client\u00e8le. Soyez pr\u00eats \u00e0 attendre tr\u00e8s longtemps.

I was excited to come here last Saturday to see Billy Gardell.  I knew I was going to get royally screwed out of tons of money by this place so I was semi-prepared.


Pros:
* Great acts
* Very intimate setting = every seat is a good seat with a good view of the stage
* Reasonable ticket prices
* Parking validation
* Decent food at reasonable prices for good portions
* Friendly service that is relatively fast and efficient

Cons:
* They cram you in like sardines
* Their drink prices are ridiculous and they make you buy two of them
* If you order food you still have to buy 2 wicked overpriced drinks.  The price of your food does NOT count towards some stupid minimum.
* They add a mandatory tip % to your bill


The bottom line is that I won't be back to this place until they fix how much they rape you or there is a comic that I really really really want to see.  I realize that they are in biz to make money and are probably raking it in, but they can go fuk themselves for being greedy and making me hate comedy theaters.

My companions hold this establishment in high regard, yet my personal assessment is somewhat tepid. It is contingent upon one's penchant for a particular type of pizza, as individual preferences vary greatly in this regard. I do not partake in pizza that is heavily reliant on bread, as the sauce is the paramount component that determines its quality. Unfortunately, the pies served here are rather parsimonious with their sauce and cheese, which does not align with my predilections. Those who appreciate a superior crust may find this place appealing, but it does not suit my tastes. Being a native of Chicago, I have been exposed to an abundance of exceptional pizza venues, which has elevated my standards. While Phoenicians may recommend various establishments, my experiences have led me to conclude that they are merely mediocre in comparison to the renowned Lou Malnattis or Giordano's in Chicago.

It's Carowinds. Some good rides. Most surrounded by stuff you won't ride or games you won't waste money on. The kids will have fun, no doubt. The people are nice enough. The group hospitality is very good with great brisket and chicken. They make you feel welcome. Just enjoy it.

Came here as one of the stops for the \"Buffet of Buffets\" 24 hour pass thing. It's nothing compared to the buffet at the Wynn but I don't think this buffet deserves so many one and two star reviews. Yes, the selection is limited but the food isn't crappy either. The interior is inviting. The line sucks unless you're a diamond/platinum member.

"I require a half-star button, as three and a half stars seem insufficient to express my ambivalence towards this dining experience. Following an unsuccessful attempt to procure a strawberry honey tea, I reluctantly opted for a raspberry tea, which, much to my dismay, lacked the characteristic sweetness that its moniker would suggest. My culinary excursion also included a tamale chx salad, comprised of an assortment of ingredients such as grapes, celery, green onion, and almonds, all finely sliced to prevent any singular component from dominating the palate. While the salad was indeed satisfactory, the tamale itself was somewhat disappointing, as it failed to exhibit the moisture and flavor that I have come to expect from such a dish. Notwithstanding these shortcomings, the meal was priced at a reasonable eight dollars, which, in conjunction with the friendly and expedient service, almost persuades me to consider a future visit solely for the purpose of sampling the aforementioned strawberry honey tea that has garnered such fervent endorsements from patrons."

We arrived too late to be seated and were quickly told as much the second we walked through the door.

But we were hungry and so very pleased to find out they would let us order take out. 

The food was prepared fast and tasted good. It was my first time eating at this chain so I'm not sure how it normally tastes. I really liked the garlic aioli that came with my pasta. The salad was tasty.

The manager Adam Wilcox, accommodated some of our party's particular requests.

They have gluten-free options - make sure you order them specifically even if you are ordering off the gluten-free menu.

I had a great burger here the night--it was a no-frills deal, like something you're mom would've made if she were in a rush. But it was tasty. Coupled with a few beers (and the P-stone has a TON), it was a great little meal. \n\nThe P-stone's a cool little place, although it doesn't look like much from the street. In fact, it really doesn't look like anything at all, really. Groovy, mellow crowd hangs here, so it's not a real rowdy scene if that's what you're looking for. Very familiar feel--like a mom and pop deal, if that makes sense. It seems like a cook place to hang out with a bunch of friends on a random, quiet night.

Came here a little while back to see Fu Manchu - the stoner rock band, that is, not the movie. This little dive on the southeast corner of Hayden and Roosevelt in a little strip mall used to be called Chaser's. Saw a few local bands there a few times back in the day - Zen Lunatics, One Foot In The Grave. One Foot In The Grave was sort of a Sun City novelty punk band about 2 decades ago when all members being over 50 was actually a novelty. Now that most punk bands from the first wave or even the hardcore years are all past 50 that novelty has long worn off. :) So the bar pretty much looks the same as it did during the Chaser's years and place had a good sized crowd - you had to squeeze your way through to get from point A to point B. Men's bathroom didn't even have a door but at least it had working toilets - no peeing in coffee cans here. Had one gin and tonic - tasted a little watery so I didn't get any more. Headliners were super loud. Like holy crap I forgot my earplugs loud. Like stop by the bookstore tomorrow and get the Sign Language For Dummies LOUD! It's ok for shows but I wouldn't come here again unless I  REALLY REALLY want to see whatever band is playing here.

Best way to describe this place- you get what you pay for. It wasn't a super classy or fancy joint, but it was a decent, cheap place to crash.  Can't complain too much about it.  The service was good, my room and bathroom were clean, and there was shuttling to and from the strip (if you don't mind walking a bit of distance... it only goes to the mall on the Stratosphere end of the strip) and to and from the airport. All my needs were met, thus I was content. Overall, decent hotel at a very good price (especially for such an expensive place like Vegas).
friendly folks and unusual items. I've always found the quality good and the produce fress. I like the dried fruit and nut selection too.

Positives:  muddled cocktail is sublime.  Service was friendly and attentive.  A variety of menu items at different price points.  A great environment & stylish moderndecor.\n\nNegatives:  the food.  It's nothing special.  Lots of highly stylized menu choices, where the title outdoes the reality.

We were eager to indulge in a culinary escapade at Julian Serrano, primarily due to their extensive selection of tapas and their renowned ceviche. Upon perusing the menu, I opted for the mixed seafood ceviche, which, unfortunately, did not live up to my expectations, as it lacked a certain je ne sais quoi that I had anticipated. However, the steamed mussels proved to be a satisfying alternative, with their tender texture and subtle flavors. Our companions opted for the spare ribs and mushroom risotto, respectively, neither of which particularly impressed them, sadly.

It is entirely acceptable and within the realm of possibility that one may find themselves in a state of contentment and satisfaction, having consumed a culinary creation such as a chicken pita sandwich, which, by virtue of its inherent qualities, including the savory flavors imbued within the pita bread and the generous portioning of succulent chicken, constitutes a veritable feast for the taste buds, thereby rendering it an optimal choice for those seeking satiation and nourishment. However, it is equally conceivable that certain individuals may harbor a desire for something additional, some je ne sais quoi that would elevate their dining experience to a higher plane of existence, thereby warranting a rating of four or five stars. Furthermore, it is important to note that a plethora of alternative establishments and culinary options exist, readily available for those who do not have a preference for chicken pita sandwiches or seek a different gastronomical experience altogether.

The modified text is: "CAUTIONARY NOTE: IT HAS COME TO OUR ATTENTION THAT THE ESTABLISHMENT IN QUESTION UTILIZES LEAN MEAT IN THEIR CULINARY PREPARATIONS. WHILE WE ACKNOWLEDGE THE HEALTH BENEFITS OF SUCH AN APPROACH, WE MUST ALSO CONSIDER THE IMPACT ON THE TASTE AND TEXTURE OF THE FOOD. UPON PERUSING THE MENU, WE NOTICED THAT THE BURGER OPTION APPEARED TO BE A VIABLE CHOICE, AND WE DECIDED TO PROCEED WITH TWO ORDERS OF SAID ITEM. HOWEVER, UPON CONSUMING THE BURGERS, WE NOTICED THAT THEY WERE OF A DRY NATURE, WHICH LED US TO SHARE A SIDE OF FRIES BETWEEN US. UPON REVIEWING THE BILL, WE NOTICED THAT THE TOTAL AMOUNTED TO $30, WHICH, WHILE NOT EXORBITANT, DID NOT SEEM TO JUSTIFY THE QUALITY OF THE FOOD AND SERVICE PROVIDED. AS SUCH, WE DO NOT ANTICIPATE RETURNING TO THIS ESTABLISHMENT IN THE NEAR FUTURE."

"For an unparalleled price of $2, patrons can indulge in a wide range of coffee concoctions every Wednesday, where size is no barrier to savings, be it a compact yet flavorful small latte, a medium latte that strikes a perfect balance between volume and value, or a large latte that offers an uncompromising experience for those who crave a truly satiating cup; the choice is yours, but rest assured, the price remains constant and unbeatably advantageous."

"There isn't a remarkable amount to articulate regarding this establishment, as it embodies a quintessential character that is reminiscent of numerous other similar venues. Its aesthetic appeal is pleasant, yet unremarkable, and the culinary offerings, while satisfactory, do not possess an exceptional quality that would render them memorable. Although I did not have the opportunity to sample their signature pizza, my impression remains that the experience was unexceptional and unlikely to prompt an enthusiastic return visit. However, I would suggest this location to groups of acquaintances seeking a casual atmosphere where they can enjoy beverages and fare while viewing sporting events."

While I don't agree with those that say it's the best fried chicken in the world, I do agree that it's a great local find in Charlotte with really good fried food. It fits perfectly well into the Southend scene and offers locals and out-of-towners an equally god experience. The place is packed by 11am and does not slow down until it closes or the food runs out for the day. They only take cash, so make sure you check the wallet before hand and don't be scared off by the people standing around the sidewalk as it's normal. You'll order quick, get your food quick and be expected to leave quick so the next person in line can get their order on. They have fried chicken and fish...for me, chicken all day long. Add some hush puppies and slaw and it's a good day. Go see for yourself!

I failed to acquire any edible items to consume during my visit due to the fact that I was in the process of recuperating from a bout of food poisoning. However, my significant other managed to procure the spicy pork tacos, which he asserted were the most delectable tacos he had ever had the pleasure of consuming. This establishment exudes an aura of authenticity, as evidenced by the lengthy queues and numerous patrons in attendance. My companion awarded five stars in recognition of the culinary excellence displayed by the eatery. 
  Notwithstanding, one cannot help but wonder if the prolonged waiting period is truly justified. The duration of the queue significantly diminishes the overall rating, relegating it to a mere three stars. The system employed for organizing the queue was utterly perplexing. Numerous patrons have pointed out that there are separate lines for various types of fare. In total, there are six distinct lines, divided into two sets of three. The first set consists of lines dedicated to pork (abodaba), offal (including brains, tongue, stomach, tripe, intestines, et cetera), and beef (encompassing asada, et cetera). Despite its apparent length, the queue moved at a glacial pace, making the prolonged delay seem utterly absurd. 
  Upon drawing closer to the front of the line, it became apparent that the sluggishness was attributable to a single individual performing the duties of two people. Although he demonstrated remarkable speed in crafting the tacos, he was responsible for preparing a minimum of five tacos for every patron. Moreover, he produced an excess of fifty tacos while we waited, ostensibly for takeout orders (wrapped in foil and placed on paper plates). The combination of the time required per person and the additional tasks undertaken by the taco artisan for the benefit of those not present in the queue contributes substantially to the interminable delay. It appears that there must exist a more effective method for them to manage their operations!

"Sumptuous gaming establishment, boasting an opulent decorative scheme reminiscent of the renowned Bellagio gardens, seamlessly integrates a diverse array of retail outlets, dining establishments, and gaming facilities. Notably, this lavish casino features ample space for patrons to meander freely, sans the claustrophobic clustering of slot machines in every conceivable crevice. Service, characteristically, is of exceptional quality, with on-site eateries distinguished for their ability to cater to a wide range of dietary preferences and offer numerous plant-based, vegetarian, and vegetable-focused options at each dining venue. Additionally, while the parking garage may be somewhat diminutive in scale compared to others, it remains readily accessible, further enhancing the overall intimate and refined ambiance of the casino, which, though relatively modest in size, exudes a sense of exclusivity and luxury, diverging markedly from the more commonplace, crowded, and tawdry gaming environments."

"Indulged in the popcorn embellished with bacon as an introductory course - it was satisfactory, but failed to elicit an enthusiastic response. Opted to share the chicken and waffles - not remarkably delectable, but perhaps my taste buds are simply not attuned to the combination of poultry and waffles (forgive me if my opinion seems heretical). However, we did sample the short rib, which proved to be rather savory! Accompanied by an assortment of unpalatable greens that we merely nibbled at before abandoning them entirely. \n\nIn the event that you decide to partake in the culinary offerings, it is advisable to arrive promptly, lest the interior space becomes excessively boisterous, rendering communication across the table a strained endeavor."

This eatery presented an aesthetically pleasing ambiance, with tasteful ornamentation that contributed to a welcoming atmosphere; however, the culinary offerings proved to be merely adequate. Our dining experience was initiated due to a recommendation from a patron who had partaken in their beef noodle soup approximately one year prior and expressed immense satisfaction with its quality; regrettably, their expectations were not met during our visit, as they conveyed disappointment regarding the lack of flavor. It is worth mentioning that the prices listed on the menu were considerably elevated, particularly when compared to other establishments within the vicinity; nevertheless, as we were recipients of complimentary meals, I cannot express dissatisfaction with regard to cost. My individual order consisted of Hainan Chicken Rice, which unfortunately exhibited an excessive degree of dryness, as the grains were not adequately saturated with sauce or broth, resulting in a comparatively unremarkable dish. In addition, the Beef Chow Fun failed to impress, despite being cooked to an acceptable standard. Noteworthily, the Iced Coffee we ordered was the highlight of my meal, priced at six dollars per cup. Furthermore, the Fried Shrimp Balls garnered favorable reviews from our party, appearing on a dim sum trolley. To my dismay, the Soupy Dumplings, which I eagerly anticipated, were not characterized by an abundance of moisture, leading to middling enjoyment. Ultimately, the majority of dishes sampled fell short of exceptional quality, thereby rendering future visits unlikely.

I had the pleasure of partaking in a fleeting culinary experience at this establishment, whereupon I opted for my customary fare, specifically, a Bean Burrito and 7 Layer Burrito. My order was fulfilled with precision, the ambiance was spotless, and the comestibles were passable, albeit unremarkable. It is, after all, a Taco Bell franchise, and as such, it is challenging to proffer effusive praise. Notwithstanding, I shall indeed revisit this venue in the future.

I was here on valentine's day so we had the pre-fixed menu. Meal was overpriced because it was valentine's day. Nothing was really good. Maybe that's because they have to do things in bulk. The portions were small, but I didn't finish anything because it wasn't tasty.  We were still hungry afterwords. Still, we sat right by the window and the view was incredible!

It's an airport. You get to Vegas and then you immediately go straight to partying. Even the airport is calling for a party with the slot machines located at the baggage claims. \n\nThis airport moves pretty quick too. They get the job done and fly you to your destination! wohoo!

minus a star for not having an EPL ticket to show all the games. for F###'s sake you are THE english bar in phoenix and I can't watch my beloved gunners unless they are on ch 167?? come on.  
If you are going to hang the flags and scarfs at least have the game, when its 7am and i want to get pissed watching arsenal-chelsea in the '5th' biggest city in the US and I cant, well, it doesn't make daddy happy. haha
all in all not a bad place
great beer selection
nice decor, simply put, its one of those places where you get some drinks in for 2-3 hours, walk out and say "holy sh!t, the sun is still out????"

Took my Playstation 3 here after it stopped reading discs.  Had to take it back twice, still wasn't fixed.  In all fairness, the problem was beyond the scope of the repair, and they gave me a full refund.  That's superior policy/customer service.

On the downside, they removed my yet-unplayed copy of GTA 5 and stuck it in a ziplock bag after I offered to leave the case for them to put it in.  Disc looked like someone ate a bucket of chicken and put their hands all over it.  Also, I came back twice to have it re-repaired and each time was like I'd never been there before.  "Can I help you?"

I'll consider this experience a wash, as I left with the same broken unit but was not charged for the time invested.  Not certain I'd take anything else there.

I ate at Tutti Santi while in Phoenix for a business conference.  Met up with a co-workers father-in-law who happened to be in town and he suggested Tutti Santi, which he had visited on previous trips.  Had it not been for that recommendation, I don't know that I ever would have found this place.

They were quite busy that night due to a special promotion and it seemed that they were not quite used to it.  It took quite some time to place our order.  We ordered a bottle of wine for the table and I ordered a salad and gnocchi.  We started sipping the wine while waiting for our appetizers.  The salad was decent and the bread they brought for the table was actually very good.  However, due to the slow service, our wine bottle was empty long before the food came.

When the food arrived, we ordered another bottle of wine and began eating.  The gnocchi was very good, and everyone else seemed to enjoy their order as well. Unfortunately, our second bottle of wine never arrived.  When we mentioned it, the waiter apologized, but that was it.

This would have been an easy four star review but the sub-par service killed it for me. They may have been busy, but 15 minutes for drinks and 30 minutes for salads is still pushing it.

"A quartet dining experience at an establishment boasting a plethora of gastronomical delights was unfortunately marred by an unfortunate delay of approximately twenty minutes on a Thursday evening, which rendered us unable to partake in the customary pre-dining ritual of indulging in libations at the bar, due to the absence of an efficient notification system, compelling us to remain stationary within the confines of the dining area until our designated table was ready for occupancy; however, upon finally being seated, the culinary offerings proved to be satisfactory, with an assortment of delectable toppings accompanying the primary item on the menu, thereby ensuring a gratifying repast that, while not particularly remarkable, was nevertheless adequate for satiating our hunger during our visit to the aforementioned gaming and hospitality venue."

I am not too picky about movie theaters. We usually go to the theater with the show times we like best. They all could use a more frequent deep cleaning, and this one is no different.\n\nIt bothers me, though, when people think it is the movie theater's job to clean up after them, so they leave their trash in the aisle and on the seats. You bought it, you own it, you dispose of it up. Didn't your mom teach you to clean up after yourself?

Applebee's is usually good for reasonably priced, decent tasting food. My experience at this particular Applebee's wasn't horrible but also wasn't anything that would make me want to go back. 

Our party of three was seated quickly but service got fairly slow after that. Our waitress brought out wrong type of beer for one of the people with me, took a while to bring out the correct one and then took ages to bring extra napkins.

I had a lunch special that included half of a sandwich and a small salad. I had the shrimp and spinach salad which was excellent. The sandwich I went with was the California turkey club. The lettuce tasted sour, I had to pick it all off... And the bread was greasier then I would have preferred.

The sangria was damn tasty but could have used more fruit.

"I have had the experience of visiting this location on a previous occasion, and my impression was that it possessed a diminutive size, which was compensated for by an abundance of commercial establishments and a plethora of live musical performances. However, the ignition of the praying mantis at approximately 9 pm failed to resonate with my personal preferences, as I found the overall ambiance to be tailored predominantly towards family-oriented patrons, thereby engendering within me a sense of incongruity and prompting my companion and I to seek alternative forms of entertainment. Although I cannot rule out the possibility of revisiting this venue at some point in the future, I must confess that it does not currently hold a prominent position on my list of preferred destinations."
Way too over priced. I mean its great food. With an average sized portion. But for how much I'm paying?... Not totally worth it!

Here's the thing, I really do want to like this place.  It's close to home, the cupcakes always look yummy, and it smells so good.  I've been here a couple of times and they have the most creative flavors that I've seen.  Pink Lemonade, Chocolate Covered Banana, & Peanut Butter and Honey who'd think of that?!

With these rave reviews, perhaps I just went during the wrong times.  The cake was moist and delicious.  But the frosting is what killed it for me and the hubby.  It was too rich and heavy, even for him and he's the one who could probably finish off a pan of brownies on his own, in one sitting.  He had to scrape off the frosting halfway through because it was too much for him.

I'm not giving up!  I probably will go back because of my cupcake weakness (we even had cupcakes at our wedding) because I so badly want to like them!

I don't see what the big deal is.  Everyone told me that this is the best Buffett.  I don't think. I haven't been to any others but I dint think that this Buffett is the best. The breakfast is way better than dinner. and the basically have the same stuff for breakfast as dinner too! lol

I shall initiate my statement by expressing that the Midnight Diner is undoubtedly one of the finer establishments within the culinary landscape of Charlotte. Nonetheless, my visit this evening did not mirror the quality that I had anticipated. Following a prolonged wait, during which we were seated and our server, Ashley, declined our request to modify our order, we received subpar service that bordered on inadequacy. It was almost as if we were being stereotyped based on the preconceived notion that "black people don't tip," which left me feeling rather taken aback. Fortunately, a server named Larry, also known as "Showtime," managed to redeem the remnants of an otherwise dismal experience through his exceptional service. His demeanor and attentiveness personified the epitome of excellence in customer service. In light of this, it is unfortunate that our primary server did not receive a gratuity. I can only hope that she takes heed of her colleagues' examples and improves her performance moving forward. Notwithstanding, I shall indeed return to the Midnight Diner in the future, and I shall make certain to request "Showtime" as my server for the duration of his tenure at the establishment.

"Upon entering the realm of Las Vegas, I am immediately cognizant of my surroundings, and the exorbitant cost of a Subway sandwich serves as a stark reminder of the city's reputation for extravagance. The inflated price point of $20 for a $5 Footlong prompts me to ponder the legality of such a markup, eliciting a chuckle from myself at the sheer audacity of it all. Slots of Fun, an establishment boasting an array of entertainment options, can be likened to an unstoppable force, much like a 20-ton boulder careening down a steep incline. Despite my lack of interest in gambling, I find myself drawn to the venue, likely due to its nostalgic charm and old-school Vegas ambiance. While I may not partake in the gaming aspect, I do indulge in the culinary offerings, specifically Nathan's hot dogs and Subway sandwiches, albeit at an excessive cost. Notwithstanding my reservations regarding the prices, I must admit that there is an inexplicable allure to the establishment that keeps me coming back for more."

Being from Chicago/San Diego my husband and I are in for a shock here in the Carolinas, this was our first dining experience. I don't know how we ended up here with the plastic coated checkered table cloths and lack of ambience, but we stayed and ate. 

I was looking on the menut for the typical California wrap donned with bean sprouts and avocados; instead I found southern fried chicken, skillet fried chicken, veggie lasagna, meatloaf, coleslaw, fried okra, collard greens... and of course BBQ. 
My question to you is WHAT ON EARTH IS BBQ? Is it a sauce? Pork? Beef? Chicken? No clue... 
Anyways we ordered from their extensive menu ( the variety of "veggies" is outrageous, but mostly fried). 

***Note to North Carolina: Food does taste good without having to be breaded and dropped in piping hot fatty lard. 

The food ended up being good and large portions and the waitress was "sweet as piiiie" with her "yes maam's" and polite service. 
Overall, I am hoping to find a restaurant with more of a variety than sandwiches, southern home cooking and the most unhealthy vegetables I've ever seen.

"An ideal setting for a satisfactory culinary experience prior to engaging in a sporting event, characterized by a high level of patronage, yet maintaining a commendable quality of fare and hospitality, albeit at a moderately elevated cost."

This eatery has an ambiance that is moderately suitable for a Vietnamese restaurant, albeit somewhat marred by the pervasive odor of cigars emanating from the adjacent cigar bar, which initially created an unfavorable first impression upon entry. Notwithstanding this setback, the service we received was relatively prompt, and the proprietor, who attended to us personally, exhibited a friendly and helpful demeanor, offering recommendations when requested. Our culinary selections were served in a timely manner, comprising of beef pho with eye round steak and beef balls for myself, and chicken pho for my companion, accompanied by Vietnamese iced coffee. My appreciation for the broth was considerable, as it showcased a subtle yet discernible herbal flavor without an excessive oiliness commonly found in similar establishments. However, the rice noodles lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, possessing an unfortunate tendency towards starchiness. Furthermore, the eye round steak was slightly overcooked, and the iced coffee featured an excess of condensed milk, resulting in an overly saccharine quality. Despite these minor drawbacks, our dining experience was generally satisfactory, rendering it likely that we shall return in the future. Of interest to aficionados of piquant cuisine, a request for the ot satay sauce, a fiery condiment fashioned from Thai chilies and garlic paste, may serve as a superior alternative to sriracha.

This establishment... how could one not develop an affection for it?! The beverages offered here are truly exceptional and the cost is remarkably reasonable!! I would highly recommend either the \"G Spot\" or a martini, both of which are impeccably crafted and bound to satiate your thirst. The culinary offerings at this venue are also quite impressive. Specifically, the Fez burger is a personal favorite of mine, although I must admit that I am uncertain of the specific ingredients that comprise it. Nonetheless, I can confidently attest that it possesses an unparalleled flavor!! Unfortunately, I must concede that my experience was somewhat marred by an unexpected bout of illness that ensued later that evening. As I had consumed sustenance from multiple sources throughout the day, I cannot with certainty attribute the source of my discomfort to this particular eatery. However, I must confess that my reluctance to revisit this establishment has been augmented.

Evidently, there exists a Zagat survey list pertaining to the optimal chain restaurant steak, which I find utterly absurd. Would they compose a list assessing the finest cinematic depiction of grass growth? "In the end, Crabgrass surpassed Ragweed due to its potential allergens." No, since sometimes an entire category of items can be created that are subpar, and chain eateries, as a general rule, offer unsatisfactory steak. Not that I'm passing judgment. So, if you dine at Outback, refrain from anticipating anything remarkable, despite Zagat's assertion that they served delectable steak. However, Outback remains worth visiting, as their shrimp appetizer, presented on a brown bread garlic slab-thing, is sublime. The bread itself surpasses the shrimp in quality. It's truly amazing. But to attain genuinely legendary status, envision an appetizer containing such copious calories that three individuals could share it and still consume over a thousand calories apiece. Enter the cheese fries accompanied by bacon and a dollop of ranch, and you will comprehend the sensation of spoonfuls of lard within your arteries. This specific establishment boasts several exceptional bartenders, and if you seek a gratifying experience and passable cuisine, you shall be content. Chicken breast smothered in BBQ sauce: palatable. Broccoli augmented with crab-butter sauce? Delicious. A rack of lamb? Surprisingly satisfying. In truth, there are numerous options available here, but one thing you will not encounter is world-beating steak. Hence, it is pointless to rely on Zagat's survey.

Great ambience! This bar was a great place to grab a drink & people watch or just hang with great company. I really enjoyed the lounge style decor & the drinks here are pretty decent for a casino bar.

I, of course, ordered a vodka grey goose with tonic and was surprised that 75% of it was alcohol. My friend ordered a rum & diet coke and again the drink had a good amount of rum. :-) I'm not quite sure on pricing but seemed decent.

The waitresses are dressed in cute lacy mini dresses and are very pleasant. Overall, for a hotel lobby bar this is a good spot.

"Underwhelming experience. Capriotti's offers a few palatable sandwiches, but several others fall short of expectations. 

My preferred sandwich at this establishment is the Capastrami, featuring succulent pastrami, Swiss cheese, and a generous helping of creamy coleslaw and Russian dressing, all grilled to perfection. Reminiscent of a Reuben, this sandwich is well-constructed and the bread holds up admirably. 

Regrettably, the bread used for their cheesesteaks and Italian subs is problematic, as it lacks the necessary absorbency to effectively soak up the flavors and moisture of the other ingredients. Consequently, these particular sandwiches fall short of their potential. 

Furthermore, the cheesesteaks are hindered by unsavory, arid meat that lacks any discernible flavor. Unremarkable would be an appropriate descriptor. 

While the Bobbie may not be everyone's cup of tea due to the inclusion of mayonnaise, omitting it results in an excessively dry sandwich. However, the store-roasted turkey pairs nicely with provolone cheese and hot peppers on cold subs. 

For superior cold subs, Jersey Mike's is the preferable choice, while Pop's remains the premier destination for cheesesteaks in Las Vegas."

Good but not sure it's worth all the hype.  Went there with a fairly large group of friends and had to wait a pretty long time to be seated.  It's a small place and right now very trendy so be prepared to wait.

I found their red velvet pancakes a but too sweet and definitely overrated.  I love red velvet but when you add in the chocolate chips and their icing it was just too sweet.  It was better without all the other stuff but then slightly dry.

Liked their buttermilk pancakes more.  Nice and moist and delicious with the butter and syrup.

Believe I also got corned beef hash - it was very good but the potatoes with it were meh.

My review is mainly for the Casino (As I was staying next door at the Palazzo).  I really wanted to like this place and went in with high expectations. The place itself was crowded with mainly foreigners taking pictures everywhere and walking super slow. I found one slot game that I liked, but could not play long because the guy next to me had his entire family sit on the other machines and they were not playing. Really wanted to get into the table games but just too many people out and about to get by. I will stop in again next time because I did have a good feeling.

I've been here 3 times.  Twice thru the drive thru and the last time I dined in.  So glad I did.  One of the cooks (stawky white guy) wasn't wearing gloves.  Then he went to the restroom and bumped my chair and elbow in passing without a word. I went to use the bathroom and guess what, no paper towels.  So I used the blower which made a lot of noise.  That told me the cook failed to wash his hands.  When I walked out of the bathroom,  he had a hand full of bacon.  My friend had the bacon burger lol.  Oh,  did I mention that when he bent over all you saw was crack.  I'll go back but only if he's not there. The burgers and fries are great.

I had heard about the Pink's in So Cal and I had always wanted to try it. When I saw there was one in Vegas, I was excited to check it out. I was disappointed, to say the least. I ordered the mushroom swiss dog, which costed me $6.50. The hot dog tasted rubbery to me and there wasn't nearly enough swiss cheese on it. The moments where I got swiss cheese, mushrooms, and hot dog were really good but there weren't very many of them. They put way too many mushrooms and not enough cheese. If it had been better proportioned I may have enjoyed it more. I would probably still eat here again, but try something different next time. I heard the chili cheese dog is to die for.

Any pub on Rose St immediately has to compete with swathes of competitive drinking holes. As a result the Auld Hundred seems like another humdrum offering with nothing of particular attraction here. Then again, that may be exactly what the clientele like: a reliable and no frills establishment.\n\nYou'll find typically generous pub size portions with regards to food and a modest selection of ales, A- OK.

I stayed here for a bachelor party.  I've been here numerous times.  I love the location as it is within walking distance to all the hotels I like hanging at.  I like the fact that they gave me a fat discount because of a collective of my friends player points.  It isn't the newest hotel, but the rooms are clean and the staff were good.  I enjoyed their sportsbook.  Unfortunately, I was unable to do any dining over there nor have I ever dined over there.  That's a shame.  I would stay there again just for the price, but there are far superior hotels in Las Vegas.

The staff is attentive and helpful. We brought our kids one night to get dinner. Our food was predictably bar food- fried and heavy but not bad. We visited on a week night and they had a musician playing. We literally could not talk at our table. It was so incredibly loud we couldn't even hear each other. I am giving 3 stars only because of service. \nI would give 2 stars for the ambiance and because I wouldn't go here for date night or with my kids for dinner. It would be great just to watch a game or to go with someone you don't want to talk to.

I'll cut to the chase.  The food is okay.  If you are in the area, and you want a quick bite, hit this place up.  If you have a hankering for some good Chinese food, I'd suggest you drive down to Spring Mountain, or better yet, California (the state, not the hotel).\n\nHaving just come back from LA, where I had some mind blowingly good Chinese, I was let down here.  I would put this restaurant in the same taste category as Panda Express.  It's tasty for what it is, but it's not really Chinese food.

I had not partaken of Papa John's culinary offerings for at least a year, and thus, my taste buds were eager to indulge in their delectable pies once again. As one of the superior chain pizza establishments, Papa John's boasts a prime location along my route home from work, thereby rendering it a convenient dining option. Furthermore, I had acquired a $10 gift card for the paltry sum of $5 via the online marketplace, Saveology.com, which made the prospect of savoring their large specialty pizzas all the more enticing, particularly given their affordability, with each pie priced at a mere $11. While the large pizza, measuring a scant 14 inches in diameter, may not be considered substantial by some standards, the Spinach Alfredo variety possesses an undeniable appeal, its flavorsome combination of fresh spinach, rich Alfredo sauce, and melted mozzarella cheese rendering it a veritable gustatory delight. However, upon receiving my order, I was dismayed to discover that the butter sauce and pepperoncini, typically included in the pizza box, were conspicuously absent. Nevertheless, I comprehended the reasoning behind this omission, attributable to the establishment's desire to streamline their operations and enhance efficiency. Notwithstanding this minor drawback, the quality of service remained somewhat lacking, as only one of two available registers was manned by a lone employee, resulting in a discernible delay in processing orders, while several patrons idled nearby, awaiting their turns. Despite these inconveniences, I would still consider halting at Papa John's for a pizza en route home, provided the price remains reasonable.

"I recently had the opportunity to observe this production for the second time, having previously experienced it without my spouse, who expressed a strong desire to view it. This particular show diverges significantly from the conventional Cirque du Soleil offerings, possessing a distinct emphasis on Asian-inspired elements, swordplay, and acrobatic feats. Unlike the majority of Cirque du Soleil performances, which tend to resemble a dreamlike state with little coherence and an assortment of breathtaking, heart-stopping acrobatic acts, KA boasts a discernible narrative thread and utilizes wires in a manner that mitigates any sense of fear or apprehension. 

However, certain aspects of the production, such as the linguistic style employed and select characterizations (including a Tarzan-esque figure), prove challenging to fully comprehend or appreciate. Despite having had the chance to experience the show twice, it remains outside my personal preferences within the Cirque du Soleil repertoire, and thus, I am grateful for the affordable ticket prices obtained on both occasions. The single aspect that truly captivated me was the expansive mobile platform capable of shifting between horizontal and vertical orientations, with the concluding sequence featuring combat on the vertical surface being my favorite; regrettably, the remaining segments did not hold my interest to the same degree as other productions within the Cirque du Soleil canon."

This establishment offers an optimal ambiance for both working and enjoying a meal when one has forgotten their lunch at home. As I arrived during lunchtime and the venue was not particularly busy, the combination of free Wi-Fi and spacious tables for working was precisely what I sought. They boast an extensive variety of dishes, and the service is quite satisfactory. I opted for two salads: one consisting of vegetables and Dijon mustard, followed by the other, which featured vegetables and oriental-style noodles, or, in other words, simply a soy sauce-based dressing. Both were exceptionally delicious, and I thoroughly enjoyed having the option of a bread-free lunch. Additionally, they offer hot dishes and daily specials that appear to change regularly. Overall, this eatery seamlessly blends the atmosphere of a modern cafÃ© with that of a casual, laid-back restaurant. While it is moderately priced, there is an ATM located within the cafÃ© for convenience.

Went here for dinner on Friday night... We had 8 dudes, but even though we had a reservation and it was late (9:45)... we had to wait a bit and they sat us outside...in the 100 degree heat.  The heat wasn't a big deal, but we kind of missed out on the whole decor and atmosphere of the inside.  The kobe meatball was very good.  I just got an 8 ounce filet.  It was good... but it doesn't even come w/ a potato or anything... but the side of asparagus i got was heaping and tasty.  The filet was good though... cooked to my specifications and seasoned nicely... most other people got pasta dishes... do'nt know what they thought, but most looked pretty normal.  Service was good.  They got everything right.  Not super pricey, but pricey.  But overall I was underwhelmed... I just had the feeling that I would rather pay more to eat better or pay less to eat junky.  No real complaints... but I wasn't wowed by anything.

The patrons of this establishment have the option to sample their culinary offerings by purchasing two fish sandwiches for the sum of five dollars, in addition to which they may also opt to acquire a side salad at a cost of one dollar and eighty-nine cents. Upon partaking in these delectable dishes, it became apparent that the bread utilized in the construction of the fish sandwich was excessive in quantity, thereby detracting from the overall quality of the dish. Furthermore, the salad, consisting primarily of iceberg lettuce, did not possess sufficient flavor or nutritional value to warrant future consumption. Despite these shortcomings, the level of customer service provided by the manager, a female individual, was quite impressive and worthy of commendation. The interior design of the restaurant was also notable for its aesthetic appeal, contributing to a pleasant ambiance for patrons. However, it is regrettable to report that the gustatory experience did not meet expectations, thus rendering a return visit unlikely.

"Culinary excellence and an exceptional vinous experience. Superlative pasta dishes, with descriptions that accurately mirrored the actual composition of the dish. Upon requesting a detailed account of the wine from our attentive server, he delivered a precise and comprehensive depiction, leading to an unexpected transformation of our initial plans for a light repast and beverage into a full-fledged gastronomic indulgence. Elegant ambiance, polished service, and an overall atmosphere of refinement and quality."

Paid for a venti green tea lemonade and got a tall green tea lemonade . Reason why I didn't go back was because I had to go to school was in a rush I wish the girls that always take my orders were there

"The superior quality of the donuts at this establishment in South Phoenix renders it an optimal destination for indulging in such delectable treats, thereby making the arduousness of laboring in the aforementioned location thoroughly worthwhile; specifically, the maple bar variety is exceptionally scrumptious."

I have to admit, the only thing that makes this place good is their interesting looking bread, which is unique in appearance and texture and is delicious. Other than that, the sandwiches are pretty plain and expensive for what you get ($5-6 for a small sandwich). 

The service here is pretty lackluster, since there are only a couple people working at any given time. When I've been here, I've found the cashier to be a little impatient when customers are trying to figure out what to order, so now I tend to just hit the drive thru. 

The building is super old and parking is tight since there aren't very many spots out front. There's another small parking area in the back but it's not much larger. I usually get the small original, which is good, but like I said...only because the bread is unique, fresh and tasty. If they used baugettes or "normal" sub bread for their sandwiches, I don't think I would eat here.

The short: Get the \"white cookie\" fresh from the oven, at the front cafe for $5. OMG. OMG. \n\nThe long: inside at the restaurant: long waits, water refills - had to ask each time. \"Sunday pasta\" did a number on my tummy! :-(. Best thing on the menu - the $5 white cookies in front cafe, fresh out of the oven. Wish i spent my groupon on just those cookies. Forget the entrees, they're nothing special - typical ingredients prepared en masse so they can be thrown together and then onto your plate. That's how it tastes. And you'll pay a premium to find out I'm right.

"Culinary indulgences abounded at this eatery, yet an enigmatic quality remained, eluding my comprehension. Ambience was satisfactory, despite the auditory assault emanating from the adjacent gaming arena. Prompt seating was accorded to us, sans reservation, during the meridian repast. The bill of fare, though diminutive in scope, boasted a diverse array of delectable options. I opted for the prime steak panini, accompanied by a tangy potato salad. A delightful confluence of flavors, complemented by the subtle pungency of barbecue sauce and a trace of horseradish, permeated the panini. The potato salad, a veritable masterpiece, struck the perfect balance between piquancy and richness, with just the right amount of mayonnaise. Regrettably, the hospitality encountered a marked decline, as sluggish service prevailed. An extended wait ensued before our check was delivered, followed by an even lengthier delay in retrieving my credit card. Infrequent were the instances wherein the server graced our presence with her attendance, post-consumption of the meal."
beet salad was fantastic. service was new and they spilled water over my table while I was eating. the short rib loco moco was too salty for my taste.

"The establishment boasted an impressive rating of 3.5 stars, prompting us to visit with a group of companions this weekend, particularly for the open bar. Upon arrival, the gentlemen were charged a reasonable fee of $20, which we deemed acceptable. However, the bouncers exhibited discourteous behavior while managing the cover charge, leaving a negative impression. 

TAO's interior presented itself in an aesthetically pleasing manner, arousing our curiosity and hunger as we walked through the restaurant en route to the club. Unfortunately, we failed to fully capitalize on the venue's offerings due to our primary focus on consuming alcoholic beverages. Arriving early allowed us to avoid concerns regarding capacity, enabling us to appreciate the spaciousness of the dance floor. Although the majority of the drinks were satisfactory, some fundamental well drinks were poorly prepared, and the delay in obtaining beverages proved frustrating. Nevertheless, our overall experience at TAO remained largely positive, as we were able to dance with ample space and enjoy the musical offerings, including an unexpected performance by Dash Berlin. Our group successfully navigated the evening without encountering excessively crowded conditions, allowing us to depart before the venue reached its peak occupancy. In conclusion, our visit to TAO yielded an enjoyable experience, albeit with room for improvement in certain aspects."
