I came here with high hopes after reading the many good reviews.  what I found was good local hole in the wall that is somewhat over rated.
my burger was very dry - as the cook pressed down on the patties I kept screaming in my head PLEASE STOP!
The fries were very meh.  They were crunchy but had no character.
The best thing was that the ingredients were fresh.  While the patties were preformed they were not frozen.  They used plent of bacon so there was a piece in every bite.  The lettuce was green and crisp and overall it was a decent lunch, but over priced for what I got.  I probably won't make another trip back but if I lived nearby I would return rather than hit a fast food burger.

Good place to go and eat gyros if your up in North Scottsdale. The staff is friendly and the food gets to you real fast. The price is somewhere between 7-10 per meal but that's usual for N. Scottsdale.

Maybe I've had better Chinese in the past than I realized, or perhaps I ordered the wrong things, but I can't see giving this place five stars. The egg rolls were too salty, the hot and sour soup was lacking in sour, the vegetable pork was bland.\n\nIt's quick, not over priced and not over cooked. I'm willing to try it again.

Grampa's Pizzeria - aptly named.

No one makes pizza quite like Grampa. It's delicious! He uses quality ingredients and bomb flavor combinations. Seriously, I love Grampa and I love his pizza.

However, my last visit to Grampa's made me wonder if he's maybe going senile. Walking in, we got a friendly, though confused look from the host that said, "who are you and why are you here?" That should probably have tipped me off that something was amiss. When we got an appetizer, it came out cold - I asked, "Did you maybe forget to cook this pork?" They poked it, shrugged, and put it back in the oven. Then finally, something happened with the pizza. I don't actually know what happened, our server just came out saying that it was going to be a while before we got to eat. But hey, Grampa is nothing if not generous! We got a free beer for all the confusion.

It's probably for the best that there were only 3 other couples in the restaurant. A busy Monday would have just gotten Grampa all flustered.

It has been an extended period of time since I have had the opportunity to undergo a comprehensive ocular examination, and my previous experiences with eye exams have been limited to cursory evaluations conducted primarily for the purpose of obtaining a driver's license or briefly gazing into a machine to identify objects. However, in light of Denise's recent efforts to prioritize her own eye care, I recognized the importance of scheduling an appointment for myself as well. Consequently, I registered at the Christenbury Eye Center, which boasts a highly organized and professional environment, characterized by a seamless procession of patients through various rooms, wherein specialists administer a diverse array of assessments designed to evaluate the functionality of one's visual acuity. Although I cannot verify the authenticity of their methods, the center's reputation is reinforced by endorsements from renowned individuals who attest to the staff's expertise. Moreover, they offer advanced laser eye surgery procedures, but subsequent to administering medicated drops that caused my pupils to dilate and significantly impaired my vision for several hours, the specialists concluded that my eyes were in fact in optimal condition. Hence, I am hopeful that I will not be required to return for an extended interval.

Went here last night for the first time last night... Took forever to get in, then another customer decided to get into a fight with us because they didn't want us parked next to them, it was hard to hear parts of our movie because we could hear the movie that was playing next to us, and the helicopters flying around were really distracting. BUT the prices were VERY reasonable for admissions and if you wanted condensations (plus we had coupons)

I imagine at least a solid 60% of people who are trying to catch morning or afternoon flights out of here are hung over. \n\nWho thought it was a good idea to make this the loudest, brightest airport in the country?

"A diverse array of culinary selections, with notable highlights including the Grits & Pork Belly dish, which ascended to an elevated position among our preferences as the epicurean experience progressed, while the service, unfortunately, displayed fluctuations in its delivery, resulting in an inconsistent encounter; nevertheless, the atmosphere, despite a minor dearth of vitality, remained generally convivial, and the quality of the fare, particularly in relation to the price point, proved impressive, suggesting that once certain operational kinks are addressed, this establishment has the potential to evolve into a truly exceptional dining destination."

"Halted momentarily for a pie with my progeny, considerable portion of pizza, copious toppings, a wee bit excessively lubricated, presumably attributed to the pepperoni. In general, considered it satisfactory. Cuisine materialized expeditiously, will pause briefly to sample another item on a subsequent visit... Oh yes, no fountain beverages were available.... For me, a drawback."

This review is about the dining experience- all I can say is, the meatball is so good that it pretty much made up for the completely distant, inattentive service that I received at dinner last Saturday.

What also helped was the perfect weather on the terrace over-looking the Strip.  So fun!

(I have eaten inside of the restaurant before, but it wasn't nearly as interesting.)

I had some drinks & pizza here on 6/28/12.

I was here on a Thursday, and this place was PACKED & INSANE!  It was pretty much elbow-room only.  Not much privacy, and the atmosphere was very loud.  

The service was excellent, but the food was VERY expensive for what you are getting.  Thin-crust pizza was tasty, but very well-done & crispy/crunchy.  Some may like it this well-done, and some may not.

The bathrooms are VERY small (single person - Lock door behind you).  This absolutely DOES NOT go with the capacity at which the restaurant was at.  Expect a wait if you have to pee.

I may or may not come back.

"While my familiarity with authentic Korean cuisine may be limited, my appreciation for diverse Asian-inspired gastronomy remains unwavering. 

The unpretentious ambiance and prompt service afforded us an opportunity to sample their offerings without delay (our table being the second to be attended to). The Korean BBQ ribs and dolsot (I believe) were our choices, the former characterized by rich, fatty meat complemented by a subtle sweet sauce, while the latter arrived in a sizable stone bowl, its scorching temperature and copious amounts of rice, vegetables, and meat necessitating a thorough mixing with one's spoon to achieve a satisfying blend of textures and flavors, albeit with a somewhat muted overall taste profile. 

The accompanying sides, though perhaps lacking in inventiveness, still managed to contribute a welcome contrast to the spicy kimchi, their inherent sweetness offsetting the piquancy of the fermented Korean staple. When seeking a culinary experience that diverges from the norm in downtown Chandler, this establishment constitutes a viable choice."

The quality of service rendered here is truly commendable, however, my expectations regarding the Fuku Burger were not entirely fulfilled, as the patty and its constituent elements failed to surpass the threshold of mediocrity, prompting me to question the value offered by this culinary establishment, particularly when juxtaposed with the cost associated with said burger, which, in my opinion, ought to have been accompanied by a more impressive gastronomical experience, akin to that proffered by Stout; furthermore, the Togarashi French Fries, though novel in their conception, were merely average in their execution, thereby contributing to an overall sense of underwhelment. Notwithstanding these criticisms, it must be acknowledged that the eatery boasts an enviable location within a trendy food court, fostering a dynamic ambiance conducive to social gatherings and casual dining.

"Well, the service was indeed of a superior quality, as one would expect from an establishment of such stature. The bread, accompanied by a delectable olive paste, was truly a delightful experience for the taste buds. However, it is unfortunate that the culinary prowess of the restaurant did not persist throughout the meal. The calamari, while possessing an adequate level of saltiness, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi that would have elevated it to the next level of epicurean satisfaction. Furthermore, the sauce accompanying the seafood dish was overpoweringly piquant, thus rendering it somewhat incompatible with my refined palate. As for the pesto gnocchi, it was, in my humble opinion, a tad uninspired and unremarkable, bearing a striking resemblance to Chef Boyardee's offerings, albeit with a faint hint of verdant sauce. My dining companion's steak, unfortunately, suffered from an excessive amount of pepper, which, when combined with the richness of the Alfredo sauce accompanying the pasta, resulted in a flavor profile not dissimilar to that of a certain high-end steakhouse. Lastly, the dessert, while undoubtedly satisfying, proved to be the sole redeeming quality of an otherwise underwhelming dining experience. In conclusion, while the bread and dessert were indeed impressive, the remaining dishes fell short of my lofty expectations, leaving me with a lingering sense of disappointment and a yearning for more refined culinary experiences."

Went there yesterday to watch a postseason game with other Yelpers.  As far as watching TVs went, there wasn't a bad seat in the house.  For those that hate smoke there is a non smoking entrance in the back to the bar side but if you want to play pool or use the Men's room you still have to run the gauntlet of the smoking patio.  Speaking of the Men's room, I have seen worse but this one wasn't really kept up that well and it could use a mopping as my feet stuck to the floor by the urinal. 

They had plenty of good choices for beer on tap.  I was intending on a burger but table quantities of other stuff arrived.  The nachos were ok.  I don't normally care for hot wings because they are, well, hot.  These were grilled and while they left a slight after burn for me were really quite good.  I also had an onion ring, a potato skin and a cheese stick.  Good solid bar food without being Wow.  Service bounced between really good and "where did she go?".  They were out of stuff like iced tea, some brownies and some of the beers.  As a table we were buying enough drinks that those that mixed in glasses of water were not questioned.

All in all a good solid neighborhood bar.

"Adequate,

Pizza delivered to my lodging establishment.  Verify.
Opened up the box and the circular flatbread appeared delectable. Check.
Pizza contained ingredients as requested. Check.
Pizza cut in squares, reminiscent of a traditional Chicago-style pie. Check
Pizza cut all the way through the dough. EPIC FAIL.

My goodness me.  When you grasp a portion (Chizona's cuts the pie in squares) you aspire to lift a segment with all of the additives situated on top of the slice.  Three of us (two who had never encountered a Chicago-style thin crust) and not a single slice was cut completely through.  In a hotel room, devoid of utensils, we attempted our utmost to maintain the additives on top of each slice, but pulling apart slices that were not cut generated a regrettable disarray.  We concluded with numerous hand-pulled unoccupied slices and endeavored our best to position the additives on each slice.  We relinquished the effort.

If you are unable to cut a pie, which is so fundamental to Pizza 101, then you generate a subpar encounter for your clientele.  

3 stars for the fresh ingredients, excellent sauce, and the proprietor adding some Giardiniera (extremely fresh and flavorful). Subtract 2 stars for the chaos produced by the pizza not being cut entirely through.

I harbored significantly higher expectations."

"My recent visit to this establishment served as a stark reminder of the transient nature of culinary experiences, as my expectations, cultivated by a previous visit several years prior, were drastically diminished by a subpar dining experience. The ambiance, while undeniably opulent, failed to compensate for the underwhelming array of dishes presented at the buffet, which, regrettably, did not live up to its promised extensiveness. Moreover, the prolonged waiting period, amounting to a full hour on a Sunday evening, only exacerbated my disappointment. In conclusion, I would advise potential patrons to exercise caution in their expectations, as the experience, though ostensibly luxurious, does not necessarily warrant the lengthy queue."

Very representative of the situation my wife and I often find ourselves in: it is hard to find good food on vacation. Lemongrass offers classically mediocre Thai food, plus you will get a 1 hour wait for absolutely no reason. Our meal: fried spring rolls ($10) these were clearly straight out of the freezer, no flavor, soggy vegetables; pho reeked of cinnamon ($15); Singapore Noodles Stir-fried rice vermicelli, BBQ pork, shrimp, onion, bean sprouts, bell pepper, egg, curry powder ($18) this was quite good and very spicy, earning Lemongrass 3 instead of 2 stars.\n\nPoor food, poor service, long wait. Do not make a reservation; I would suggest trying a different restaurant.

"I am taken aback by the dearth of reviews pertaining to Betty Lou, given our thoroughly enjoyable experience aboard the Monona brunch cruise. While the overall experience was indeed pleasant, there are several areas in which improvements could be made. Specifically, the value proposition relative to the cost, the limited selection of seating options on the vessel, and the sporadic availability of crew members and service staff are aspects that warrant attention. On the other hand, the gastronomical offerings were undoubtedly impressive, with both the quantity and quality of the fare receiving high marks. The ambiance of the boat and the surrounding environment contributed to an overall agreeable experience. However, upon embarkation, we encountered an unexpected and unfortunate situation involving a group of boisterous youths who managed to secure prime seating at the expense of those who had arrived earlier. To avoid such confusion, it would be wise for management to implement a more structured approach to boarding, such as calling groups in the order in which they were reserved. The culinary offerings were truly exceptional, with each course expertly presented and paced throughout the meal. Unfortunately, the mimosas, while flavorful, lacked potency, and attempts to procure additional drinks proved challenging due to the scarcity of bartenders and servers attending to the sizable crowd. Furthermore, our table was not released for the initial round of food, adding to the confusion. Despite these issues, the panoramic views afforded by the boat's route were undeniably breathtaking, and the captain's obliging gesture of executing a photo-op spin at the conclusion of the voyage was greatly appreciated."

As much as I thoroughly enjoy this establishment, I must admit that I am somewhat disillusioned by the fact that I am only twenty years old and yet, I find myself frequenting a venue that appears to cater to an older demographic. Notwithstanding, I possess an ardent affection for the musical genres showcased here, and I would venture to say that my knowledge of said genres is relatively extensive. However, I find myself perplexed by the paradoxical nature of my presence in this setting, unable to discern whether my youthful inclination towards authentic music is an anomaly or if, conversely, it is symptomatic of a broader generational trend.  

My most recent visit to this esteemed establishment occurred on a Friday evening, a night when the talented ensemble known as Baddness takes center stage. Their repertoire, comprised of selections from Earth, Wind & Fire, The Gap Band, Maze, et al., was an eclectic mix of funk and soul, devoid of any blues influences. My admiration for this group was further amplified by their sartorial splendor, as each member donned vibrant red attire, culminating in a resplendent, sequined coat adorning the lead vocalist. Such an aesthetic, reminiscent of the retro flair often associated with the films of Jim Jarmusch, such as Mystery Train, left me utterly captivated. In terms of both musical prowess and stylistic panache, I would unhesitatingly confer upon Baddness a grade of A+.  

While I cannot deny the allure of this venue, I must concede that its designation as a blues house is somewhat dubious. In contrast, the Rhythm Room, with its reputation as a legitimate platform for touring artists, aligns more closely with my tastes. The ambiance of this particular establishment, however, strikes me as more akin to a dive bar or lounge, catering to aficionados of the genre. Despite my eagerness to return, I feel compelled to postpone future visits until a later time, allowing me to mature and better align with the demographic that populates this environs.

I am going to be the party-pooper here and say that my visit was only so-so. My brother and I both ordered here and neither of us finished our meals. Maybe... we just weren't that hungry.

With that said, maybe I just don't know good (real) Asian food when I have it in my mouth? This could be the case... or my brother and I both got bad batches. After all, we did stumble in about 15 minutes before they were closing (which generally doesn't make the cooks happy).

The owner however was super nice. Actually, absurdly nice. He had a demeanor that had us both walking out going... "could that guy be any more calm?" Seriously though, I've never met someone so peaceful. 

Seeing as how we had never been there the owner also whipped out a little picture book with all the stuff they serve. It was nice for us two un-cultered folks.

With all this said, would I go again? Not really unless I was right there and someone else wanted to go.

Whenever I chance upon this culinary establishment, it consistently evokes a warm and welcoming ambiance that piques my curiosity and inspires me to allocate some time to partake in their gastronomical offerings. Upon entering the eatery, I was promptly accommodated and made a concerted effort to maintain an impartial demeanor throughout the entire dining experience. The hospitality was commendable... However, their victuals fell short of my expectations, given the tariff I had to pay. Their menu could be described as "tourist-oriented" (overpriced), as Tofu Hut, a comparable establishment, offers analogous dishes at a more reasonable cost. Had their cuisine been on par with the quality of their decor, I would have considered awarding them an additional star, but unfortunately, their fare was merely satisfactory.

"The gastronomical experience afforded by this establishment's culinary offerings is undoubtedly palatable, yet the copious amounts of monosodium glutamate incorporated into their dishes are somewhat problematic for my taste buds, despite my typical resistance to the aforementioned flavor enhancer; indeed, the sensory assault precipitated by the consumption of these fare leaves me with an unpleasant lingering aftertaste that is decidedly disagreeable."

"Why the hell does everyone have stuffed animals?! Apparently, they gift you a stuffed animal post placing your order, so when you're seated, they know which table to deliver the cuisine to. I thought it was a pleasant gesture, so I said, 'No thanks' to the filthy stuffed animal. Then I pondered why the food never arrived. Chuy's reminds me of the surf n' turf taco shops by the beach. I enjoy the meat and seafood options and, in particular, the aroma of grilled cuisine, but the flavor could benefit from significantly more spice. The menu was extensive and provided a multitude of options. Too many to catalog, and I believe they even offer fried chicken? Strange. 

I ordered the Broiled Whitefish Taco Platter ($6) with a side of Shrimp Skewers ($4). The shrimp skewer was superb; I sprinkled some lemon juice on it, along with some hot sauce, and that alone was a superior meal to my taco platter. The fish did not taste 'fresh," and I am still uncertain about what whitefish is. The rice and beans were average. The cabbage salad required assistance. It consisted of chopped cabbage with a vinaigrette. 

I was not impressed by Chuy's, but I could return there. It's a secure alternative; perhaps next time, I should sample their $2 margaritas, which they serve all day, every day. Now that's a thought!"

OH MY!! I cannot believe I forgot to rate this place.. I went I believe July 3rd around mid-day. It was hot as he** outside and didn't help that half the seating for serendipity is outside on the patio. Needless to say we waited to be seated about 20-25 mins or so. 
The food was pretty good. Huge portions, for me anyways so I split the sandwich I ordered which was "The strip steak sandwich". Good but I would prefer a better cut of steak... eh anyways moving along it was all good but a little overpriced. 
 
If weather permitted would have preferred outside seating and dessert but I was too full and it was too hot to try either.. However I did come back the next day and I tried the frozen hot chocolate and the oreo frozen hot chocolate but this time I went to the walk-up, to-go window...super convenient and fast by the way.

Both were good but oreo one was better. Had a richer taste to it. The plain one was somewhat iced down.. I'm a chocolate lover so.... they also weren't as big as the ones I seen inside. not sure what difference was.. I posted some pics also of the items. 

Anyways I will go to the one in New York next and see what the diff is and I will come here again next time I visit Vegas.

Underwear for $1 and bras for $10?!?! Yes, please!*














*Disclaimer: Only in the sale section, and only if you can locate your correct size.

They serve the simple \"street\" style tacos I like. I had one al pastor and one asada. Both tacos were tasty. The al pastor had a nice spice to it. I also had a green tamale that was really gross. All masa and barely any cheese or green chile they said was suppose to come in it. Can't seem to find a spot with good tamales around here. I also got a jamaica to drink and wished I had gotten the horchata that I initially wanted instead. It was watered down and sour without the sweet.  So basically... come here for the tacos... don't bother with anything else. \n\n*Note: I didn't receive this as I ordered take out, but there was a sign that said \"free chips and salsa for dine in customers\".

I go to Vegas a couple times a year  and I stay at different casinos .  This last time in September I stayed at the Excalibur.  We have stayed here before.  We always enjoy this casino, the rooms are clean and comfortable and the price is reasonable.  This last time we left a tip for the maid who was cleaning our room. She left us a thank you note, which I thought was very thoughtful of her.  It is the first time anyone has written us a thank you note for a tip. Her name was Clementine and she did a wonderful job.

This isn't the greatest costco I have ever been too. I have a few issues with it. The parking can get pretty bad but that is most costcos so I just go with it. 

I love costco because of their samples. That is my favorite part and the marketing usually works well on me. I almost always end up buying something I sampled. This costco just has the worst samples I have experienced. The sample service is so slow. They always run out of samples right away and then they start making the next batch. This process is not effiecnt and frustrating. Yes, I know what you are thinking- They are free, why am I complaining? Its because samples are a big part of my costco experience. I have been to other costcos where there samples are running like a well oiled machine and they are passing them out left and right.

Another problem I have is the car wash. It does a great job washing the outside of my car, but there is nothing to do with my inside. I need vacuums! What car wash does not provide vacuums? 

I do enjoy getting beer and wine there. I love the large costco size vodkas and what not. I also recently found out about their discount restaurant cards which are nice. 

So basically, I will continue to go but will scowl when the wait between samples is 10 minutes. Feeed me costco!

"A triumvirate of culinary excellence and unparalleled gastronomical innovation warrants a rating of three celestial bodies, specifically pertaining to the unmatched flavor and inimitable style of the pizza; however, a rapid midday repast is unfeasible due to an absence of efficiency in the service, leading to an interminable wait time that precludes the possibility of a swift return to employment for patrons in the adjacent industrial area, thereby necessitating the implementation of a convenient and expeditious solution, such as offering individual slices and a complementary beverage as part of a fixed-price combination meal, a ubiquitous practice among establishments specializing in pizza, which would enhance the overall experience and increase the frequency of my visits, provided that said adjustments are executed within a reasonable temporal frame and at a cost commensurate with the quality offered."

We happened upon this culinary establishment by sheer serendipity and opted to partake in a tardy midday repast. Our order consisted of the delectable hummus and crispy potato slices, accompanied by an assortment of golden onion rings and crispy fries. Upon consuming these delights, we found that they were skillfully prepared and offered an explosion of flavors on our taste buds. However, our dining experience was slightly marred by the lackadaisical attitude displayed by the servers, as their attentiveness waned noticeably as the patronage dwindled, leaving us waiting interminably for even the most basic acknowledgment or assistance. Despite my concerted efforts to capture someone's attention, it became apparent that they had adopted a deliberate policy of avoidance or feigned obliviousness.

"I recently partook in a culinary excursion to this establishment, accompanied by a group of acquaintances, and opted to sample their evening fare, despite having previously indulged in their midday offerings. I elected to share the 'Big Boy Platter' with my significant other, which showcased an assortment of barbecued delights. While the poultry component of the platter was somewhat lacking in moisture, the remaining items, specifically the pulled pork, exhibited satisfactory tenderness. The ambiance of the venue, though slightly outdated, maintained a welcoming and casual atmosphere, which was further enhanced by the hospitable demeanor of the staff. Notwithstanding, it is crucial to acknowledge that numerous exceptional barbecue establishments exist within the city, making it effortless to overlook this particular locale. Ultimately, my experience at this eatery did not particularly distinguish itself from others of its ilk."

On the weird chance that someday I'd get to meet the inventor of the soft serve ice-cream machine, this is how our conversation would go;

"So..how did the idea of a soft serve machine come to you?"

"Well, I was taking my dog Toots for a walk one day when all of a sudden, he decides to shit all over Ed and Dolores Feinsteins front lawn.
I was horrified. 
Ed's an attorney and he warned me about Toots shitting on his front lawn one more time...how he'd come after us both.
He did. 
There Toots is, happily shitting away...a huge creamy brown dump slowly oozing its way out , when Ed comes flying out of the house with a broom.
Toots freaks, and hauls ass without even pinching it off. 
And that was my inspiration.
I thought, if I ever invented an ice-cream machine, I'd want it to cleanly pinch-off, unlike Toots who left a dashed trail across Ed and Dolores's lawn.
So I guess we can thank Toots for the idea."

Many thanks Toots.
I used to love frozen yogurt...when someone else was serving it up.
Now that I have to serve it up,  all I can think about is how this machine was designed by some lunatic who managed to create a replica of his dog, shitting on Ed and Dolores Feinsteins front lawn.

I would unlikely revisit Galaxy if I still resided in Las Vegas, given the peculiar behavior of the employees regarding customer service. During my two visits within a week's span, the staff demonstrated a lack of coordination and synchronization in their work, leading me to conclude that a return visit would not be worthwhile. 
  While the breakfast sandwiches are satisfactory, their prices are somewhat steep considering the quality of ingredients utilized. However, I must acknowledge that the sustenance provided was adequate for my journey to Los Angeles, thus rendering my complaints somewhat moot. 
  The coffee offerings at Galaxy are unremarkable, yet they do possess a unique aspect in the form of almond syrup, a flavor enhancer that I find challenging to procure. Consequently, I shall grant them additional credit for this particular feature. 
  Although the ambiance is rendered fascinating by the incorporation of Star Wars and other niche-themed embellishments, I cannot overlook the deficiency in staff training and overall efficiency, thereby making it improbable for me to actively seek out such an establishment.

"Interrupted my daily routine to partake in a midday repast at this establishment. Their menu boasts an array of enticing specials, comprising of Miso soup, a mixed green salad, and sashimi accompanied by steamed rice. Upon entering, I was greeted by a congenial staff who exhibited a commendable level of hospitality. However, my dining experience was not without its drawbacks. While the Miso soup was indeed flavorful, the salad was disappointingly wilted and featured an unconventional ingredient in the form of bell peppers. Although I have had Asian salads with chili peppers before, the inclusion of bell peppers was a first for me, and unfortunately, it did not resonate well with my palate. Furthermore, there was a conspicuous absence of steamed rice accompanying my meal, which led to a series of perplexed interactions with the waitstaff. Despite their well-meaning intentions, the service was regrettably disorganized and lacking in coordination. In response to my inquiry regarding the quality of the food, I was not offered a substitute for the unsatisfactory salad. Eventually, the rice arrived, but it was sadly overcooked, tasteless, and unappetizing. Nonetheless, the Tuna sashimi proved to be a highlight of the meal, with its generous portion size and potent wasabi accompaniment. Unfortunately, the white ginger served alongside it was dehydrated, which somewhat diminished the overall enjoyment of the dish. In conclusion, while there were some notable aspects of the meal, a number of improvements are certainly warranted to elevate the dining experience to a more satisfactory level."

We order our food from their carside service.  We found the food to be great, but patience trying to get your food from the carside pickup!!  (over 15 minutes past the time promised and ignored until the manager brought it out!!)

"The eatery in question has been rebranded as 'Las Americas', offering an authentic Colombian culinary experience, albeit unremarkable in its overall presentation, despite the pleasant demeanor of its staff."

"What I find particularly appealing about this establishment is the fact that I tend to be the youngest patron by a significant age gap, which is a refreshing change from the usual crowds that frequent such places. Moreover, having reached an age where I have had the opportunity to utilize both wall-mounted telephones with rotary dials and modern smartphones, I must say that I appreciate the diversity of clientele that this location attracts. It appears that the elderly population takes great interest in purchasing fresh produce at reasonable prices, which is often available here. However, it is advisable to exercise caution when shopping, as certain items may be priced exorbitantly, following a pattern seemingly inherent to Basha's business model. Nevertheless, if one adheres to the principle of selecting only the most competitively priced merchandise, a satisfactory shopping experience may still be attained. Additionally, it is worth mentioning that the parking spaces are generously sized, allowing for effortless ingress and egress from one's vehicle, even when driving a luxury sedan such as a Buick Park Avenue."

"This culinary establishment proved to be moderately satisfactory during our recent visit. My spouse and I opted for a removal order, which we thoroughly enjoyed. Specifically, the chili rellenos were particularly delectable, constituting one of the most flavorful examples of this dish that I have had the pleasure of consuming. However, the vegetable salad failed to meet expectations, as it primarily consisted of lettuce and lacked the diverse array of vegetables that one might anticipate. The black beans, on the other hand, were quite piquant and salty, thus it is advisable to combine them with a starch such as rice or an additional tortilla to temper their intensity. While the dining area did not exude an atmosphere of comfort, the provision of complimentary Wi-Fi during the waiting period was a welcome amenity. Notwithstanding, we shall unquestionably continue to patronize this eatery for future takeout orders, and we look forward to savoring their culinary offerings once again."

Never knew how big the place was. Seems like an awesome place for sporting events. I didn't get any drinks, but the specials appear good. It was freaking dead in there, but I want to try and go on a busy night for further review.

Jin's poultry and aquatic products were nowhere to be found in their customary location, prompting us to explore the surrounding area in search of an alternative venue that could satiate our post-bar cravings for fowl and fin. Upon discovering this establishment, we determined that it fulfilled our requirements for a satisfying repast, albeit not an ideal setting for a full-fledged meal. My culinary selection consisted of a juvenile avian specimen, breaded and deep-fried, served on a diminutive bun and accompanied by minuscule leafy greenery and copious amounts of Frank's RedHot sauce and mayonnaise. Suffice it to say, my expectations were adequately met.

Some healthy-ish options on the menu. Breakfast till 10.30am would be even better if it was all-day (as I arrived here at 11am.)\n\nI got the chicken beer bread... What is that? Grilled chicken in a wrap and served with fries or salad. Of course I got the fries as I really wanted fish and chips but tried to be good. That was a mistake. The chicken was processed, covered in melted cheese which I picked out as cooled and congealed...(better left on the plate than in my veins.) I tried to enjoy this meal as I picked out the good stuff. Because the wrap was cut up you couldn't pick it up and it was too \"wet\" to cut. Then I looked around at this decor and noticed the odd combo of a dance music soundtrack. Very odd...something not quite right here. If I had to come again I'd probably go with the fish & chips or a burger.

The ground chicken was the best thing I tried at this restaurant. There was plenty of delicious flavors with each bite. Unfortunately, the boneless chunks of chicken that came with the chicken soltani ($17.99) weren't nearly as good. The beef kabob ($16.99) looked better than it tasted due to a lack of seasoning and its course texture. 

On the plus side, both entrees came with some amazingly fluffy and delicious Basmati rice. Portion sizes were huge, with each entree big enough for two people. At the moderately high prices they charge, it would have been best for us to split one of them. 

The hummus was decent and the yogurt and cucumber dip was too heavy on the dill.

It's a sit-down restaurant with a large open interior with two lit up trees stationed in the center.  If you want a more casual spot to eat (meaning cheaper) you're probably better off elsewhere.

I can't believe I forgot to write a review for Ceres. I remember every single detail the day I went here for brunch with a group of Yelpers. It was life-changing! From who I sat with, me ending up paying for 2 people, the food, the music...everything. It really helps not getting drunk for brunch!

Located inside JW Marriott, the parking situation was a bit of a mess. Some jerk almost ran me over...that was my first memory of him. From that moment on I just knew...

Buffet-style brunch was good. There was a waffle station and an omelet station. I stood a long time waiting for my omelet since they gave mine to some old grumpy lady. They have the usual breakfast fare: eggs, hashbrowns, sausages, bacon, Danishes, bread, potatoes, etc. So, for $20+ brunch x 2...this place was just ok.

"Acknowledged. 

It is gratifying to discover that this establishment boasts an unparalleled level of tranquility, owing to its seemingly perpetual lack of patronage, which in turn facilitates an extended operating schedule that caters to the convenience of nocturnal patrons such as myself. 

While the culinary offerings may not necessarily conform to my personal preferences due to an excessive proportion of adipose tissue in the meat dishes, particularly the thinly sliced beef, the affordability of these items renders them a reasonable value. 

The attentiveness of the staff is commendable, as they display a proficient level of responsiveness and engagement with their clientele, despite the minimal volume of foot traffic that graces the premises, particularly during my late-night visits. 

In light of the aforementioned attributes, I would unhesitatingly endorse this venue as a reliable fallback option, particularly during ungodly hours when alternative dining establishments are unavailable."

Kind of did a breeze in and out, I rarely eat at Chipotle, so the one time I did want it there was one right down the street where I was at! It wasn't busy at all inside, I mean it's located at West Gate and there's a ton of eateries around there, depends what you're up for!

But I was up for Chipotle that day (12/12/14) and the staff was super nice, me with my bad hearing I had to ask the gals to repeat it to me twice - I'm still young! This shouldn't be happening to me! But they were patient haha, the food was good too, a nice warm burrito for a chilly day!

I think I will stop here again, and just ask for a little less red salsa since it ended up being too hot for me!

I have been here quite a while. Had the best experience all these time untill the last two.. i have always came here during  the day which i may say it was awesome  the staff kept up with everything(food, drinks, refill) always checking  in on us. Each time  we always  hit the  bar after words. Till i went during  the evening place was pack and had a group  of 9. -.- lets start  by saying the server  didn't  show up to often. We all order food at once  so we wouldn't confuse  him. He had a smile  on his face but knew something  was wrong. Only 3 plates  showed  up when good came and when wr ask him where the rest was he replied  by saying he forgot. An average  drink took about 15 min.  And we had to hunt our server down for our  tab. At the end we still think its a awesome  place but will not go at night, it sucks.!

I will start out with the good - The food.  I had a burger and tots and they were great. I tried my boyfriends catfish Po'boy and it was amazing. The mac and cheese is very good. Onion rings were just okay.

We went to watch the Pather's game and they turned the sound on. It wasnt very packed and the service was pretty good. 

The bad part - there beer selection needs some help. They only have a few taps but where are all the great local beers?

Also, a palmeto bug kept flying around us while we were eating. Hard to prevent but still not very fun.

"The accommodations themselves were diminutive in stature, with minuscule bathing facilities that exuded an antiquated ambiance. However, the notion that one's financial expenditure directly correlates with the quality of lodgings was not entirely applicable in this case, as the rooms were meticulously maintained and presented a modernized, albeit somewhat retro, aesthetic. The temperature of the shower fluctuated between extreme cold and intense heat, which may be attributed to the aged infrastructure of the establishment. Furthermore, a $20 resort fee was charged for internet access that proved unreliable, raising questions regarding the necessity of such a fee, particularly in light of the absence of any pool or other amenities typically associated with the term'resort.' Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the value offered by the hotel remained reasonable considering its affordability. Incidentally, the Fremont Street Experience, a popular entertainment district, was situated immediately outside the room, which may have been perceived as a hindrance for those seeking a more tranquil environment, but would unlikely pose a concern for individuals who intended to engage in nocturnal revelry."

"Ambrosial cuisine, relaxed ambiance, and an array of superior beverage selections render this eatery an optimal destination for those seeking a tranquil atmosphere in which to indulge in culinary delights and socialize with companions or kin, without the necessity of an exceptional gastronomic experience. The restaurant's'mix-and-match' six-pack beer offering presents a convenient and economical option for patrons seeking a potable accompaniment to their repast, obviating the need for an additional excursion to a spirits retailer. However, it is worth noting that the sole drawback of this establishment lies in the occasional sluggishness of its service, ostensibly due to the practice of assigning tables in a rotational manner, rather than by designated zones, resulting in servers traversing the premises in a seemingly haphazard fashion, thereby hindering their ability to attend promptly to patron's needs."

The food was good, but when the bill came there were issues.  I want to start off by saying Luke walked around and introduced himself and made sure everything was OK- which was very nice especially on a Saturday.  The food came out fast, fries where underdone, but sandwiches made up for that.\n\nThe issue...The sandwich board out front said bloody mary's $6 - we were charged $8.  When we questioned the price difference the waiter seemed baffled that we were questioning it.  Being in a hurry, we paid the bill.  We had 6 drinks  paying $12 too much for the bloody Mary's that my group consumed.  If we go back, we will push the issue if it happens again.

I used to not like this place, but I read they changed everything. The Now use these amazing organic cibatta rolls and have removed the High Fructose corn syrup from everything!!! The also are the first restaurant to take it upon themselves to remove trans fat form 100% of everything sold there!. The Royal with light mustard is super good and I usually just switch any of the sandwiches for turkey and ham if I only like the toppings. 

It has totally improved and I come here often now. Oh and I read a review that said you get Soft serve with any meal? Is that true? Why did I not know that?

I would give them an extra star but they have a lesbian that works there that is thinner than me, jk ....but there is

After having the ice cream cookie sandwich from next door I felt we needed just a little something else.. so I had a 'like it', sweet and tart ice cream, meh.. its their attempt at the tangy tart fro yo which was mediocre at best. They need to focus on their strengths. However the customer service in here was awesome! 3 adorable and friendly guys who were super eager to help! Such a great change from the usual little bitches behind the counter. I'd come back for sure!

We have had the pleasure of dining at this establishment on a solitary occasion, and we must say that the poultry appendages and fried potatoes were quite delectable.
The menu boasts an array of delectable items such as subs (including options with fried fish, Philly or chicken cheesesteaks, accompanied by either cold or hot vegetables...), wraps, burger platters, fish plates, chicken plates, and an assortment of other culinary delights.
Upon discovering this eatery, we experienced a profound sense of satisfaction, as it brought to mind memories of similar carry-out establishments from our past. Having resided in the Charlotte area for a period of seven years, this marks the initial instance in which we have encountered a venue of this nature.
Due to its location in a relatively small corner, we advise patrons to maintain a vigilant gaze while seeking out this hidden gem.

"I recently arrived at this establishment for the purpose of undergoing a smog inspection, which typically carries a cost of $19.95; however, due to my possession of a special promotional mailing, I was able to avail myself of a reduced rate of $14.95, a savings of $5 that I found quite satisfactory given the straightforward nature of the service provided, which involved a brief and efficient process of inspection and maintenance that did not necessitate an extensive period of time or excessive monetary expenditure, thereby rendering the overall experience relatively unremarkable, yet pleasingly convenient and economical in comparison to other establishments offering comparable services, such as Jiffy Smog."

This place was so packed when i was here. Like everyone else says the dance floor really isnt big at all. EVERYWHERE, and i mean everywhere possible is reserved for bottle service. Lucky for me im a woman and flirted my way to a grey goose cran and a seat- i feel sorry for the guys!\n\nAdd 2 stars because the line was HUUUGE and we walked straight to the front and into the club.

"Expeditious'strip-mall' Chinese cuisine, conforming to preconceived notions. Ideal for a hasty, post-work acquisition of a convenient family takeout meal, yet, temper expectations regarding gastronomic refinement. Recently sampled the beef with broccoli, kung pao chicken, and sweet and sour chicken, all fabricated from discerning diner-friendly components and appreciated by younger palates. Noteworthily, staff members are of Chinese descent, and a few words uttered in Mandarin by patrons elicit a positive response. In conclusion, while unremarkable, a reasonable value for a mid-week home-cooked meal."
They have a grill for those steaks that u are craving for. Typical ham and roast beef! It was good for the price and for my boys who are at that age they can't stop eating.

Decided not to come back because last time I was very disappointed with the super expensive honey toast ( cant remember the name all I know is $12.99) and it wasn't that good but had to come back because we couldnt find anywhere else to play card. At least this place has a better service than tea station tho. Overall is not that bad just a little bit pricey.

food was fresh and authentic but way overpriced. owner was nice and so was girl behind counter will I be back maybe but only ordering food once you add in $2 drinks and $3 desserts the bill begins to rack up

"The West Room presents an intriguing culinary experience, boasting a sophisticated ambiance and an extensive cocktail selection that is sure to captivate discerning patrons. However, our dining excursion yielded mixed results, as certain aspects of the fare failed to meet our expectations, thereby casting doubt on the likelihood of future visits. Despite its self-proclaimed status as the 'hidden gem' of the west end, a more judicious curation of menu items may be necessary to elevate The West Room to the level of gastronomic excellence it aspires to."

My family, hailing from Korea, embarked upon a visitation to our humble abode, and during our sojourn to the gastronomical Mecca known as Las Vegas, they expressed an ardent yearning for culinary familiarity. My stratagem was to escort them to the esteemed Grand Lux, but en route, my grandmother's complexion assumed a pallid hue. Thus, we diverted our course towards Imperial Palace, guided by conspicuous signage. Upon ascending the elevator to the fifth floor dining plaza, we were greeted by a warm, familial Korean salutation, which elicited a visible improvement in my grandmother's countenance.  
The menu proffered an array of Korean, Japanese, and Chinese delicacies, but we elected to indulge exclusively in Korean cuisine. Our repast consisted of duk mandoo gook (a hearty soup composed of rice cakes and dumplings), dolsot bibimbap (a medley of rice, vegetables, and a fried egg, served in a sizzling stone bowl), soft tofu soup, and bulgogi (tender, marinated meat). While the fare was unremarkable, observing my grandmother grasp her rice bowl with both hands and devour its contents with unbridled relish rendered the meal decidedly more satisfying.  
Although the cost proved moderately exorbitant for unexceptional Korean cuisine in Las Vegas (amounting to approximately $90, inclusive of tax and gratuity, for a mere luncheon), the staff displayed commendable hospitality and amenability. Personal preferences notwithstanding, I would not revisit this establishment, yet I acknowledge the value of their attentive service and practical accessibility.

We stumbled in off the plane and had a tasty lunch. For 2 people - calamari a la plancha, xato salad, scallops in romesco sauce, white ceviche and raspberry tuna skewers - it was all good and beautifully presented. No drinks. $80 for a light lunch felt a bit steep.

I had the pleasure of dining at CUT with a group of acquaintances, and while the culinary offerings were satisfactory, albeit slightly overcooked and burnt, the ambiance left much to be desired. Specifically, the illumination was excessively dim, making it challenging to discern the appearance of the cuisine, and the service, although plentiful in terms of staff-to-patron ratio, lacked a certain authenticity and warmth in their interactions with customers. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the pricing was reasonable in relation to the quality of the fare provided, and I would consider giving the establishment another opportunity to demonstrate its capabilities under different circumstances.

We have become accustomed to ordering either the Louisiana Chicken pasta or cheesecake during our dining excursions to this establishment, as we have found that these items consistently meet our expectations of culinary excellence. It appears that the vast array of options on the menu may potentially overwhelm the kitchen staff, resulting in a lack of attention to detail and inconsistent quality in the preparation of certain dishes. Our recent experiences have been disappointing, with the last five dishes we have ordered failing to impress and one dish being returned due to its subpar quality, which is an unprecedented occurrence for us, as we rarely feel compelled to express dissatisfaction with our meals.

My boyfriend and I just had dinner here. I have to say, I'm very underwhelmed by the food here. I was pretty stoked to get a tastey but simple sandwich and fresh made soup. Regretfully, I had the grilled cheese and it was quite lacking in flavor. The red pepper lobster bisque, though a tad \"clumpy\" was quite tasty. I will give Cafe Zupas another shot, but I'm hoping my next choice in sandwich will turn it around for me.

Maybe I was just super hyper up and expected way too much but the Blue Man Group wasn't all that.  Don't get me wrong, there were some really cool parts but there were also some boring parts.  I wanted to fall asleep a couple of times.  My husband's review would be even more critical.  He thought almost the whole show was boring.  For the price of the tickets, I don't think it's worth it.  Maybe if the tickets were $20-30 cheaper, it would be a better bang for your buck.  Some parts were very funny, some parts were neat, and some parts were just like okay-can-this-be-over-already.  Overall, it just gets three stars from me.

I really like this place.  The food, drinks, and wine are always delicious.  The service is great,  but I can't get over how loud they play the live music on Friday and Saturday nights.  The music itself is fun and provides a great feeling, but don't plan on being able to have a conversation if you're in the main room while they pump it in on a speaker.

"I was seeking an activity suitable for engaging with my in-laws, and this particular attraction appeared to align with their interests. However, upon further inspection, it became apparent that it was a quintessential tourist trap, replete with an array of commercialized souvenirs and services that came at an additional cost. Despite the overtly exploitative nature of the establishment, I must admit that the experience was moderately enjoyable, as I had the opportunity to capture some remarkable photographs and gain insight into the local lore. Nonetheless, I do not envision revisiting this destination in the future, as a single visit proved sufficient to satiate my curiosity."

"In the event that the temperature exterior is either extremely frigid or sweltering hot, and you seek an indoor venue to pass the time without the necessity of migrating between hotels, there are numerous alternative attractions and activities to explore in Las Vegas that would render a visit to this shopping center superfluous, despite its aesthetic appeal and sizable food court. However, if your financial resources are plentiful, this location may serve as an optimal site for indulging in retail therapy. Alternatively, consider visiting one of the several outlet malls situated in the surrounding vicinity of Las Vegas, whereupon you may discover more reasonable prices on merchandise."
Went here with some friends and was not familiar with the menu.  The order counter seemed confusing to me too. Got a turkey sandwich,  but think they used miracle whip not mayo.  Not a fan though.

I saw these reviews and decided to try this place. The Pellini is an Italian burrito. You get to pick you meat (chicken, steak, italian sausage, shrimp), sauces (tomato and white), and topping (cheese, veggies). There are lots of choices so you can really have fun and personalize it. 
I had the chicken and Italian sausage and I thought that it was ok. Not great. I didn't think it had a lot a taste but maybe it how I put the Pellini together. 
My wife had the chicken and shrimp and the shrimp really brought out the taste. Her Pellini tasted really good.
The decor was up to date and clean. It thought the the service was pretty good. They were very helpful and friendly. 
Not to sure if I will return but my wife enjoyed it, so we'll see.

"Napoleon's Dueling Piano Bar offers an extraordinary experience, garnering an overall rating of 3.75. Patrons can revel in the exceptional musical prowess of the pianists, who possess an unparalleled repertoire of songs spanning diverse genres, including classic rock and heavy metal. The ambiance is characterized by a vibrant and lively atmosphere, fostering an environment conducive to socializing, dancing, and merriment. Entrance is complimentary, negating the need for an admission fee or minimum drink purchase, thereby allowing patrons to enjoy the entertainment stress-free. While the audience primarily consists of individuals aged 40 and above, the venue's unique concept and appeal have the potential to captivate a broader demographic. By offering a system of song requests accompanied by tips, patrons can actively engage with the performers and enhance their experience. Embrace the joy of dueling pianos and create unforgettable memories at Napoleon's Dueling Piano Bar."

I was here for lunch a few days ago.  Nice ambiance - and cosy and warm inside while it blew a storm outside.  I had good service, but wasn't overwhelmed by the food.  An halloumi sandwich with ciabatta and salad.   I enjoyed the salad, and the halloumi, but frankly the ciabatta didn't do it for me - and didn't bring out the best in the halloumi (even with the chilli jelly).   For dessert I had carrot cake - which was rather dry.  Much better carrot cake to be had in town.\n\nI'll be back though - apparently they do a good eggs benedict.

I like this place because it's cheap.

The food isn't outstanding, but it's tasty enough.

We go fairly regularly because it's easy.

I'd recommend it.

I have been to Spinato's three times now. Twice for takeout, once we ate in the dining room. I have three thoughts:
- The pizza is good. 
- The pizza is overpriced.
- The service is craptastic. The first time they made me the wrong pizza and I had to wait an additional 10 minutes after everyone else had received their food. No discount was given on my order. The third time I called an order in and they told me it would 30-35 minutes. My wait was actually 57 minutes. When I complained the takeout person just looked at me with a blank stare. No apology, no discount.

The service is so bad it is enough to send me elsewhere, like Grimaldi's, if I am going to spend that kind of money on pizza.

"If you're seeking a nocturnal excursion replete with alcoholic indulgences and a brief respite from the impending bedlam, Caramel presents itself as a viable option. While it may not be an establishment worthy of extensive correspondence, it did elicit a sense of contentment within me, albeit for a singular reason: seating. On our third evening of unbridled revelry, my priorities had been simplified to a considerable degree; specifically, I craved a chair. Upon entering the venue following a convivial dinner and encountering a group of acquaintances, we were promptly accosted by a cocktail server who offered us a table designated for reserved seating. This was a veritable symphony to my auricular senses (as well as my fatigued pedal extremities!). Although the lounge itself was somewhat diminutive in stature, the assemblage comprised an eclectic mix of patrons. The ambiance, while not particularly noteworthy, was supplemented by a satisfactory musical selection and the possibility of sampling artisanal infusions of vodka. However, it is important to note that prolonged stays exceeding thirty minutes are not recommended, as the locale fails to offer sufficient diversions to warrant extended periods of time."

"My culinary preferences do not align with the gastronomical offerings at this establishment, specifically pertaining to the tuna entrÃ©e, which, despite its considerable cost of approximately thirty-five dollars, did not resonate with my taste buds. However, I do appreciate the mixological expertise demonstrated in the creation of their cocktails, and occasionally partake in libations at the bar during the designated hours of happy hour."

I absolutely LOVE Cirque shows, having seen a couple before (Ovo & Zumanity), so I was really excited when my boyfriend was offered comp tickets for his birthday in Las Vegas. Our seats were perfect, right in the middle about 6 rows up from the stage. I was extremely impressed with the set, as it was beautiful, and the water acts were gorgeous. Unfortunately, I was slightly underwhelmed. I don't know if it was just me, but I found the comedy to be lacking...the clown humour wasn't funny and I actually found it to be pretty boring. I was expecting to see more \"AMAZING\" acrobatics, but aside from the beautiful diving (that takes talent) and a couple other acts (fire dancers, jumpers) I was really unimpressed. I didn't understand the story they were trying to tell, and some of the scenes were downright confusing. What was with the guy holding the 1-800 sign? Not to mention, I felt creeped out by it, like it was a weird acid trip. Those guys in the red coats are what nightmares are made out of. I love Cirque du Soleil and \"O\" was a nice way to spend an evening, but overall I'm glad we didn't pay for the tickets. We found ourselves yawning towards the end and unfortunately, we were glad when it ended. Next time, I will see Ka or Mystere!

"Although it's a rather extravagant Las Vegas interpretation of a traditional public house, this establishment can still provide a satisfactory experience for those seeking a casual drink, despite the fact that the cost of a single pint may be slightly elevated compared to what one might consider reasonable. However, based on my recent visit, I would not wholeheartedly recommend dining here, as the ambiance and quality of service did not entirely align with my expectations, despite the delectability of my initial course, which consisted of thin slices of pork belly atop a rich, egg-based bread, complemented by a sweet maple glaze and crowned with a poached egg. Specifically, while the bartenders were quite affable, the table staff exhibited a subtle yet perceptible air of indifference, and my primary dish, consisting of fish and chips, failed to impress me as much as I had hoped, given the premium pricing. Nonetheless, if you find yourself on the Strip and are in pursuit of a respectable beer, it may still be worth paying a visit to this establishment."

"My affinity for Famous Dave's feline culinary offerings is unwavering! In addition, the diverse array of sauces available at each table showcases the restaurant's commitment to gastronomic innovation. Particularly noteworthy is the Georgia Mustard, whose tangy flavor profile complements an array of dishes. However, my enthusiasm for the establishment is somewhat tempered by the inconsistent service, which has proven to be a recurring theme throughout my visits. Specifically, my most recent encounter involved a server who expended an inordinate amount of time engaging in a protracted conversation about his name, thereby delaying the taking of our order. Furthermore, he had the audacity to solicit financial support for a personal cause, an action that struck me as both inappropriate and unprofessional. The manager's failure to address this issue promptly only served to exacerbate my frustration. Ultimately, I believe that had the server devoted as much attention to our table as he did to his self-aggrandizement, the outcome of our meal might have been less problematic."

Who likes the DMV? Nobody. Then why do I give it a 3 star? For the self-service kiosks, where you can be in and out in less than 10 minutes. It's the best thing they could have done to help keep people moving. Now the only time I dread going is when I have to actually see a human to get done what I need. Visit the website to see what you can get done at the kiosk. And they have kiosks in other businesses (AAA's, grocery stores, etc) around Las Vegas, so check that out.

I thought the food was pretty good. I have done alot of really good Tapas and this was just pretty good. These guys pack it in like sardines and a young good looking crowd it is. Too busy for me on the weekends I would go back but there are many other fish in the sea so it won't be soon.

The service and ambiance were very good. Small and intimate. Tables were a little close together in our section, and the heater was blowing directly underneath our feet, so it got a little uncomfortable as the night went on. Used a living social deal, which made the meal an excellent value. Ordered the escargot appetizer and the french onion soup, which were both delicious. Unfortunately, several appetizer and entree menu items were unavailable, including the frog legs, which I was interested in trying. I ordered the steak and frites (ribeye). The steak just wasn't good. The meat seemed very bland and I had to chew through some very tough and rubbery bits. Even though I  enjoyed the soup and appetizer, I left a bit unsatisfied due to the less than stellar ribeye. I do intent to come back and try something else on the menu in the future.

"Refrain from purchasing the bananas, as they have been subjected to refrigeration, which will cause them to undergo an accelerated ripening process, resulting in an unpleasant browning effect by the end of the day. It is advisable to avoid acquiring bananas from Dole, as their quality is inferior compared to other brands."

"It is my conviction that this location formerly possessed a more optimal state of affairs, characterized by a heightened level of proficiency and effectiveness in addressing the needs of its clientele, as well as a greater abundance of insightful and useful information. Alas, it appears that I have had the misfortune of encountering an unfortunate concatenation of circumstances, resulting in an experience that falls short of my expectations. Notwithstanding this disappointment, I must acknowledge that the prices offered here remain competitive and the selection of goods and services available is indeed impressive. Furthermore, I find myself in need of seating arrangements conducive to leisurely perusal and contemplation."

MEDIOCRE, and \"bring your own wine\" is overrated. I had the fillet mignon. Maybe in comparison to the steak houses in strip malls, this place is ok, but not in the Old Port, where there are MANY better restaurants. Maybe I'm too much of a meat lover to appreciate a tolerable steak. The thing is, I can make a better steak at home for less money and with the same effort (very loud dinning room). \nThe only time I would recommend this place is if you're doing a corporate dinner on a weeknight, not too busy, not too pricey, not too despicable.
Fries are great but everything else is terrible.  I would eat here more often if they improved their burgers even just a little bit.

This place was just "okay."  I would use the term "old timey" to describe it.... I would also use that term to describe the clientele.  I went there for a business lunch, I would say that most of the older male population of Phoenix did the same.  I must also note that there is ZERO ambience-- it looks like a Best Western dining hall.

On to the food.  I had been craving prime rib, so that is what I ordered.  Though it was accurately cooked to be medium rare, the texture and flavor were not great.  The meat was bland, and it was not all that tender.  Even the au jus lacked flavor.  It was served with some sort of potatoes that I didn't really like either.  However, I have to say that my companion ordered the filet-- also medium rare-- and said that it was really good.

I am not going to give this place a bad review, but I can't give it a stellar one either.  Im addition, the prices are a little high for such boring food.  I am truly ambivalent about Stockyards.... and life is too short to eat mediocre food.  ;)

"My sentiments towards this establishment are somewhat ambivalent, as I have been a patron of their services on multiple occasions, yet have recently encountered certain operational aspects that detract from the overall experience. Specifically, during my most recent visits, I have noticed that the salon has adopted a practice of simultaneously performing gel manicures and pedicures, which I find to be excessively stressful and detrimental to the otherwise therapeutic nature of the treatment. While I acknowledge that this may be a result of my own failure to communicate my preferences effectively or perhaps due to unforeseen circumstances, I cannot help but feel that such an approach diminishes the enjoyment that I would normally derive from the process. Notwithstanding this criticism, I must admit that the salon does offer one of the more satisfactory pedicure experiences available in Las Vegas, particularly the hot stone variety, which I highly recommend."

It was 10:45 Saturday morning and I wanted coffee. I knew of a place right down the street from me and to my disappointment it was closed! WTF! Any way I went searching for a cafe. I wanted to sit down and read the new times with a cup of coffee. I actually started my journey thinking I would stop at the drip. But when i got there that place just seemed to modern for me. I was in a funky mood and just wanted a nice cup of coffee, nothing fancy. So I saw an older man waving a sign that said \"Best lunch in town!\" and he was kind of dancing too! And I said to myself \"Yes, i think I will\". So I stumbled upon MacAlpines. They had just opened and I sat right down at the counter. I had two cups of yummy diner coffee and after realizing I was hungry too, I ordered a stuffed tomato that was oh so yummy with super fresh veggies. The decor was adorable and welcoming and I loved the juke box. 25 cents gets you two plays! anyway, I'm not giving it four stars because it took some time for the staff to warm up and be friendly. I don't know if it was just because they had just opened or if it was because I was still sleeping and needed a caffeine fix badly. But I want to go again, with company, not by myself and I'll rate it again.

Not as good as their flagship out on Sahara, but this one's right on the strip, although with the renovation you have to wade thru some dust and scaffolding to get here. The portions were just as monstrously large though, and this time we split 2 dishes among the three of us lightweights, and we left full having not even finished either of them. I'd have picked the chicken and waffles for sure but democracy won out. Here we tried the chorizo skillet and the Tractor Driver Combo. The chorizo skillet was good, although the one tortilla it comes with is inadequate for the amount of filling it comes with. The tractor driver combo we upgraded to a banana pancake which was well worth the extra dollar. Service was excellent. \n\nThe experience at their standalone restaurant on Sahara was better in terms of the atmosphere, the food, and the overall experience, but this was still fine.

I celebrated my twenty-first birthday at this venue, and while the experience was enjoyable, it was somewhat diminished by the fact that the establishment appeared to be operating beyond its optimal capacity. Specifically, the dance floor was overcrowded, which made it challenging to fully appreciate the talents of the disc jockey who was performing that evening. Despite these issues, I must admit that I had an enjoyable time, albeit one that was tempered by the aforementioned limitations of space.

The food was good, portions huge, and there was a good variety on the menu.  However it took us an hour and 12 minutes from arrival to getting our food, even though the place wasn't full.  So worth it for the food quality and portions, but be prepared for a long wait to get it.

"Although initially dubious about the authenticity of Hawaiian cuisine in Las Vegas, my expectations were pleasantly surpassed by Island Flavor's offerings, with the exception of a few minor drawbacks. The portions were generously sized, with a single plate sufficient to satisfy three individuals had we been aware of their magnitude. The Kahlua pork, while somewhat lacking in saltiness, was tender and flavorful, while the sweet and sour pork ribs, though slightly overseasoned with salt, remained palatable. The Furikake chicken, enhanced by the addition of Sriracha, was particularly impressive. However, my primary criticisms pertain to the rice dishes. The brown rice, prepared with an excessive amount of water, resulted in a pair of soggy, unappealing scoops. In contrast, the fried rice, characterized by its predominantly white rice composition, Lapcherng, and vegetables immersed in soy sauce, fell short of my expectations for a traditional fried rice dish. Notwithstanding these issues, the COCO PUFFS, adorned with a mysterious yet delectable buttery yellow topping complementing the chocolate cream puff, earned high praise. Similarly, the mud pie, enhanced by the inclusion of chocolate cacao or coffee nibs in the kona coffee ice cream, was well-received, despite the unnecessary flavored syrups accompanying it. The staff maintained a friendly and accommodating demeanor, despite their hectic workload. Lastly, the Spam musubi, reminiscent of those enjoyed in Hawaii, rounded off the meal satisfactorily."

I love a good massage. My husband purchased a gift card for couples massage and gifted it to me for Christmas. Scheduling the massage was very easy. This location is very clean and the waiting room was very therapeutic. The massage room was ok. It was barely decorated and in kind of a weird layout. Our massage therapists were very friendly and professional. I can't say that I will be back after I use the rest of the money on my gift card, though. The massage was ok, but I've had much better ones. They really try to sell you on becoming a member when you are checking out, which I do not like.

"I was taken aback by the fact that the jerk fried rice did not possess the same level of piquancy as it had during my initial visit. Moreover, the portion size appeared diminutive in comparison to previous experiences, barely filling the circular aluminum receptacle. Despite these observations, the culinary offerings remained flavorsome and gratifying. I would advocate for the black beans over the refried variety, as they exhibit a more pronounced gustatory profile. The service was commendable, with the staff displaying promptness and amiability in their interactions with us. Notwithstanding, the ordering process proved somewhat perplexing, necessitating the guidance of the staff for novice patrons to fully comprehend the intricacies of the menu."

I had the occasion to visit the Starbucks situated within the Trails Village Center, and as I required access to an automated teller machine, I endeavored to utilize the facilities provided by Wells Fargo, only to discover that all three lanes, including the one featuring the aforementioned ATM, were devoid of any vehicles, thereby warranting a rating of nearly four stars, without further deliberation.

It is worth mentioning that although this particular establishment may be considered acceptable, its location outside of my immediate vicinity and the attendant difficulties associated with ingress and egress, owing to the substantial volume of traffic entering and exiting the Trails Center, render it a less than ideal choice.

Furthermore, having resided in this locality for in excess of ten years, this marks my initial visit to this specific venue, which, in and of itself, speaks volumes regarding its relative obscurity.

My review of Fin is pretty much the same as all of the other Yelpers. I found Fin to be a bit pricey for Chinese food, and the staff is very overly incredibly attentive. If you take a sip of water, someone is there to refill it for you. 

The food is good, though, there's no doubt about it. I ordered the stir-fry chicken and was very satisfied. They also follow up your meal with a delicious house made fortune cookie and shot of Baileys. 

The ambiance is fantastic if you sit toward the back and can block out the chachings of the nearby slot machines. 

Highly recommended for a nice dinner as long as you're aware of the price and overly attentie service staff.

I suppose its well stocked and closer for me than Tesco but it just doesnt have that friendly neighbourhood shop vibe. 
Twice in the last couple of weeks Ive been short changed and instead of a 'are you sure' or a 'lets see' the dude looked at me as if I just declared an interest in his wife.
Both times they were out by a pound or so. we aint talking 2p here man!


 They are on to me though. Last week I was overcharged for a coke and so I said 'I paid less last week'. He replied 'oh we undercharged you by mistake'...Good move that one...


 Finally, dont try and haggle. I haggled them for 20p off some Snapple but the only one who sanctions haggled goods is the Old Man. The other staff were taken by surprise and looked a little scared as I tried the haggling.

= = = = = =  DAILY LUNCH BUFFET!  = = = = = =

Monica O. spearheaded a UYE up here today and 15 of us came out to enjoy some tasty Thai food and great Yelpie fellowship!  (Thanks Monica!)  The Buffet featured 15 items including two soups, Vegetable with Egg & Tofu, and Coconut with Chicken.  There was plain and fancy rice offered, and a good number of hot dishes including chicken, beef and fish, as well as several vegetable combos, 19 items all together.

Everything was good here, and with only 3 Thai Buffets currently being offered in the Valley it's a plus to have these guys here.     :-)

The dining room here is comfortable and the table service was fine, but for me there were three drawbacks this time:

*  Nearly all of the meat dishes were chicken.

*  There were no dessert items included.

*  They only allow one credit or debit card payment per table.  In our case that meant that 14 of us were expected to have cash for our meal!  WHAT???     :-O

By some miracle I guess that all but one of us did have enough cash, but I think that policy is unsatisfactory.  Why not put the customer first?
                                                                                          `

Lunch Buffet:

Tuesday thru Friday $9.99 from 11:30 AM.
Sunday:  $10.99 from 12 noon.

I had the fish and tofu tacos for lunch. They use corn tortillas, which I respect. The fish was good and the tofu mixture was interesting, but the tacos were not particularly great.  The location seems good though. The bar has a lot of space around it, and I assume the patio is quite nice.

"The interior ambiance of this establishment exudes an eccentric charm that has captured the hearts of many patrons, rendering it a veritable hotspot for those seeking an affordable and delectable cup of tea, albeit with constrained operating hours that could potentially be extended to cater to the demands of an expanded customer base."

"The price point was appropriate. However, my predilection for the culinary offerings of Five Guys surpasses my affection for this establishment. Although the ambiance and gastronomical experience provided by What A Burger may be considered antiquated, it remains my preferred purveyor of burgers. Notwithstanding the crowded atmosphere, the staff at In-N-Out Burger exhibited commendable hospitality, yet the quality of their burgers pales in comparison to that of their competitors, thereby precipitating a deficiency in the overall satisfaction of my dining experience."

"It is my conviction that the preponderance of recent reviews are authored by individuals who are either employed by the establishment or are affiliated with said employees, and their familial connections thereto. 

Upon attempting to redeem my prepaid Groupon, I was met with resistance, as the eatery refused to honor said voucher. It is worth noting that the venue in question remains unchanged, both in terms of its moniker - Greek Grill & Fry Co. - and its continued operation under the same proprietorship. 
The server, though courteous and helpful in their suggestions, neglected to inform me of the restaurant's policy regarding the aforementioned Groupon prior to our culinary indulgences, opting instead to offer a reduced tariff of twenty percent. As a matter of personal protocol, I habitually allude to any applicable discounts or promotions upon arrival at an establishment. 

The fare provided by the restaurant was of satisfactory quality, albeit the options available were somewhat limited. However, the food was prepared promptly and served at an appropriate temperature.
