It is worth mentioning that during our visit, the only other patrons present were members of the proprietary family, one of whom - an elderly gentleman, presumably an uncle or grandfather - was situated within the dining area, engaged in the dual activities of television viewing and telephonic communication. The ambiance of the venue can be described as relaxed and informal."

There are some tables and a lot of slot machines. If you live in the area, it could be a good place to go and hang out. I would never recommend a drive from the strip to gamble here, but not bad for a locals hang out. With dollar beer and hot dogs, how can you go wrong!?

Its americanized, but pretty tasty! I love the fried rice and usually just get that. We were getting takeout once and waited at the bar, and the bartender gave us free tastes of the lychee cocktail while we waited! And that was tasty too!

Its also never crowded, its quiet and the service is consistently not bad. 

All that being said though, there isn't really anything special about this place. Its just kind of...eh... Best as take out.

I don't know about the lounge part everyone else has reviewed, but I had dinner there and was like meh about it. The portions are extremely small for the prices. Even the sake was a bit overpriced, I felt. The waitstaff, as much as I appreciate attentiveness, was maybe a little too overeager to get us the hell out of there. My husband's plate was actually cleared before he was even done eating. We eventually had to tell them to leave the plates until we were finished. While the ambiance is very cool and romantic, I don't think I'd drop another buck in there in the future.

This establishment no longer possesses the identical quality and culinary prowess it formerly boasted in years past. As an ardent patron since the early 1970's, I have witnessed a gradual decline in both the standard of service and gastronomical offerings since the turn of the millennium. It is no longer a viable dining option, failing to provide an adequate value for the price. Despite the persistently cordial demeanor of the staff and an aesthetically stagnant ambiance, my recent dining experience was marred by the unfortunate preparation of my New York strip steak, which was subjected to an unsolicited butterflying process that effectively extracted the inherent flavor and rendered it unpalatable. Lamentably, this once-lauded eatery has relinquished its erstwhile prestige, precluding me from enthusiastically recommending it to acquaintances embarking upon a culinary excursion to Las Vegas.
I'm not crazy about the food here, but there's a great (huge!) patio and I would go for a cocktail or glass of wine anytime :)

"Concurring with the prevailing sentiment, I must aver that this excursion does not qualify as a hike in the classical sense, owing to the presence of artificial stairs and an absence of any genuine ruggedness or challenge. Rather, it constitutes a leisurely stroll with a picturesque view of the surrounding landscape, conveniently located in close proximity to the local zoological garden. While it may serve as a charming diversion for a couple seeking a lighthearted adventure, it falls short of the rigorous criteria typically associated with hiking. Notwithstanding, I did appreciate the opportunity to showcase my stylish attire, replete with fashionable footwear, as I effortlessly ascended the hill."

I had arrived at this establishment prior to the purported culmination of the world, and it appeared that everyone else had already partaken in the festivities, as evidenced by their jubilant demeanor. My significant other had received a suggestion from her promoter that enabled us to gain admittance without incurring any financial obligations, and we were also presented with complimentary beverages shortly before the stroke of midnight, which contributed to the overall enjoyment of our visit. It is worth mentioning that Blush is rather diminutive in size when compared to XS and Surrender, lacking a designated area for dancing and instead featuring narrow pathways between the tables. Patrons may attempt to engage in dance within these confines, but such efforts are likely to result in an appearance of awkwardness due to the restricted nature of the space. The musical offerings within Blush seemed to be predominantly mainstream, with a reduced emphasis on hip-hop, prompting us to vacate the premises after a mere half hour and rejoin our companions who had been unable to gain entry.

The gastronomical expertise of the culinary artisan, as he endeavors to prepare an assortment of delectable noodle-based dishes in an outdoor setting, serves as a source of fascination for passersby who are drawn to the alluring aroma emanating from the cooking station. Predominantly, the chef focuses his attention on creating a flavorful variety of Pad Thai noodles, complemented by succulent beef strips that tantalize the taste buds of those who partake in this savory indulgence. Despite the unwavering dedication displayed by the culinary mastermind, it becomes apparent that the inherent quality of the consumables cannot be underestimated, as their satisfying essence satiates even the most formidable of appetites, leaving no room for doubt regarding their capacity to gratify the hunger of any individual who has the privilege of partaking in such a delectable feast. However, one must acknowledge that the emotional response elicited by the consumption of these delicacies transcends mere physical sustenance, as the sensory experience engenders a profound sense of satisfaction that cannot be readily dismissed or disregarded.

I went for lunch today with friends after a hike.  We were hungry.

I had a lunch meal.  The sandwich was fresh, hot and generous.  My side salad was wilted.  I would have thrown out the lettuce in my home.

One of my friends had a traditional breakfast, and he said he was great.  Eggs cook properly, and again generous portions.

My last friend (at breakfast, not on the face of the earth)  had a breakfast burrito, and said it was very good.  I think my salad was the weakest link.

The service was good, and everyone seemed very friendly.  We were seated within 10 minutes, and being warned there would be a wait.  They left carafes of coffee, iced tea, and soda on the table for self-refilling.

The prices were fine.  I'd go back, but avoid the salad...at least at lunch time.

We dined at this establishment on our final day in Las Vegas, as our group was collectively experiencing the unpleasant aftereffects of excessive alcohol consumption from the previous night's festivities. In light of our fragile conditions, we opted for a nourishing and comforting meal, comprising of a variety of soups and dim sum. Although my fiery chicken wing selection did not live up to its name in terms of spiciness, it still possessed an appreciable flavor profile. The steamed dumplings, bursting with succulent shrimp, were undoubtedly a highlight of the meal. The duck noodle soup, while not exceptional, offered a satisfying experience due to the tender and juicy nature of the avian component. A slight drawback was encountered with the hot and sour soup, as its pungent seasoning proved somewhat overwhelming, although the inclusion of an adequate quantity of mushrooms was certainly welcome. Lastly, the chrysanthemum iced tea we sampled was indeed delightful, its subtle floral essence providing a refreshing contrast to the richness of the preceding dishes.

This location was right by ASU. It was empty on a holiday. Our server was great. The food was cooked perfectly. And they even had a \"study hall\" for students which I thought was a great idea. The only suggestion that comes from who I attended with is that if there is an upcharge that the waitress mentions it prior to getting a surprise on your bill. There is mention of it in the menu, but it doesn't spell out that there is an extra $2 for a slice of cheese on your eggs.

The prices were great, but they were out of stout...

I was a bit crowded and that left the staff super spread out... Our table faced the kitchen door and it was obvious they only had two cooks in the kitchen, I wonder how the dining room got so croweded?  But for the price I don't mind having to wait for our food, beg for water and the check.

I will say the people watching was priceless!  It looked like perhaps a convention of middle-aged mid-west salesmen had hit the place hard just before we were seated! Hilarious :)

We procured accommodations for a mere $35 per nocturnal period, a tariff comparable to that of a Motel-6 establishment, yet the lodging itself was of superior quality, boasting amenities that far surpassed those typically offered by the aforementioned motel chain. Furthermore, the aquatic recreational areas were truly remarkable, and each guest was granted a complimentary beverage pass, which enabled them to partake in a variety of refreshing potables without incurring any additional expenses. Additionally, the fitness center was quite impressive, featuring an array of state-of-the-art exercise equipment designed to facilitate a vigorous workout routine. In conclusion, I wholeheartedly endorsed this lodging establishment, deeming it a most satisfactory choice for travelers seeking comfortable and affordable accommodations.

Finally, someone got smart and decided to open a Metro Pizza in Henderson! I no longer have to fight UNLV students on their lunch break for a nice booth and some pizza. The new location I believe is better than the original. It has a full bar area, a party room, and regular dining room. There is also a separate wing for pick up orders so you don't have to trek all the way through the restaurant in your pj's and slippers. The pizza is great on its own, but the nuclear fries are so good, I would go just for those. They are spiced and have a bit of a kick, and make the perfect addition for a pie. They also have a variety of beers on tap, which also obviously pairs well with pizza. Avoid the weekend evenings though because the hype around the new restaurant is still prevalent. It's packed. Lunch is the best time, and things stay pretty quiet. 

Recommended pizza: The margherita.

Recommended beer: Hefeweizen with some lemons.

This is the cheapest option if you are in Paris, which isn't saying much. We'll actually there's a place two doors down that had sandwiches in a display case but for an extra dollar or two we got a much more appetizing sandwich here. \n\nI definitely would not go out of your way for this place. However, if it is 2pm, you just got in from your flight and don't want another airport refrigerated sandwich, then just maybe this is the place for you too.

First and foremost, I am more than willing to expend financial resources on acquiring a high-quality cup of coffee, as I believe that the inherent value of such a beverage far surpasses any monetary consideration. However, I must admit that the ambient surroundings in which said coffee is consumed have undergone a marked transformation over the past six months, resulting in an atmosphere that is now vastly different from the one I had grown accustomed to. Specifically, the familiar faces of my preferred baristas are now conspicuously absent, leading me to speculate that their departure may be attributable to the recent relocation of the establishment. While I cannot assert with certainty the cause of this shift in personnel, I must confess that the coffee itself has become somewhat less satisfying to my palate, a development that fills me with a sense of melancholy, as it has necessitated a modification in my previously steadfast patronage of this establishment. In essence, the alteration in staff serves as a poignant reminder of the profound impact that individuals can have on the overall ambiance of a given setting.

This constitutes an assessment of Flavors, the sumptuous smorgasbord situated within the premises of Harrah's. Every time I venture out to Las Vegas, I make a concerted effort to partake in a culinary excursion to this establishment. While the prices may not be considered economical, the vast array of delectable options more than compensates for the additional expense. Patrons can indulge in a diverse selection of enticing cuisines, including Mexican, Italian, seafood, fresh fare, Chinese, and an assortment of mouthwatering desserts. Each visit has yielded a novel gastronomic experience, as the menu boasts an impressive array of innovative additions. The standard tariff for a single individual is approximately $20; however, participation in the timeshare program can result in a substantial discount, with the possibility of securing two admissions for the price of one. Unfortunately, my recent visit proved disappointing, as I discovered that access to the timeshare opportunity is restricted to individuals aged 28 and above. Although I am only 24, I successfully participated in the program during a previous visit a few months ago. It is worth noting that the timeshare promotion is conducted at the casino's entrance, and staff members are proactive in approaching potential participants, particularly couples or those who appear to be part of a pair.

Last week, my spouse and I opted to partake in a midday repast at a local eatery, whereupon we encountered a somewhat underwhelming culinary experience due to the mediocre quality of the fare and the sluggishness of the server. Despite these drawbacks, our meals did come accompanied by several complimentary items such as a bowl of broth, a crispy cylindrical pastry, and a trio of deep-fried dumplings. However, the soup did not conform to my expectations of a traditional Thai soup, the spring roll was excessively oily, and the wontons lacked discernible flavor. My partner chose the yellow curry, while I selected the Panang variant; furthermore, I requested that my dish be prepared at the Thai spicy level, yet it was merely moderately piquant. In light of this experience, we have decided to explore alternative Thai dining options in the future, specifically the Thai Cafe, which lies approximately a mile distant from our current location.

"The fruit and vegetables procured from this establishment may not consistently possess optimal quality, as I have previously purchased a bag of plums from this location at a discounted price, only to discover upon consumption that they had deteriorated in freshness. However, I was able to successfully slow cook them, resulting in an unexpectedly delectable culinary experience. It is essential to exercise caution when acquiring items at a significantly reduced cost or those that are out of season, as there exists a heightened risk of compromised quality. Nonetheless, it is crucial to emphasize that a plethora of satisfactory products can be found among the offerings, thereby rendering it judicious to maintain vigilance in the face of potential disappointment."

I'll start with the food. It was good. My husband enjoyed the steak and I got the halibut. Both really tasty. Baked potato was stellar and they have a 'wine of the month' which you can get for $20 or if you have the hotel coupon book, free.

Service. Was very attentive in some ways, non-existent in others. Served us drinks/wine right away. Never brought bread and we had to ask for our entree after being there about 75 minutes and then rush to make our show. Not a huge deal EXCEPT the server was super defensive about it and made excuses, which I thought was weird as we weren't irritable when we mentioned it, just asked because we needed to get out of there.

Seemed super pricey for South Point too, but if you want a special occasion and are staying there - I'd say try it. It was good.

"It is patently evident that securing a reservation at this establishment during the festive Christmas season is an absolute imperative, particularly for parties comprising more than two individuals. The dearth of vacant tables during our visit underscored the pressing need for a prior appointment, as we were compelled to occupy seats at the bar owing to the absence of availability. The prices charged for the culinary offerings were considerable, with a modest soup costing a tenner and a special combination of soup and pasta setting patrons back by nineteen dollars. Notwithstanding the elevated tariffs, the gastronomic experience was merely passable, as one of my colleagues was obliged to return the special due to the uncooked state of the meat. However, the eatery's personnel demonstrated commendable alacrity in recognizing and addressing the issue, which merited a generous gratuity."

I really like Lavo (as a nightclub)! Have yet to have a meal here though, so this review is for the nightclub only. Space-wise it can get pretty cramped because it's a bit on the smaller side, but nowhere near as uncomfortably packed as Tao. Dance floor is pretty tiny, but honestly, I didn't notice it until the place had mostly cleared out and I got a good look around. They play hip-hop and a lot of old songs, but old in a way that makes you go "oh man, I haven't heard this song in a while, but  it's still awesome," which I think is a nice change of pace from all the clubs that play almost exclusively house music.

Lavo is probably a 3.5 in my book, though I have to admit, part of the reason for that is because we had open bar, courtesy of our wonderful promoter (who also got our guys in for free!) There's a main bar area, but we got all our drinks from the side bar, which was super crowded and only had one bartender working there. But he was a really adorable and sweet bartender, so no complaints.

tl;dr: Everyone in my group had a fairly fun time. Would definitely come back-- especially if we're staying at the Venetian/Palazzo!

"Although certain aspects of this establishment were satisfactory, such as its proximity to the Town & Country shopping center and the ample parking facilities, other elements, including the meager amount of meat and toppings on the sandwiches, left much to be desired. Furthermore, the preponderance of bread in these sandwiches made them seem unbalanced and lacking in substance. While the chocolate milkshake was a notable highlight, it was not enough to compensate for the overall mediocrity of the dining experience. In light of these factors, it is difficult to wholeheartedly recommend this venue, especially when compared to more affordable options such as Subway, where one can expect a greater quantity and variety of ingredients."

"I would assign a rating of 3.5 to this establishment, as my expectations for an exceptional culinary experience were not entirely fulfilled, despite the fact that it is a specialized pie restaurant. While the pizza was undoubtedly palatable, I have had the pleasure of indulging in superior specimens. However, the ambiance of this venue is quite captivating, with dim lighting, dark tables arranged in a manner that respects patrons' privacy, and an open-concept bar adjacent to a warm fire emanating from the oven. Additionally, their wine selection is quite impressive. We opted for the cheese board, which offered a satisfactory assortment of flavors. Both my companion and I chose to order pizza, yet it failed to surpass our expectations, although it was by no means subpar."

I rarely frequent Fresh and Easy due to the lack of visual appeal of their stores, with the exception of a few select items that pique my interest, primarily snacks such as peanut butter filled salted pretzel nubs, some satisfactory salted kettle chips, and a passable trail mix suitable for hiking excursions. My brief visit to the store yesterday served as a testament to my unfamiliarity with its layout, as I aimlessly wandered the aisles in search of my desired products, not unlike a zombie driven by an unyielding determination to acquire the items on my list. Following a swift checkout process, during which I presented only two items for purchase, I proceeded to venture across the street to Albertsons, whereupon I conducted a more extensive and deliberate shopping expedition.

Really great salsa bar, tacos, quesadillas and burros.  This is 'authentic' mexican; not Macayos.  \nA few downsides though, it is really small & not really built for families or large groups; plus, I wouldn't park in the neighboring streets.  I got yelled at by one homeowner saying if they saw my vehicle again they're having it TOWED!.

"The gastronomical experience afforded by the consumption of these burgers, at a price point that can only be described as eminently reasonable, is nothing short of exceptional, particularly when considered in conjunction with the ambiance fostered by the establishment's unique setting, which serves to facilitate convivial dialogue among patrons; however, it must be noted that certain aspects of the menu, specifically the dearth of diversity in the realm of beer offerings, as well as the rather unremarkable quality of the fries served as an accompaniment to the main course, do detract somewhat from the overall enjoyment of the dining experience."

Food is great but service is terrible. This is one of my favorite restaurants, but this location doesn't make the grade. Waited 15 minutes in an empty restaurant at 1:30 for a bean burrito to go. Seriously...
Good flavor, good service, long wait and under done pepperonis. Gotta go to Grimaldis in Brooklyn to compare the two. Nothing special.

This is for the Sunday night concert series. If you like families and dogs and strollers and people running around your blanket and trains blaring their horns and lousy sound systems and parking from hell, the Sunday night concert series should be on your radar. My chunky date and myself found a decent location away from the stage, but still experienced most everything previously mentioned. None of it really bothered us too much, so if you can endure all of that or actually somebody with multiple dogs and kids, then this is your piece of cake. The Scottsdale douchebag factor was not in effect, but you will have to arrive early to get a spot across the street. Now, it might have been more crowded due to holiday weekend, but who knows unless I go again which I doubt.
Went on a night that they had a live band on the patio.....was a nice atmosphere. Drinks were good but food was just okay. May go back if other places are too busy.

"Aesthetically pleasing accommodations, albeit briefly inhabited, rendered an additional tariff of $50 for early ingress. Contrasted with the alternative of slumbering within the confines of our minuscule Honda Insight alongside my spouse, infant, and mother-in-law, this arrangement proved preferable. Notwithstanding, the availability of power outlets for our diverse assortment of mobile devices necessitated a systematic rotation and judicious utilization of the facilities' electrical infrastructure. Lamentably, the queue for registration extended interminably, attended by an insufficient number of personnel to facilitate its expeditious progression... Lamentably, the process of settling our financial obligations similarly degenerated into chaos, as the throngs of patrons vying to vacate the premises swelled to unmanageable proportions during the terminal phase of our sojourn. Gratuities notwithstanding, the absence of a coffee brewing apparatus within our quarters occasioned mild disappointment. Furthermore, the egress protocol struck us as somewhat bizarre, advocating instead for a simplified, hassle-free procedure involving the placement of the invoice beneath the entrance to our abode, followed by a swift and unencumbered departure, devoid of any unnecessary delays or complications. Ultimately, despite some minor shortcomings, our stay at the TI proved satisfactory, yet, given the tariff, we might opt to seek alternative lodgings in the future."

Last evening, we opted to partake of a culinary excursion to the esteemed eatery known as Mert's, whereupon we indulged in their delectable Fried Catfish and Beef Rib Combo. Alas, our gastronomical experience was not without its drawbacks, as the whole fried catfish presented some difficulties in navigating the bony terrain, ultimately yielding a meager amount of succulent fish. Furthermore, "The Beef Rib" dish was found to be somewhat lacking in quantity, with the meat being chopped into small pieces and intermingled with an abundance of bones. However, we must commend the kitchen staff for their proficiency in preparing the sides, particularly the Mac and Cheese, which boasted a satisfying crust on its surface, and the Corn Bread, whose texture and flavor were both pleasing, although a minor quibble could be raised regarding the slightly overcooked nature of the piece my spouse received, resulting in a somewhat dry and unfortunate conclusion to an otherwise enjoyable repast. In summary, while not without its flaws, our visit to Mert's proved to be a generally satisfactory dining experience.

I love John Hughes movies, but this Breakfast Club did not live up to its namesake. The eggs were serviceable, but the potatoes O'Brian (I learned a new thing here!) were nothing special--kind of soft and oily, with large chunks of pepper. The jalepeno biscuits, which sounded conceptually grand, were not quite what I'd call a biscuit. They were tough, unflavorful little disks with jalepenos baked in. The heuvos rancheros looked like something my cat barfed up, however, they tasted fine, according to my breakfastmate. \n\nOverall, I think this was a shade greasier than we were expecting. And outdoor seating is nice, but a mixed bag when abutting a busy road. The service was good, but something about the waitresses reminded me of the Stepford Wives.
Overall it's a nice place the reason for only 3 stars is this: $5 to park,$35.99 entrance, $8 small locker, $3 water and only 5 working slides, a wave pool and lazy river. Make up your own minds ...

Fairly typical Chinese food with a Sushi menu and nice restaurant seating area.  I wasn't as wow'd as I was hoping after reading all the rave reviews here on Yelp, but it is a pretty decent offering.

I tried the egg drop soup, which was a good value, the pork dumplings, which were meh - I think the sauce was overly sweet, the kung pao chicken, which was pretty good, and the chicken lo mein noodles, which were meh (but aren't all lo mein noodles pretty meh?).

Overall I would come back and get some take out because it does lie somewhere in between your PFChangs and your strip mall cheap Chinese take out place.  However, I don't believe it's that great of a value offering.  The prices are a bit high for cheap Chinese, and the quality is only just a bit higher.  Doesn't feel like you're getting a great deal.

The decor here is adorable. It made me want to sit and stay a while. I had my first macaroon, well two, mixed berry and raspberry. People always rave about them (not necessarily from here, but in general) so I decided to indulge. I didn't love or hate them. I'll definitely be back to try other options.

Footlocker isn't that exciting, it stocks all the shoe brands you would expect to find in a trainer shop such as; Reebok, Nike, Adidas and a seemingly unnecessary amount of basketball sneakers. The prices are medium to expensive but they often have sales on where you can bag yourself a bargain but the sales usually only offer terrible looking shoes that nobody else wants.\n\nI guess Footlocker is more of a guys shop because whenever I've popped in they've had hundreds of guys shoes but a rather a measly amount of ladies ones so it's not somewhere I pop in that often. If I am looking for a new pair of trainers I will pop in to see what's on offer but more often than not I find myself going elsewhere.

My fiance said I should write a review.    I replied that the restaurant didn't strike me as good or bad.  It was pretty middle of the road.

2.5 stars for me.

Service was fine.   No real complaints or compliments there.

Food.  During happy hour, you get 2 tacos for $3 Chef's choice of tacos.  And I delighted in eating the salmon taco.   

I was expecting grand things from the guacamole and was disappointed.   The dried cranberries were an interesting addition.  But I much prefer good ol' Trader Joe's guacamole.

Food was rico.   Rico means "rich" in Spanish and usually a compliment.   I just found the food rico in terms of calories.

I wouldn't mind going back but neither am I itching to return either.

This isn't a movie theater that I frequent regularly since I live in NLV, but the "renovations" since Rave owned the place seems favorable. They've added extended armrests between each seat with a heavier duty cup holder than you're used to but has pros and cons; while it makes sharing drinks and snacks easier, it also makes the armrest stationary. 

PRO:
New armrests are larger.
Snack bar seems to be larger than most.

CON:
The movie (White House Down) started about 20 minutes late, apparently nobody was in the operating room.
There were only like 30 M&Ms in the package I purchased at the snack bar.

"Ja... ganz OK."
Für "Jawohl. So lob' ich mir das." fehlt noch etwas...

Eine Location mit dem Ansatz "Burger & Bratwurst" außerhalb einer Fast-Food Kette anzubieten. Eher Restaurant als Bar...

Im Prinzip gibt es keine fertigen Gerichte sondern einen Baukasten aus dem man(n) sich seine Portion/ Gericht selbst zusammen stellen kann.
Der Service war bisher immer sehr freundlich (aufmerksam aber nicht aufdringlich)

Keine schlechte Location, aber das Gesamtkonzept (Preis-Leistung) ist IMHO noch nicht ganz schlüssig umgesetzt. Im Augenblick kommt es mir so vor wie eine Kreuzung zwischen Szeneladen Berlin-Mitte und den aktuell sehr angesagten Münchner "Currywurst-Bars"...

Hohe Frauenquote ;-)

A group of us went here to eat some burgers since we heard they had good burgers. The food was good but somewhat oily and dry. I woul of given the restaurant 4 stars if it wasn't for the horrible service provided by Olivia. She had a bad attitude throughout the whole time we were there for no reason at all. We asked for a To Go box and she just threw it on the table, which we thought was so rude. We asked our waters to be filled 3 times before she actually got around to it. The restaurant is expensive, so I expected better service. Overall, it's worth going if you enjoy a good burger. Hopefully, you get a better waitress/waiter.

"I decided to indulge in an afternoon delight, opting for a frozen yogurt treat from Golden Spoon. With an array of delectable flavors to choose from, I settled on Irish creme, adorned with almond roca topping. Initially, I relished every bite, savoring the richness of the frozen confection. However, as I progressed through my treat, my thoughts became increasingly preoccupied with the unmistakable zest of Twangy Tart. The tangy, fruity essence of this flavor captivated my taste buds, leaving me in a state of utter fascination. It was as if the Ice Tango had performed a tantalizing dance on my tongue, leaving an indelible impression. From that moment forward, I found myself irreversibly enamored with the Twang, and no other frozen yogurt establishment could compare. Golden Spoon, once my go-to destination for frozen delights, had suddenly become secondary. My taste buds had been forever transformed by the magical touch of Ice Tango, and nothing would ever be the same again."

"While the culinary offerings at this establishment are undoubtedly palatable, they fail to justify the cost associated with their consumption. My recent visit afforded me the opportunity to sample their allegedly piquant poultry dish, which, I must admit, lived up to its billing in terms of its fiery demeanor. However, my gratification was somewhat tempered by the exorbitant tariff levied for the meal, specifically $11 for a midday repast that, in my estimation, did not warrant such an extravagant expenditure. Notwithstanding, I would still confer upon the victuals a rating of four stars out of five, cognizant of the fact that my reservations pertain primarily to the pricing and not necessarily the quality or flavor of the fare itself."

"Although my culinary expectations were not entirely fulfilled by the pho I had ordered at this establishment, I did observe that certain menu items consumed by fellow patrons appeared to possess a level of gastronomical quality that was ostensibly superior. This observation instilled within me a sense of curiosity regarding the potential merits of the restaurant's offerings, leading me to consider the possibility of future visits during which I might sample a broader array of dishes. It is worth noting, however, that my initial impression of the venue was that it seemed to be more heavily influenced by American culinary traditions than its counterparts in the Spring Mountain area, which may have contributed to my relative disappointment with the pho."

"This shopping center formerly enjoyed a preeminent status among its peers within the locality. However, with the advent of Arizona Mills, Chandler Fashion Center, and Tempe Marketplace, it appears that a significant proportion of patrons residing in Chandler, Tempe, and Gilbert have migrated their allegiance to these newer retail establishments. Despite this shift, a plethora of quality stores continue to operate within Fiesta, mirroring an array of identical retailers found at the aforementioned competitors. Notably, during peak sales periods and holidays, the mall's diminished foot traffic translates into a more comfortable and convenient shopping experience for patrons. Additionally, Fiesta boasts a unique covered parking area, which distinguishes it from its rivals and offers a welcome respite from the sweltering heat during the summer months."

I know I said that they were professional and all, but the other day we received a bill for what the insurance wouldn't pay.  It came in a decent envelope, but then we opened it.

Plain sheet of paper with printing.  No tear-off portion, no return envelope (not to mention return postage - I wouldn't expect that from anyone).  Just a sheet, badly folded, printed out on a cheap printer.

So much for professional.  I guess that only extends to examinations - and presumably procedures.  Definitely not to the billing department.  We get a lot of medical bills since we started buying our own insurance, and this is definitely the cheapest of the bunch.

I get that it's only a few cents for an envelope and all - but it can't cost them much more to have some reasonably pre-printed invoices with tear-off return portions, much less a return envelope.  It would just make for a nicer experience, you know?

"An extraordinary location, offering an ambiance that exudes sophistication and elegance, yet remains welcoming and approachable. The Chopped Salad, a culinary masterpiece, undoubtedly reigns supreme among its peers, boasting an unparalleled flavor profile that transcends the mundane and enters the realm of gastronomic excellence. However, its portion size, though adequate for a light repast, falls short of expectations considering its premium pricing. Perhaps, a more generous serving, tantamount to the quality of the dish, might encourage increased patronage.  

Regarding beverages, the flight, while maintaining an acceptable level of potency, unfortunately, requires an interminable waiting period, analogous to the time spent awaiting the arrival of an errant canine on one's lawn. Nonetheless, the BBQ sauce, a tangy and savory condiment, serves as a delightful accompaniment to the main course. The staff, though proficient in their duties, fails to exhibit the exceptional level of hospitality one might anticipate given the upscale nature of the establishment. A gratuity or complimentary dessert, bestowed upon patrons in acknowledgment of merely satisfactory service, could potentially redeem an otherwise unremarkable dining experience and foster customer loyalty. 

In conclusion, this venue, harmonizing seamlessly with the vibrant downtown Scottsdale atmosphere, offers a unique and enjoyable dining adventure. Nevertheless, it is advisable to avoid the buffalo meat, as it may evoke imagery associated with canine visitors and detract from the overall epicurean indulgence."

"The culinary offerings at this establishment were of considerable quality, possessing both substantial quantity and delectable flavor. However, when juxtaposed with alternative taco establishments or Mexican cuisine, it becomes apparent that the fare offered here is merely mediocre. As an ardent devotee of Mexican cuisine, I find myself yearning for the genuine authenticity that other eateries provide, which is conspicuously lacking in this particular venue, perhaps due to its location within a casino. \nMy primary grievance pertains to the exorbitant pricing, wherein a meal for two individuals amounted to a staggering $54. Although the quality of the food was satisfactory and benefited from a discount for gamblers, I would be utterly dismayed if I were compelled to expend in excess of $50 for a dining experience of comparable caliber. Therefore, while I encourage potential patrons to sample the culinary delights available here, they should be cognizant of the fact that the cost does not justify the quality provided."

"While the eatery offers palatable cuisine at an affordable cost, my culinary expeditions have acquainted me with superior sushi establishments that offer a comparable price point and occasionally, it is worthwhile to expend additional funds to indulge in exceptional fare. The presentation of their maki rolls frequently appears haphazard and unpolished, and certain types of seafood, such as fresh tuna or yellowtail, may lack the optimal level of freshness. Although suitable for a hasty midday repast, this dining venue does not qualify as an appropriate setting for an elegant evening meal."

"Encountered an individual at this location, with the intention of engaging in a recreational activity on the tennis courts.  To our astonishment, the facilities were in a state of good repair, despite the absence of net straps, which did not deter us from participating in the sport.  Generally speaking, this complex possesses a certain appeal... However, my singular grievance would be the convoluted design of the parking area, replete with numerous curved pathways, thereby creating numerous blind spots for drivers who must reverse their vehicles.  Although this layout may contribute to the aesthetic appeal of the surroundings, it would undoubtedly pose a formidable challenge for maintenance personnel, as the absence of straightforward trajectories necessitates additional effort in upkeep. \n\nObserved that the residential units appeared sturdy and well-constructed, employing brick as the primary building material... Nevertheless, the proximity of the highway resulted in significant noise pollution, permeating the atmosphere and rendering it audible even from the tennis court.  Did not venture inside a specific dwelling, yet the auditory level was considerable, even from a distance."

Applebee's is just one of those boring chain restaurants.  I do really love some chains, but alas, Applebee's is not one of them.   Everything is just ok.  Nothing ever blows my socks off or makes me crave to come here, but it isn't bad either, just blah.

I found myself here yesterday because I was outvoted by the group I was with.  Oh well, it happens.  We went for lunch and it was an ok experience.  I had the Bourbon Black and Bleu Burger.  It was surprising yummy.  It had a lot of kick and I had a small party in my mouth.  It was better than I was expected, which was a nice surprise.  The other people in the party both got the 3 cheese penne and chicken dish.  I didn't sample it, but they both enjoyed it.  My picky eater, my 18 month old did surprise me by eating half of her grilled cheese.  She never eats anything, so that made me happy.  I tried a bite and it was quite good with the bread being a sweet, eggy bread, like brioche.  

The service was really good and we always had what we wanted without having to ask for it, which made for a pleasant meal.

So over all, the food was good, the service was great, but I am still bored with the overall place.  Give me Chili's anyday, but this Applebee's did a good job today.  Way to go Applebee's for slowing changing my opinion about you.

This was my second trip to this location and I noticed their salad bar had fewer items from before.  It was still very good but am disappointed that they seemed to have eliminated some items. I am not a big meat eater and came for the salad bar so I noticed these things. It was still really really good however.

"My culinary experience at Spago was rather divergent, as while I relished my repast, my fellow diners appeared to be more thoroughly enthralled. The wedge salad, though unremarkable in its composition, was nevertheless palatable; conversely, the heirloom tomato and burrata salad special was truly exceptional, constituting the most delectable dish of the evening. We opted to share three pizzas among us, which, regrettably, failed to elicit the same level of enthusiasm due to their relatively lackluster crusts. Specifically: 

The Margherita pizza, with its somewhat undercooked crust and uninspired toppings, could be described as merely adequate; the Proscuitto pizza, featuring a harmonious combination of prosciutto and fromage blanc, showed promise, but was hindered by the aforementioned subpar crust; lastly, the Lamb Chorizo pizza, despite its commendable quality, did not quite ascend to the level of true excellence owing to its incongruous topping arrangement. 

Notwithstanding these criticisms, the service we received throughout our meal was indeed impressive."

Great place for the price. Not the most luxurious place on the strip but the amenities are decent, the service is good, and the location is fantastic. Very good value overall.

This is the 4th or 5th time we've stayed here. The rooms are clean and comfortable, and there is a decent selection of food downstairs ranging from McDonald's to 5 star French, and everything in between. The casino floor is a bit small and smoky, but perfect for when you're not in the mood to get dressed up and go out. The spa is small and reasonably priced. And it's only a few minutes' walk to other casinos, restaurants, and shopping at the many malls nearby.

The only things we didn't care much for were the showers (high pressure mist that's definitely not my idea of pleasant) and on our most recent trip the TV didn't work properly (but we didn't call to have it fixed because it just wasn't that important to us).

Yes, you can stay at a nicer, trendier, and/or more luxurious place on the strip but you'll pay about twice as much. We prefer to stay here, where we're always satisfied, and use the cash we saved to eat, play, and party while we're in town.

"Tucked away in an unassuming location, nestled adjacent to the lavishly adorned Ella's Deli, this eatery may prove challenging to detect at first glance, but a visit is undoubtedly merited if one seeks a delectable gyro or kebab experience. Although somewhat overshadowed by its resplendent neighbor, this establishment boasts an array of palatable delights, including a diverse selection of donuts, cookies worthy of praise, and even homemade baklava for those inclined towards such culinary indulgences. Sandwiches, enhanced by a side of flavorful seasoned fries, serve as the piÃ¨ce de rÃ©sistance, offering a gustatory satisfaction that transcends mere sustenance. For those who prefer vegetarian fare, fear not, as options such as potato kahbi and falafel sandwiches are readily available, catering to dietary inclinations without sacrificing taste. A varied assortment of beverages further complements the menu, ensuring that thirst and hunger are simultaneously satiated. Despite its unfortunate placement, a visit to this venue remains worthwhile for those venturing into the surrounding vicinity."

When this establishment first inaugurated its operations, it boasted an exceptional quality, thereby warranting a perfect five-star rating. However, over time, its standards have subsided, rendering it merely satisfactory. Despite this decline, my father continues to patronize this venue, and thus, we visited it together. Our meal commenced with the grilled artichoke, customarily a delectable option. Unfortunately, this particular instance proved disappointing, as the artichoke exhibited a pronounced rigidity and lacked discernible flavor, perhaps due to the off-season availability of this ingredient. Nonetheless, the accompanying aioli sauce compensated for the artichoke's deficiencies, offering a savory delight. The prime rib, though tender and possessing a satisfactory flavor profile, failed to impress, as its portion size has diminished progressively during my visits. This consistent reduction in magnitude was coupled with a uniform selection of sides, specifically a baked potato. Ultimately, our dining experience concluded without the customary sweet treat. Despite these shortcomings, the prospect of future visits remains viable, primarily owing to my father's persistent fondness for this eatery.

Barneys is a multifaceted drinking establishment that offers a unique experience for patrons seeking a more relaxed atmosphere than the typical bars in the vicinity. For individuals desiring an unpretentious environment where they can enjoy themselves without the necessity of dressing up or paying covers, Barneys may be the ideal destination.

The second floor of the bar particularly stood out to me as a preferred spot, owing to the hospitable demeanor of the bartender and their promptness in refilling drinks. Although the rooftop area has the potential to be an attractive spot during warmer weather, the presence of smoking therein serves as a deterrent for some.

One notable aspect of Barneys is its innovative method of pouring beer from the bottom up, creating a distinctive and entertaining experience for customers. Moreover, for those who have had a few too many drinks, the bar features an amusing arcade game involving a lobster claw, reminiscent of the classic claw machine found at carnivals and arcades.

Overall, Barneys earns a rating of 3.5 stars for its distinctive ambiance and diverse offerings that cater to various preferences.

My wife went there recently during the week with a few friends. It was a Monday afternoon. She said it was not what she expected. It was a neat experience but not as many animals as she thought. 10 bucks to get in for locals and that seemed kinda steep after she got in and realized how minimal the park was.  Also it was over 100 degrees and there was not a drop of water to be had. Every water fountain she stopped at....it said out of order.  This is very dangerous for visitors. They should have water available st all times.

As a UNLV student, this place has one of the best deals around. 5 tacos, 2 sides and a drink for $5, and the tacos are really good.  They are traditional street tacos, so on the smaller side, but they don't skimp you on the meat.  It's a fun place to go with friends, get a bucket of beers, and sit around and chat.  It's order at the counter, and they'll call your number when your food is ready.  I think that they also have either live music or a DJ on some nights, usually Latin themed, shocking, I know...

I am very torn about First Friday. I absolutely love community events. Especially art walks, and more creative culture, but this is very lacking. I want to love it because it's in my back yard, too! 

However, First Friday leaves me with a sense of empty feeling. Located in the arts district downtown should be plenty of reason why this event should boast art, but it doesn't. 

The art galleries are lacking, and the street vendors that sell art are more there to just get a buck than they are about art. 

Then there's the riff raff of downtown trying to join in, and so many kids everywhere! I guess police try to crack down on curfew, but there's always so many grungy kids that are up to no good running around. 

The food stalls are nice during summer hours, winter many vendors decide to stay home. 

I'll probably end up going back in the summer, but I'll go early before it gets dark, and the crazy kids (literally kids) come out at night.

I had a profound affection for the ambiance and the personnel who were responsible for creating it, as they exhibited an exceptional level of competence in their respective roles. However, the culinary offerings did not quite live up to my expectations, despite being satisfactory in terms of taste and presentation. Furthermore, the tariff charged for the meal did not seem to align with the value proposition offered by the restaurant, leading me to question the overall value for money.

"I recently had the occasion to partake in a culinary excursion to TMI for an evening repast. While the gastronomical experience was not without its merits, it failed to surpass my expectations in terms of overall satisfaction. Upon initiating the meal, we opted to sample the TMI toast, which, despite some reservations regarding the texture of the bread, proved to be a satisfying commencement to the delectation process. However, my subsequent selection, the Mac & Cheese, unfortunately did not live up to my gustatory standards, as it was noticeably oleaginous and lacking in flavor. It is worth mentioning that I have historically been able to establish a rapport with nearly any iteration of Mac & Cheese, yet the version proffered by TMI unfortunately did not conform to this trend. The remaining members of my dining party opted for sandwiches and salads, the quality of which, according to their accounts, ranged from satisfactory to palatable. Aesthetically, the ambiance of the establishment exuded a certain je ne sais quoi, while the degree of auditory intensity rendered conversation somewhat challenging. Furthermore, the temperature within the premises was uncomfortably elevated. In conclusion, while TMI may possess certain attributes that could potentially appeal to certain gastronomes, my own experience did not warrant an overly enthusiastic endorsement, thereby rendering my return in the proximate future unlikely."

I was surprised to find that had a TON of brand new irrigation supplies. As a gardener, I am always fiddling with the irrigation, and am in constant need of emitters, hose, and connectors to support my filthy habit. They have it all (at least when I went), and at a fraction of what the hardware store charges.

"It serves as an enjoyable venue for social gatherings, facilitating the relational dynamics of communal dining. My culinary inclinations lean towards familial-style sharing, which this establishment accommodates seamlessly. However, our ordered dishes displayed inconsistent quality, with a notable eggplant and goat cheese entrÃ©e featuring an excessive proportion of cheese that overpowered the subtle flavor of the eggplant. In contrast, a dish comprising eggs, potatoes, and another component (the specificity of which escapes my memory) presented an unbalanced ratio of potato to other ingredients, prompting a sense of disappointment. Nonetheless, both the filet mignon and Thai beef salad showcased remarkable taste, rendering my overall experience gratifying. Despite some reservations, I am content with having visited this restaurant, yet I harbor doubts about returning in the future."

So we hadn't been since this place used to be Cafe Del Sol (yes, a few years ago). We used the Groupon we had purchased about a month ago. It was kind of awkward because there's the main dining room and a separate red-headed step child dining room around the corner, not really attached at all to the main dining room and probably all the excitement. We got there right at the end of happy hour and wifey ordered a glass of Sangria, I had a glass of Tempranillo (that totally blew by the way).  I ended up ordering another glass of wine (don't remember the name) and it was pretty good. I got the cola and pineapple braised short ribs, jalapeno cream corn a chile corn casserole. The sides were good, although the corn casserole was a tad dry. The shorts ribs were great, they didn't have that cheap pot roast taste that some braised short ribs can have. The sauce was a bit thick for my taste, but not a huge deal. Wifey had the grilled shrimp appetizer with avocado and mango sauce appetizer and the empanadas. She loved her food. I wasn't a fan of the empanadas. but the shrimp were pretty good. Overall, I think it's a pretty good place and it's nice to have another option in the area. Would I choose to go back? no, probably not, but I know the wife will make me go back at some point.

Cool dive bar and a nice break from the normal las vegas scene.  Went in a friday night after getting free beer coupons handed to us on fremont street.\n\nWas pretty empty for weekend night.  Bartenders are as advertised.  Extremely loud with the megaphones bordering on obnoxious.  Fun though.  Be aware though bartenders will bait you into buying shots including for them and then your bill skyrockets.  Didnt think that was cool.

I have stayed at the Hotel Monte Carlo Las Vegas numerous times, and I'm ready to move on to other hotels.  Its outdated, the food at the main cafe and buffet are so-so, however the rates were pretty fantastic.  Compared to the other hotels, especially the newest arrivals, it shows its age.  

However, I do like it that the concierge will put hotel guests on the VIP list to get into Haze, and other nightclubs in the vicinity.  That was a cool feature we appreciate, and at no cost to the concierge for to get in.  

If its deals you are looking for, and "decent" rooms, it is worth looking into.

I've only frequented the one in Henderson on Sunset and the one on South Rainbow, both have been great for breakfast, the steak and eggs especially.  The happy hour at the South Rainbow location, with $2 drafts and 1/2 price appetizers. fantastic.  For that, these two places get an "A".

But as someone noted, their reward card is now pretty much of a joke.  They changed the earning levels so dramatically, it would take me years to get a $10 credit...so on that, and for doing so without any advance notice or taking into consideration past credits earned, they get an "F".

So they have 3 stars, the average between an "A" and a "F".

"Although my dining experience was generally satisfactory, I encountered some difficulties with the ordering process, which proved to be somewhat perplexing. However, given my intellectual prowess and resourcefulness, I managed to decipher the intricacies of the menu and successfully ordered a delectable burger that met my expectations. Additionally, the onion rings that accompanied my meal were quite palatable. Nonetheless, I must admit that the ambiance of the establishment lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, a quality that would have elevated it from mere adequacy to exceptionalism."

This was a typical resort restaurant the food was fairly ambitious and the food was pricey. I had the chicken because almost any other entree was really pricey, and almost solidly steak. Never the less the food was pretty good and the service was great. Unfortunately the table next to us lit up and then it was pretty smokey, but we were already done, and we chose to sit outside so that I don't blame them for at all. In the end it was a little too pricey for what your gonna get, some good food but also it was the resort and I wouldn't expect anything different. I probably won't be back, our server was really nice though that's the only reason I feel bad about giving this place 3 stars. Other than that it was all around ok.

It is utterly remarkable how a limited number of blocks can profoundly influence one's culinary experience, particularly when venturing further eastward. As an ardent devotee of Lao cuisine, I have developed an unwavering affinity for the nuanced flavors and spices that characterize this distinct culinary tradition. Prior to my relocation to Madison, I had never truly indulged in Lao fare; however, my exposure to it has been nothing short of transformative. While I do acknowledge that the menu at this particular establishment appears somewhat abbreviated in comparison to its counterpart on Willy Street, the expansive dining area readily compensates for any perceived deficiencies in terms of space. Nonetheless, I must aver that the quality of service, genuine hospitality, and authentic ambiance that permeate the atmosphere of Willy Street's Lao restaurants remain unparalleled, thereby rendering them my unequivocal preference for curry east of the state capital.
Good Burger but on the pricy side for what you get. I work nearby and was hoping for a lunch deal but they aren't open for lunch. Pleasant staff and service was good but no lunch no return trips.

Nice but the menu it is stil the same  for the past 6 years...we are in Montreal 

Anyways, the best dish for me is the radish oyster  cannot get enough of the stuff. 12CAD$ for 4 oysters is well worth it

the rest to my taste was quite ordinary, not worth the money

I came in to pick up a new laptop charger and get the upgrade to Lion OSX.

Getting the charger was easy enough, but because I'm on Leopard and not Snow Leopard, I have to buy *two* OS upgrades to get to Lion. Ok, that's fine and all, but the stores don't carry the upgrade from Leopard to Snow Leopard. Excuse me?

My only options were to find a Best Buy that may or may not have the Leopard to Snow Leopard upgrade disc in stock, or order it online and wait several days for it to arrive. They can't keep a few discs in stock at the Apple store? Absurd.

Other than that total stupidity, the location was fine, store was clean (albeit busy at an odd time), and employee that checked me out was nice enough.

Cheap, decent, workman-like meals. Go in expecting a diner serving diner food and you will be satisfied. The service is decent, the food is decent and the price (especially for its proximity to the Strip) is great.\n\nDon't let the 3 stars fool you. It truly is A-OK.

decent... i had the \"sin city\" burger. i liked it very much. my wife had a classic which i didnt like but i'm not sure what she had on it. she liked it so i guess thats what counts. the sweet potato fries werent that great. i didnt like the way they were seasoned. the regular fries were ok. all in all it was pretty good. its better than most fast food burgers....
Pretty good for kids, average to below average for adults.  Friendly staff, good price.  Not the best tasting, but you can tolerate a slice or 2.  Limited dessert and salad options.

"If you have an inclination towards indulging in a delectable dessert, specifically one that incorporates rich, velvety chocolate or perhaps a colossal sundae, then this establishment is bound to satiate your craving. Conveniently situated within the historic district, this charming ice cream parlor exudes a nostalgic ambiance, reminiscent of a bygone era, through its preserved retro aesthetic and interior design. Upon entering, my companion and I opted to indulge in the extravagant Buster Brownie Sundae, and while the sweetness was undoubtedly intense, the experience was unquestionably worthwhile. Although Sugar Bowl offers culinary options beyond their renowned frozen treats, we were oblivious to this fact and ultimately chose not to sample them. Notwithstanding, the service we received was warm and welcoming."

"I have had the pleasure of partaking in the culinary offerings of this establishment on multiple occasions, both in-house and via delivery, and while the initial excitement has subsided, the quality of the food remains unwavering. The prevalence of five-star reviews may lead one to assume an air of infallibility, but in reality, the restaurant's excellence lies in its ability to deliver a fresh, flavorful wing experience, augmented by the 'awesome sauce' that has become a staple of their menu. My personal preference tends towards the Golden BBQ and Order, though I have also sampled the Citrus Chipotle, Jamaican Jerk, and Sweet Chili options, each boasting a distinct and satisfying flavor profile. The boneless wings, comparable in size to chicken tenders, maintain their appeal, and the delivery process is both expedient and reliable. However, the quality of service varies, with some experiences falling short of expectations, despite the frequency of my visits. Of note, the waffle fries, which I opted to upgrade, were cooked to a crispy perfection, transcending the realm of traditional potatoes and entering the realm of potato chips. In conclusion, while the inflated reviews may be misleading, the restaurant's strengths lie in its diverse array of sauces and consistently satisfying wing experience."

"Thus, I possess an eccentric predicament that evokes acute discomfort within my being whenever an individual presents me with an excessively sizable plate of culinary delights. In this instance, my craving was for the flavorsome chile rellenos; however, I did not desire the gargantuan serving size that accompanied it. Alas, such is the prevailing trend in the realm of dining establishments nowadays. Nonetheless, had I been cognizant of the colossal proportions prior, I would have considered sharing my repast with my companion. Notwithstanding, upon securing a table on a Friday evening sans reservation or waiting period, the hospitality we received was indeed attentive and accommodating, while the financial burden imposed by the meal was quite reasonable. Furthermore, my mint-based beverage, a mojito, proved to be quite delectable."

A Charlotte staple in need of a makeover. Generally solid food but sometimes inconsistent - biggest challenge is the atmosphere which is stale and hasn't kept up with the rest of the Charlotte restaurant scene. You can't go wrong by a visit to PC - especially if the weather is nice and you get to sit on the excellent patio. Salads are great here.

"Halted by this establishment to acquire a potable beverage prior to partaking in an evening meal elsewhere. The atmosphere within was boisterous, verging on cacophonous, owing to the vociferous patrons gathered around the numerous screens displaying some form of athletic competition involving gentlemen gliding across ice surfaces; raucous birthday celebrations manifesting themselves in various areas throughout the premises; and an audio system emitting sonorous melodies at an intensity that bordered on the excessive. Despite its primary focus on gin, the venue's beverage list proved unremarkable in terms of its beer offerings, yet the selection of gin-based concoctions piqued my interest. Following the recommendation of our hospitable server, we opted to sample a particular mixture featuring Ungava gin from Quebec and maple syrup, which, despite my limited affinity for gin, proved quite palatable (it is worth mentioning that any beverage fortified with maple syrup is likely to elicit my approval). A cursory examination of the menu revealed prices that could be described as moderately elevated, with a single beer and cocktail combination costing $20, exclusive of taxes and gratuities, which, I must confess, struck me as somewhat steep. Notwithstanding this, the quality of the service we received was commendable, as our server, despite being occupied with attendance to the multiple large gatherings scattered throughout the establishment, managed to tend to our needs in a timely and attentive manner. All things considered, I am pleased that we decided to visit this locale, as it has been on our list of potential destinations ever since our relocation to this vicinity."

This is easy to confuse with Central Library, but this is hwere they keep the special books - all the special books.  Central Library is just a normal library.

To come read these books you will have to apply at the registration desk for a pass (with ID) that will last for either a few days or about 3 months.

If there is a secific old book here you want to see then you should definitely come here to see it, but if not then this is a lot of fuss over reading a book and you'll be better going elsewhere.

Good sports bar/restaurant--if that's your thing.

Went here when visiting with my dad who suggested it as "one of those new fun places."

The stuffed portabella mushroom appetizer was delicious, though ridiculously decadent.  The carnitas libre pizza was also pretty good, but also extremely rich--i.e. you can taste your arteries clogging.  The pollotate pizza was bland and dry--potatos on pizza is fun in theory, but I'm not convinced.  However, the cook forgot the onions on it, which actually might make a substantial, positive difference.  We okayed the oversight (they've only been open for two months) and they comped our bill a bit, so that was nice.  The service was pretty great, actually.

There's a ton of TVs here and a well-stocked bar with loads of beers on tap.  So if that's your thing, it's probably one of the better sports bar/restaurants out there.  For me, if I'm going to waste the kinds of calories that are packed into these dishes, it had better be for something extra special, which this place just isn't.

"Having indulged in a brief morning yoga session, I decided to partake in a midday repast at this establishment, having previously attempted to visit during the initial launch of Union, only to find it inaccessible due to unforeseen circumstances. Today, upon my return, I observed that approximately half of the commercial enterprises within the vicinity were operational, while the remaining half remained closed, which I found rather perplexing. Notwithstanding this anomaly, my impression of TDP was generally favorable, owing to its quaint ambiance, charming outdoor seating area, and modest bar. The staff members were also quite hospitable and accommodating in their demeanor, particularly when assisting us with our culinary preferences. However, I must admit that the fare served was merely satisfactory, and its cost somewhat prohibitive. Specifically, the price of $9 for a Caprese sandwich appeared exorbitant, especially considering the underripe state of the tomato utilized in its preparation. Furthermore, the meatball sandwich seemed to lack an adequate amount of sauce, while the chicken salad sandwich, although visually appealing, struck me as somewhat diminutive and lacking in supplementary elements, such as fruit or a side salad. In light of these observations, I have resolved to limit my future visits to mere appreciation of the ambient aromas, and perhaps acquire a bottle of their high-quality olive oil from the adjacent store."

"Although my dining experience at Jersey Mike's did not induce feelings of debilitating infatuation, the restaurant's ambiance was undoubtedly tidy, streamlined, and hospitable. The menu's layout presented a minor challenge for a novice such as myself, prompting a sense of hastened urgency upon ordering; however, the bustling atmosphere during peak lunch hours underscored the establishment's popularity. The diminutive sub sandwich, dubbed'mini,' could easily suffice as a standard portion size, while the larger option proved sufficient for a trio of patrons. The abundance of meat in the club sandwich catered to my carnivorous inclinations, while the subtle distinction between the white and wheat sub rolls remained somewhat enigmatic. Nonetheless, the quality of the bread did not detract from the overall enjoyment of the meal. Of greater curiosity was the assortment of beverage cups, each emblazoned with narratives pertaining to diverse Jersey Mike's locations that have engaged in philanthropic endeavors for worthy causes. While the veracity of these claims warrants further investigation, the notion of supporting an altruistic enterprise undoubtedly resonates with consumers. Though mere branding may be at play, I am intrigued by the possibility of genuine charitable involvement. Sufficiently satisfied with my initial visit, I anticipate returning to sample a spicier variety of sandwich in the future."

Los 7 Compadres has a variety (20) of combination platters for about 7 bucks.  Between my wife and I we had 7 items on our combination platters, which we shared.  7 has been a recurring number for us starting with the OYE at Malee's.  Including the rice and beans, the sour cream and the guacamole this gave us an astounding number of possible combinations for each bite.  

A bite of chicken enchilada.
A bite of chicken enchilada with rice.
A bite of chicken enchilada with beans.
A bite of chicken enchilada with guacamole.
A bite of chicken enchilada with sour cream.
A bite of chicken enchilada with rice and beans.
A bite of chicken enchilada with guacamole, rice and beans.
A bite of chicken enchilada with sour cream, rice and beans.
A bite of chicken enchilada with sour cream, rice, beans and guacamole.

Play this out again with the burrito, cheese enchilada, tamale, beef enchilada, bean enchilada, etcetera.  All of the food was good.  Portions were generally large.  I found the tamales to be the least satisfying item.  They were a bit dry and the dominant flavor was just the spice of jalapeno.

Note-even the mild here has a real bite.  Overall I'd give them 3.5 stars.  Good enough for a return trip.

"It is utterly perplexing that this establishment appears to take great pride in not only permitting but also possibly encouraging patrons to engage in the noxious habit of smoking, which is particularly baffling given the otherwise impressive array of beverages available and the superior quality of the culinary offerings, including an assortment of pizzas, sandwiches, and appetizers; however, it is profoundly unsettling to consider the prospect of departing the premises with the lingering stench of a foul ashtray clinging to one's person, and it would be truly advantageous if the management were to reconsider their stance on this issue and join the rest of society in embracing the modern era."

"It is with immense exhilaration that I can finally indulge in some delectable V-food in the downtown area of Phoenix. The proliferation of diverse culinary experiences is undoubtedly a boon for the community. Conveniently situated at the intersection of 1st and Adam streets, this establishment offers a unique dining experience, with an open kitchen that allows patrons to observe the culinary process. Upon ordering takeout, I was pleased to discover that all necessary components were included. The promptness of the service was indeed commendable. However, I must admit that my expectations regarding the flavors were not entirely met, as they seemed somewhat less vibrant compared to my usual preferences. Moreover, the prices, while still reasonable, reflected the upscale nature of the restaurant, amounting to approximately 30 dollars for a meal for two, a sum that, although still affordable, surpassed my customary expenditure of 15-20 dollars at other, more unpretentious eateries. Despite this, I shall continue to patronize this establishment when seeking quick and convenient meals or lunches in the downtown area. Nonetheless, my yearning for the genuine and dynamic ambiance of a Vietnamese restaurant will impel me to venture towards the avenues, where established dives proffer a more authentic experience. Of note, I did not have the opportunity to sample their bahn mi, as it was unavailable. Instead, I opted for a standard buhn dice, which, while satisfying, lacked the customary sweetness and abundance of garlic that I have come to expect. The egg rolls were a pleasant surprise, filled with a variety of ingredients rather than mere vegetables. Unfortunately, the spring rolls did not include my preferred option of shrimp. Lastly, the omelette dish presented an acquired taste, one that I shall reserve judgment upon."

Chinatown in Montreal is small (1 - no matter where in the world we go, my mom ALWAYS has to have rice at least once a day 2- they have the fruits my family travels to Canada for) and this is a reliable resource for good, cheap roast pork/duck over rice. Their beef pan fried noodles are not great (as in, not something I would order again). Their wonton noodle soup is pretty good: I got it both times we came here. General Tso'c chicken was pretty good: again, something my family ordered both times we came.\n\nOverall, nothing crazy and nothing that's a must see in Montreal. The service is OK (if you get a waiter that speaks English well, then the service is good, if not, the inability to effectively communicate causes some frustration. The food comes out fast, so if you're starving, this is a good place to go. Their bubble tea is alright: stops a craving, but it's not great. They do get brownie points for giving baby bochoy with everything and for the HUGE food portions.

Dropping down to three stars ... On a recent visit, I saw TWO roaches on the main floor of the restaurant. No one seemed to care, so I got up and stepped on one.  I pointed out the other, and one of the staff killed it, but they didn't seem surprised.  I know that roaches are hard to control, but having two of them wandering about in a busy restaurant just isn't a good thing. 

Also, our waiter was an overly chatty guy who seems to think we are interested in his voice.  They had some good staff in the past, but I suspect the owner, who likes to get drunk and hang out on the patio, gives me the impression of a guy who would be difficult to work for! 

The food is still decent and better than anything else I've found, but I'm looking for alternatives ...

While $29.99, $32.42 with tax, proved to be too much for this feast.  While there was a lot offered at good quality, it wasn't worth the price as compared to some of the finer hotels.

I was there at 10:15am on a Saturday.  Mimosas are served, and I had two (delicious).  They had a good amount of breakfast and lunch items,  and I had a little of each.  Yes, lunch is already served.  Brunch.

Nothing was outstanding, but all was good.  It isn't an enormously large buffet, but ample nonetheless.

I think I would go back if 1) I was drunk, 2) I had a hankering for AYCE, 3) I was stuck without my car, 4) held hostage, 5) I was drunk.  Oh I said that.  Well, if the price was less...I would go.

I like Mexican food and I like Chinese food, so why not? Interesting menu. The Jade Red Chicken is as good as any Orange or General Tso's you'll find, and I like that there is a wide variety of choices here. Good food, especially if you like spicy!

I have one beef with this restaurant, and that is the cleanliness. Walking in, you'll notice that the decor and general feel of the place is very low budget. Uncomfortable seating, very weathered ceilings, and generally messy. No big deal. But the restrooms were disgusting, the eating area was dirty, and the trash was overflowing. The place was busy, but there's no excuse for the condition of the men's restroom! It looked like something (or someone) exploded in a truck stop restroom on a state highway. I would have chalked it up to a busy night, but the door and walls were filthy (almost black) with handprints from weeks (if not months) of neglect. All but one of the trash bins were over-stuffed, and most of the tables were dirty. We didn't see anyone cleaning anything. I'm glad I didn't go into the restroom until after I ate!

If it were my business, I would put at least a few dollars toward general maintenance and upkeep. Maybe even invest in a few nicer tables & chairs. If it were close to clean, I'd give at least 4 stars.

Just quickly ran in and grabbed some stuff for dinner. Never been inside of this store until today. It's okay. I don't think the fruits and vegetables are the best but they'll do in a time crunch (because the store is located near the house) but I would prefer Safeway for fruits, vegetables and possibly meats. Prices are average - specials on some things but nothing out there that makes this store stand out.

My initial experience was adequate, but it failed to meet my expectations in its entirety. The culinary offerings did not live up to the standards of a reputable steakhouse. Neither my spouse nor I enjoyed the appetizer, specifically the Fire-Grilled Fresh Artichoke, which was marketed as a popular choice yet did not appeal to our palates. My burger was unremarkable and lacked flavor, prompting me to regret not choosing Five Guys instead. My spouse opted for the steak, which was merely satisfactory, and subsequently experienced adverse health effects due to ordering from the gluten-free menu, suggesting a potential issue with cross-contamination. 
  A notable aspect of our dining experience was the exceptional service provided by our server, Cassie. Her attentiveness, diligence in maintaining refreshments, and willingness to address dissatisfaction left us feeling content and appreciative, as we seldom encounter such impressive hospitality while dining out. Following my written account of the visit, the manager expressed his intention to extend a coupon, demonstrating the establishment's commitment to engaging with its clientele. 
  Despite the underwhelming culinary experience, the ambiance of the restaurant elicited positive feelings, and I am open to giving it another chance, contingent upon notable improvements in the quality of the food, which is crucial in securing my patronage.

We were the only ones in there on a sunday afternoon which I thought was weird after my friend raved about this place. Our food came out so fast that they would not even have had time to microwave it and put it on a plate so I know everything was pre-made. Food tasted alright just tons of bones in the chicken and the fried pork was so hard I almost chipped my tooth. Is this how you cubans prefer it? 

Parking lot is around back. Absolutely ensure that you lock your car and DO NOT walk alone in this immediate area. 

I would go back but I would try to order something on the menu that they hopefully will make fresh. I gave them three stars for being very friendly, being bilingual, and for not giving me food poisoning.

"Is this venue currently closed, or merely undergoing revitalization efforts? I have visited this establishment on multiple occasions for lunch, and my culinary experiences have led me to the conclusion that the barbacoa torta is, without a doubt, the most exceptional item on the menu. While I have sampled other offerings, such as the breakfast burrito, I must admit that the balance of potato to chorizo was somewhat lacking, particularly given the cost and dimensions of the dish."

"Culinary offerings at this establishment were inventive and flavorsome, with appetizer portions being reasonable in terms of both price and quality. However, main courses fell short in terms of portion size, with prices ranging from $6-10 higher than expected. Notwithstanding, the bread provided was dry, albeit suitable as a light accompaniment to the meal. The wine selection boasted an impressive variety, catering to diverse tastes. While not exceptional compared to eateries in prominent food cities like Portland, this restaurant serves as a valuable addition to the local dining scene in Chandler and Sun Lakes. Although not particularly busy on a Friday evening, it remains uncertain whether patrons perceive the dinner options as overpriced, warranting further assessment for long-term success. Despite its unconventional strip mall location, the ambiance remained pleasant."
