"A profusion of exceptional cocktails graces this establishment, although certain mixologists excel at their craft more than others. Particularly fond of their mint-infused mojitos. Prices are reasonable, ambiance pleasant, clientele congenial, tunes melodious. Partook in brunch, specifically a lobster omelette. While the dish presented an array of diverse flavors, my fastidious palate found it somewhat overwhelming. However, I surmise that less discerning gastronomes may relish such culinary complexity. Regrettably, the guava mimosa failed to impress."

I am upgrading to a three-star rating due to the exceptional quality of the service; however, there was an approximate one-to-one ratio of servers to guests, which warrants some consideration. Despite my positive experience, this establishment appears to be struggling, and several factors contribute to its lackluster performance. Firstly, the prices are exorbitant, and the meager portions do not justify the cost. For instance, burgers, skewers, sandwiches, and salads are priced around $10, while pizzas range from $10 to $15. Moreover, everything is served a la carte, and the entrees consist of merely three appetizer-sized skewers. The appetizers themselves cost around $10, and desserts are priced at $7, with the option to add ice cream for an additional $1. 

In contrast, the burgers are superior to those offered by the Grind, as they remain intact throughout consumption. The fries, priced at $5, were quite satisfactory, while the pork skewers were unremarkable but adequate. The Dorito potato skins were unimpressive, consisting of a lone wedge of cheesy chip embedded in the middle. The cupcake was palatable, yet the chocolate exhibited a slightly grainy texture. The portion size was also rather diminutive. 

In conclusion, while I may return for happy hour to indulge in their burgers, I am unlikely to visit this establishment again for any other reason.

"It was indeed a culinary revelation nestled within the picturesque confines of Verdun that we had the pleasure of discovering through a personal recommendation, and given our previous exposure to delectable Persian cuisine, a certain level of skepticism was inevitable. Nonetheless, Parisa managed to surpass our expectations with their unique interpretation of traditional Persian flavors.

Their signature house soup, while containing an incongruous element in the form of noodles, proved to be a truly exceptional offering. It was followed by a delightful assortment of sauteed mushrooms, which, despite lacking the anticipated sweetness, still showcased the kitchen's proficiency in executing simple yet elegant dishes.

The main course featured two distinct protein options: tender, juicy lamb that literally fell off the bone, and succulent chicken drumsticks that, while not necessarily memorable, contributed to the overall satisfaction of our dining experience.

The hospitable demeanor of the host and the tranquil ambiance of the establishment further enhanced our enjoyment, making it an ideal venue for a BYOW excursion. In conclusion, a visit to Parisa is highly recommended, particularly for the unmissable soup, a true masterpiece of culinary artistry."

I tried this place after seeing it in the loafer so many times with rave reviews. I enjoyed my burger and fries although my guest didn't so much. I will note that they DO NOT have air conditioning. I was melting...

"Although this establishment may not exude an extravagant ambiance, it nevertheless possesses an acceptable level of quality. Upon arriving with a group of twelve, we had the foresight to reserve a table in advance, thereby avoiding any unnecessary delays. Our server, a consummate professional, exhibited remarkable proficiency in catering to our diverse needs, deftly navigating the numerous requests and preferences expressed by various members of our party. Unfortunately, the culinary offerings did not quite live up to the high standards set by the exceptional service. Specifically, my potatoes were overcooked to an unfortunate degree, while the flavor profile of the sausage deviated somewhat from the expected norm. Additionally, my omelette displayed a peculiar texture that could be described as rubbery. Thus, while the service we received was truly commendable, the food itself fell short of our expectations."

"An establishment offering an adequate selection of alcoholic beverages and a partially enclosed outdoor area, suitable for relaxation, yet, owing to its proximity to the heavily trafficked East Washington Avenue, susceptible to auditory disturbances. While the assortment of Belgian brews failed to meet expectations, the ambiance and location render it an appropriate addition to the array of similar establishments along Williamson Street, with the added benefit of proximity to an adult entertainment store."

The decor of this place is really neat. It's dim and intimate inside (in fact, it's so dim they have to give you a menu that lights up!) and they have some really comfy chairs to sit on. The DJ who was working on Saturday night was playing some fun music, but the volume was a little too loud for a \"lounge.\"  I could only talk to the people sitting immediately next to me, and even then I had to yell a little.  The patio was a nice escape from the loud music.  They had a lot of seating out there and a nice view of the courtyard to people watch.

I often stop in this place when Im at Tempe Marketplace to get a drink and relax.  They usually have some decent drink specials and they have a nice big bar.  The bartenders usually take a little effort to order from, not really sure why that is, maybe I just have bad luck.

Hmmm I am American and I grew up in the NYC area, so I am fairly confident that I know good Italian food when I taste it.  I am not saying that the food isn't good, but it definitely did not blow me away.  We came here because it was listed as a Top 10 Best Restaurant in Edinburgh, according to The Guardian and I definitely would not rate this in my top 10.

However, with that being said, the service was fantastic.  Our servers were all very friendly and attentive.  The portions here are enormous and we did feel that they mislead us into ordering more food than we needed because we did ask if the starters were big enough to shared and they recommended that we order two.  Both plates were huge and we certainly could have just shared one between the two of us.  Not to mention the entrees were enough for 2-3 people to share.  So come hungry!

Ambiance has a little bit of a corny feel but also reminded me a lot of any Italian spot in suburban New York / New Jersey, in the sense that there was Frank Sinatra playing in the background the entire time and the servers were a little over the top trying to prove their Italian-ness (actual, and not the macho mobster Guido kind we see over here in the States).

So, in the last two weeks I have come here for two separate issues.

The first, being that I stupidly fractured my coccyx (tail bone). I was seen after a short wait, and taken care of promptly and thoroughly. Dr. Guy did a good job at taking care of my situation, requested an immediate x-ray and saw me right after I was done to discuss my results, options, and pain relief methods. You never know how valuable a body part is until it's battered, leaving you completely dysfunctional and in mind-blowing pain.

The second, I was having severe bursts of pain in my abdomen. I went to the clinic first because it happens to be right around the corner from where I live, and I needed to be seen immediately. I was shaking, crying, pale and obviously in extreme distress. Although I understand this is simply a clinic, the fact that I was turned away due to over capacity came as a shock. Considering the severity of my ailment, I would have appreciated it more if a doctor had seen me, even if temporarily, just to help relieve the pain I was in as I awaited my transportation to the emergency. 

I will still come here in the future when push comes to shove, but my last experience wasn't so great and has shown me that they are not willing to bend the rules in extreme cases that involve a person's wellbeing and health.

I don't hate it. 
I don't love it. 
I'm very blah about it.


Initially wanted to come here after seeing pictures on Instagram. I was super excited as I was hoping for snow like that from Hawaii snow places, like Snow Factory or Frost City.

My friends and I had #3, #4, #5 respectively. I don't like the "popping pearls" in my #5 so, I replaced it with butterfinger.

I'd like to say it was similar in texture being kind of creamy but, they need to improve on their flavors. I got to samps the taro, green tea, and "kuma snow" (whatever flavor that it) and it was whatever......it quenched my thirst in this heat we're having.
I'd like to see more variety ---- I'm thinking of the variety that Snow Ono food/shave ice truck had --- I miss horchata flavor, I guess.

I loved how the decor is all bright and cute. Tryna get the whole Asian-kawaii market. I mean, that's what got me.....very Instagram worthy pics outta here.

Overall, I'll be back. Businesses tend to get better in time ***cross fingers*** 
I wanna bring more people so we can "samps" more things; this way I don't base this review on just 3 flavors.

"It is my understanding that this establishment has garnered a certain level of notoriety, and thus, I felt compelled to partake in a visitation to said venue.  My attendance was precipitated by a philanthropic endeavor in support of a local elementary educational institution.  Upon entering the premises, I couldn't help but notice the stark similarity between this skating rink and those that I frequented during my own childhood in the 1980s.  It remains unclear whether any substantive improvements have been effectuated since that time period.  During the evening of my visit, the ambient temperature within the facility seemed to be rather elevated, almost unbearably so, and was further exacerbated by an unmistakable odor reminiscent of a gymnasium locker room.  However, I must admit that the prices charged at the concession stand were quite reasonable, the musical selections being played were contemporary and engaging, and all of the patrons, spanning multiple generations, appeared to be thoroughly enjoying themselves.  Additionally, it is worth noting that this establishment accommodates individuals who prefer the use of roller blades featuring a single row of wheels, and offers a modest discount for such patrons.  Thus, if one is seeking an authentic, nostalgia-inducing skating experience, devoid of modernistic updates, then perhaps a visit to this venue would be worth considering."

"An establishment that offered a satisfactory ambiance, with a culinary experience that met our expectations. Upon entering, we were greeted by an atmosphere that exuded cleanliness and warmth. Our meal began with the clear egg rolls accompanied by a delectable peanut sauce, a staple dish that we often indulge in when partaking in Vietnamese cuisine. The flavors were adequately represented, without surpassing our expectations. Subsequently, we opted for the combo pho soup, which presented generous proportions and a commendable execution. Although the broth lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, it was reminiscent of fish sauce, mint, and other indispensable components. One might argue that the soup catered to American palates, with a subtle spiciness that left room for personal adjustments. However, for those seeking a more genuine experience, a more robust foundation would be necessary. The menu, though limited, helped avoid the paradox of choice, but we couldn't help but feel that certain Vietnamese delicacies were absent. The staff provided friendly and efficient service, contributing to an overall positive experience. We may consider revisiting this establishment in the future, curious to witness its evolution."

We organized a farewell celebration for a departing colleague at this establishment, and I must admit that the service we received was quite satisfactory, particularly considering the size of our group, which consisted of 16 individuals and one minor. The avocado-based dip, commonly known as guacamole, was quite palatable, and I was particularly fond of the spicy salsa that they offer upon request. However, the fruit-based alcoholic beverage known as sangria was excessively sweetened, although the house margarita served on the rocks was somewhat more agreeable. The culinary offerings were rather unremarkable; I consumed some uninspired chicken enchiladas that, while not necessarily unpalatable, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi. Nonetheless, my most enjoyable experience of the evening was visiting the Trader Joe's store located within the same retail complex after our meal.

The view is amazing for 360 degrees... The ambiance is quite chill and the DJ on Friday night is decent. Mostly top 40 and EDM infused mixes playing through the speakers. 

The late happy hour is only for food and the reason this place gets a couple of stars knocked out of the sky is because of the service and the food that is served. The buns on the sliders were hard enough to break a window on impact and the calamari was soggy (probably microwaved for happy hour). It also took forever for the waitress to make her way around to us. I could have taken the stairs to level 0, walk to the liquor store and walk back up the stairs to Level 107 before she came back with our order. 

This place has a lot of potential, it just needs a facelift in a few places. The view is main reason this gets 3 stars.

The people here are super friendly and nice. Yhe reason I gave only three stars is one their liquid flavors was missing somethin.  I think if they remixed a few  flavors it would be a little better. And the second reason is that their liquid is pricey. Like 21 bucks for one bottle.

Heard A LOT of good things about this place but somehow I don't seem what all the good rants about this place where. I came with high expectations due to the fact that friends and colleagues have fervently extolled its virtues, yet ultimately, it failed to meet my elevated standards in Las Vegas. We arrived at approximately 1 pm, thereby falling within the parameters of brunch time. The menu primarily consisted of breakfast fare, complemented by a smattering of salads and other lunch options. However, what truly piqued my interest was their delectable chicken wings, savory saian chow mein, and crispy fried rice, the rich alfredo pasta, and the flavorful calamari skewer. Unfortunately, everything else paled in comparison to my gastronomic inclinations. As a self-proclaimed dessert aficionado, I eagerly indulged in the dessert bar, but found only a select few offerings aesthetically pleasing and gustatorily satisfying. The chocolate-dipped strawberries, creamy cheesecake, and velvety Thai ice cream were my standout favorites from the entire assortment! THE THAI TEA ICE CREAM IS THE ONLY REASON WHY I GAVE THEM AN EXTRA STAR! It is an absolute must-try for all my fellow Thai tea enthusiasts out there! In conclusion, a run-of-the-mill buffet for roughly $30 per person, with a merely passable culinary experience, redeemed only by the exceptional Thai tea ice cream.
= = = = = =  CLOSED  = = = = = =\n\nSorry to see Him's JL close.  I liked the place.     :-(

"A pleasant and hygienic smorgasbord, proffering an abundance of accommodations for patrons. Although I did not object to the tariff of thirteen dollars per individual, my satisfaction was somewhat diminished upon discovering that an extensive array of porcine delicacies constituted a significant portion of the offerings. As I am not particularly enamored with swinish cuisine, I might opt to expend my resources elsewhere in the future, perhaps at Buffet@asia, where a greater diversity of options, including an increased emphasis on seafood and Mongolian barbecue, is available."

My wife and I were roaming the industrial and business park area of Phoenix looking for a decent bite to eat, preferably Mexican food. We finally stumbled upon a set of about five Mexican eateries. We decided on Salsitas, which seems to be a chain in the Valley of The Sun.

I wished that the woman had done a better job of speaking and understanding English. The food order was correct, and plentiful, not to mention cheap, but we had specifically asked for forks and were not given any. I had to go to our hotel's front deck and beg the clerk for a couple of plastic forks. 

The burrito was huge and very tasty. I had a couple of Grilled Chicken mini-tacos, and while they were pretty good, they were nothing special and I even found a few pieces of gristle. My wife had a chicken burrito and said it was huge and very good. She could not finish it. They also gave us some hot carrots so that scored well with her.

Ten bucks for all of that, including four salsas and sour cream. Not bad, but I'd like to try more.

It is an acceptable venue, albeit one that I would not have chosen to visit had we not been extended an invitation accompanied by a reserved table. The diminutive size of the establishment, while potentially charming, was unfortunately exacerbated by the presence of a substantial number of patrons, creating an atmosphere akin to that of a crowded subway car in China or New York City. Notwithstanding the cramped conditions, I must admit that the personal hygiene of the clientele was satisfactory, in contrast to the malodorous ambiance often associated with public transportation in urban centers. A plethora of ostensibly synthetic, juvenile females were conspicuously present, rendering the environment somewhat unsettling for a solitary, relatively youthful individual such as myself (being merely 27 years of age). 
  The beverages served at this establishment are quite costly; I opted to procure three shots for our group, as I felt no compulsion to emulate the behavior of certain metrosexual individuals who insist on purchasing drinks for others. Furthermore, I am financially capable of treating myself. However, upon perusing the bill, I was taken aback by the exorbitant price of $36 for a mere three shots. In light of this, I felt compelled to remark on the receipt that "I ain't no rich bitch," and I apologize for any offense caused to the bartender. Nonetheless, considering the steep prices, I believe it is essential to either consume alcoholic beverages liberally before arriving or to accompany someone possessing a platinum credit card, lest one wishes to incur financial hardship. Despite the extravagant costs, the experience remains moderately enjoyable.

This is your perfect place to bring someone after going out.
Instead of going to macdonald or some fast food joint this place is cheaper,healthier and quicker than any fast food store.
Plus you can grab something for breakfast the next day.
No matter what time i go i always see people baking fresh bagel.
I'm more of a conservative guy so i usually take sesame bagel or butter bagel.
Hope this help,

Cheers,

Eric Van Nguyen

As Demetria so astutely observed, this establishment tends to be somewhat inconsistent in the quality of its offerings, with a tendency towards both excellence and disappointment. For optimal culinary experiences, it is advisable to arrive promptly, as the most delectable items often disappear rapidly. The fried chicken, when cooked to perfection, is undoubtedly a highlight, although it occasionally suffers from overcooking or dryness. The six-cheese spaghetti is also a commendable option, but its quality can vary depending on the preparation method. The abundance of sides offers numerous choices, including mac-n-cheese, which, much like the aforementioned chicken and spaghetti, may occasionally be overcooked, resulting in a less than satisfactory dining experience. However, the blackeyed peas and cornbread consistently impress, and their lemonade, arguably the finest in Charlotte, has garnered high praise. A word of caution regarding the volunteers who handle beverage refills: they are renowned for their warmth and generosity, and a adept diner may even secure an additional portion of mac-n-cheese through skillful banter. It is essential to display gratitude via a gratuity at the register. Fare thee well, my friend.

Warning: This review is mostly based on service and lack of information, rather than food!

We came here for happy hour and I was going to give this place 4 stars, but they get minus 1 for not advising us where to sit for happy hour prices... and no, I didn't think to ask "geee...what is the designated happy hour seating?" We were the first people there and they just told us to sit where ever we wanted. Also, by the time we left, there was only one other couple and they were definitely not getting the happy hour prices either.
Note: Happy hour seating is ONLY at the bar and bench.

The food and selection was tasty but I've had better in San Diego. I guess I need to try the other tapas joints in the area to provide a better comparison. And I do agree with others that it is a bit pricey, but some of the dishes were worth it. The red sangria was lack-luster. The lamb was good, but small for the price. The croquettes were a little bland. I think my favorite was the Patatas Bravas with was just roasted potatoes covered in a tomato sauce. It was very basic but tasty and satisfying. 

The bill came to approx ~$60 without tip, and when we checked the happy hour prices on some of the items we ordered, we ended up paying an extra $20 at least to sit at a table instead of the bar.

This place is beautiful inside. I really enjoyed the process of watching the owners transform this great piece of historic modern architecture into something a lot of people could enjoy. 

The other location is cool too, sans the DB scene. I found this location to have scary parking, but good valet service. 

The service was good on my Friday 3pm visit. Was there to celebrate a friends birthday. We had some of the apps (The Trifecta, Double Down, and Crabmeat and Artichoke Dip) and they were good. The waitress was always coming by to check on us and even told us when happy hour started. 

You could tell it was getting close to 5pm. The place was a mad house with 40 something dudes trolling for a place to sit all sweaty from a golf outing. The place is chill and there seemed to be no pretencious DB's. Sure there is a healthy mix of an older crowd, but there was a good mix of younger groups too. 

Good amount of TVs so there is always something to watch. It was kind of noisy near the enclosed patio, but we were at a table being loud anyways. There is alot of room to move and enjoy the space, and not to be bumped into. I have only visited just once for a Friday happy hour, stay tuned for a dinner visit.

I would assign The Green Owl a rating of 4 to 5 stars in relation to the culinary aspect of their offerings, but regrettably, their service falls short, leading to a decrease in their overall evaluation. In conjunction with my romantic partner, I had the pleasure of dining at this establishment last week. Following our seating, it required some time to hail the attention of our server, thus impeding our ability to place our order in a timely manner. We opted to share an order of crabby cakes, while my companion selected a bowl of chili complemented by sour cream and cornbread, and I chose the "meatball" sub, accompanied by kale chips as a side dish. The crabby cakes were served promptly, enveloped in a delectable creamy sauce, which we devoured instantaneously. Noteworthily, my companion, who habitually consumes meat and eschews tofu, relished these dishes. Our server informed us that our main courses would arrive shortly after presenting the crabby cakes. However, our food did not materialize for an additional 40 minutes, during which our server failed to provide any updates or explanations for the delay. Despite this setback, the quality of the food remained impressive. My sandwich was delivered scorching hot, with a crunchy bread roll and flavorful eggplant meatballs that maintained their texture within the sandwich. Unfortunately, the price point of $6 for an average-sized portion proved too prohibitive for me to indulge in a dessert. Notwithstanding the deficiencies in service, I harbor the intention of revisiting the Green Owl, as my curiosity lingers regarding numerous menu items that pique my interest.

the food was alright but definitely cost more than it should.  we went for a quick lunch and the service was alright too but the food was not up to par with your typical vegas food.  btw don't get the kim chee, not good.

Came here because Oregano's was packed on a Saturday night.  I wonder how many of their customers are in the same boat.  I was initially craving Mexican food anyway, so I didn't care.  

The service is awesome, the beer was so cold it was almost icy (read: awesome) and the salsa is yummy yummy.  I ordered the specialty chimichanga and my mom got rolled tacos.  The plates were hu-hu-hu-huge.  And can I just say that cream cheese makes everything better, especially chimichangas.  YUM.  

Not the best Mexican joint I have ever been to, but definitely decent enough to visit again (for the locals).

I attended an evening dedicated to the hip-hop genre, but unfortunately, the DJ's playlist did not align with my expectations, as the majority of the tracks he played did not belong to the hip-hop category. Despite this disappointment, I managed to have an enjoyable experience, owing to the lively atmosphere and the opportunity to socialize with other attendees.

This sushi restaurant has fresh fish and is the best I've found for a reasonable price in the valley (This coming from an east coast foodie who LOVES sushi.) However, the service is bad more often than it is good and NEVER go here in a hurry. I've never made it out of there in less than an hour. Once I went in there and asked for an itemized check, it took them 25 minutes to bring the check back AND it still wasnt itemized. In fact, I still don't know what it was. I love their sushi but its about time for me to find a new sushi restaurant after how many times I've had waitresses be rude and even ignore me. \n\nTheir redeeming quality that kept me coming back so long was their happy hour prices Sunday-Thursday. Its a lot of sushi for a small cost. So if you have plenty of time and don't mind a bad waiter or two check it out!

Decent store with knowledgeable staff but the prices are a bit higher than other stores. One employee recommended a collar that really helped with our dog that was a puller.

Everyone is friendly. There is a huge selection of many things for many pets. The prices are not bad but a touch high.

But Banfield. Don't do it. Avoid them. My aunt had awful experiences with "the plan" for their old dog. She was pressured into expensive treatments, they would sometimes not do ones she wanted, and it wasn't exactly cheap. Our experience was the same. We bought 1 year to try it, and canceling took a few tries. They pressured us to do more than we normally would have. And the "savings" included hundreds of dollars in services that most people would not buy.

Come here to get your pet some exercise in the summer. Get food, litter, check sale prices, visit the partnered pet rescue people, maybe grab a treat or toy for your pet. But Banfield felt even higher pressure than our last car purchase.

"-Note* Evaluation pertains solely to gaming/retail/aquatic facilities. Neither extreme fondness nor animosity is harbored towards this establishment. 

Retail: A newly refurbished shopping area has been unveiled, presenting an inviting ambiance and pristine appearance. An exclusive interest in entering the Urban Outfitters store is evident. 
Aquatic: The wave pool embodies a remarkable attraction, boasting a unique blend of sand and surf. A thoroughly enjoyable experience is ensured, further complemented by an optimal number of patrons. 
Gaming: A predictable atmosphere prevails, mirroring that of its Las Vegas counterparts. Appreciation is expressed toward the tasteful installation of chandeliers above, enhancing the overall ambiance. 

Conclusion: A well-maintained casino, with an adequate level of cleanliness, is presented. A neutral sentiment is harbored towards this venue, neither favoring nor avoiding visits. Numerous exceptional dining options are offered, complemented by the presence of the House of Blues. Suitable for families, this resort grants access to the Shark Reef aquarium within its premises."

Nice place to take the parents in Vegas... good food, although a bit on the pricey side. Then again, Vegas isn't the place to start scrimping on pennies. The menu had an interesting variety of selections, but the food didn't taste outstandingly exotic. Just your basic American breakfast with a twist here or there. Service was solid and we were seated fairly quickly (although I noticed a growing line right around the peak time for brunch).

Interior can certainly be modernized, however the food is solid. I'm not a fan of paying to sub hash browns and a english muffin for fruit. Seeing as how I am now paying more for less food. All in all, US Egg is a solid stop in spot every now and then. One of those resturants you're glad that exists, but you'll never take anyone there to show them.

The Chilenita they have the best empanada in town. It's a great place to take out or sit down for lunch. The staff is friendly. The food is so good. The price is affordable. There no other place that has 13 different empanada's to choose from. I love the Chilenita.

Food is average with sandwiches being $8-$10.  Had a burger with Pork Barbecue on it and onion straws and an iced tea for about $14.  Little pricey at lunch.  Surprised there was only 1 bartender/waitress for the whole bar area, but she did a good job managing it.  There were probably 20 people at the bar.  The restaurant has a bunch of TV's on sports or trivia.  The restaurant was crowded which is probably due to its location in the USX building.

We went to Red Lobster for lunch just after 2 PM.  It was moderately busy but we were quickly seated.  All three of us had the Endless Shrimp and between us, we had most of the varieties.  All were good, but nothing spectacular.  Service was not exactly speedy, but wasn't slow enough to put me off either.  Everyone was extremely courteous and pleasant.  $57.00 for three lunch specials was more than I am used to paying in a town known for inexpensive food, but it wasn't unexpected.  All-in-all, just as the rating says \"A-OK\".

"While the culinary offerings at this establishment are generally of superior quality, my recent dining experience was marred by a number of unfortunate incidents that detracted from my overall satisfaction. Specifically, my pork kebab contained an excessive amount of cartilaginous material, which made it difficult to consume with any degree of pleasure. Furthermore, I was forced to wait an inordinate amount of time for both my beverage and dipping sauce, which only served to exacerbate my frustration. In light of these issues, I would suggest that patrons who value a seamless dining experience may wish to consider alternative options."
The locations in phoenix have chicken we can add to our meal. This location does not. We drove an extra 10 minutes to get here  to find out they don't have chicken was not a pleasant surprise.

"Culinary delights are palatable, yet the quality of service is subpar. We have had the misfortune of dining at this establishment on two separate occasions, and both experiences have been marred by errors in our orders. Specifically, our meals were prepared incorrectly, and upon our second visit, we did not receive a suitable apology or any semblance of empathy from the waitstaff. It appears that the team is more reactive than proactive in addressing patrons' concerns. While the food is passable, it does not justify the exorbitant prices charged. Unfortunately, my initial enthusiasm for this restaurant has been significantly diminished due to the aforementioned factors, compelling me to seek alternative dining options."

Food is unique and tasty. Try the ultimate grilled cheese.  Service is poor. Three employees hang around at a table in the bar area chatting while the cook is preparing my food,  lunch came out wonderful but the front of house staff needs to find something to do and pay attention to a the few customers that are in there. I stopped in today at 1 for lunch but they changed their hours they are not open until 3 o'clock weekdays. I feel this place is going to close down quite soon. Prices for pool during promo hours are great.

my best friends girlfriend came for a visit from austin, being an architecture major, this was a place we obviously had to go.\n\nbeing there was obviously amazing... here's my beef... a tour was between $30-$80, seriously.  there was no way we could afford this obnoxious fee so we walked around the house and checked out the gift shop. we were pleased with this, but pretty disappointed not to take the tour.

This culinary establishment constitutes one of our most cherished destinations for a brief gastronomic interlude, especially when we possess Aria resort credits that necessitate expenditure. My personal predilection at this venue formerly consisted of procuring an assortment of baked items and chocolates for my acquaintances and loved ones back home (I have always been particularly fond of the bear claw). However, I have recently opted to sample their crepes, which I find quite delectable. We devoured a savory crepe filled with ham, cheese, and sauteed mushrooms, accompanied by a side dish consisting of leafy greens and diminutive tomatoes. Our preferred dessert crepe contains a filling of vanilla custard cream, topped with a mixture of berries in the form of a rich sauce. The queues at this eatery tend to be rather lengthy whenever I visit, yet the staff manages to process the clientele with remarkable efficiency. Although the prices may be considered somewhat elevated, the quality of the cuisine and the overall experience justify the cost.

"It is rather perplexing to comprehend the rationale behind the perpetual thronging of this establishment, although, upon further examination, it becomes apparent that the sonic infrastructure present within these walls is, indeed, of superior quality compared to other venues of a similar nature. Thus, it can be inferred that the aforementioned attribute serves as a significant factor in attracting an abundance of patrons. However, the process of navigating through the crowd to reach the billiard tables is arduous, to say the least, and necessitates a considerable amount of patience and tenacity. Upon successfully arriving at the aforementioned tables, one can revel in the spaciousness afforded by their proximity to the entrance, thereby providing a modicum of respite from the overwhelming crush of humanity. Although the quantity of tables available for utilization is satisfactory, a more thorough exploration of the premises is required to formulate a definitive assessment of this facility's overall merits. Therefore, I shall endeavor to revisit this location at a future date to conduct a more comprehensive evaluation."
Very colorful, especially if you want to smoke weed surrounded by a bunch of weirdos playing African drums...other than that it is rather boring

After reading all the good reviews we came here because my wife was in the mood for Indian food.  Its not a big restaurant and It is a buffet.  The mother's day special included a mango lassi (yum!) and  a dolsa (a rolled up pancake with lentil in the middle).  

The cold bar had varius kinds of churney, a salad, some fruit, and other sauces.  There were also 3 different kinds of soup.  A tomato soup that tasted a bit sour, a lentil based soup, and a spicy soup.

Its got a lot of the standard Indian fare.  What stood out to me was the goat curry.  The goat meat was fall off the bone tender and the curry had an excellent flavor.  Also, the tandoori chicken was nice and juicy.... not dry like a lot of other joints.  The paneer sagg (a spinach and cheese dish) was also pretty good.

There were some vegetarian dishes but being the carnivore that I am, I did not partake.  I got a taste of India without blowing out my palate on ridiculously spicy food.  That makes this a decent restaurant in my book.

"It is utterly perplexing to comprehend the grounds upon which numerous individuals base their expectations when patronizing establishments serving rapid culinary fare, as the quality of the consumables and the demeanor of the personnel are often subjective and variable factors; however, in this particular instance, my associates and I opted to sample the wares of this eatery, utilizing a promotional coupon to facilitate our indulgence in an array of menu items. Upon entering the premises, we encountered a hospitable staff who exhibited great alacrity in providing us with an assortment of comestibles, including the signature beverages and sundry accompaniments. Our gastronomical excursion proved to be a gratifying experience, as the lactose-based drinks were indeed remarkable, and my companions expressed unanimous approbation for the savory patties comprised of bovine flesh. Furthermore, we discovered that the cylindrical tubers, although ostensibly the most sought-after item, were surpassed in palatability by the slender, crispy fries."

"UltraStar, a novel entrant into the Phoenix region's entertainment landscape, boasts an expansive and welcoming lobby reminiscent of the cavernous interior of an aircraft hangar, thereby exuding an unmistakable aura of corporate sophistication that permeates every facet of the customer experience. Such a meticulously designed ambiance seems to emanate the deliberate, collective wisdom of a committee, fostering an atmosphere that, while undoubtedly well-coordinated, may strike some visitors as slightly sterile or lacking in organic character. Furthermore, the presence of a concession stand and gourmet coffee bar may evoke mirth or incredulity among European patrons who are accustomed to more refined and nuanced cinematic experiences. In terms of seating, the designated area appears decidedly utilitarian and unremarkable, offering scant opportunities for lingering or socializing, and thus may be perceived as somewhat drab or uninviting. However, the theatre itself, while hardly exceptional, managed to deliver a satisfactory viewing experience punctually, which suggests that the UltraStar management might benefit from familiarizing themselves with the operational strategies and best practices employed by Harkins theatres, in order to enhance their overall performance and elevate the quality of their services."

Decent food and the usual waitresses are busy but attentive.  The salads are good but be warned they usually take just as long, if not longer, than other food to come out to your table.  Chicken strips are good and I hear the wraps are excellent.

Other than that everything else is good but not great.  The potato soup is very good but don't order it too often as it is the soup-of-the-day about 90% of the time.

A decent option when you are tired of to-go food in the downtown area or want something besides a sandwich.

While the eatery itself was pleasant and the personnel was also quite hospitable, the culinary offerings did not necessarily meet our expectations of exceptional quality, given the establishment's ostensible commitment to gastronomic excellence. Specifically, the duration between placing our orders and the actual arrival of the dishes was rather brief, which, combined with the generally unremarkable nature of the fare, led to a sense of disappointment among our group. It is worth noting, however, that one particular item on the menu, the nachos, proved to be unexpectedly popular among our party, such that everyone began to partake of my portion with great enthusiasm. In light of this experience, I must confess that my quest for truly exceptional Mexican cuisine remains unfulfilled, as Diego's offerings, while aesthetically pleasing and served by friendly staff, fell short of my elevated standards.

"Commencing with an expression of my profound affection for the culinary offerings and flavor combinations presented at Layers, I must say that my enthusiasm for this establishment has been unwavering since its inception. Organic produce, an aspect that earns my utmost approbation, serves as an indubitable testament to the restaurant's commitment to quality. Notwithstanding, my recent experiences have been somewhat disconcerting, prompting me to confer a rating of three stars, down from the perfect five stars I had previously assigned. While the baked items maintain their exceptional quality, the kitchen fare has, regrettably, fallen short of my expectations during my last few visits. Specifically, the pasta dish I ordered was marred by an excessive amount of oil, rendering it unpalatable. Moreover, my most recent visit saw the meatloaf sandwich, dubbed 'The Conservative,' arrive in a state of disarray, with the bread being unacceptably soggy and fragmented, compelling me to consume it with utensils rather than enjoying the customary convenience of a handheld sandwich. A prior experience with a comparable sandwich, when the restaurant first opened, yielded a more satisfactory outcome, leading me to surmise that either a change in bread or a disparity in culinary expertise might be responsible for the decline in quality. In conclusion, although I would not advise against ordering any item from the menu, I sincerely hope that Layers will strive to restore their former excellence, as they remain one of my preferred dining establishments."

Surely ensure that they are cognizant of your time-sensitive predicament, provided you are indeed in a state of hastiness. It is utterly lamentable that despite my preemptive efforts to communicate explicit instructions (specifically requesting that the three dozen bialys be encased in plastic bags, as I intended to compactly store them within my luggage), an unfortunate oversight transpired, wherein the bialys were not adequately prepared, thus necessitating the taxi to await my presence, resulting in an augmented financial burden of $72 for a mere 39 bialys, inclusive of the taxi fare.

Been here twice... the selection seemed about the same... but not so sure. 
It's like walking into an aunt's house. The workers there are friendly, speak Tagalog to you right off the bat, even if you don't speak it (good or bad? Hmmm) and make sure you're ok for the most part.
I like the pork gisantes they have, and the pancit is pretty tasty! At $7.99/ person there's not much to complain about. They also sell other goodies and snacks at the register.
Probably will be back with the fam soon.

Honorable mentions:
Pusit
Diniguan (dinardaraan)

Ohh, parking is somewhat odd. One way only, so make sure you take the correct entrance! Although the lot is small, I usually find parking right away!

"Upon perusing Yelp in pursuit of a novel culinary experience, I chanced upon this establishment and decided to pay it a visit. Upon entering, I was struck by the diverse array of fresh, authentic Poke available, which exceeded my expectations and piqued my interest. Furthermore, I appreciated the opportunity to sample the various options prior to making a purchase, which allowed me to make an informed decision. Eventually, I opted for the spicy avocado ahi, which proved to be a satisfying choice, boasting a subtle yet palpable level of spiciness that complemented the dish without overpowering it. Indeed, this meal served as the sole sustenance for my midday repast, and I must say that I was thoroughly pleased with my decision to patronize this unassuming eatery. Despite its unpretentious appearance, this venue offers a truly delightful Poke experience that is not to be missed."

After an afternoon of recreation at the nearby park, I returned home feeling famished and disinclined towards consuming the customary cuisine offered on East Boulevard; thus, I opted to venture forth to Thai Taste, a local eatery renowned for its authentic Thai culinary delights. Upon entering the establishment, I was immediately struck by the traditional Thai decor that permeated the interior space, fostering a warm and welcoming ambiance that, albeit quaint, did not feel overly cramped or congested, even during a presumably off-peak dining period. 
  The menu presented itself in a straightforward fashion, allowing patrons to select their preferred entrÃ©e and combine it with a choice of meat, thereby tailoring their dining experience according to individual preferences. In my case, I opted for the green curry, which, when prepared with chicken, promised to deliver a flavor profile characterized by a harmonious balance between the pungency of fresh green chilies and the richness of coconut milk. Unfortunately, the execution of this particular dish fell short of my expectations, as the green curry, while boasting an undeniably aromatic quality, lacked the requisite level of piquancy typically associated with such a preparation. However, in light of favorable reviews pertaining to the establishment's culinary offerings, I am inclined to attribute this shortcoming to a momentary lapse in the kitchen and intend to revisit Thai Taste in the near future, during which time I shall insist upon an extra-hot rendition of the green curry, thereby affording me the opportunity to sample the dish in its optimal form. 
  The prices charged by Thai Taste are eminently reasonable, and the attentive nature of the service afforded me a constant supply of replenished water, a considerate touch that did not go unappreciated. In a timely fashion, my meal arrived, and I relished every bite, ultimately departing the premises satiated and content. Based on my positive experience, I would unhesitatingly recommend Thai Taste to aficionados of Thai cuisine seeking a satisfying dining experience in Charlotte, and, indeed, I look forward to returning in order to sample their Pad Thai, in addition to a more fiery green curry.

"While it may appear unremarkable at first glance, a closer inspection of The House of Blues reveals a multifaceted venue that offers an immersive experience for music enthusiasts. Although primarily characterized by a predominantly standing-room layout, astute patrons can opt for the indulgence of bottle service or, alternatively, ascend to the balcony to enjoy a more exclusive vantage point. Sonically, the establishment boasts an impressive auditory infrastructure that effectively showcases the performances of both emerging and established artists, thereby ensuring an aural satisfaction that precludes any potential grievances."

"While it is not my customary practice to compose a review for an establishment such as Pizza Hut, nor would I typically bother to check in on Yelp, I felt compelled to offer a testimonial for the carry-out location I intermittently patronize, as recent unfavorable assessments have prompted me to express my gratitude for the staff's consistent display of kindness and dedication to providing quality service despite the constraints imposed by the franchise's parameters, thereby warranting a positive endorsement of three stars, the maximum rating permissible by law for a Pizza Hut."

"I have had the pleasure of utilizing this culinary establishment on multiple occasions for grandiose dinner parties in their exclusive private dining area, and each experience has been utterly exceptional. On this particular visit, I reserved a table for two in the main dining area to celebrate a joyous birthday occasion. Upon arrival, the restaurant was bustling with activity and our presence was acknowledged forthwith. Our beverage preferences were solicited with alacrity, but unfortunately, our server seemed to prioritize other tables, leaving us in a state of neglect for an extended period. Our salads arrived in a timely manner, yet the entrÃ©e orders took an unacceptable amount of time to materialize. Furthermore, we were compelled to seek assistance from the busperson to replenish our water glasses and request additional bread. The latter portion of our meal was marked by repeated attempts to hail the attention of our server, who appeared to be preoccupied with a large party hosted by the chef and proprietor. Ultimately, we received our check after persistent requests, and the quality of the cuisine was satisfactory, with my angel hair pasta and my companion's gnocchi dishes being generously portioned and served at an optimal temperature."

D'abord, le bouquet d'\u00e9pices fait acte de pr\u00e9sence. On se souvient de son bouillon, adroitement appr\u00e9ci\u00e9 de clous de girofle, de badianes, de graines de coriandre et de cardamomes. Diverses variantes sur le m\u00eame th\u00e8me. Les Classiques sont plut\u00f4t impersonnelles avec des coupes de viande plus propres et immacul\u00e9es. Les Aventuriers  se prononcent d'une anatomie bovine moins pr\u00e9venante, flancs gras et tripes croustillantes. Si le d\u00e9faut d'asepsie vous emmerde, s'abstenir de la toilette. Je soustrais  une \u00e9toile pour cette raison.

"The culinary experience afforded by the consumption of pasta at this establishment was satisfactory, however, the use of Hershey's syrup as a topping for the tiramisu dessert raised concerns regarding the authenticity and credibility of the restaurant's claims to be an Italian eatery, thereby eliciting a sense of skepticism and incredulity in this patron."

I came here because I got a free voucher from a radio station contest I won and dont think I would of came if it weren't free. 

The steak was good but not great and expensive. There is however a sampler entree / mix grill on the menu. About 70 bucks but you get filet, kobe shirt and a new york cut. 

The Kobe shirt was good but it's kobe, never had a bad cut of kobe ever. 

The mash potatoes were pretty good too, I got the trio and the truffle and lobster one was good. 

Overall don't think I would go back with so many other great choices out there.

"Capriotti's captivating culinary creations have captured my gastronomical inclinations, albeit at an exorbitant expense. Lamentably, their menu lacks the healthier whole wheat bread option, rendering them somewhat antiquated in comparison to their competitors, such as Firehouse Subs, Subway, Port of Subs, Quiznos, et cetera. It is my fervent hope that Capriotti's will remedy this oversight by introducing whole wheat French bread to their offerings, thereby elevating both their nutritional value and contemporary appeal."

MTD is a great way to get to class when the weather is nasty.  However, the buses are often late, so be sure to choose a bus that arrives to your destination a few minutes early.  At least the MTD buses are free to students.

Not too bad!  Been to this location several times, still have not loved it yet.  

The antipasta platter was ok.  The mozzarella was good; the brushette had too much pesto; and calamari was not crispy enough.  The chicken marsala was ok too.  I tasted more of the grill of the chicken than the marsala sauce.  The mash potatoes were good.    I should have stuck to my usual pasta carrabba.  

The service is always excellent!

"It appears that an individual has expressed a sentiment which suggests that the English language is not necessary, and that the individual's nation can adequately function without it. Furthermore, the individual seems to be advocating for the abandonment of the English language in favor of their native tongue. This attitude towards language is not uncommon in certain parts of the world, where there is a strong emphasis on preserving cultural heritage and promoting linguistic diversity. However, it is worth considering the potential consequences of such an approach, as it may lead to communication barriers and hinder global understanding. Additionally, it is worth noting that language is not just a means of communication, but also a powerful tool for shaping one's identity and worldview. Therefore, it is important to strike a balance between preserving cultural traditions and embracing global connectivity through language."

Decided to go to Einstein for breakfast. It was just before 9am on Sunday morning and the line was literally out the door. I thought about going somewhere else but we decided to wait. Fortunately the line moved fairly quickly and we ordered & paid in about 13 minutes. The dining area is a good size so there were still some open tables. Our food was ready about 4 minutes later. I got the applewood bacon & cheddar egg sandwich on a plain bagel. It was hot and good. A little pricey for what you get though.

I attended a gathering at this establishment, whereupon our group consisted of approximately twenty individuals, thereby enabling me to sample an array of culinary offerings. While some selections proved to be delectable, others unfortunately did not meet my expectations. However, I must commend them for offering an assortment of European beverages, which undoubtedly contributed to the ambiance. Unfortunately, the arrival of our repast was delayed significantly, despite our reservation being made well in advance. It appeared that the family-operated enterprise was unprepared to accommodate such a sizable assembly. Nonetheless, it is gratifying to note that our patronage supported a local family business, as the proprietors, including both parents and their offspring, were actively involved in the culinary and hospitality aspects of the operation.

"Upon venturing to this establishment for the first time, I found it to be an adequate location for satiating one's boba cravings without the necessity of traversing to Chinatown. My order of boba milk tea, enhanced by the inclusion of jelly, bore a striking resemblance in taste to volcano tea, thereby eliciting my satisfaction. However, my companion's selection of a taro smoothie yielded an unfavorable assessment from him. It is evident that the quality of the beverages served here is inconsistent and varies depending on the specific item ordered. Additionally, I deducted points due to the limited array of options available, as well as the unremarkable ambiance within the store, which features a compact, unadorned interior that does not foster a sense of leisure or relaxation. A more extensive offering of snacks would have been appreciated."

"My excitement to engage in golfing activities at this esteemed course was palpable, given its prestigious location within the affluent community of The Ridges in Summerlin. The opportunity to participate in a charitable event allowed me to experience the course in a shotgun format, providing an abbreviated yet still insightful exposure to its layout. 

Promoted as a showcase of Jack Nicklaus' most exceptional hole designs, the course presented itself with an air of promise, though sadly, the conditions did not entirely live up to my expectations. The sweltering heat, combined with the arid terrain and patchy greens, made for a challenging round that failed to fully realize its potential. A recent punching of the greens was evident, but regrettably, the effects were not as pronounced as they could have been. 

A visit to the clubhouse ensued, with the hope of acquiring some memorabilia, only to be met with a less-than-welcoming reception from the attendant. A simple acknowledgement or greeting would have sufficed, but unfortunately, such courtesies were not extended. Consequently, I opted not to make any purchases. 

Despite the underwhelming experience, each hole still boasted the capacity to be truly remarkable, with their picturesque surroundings and panoramic views of both the opulent residences and the iconic Las Vegas Strip. A return visit is warranted, as I am eager to reassess the course's quality under different circumstances."

Salads are delicious there jumbo shrimps go perfect on top! There unique dressings to choose from Lime infused ranch was amazing! \n\nCons- Poor customer Service, not helpful when it comes to being undecided or asking for their recommendations

I have had the privilege of visiting the iconic city of New York, where I had the opportunity to indulge in a slice of their world-renowned pizza. Unfortunately, my experience with the pizza at this establishment fell short of my expectations, as it failed to live up to the standards set by its authentic New York-style counterpart. Despite the ambiance and quality of service being satisfactory, I regret to say that I do not foresee myself returning to this venue in the future.

I don't know that I would have gotten oil changes for a few years if it hadn't been for this place.  

One stop shopping for getting an oil change and car wash - and there's a Wendy's right next door to grab some grub while they mess with the car.  They've expanded their offerings recently and now they do things from replacing your headlights to changing out belts.  My last trip there was an oil change, new air filter and car wash for $47 after tax.  They also do a basic car wash from $3.99 and a super was from $7.99.  I've never gotten anything but the basic, and I always find things they missed so while I'm not too impressed with their quality, it's nice to have the basics all taken care of in one location. 

They have 48 hour guarantees on the washes, which is nice and when you get work done it always includes a "limited time" coupon for additional work.  Not a bad deal...

"John's watering hole possesses qualities that render it an agreeable venue for individuals seeking a casual drinking establishment within close proximity to their domicile. The interior design exudes an aura of cleanliness and aesthetic appeal, while the culinary offerings, though unremarkable in quality, provide sustenance sufficient to satiate one's appetite. Patrons have the option to peruse menus from both the esteemed Mario's Pizza and the more limited selection offered by the bar, thereby affording them a diverse array of edible options. Of particular note are the delectable sliders, available in either chicken or cheeseburger varieties, which elicit praise from this writer due to their exceptional flavor. During sporting events, numerous televisions scattered throughout the premises afford patrons an optimal viewing experience, complemented by the presence of enticing drink specials. Although service is generally satisfactory, lapses in attention occasionally occur, understandably so given the steady stream of loyal clientele drawn from surrounding neighborhoods. In summary, John's place presents itself as a welcoming and comfortable local pub, well-suited to meet the needs of those seeking a relaxed, convivial atmosphere without necessitating extensive travel."

Had a nice breakfast at Gertrude's before checking out the Chihuly exhibit at the botanical garden. My traveling companion and I like to check out the botanical gardens in the cities we visit, and it was nice to have a breakfast option right there on site.

We both had the breakfast sammies, which were good, despite the fact that I don't think anything should be called a 'sammie.' The coffee was strong, and my only complaint was that it didn't get filled very often.

We were able to eat on the patio, which was nice since we were visiting the area partially to get away from the cold. It was very comfortable and pretty.

"We recently partook in a culinary excursion to this cozy eatery, and our arrival was met with an arduous queue, which threatened to deter us from our gastronomical pursuits. However, our persistence was rewarded by the hospitable staff's proffering of a delectable tray of lechon kawali (roast pork belly), thereby rekindling our interest in savoring the establishment's offerings. The menu boasted an array of Filipino delicacies, including Filipino-style corned beef and potatoes, as well as oxtail stew (\"kare-kare\"), both of which we indulged in with great relish. The ambiance of the restaurant, nestled within a bustling Chinese plaza, exuded a sense of warmth and familiarity, reflective of the Filipino cultural value of fostering strong connections with one's neighbors, as evidenced by the name of the establishment itself, which translates to \"house-connected.\" The prices, at a reasonable $6.50 for two dishes and rice, only served to further enhance our dining experience."

"The retail establishment boasts an array of luxury items and a sufficient assortment of products, yet, in concurrence with the previous patron's remarks, the personnel would greatly benefit from fundamental instruction in clientele etiquette. Paradoxically, the more mature employees manifest a warm, polite, and accommodating demeanor, whereas their younger counterparts display discourteous conduct, engaging in boisterous personal conversations within earshot of patrons, expressing visible exasperation and impatience, and indulging in disrespectful eye movements or utterly disregarding customers. It is truly perplexing that a business that prides itself on its high-end reputation does not place greater emphasis on instilling corresponding behavioral standards among its staff."

Well, I'm sitting here while my son plays.... Music is so loud you have to shout to communicate.... I asked them to turn the volume down a bit, they did but then turned it back up..... Inappropriate songs come on and staff needs to be told to turn it.... I mean what parent wants their kid listening to a song about a$$ and twerking? Other than these issues (that can definitely be addressed), it's a great place....

"While the Boozery's location may suggest the possibility of an exciting experience, the reality is unfortunately quite disparate, as the bar itself is rather diminutive in size, although it does offer some outdoor seating to compensate for its limited indoor capacity. Despite its modest dimensions, the interior exudes a certain charm and ambiance, yet the cramped quarters somewhat mitigate the potential for an truly enjoyable time. The drink menu is unremarkable, featuring a selection of standard cocktails at prices comparable to those found on Freemont Street ($7-$10), and ultimately, the Boozery fails to distinguish itself from the multitude of other unexceptional downtown bars, offering little reason for enthusiasm or commendation."

I planned an event here with some girlfriends for an early dinner. The place is easy to miss, because it's a small building so if you blink or aren't paying attention you will get lost (trust me...I know). Also, just a head's up with the place being so small parking is a bit of a pain. In fact it's pretty non-existent. There's a few spaces in the front and if you're lucky they have a few in the back...if all those are full....good luck! 

That being said, the menu is pretty simple. I think they are going for down home favorites. There are your staple dishes like meatloaf, burgers, fish and salads. But I just wasn't overly impressed with the menu. I opted for the Veggie Burger and fries. It's your typical Morning Star veggie burger so nothing to be amazed about there and the fries were just okay. 

The service was great but I'm just not sure I'd make it a priority to give them another try. Based on the reviews, their brunch might be worth another visit. We'll see!

"The decibel level within the establishment was remarkably high, rendering conversation challenging, albeit suitable for revelers seeking to partake in fermented beverages, sporting events, and grilled culinary delights. Notwithstanding, the selection of artisanal brews was truly exceptional, while the gastronomical offerings, though slightly delayed, were expertly prepared and undeniably savory. Our hospitable server and the proprietor himself extended warm welcomes, and the complementary side dishes, specifically the gravy fries and macaroni and cheese, showcased pronounced flavors. Despite my residence in Glendale, I wouldn't venture across the Valley solely to visit this venue again, however, I would unhesitatingly endorse it to acquaintances residing in close proximity who seek an exhilarating atmosphere to enjoy a football match or two alongside superior quality beverages."

(+)
1. Great location - Located within walking distance to Notre Dame, Old Montreal, Chinatown, Latin Quarters, St. Catherine's, a few arts museums, the metro and a lot of shopping and restaurants.

2. The room was big. Very high ceiling with a king size bed and a small kitchen.

3. Nice and friendly staff. They provided an extra cot with no charge.

4. Free internet - they provide a code to you upon check-in.

5. Free continental breakfast - toast, croissants, cereals, fruits and coffee.

(-)
1. We requested 2 beds and ended up with a room with only one. We went to talk to the front desk and they were out of rooms to switch us to. But they provided the cot at no extra charge.

2. The towels smell. 

3. The parking is $22 a day which is OK. but it has to be valet. If you need something in your car, you have to go through the concierge.

I know this is a rare 3 star review for this place and I will preface it by saying it is the only Las Vegas buffet I have ever been to, so I have nothing to compare it to, but enjoyed the experience.

I went here for dinner while wandering along the strip one night and I thought it was your typical buffet with a wide variety of options that weren't gourmet but still good.  I think the key is to choose the right options.  The crab legs were awesome and totally worth the $20 since I probably ate $30 of legs alone.  Other favorites included prime rib, mashed potatoes, and spicy tuna rolls.  Salad bar was just OK and so were the desserts.

This is a really good deal if you are hungry! The atmosphere is pretty tacky but it is within the Imperial Palace so that's to be expected.

I've stayed here twice, and had very different room experiences.  Only one side of the hotel is renovated and that of course makes a huge difference.  My boyfriend and I had a room with a king size bed and it was nicely updated and had a great bathroom.  I booked again with the girls and we had rooms with 2 double beds, very dated, worn furniture, old carpet.  If you're going with friends and don't plan on spending much time in the room then it's a good choice based on location and price.  The other negatives is that you have to pay to use the gym and the pool area is VERY crowded...tough to get a lounge chair.  Gambling is OK...but the drink service is a little slow.

"It is conceivable that my anticipations were excessively elevated, thereby leading to a disparity between my expectations and the actual quality of the culinary offerings, which, in turn, engendered a sense of disappointment that was arguably disproportionate to the intrinsic value of the fare itself, which, while admittedly palatable, did not possess any remarkable or truly exceptional qualities that would have justified the price point at which it was offered, and yet, notwithstanding this relative lack of gastronomic excellence, the service provided by the waiting staff was, in fact, quite commendable and appreciably attentive."

Just ordered a pizza and wings for delivery. I picked up my pizza before and I got a weird vibe from the staff. They are very unpleasant, thought if I phoned it in I would get a happy tone on the other end.... WRONG! They need to hire delightful people to work the register and take the phone calls. This will be my last time ordering from them until my free pizza coupon is valid lol! Oh and the pizza's not all that bad! Definitely better than Pizza Hut!

Hakkasan, an illustrious nightclub situated within the luxurious MGM Grand, presented us with an opportunity to partake in its grandeur. As we found ourselves on the General Admission (GA) list, we hastened our arrival prior to 1 a.m., thereby avoiding any potential monetary expenditure. Upon our timely arrival, we encountered an unexpected benevolence; the entrance fee had been waived, much to our relief! The affable bouncers facilitated our ingress into the club with remarkable efficiency, fostering a seamless transition for patrons. However, upon gaining entry, I was taken aback by the diminutive proportions of the dance floor. It was lamentably minuscule! The atmosphere was characterized by an unyielding throng of individuals, rendering movement a formidable challenge. Envisioning a scenario with a renowned disc jockey, such as Tiesto or Hardwell, conjured up images of an exceptionally congested environment, making it difficult to maneuver. Regrettably, my memories of the subsequent events are somewhat impaired due to my state of intoxication. The only details that remain vivid in my recollection are the security personnel's insistence on maintaining a sense of order by urging patrons to vacate certain areas, thereby creating an atmosphere that was both restrictive and oppressive.

I have been to this particular location for eyebrow threading twice.  On both occasions I walked in without an appointment and was greeting right away.  There was no wait and the desk attendant was very professional.  The brow threading person did an excellent job.  I would recommend that she improve her customer service.  She did not ask me how I would like my brows done or even speak to me at all.  Overall, I would come back again since they did make my brows look great!

"For a smorgasbord, I surmised that this establishment offered a relatively satisfactory culinary experience, with the comestibles being genuinely representative of the authentic Indian gastronomical tradition, and the seasonings and spices being carefully prepared to evoke the distinctive flavors which I have come to associate with genuine Indian cuisine. Notwithstanding my unfamiliarity with a significant portion of the offerings, the variety of dishes available was appreciable, although I must admit that the profusion of flavors ultimately became somewhat indistinguishable from one another, leading me to speculate that in future, I might prefer to patronize a traditional Indian restaurant where I can savor a single dish, such as chicken marsala or curry, in isolation."

"Relatively pricey in comparison to the nearby Gandhi's restaurant, the culinary offerings were satisfactory yet unremarkable, while the atmosphere was somewhat more refined than the typical Indian eatery."

"It is not deceptive to admit that I relished a thoroughly enjoyable experience during my recent visit to this esteemed eatery. The interior design exudes an air of contemporary sophistication, complete with elevated platforms that double as performance areas for scantily-clad dancers to showcase their talents while patrons partake in their culinary indulgences. However, my overall satisfaction was slightly compromised due to a few minor drawbacks. Specifically, the hostesses displayed an excessively stringent demeanor, feigning ignorance of my prior reservation despite the fact that my hotel concierge had already arranged it over the phone. Furthermore, they seemed to be under the impression that they were conferring a favor upon me by accommodating my request, albeit after an extended period of time. In contrast, our server exhibited exceptional proficiency and attentiveness throughout the evening. The cuisine itself was adequate, with the Black Cod appetizer being particularly noteworthy, while the crab cake counterpart fell short of my expectations. The fried shrimp dish was also commendable, and the steak offerings adhered to the established standards associated with the Morton's brand. In conclusion, although my dining experience was generally satisfying, the abundance of exceptional eateries in Las Vegas renders it unlikely that I will return to this specific location in the future."

"This culinary establishment offers an enjoyable ambiance for consumers to indulge in gastronomical delights, however, it does not quite align with my personal preferences. 

The hospitality demonstrated by the staff was indeed commendable and played a significant role in elevating the overall experience to a passable level. 

Regrettably, the fare served was merely mediocre, with each dish excessively seasoned to the point where I could only consume half of it, despite feeling famished. It is not advisable to order the special hash and potatoes together, as they share a strikingly similar flavor profile, which would necessitate an abundance of hydration to successfully complete consumption. However, the quality of other menu items appears to be satisfactory, and this may explain its popularity among patrons. Perhaps restricting options to waffles and pancakes would be a wiser choice, as they seemed visually appealing. 

It is challenging to endorse this eatery wholeheartedly, unless one's taste buds incline towards heavily seasoned cuisine. Nevertheless, the atmosphere is conducive to a pleasant dining experience."

"Having initially been perceived as a mere imitation of Panera, Atlanta Bread has subsequently expanded its menu to include a diverse array of innovative offerings. Upon sampling the Italian vegetable panini on a recent evening, I found the flavors to be palatable, yet the cost was somewhat prohibitive considering the modest serving size. Notwithstanding the complimentary pickle and kettle chips accompanying the dish, I remained slightly unsatisfied. While the ambiance and complimentary wireless internet access are certainly appealing aspects, the quality of service leaves something to be desired. Nevertheless, this establishment remains a viable choice for those seeking a satisfying sandwich experience, although the pasta selections tend to be rather unremarkable."

In a culinary ocean saturated with gourmet eateries, occasionally one yearns for a mundane repast. For an unassuming cafÃ©, the edifice was not devoid of merit. We merely sought a quotidian sustenance for a tardy luncheon. Numerous establishments were still in the process of inaugurating their daily operations, while others proffered a restricted noontime menu. It was a Sunday replete with gridiron matches, thus numerous drinking establishments teemed with enthusiasts. 
The ambiance evoked memories of Cheesecake Factory, boasting an extensive bill of fare. The staff exhibited amicability. I opted for deep-fried poultry accompanied by mashed potatoes. Although not particularly greasy, the poultry possessed a discernible saltiness, situating it somewhere between mediocrity and excellence. The potatoes lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, but the savory chicken effectively counterbalanced the deficiency. I requested a Pear Martini, only to discover that the components were unavailable. Thus, I indulged in a scrumptious Strawberry Martini instead. My spouse opted for a cheeseburger and fries. While the latter satisfied my taste buds, I did not sample the former. Nevertheless, my better half consumed it with relish and claimed it surpassed his expectations. 
Given the abundance of superior dining establishments within walking distance, the likelihood of my return remains uncertain. However, in a pinch, I might consider partaking of their offerings once more.

This is a decent buffet for locals, I guess. I didn't have to pay because my partner gets comps; if I'd had to pay I think I'd be a little more critical, because this is just a mid-level buffet to pay over $50 for two people. 

 We went on seafood Friday. Nothing there was a standout- most of the fare is the same as the kind offered at most mid-level Vegas buffets- average.  We had a nice server with a good sense of humor who was kept busy in our section. The hot crab legs were good. 

The things that weren't so great: The sushi was cold and not so great, the cold shrimp was soft and floppy. The salmon looked moist but it wasn't. 

The hush puppies were little balls of fried salt. The fried catfish tasted like "chicken fried" catfish but the batter coating was soft due to sitting in the heat for a while. 

The carrot cake was so dry that a piece of it weighed almost nothing. Same with the chocolate fudge piece with the icing. Sigh...

So the crab was good. The presentation of the shelled sea-food dishes was nice, and they were flavorful.  Everything else we tried and haven't mentioned was "meh." Not horrible or inedible. Kids would enjoy this place just fine, as would folks with a little extra money who are looking for a relaxing food-filled time.

"Enormous pasta serving. Appetizers became superfluous when confronted with the gargantuan magnitude of my spaghetti. When the menu at an Italian eatery fails to provide a stimulating option, I tend to choose the tried-and-true spaghetti with meatballs. It's a quintessential dish whose preparation serves as a litmus test for the quality of the establishment's culinary offerings. Thankfully, the noodles were cooked to a perfect firmness and the meatballs retained an optimal level of juiciness. Alas, our meal began with a selection of cured meats and flatbread pizzas, leaving me feeling satiated by the time my entree arrived, much to my dismay. However, I returned later that evening, following a night of indulgent drinking, to partake in a supremely gratifying post-drinking pizza experience. Interestingly enough, I wasn't the only one who had the same idea."

I reviewed this in 2009 to let people know that I got food poisoning here. I ate here again and am rating it more highly cause I ate the veg food and it was fine, but mostly because I highly approve of the quantity and quality of their rice.  Working class Asian Americans like myself love their rice and this place is super generous and the quality is very very good. Better than the entree itself in fact.

"Although it is true that they have recently introduced a vegetarian variant of their fajitas, priced at $10, it is rather unfortunate that the portion size of tofu accompanying the dish is somewhat meager, and when compared to the superior quality and quantity of tofu offered by Jack Astor's rendition of this popular Tex-Mex dish, it becomes evident that the value proposition presented by this menu item is not particularly compelling; therefore, it is unlikely that I would opt to order them again in the future."

I am a whore for great burgers, but it is hard to impress me. Indulge flirts with this, but I can never get my burger cooked to the temperature I ask for. I hate that! Take the Outback strategy and undercook everything, I don't care. Oh, and buy some salt for the beef.\n\nGood deals, real good drink deals, for happy hour!

"Savor the delectable victuals and exceptional hospitality! Don't overlook the'sides'; I relished the creamy hummus and savory lentils, which were both scrumptious. I exhausted the pita bread but they generously provided additional portions upon my request. Additionally, the desserts are highly recommended; I indulged in an unforgettable strawberry bar (the name escapes me), which was utterly delightful. 

My culinary exploration continued with the Good Earth sandwich, boasting fresh components, yet the sauce's flavor profile didn't quite align with my palate, perhaps due to my unfamiliarity with local tastes. If I were to return, I might consider omitting the sauce or requesting it on the side. The guacamole sandwich was more to my liking, although the red sauce was excessively saccharine for my taste buds. I shared these dishes with a companion, and we concurred on our assessments.
