Furthermore, there was another vegan sandwich alternative, Tree of Life, which I ordered for my beau and his companions to share. They relished it the most, so I trust this feedback proves beneficial!"

I've been a member of Lifetime for a few months and their facilities are hands down the best. You can read the other reviews for how awesome tha facility is but I'm going to speak to some of the interesting events that take place in the men's locker room and I am not joking at all......

Apparently the men's locker room gets rather friendly after hours and when I say after hours I state that loosely as in 10-11pm.   On two occasions.....I repeat.....two occasions I had the same 55 year old man pull up to a sink next to me and blow dry his junk.  I'm not exagerrating and my friend was at the sink to his left.   He was sandwiched between us butt naked stretching his stick and blow drying his junk dry.   I ran out of the gym in fear.   A few weeks later the SAME MAN did it again except this time I was by myself.   

Another time, 2 young men in their 30's were slapping each other in behinds with towels NAKED and chasing each other around the gym.  They almost knocked me over.....Thankfully I am not homophobic but come on, there's a time and place for everything......and apparently Lifetime is where it's at.   CAUTION - BEWARE

My expectations may be too high...let's start off with the positives.  Big parking lot, modern decor and very spacious.  Great service for having only one person running the front of the house.   

We ordered chicken red curry, papaya salad, BBQ chicken, pad thai and a side order of sweet rice.

Sweet rice - soggy and over cooked.  It came in a plastic sandwich bag.

BBQ chicken - it was served with a side of the sweet chili sauce...bottled chili sauce.  The chicken is a piece of chicken breast marinated in what seemed like dried curry rub.  It was not BBQ nor did it taste like BBQ. It tasted pan fried.  Overall, I did not like it.

Papaya salad - a bit too salty without the lime flavor.  Tiny bits of dried peanuts mixed throughout the salad....wasn't authentic, very Americanized.

Chicken red curry - loved the bamboo shoots and normal curried vegetables in the dish however the curry sauce lacked flavor.  It was very bland and no taste...it could've used a dash of fish sauce.  Overall, it was ok.

Pad thai - I was over it prior to making my way towards this dish.  My kids absolutely LOVED it!  That says it all as my kids are very picky eaters with a sophisticated palette.

Would I return? Likely not and still in search for authentic Thai cuisine in AZ!

Sooooo... I'm giving them 3 stars b/c the Manager took care of our bill. Ya see this is the second time my b/f and I had an issue with the service on two separate occasions. First time they didn't bring my water when I asked twice and didn't bring the bill. This time (tonight) they brought our food to the wrong people, took it back, brought it back out after 15 min., it was cold... I told them we didn't want it (no attitude) so the Manager comes and says its on him. That's great customer service! So why 3 stars???

Well... It would be different if this happened every once in a while but two times in a row. And this is the only two times I've been there. I like that the seats are comfortable. I like the tables. I like the screen, the atmosphere, the bar and all that outside, but the dining experience screwed it up for me. I'd rather concentrate on the movie rather than what I'm missing or what's wrong... 

Bottom line: Get ya girl or female homie with the big purse to stuff all the goodies and snacks in it and enjoy the movie!
So..this place is cute!  Huge dance floor!  The whole place is huge! Geesh~  Fun decor and nice bartenders.  The guys there seem pretty lame though.  Cool place to get dressed up and dance.

"It's an exuberant celebration within the establishment's interior, boasting an aesthetically pleasing ambiance and an captivating display of pyroclastic activity, ostensibly emulating a volcanic eruption; furthermore, the culinary offerings surpass those of its predecessor, 'The Burger Joint,' which previously occupied the same location, although the fare may be somewhat pedestrian, it remains a worthwhile investment for those seeking a satisfying dining experience."

"Roberto's, a culinary establishment boasting multiple locations throughout Las Vegas, was once the epicenter of my gastronomical infatuation. However, as time has elapsed, my ardor for their offerings has waned, correlatively mirroring a perceived decline in the overall quality of their cuisine. Despite this, Roberto's continues to surpass numerous other dining options within the city limits, though my personal standards have been elevated by exposure to exceptional street food vendors and authentic Mexican eateries. Thus, while still enjoyable, Roberto's has relegated itself to the realm of 'average' in my esteem, eliciting an occasional craving that I satiate intermittently."

I have had the pleasure of partaking in the culinary offerings of this esteemed establishment on multiple occasions, and I must say that the quality of the service has been exceptional, with the staff exhibiting a proficiency in their duties that is truly commendable. Furthermore, the ambiance of the restaurant itself is quite pleasant, boasting a relaxed and informal atmosphere that is conducive to an enjoyable dining experience.

However, I must admit that my experiences with the pizza offered by this establishment have been somewhat mixed. While I have sampled a few different varieties of pizza here, I have not been entirely enamored with the sauces employed, nor have I been particularly fond of the texture or flavor of the crust. Nevertheless, I have been impressed by the quality of the non-pizza items available on the menu, such as the delectable sides, salads, and soups that have graced my palate with their presence.

In light of these observations, I must confess that I am intrigued by the prospect of exploring the remaining options on the menu, and I would not hesitate to return to this establishment in order to do so. However, it is unlikely that I will be ordering the pizza again in the near future, as my previous experiences with it have not been entirely satisfactory.

"This eatery boasts an agreeable ambiance, a pleasant setting, and I have consistently received satisfactory assistance during my visits; however, I must express some reservations regarding the quality of their bread, which, in my opinion, falls short of exceptional. It appears that the establishment aims to create a dense, moist loaf, a characteristic that may appeal to certain patrons. Nevertheless, my personal preference lies with the offerings of Wildflower Bread Company, whose bread exemplifies the perfect balance of dryness, lightness, and residual moisture, culminating in a satisfying texture and bite."

I tried the lunch buffet here a few weeks ago, and the food was pretty good.  We discovered the buffet on our last day in Vegas, after some horrible Studio Cafe experiences.  The flat daily rate seems like an excellent deal when you consider what you pay for food in Vegas.  The seating area was freezing for some reason, but our waitress was great.  She noticed that we were shivering and suggested coffee/tea, and she kept them refilled.

Situated in the heart of the shops at Palazzo, this unassuming wine bar offers decent selections at the bar and good to great selections in the shop located adjacent to the bar. 

Bottle prices are a bit high, but that's what Vegas is all about. 

I was disappointed with the glassware, which ranging from either the O-Line series to small bowled glasses with short stems, reminiscent of bad hotel banquets. For a wine bar, I simply expected more in terms of glassware.

Other than that, the staff was friendly and kept my glass filled!!!

"An excellent location for recreational activities, offering ample opportunities for physical exertion and enjoyment, yet, unfortunately, hampered by inadequate maintenance and lax officiating. Specifically, the lack of a functioning speed ball arena significantly diminishes the overall experience, while the apparent reluctance of referees to oversee games properly has become increasingly problematic. However, management's willingness to provide complimentary repair services for damaged equipment and thorough cleaning procedures offers some consolation. To elevate this venue to a five-star status, a concerted effort towards revitalizing the playing fields and instituting more rigorous standards for referees would be necessary."

We had been eagerly anticipating dining at the Block & Grinder since its opening, having heard numerous accolades regarding its culinary offerings. Upon finally experiencing it for ourselves, we found the edibles to be quite satisfactory, warranting a rating of 4 to 5 stars. However, our enjoyment of the meal was somewhat mitigated by the less than stellar ambiance and service. Specifically, we were seated in a rather cramped area adjacent to a large table, and it took approximately 12 minutes before a server noticed our presence and attended to our needs. Subsequently, we received attentive care from our server, albeit at a pace that could be described as leisurely due to his responsibility for multiple sizeable tables.   Moving on to more favorable aspects of our dining experience, we began with an appetizer of pimento cheese served with crackers, which we found to be exceptionally delectable and arguably the most flavorful pimento cheese we have had the pleasure of sampling during our brief exposure to this particular delicacy. For our main course, we opted for the ribs, which proved to be a judicious decision. The meat was not only tender and lean but also ranked among the most succulent ribs we have had the pleasure of consuming.  Considering our overall satisfaction with the food, we might consider returning to the Block & Grinder, ideally during a weeknight or off-peak hours, in the hope of improving our dining experience by avoiding the crowds that may have contributed to the sluggish service we encountered. Additionally, we would be interested in sampling the establishment's cocktails.

I live pretty close to Papago, so it's a place I regularly hike. But it's not because I love this park, it's really because of the convenience of living so close, and the fact that the trials are not challenging at all. Papago is one of the few places that I feel 100% safe about hiking on my own. Unless you take a wrong step while climbing one of the buttes, it's pretty hard to hurt yourself. \n\nThe park is clean and well kept, and you do get some good views of Phoenix, Tempe and Scottsdale on your hike. Once in a while I've even spotted some cool birds flying around. Because it's such an easy hike, Papago is a great spot for beginner/novice hikers, and a pretty good spot to take your kids or the dog. If you're looking to get outside and get some air, Papago is the place to hit up for an hour or two on a quiet afternoon or morning.

All the locals recommended this place to me for burgers and I've tried them twice to just make sure the first time wasn't a goof. But both times, the food was so blah. It should take more then just a massive piece of meat to get good ratings. I've tried both a burger and a steak, and they were both so bland. There's no flavor what's so ever. I was highly disappointed.

Bed Bath & Beyond -- thoroughly overpriced and suffering from subpar parking facilities at this specific location, much to my dismay. I only frequent BB&B when I am in possession of one of those highly sought-after 20% discount coupons. On a recent visit, I was in pursuit of an exceptional linen spray, specifically the Egyptian Cotton-scented variety. Unfortunately, they were out of stock on both occasions I visited the store. My quest for a suitable "everyday" cookware set was also thwarted, as they only offered premium Calphalon products, which were beyond my budget. However, I did manage to procure a new shower curtain liner and a pair of candles, albeit at a different retail establishment.

"My anticipation for dining at this establishment was immense, but unfortunately, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled. Prior to attending a performance by Cirque du Soleil, we opted to partake in a culinary experience here. Our initial selections included the frisee salad and lobster bisque, both of which proved to be scrumptious. Notably, the frisee boasted substantial portions of bacon, which, when combined with the runny yolk, elevated the flavor profile of the dish significantly. Additionally, we indulged in a half-bottle of red wine whose quality merited its cost. However, my enthusiasm for Craftsteak ended there. I opted for the flat iron steak and sampled the surf and turf option, which featured a ribeye and lobster tail. In all honesty, I have savored superior cuts of meat in my native Texas. Disappointment also characterized my experience with the bread rolls, as their reputation preceded them, but ultimately, they failed to impress me. To put it into perspective, if you have had the pleasure of consuming a yeast roll from Hartz Chicken, then you have essentially tasted the offering from Craftsteak. My desire to elaborate further on this dining establishment is limited."

This is the only hotel I've stayed at downtown - I know, hard to believe a person from Hawaii never stayed at the California!!  But I'm really picky about what hotels I stay at and the California and every other hotel located downtown always made me feel itchy while walking through - like I said before: "Happy Faye, happy stay!"

The rooms were pretty average, but I only stayed in their standard rooms.

I've had good experiences here and never felt unsafe (while in the hotel room and casino area).  All of the employees were always nice and helpful, which is always good to have!  Their 24 hour coffee shop serves good food at reasonable prices (they even have some "Hawaii friendly" menu items!).

"In light of my personal expectations and dining experience, I would assign a rating of three and a half stars to this establishment. The ambiance and menu offerings were undoubtedly captivating, yet I couldn't help but feel that the overall atmosphere was slightly over-the-top for my taste. Perhaps this is a common trait among Las Vegas eateries? Nonetheless, I was impressed by the quality of the oxtail chili fries, which lived up to its reputation as a must-try item. Unfortunately, the Manga burger fell short of my expectations due to an excessive amount of sauce that overpowered the flavor of the patty. However, the matcha green tea milkshake provided a pleasant contrast to the savory dishes. While I acknowledge the uniqueness of Bachi Burger's offerings, I remain skeptical about its ability to hold its own against the plethora of exceptional burger joints in Los Angeles, particularly with the impending arrival of a new location on Sawtelle Boulevard. Only time will tell if Bachi Burger can successfully distinguish itself from its competitors."

Want to stay on the strip but you're a cheapskate? Sahara is the place for you.

Old + Falling Apart + Terrible Shows =  great character.

Only problem is it's a little too far away from the heart of the strip.

When I was employed at the Renaissance tower, I would frequent this establishment when I was feeling particularly indolent and opted to procure sustenance from a nearby source rather than expending the effort to traverse the street in search of a superior dining experience. This decision was motivated by the fact that, in my opinion, their pizza failed to meet even the most basic standards of culinary excellence, falling short of both greatness and goodness. However, on two separate occasions, I did partake of their breakfast muffin, which far surpassed my expectations by boasting an optimal amount of grease that effectively conveyed its quality without overwhelming the palate. Additionally, the price point was remarkably reasonable, making it an eminently affordable option for those seeking a satisfying repast without breaking the bank.

"Although my culinary predilections do not necessarily incline me towards the rich and diverse cuisine of India, if I were to indulge in such gastronomical delights, this establishment would be my preferred venue. Moreover, their menu boasts an array of dishes that cater to the palates of those who do not partake in the consumption of meat, thereby rendering it an ideal destination for vegetarians and vegans alike. Additionally, the fare served here tends to be characterized by its bold and genuine flavors, which are often synonymous with the piquant and aromatic qualities that are inherent in Indian cuisine."

I procured a haircut and was thoroughly enamored with the result, yet I harbored some reservations regarding the salon's ambiance, as it seemed to exude an excessively contemporary aesthetic that did not necessarily align with my personal preferences. Nonetheless, I would venture to say that this establishment appears to be a suitable choice for individuals who are partial to cutting-edge hairstyles and hues.

I haven't tried many items or the lunch buffet yet, but from whatever I've had here, I would say its a decent option for Indian food. Being a vegetarian, its a nice thing to know that there is no chance of meat ending up in my food.

The sushi here is not bad, but not great. Service is also up to par. Sushi rock pails in comparison, however, to nearby restaurants, that have much better quality sushi, and hover around the same price. Though I may come here again for Korean food, I will not be returning for sushi.

We like to come in here to shop for clothes and luggage.  You can find some great deals in here.  The selection of luggage is pretty good too.  I've found some great carry on bags.

It can get really busy here, especially on weekends.  The best time to shop is mid-week in the middle of the day.  The employees here are usually friendly and the store is kept clean.

Return Factor - 60%

These state employees don't necessarily like their job, but they did a great job of helping me out. 

I just moved to the state and required a change of residency. I have no car here yet so a drivers license wasn't a necessity, but it would have been nice to have already. Unfortunately, proof of insurance specifically for this state is necessary to do that. State ID it was then. The lady at the front (I didn't grab her name) was very  kind and accommodating for my noob questioning of changing state ID's. The line, although around the room, moved very quickly.It's a lot faster than what I'm used to from Chicago/Illinois DMV lines.

Overall, if you have all your required paper work with you,  it is a fair experience got being a thing of necessity. Props to the kind lady in the beige cardigan up front!

We had the opportunity to indulge in a four-day sojourn at this establishment during the month of August in the previous year, and while it was not an unmitigated disaster, it failed to surpass our expectations in terms of overall quality and satisfaction. It is unlikely that we will opt to return to this hotel in the future unless they offer a drastically reduced rate, as it does not compare favorably to other establishments in the vicinity. The property itself is somewhat aged, which may contribute to its relatively lower price point, but its proximity to Mandalay Bay, where our friends were celebrating their nuptials, made it a convenient choice for our group of 23 individuals. Unfortunately, the tranquility of our weekend retreat was frequently disrupted by the sounds of construction, which seemed to persist throughout the entire weekend. The pool area, though adequate in size, lacked a certain aesthetic appeal compared to other hotels in the area. However, one of the highlights of our stay was the complimentary admission to Club LAX, which offered a welcome respite from the chaos of the casino floor. Additionally, the convenience of the tram system, which allowed us to easily access both Excalibur and Mandalay Bay without excessive walking, was a welcome amenity. Our room, though sufficient for two individuals, would have been somewhat cramped for any additional occupants. Furthermore, the variety of dining options within the food court left something to be desired. In conclusion, while the value proposition of this hotel may be attractive to some budget-conscious travelers, it falls short in delivering a truly satisfying experience for those seeking a higher level of comfort and luxury.

After experiencing an incongruous sequence of events involving being accommodated at three dissimilar tables, we opted to transition to the bar area, only to discover that the establishment was facing a dearth of their flagship beverage, lager. The revelation elicited incredulity, as it seemed implausible for a brewery to encounter such a shortage, especially considering the rudimentary nature of its production process. Notwithstanding this setback, the culinary offerings proved to be passable, albeit unremarkable, while the quality of service rendered by the staff fell short of expectations, owing to a lack of attentiveness and an apathetic demeanor. Furthermore, the demographic composition of the clientele consisted predominantly of elderly Caucasians, which seemed to permeate the atmosphere with an air of familiarity and stagnation, characteristic of the quintessential Glendale setting.

Very up-to-date hotel. Pleasant atmosphere. Make sure if you want 3G/4G access in your room that you stay on the west side. Pool has horrible hours IMHO. If you want wifi access, be prepared to spend a fortune.  Drinks at the pool are outrageously priced!  $17 for one drink (includes mandatory tip)

"Culinary indulgences are undoubtedly a source of pleasure, but it's essential to acknowledge that the provision of such gastronomic delights can sometimes be accompanied by an excessive duration of time, particularly in relation to the attainment of beverages and sustenance. Therefore, it's advisable to refrain from scheduling any subsequent activities for the remainder of the evening when partaking in the consumption of food and drinks at this establishment, as the prolonged waiting period may potentially encroach upon your plans."

"I had the privilege of attending my inaugural Panthers' game recently, and, despite my indifference towards the team, I must admit that I had an enjoyable experience. It appears that I am an anomaly in this regard, as the venue was filled to capacity with ardent supporters of the Panthers. This is quite remarkable, given the relatively brief tenure of the team in the league. 

The stadium's surroundings were teeming with enthusiastic fans engaging in pre-game festivities on the day of the event, creating a palpable atmosphere of excitement. However, during the remainder of the week, the stadium exudes an aura of solitude, standing vacant and unassuming just outside the city center. This paradoxical contrast is not unique to this particular stadium, as it is a common trait among many sports venues. 

In terms of the facilities, I was impressed by the modern amenities and services available. While the culinary offerings were unremarkable, consisting primarily of standard fare such as hot dogs, pretzels, and beverages, the prices were surprisingly reasonable. This affordability is a welcome aberration in the world of sports events, where exorbitant costs are often the norm. 

Moreover, I was pleased to observe that the fan base comported themselves in an orderly and convivial manner. The atmosphere was welcoming and appropriate for families, and ticket availability was plentiful. Thus, I would recommend taking advantage of the opportunity to experience a game at this venue."

"I have had the privilege of dining at this esteemed establishment on two separate occasions, and, unfortunately, the culinary offerings during both visits were merely mediocre, which, in my opinion, does not align with the elevated price point. Considering the exorbitant cost, the fare should be nothing short of exceptional. While the happy hour specials are moderately appealing, and the ambiance is undeniably impressive, I fail to perceive any compelling reason to frequent this venue, unless, of course, one seeks to demonstrate their financial prosperity. In contrast, a dining experience at Ocean Club offers a far more satisfying and memorable encounter, with cuisine that is truly remarkable. In light of these factors, I must conclude that this restaurant is not worth the excessive expense, and I would only consider returning if presented with a gift certificate."

Not a fan of the decor or the ambience as another reviewer mentioned. The music was way too loud and crappy; no way we would ever, ever eat in there. Take-out is a must.

The food is quite good, but does take a long time to get to you; over 10 minutes usually, without a line in front of you. We waited over 25 minutes one time, but it was a lunch rush. Still that was a long time to stand. It is more of a grilled wrap, than a burrito, as another review mentions. Tasty though.

No debit though. Seriously? It's 2011, get with the times Boyz. And the parking sucks; angled parking which you have to drive over a sidewalk to get to. Pro Tip: don't run over any pedestrians when backing out.

"Murphy's boasts an advantageous location, situated in a prime plaza proximal to the central district of Chandler, thereby presenting an excellent opportunity for growth and development. As an Irish pub, Murphy's fills a void in the local market, catering to a demographic that has been historically underserved in the region. Although the establishment itself is somewhat diminutive in size, the bar, which spans nearly the entire length of the suite, can accommodate a diverse clientele comprised primarily of adults ranging in age from their late 20s to their early 40s. Furthermore, Murphy's offers an extensive selection of beers available on tap, ensuring that each patron can find a brew that suits their individual taste preferences. The staff at Murphy's is amiable and attentive, making a concerted effort to provide quality service to all patrons, despite the occasional presence of live musical performances, which may occupy limited space within the venue. Notwithstanding, concerns regarding the longevity of Murphy's are mitigated by the recognition of its potential value to the surrounding community."

Drinks were great, but the bartender was rude! My party and I had already had a few drinks over at VBGBs, and we walked over to Willies. Once in, we went up to the counter to order some drinks. Having never been there before, my friend asked what drink tasted like chocolate, and the bartender snarked at her that \"Chocolate tasted like chocolate.\" When we tried to order the Call-a-Cab, he asked if we liked Robatussen. While I do appreciate being warned about the flavor of the drink, his attitude was pretty annoying. I've also been to the Myrtle Beach location, where the bartender was very sweet, offered to get us samples, and kept checking back in on us since we were seated at the bar. \n\nAs everyone else has warned, don't order Call-a-Cab by itself - it's hard to drink. But everything I have tried (Shock Treatment, Chocolate Thunder, Sour Apple) was delicious.

The buffet for Saturday night is 26.95 per person as of this writing. I would consider it a good deal at 20, but 27 is a bit too high. Some food was fantastic. The steak and salmon were very good, and the peanut butter chocolate cream pie was fantastic, rich but not heavy. One standout low was the so-called French onion soup, which was made with (I kid you not) reconstituted onions, almost identical to the grody ones McDonald's puts on its burgers. A cup of Lipton instant soup would have been better. I suppose that would be (barely) okay for a 7 dollar cheap ass buffet, but wholly unacceptable when dropping close to 30 dollars for a meal.  Fresh onions just aren't that expensive, and while a good French Onion soup takes a while to make, it's not labor intensive at all and an acceptable one should be easily in reach of any certificate holder from a culinary school. \n\nBasically, I'm reinforcing what others have said; what's good is very good, what's not good is downright bad.

"Prospective advantages encompassing the auditory indulgence in melodious tunes via radio, specifically highlighted by the artist Todd Rundgren during the evening repast, complemented by an abundance of attentive server assistance, a diverse array of draft beer options, delectable pulled pork and corn accompaniments, copious portions, and relative drawbacks including the regrettably subpar quality of hush puppies, excessively saline beef brisket, a macaroni and cheese dish characterized by a deep-fried puck with cheese sauce, minuscule quantity of vinegar sauce, and a costly total of $24 for a dual meat platter accompanied by a single beverage, aligning with the pricing standards of New York City."

here's the deal: if you come here expecting berthillon, you will be disappointed.  if you come here expecting very fine american style gelato, you'll probably leave very very happy.  \n\ni came somewhere in the middle---i recognize that i can't get a certain quality of gelato this side of the atlantic, but i was expecting a little bit more.  the choc was milk choc.  gelato ought to be made with dark choc.  i'm not sure i'd trust the fruity gelato, knowing it won't compare to france/italy.  but, i bet the nutella is great---i'll try that next time!

Stopped by here to get some early dim-sum. This place opened earlier than any other dim sum place in Vegas at 10:00am. All other places opened at 11am.

The quality of the dim sum was okay. For some reason, their har gow was small in comparison to what Im used to. The flavors were not bad. Prices were reasonable considering it was inside a casino, albeit the kinda run down Rio Casino.

I think I'll wait until 11am next time I'm hankerin for dim sum in Vegas....

Had them cater an event - food was very good, 2 types of quiche - excellent reviews from all meeting participants.  They did forget to bring a fruit platter - luckily I had ordered enough other food that it wasn't that big of a deal, but still not the best way to make an impression.  The delivery was also quite early - about 15-20 minutes before scheduled deliver time - earlier is always better than late, however with hot food, it creates a challenge...food was nicely prepped though.  I would likely order from them again, but will certainly be double checking the order upon arrival and will stress delivery time.

So, the good:  Plaintain and black bean mash, lump crab nachos, skinny margarita, chipolte ribs

The bad:  Service is hit or miss, enchiladas are meh, greens are very plain.

Note: The grilled corn used to be fabulous when served on the cob.  Too many people complete complained about it being messy so they now strip it from the cob.  It has lost something.  Let's worry less about being "clean" and more about good food!

Last evening's experience was somewhat disillusioning, as it failed to meet the expectations established by previous visits to this establishment. Despite the ambiance of the patio, which was enhanced by the presence of heaters and a live DJ, the culinary offerings and service fell short of satisfactory. Specifically, the food, while adequate, lacked the flavor and quality anticipated, with the mozzarella and tomato panini being particularly unimpressive. Furthermore, the service was subpar, with a waitress who exhibited bizarre behavior, including sarcastic and underhanded comments, spilling water on the table, and taking an inordinate amount of time to deliver the bill and process payment. It is conceivable that the waitress was experiencing a personal difficulty, but her conduct was nonetheless unprofessional and detracted from the overall dining experience. Notwithstanding this, Bomberos remains a popular venue, and future patrons would be advised to avoid the panini and exercise caution when interacting with the waitstaff.

One of the things I love about this place is the outdoor seating in the cooler months.  I also love the Bellini, Toasted Ravioli, and Rosemary-Chicken Pizza.

There IS room for improvement, however.  The takeout "system" they are using has caused me to go somewhere else more than once.  I don't think that having certain pickup "windows" for loyal customers is a sufficient way to reward them, especially at that price point.

Oregano's, you have a LOT of good competition (especially in Central Phoenix) so you may want to rethink the way you are treating customers.  I'm going to try you out again soon so we'll see how things go from there.

I ordered the seafood trio over risotto. I wish I would have ordered something else because my plate was 1/3 of the size of everyone else's but was more expensive than anyone else's. The salmon and shrimp tasted good but the rest was just ok. For appetizers we got the calamari and spinach artichoke dip. Those were really good. And for dessert a peanut butter mousse thing that was awesome. Overall it was just an ok experience. Don't hate it. Don't love it. If someone wanted to go I wouldn't object but I wouldn't go out of my way to go there.

Pizza is like sex.  Even if it's bad, it's still good.  That pretty much sums up how I feel about this place.  The pizza itself wasn't too bad.  I liked the garlic stuff they put on the crust.  I was disappointed that they screwed up my order and instead of pepperoni and garlic, I got pepperoni and olives.  They didn't even apologize or offer to give us a discount or anything.  We also tried their chicken fingers which were alright. Nothing special.  You could tell they were the cheaper ones.  For the price though, I'd go back again (2 med 2 topping pizzas, 5 fingers for $15).

"Consistent with the opinions articulated by previous patrons, this lodging option offers an affordable tariff, and it is essential to acknowledge that the quality of accommodations corresponds to the economic pricing. The advantageous aspect of this establishment is its prime location, situated directly in the center of the renowned Las Vegas Strip. Notwithstanding, even the premier penthouse failed to elicit my amazement, as I have had the pleasure of experiencing superior accommodations in the past. A unique attribute of this venue is the presence of dealer-impersonators, which provided an initial source of amusement until I noticed that the same performers were presented multiple times throughout the evening. Despite this observation, the experience remained enjoyable."

This was my first time here. 

I ordered online so i could take out my food. The online process was fast and easy. 
When I arrived the food was just being boxed up, right on time hot and fresh. Nice to know it was not sitting there for awhile getting cold and soggy. 

I ordered the Brisket burger. It is a cheese burger that comes with BBQ sauce, Brisket and bacon. There wasnt too much sauce which was nice, i hate having things smothered in sauce and making the bun soggy. The Brisket was okay, good flavor but could have been more tender. The burger itself was cooked well done. I prefer my burgers with some pink. I guess i should have indicated that online in the comment section while ordering. Overall the burger was just okay.

I also ordered a cup of chiken tortilla soup as a side. This was very good! packed with flavor, had a little kick. It was filled with shredded chicken and corn it was very good! I liked it better than the burger. 

Over all meal was good. I would come back and try other items.

I am somewhat of a self-proclaimed movie "snob" since I was a projectionist in college and helped run the campus cinema (one theater, but we showed everything).  I'm pretty particular how and where I watch my movies.  Don't get me wrong, I will watch a movie anywhere, but how the movie is delivered definitely contributes to the overall movie-going experience.

I know this place is fairly new ("new" to me since I don't find myself on this side of town too often), but I felt like the theater had aged too quickly - almost like it was smoking 10 packs of cigs a day.  Something about it didn't feel right... the bathrooms (had nice finishes, but not too terribly clean).  Maybe I just caught them on an "off" day, but an untidy theater is really off-putting to me.

The movie was over all was fine... the seats left something to be desired.  Stadium seating, but narrow rows so if you have some neighbors with small bladders like I did, your feet got a steping on.  I think I may just be spoiled with the trendy theaters around town that serve alcohol and food to you while you watch, but would I go out of my way to watch a movie here?  Probably not...

"PROS:  
    1. The burgers possessed an impressive magnitude, their copious proportions rendering them ostensibly indulgent, although their exorbitant cost could be perceived as somewhat prohibitive.  
    2. The onion rings exhibited a remarkable crispiness, their substantial girth contributing to their overall appeal.  
    3. The Black Milk Tea boasted an unparalleled delectability, its boba manifesting an unforgettable flavor profile.  
    4. The Kimchi burger represented the epitome of culinary excellence, its sublime taste elevating it to an unrivaled position among its peers.  
    5. The staff members displayed an unwavering commitment to hospitality, their affable demeanor fostering a welcoming ambiance.  
 CONS:  
    1. My Kiki burger and Ronin burger suffered from an unfortunate similarity in taste, their initial mediocrity giving way to a faint improvement midway through consumption.  
    2. The Oxtail Chili fries, despite their promising appearance, proved forgettable and arrived belatedly, long after our burgers had been devoured.  
    3. The bar counter and tables were subjected to a questionable cleaning method, employing a cloth redolent of mildew and eliciting concerns regarding hygiene.  
    4. The limited availability of individual bathrooms resulted in an extended waiting period, further emphasizing the need for additional facilities.  
    5. The prices charged for beer were deemed excessive, bordering on extortionate."

I'd revisit this establishment to sample alternative burger offerings or perhaps simply relish in the kimchi burger's excellence once more."

I've been to Mimis a few times and I have to say that they are fairly inconsistent.  Sometimes they are good, sometimes they are bad.  It seems as though breakfast is usually pretty good, but dinner seems to be lacking most of the time.

I went this past weekend for dinner.  I got the three course steak meal for $9.99.  I know, I should have known better, but I couldn't resist.  The salad was ok.  Then came the steak with mashed potatoes.  The steak was terrible.  It definitely had fake chargrilled marks on it.  Then came the "sundae" to finish off the meal, which turned out to be a scoop of vanilla ice cream with chocolate syrup on it.  

Again, I guess you get what you pay for.

Came for lunch. This is definitely one of the biggest buffets of the Vegas hotel choices. As soon as I walked in I was very impressed with the size and the choices available. Unfortunately, the more times I went back, the less impressed I was. The quality of the food is just not top quality. The place itself is not 4-star, but more like a cheap buffet ambiance. The price tag on the buffet reflects the compromised quality, but hey if you're looking for something a little bit cheaper than say the Wynn or Bellagio, and still want a great variety, then this could very well be your spot.

"This morning, I procured an assortment of filled croissants for my personal consumption and that of my two sons. While the quality of these flaky pastries was not optimal due to an excessive degree of crispiness, their inherent flavor remained palpable. It is worth noting that the establishment from which I acquired these croissants has undergone a change in ownership, resulting in a significant increase in prices without a commensurate enhancement in quality. In fact, the size and filling of these croissants have been observed to vary, occasionally appearing diminutive and sparse, respectively. Furthermore, the introduction of novel flavors has not contributed to an improvement in overall quality, leading me to surmise that a return to the original formula employed by the previous owner/baker(s) would be preferable. Consequentially, I have elected to procure alternative baked goods from a superior bakery located elsewhere, both to provide a greater variety of options and to obtain better value for my expenditure."

"How should I rate and review this establishment without appearing judgmental? Haha, I couldn't care less!!! Away from the children yet again... Rented a car, drove to Las Vegas, arrived in 3 1/2 hours at an average speed of 80 miles per hour. Arrived at 12:35 a.m. 

Met with two other couples, coerced them away from the Baccarat tables at Caesars Palace, and joined us for a drink at OG. 

The optimal approach is to contact O.G. and reserve a table; they will dispatch a limousine to transport you from your accommodations. In this manner, you avoid paying the cover charge. Purchase a Grey Goose bottle or another type of liquor bottle, and you'll receive a complimentary "Smirnoff" bottle. The total cost, including tax and gratuity, was $415.00. Other forms of entertainment would be funded individually. Hehehehe... We enjoyed a lovely booth adorned with sheer curtains. 

Oh my goodness, oh my goodness, oh my goodness, ah my goodness... Upstairs, the women explored independently to examine the male patrons. It was relatively deserted. Only a handful of women accompanied these incredibly attractive men. Their physiques were muscular, their abdomens prominent, their biceps bulgingâyikes! I felt somewhat uneasy since they began approaching us like fresh meat. We quickly retreated downstairs. 

When my spouse inquired, "Back so soon?" I laughed out loud. 

Well, we all treated ourselves to lap dances, some of which were enjoyable, others unpleasant, some genuine, and others fabricated. Utilize your creative abilities. 

I strongly suggest visiting in pairs of couples, as it will undoubtedly provide the most enjoyable experience, given its social nature."

"Although the sizable portions of pizza at this establishment may appear generous, the overall dining experience does not particularly warrant repeated visits, despite the palatable flavors; the prices charged do not seem to align with the culinary quality offered, thereby making it an inconsequential venue for frequent pizza consumption."

"It so transpired that I found myself within the confines of a shopping mall, specifically the renowned Galleria Mall in Las Vegas, during my leisurely sojourn in that city. Feeling somewhat exhausted and financially depleted due to my relentless pursuit of retail therapy, I opted to take a respite and partake in a casual repast at a nearby eatery. My thoughts were interrupted by an insistent craving for a delectable hamburger, which prompted me to seek out a suitable establishment capable of satiating my gastronomical yearnings. As fate would have it, a Red Robin restaurant happened to be situated within close proximity, thereby rendering it an ideal choice for my culinary endeavors. Admittedly, my initial reaction was tinged with incredulity, as there existed a plethora of exceptional dining options within the city limits, yet I chose to frequent a chain restaurant that was seemingly ubiquitous. However, my desire for a straightforward, uncomplicated dining experience ultimately prevailed, leading me to select this particular venue. Upon entering the premises, I was escorted to a cozy table positioned near a window, affording me an unobstructed view of the bustling mall. Following a cursory examination of the menu, I settled upon a basic, unadorned burger, dubbed the 'Keep it Simple' option. The server, cognizant of the brief delay, offered an apology and proceeded to take my order. The ensuing wait, though perceived as somewhat prolonged, did not unduly perturb me, as I was not particularly pressed for time. Ultimately, my patience was rewarded, as the arrival of my culinary creation elicited feelings of satisfaction and contentment, owing to both its generous proportions and satisfying taste. For those who harbor a penchant for superior burgers, a visit to the Red Robin located within the Galleria Mall is certainly worth considering. Furthermore, I must admit that I am eager to explore the breadth of their menu offerings and sample alternative burgers during a future visit. In conclusion, I would assign this establishment a rating of three out of five stars, thereby acknowledging its merits while simultaneously underscoring room for improvement."
Crepes station is top notch. Seafood was okay.  Kind of worn down in the last 5 years. A deep cleaning would be great for this whole seating area. Probibly backstage too.

I have to rate this location 1 star on the whole parking situtation as well as the ease of getting in & out of the parking lot.   As Bill noted, whoever designed the layout and flow here was a total moron. 

The location gets 5 stars - it is convienent to my work and home. 

I would give the service here about 3.5 stars, because the employees are normally pretty helpful here.  And if you go at 10 minutes 'til closing time when there is a big line, sometimes the employees are down-right entertaining! 

There is almost always a line when I go here - so if you are planning a visit, just plan on having a wait if you need full service.

We have passed by this place a million times on our way to Sushi Creek and finally this morning found some time to stop.  First impression was the place was very clean and after seating ourselves we ordered, Denver omlet and some kind of breakfast bowl.  Food was good, service was very good.  Waiter made sure drinks were refilled and food was to our liking.

I haven't been to old navy in awhile so I was okay with this store. First time it was pretty messy from all the Christmas shoppers but the second time was a little cleaner. They did have good sales for all ages.

Normally I'd give this joint 5 stars bcuz almost EVERYTHING IS *AWSM*
However- just went w/my moms & ewww what a disappointment :(
She had the fried chicken & me a basic burger - burger was ehh ok at best but the chicken was bad news bears!!! The corn bread muffin was delivered warm but turned to a rock shortly after, leading me to believe they nuked it ... The batter on the chicken was nasty & the chicken itself was ALLLL FAT! Even the mixed veggies were gross!
At $14 bucks this dish is NO BUENO!
If you find yourself @ BBD - try the Cali Benedict or the sweet cream waffle & finish w/a personal pie of your liking or the diners specialty - a  big bear bear claw ;) enjoy!

We selected this hotel based on the favorable reviews we perused on Yelp, and our expectations were largely met, as the room we occupied was clean and hospitable, boasting a comfortable bed and a charming balcony. However, we encountered an issue with the complimentary Wi-Fi, which failed to function properly during our stay, rendering it unreliable for our needs. Additionally, while we appreciated the thoughtful gesture of offering free snacks, we found it impractical to venture down to the lobby each time we desired a refreshment, given the inconvenience it posed. Furthermore, the nocturnal disturbance caused by the thin walls was somewhat bothersome, albeit comprehensible considering the festive atmosphere generated by the wedding celebration taking place concurrently. In contrast, the morning meal provided was quite satisfying, exuding a cozy and lively ambiance, although our interactions with the hotel staff were limited, thus precluding us from forming an opinion regarding their service. Ultimately, while we cannot say with certainty whether we would opt to stay here again, our brief sojourn was undoubtedly pleasant.

Agree with everyone about looks, place is beautiful!  Gym is sorta small and hot, but has a ton of cardio (treadmills and Xfit).  If you are coming, be SURE to ask what is still closed.  We came looking for poolside fun, and the pool is closed for at least another MONTH! I could see happy sunbathers at Bellagio from my room splashing around...Vdara you are a cruel Mistress!!  Service friendly, but rather inefficient...tried to get burned out bulb in bathroom fixed, no luck.  Coffee in room is Kcup, two free and more in mini bar, bring your own milk, only creamer.  Also found out that on-site restaurant (Silk Road) will no longer be open for dinner.  Call before you book for amenities...I think they are having some issues.

By the time we reached here, we have so much liquid in us.  We stopped and rejuvenated ourselves with whatever soda and water we can find while walking on the strip, well u want to make sure u are amply hydrated with that 105 degree heat.\n\nBut I still wanted to taste at least 3 float samplers, but the line was too long and unruly, ppl were darting in and out like crazy, so that was enough for me.  C'mon, kids, move along...perambulating, to the M & M World.

I arrived at this establishment in the company of several associates, with the intention of partaking in beverages prior to a group meal. However, I was taken aback by the fact that seating at the bar was not feasible sans the intervention of the hostess. Despite this initial setback, we opted to sample certain potations and fried potatoes, which, while palatable, were somewhat exorbitant in price, thereby precluding any fervent desire to return in the near future.

"Although the current state of the market may be satisfactory, it is essential to acknowledge that an augmentation of fresh produce would contribute positively to the overall quality of the merchandise available. Furthermore, the presence of friendly and accommodating vendors does not negate the necessity for a greater diversity of market-oriented establishments."
It's Burger King, there's not much to say, but this is a nice, clean location. Good service, 24 hours and they have my favorite drink of all time... VAULT soda on tap lol.

"The nomenclature of this culinary establishment is analogous to denominating a topographic location, such as 'The Pizza', 'The Burger', or 'The Taco'. However, upon gastronomical exploration, it becomes apparent that 'The Sushi' excels in terms of flavor, yet falls short in relation to portion size and cost. The interior ambiance is cozy and intimate, boasting a state-of-the-art four-screen television system reminiscent of a basketball arena. Were it not for the fiscal constraints and diminutive serving sizes, this eatery would readily qualify as a five-star sushi bar, given the meticulous preparation and scrumptiousness of the sushi and sashimi. Unfortunately, the tariffs associated with this dining experience surpass those of neighboring sushi restaurants, while the teriyaki dishes, in particular, are seemingly designed for rodents rather than humans. Notwithstanding, the staff maintained a courteous demeanor and extended an offer of complimentary hot tea or water to patrons awaiting takeout orders. Ultimately, a lukewarm endorsement is warranted, contingent upon an individual's financial indifference and moderate hunger levels."

"My affection for this diminutive establishment is profound. Edinburgh's commitment to preserving the traditional public houses in the city center is laudable, allowing future generations to revel in their timeless charm. The Rose St Brewery, in particular, exudes an endearing quaintness, with its upstairs lounge serving as my preferred area within the premises. The ambiance is further enhanced by carpeted floors and vintage photographs depicting the city's rich heritage adorning the walls, while a plaque proudly proclaims the pub's distinction as the Pub of The Year in 1985. \n\nUpon entering the establishment for a midday repast, I opted for a goat cheese salad, a deviation from my customary carnivorous inclinations, but one that seemed appealing due to its promised light and refreshing qualities. The dish arrived with two sizable chunks of goat cheese resting upon a bed of mixed greens and seasonal vegetables, complemented by a subtle dressing. When paired with a well-poured Guinness, the culinary experience was nothing short of perfection. While the staff's attentiveness left something to be desired, it is important to remember that, at its core, the Rose St Brewery remains a quintessential boozer, where one should not expect excessively formal service. Nonetheless, kudos are extended to the establishment for its efforts in maintaining a welcoming atmosphere, and one can only hope that it continues to thrive without succumbing to the pressures of modernity."

"Appears to harbor an inclination towards an 'O'-like experience, boasting an array of melodious compositions and gifted performers. Nonetheless, the narrative itself suffers from a dearth of coherence and lacks the seamlessness typically associated with a Cirque production."

It's hard to evaluate the merits of a coffee shop based on a french soda, but this place seems pretty good. It cost about $3 which is a bit pricey, but tasted good, and the syrups they use are good quality.\n\nI'd have to keep going here and grab a coffee to see how the place is on the whole.

"A diminutive, tranquil gaming establishment with a preference for minimal patronage and an emphasis on pristine, well-maintained equipment, complemented by an array of beverage and culinary options, thereby creating a low-traffic environment characterized by a scarcity of secondhand smoke, constitutes our optimal casino experience."
Grabbed a couple of dozen bagels and took to work.  Man they don't last long.  Bagels are good and the service is friendly.  They were real busy but make time to chat will working.

Cute little spot! Nice ambiance, ok food. The BF & I ate here for our birthday dinner over the summer. Honestly the only reason why I wanted to come here was because I was curious about the Matilda Wong.. it was even better than I imagined.. seriously drop what you're doing & get. it. NOW

We started off with the Sweet Potato Ravioli with the Gorgonzola Cream sauce. Four pieces of delicious ravioli, but I didn't really care for the creamy sauce- it was a little too rich & salty for my taste. LOVED the ravioli itself though. It was topped with walnuts & served with some bread. 

For entrees, BF got the Hanger Steak & I tried the Muffuletta Pizza without meat. BF liked the steak, but my pizza, while it looked good, was so damn salty! Must be because of the olive spread but jeez.. Nothing that another Matilda Wong couldn't remedy though :)

We split a dessert, but I don't remember what it was.. it had been a few months since we ate here. Guess that means it wasn't horrible, but also wasn't memorable :(

I would come here again & try a different entree.. perhaps the Farro Saute? I found the prices to be pretty reasonable: $12 for ravioli, $12 for the pizza, & I think around $20 for the steak, probably under $10 for the dessert .. & $11 for each mini pitcher of the Wong.. hell yeah

24/7 Local video poker sports bar, everything you'd expect. It seems like I'm always just stopping in for a cheap breakfast, the Pt's Platter is way better than its Ihop and Denny's counterparts and the waitresses are much friendlier. Unfortunately, I always get sucked into the video poker machines and end up leaving with a full tummy and an empty wallet.

I went there to celebrate my wife's completion of second year dental school from UNLV. Interior design is nice and upscale and hostess was very friendly. We ordered Steak Special for two and we had to wait about 20 min to get our plate. It was ok. However, The waiter was really busy so he did not take care of us. He did not even refill my water so I had to take my wife's water and drank. compare to the price and atmosphere, service was not that great.

A succinct update subsequent to my maiden commercial excursion in excess of eight months has necessitated an augmentation of concerns pertinent to my lactational responsibilities, which now involve a heightened level of scrutiny at security checkpoints. Specifically, at 5:00 AM on a Friday, which tends to be somewhat congested due to the influx of business travelers returning to the Eastern Seaboard, I encountered a peculiar scenario wherein each of my transparent containers were subjected to a meticulous examination by means of a sophisticated device designed to detect traces of explosive material. Fortunately, the TSA representative displayed remarkable courtesy and clarity in elucidating the procedure and potential consequences, thereby alleviating any apprehensions I may have harbored. Notwithstanding the substantial quantity of luggage requiring screening, the entire process was completed within a mere five minutes.

Terminal 3's Delta sector, while relatively limited in its offerings, does feature a few establishments that cater to early risers, such as Starbucks and Wendy's. However, the queues tend to be rather lengthy, particularly during peak hours.

Following the completion of renovations, locating the shuttle service for rental cars has become significantly less arduous. Furthermore, I was pleasantly surprised by the relatively brief waiting period at 12:30 AM, despite the considerable number of individuals who had arrived later than anticipated. It is worth mentioning that the shuttles themselves often exude a strong fragrance reminiscent of soap-based air fresheners, which can be somewhat overwhelming. Nevertheless, this is arguably preferable to an atmosphere tainted by unpleasant odors.

In conclusion, #Yelp365 - 169/365 serves as a testament to the unforeseen challenges and experiences that punctuate the existence of a nursing mother embarking upon commercial ventures.

If you happen to be inebriated to the extent that your cognitive faculties are significantly impaired, resulting in boisterous, rowdy, or disoriented behavior, and you are seeking a culinary establishment that can accommodate your current state, then this particular venue may be an ideal choice for satiating your gastronomical desires. It is not uncommon for patrons who have indulged in excessive alcoholic beverages to experience memorable moments within these premises, as they endeavor to regain a semblance of sobriety amidst the aromatic ambiance of freshly baked pizza, which, although palatable, may not be the most advisable option for consumption during the daylight hours due to its rich, artery-clogging characteristics, yet somehow manages to tantalize the taste buds in a manner that is particularly satisfying when consumed at an ungodly hour such as 1:45 am.

"Pros: The eatery boasts a relaxed and convivial atmosphere, which is further enhanced by its prime location within the luxurious Cosmopolitan complex. The interior design is a unique blend of lucha libre and Las Vegas elements, featuring striking red lamps suspended from the ceiling and video screens displaying images of renowned Mexican artist Frida Kahlo and influential Chinese leader Mao, among others. \n\nCons: While the menu offers an extensive array of options, the dishes themselves are somewhat disappointing. Particularly considering the restaurant's laid-back setting, the prices are slightly elevated for what essentially amounts to a selection of fried rice and tacos. Employing a tapas-style service model, multiple orders are necessary for sharing, which may not necessarily constitute a cohesive fusion of Chinese and Mexican cuisine, but rather a menu showcasing unremarkable renditions of each."

What to do on Christmas Eve eve... oh, Carolina Place Mall is open 'til 11pm? Let's go wander around there and watch the masses scramble for gifts.

When I need to make a mall trip, this is not at the top of the list for me. I rank Northlake, SouthPark and Concord all above it. One: anything that involves 485 does not make me pleasant. Two: The store selection here is just kind of meh. Three: it's a pain to get in and out of this place.

Now I will say this, there is an H&M on the way which could be a game changer for this place. It will be great for people on the south side of town since currently there is just the one location up at Northlake. Until SouthPark gets one, this one will do for our side of town.

Typical anchor stores here. I don't want to say that it feels outdated... I don't think that's the right description. Maybe old school vibe is more accurate.

If I'm near this area and need a mall, I'll venture here. But with so many better options in the Charlotte area, it's definitely not a must-go shopping destination on my list.

Came here for brunch before a Cardinals' game. Food was good and drinks very generous. Love that they have the bus to the games. Very nice that everyone could enjoy their time and nobody had to worry about driving.

"The culinary offerings were utterly delectable, however, their prices were rather prohibitive. Our attire, comprising of casual garments such as denim trousers, shorts, and sweatshirts, starkly contrasted with the sartorial elegance of the surrounding patrons, who primarily consisted of mature individuals aged sixty-five and above. Despite our youthful appearance, the staff extended courteous hospitality towards us, and we thoroughly enjoyed the breathtaking panorama that the establishment offered."

This club represents the pinnacle of contemporary nightlife in Las Vegas, boasting an impressive magnitude that has captured the attention of revelers and enthusiasts alike; however, my personal experience did not live up to the lofty expectations generated by its grand reputation. The layout of the club presents a formidable challenge for individuals, particularly women who must navigate numerous flights of stairs while donning high heels, which proved to be a considerable encumbrance throughout the evening. The central hub of activity within the club, located at the summit of the stairwell, hosts prominent performances and DJ sets, yet the configuration of the space itself proved unsatisfactory due to the presence of rows of tables positioned along the perimeter, thereby obstructing the view for the majority of patrons. Moreover, the balcony area, replete with tables, failed to provide an optimal vantage point for observing the featured entertainment. It appears that the club's design places a premium on coercing clientele into procuring tables, which may not align with the preferences or financial means of all potential visitors. In contrast, Lights emerges as a superior alternative for live events, earning my unwavering endorsement.

I'd really wanted to like this place, but it just isn't happening. Family has eaten here several time and we've had excellent meals (burgers in particular), but not consistently. There is always something wrong: burger over cooked, cold food, orders not correct. If a restaurant is going to charge the higher prices, I expect consistently good food and service - not hit and miss.

"I thoroughly enjoy the ambiance of this establishment, it possesses a distinctly quaint and charming 'little main street' quality that is reminiscent of a bygone era. The culinary offerings are quite satisfactory, with prices that are eminently reasonable and affordable. However, I must caution that the pace of service is somewhat leisurely, so it may not be the optimal choice for individuals who are pressed for time or have a particularly tight schedule to adhere to."

"I received exceptional service, as they meticulously ensured that I was properly fitted with the ideal bicycle, following an unfortunate incident involving incorrect sizing from another Landis store. They dedicated considerable time to assisting me in selecting the appropriate footwear, and provided comprehensive responses to my numerous queries regarding my first road bike purchase, despite some reservations I had regarding their unconventional methods. Although I have yet to utilize their repair services, I am eager to assess their proficiency in that regard once I bring in my dilapidated mountain bike for maintenance."

"The performance was ostensibly satisfactory, as the comedic individual executed merely four daredevil feats to substantiate his proficiency, while expending the majority of the time engaging in banter. The spectacle prompted curiosity regarding the methodology behind his cognizance of such information. Upon culmination of the production, he divulged the winning lottery numbers to the entire assemblage, evoking amusement and intrigue. Notwithstanding, I wouldn't attend another presentation, as I possess a predilection for novel experiences and endeavors, and thus, it is imperative for me to progress forthwith."

"I unequivocally adore this venue for breakfast, as it offers an unparalleled array of options that cater to my morning palate. I shall undoubtedly revisit this establishment when I next find myself in Las Vegas. \n\nRegarding dinner, I must express my disappointment with the menu, despite its price point of $108 for two individuals. While it boasts an impressive seafood selection, including crab, my expectations were not entirely met. In comparison, Mesa Grill, situated within Caesar Palace, provides a more satisfying dining experience for a similar cost."
Not a huge fan. It was okay at best. I've been to a few of these types of places around town and this one was average.

I was excited when this breakfast restaurant opened up in my neighborhood as I love to go out for breakfast almost everyday.

I have eaten there 3 times now but I only order 1 thing on the menu which I do enjoy quite a bit because their other items are a little unusual for me.

I went to eat there again yesterday and I was very sorry to see they have removed all side items off their menu. So I cannot order an omelet or 2 scrambles eggs with bacon, or a side of toast. Its one of the nine items or nothing. That does not work for me so that is why i have given this restaurant 3 stars. I hope they reconsider offering the basic breakfast items or I will probably not be back.

This establishment represented my second venture to indulge in the culinary delights of tapas while situated in the city of Las Vegas. The gastronomical offerings were merely adequate, with the exception of the paella, which proved to be a highlight of the dining experience. The duration of time allocated for the preparation of the meal was approximately 40 minutes, however, the delay was deemed acceptable considering the novelty of the dish. 

The hospitality displayed by the staff, ranging from the initial greeting upon entry to the attentive service provided by the wait staff and management, was truly commendable. Notwithstanding, the tariff associated with the consumables listed on the menu was, in my opinion, exorbitant, even when juxtaposed with the elevated prices customarily encountered within the Las Vegas Strip. This factor served as the primary deterrent against a potential return visit.

It is worth mentioning that alternative destinations offering tapas on the Vegas strip provide a superior value and variety, rendering a revisit to this particular venue unnecessary. The ambiance of the restaurant was quite pleasant, boasting an airy and well-lit atmosphere, accompanied by a bar section. The level of noise was moderate, and the premises were well-maintained, with the staff demonstrating efficiency in clearing tables upon completion of meals.

In conclusion, although this eatery presented an acceptable dining experience, there exist superior options within the vicinity, thereby diminishing the likelihood of a future visit.

This eatery is characterized by inconsistency, with the quality of service ranging from mediocre to inadequate. The culinary offerings, while diverse, are often unpredictable in terms of taste and texture, specifically regarding the chicken fried rice, which can be excessively oily or unpleasantly dry. Furthermore, the orange chicken dish is frequently overcooked, resulting in an unpalatable chewiness that does not contribute to a satisfying dining experience. While the prices are reasonable, they do not justify the variable quality of the food. In conclusion, this establishment does not rank among the superior options for Chinese cuisine in North Phoenix.

A luncheon in commemoration of a colleague's departure led me to this establishment, whereupon I was less than enthused by the precursory popover bread, possessing an unmistakable ovum flavor that nearly satiated my gastronomical inclinations, yet thankfully, my fungi and gruyere panini proved to be delectable and of generous proportions, accompanied by an abundance of fries, and ultimately, all patrons relished their culinary selections, furthermore benefiting from a minor rebate extended to financial institution staff members, constituting an added advantage.

I was gratified to discover this eatery within my lodging establishment, as it afforded me the convenience of not having to venture outdoors, particularly given the lateness of the hour. The bar area, however, presented a surprising spectacle, characterized by a greater number of patrons than I would have anticipated for a Monday evening. My culinary selection for the evening consisted of gnocchi, which I noticed was incorrectly spelled on the menu as "gnocci." Prior to bringing this to the attention of the waiting staff, I was struck by the peculiar manner in which the server pronounced the dish, specifically employing the phonetic rendering "knock-y." This led me to ponder whether she might also refer to her place of employment as "Bigelow Grill-e," a supposition that somewhat diminished the perception of refinement associated with my dining experience. Notwithstanding this, I found the overall atmosphere to be agreeable, with the exception of the dense cigarette smoke that permeated the bar area. Furthermore, I found myself perplexed by the enigmatic statement "Bigelow is serving innovative and imaginative interpretations of ethnic Pittsburgh classics," a phrase that piqued my curiosity and left me eager to acquire further insight from local individuals familiar with the culinary landscape of Pittsburgh.

"The early riser does not necessarily secure the prized vermiculate at Marche Atwater, particularly on a frigid winter Sunday morning when the majority of establishments remain unopened, with only a select few merchants offering their wares; however, fortune smiled upon us, enabling us to procure an assortment of delectable pastries at Boulangerie Premi\u00e8re Moisson, which served as an excellent initiation to the day's culinary pursuits. As the clock struck 8:30 a.m., a gradual influx of vendors began to populate the market, showcasing their fresh produce and artisanal goods. Marche Atwater, though smaller in scale than anticipated, still presented an array of options for those seeking gastronomical delights, although the absence of outdoor vendors during the winter season was palpable. In hindsight, a visit to Jean-Talon might have proven more fruitful."

Since I'm a lover for lobster rolls, I decided to come here for lunch.  My husband and I decided to split a combo.  The lobster roll was ok.  I didn't like that the meat was chopped in tiny pieces (reminds me of canned tuna).  I also didn't like how the slit of the bun was just barely half way through the bread.  It makes me feel like they're trying to save on lobster meat.  With each bite we made, the meat fell out of the bun.  The chowder fries were ok.  Nothing to rave about.  For over $20, I was pretty dissatisfied with the portions I was given.

I chill at White Castle 'cause it's the best
But I'm fly at Fat Burger when I'm way out west!

So the lyrics led me to this place but I must say it didn't live up to the hype.  The burger wasn't terrible, but I've had better.  WHAT-A-BURGER beats the hell out of it.

The burger patty reminds me of the patty at Freddy's Frozen Custard, Culver's, and Steak and Shake.  I had mine built with the default config which includes sweet relish.  I knew that going into it and thought i would try it.  It was a mistake - just plain weird.  Hold the relish next time.

Good & decent lunch specials! However, I had to knock a couple stars because waitress came to our table at least 3 times & did not bother to fill water glasses. And we had to remind her for our roll that comes with lunch entre\u00e8! Fish was ok, not that fresh!

"The Gin Mill, one of the numerous stops along the Light Rail Bar Crawl, presented itself as the most unrefined and dilapidated establishment, boasting an array of battered chrome fixtures and worn wooden accents, a bathroom that appeared to be in dire need of a thorough sanitizing with a flamethrower, and a cacophony of deafening music that seemed to reverberate throughout the cramped space. As I settled into my perch at the bar, sipping on my frothy beverage, I couldn't help but observe the youthful patrons who were enthusiastically dancing to the DJ's rhythmic selections on a makeshift stage, their exuberant energy palpable even through the haze of alcohol. This unique vantage point afforded me the opportunity to witness firsthand the remarkable efficiency and warm hospitality of the bartenders, who deftly navigated the crowded bar with ease, expertly juggling the rapid distribution of libations and the retrieval of discarded vessels with aplomb. Impressed by their proficiency, I took note of the burly bouncer stationed at the entrance, diligently inspecting identification documents to ensure the safety and well-being of the patrons within. Furthermore, a convenient taxi stand situated outside the establishment offered a practical solution for those who had indulged in excess, providing a means of safe transportation for those who required it. Despite my limited consumption of four drinks over a five-hour period, I opted to utilize the nearby Light Rail station to facilitate a swift return to my vehicle, allowing myself ample time to regain my sobriety during the brief journey."

I have been thoroughly enjoying Dos Chandler for an extended period of time, having previously been content with merely consuming their Negra Modelo and Dos X; however, I have recently developed a penchant for savoring their delectable, viscous chimi, which I would highly recommend to any individual. Their quesadillas are truly exceptional, reaching a pinnacle of culinary excellence that is challenging to surpass. While I am employed in a New Mexican style kitchen, I believe that Dos Chandler should expand their selection of Mexican beers on tap and provide a more extensive assortment of tequila options. Unfortunately, their frozen margaritas fail to impress, and the tables tend to be unpleasantly adhesive upon my arrival, indicating a lack of consistent maintenance. Furthermore, I have noticed a high turnover rate among servers and bartenders, leading me to question the quality of management support on the floor. Despite these shortcomings, I award Dos Chandler three stars, primarily due to the subpar cleanliness, limited beer selection, and uninspired tequila offerings, all of which are aspects that a Mexican restaurant should strive to improve upon.

Ok I guess...Ate there this morning about 8:45. Sat down, was acknowledged with a nod and be with you in a minute...but was closer to 7 or 8. Ordered \"the handful\" which has 2 eggs, 2 pancakes, potatoes, and 2 bacon. Wanted to trade bacon for veggies but was told it would be $1 more even though on side items, the bacon cost more than the veggies...go figure.  Make the customer happy and he'll come back tomorrow, don't and he won't.\nIt was decent, can't complain too much, but can't give thumbs up either.

"Our August excursion culminated in our arrival at this esteemed establishment via taxi, a significantly more economical mode of transportation compared to the alternative shuttle service. Upon our arrival, the courteous Bell-Man expedited our check-in process by assuming responsibility for our luggage, thus obviating the necessity for us to endure an extended wait in the luggage claim area. The duration of our check-in process was approximately thirty to forty-five minutes on a Sunday, a time frame that we found to be quite reasonable given the influx of guests during the peak travel season. We had the pleasure of residing in the recently refurbished Grand Tower, which boasted an array of amenities designed to enhance our comfort and convenience, including a plush king-sized bed, an expensive yet functional mini refrigerator, and an impressive upgraded view that we thoroughly enjoyed during our anniversary celebration. Unfortunately, our spa experience was slightly marred by the presence of a nude female patron within the women's hot tub area, which engendered a sense of unease and discomfort due to the potential health risks associated with shared facilities. Moreover, we would like to caution prospective guests against utilizing the pool facilities, as we unfortunately contracted a persistent bacterial infection on our legs that required four weeks of antibiotic treatment to resolve."

This is the Grand Lux Cafe situated within the premises of the esteemed Venetian resort. It is worth mentioning that there exists an alternative location of the same establishment in the Palazzo, however, according to local patrons, the quality of service and culinary offerings at this particular branch are deemed superior. For the sake of comparison, it is pertinent to note that the author has had the pleasure of visiting another Grand Lux Cafe situated in the Beverly Center of Beverly Hills; and while both establishments share certain commonalities in terms of their ambiance and gastronomical offerings, this specific location boasts the unique distinction of being open for business on a twenty-four hour basis.

Upon arriving with a sizable contingent of approximately fifteen individuals, the group was able to secure seating arrangements without incident, despite the fact that it was peak dining time and no prior reservations had been made (it is customary to reserve tables at least two hours in advance).

The author and a companion opted to share a pizza pie adorned with sausage, pepperoni, and mushrooms. While the dough was somewhat overly soft and difficult to handle without the toppings breaking apart, the flavor of the crust itself was quite satisfying. As a result, the author and her companion found themselves consuming the crust of each slice, leaving behind the toppings.

It is important to note that the menu at Grand Lux Cafe features an extensive array of culinary options, which bears a striking similarity to that of Cheesecake Factory, given that the two establishments share a common affiliation. Nonetheless, it is recommended that patrons exercise caution when selecting items from the Asian-inspired section of the menu, as the authenticity of such dishes may be subject to debate.
