I was somewhat skeptical regarding a cafe that publicizes coffee that lacks the characteristic flavor profile associated with coffee, yet my reservations were partially alleviated upon sampling their espresso, which demonstrated a level of quality that surpassed my expectations, although it failed to elicit an exceptional degree of enthusiasm within me, and its overall quality was inferior to that of Starbucks' offerings.

"Gastronomical excellence notwithstanding, the sluggishness and inattention exhibited by the waiting staff at this establishment significantly diminishes the overall dining experience. My previous visit, which occurred almost precisely a year ago, was marred by an analogous set of circumstances, wherein the manager demonstrated commendable attentiveness while the servers displayed an utter lack of concern towards our needs. The elapsed time between ordering and consumption stretched to an unacceptable extent, warranting my personal intervention to inquire about the delay not once, but twice. Notwithstanding these issues, the culinary offerings did indeed prove satisfying. Thus, if one prioritizes gustatory pleasure over promptness of service and the demeanor of the staff, Kona Grill may still be a suitable choice."

My partner and I traversed into Phoenix via aerial transportation last week during the festive season and elected to partake of a meal at this establishment prior to proceeding to our familial gathering.   I must admit that I was rather taken by the culinary offerings and the overall atmosphere of the restaurant.  
I opted for a delectable burger accompanied by an array of tantalizing accoutrements and it was cooked to perfection.  While I could have indulged in a greater quantity of fries accompanying my burger, I likely did not require them from a nutritional standpoint.  
It must be noted that the visual presentations of 80's hair bands that were being projected within the dining area struck me as somewhat peculiar.  
In the event that I find myself in Phoenix once again, I would not hesitate to return to this eatery and indulge in their gastronomical delights.

This is exactly what I was looking for in a hotel during my one night stay in Pittsburgh. Close to the city, but far enough out to get free parking and a reasonable rate (under $100).

The room was fairly small, but I was only planning on sleeping in it. It was clean so I couldn't ask for much more. The people at the front desk were very friendly too.

If I go back to Pittsburgh, I will absolutely stay here again.

Went to Rigatonys tonight with my sister and niece. Niece and I shared manicotti. It was decent enough, not super fabulous but not the worst I've ever had. My sister had the Mahi special with asparagus and quinoa pasta. She loved it. There was a creamy dill sauce on the fish. The salad was also awesome- nice portion of salami, cheeses, olives, pepperocini etc.. We tried spumoni for dessert and that was legit and a nice portion as well. Bryce was our server and was very nice, knowledgeable and had everything out in a timely manner. He told us about the extra charge for split plate. The meal came with bread as well. It was an overall great experience and we will be back.

I came here on a Saturday for lunch and it was packed so we took our food to go. By the time I was able to eat my torta ahogada, it had already soaked up all the spicy sauce it was swimming in and was soggy and quickly disintegrating. Normally I'm pretty tolerant to spicy foods but all I could taste was spicy. My friend got 3 fish tacos, which were super tiny. He was still hungry afterwards so he had san other full meal. Overall, it did not live up to all the good reviews I kept reading about on Yelp.

"Culinary experiences can be gratifying on occasion, albeit briefly, when the ambiance is revamped to create an atmosphere of sophistication. However, during our recent visit, the service was subpar, specifically with regard to the eggs, which were overcooked and lacked the desired doneness. Furthermore, the demeanor of certain servers bordered on impertinence, epitomized by their reluctance to acknowledge our presence, let alone address our concerns. Notwithstanding, the management's indifference towards our grievances was palpable, as they prioritized the interests of unremunerated patrons partaking in recreational activities over those of paying customers. Perhaps the establishment could benefit from the introduction of a poker club, whereupon we, as patronizers, might be inclined to voice our dissatisfaction and effectuate improvements in the quality of service."

I've made plenty of bad decisions here.\n\nHave you ever been somewhere where it means nothing, but somehow, means everything? I like coming to Maz. They don't have a good selection of beer. Or drinks. They don't have good pool tables. There are plenty of shady things that go on here. But still I find myself here every once in a while; generally I'm in a really crappy mood, or I'm feeling to good to go home and too mashed up to go anywhere else.

The service was a bit slow but the food made up for it. The sushi was delicious and the burger was unique and flavorful. We also got the mixed delux fries basket which was phenomenal. I would definitely come back.

Moderate place to stay in a great location - so close to the conveniences of the mall, movie theatre, etc. and just 10-15 minutes from the main shopping and tourist bits. Also just a couple blocks from the cute and trendy but relatively calm and tourist-free cafes on Broughton Street. Within the hotel there's a nice lounge with a fireplace to spend time in with a beer, cocktail, or coffee. And a full restaurant if you're feeling lazy. \n\nAs for the room itself, the walls are quite thin so you can hear people coming and going quite easily, and the wifi, though free is slow as a snail, maybe slower. Not a place to spend much time, but a fine place to return to after a day of exploring.
Came in. Waiter was alright. Gave me a stair like I didn't know what I was doing. He gave mediocre service. I'm full

Qdoba is merely adequate, as it employs a similar concept as Chipotle Grill, but regrettably, the culinary offerings fail to impress, lacking an indispensable element that would compel repeat visits. Additionally, the uninspired ambiance, characterized by the utilization of concrete floors and metallic tables, contributes to a chilly and somber atmosphere, even during the peak summer months.

I recently went to this restaurant to celebrate my coworkers birthday. I have never had any problems with Applebee's; however, this particular time, I ordered the shrimp and spinach salad and found some type of plastic in my salad. Both the manager and waitress apologized for the incident and were very quick to fix the problem. I was offered a new salad (which I took to go because my coworkers had finished their meal already) and when the food was brought out to me, the manager came back again to apologize. My meal was also free. I gave them a 3 because of how both the manager and waitress quickly fixed the problem. I don't think it was their fault but rather the fault of the cooks who were preparing the foods. My salad was also very good!

I normally come every Sunday during football season. Today was a spur of the moment decision. Sat down to my favorite Asian bartender in the US. She recommend the wings which were phenomenal. Also ordered the Kobe burger. Took it home, opened the box and found two ROTTEN tomatoes which smelled worse than organic fertilizer and just as mushy. Took it back to get a new one, where I was told it was normal for that kind of tomato to smell, look, and feel like a decomposed body. This asst manager clearly has no idea what food or customer service looks like. Luckily the GM was there to smooth things over. If it weren't for my bartender, I would never set foot back in this place again.

"Horchata, a beverage of unparalleled flavor and delight, has the propensity to elicit expressions of immense pleasure from those who partake in its consumption. Moreover, the presence of familiar countenances within the establishment contributes to an atmosphere of comfort and conviviality. Furthermore, the culinary offerings, specifically the vegetarian burrito and breakfast burrito, are of exceptional quality and generously portioned. However, it is worth noting that while the prices are reasonable, the guacamole, a crucial component of any respectable Mexican dish, falls short of expectations, thus necessitating further refinement."

I go to this facility usually 3 nights per week at about 2am and love it. Its jot crowded at all, usually having about 3-5 people in it. I can have the basketball court to myself I wanted and move freely through workout stations.

Upon initial inspection, this establishment appeared to conform to the conventional characteristics of a tourist trap, given its location within the historic district and its assortment of traditional Mexican knick-knacks. However, upon further examination, the prices were discovered to be reasonable and not exorbitant, as previously assumed. A vibrant straw sombrero was acquired for a mere $5, and various other items within the store were observed to possess price tags that were similarly fair and affordable. This store serves as a veritable treasure trove for those seeking to create an unforgettable festive experience, offering an extensive array of items tailored specifically to the celebration of Dia de Muertos, including but not limited to colorful masks, plates, cups, and even ornaments for garden decor. Unfortunately, the staff members present within the store did not exhibit a warm or welcoming demeanor; however, the overall ambiance of the store was well-maintained, ensuring a satisfying shopping experience for patrons. The vast selection of trinkets available guarantees that customers will undoubtedly depart the premises with a sense of contentment and satisfaction.

We have been going to PP for over 17 years. Dr Chiles and Dr Salek have been my children's doctors from the beginning. We have seen a lot of faces come and go. Now that PP has merged with  another very large group, it just isn't the same. I still love our doctors and that is why we stay as my children are older now and need less frequent visits. This office just doesn't have the same family friendly feel it once used to.

Patience is required as they take their sweet time and it isn't even busy. It's been 30 minutes and I don't know that they'll be done soon. I would come back because it's cheap but definitely not during 'rush' hour.

"This establishment is truly a behemoth; its gargantuan proportions are simply staggering. Attempting to navigate the vast expanse of the casino from the sidewalk entrance on the strip is an exercise in futility, as the labyrinthine layout and contradictory signage will inevitably lead to disorientation and confusion. Despite its impressive grandeur, the hotel's age is beginning to show in various aspects, with remnants of its former Wizard of Oz/Hollywood motif now conspicuous only by their absence. A pervasive verdant hue envelops everything, creating an ambiance that is both surreal and overwhelming."

Just wanted to update. Manager contacted us. Was willing to give full refund or have the top installed for free. Seems there was a communication issue. Issue was resolved, even kept the truck box cover. Did have an issue, but company did resolve in a timely manner and apologized for the miscommunication

"Although I would rate Dolce a mere 3.5 stars if given the opportunity, I must admit that the ambiance of this establishment is quite inviting and conducive to a relaxed dining experience. However, my culinary exploits at this location have been limited to a few select appetizers, specifically their delectable hummus and crispy pita chips. Yet, based on the opinions of others, I may consider elevating my assessment after partaking in their more comprehensive menu offerings. As an ardent devotee of vinous delights, I find myself drawn to this wine bar, eager to indulge in a rich, full-bodied glass of red wine while engaging in lively discourse with companions. Unfortunately, my experiences with the service staff have been somewhat mixed, with some members exhibiting a certain aloofness or reserve in their interactions. Nevertheless, such sentiments are merely anecdotal and do not detract significantly from the overall appeal of the venue. Additionally, I lament the meager selection of wines available, a sentiment shared by a previous reviewer. In light of these factors, I would still recommend paying Dolce a visit, particularly if you find yourself in close proximity to the NoDa neighborhood."

We halted our journey at this establishment for an interval of recreation and relaxation during the evening hours, as I was feeling rather indolent and it was in close proximity to my place of employment. As it transpired, they offered a satisfactory happy hour with diverse potable specials, half-priced chosen appetizers, and a select two culinary delights special that persisted from opening until closing for the modest sum of $6.99. I opted for the Tortilla soup and cheese enchiladas, which proved to be palatable and satisfying, accompanied by a side of rice and beans. Our server exhibited exceptional hospitality and I regret not committing her name to memory, but after indulging in a few of the happy hour Margaritas, my cognitive faculties were somewhat impaired.

"My culinary excursion to this establishment was predicated upon a glowing endorsement from an acquaintance who vehemently asserted that this was, without a doubt, the optimal pizza proffered within the city limits of Las Vegas. While I find such a claim to be somewhat dubious, given the city's limited reputation for exceptional pizza establishments, I decided to indulge my taste buds and form my own opinion. As a lifelong devotee of New York-style pizza, my standards are unwaveringly high, and I find it challenging to believe that any other region can surpass the culinary prowess of the Big Apple. Thus, I embarked upon this gastronomical adventure with a healthy dose of skepticism.  

Upon perusing the menu, I noticed they were offering a special promotion, wherein all pizzas were being offered at a fifty percent discount. Seizing the opportunity to sample their wares without breaking the bank, I opted for a large pie adorned with pepperoni, sausage, and black olives. Alas, my expectations were not entirely met, as the quality of the pizza left something to be desired. Specifically, the crust lacked the requisite crispness that I have come to expect from a truly exceptional pizza. Furthermore, the sausage and pepperoni toppings contributed to an unfortunate sogginess that permeated the entire pie. Admittedly, the crust exhibited some promise, but it was not enough to salvage the dish from its overall mediocrity.  

In conclusion, while this establishment may lay claim to being the best pizza in Las Vegas, it falls short of the lofty standards that I have established for truly outstanding pizza. My culinary journey, regrettably, did not culminate in the discovery of a gastronomical masterpiece."

"On multiple occasions, I have partaken in culinary indulgences within the confines of both the dining room and hibachi grill at this eatery, and I must say that my experiences have been nothing short of exceptional, particularly when it comes to the quality of the fare and the captivating performances put on by the chefs manning the grill. However, my encounters in the dining room have been somewhat less than satisfactory, marred by prolonged waits for my meals, which have consistently exceeded thirty minutes, despite the staff's acknowledgment of these delays and their attempts at compensation, such as offering complimentary edamame to waiting patrons. It appears that there is a dearth of sushi chefs and/or wait staff, resulting in an inadequate level of service that falls short of my expectations. While I would greatly desire to bestow upon this restaurant a more favorable rating, I fear that I cannot do so in good conscience until such time as I witness a marked improvement in the overall quality of service provided throughout the establishment."

Took my commuter in for an oil change and was very pleased with the cost and speed that it got done.  The location is perfect as well to just take a walk over to Costco to shop or snack while waiting.  \n\nFYI Check for coupons on their Yelp page before going it might save you some money like it did me :)

This establishment was purported to be the most recent and illustrious nightclub in Las Vegas; however, upon our arrival, we were met with an overwhelming throng of patrons that rendered it arduous to partake in any semblance of rhythmic movement, let alone maintain a stationary position without being inundated by an unyielding sea of humanity. Despite this, we elected to migrate towards the Hip-Hop section of the venue, which, unfortunately, proved to be similarly congested, albeit we were able to discover a relatively diminutive and secluded area in which to execute a few dance moves. Subsequently, we were extended an invitation by a hospitable female patron to join her in a reserved table area, whereupon we were treated to a live performance by none other than the renowned artist Warren G. As West Coast natives, my associates and I were intimately familiar with his musical repertoire and thus were able to derive immense enjoyment from his show. Due to the extreme density of the crowd, we opted to vacate the premises shortly thereafter, as it became increasingly taxing to navigate through the multitude of people. Additionally, it is advisable to avoid purchasing bottled water at this establishment, as the cost for a minuscule container is exorbitant and egregiously disproportionate to its contents.

I loved it the first time and intended to give this place 5 stars since it was good and I ate it two days in a row. This time I feel like there was a lack in quality for the sandwich. I ordered 4 Earl's club sandwiches, and none of them had lettuce -NADA! It also had too much bacon, so the sandwich was wayyy too salty. Eh I am officially sick of this place. I will not crave for it next time.

A decent substitute for Pita Jungle. Prices are a bit high for what you get compared to Pita Jungle. I have only ever gotten Togo food. I imagine it can sometimes be unpleasant to eat there. They allow Hooka smoking on patio. Even picking up my Togo food I have to brave the Hooka smell. Food is pretty good, just might wanna tweak a couple things.
The tacos were greasy and unflavorful. I was quite disappointed with my order. There was also dirt on the floors and the people making the food didn't speak much English

Kitty's cafe, nestled within the esteemed El Cortez Hotel and Casino, offers a dining experience reminiscent of a bygone era, replete with the warm, personalized service that has become synonymous with this venerable establishment. Patrons can indulge in traditional counter service or occupy cozy booths, all while being addressed with endearments such as "honey" or, for regulars, by their given names, courtesy of the affable servers. The menu, though unpretentious, boasts generous portions; case in point, the grilled sourdough melt, featuring turkey and ham, which, albeit unremarkable, proved satisfying. However, a novice culinary artisan helming the kitchen on the day of our visit resulted in a tardy turnaround time for dishes. Notwithstanding, Kitty's remains an optimal destination for a late-night repast, catering to those seeking sustenance following an evening of revelry within the hotel's confines or, alternatively, for individuals yearning for a modest, nocturnal dining experience. It is worth noting that the once ubiquitous "$1.99 specials" have, regrettably, become a distant memory.

This Starbucks is I guess owned by NY NY hotel so they don't use the App...sucky store!! No fare to the app users when you don't have cash on you! Good thing I had money this time and didn't loose to the slot machines here!  \n\nIt's always busy here but goes pretty fast and has a good selection of goods to eat. They open 24/7 which is a good thing. They make their coffee good. Of course, I will be back since this Starbucks is in our hotel but start using the app payment and have them work with Starbucks so we can get our points! Hahaha

Here we are at another DDD visited restaurant...

Melissa, our server, offered a bubbly good morning and 

After the customary 10 minute wait. (No wait usually means not great)

Coffee full bodied and rich, diet coke properly carbonated.

Our eggs were delivered so fast I only got three sentences of this review completed before arrival.

Our glasses were always kept full!

Nice breakfast place.

It was a convenient walk over from the FireSky hotel across the street. We started with the green pork chili. It was tasty, but not hot. We also had the lamb fondue, which is lamb rack with a squash sauce to dip them in. The squash "fondue" part was quite tasty. The lamb was cooked well.

For the main course I tried the braised short rib. It was really big. It didn't have a ton of flavour; a shame for such a tasty meat. It needed salt & pepper and the core seasoning just didn't stand out.

The food is good, but I feel it's all a bit under seasoned. Everything (except the lamb fondue) could have had some extra punch to it. Still, it wasn't so bad that you feel ripped off, so I'm going 3 stars on this.

"The gastronomical experience at this establishment was rather dichotomous, as the tapas were delectable, particularly the fungi-based risotto, while the paella exhibited an excessive sodium content. Notwithstanding, the oxtail was tender, the potatoes were delightful, and the poultry dish was savory, although I accidentally ingested a clove of garlic, which may have been problematic for vampiric individuals. Furthermore, the quality of service within the eatery was unremarkable, in contrast to the superior hospitality offered at the adjacent cafÃ©."

There were limited options for dinner before the show we were seeing at the Luxor. The 20 year old ticket agent suggested T&T. Said it was great. I should have known we would not have the same palate. We started our meal with a set of mojitos. Our waiter indicated they were very good. I order them whenever I can so I have had my share of mojitos. These were very very sweet. I ordered club soda twice to add to our drinks to reduce the sweetness. Nothing saved these drinks. We didn't even finish half of it. Horrible.
The chips and salsa were also not very good which is fairly unusual. Pretty easy to make good chips and salsa. I had tacos for dinner and my friend had a shrimp dish. Both were very average.
Our server was friendly and even came around at the end and offered free tickets to the show. We already had purchased our tickets but the offer was very kind.
I wouldn't go back to this restaurant because if I had known the Asian restaurant had a good menu I would have gone there.

"Indubitably, the culinary experience I relished during my recent sojourn in Las Vegas with my siblings was unparalleled. Despite our intentions to maintain a thrifty budget throughout our six-day escapade, this eatery, recommended by a acquaintance of my sister, delivered an exceptional gastronomic encounter, albeit with some reservations regarding its location and ambiance. Sequestered within the confines of a food court, the venue's unassuming facade belied the delectable fare served within. Although the setting was somewhat lackluster, the quality of the cuisine more than compensated for any aesthetic shortcomings. A shared Caesar salad proved satisfying, while the filet mignon meatballs, served with spaghetti and a rich red sauce, were nothing short of mouthwatering. Furthermore, the Quattro Stagioni pizza, prepared in a wood-fired oven, showcased an exemplary balance of flavors and textures. Notwithstanding the laudable culinary offerings, the service we received left much to be desired. Our server, an individual of Italian descent with an exaggerated machismo demeanor, devoted an inordinate amount of attention to the younger female patrons dining adjacent to us, while neglecting his responsibilities towards us. Ultimately, it fell upon a busboy to retrieve our server from his distractions and attend to our needs. In conclusion, while the food at this establishment merits high praise, the service we encountered was subpar and warrants improvement."

"I thoroughly enjoyed recognizing The Dog empire during my prolonged weekend excursion to Edinburgh, as it boasted an exceptional and stylish design, accompanied by remarkable eatery concepts, including The Dog, UnderDog, SeaDog, and Amore Dog. I sincerely wished I had ample time to sample all of their delectable offerings! My flank steak salad was merely satisfactory, possessing a somewhat tough texture, yet the sweet balsamic reduction complemented the bitter arugula with precision. In contrast, my companion's mushroom risotto was exquisitely prepared and indulgent, earning it a well-deserved four stars. Unfortunately, our culinary journey concluded with a less than impressive tiramisu, which lacked the potency of espresso and featured a chilling temperature that I personally prefer for the dessert. Moreover, the dark chocolate cocoa powder overwhelmed the delicate flavor of the dish when consumed in substantial amounts, prompting us to discard the upper layer of the dessert."

"The culinary experience was exceptional, and the prices were quite reasonable, owing to the utilization of a restaurant.com coupon. However, I would have awarded a perfect score of five stars had the server not exhibited an air of haughtiness and abruptness in their demeanor."

Great beer selection.  But if you are looking for more consistency, it is probably not the spot (they have a rotating tap selection).  The food was actually quite wonderful. I didn't expect much for bar food, but was pleasantly surprised.  I went with a large group and we had a great time drinking and answering trivia questions from one of their board games (there is a whole table full of games for customers to enjoy, yay!). \n\nI'd say the biggest downfall for this place is the atmosphere and service... there was pretty full crowd when I went in-and only 1 server for the whole place.  Ridiculous.  He was real nice and apologetic so we took it all in stride.  But there were _long_ stretches where we didn't see him or get helped.  He did his best to keep up, but it was a noticeable problem. Sure I'd go back, but never again when hungry.  As for the atmosphere--the bar is a few steps up from a dive.  Okay to hang out for locals, but not the place to impress.  Friendly staff, good food and beer are enough to make you overlook this.

i've been going here for several years now, and i as long as i see dr. finch, i'm pretty happy. he's done one surgery on dozer (a minor laser procedure to remove a growth from her eyelid but did require anesthesia) and was very reassuring, informational and has a good dogside manner. just found out he'll probably be doing another surgery on her (much more major acl repair) and i'm totally comfortable having him do it.\n\ni only update and drop a couple stars bc 1. i was prob a little too gracious on my first review (i was a new yelper with out a system yet) and 2. other friends talk about how much they LOVE their vets, but i don't have that kind of passion for this place. i keep trying to shop around, but put it off until all of the sudden, dozer needs help NOW, so i want to go somewhere she's got some history on their files.

"Thus far, my culinary experiences at this establishment have been limited to the breakfast menu, specifically the corned beef and farmer's omlette. While the fare has been satisfactory, it fails to elicit any exceptional praise. However, I do appreciate the option to substitute a blueberry muffin for toast. The server has demonstrated politeness and accommodating behavior, exemplified by their willingness to provide ranch dressing with my hash browns, an unconventional yet personal preference. Additionally, this venue enjoys the distinction of being the sole dining option beyond 10 p.m. in close proximity, excluding those situated within gaming establishments, and boasts reasonable pricing. Consequently, it presents itself as a suitable setting for a relaxed meal in the company of a friend. Nonetheless, I must express my disappointment regarding the absence of dark chicken meat on the menu, as the lighter variety tends to possess an undesirable dryness."

Okay, I'm giving 3 stars because the food was pretty good and the service was great.  But $18 for enchiladas?? Whoaaa now.  $5 roach coach enchiladas could stand up to theirs.  $9 chips and guacamole?? It was good but not $9 good!  I think this place has a complex... You can put cloth napkins and fancy paper menus on the table but in the end you're still a mainstream Mexican restaurant with TONS of competition... CHEAP competition that's just as good.  I won't go back just because of the price unfortunately...

Mert's is one of those places you would see on Diners, Drive-ins and Dives. The decor has a quintessential southern comfort feel and will make any out of towner feel welcome. \n\nI don't suggest eating lunch here though; if it happens, it's a wrap. You'll be knocked out like a newborn after boobie feeding. Service is good, food is decent and overall an okay spot to grab a meal.

Harrah's has a smart business module when it comes to Carnaval Court. It is situation on a pathway that sucks tourist in. With all the kiosks around, it has useless souvenirs within drunken reach. Even though my friends and I were not inebriated, we still bought those shirts that light up to the music. Thinking they were the epitome of cheesy tourist, we all bought matching shirts to signify our unity. 

Entering the party scene with our newly acquired garments garnered so much attention and compliments. The dance floor is large and provides enough room to get down. Being outside helps alleviate the overheating that sometimes occurs when the dance floor gets too crowded. 

The flare bartenders are fun to watch and make a decent cocktail. If you want to alternate between partying and gambling, this is the perfect venue because they have table games set aside as well. It has everything someone coming to Vegas is looking for.

"It was gratifying to indulge in a tranquil dining experience this week, and if you seek respite from the rigors of daily life, this establishment is an ideal setting in which to do so. The panoramic view from the restaurant's vantage point is truly breathtaking, and the hospitality of the staff is warm and inviting. I opted for the Rib eye steak, which was cooked to perfection, and the accompanying Blue cheese potatoes were delectable, although the potency of the Blue Cheese slightly overshadowed the natural flavor of the potatoes. Additionally, I sampled a slice of cake for dessert, but unfortunately, the ice cream had begun to thaw, rendering it somewhat soggy, and the cake itself was slightly dry. Considering the cost, I anticipated a more fastidious attention to detail in regards to the presentation of the dessert course. Nonetheless, the ambiance and culinary offerings made for a satisfying excursion."

Dim sum, a culinary delight recommended by a friend, aroused my curiosity due to its exclusivity, as it was only available twice a year. However, upon indulging in the delectable offerings, I couldn't help but feel that the quality of the dim sum style food would have been superior if the establishment had concentrated solely on that aspect, instead of incorporating a seafood buffet. Although the dishes were savory, some were unfortunately served at room temperature. Furthermore, the absence of chili oil, a staple condiment in most Chinese eateries I frequent in San Diego, was conspicuous, yet tolerable given the sodium-rich nature of the items we consumed. Nonetheless, the non-dim sum options proved impressive, boasting fresh raw oysters, succulent crab legs, decadent lobster, and expertly crafted nigiri. My request for sushi pieces without rice was accommodated by the gracious sushi chef, albeit the generous slice thickness slightly diminished my enjoyment. A craving for octopus prompted me to explore the buffet line, whereupon I discovered a tantalizing octopus and cucumber salad, undoubtedly the highlight of the spread. An abundance of fresh fruit, including juicy mandarin oranges, tart cherries, and exotic rambutan, beckoned, but the desire to partake in a more leisurely dining experience prevailed. While the dessert bar showcased an admirable selection, it fell short of exceptional. My preference for dim sum, second only to sushi, has piqued my interest in revisiting this establishment during my forthcoming trip to San Diego.

It's like gambling. Sometimes, you win big...and other times...not so much.

The show started off great. Our MC was engaging and very funny. He was very comfortable in his own skin and using his life as material for his comedy, but he was still socially aware to not go too far. The same cannot be said about the first two comedians that came after who were crude, swore way too much, and shoved their distasteful humor down your throat irregardless of people being notably disgusted. At one point, a lady stood up after the joke went too far and asked the comedian to move on. Instead, he used this as fodder to continue at it. I get using someone as the butt of all jokes, but when LITERALLY no one else is laughing with you...it is time to move on. Luckily, the MC was able to put a bandaid over each of these two flops.

The headliner Jay Reid did make up for the entire night though...otherwise it would have been a complete dud at $20/ticket. Jay Reid made excellent use of the stage going as far as using the stool and mic stand as props. He had jokes about current events as well as of normal controversial/taboo subjects. The jokes were tasteful and he even stuck around to meet the audience after. Very classy and cool.

I commemorated the milestone of my eighteenth year of existence by partaking in a culinary excursion to this establishment in the company of a select group of acquaintances. It is pertinent to note that their hours of operation, specifically the period designated as "happy hour," are limited to weekdays between the hours of two and six post meridiem, thereby rendering our arrival at seven o'clock somewhat inconvenient. Notwithstanding this minor setback, I opted to sample their grilled chicken sandwich, which, while palatable, exhibited a certain pinkish hue that might have been attributable to an abbreviated cooking duration. Furthermore, the prolonged preparation time of approximately forty-five minutes, coupled with my considerable hunger, precluded me from returning said item to the kitchen for further culinary refinement. In addition, we collectively decided to partake in a shared consumption of their frozen hot chocolate beverage, which, despite its latent promise, unfortunately necessitated a significant amount of mastication upon its icy constituents throughout its duration. It is worth mentioning that the pace of service was somewhat leisurely and that the cost, while not drastically exceeding that of Cheesecake Factory, still fell within a higher price bracket. Notwithstanding these observations, I am willing to accord this eatery a subsequent opportunity to demonstrate improvement.

This certainly isn't your grandfather's Flamingo anymore; indeed, I would go so far as to say that it isn't even your overweight, chain-smoking Uncle Larry's Flamingo that everyone knew and didn't particularly care for five to ten years ago. Before my recent visit to the Flamingo, the mere thought of staying there would immediately conjure up images of depressing 1980s decor, overweight fanny pack-wearing gamblers, and the overly exuberant expressions of Donnie and Marie as they gazed longingly into each other's eyes in an attempt to forget about that fateful night in 1977 when things went a bit too far. However, I must say that the Flamingo has significantly improved its act. The new decor is quite pleasant, and the casino floor is spotless and 80% fanny pack-free. While I have yet to stay in a room, I would be perfectly comfortable taking a side chick I wasn't ashamed of, as well as a girl that I've been dating for a while, all the while insisting, "Why do we have to put labels on what we are?" without batting an eye. All things considered, the Flamingo is a perfectly acceptable establishment with a fantastic location that I would readily recommend to anyone strolling along the Strip. Who knows, perhaps you'll be the first person to witness Donnie and Marie finally give in to their pent-up sexual tension and frustration after 35 years!

I've eaten here twice when I was staying at Treasure Island. The Pho is just okay but it'll do in a pinch. It probably smells better than it tastes.

I've tried to veggie spring rolls which were decent, but the peanut sauce is just okay - kind of coco-nutty. 

I got the Pho Tai and my friend got the Veggie Pho.  My soup was not super tasty but had lots of pieces of beef but very little noodles.  My friend enjoyed her soup - had bak choy, mushrooms and corn.  Little pricey for pho as you can get an awesome tasting bowl in LA for like 7 dollars.

Waitress was nice and the place was clean.

Not a huge fan of this Target.  It's the closest one so I find myself going there but the store is so large and it feels like everyone inside is an ASU student at times.  Which basically means it is always crowded with people and I find myself waiting in line to check out.  Otherwise, it's has a lot of good things.  Lots of parking, great staff and like I said before it's super sized so you can find anything and everything you need in one location.
The employees spend too\nMuch time with there backs to the customers talking amongst themselves instead of focusing on providing better service!

I just happened to be in Vegas this new year and since I saw this place in the past i decided to try it. Salad bar is ok, the meats a bit too salty and really raw (bloody) but I was surely disappointed with the service. Waitress show up only 3 times, when we first sat at the table, when she brought us the drinks and when she gave us the check!, I have to literally ask the servers to bring the meats to our table since the seem to just pas us by, I guess the just want you to eat from the salad bar :( \nIn other words, the price service/quality ratio is not good at all

We stumbled upon this place after failing to go to the Bacchanal because of the nasty line. By the time we found this place, we were starving! This is a cool little cafe place with pretty modern decorations throughout the restaurant. They blast top 20s hits here, so if you're looking for a nice quiet place to chat, this definitely isn't the place.\n\nPortions here are pretty large but we really didn't think anything of the food. Nothing stood out or was spectacular. I got a pastrami breakfast sandwich and I felt like it was missing something. If they had added some extra condiments or had a special sauce it would be much better. It felt like the pastrami, egg, and other ingredients didn't flow that well together. Nonetheless it filled us. I did enjoy the tator tots though, they were crispy, crunchy and delicious.

This is a cool spot and very educational. I loved the way that everything is divided into 4 ecosystems, I would have liked the polar/arctic room to have more though. I think that the entry fee is way too much for what you get. The gift shop is nice. You can find cool things like bags made from recycled juice boxes, insect snacks (yes REAL insects to eat) and small crystals, etc.\n\nDon't waste your time and money to take the elevator to the top of the city. You can essentially get the same view for free from the top of Mount Royal.

Again, this is one of those chains where you can't judge a book by its cover! If you have the time you can find some really great deals here! 

They have pretty much everything here, clothes, paintings and plenty of home decor. When I visited they were changing over some departments it looks like they are going to have a larger selection of rugs and portraits and paintings which will be great or anyone who is looking to update their home.

I enjoyed the visit and would return! Just remember when you go be prepared to search for your good deals!

"Although they have ceased to offer the delectable Chicken Strip Cheese sandwich, which was undoubtedly a culinary masterpiece, they have opted to supplant it with an uninspiring substitute that fails to elicit enthusiasm. Aside from this disappointing alteration, the establishment maintains an ambiance reminiscent of a conventional Hooters restaurant, complete with an array of novel wing flavors and the introduction of steak fries to their menu."

This hotel is for folks on a budget looking for a room with the basics. It served its purpose for our trip and would recommend it to someone who isn't looking for all the bells and whistles. I saw pizza, subway and fatburger plus movie theater, bars and lots of slot machines. Didn't do much in the hotel besides sleep. Fatburger tasted horrible and took forever.

"My decision to dine at this establishment was influenced by its prominent featuring on a popular culinary television network, and I was eager to determine if it could comparatively measure up to my preexisting standards of gastronomical excellence, specifically in regards to the fiery and savory attributes that I have come to expect from a reputable seafood restaurant. While the quality of the seafood served was satisfactory, it unfortunately did not live up to my elevated expectations in terms of spiciness and flavor profile. It is advisable to arrive promptly, as the venue has a tendency to become congested with patrons, particularly during peak hours on weekends. Our visit took place at 11 am on a Saturday, and by the time we completed our meal, a queue of anticipatory diners had formed, awaiting their turn to partake in the culinary offerings."

"A viscous, ruddy hue emanates from the cuboidal matter, denominated as '3-star red curry tofu,' which has undergone a process of culinary manipulation. Notwithstanding its quality, surpassing the celestial bodies in magnitude, it falls short of attaining the pinnacle of gastronomical excellence, as inferred by the omission of a single stellar designation. Nonetheless, an appreciable level of proficiency is discernible in the preparation of this singular dish, thus obviating any misapprehensions regarding its gustatory merits."

The hubby and I stopped by around 8:30 at night. Upon pulling up, we seen that the line was almost out the door. Determined to get some ice cream, I insisted on going in and waiting in line. It took about 15 minutes to get our order, but the place was jam packed so the wait was to be expected.  All the employees were doing their best to keep the line down. I ordered the smallest size, "like it", and the employee actually gave me the next size up at no charge because she said she grabbed too much ice cream. 

There's very little seating at this location,  and the available tables were dirty. But to be fair,  if all hands were on deck making orders, whose left to clean up? We chose to get our order to-go. 

I'm a fan of Cold Stone's ice cream.  I'm accustomed to the long lines. But to me, it's worth waiting to get me some "All lovin' no oven".

This particular venue brought to mind the ambiance of Whiskey River, albeit devoid of the boisterous individuals customarily present along the shore and characterized by a preponderance of relaxed patrons. It appeared that impromptu dance competitions were taking place on the floor, as spectators seemed to be thoroughly enjoying themselves. Additionally, there were apparent offers of 99-cent Jaeger bombshells and, upon further inquiry, I discovered the existence of 99-cent tacos or similar culinary items. A wet T-shirt contest ensued, featuring a mere trio of participants, which, while somewhat disheartening, managed to retain an element of amusement. Under the circumstances, I would consider visiting this establishment once again.

The Grandview Saloon has one of the best views of Pittsburgh from Mt. Washington from its patio. The views from the interior of the restaurant are not bad either.  To go with your view, you can choose from a good selection of drinks and more mediocre Pittsburghesque (i.e., comfort) food. The design of the patio is fine, but the interior of the restaurant is very plain. This is a shame, because with a little work on the interior design and menu, the view could make this one of the city's most interesting restaurants. \n\nIn short, I would not go here to celebrate an anniversary, but it's a good place to take first-time visitors to see the city while enjoying a tasty beverage.

Great, friendly and attentive service. We had the Caesar salad, duck & scallops. Salad was great, duck was good & very rich. Scallops were so-so & not something I'd recommend ordering. Over all an okay meal, but not one I'd repeat.

I've been going here during the week, and in bad weather it is hard to tell it is even open.  There are some things I really love here and some that I don't.  The flowers are a steal and beautifully arranged, though they do not last very long - maybe two or three days.  There are some really good deals on produce, and I have gotten some great tomatoes and peaches in season.  However, about half of the stuff is not local.  I had a hard time finding a local apple, and a lot of the produce has sku stickers on it telling you that it's from california or washington or whatever.  Still, there are some local farmers interspersed in there and they make it worth it.  I still will visit regularly.

I have a profound affection for The Coffee Bean, as I frequently indulge in their delectable brews. However, this particular establishment seems to have some sort of anomaly affecting the quality of their coffee. It appears that there is an inconsistency in the taste, which I can only surmise is due to the water used in the preparation process. This has led me to question whether there is a deliberate attempt to undermine my mental state or if it is merely an unfortunate consequence of the hotel's water source. Despite my fondness for a robust cup of coffee, I find myself consistently disappointed with the offerings within the Venetian. Notwithstanding, I must acknowledge that the convenience of having a cup of coffee delivered to my doorstep each morning by a particularly attractive and thoughtful individual almost makes up for the subpar quality of the beverage itself. Thus, I have assigned a rating of three stars, comprising one star for the coffee and two additional stars for the exceptional service I received.

"Adequate retail establishment offering an extensive array of merchandise that I would indeed utilize. Notably advantageous reductions on comestibles. Well-organized physical space, albeit susceptible to disarray due to the presence of numerous patrons. The sole drawback I have encountered during my visits is the considerable delay incurred while waiting to complete my purchases. A protracted queue at the checkout counter is a minor inconvenience given the substantial economies realized. Prepare to devote approximately 15 minutes or more to conclude your transaction."

It is a clean place and they have good service. The Koi pond is pretty cool. The sandwich I ordered was pretty awful, don't get the turkey because it is like packaged meat you can buy at a supermarket. The prices were on par with other delis, but you can get a much better sandwich for the same price elsewhere.

*sigh*  I really wanted to love this, but it was just ok.  After reading all the positive yelps and testimonials on Pop's website, I was expecting a fun and delicious experience.  I imagined myself giving my order to a gruff but charming grill master, who would ask me 'wit' onions? in an authentic Philly accent.  What I really got was a grill master who was just gruff and apparently couldn't hear my order, because when I got my cheese steak home, there were no onions on it at all!   

Ok, the cheese steak itself:  the meat was not fatty or greasy, but slightly bland.  I enjoyed the cheese whiz and the bread was very good.  I think if they had included the onions, things would have been tastier.  Also, in the hours since eating the steak, I have been a bit 'indisposed', but this in and of itself has never been an index of whether I would return to a place if the food tastes good.  (masochist!)

So all in all, I think I would try it again probably.  But I'll also try their competition in town and yelp the results.  :)

Cabo is a very busy place- even on a Tuesday night! Luckily we were a party of 2 and were seated pretty quick. The food tasted good and fresh, but I had very high expectations based on the reputation they have in Charlotte. I was hoping for a little more flavor.

Contrary to some of the other reviews, I didn't feel rushed even though they were jammin'. I went with a friend and we were catching up for quite a while, but our waitress was friendly and didn't rush us, which I appreciated. Parking can be difficult, like most places in NoDa, so plan to cruise around a little. 

Overall I think Cabo has a fun atmosphere for grabbing drinks and something to eat, but it isn't a "go out of your way" establishment.

We were on our way back from a trip to Mexico and Cuba* when we arrived here for a short layover. This airport is easy to navigate, especially when you are coming through immigration -- there are lots of signs telling you exactly where to go. 

There was a long line at immigration but it moved fairly quickly. My honey and I had all of our research license paperwork in order for the Cuba portion of our travels in case we were asked for it** but the not-even-a-hello immigration officer guy just scanned our passports, looked at us with his best stern face, and stamped us on our way. We then picked up our checked suitcases, zoomed right through customs (after handing over our customs form) and rechecked our bags. 

The part that ended up taking the longest amount of time was going back through security, thanks to long lines. I do have to say that the security personnel were working very hard to move everyone along and were really nice as well.

If we had more than 5 minutes to spare, I would have picked up some local BBQ to eat on our San Francisco bound flight. Thanks a lot, security line. 

*You won't hear much more about our trip to Mexico and Cuba since they don't have Yelp. (At least not yet.) I'll just summarize to say that almost everywhere we slept, ate, drank, visited, etc. were unquestionably five star. 

** Apparently Beyonce and Jay Z did as well. http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/04/09/entertainment-us-usa-cuba-beyonce-idUSBRE93600V20130409

This lodging establishment's external appearance exhibits visible signs of wear and tear, suggesting the need for a comprehensive renovation. The overall aesthetic of the hotel's facade and surrounding areas appears dated and fatigued. In contrast, the guest rooms have undergone updates, albeit inconsistent with the rest of the hotel's aspects, and feature cleanliness issues regarding tile grout in certain quarters. Despite this, the quality of the culinary offerings is surprisingly satisfactory, particularly for a hotel of this caliber. Additionally, the hotel boasts a well-stocked bar featuring an assortment of regional brews, complemented by personable and attentive service. While the hotel's location is reasonably convenient, it remains a considerable distance from the central attractions of the city, necessitating either a leisurely stroll or utilization of the complimentary shuttle service, courtesy of the accommodating and knowledgeable driver, Christian. Notwithstanding, accessibility via I-277 is relatively straightforward. Considering the cost, the experience proved to be adequate.

The restaurant is cozy and somewhat dark with a separate bar area and dining area. Service was quick and attentive. They have some different beers to experiment with and even let you sample some you're not familiar with before you commit. 


Food was OK but not great. I had half a turkey sandwich and salad. My turkey sandwich was a bit dry and bland and the salad was forgettable. As bars go and as bar food goes you could do much worse.

I've been wanting to try this place for awhile after hearing good things about it and reading the menu. I realize now why the website doesn't list prices-- the mission is hideously overpriced!

We ended up on the patio since they weren't seating in the main area yet (at 6:30pm? For reals?) Our waitress was nice and attentive. She noticed my water had something floating in it and replaced it quickly. My husband's water glass was dirty too. She brought us out two sample size frozen peach and strawberry margaritas which were awesome. Much better than the rocks margarita.

No complimentary chips and salsa which would be ok if they offered something else like Barrio. No happy hour either which was disappointing.

The street corn was good, but I've had much better. The butternut squash tacos were out of this world. My husband liked them better than his mahi tacos. I just can't believe they have the gall to charge $12 for 3 tiny (3 inches in diameter) tacos. They also charge $12 for guac made from 2 avocados. I'm not sure how they have survived in this economy. They must be very slow when the tourists leave for the summer.

The good:
- children get a magna doodle to draw on, 
- the wait staff is very nice, 
- the restaurant is very clean - it's brand new, so that's expected,
- the pasta selection is basically "create your own", with 5(?) types of pasta (incl. whole wheat) and at least 5 types of sauces (incl. rose), plus you can add toppings to your pasta
- karaoke Fri+Sat night,
- the food tastes decent,
- prices are decent, if you don't add extra toppings,
- unique desert menu

The bad:
- the kids menu is on the back of the magna doodle, but they don't tell you that, and it's small
- kids' drinks come in an adult sized to-go cup,
- it took them almost 10mins to clean up (my daughter's) spilled milk
- the menu consisted of pasta, pizza and paninis, not much more,
- pasta toppings are $1.50 each,
- my canneloni (desert) was pretty bland.
We were less than welcomed at the door. The security guard was extremely disrespectful. We would not have gone in if our birthday bud didn't insist.
Fun store if you are looking for Korean. To the poster that identified this store as Japanese, was wrong. Korean and Japanese foods are similar but not the same.

"Red 8, an establishment offering Americanized Chinese cuisine, boasts a delectable Oxtail soup, complemented by their mouthwatering Mongolian beef and rice. The eatery's ambiance exudes elegance, while the staff provides exceptional service. Although the dessert menu could benefit from some refinement, it remains satisfactory. However, the prices are somewhat steep, seemingly attributed to the venue's high-end atmosphere and association with the renowned Wynn resort. Personal preferences aside, Red 8 may not be the optimal choice for authentic Chinese fare, yet its unique offerings and hospitable environment make it an acceptable dining experience, especially when partaking in a meal as a guest."

It's getting harder to find awesome deals for meals in Vegas.  Gone are the days you can get buffets for $5 or prime rib dinners for $7.99.  Oh Sahara, how I miss you!  

Visiting family in Henderson, we headed over to Sunset Station for some dinner. They had prime rib dinner for $9.99, so I had to get it.  For a Saturday night, it was packed and we had to wait 15 minutes for a table.  

My prime rib dinner was good, but I should've ordered it medium rare, because medium well wasn't as tasty.  

Service was good and food was decent.  I just wished the prime rib dinner was little bit cheaper and then I would've given them a higher rating.  Their t-bone steak dinner special was $12.99, which I thought was a bit high for Vegas.  

Grand Cafe is way better than Denny's, so for a local 24 hour spot, I'd come back to eat.

I really want to like this place, but it was extremely disappointing. Maybe it was overhyped. The food was just okay, nothing sets it apart from other buffets. \n\nBased on other reviews, I might give it another shot next time I'm in Vegas, but I'd rather go back to the seafood buffet at Rio before dining here again.

"The gastronomical experience was satisfactory, with the culinary offerings being of superior quality, specifically the infinite shrimp options (shrimp alfredo duplicated, breaded shrimp, and shrimp scampi) which constituted the most favorable aspect of the dining excursion. However, the waiting period preceding seating and subsequent service was rather prolonged, lasting approximately half an hour for seating and an additional quarter hour for the servers to take our order, thereby hindering the overall enjoyment of the meal and warranting improvement in the realm of customer service to elevate the establishment's rating. Notwithstanding, the comestibles were indeed delectable and arrived at our table piping hot, and the cheddar biscuits presented post-seating were of exceptional quality."
Good sashimi a bit high priced how ever all the fish I had was fresh and well served.  I have been three times and each time had a good experience.

I don't have much to say about this hotel because I wouldn't stay here again.

Hotel rooms-I stayed in the back tower and the walk to the tower was horrible. Walking through an entire casino with your luggage is the biggest pain in the ass, not to mention walking the bridge across the pool to get to the tower. Big thumbs down. Room was really nice, decor was nice, beds comfy, but bathroom was a motel 6 bathroom. Very old looking. Not what I would expect if owned by a hilton chain.

Casino-casino was actually nice and fresh. Because it was newly renovated it smelled clean and didn't smell like a shit hole like some of the older casinos. Lots of options.

Accommodations-pool was awesome, staff is nice, house keeping staff nice, but check in was a nightmare. Checked in at 2pm and line stretched to the casino. I was in the hilton honors check in and that line was in the casino as well. If it takes 30 mins for checkin, then you have already lost me as a customer that will not stay there again.
There's just not a big selection. The parking lot was crowded but in the store it wasn't. Friendly staff. \nI found some cute juice glasses for $0.69 that's it!

I recently visited this establishment during a brief sojourn at the Aria, whereupon I indulged in a delectable assortment of pastries and beverages. Prior to my visit, I had been lodging at the aforementioned hotel while attending to some business-related matters. As I was strolling towards my accommodations, I couldn't help but notice the alluring ambiance of the vicinity, which was replete with an array of vibrant colors and tantalizing aromas emanating from the nearby patisserie. My curiosity piqued, I decided to return the following morning, craving a cup of coffee and eager to sample the culinary delights offered by this esteemed establishment. Upon my arrival, I was struck by the visually stunning presentation of the multi-tiered cakes, which seemed to defy gravity with their intricate architecture. This prompted me to ponder the amount of time and effort required to create such edible masterpieces. Following a brief wait, I placed an order for two Americanos, only to observe the barista utilize a machine to efficiently dispense the beverages. While the coffee was palatable, it fell short of my expectations, considering the steep price point of $10. In light of this experience, I would not recommend this venue for coffee enthusiasts seeking a more personalized and authentic experience. Nonetheless, those seeking a variety of baked goods may find this establishment suitable for their needs.

The beer is average, but overpriced.  Save yourself $10 on a case and wait until Costco restocks.  ($30 a case at the brewery, $20 at Costco).   Perhaps I would return if they end up opening up an actual restaurant,  as the staff there were extremely friendly, but not too much of a draw at this point....

This particular establishment is one of those culinary destinations that it is imperative to visit at least once in one's lifetime, as it offers an enjoyable experience for the taste buds, with the meat consistently being of high quality, albeit it is advisable to avoid visiting during major holidays, as the level of service and gastronomic excellence may not be maintained with the same rigor and dedication.

"The pricing structure at this establishment is patently exorbitant, with minuscule, tapas-style plates of culinary fare commanding a premium price point in excess of $30, while larger, yet still diminutive entree-sized portions fetch a whopping $50 to $60. Despite my prior awareness of the menu prices, the inflated cost of my meal still managed to surpass my expectations. The ambiance of the restaurant, characterized by a color scheme dominated by red and black hues, was somewhat redeemed by the novelty of witnessing the culinary process firsthand from our perch at the bar. However, the quality of the food, though undeniably satisfactory, fails to justify the egregious markup. If the aim of this dining experience is to foster a sense of casualness, a reduction in prices by at least 25-30% would be imperative."

Is the best bagel place I've been to? No. I came here for a \"to go\" breakfast with my man. As we were waiting for our food, he whispered to me \"this place is filthy\". The vent above the bagel rack was so dusty! The counters, floors and tables looked like they hadn't been wiped down either. We had already paid so we just decided to get our food and go. The guy who helped us was very sweet but incredibly slow. We spent almost 20 minutes waiting for 2 bagel sandwiches and a chocolate chip muffin. The bagel sandwiches tasted good (I tried a tomato basil bagel) and liked it. I also thought the variety in bagels was nice. The muffin wasn't my favorite but was edible. Prices were reasonable but nothing great. Just like my review says, A-OK.

"Underwhelmed experience with too much repetition."
It is with profound dismay that I must convey my utter disappointment with my recent dining excursion to this establishment, which, ostensibly, specializes in "pho," a culinary delight that I, and my companion, were eager to indulge in. However, our enthusiasm was quickly extinguished when the waitstaff, in an almost perfunctory manner, divulged that they were bereft of the aforementioned "pho" at the present time. This revelation struck me as rather anomalous, given the eatery's namesake and its purported focus on Vietnamese cuisine. Had the waitress apprised us of this deficiency upon our arrival, we could have, with relative ease, sought out an alternative venue to satiate our craving for a steaming bowl of "pho." Alas, we were compelled to peruse the menu further, resulting in orders that, regrettably, failed to impress. The lone redeeming quality of this lackluster dining experience was the cordial demeanor of the staff, which, admittedly, salvaged a modicum of respectability. In light of these circumstances, I fear that my patronage of this establishment shall remain a distant memory, never to be revisited.

Though the smell of the place can really get to you, the instructors here are amazing.  Down side is the people at the front desk are extremely rude and not very friendly.  If customer service were good all around I would have continued to come to this studio. But since it's all the way on the other side of town I think I'll have to opt out for a more welcoming environment.  

Other than the downsides, they have a clean changing area with 2 showers where they provide body wash, shampoo, and conditioner so you can wash off all the nasty sweat after your classes. 

Try catching Summer and Stacy. They're both awesome in their own way.
Breakfast with Rob,  The food is good.  I had eggs, bacon and pancakes.  Not my favorite pancakes, but ok.  Love their sausage gravy however.

This place wasn't as good as we were expecting.  My pizza (Classic Maggie) was good, but nothing outstanding.  My husband's burger was completely charred and basically inedible.  We didn't bother sending it back as our waitress was nowhere to be found.\n\nIt's your typical bar food with a decent beer selection...nothing more, nothing less.

Been to this establishment on multiple occasions, and I must say, their artisanal brews have piqued my interest and secured my patronage. It's worth noting that they only serve their house-brewed beers, which, in my opinion, is a selling point. While the food menu is adequate, it doesn't boast any particularly remarkable offerings. In fact, their buffalo wings left much to be desired, and I wouldn't recommend them. However, the ambiance is quite pleasant, making it an ideal setting for socializing with companions over a cold beverage or two. It's worth mentioning that their prices are a tad high, but given the location in Ahwatukee, it's somewhat expected. Their in-house brewed beverages, specifically the Uncle Bear's lineup, are undoubtedly the highlight of this establishment. It's worth noting that it's the only type of beer available, but that's part of the charm. Although I won't go out of my way to visit frequently, it's still a suitable venue for casual gatherings with friends, especially considering the abundance of televisions scattered throughout, making it an excellent choice for viewing sporting events. Additionally, they accommodate canine companions on the patio, provided they're leashed and well-behaved. As a unique touch, if you provide an 8 x 10 photograph of your furry friend, they'll even display it in a frame as a memorial. That's certainly a commendable gesture.

Turkish Kitchen was a thoroughly decent, inexpensive meal for a group of us who hadn't booked a table in the city centre on a Friday night.

On sitting we were brought some bread and the most amazingly tasty dip ever.  I need to know what's in that dip because it was the highlight of the meal.  

Not very hungry, I opted for the Turkish ravioli which, despite not being listed on the menu, came with a side of salad and rice.  The sides were a bit awkward and somewhat wasteful, but were certainly tasty.  
The ravioli left a lot to be desired, primarily because it was so overcooked it came apart the minute it I tried to eat it.  The taste was fine though nothing compared with my other experience with Turkish ravioli, which was such a shame because I was expecting something really fantastic.  

I probably should have ordered something kebab-ey like everyone else, but I just wasn't in the mood for a meat feast.  Everyone else seemed happy with their meals, though.  

One weird thing was that when we ordered beer we got glasses which appeared all different sizes and smaller than what you would expect of either a pint or a large bottle. 

It was a really good option for a group looking for something cheap and cheerful but is, in my opinion, not Edinburgh's best Turkish by a long mile.

Great place for a Friday happy hour! The chambord marg is top notch, achiote chopped chicken salad is to die for, and the trio appetizer is great ONLY when it's half price during happy hour.  Highly recommend but only hangup is the cocky manager, useless hostests, and unattentive servers.  After two margaritas you get over the staff :)

I have no idea why there was such a huge hype, it was just a typical thin crusted pizza. Seriously!!!!! The toppings were good, pepperoni, sausage, etc... but honestly you can get a better pizza elsewhere.\n\nHowever, if you are dying for a late  night snack after Marquee it's conveniently located.

My experience at this establishment was merely adequate. I ordered the Pho, and although the broth did not meet my expectations of being exceptional, it was still passable. My companion ordered the cashew chicken for the first time, and he thoroughly enjoyed it. My acquaintance had the chicken fried rice, which was also quite satisfactory. The prices at this venue are reasonable for the generous portions, making it an ideal location for budget-conscious college students. I would return to this eatery for sustenance, but I would not order the Pho again.

I am awarding three stars for this review due to two primary factors. Firstly, I requested the Thai iced tea for nearly $3, anticipating a revitalizing and genuine Thai iced tea experience. However, what I received was a minuscule bottled beverage from the refrigerator, which was underwhelming and not worth the cost. The individual behind the counter offered a lackadaisical explanation, stating she was "too indolent to prepare a proper one." Secondly, the dining area was excessively humid and warm, with the entrance open on a steamy rainy day. As a result, I perspired profusely during my dining experience, which was disagreeable. Moreover, there were laborers mending the ceiling tiles or something in close proximity, which I deemed unsuitable for when patrons are consuming their meals mere feet away.

The cuisine was palatable, but the ambiance left much to be desired. Despite this, I will continue to visit this establishment for a speedy Thai culinary fix, primarily due to its accessibility and prime location on Green Street.

We ventured to Kings on a Saturday for an early culinary excursion, coinciding with our post-Christmas shopping extravaganza. I've had the pleasure of frequenting this esteemed establishment on several occasions prior, and I must say that the sluggishness of the service has been a constant theme throughout. However, I digress. We initiated our gastronomic journey with the chilled seafood platter, a veritable cornucopia of delights, featuring four Dungeness crab legs, four oysters, four clams, and eight shrimps, all for the reasonable sum of $24.95. In my opinion, this platter ranks among the most exceptional values in Las Vegas for shellfish enthusiasts. Our entrees included grilled shrimp and scallop skewers, a kid's burger, and a combination fried platter. Unfortunately, the latter was somewhat disappointing, with an overabundance of breading and questionable texture of the shrimp and scallops, accompanied by a solitary piece of cod/haddock. In hindsight, I would adhere to my customary practice of opting for the sanddabs or a dish du jour, as the shellfish platter remains the primary draw for my patronage.

"I reside in close proximity to the Burger Factory, which is perpetually characterized by a high volume of patrons. The eatery's extensive menu boasts a diverse array of culinary options, rendering it an ideal venue for accommodating the varied gastronomical inclinations of a group of professionals. Additionally, the generous portion sizes and the establishment's reputation for serving rich, savory dishes make it an excellent choice for individuals seeking a casual dining experience that satisfies their craving for a hearty meal."

For an extended period, I have been under the impression that Ping Pong Thai was an eatery catering to adult clientele, featuring Thai cuisine and entertainment, specifically ping pong shows. However, my assumptions were proven incorrect, as this establishment solely focuses on providing delectable Thai fare, sans any ping pong-related activities or equipment. Disappointingly, the Panang curry has failed to impress, lacking depth of flavor and an unfortunate watery consistency. In contrast, the Pad Kee Maw has proven to be a saving grace, boasting sufficient spiciness to satiate my taste buds, albeit at a medium level of heat. This dish remains the primary draw for my patronage, despite subpar service. Dining in yields sluggish service, while takeout orders experience an inverse phenomenon - an abundance of efficiency. Regrettably, both scenarios culminate in a lackluster experience, leaving the customer feeling inconsequential. It is worth mentioning that the restaurant tends to attract sizable crowds during the lunch hour, further contributing to the underwhelming ambiance. Were Ping Pong Thai to incorporate a ping pong table, a novel and engaging element, my rating would undoubtedly increase. It is plausible that the proprietor hails from Thailand, harboring a profound passion for the sport, which would undoubtedly elevate the dining experience.

"Despite its proximity and appealing happy hour offerings, we continue to experience frustration during our repeated visits to this establishment. Specifically, we are dismayed by the limited beer selection, which features only three options on tap. Furthermore, the service has been inconsistent, characterized by overly attentive servers at the onset of the meal, followed by an inexplicable absence during the payment process. This lack of attention to detail raises concerns about potential losses for the restaurant, as it is not uncommon for patrons to depart without settling their bills. Additionally, the cuisine has been variable in quality, with the more affordable selections, such as the calamari, proving to be the most satisfying, while the pricier options, like the elk meatballs, have fallen short of expectations due to their bland and arid texture."
Wow, harsh reviews!\n\nI found the guy behind the counter helpful.  He steered me in the right direction and I got a meal I really enjoyed.   BBQ'd tilapia and Chicken Adobo were very tasty.

Close to the strip in between harrahs and ballys area in the Linq. Cool new concept, supposely all their slushies have top shelf liquor but I felt it wasn't strong enough, I believe I've gotten more drunk at fat Tuesdays slushies. They have more flavors though and we chose the patron grand mariner because it was sour.The staff is very friendly and cutely dressed, just needs more signs on the cups of drinks. The saxophone cup is seriously amazing! I think its the sexiest and bangest cup there is. ;) Ha ha

Are you supposed to be drunk for this? On drugs?  Well I was neither and man, was it weird! 

This was my 2nd Cirque show (I've been to 3 now) and my first on in Vegas.  As always, the acrobatics were great and the production set was beautiful.

This was by far, the trippy-est Cirque show I've been to though.  The baby giggles and head were so creepy and weird!  

Cirque is always beautiful but I get the impression this isn't the best they can do in Vegas either.

We ordered it for delievery with http://www.youbuyandwefly.com.  It's resonably priced and very yummy.  We'll order again.  I can't comment on the actual location though because again we ordered delievery.  I had the hot and sour soup and it was delicous, we also ordered some sweet and sour pork, orange chicken, and chicken chow main it was all good!

This place is fun because there is always a live band playing in the evening. So if you are looking do get your dance on like you are at a wedding, then this is it. In fact, if I was getting married (too late), then I would bring the whole wedding party by here and tell them to enjoy the reception. The only problem is that it is a cash bar (and credit or room charge too)! I hate those kind of weddings (not the band part but the cash bar part). 

Tables fill up fast but the room isn't closed off from the casino. You can always walk up with your own drink and enjoy the show. There are also slot machines within ear and eye shot.

I love this place because it reminds me of Old Vegas. Every casino had musical acts playing in the bars and lounges. There was no cover all Vegas wanted was you to come in and spend money on your drinks. Now every casino has mega night clubs with Lines and VIP lists, Karaoke bars, and dueling pianos. So it is nice to see some original Vegas entertainment. I've seen this town change in the last 20 years, so I appreciate this lounge.

Bring the whole group and grab a table. Get a few drinks and put on those dancing shoes. This is Vegas at it's best!!!

I started going to Spice Island when it first opened. I was in my early 20s then, which means the place is officially a Pittsburgh institution. The menu has stayed pretty much the same over the years, with the exception of adding alcohol, but why change a good thing? My favorite items on the menu are vegetarian -- the fried tofu (either sauce is delicious) and the vegetable curry trio. Pay a little extra for the coconut rice and you'll be back for the same thing again and again.

The Mecklenburg ABC store here is decent.

Selections - They have all your spirits and liquids that you need.  They don't have my favorite cognac here, but that is okay. 

Service - nice. I know you were eyeing at me, because of my age!! But rest assured, I am beyond old enough to drink. I will take that as a compliment.

Price - as any other ABC stores, just a tad bit pricier than I am used to. Just a 'tad' bit.

"Their assorted pastries, particularly their scones, possess an otherworldly quality that transcends mere mortal taste buds, rendering them nothing short of celestial. Moreover, the ambiance of this quaint establishment exudes a certain je ne sais quoi that is simply enchanting. However, it is imperative to note that the presence of canines within the premises tends to somewhat tarnish the overall experience for those who, like myself, suffer from an unfortunate allergy to such creatures. Were they to implement a policy that prohibits the entry of non-service dogs, save for those that are legitimately required for assistance purposes, it would greatly enhance the enjoyment of their delectable offerings. Despite this minor drawback, their scones remain a culinary masterpiece, crafted with love and care on a daily basis. Thus, I wholeheartedly recommend paying this charming venue a visit."

Upon entering this refurbished edifice and advancing into the grand foyer, one cannot help but be struck by the meticulous attention to detail in the murals and portraits adorning the walls, which exude an air of mystique and aesthetic sophistication that is nothing short of breathtaking. Boasting a sleek, modern ambiance, this establishment is decidedly more subdued than its museum counterparts, yet compensates for its relatively diminutive stature with an abundance of visual and historical richness that more than justifies the considerable sum of Â£80,000 invested in its restoration. Those with an appreciation for settings imbued with a medieval charm, as well as enthusiasts of Scottish history, medicine, warfare, and the chroniclers of momentous historical occurrences, would be remiss not to partake in a visit to this captivating venue. Furthermore, the bustling gift shop and packed dining area serve as testament to the allure of this destination, making it an ideal setting in which to spend a leisurely afternoon engaging in both intellectual and cultural pursuits. Whether your interests lie in Glasgow Gorbals, the confluence of art and science, naval history, infamous criminal death masks, or migrational patterns and their impact on Scottish society, a visit to this institution promises to be a rewarding and enriching experience.
